      "extracted_text": "--- Page 1 ---\n303\n DOI: 10.4324/9781003397618-1916\nADVANCES IN  \nAUTOMATING FEEDBACK \nFOR ARGUMENTATIVE \nWRITING\nFeedback Prize as a Case Study\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n16.1 Introduction\nAutomated writing evaluation (AWE) systems offer a promising opportunity to leverage the \nlatest advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) and natural language processing (NLP) \nin educational settings to improve writing outcomes. Research indicates that argumenta -\ntive writing is crucial for academic achievement ( Preiss et al., 2013 ). Proficiency in argu -\nmentative writing also fosters essential 21st-  century skills, such as critical thinking and \ncommunication ( UNESCO, 2016 ). However, many students struggle to become proficient \nargumentative writers ( Baffour et al., 2023 ).\nRegular and formative feedback on student writing can be a powerful tool for improving \nwriting outcomes, and a vast body of research shows that feedback is most effective when \nit is clear, timely, and focused on the task ( Hattie, 2008 ). AWE systems are computer-  based \napplications that can assess student writing and provide feedback using algorithms and \ncomputational techniques. The nature of AWE systems can augment the grading, evalu -\nation, and feedback process for student writing ( Stevenson, 2016 ). However, their impact \nis limited to the underlying algorithms’ accuracy, precision, and implementation. Most \npersonalized feedback in argumentative writing is given at the overall essay level, where \nstudents typically receive holistic ratings like numeric scores or letter grades as evaluative \nfeedback. Although these scores offer a baseline understanding of writing performance, \nthey do not provide sufficient formative feedback to guide improvement. Pinpointed feed -\nback at the discourse level that focuses on spans of text that perform specific rhetorical or \nargumentative functions offers students localized insights rather than broad evaluations, \nmaking it easier for them to understand and implement revisions.\nDiscourse-  level feedback can be given for organization, strength of evidence, idea devel -\nopment, and coherence. Although these features are commonly evaluated in classroom \nrubrics, capturing and evaluating them in detail remains challenging for even the most \nadvanced NLP algorithms and language models ( Farrokhnia et al., 2023 ). When feedback  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 2 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n304is provided to students at the discourse level, students can better understand the different \ncomponents of argumentation. They have increased awareness and metacognition of their \nlearning and writing processes ( Arroyo González et al., 2021 ), and they can better identify \nopportunities to strengthen their arguments. For example, a student receiving tailored feed -\nback on their thesis statement or conclusion can improve their understanding of effective \norganizational structure.\nAn important component of AWE systems is fairness because some student populations \nare marginalized due to existing achievement disparities ( Fenu et al., 2022 ). AI algorithms, \noften trained on real-  world data, can inadvertently reflect and amplify these inherent soci -\netal biases ( Schramowski et al., 2022 ). Thus, confirming that the AI models that underpin \nAWE systems are not biased is crucial to ensuring that vulnerable populations are given \nfair, just, and accurate feedback. The goal of this chapter is to examine newly developed AI \nmodels resulting from the Feedback Prize. The Feedback Prize was a series of data analysis \nchallenges hosted from 2020 to 2023 that tasked participants with developing AI models \nto provide formative feedback to writers at the discourse level. This chapter examines the \noutput of the AI models developed to provide writing support and whether these models \nperform differentially on various target populations (i.e., display bias). Providing targeted \nfeedback at the argument level, especially for historically underperforming students, is \nbeneficial to students because it can help instill beliefs that challenges in achievement can \nbe overcome through deliberate practice ( Brown et al., 2016 ).\n16.2 The Feedback Prize\nThe Feedback Prize project was designed to address challenges in delivering writing feed -\nback to students about argumentation. The purpose of the project was to foster innovation \nin AWEs through open datasets, open-  source algorithms, and data science competitions. \nThe project resulted in the creation and release of the Persuasive Essays for Rating, \nSelecting, and Understanding Argumentative and Discourse Elements (PERSUADE) corpus \n(Crossley et al., 2022 ). This corpus is the most extensive publicly available collection of stu -\ndent writing annotated for common discourse elements found in argumentative essays. The \ncorpus also includes demographic information for individual writers. Three open science \ncompetitions were hosted on Kaggle.com as part of the Feedback Prize. These competitions \nresulted in over 100,000 solutions to classify argumentative elements and assign proficiency \nscores to those elements. The competition entries are freely available on Kaggle to help \nfoster ongoing research on argumentation, discourse, and algorithmic bias.\n16.2.1  Corpus Annotation\nThe PERSUADE corpus was created by collecting and curating student writing samples \non argumentative topics and then annotating these samples for elements commonly \nfound in student writing. The Learning Agency Lab (Lab) and Georgia State University \n(GSU) spearheaded the effort with support from various education-  focused organizations, \nresearchers, and practitioners.\nCreating the PERSUADE corpus involved careful consideration to ensure that it was a \nhigh-  quality resource for developing and evaluating AWE systems. The project’s first phase \ninvolved collecting student writing samples from educational organizations, including \ngovernment agencies and digital learning platforms. The team gathered nearly 400,000  \n  \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 3 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n305argumentative essays during the initial data collection before curating them to a final \nsample of approximately 26,000. The team considered several factors during this curation \nprocess. For instance, it was important for the prompts to be diverse enough to avoid algo -\nrithmic bias toward any particular type of essay, so the team selected 15 prompts for the \nfinal corpus. The essays were collected from various organizations in different school years \nand contexts, such as annual statewide standardized exams and in-  classroom formative \nassessments. These differences in context are an advantage of the dataset as they ensure the \nalgorithms are more generalizable to various learning contexts.\nThe essays in the final corpus were also distinguished by two types of argumentative \nwriting tasks: text-  dependent writing and independent writing. Each writing task was \nequally represented in the corpus. The text-  dependent writing tasks required students to \nconstruct an argumentative essay responding to a reading passage. On the other hand, the \nindependent writing tasks required students to develop an argument without referencing \nor citing any source material. The independent writing essay topics were often related to \nschool or adolescent experiences, such as whether cell phones should be allowed in school. \nThe reading sources for the text-  dependent writing tasks were diverse in genre, length, and \nreading difficulty level.\nAdditionally, the project focused on equity, which compelled curating a data sample \nwith an adequate representation of different United States (US) student populations. The \nmajority of the essays sampled included detailed demographic information on the student \nwriters, including their reported gender, race, ethnicity, English language learner (ELL) \nstatus, participation in an Individualized Education Plan (IEP) or 504 plan, and economic \nindicators like eligibility for government assistance or school lunch programs. To ensure \nsufficient representation of historically underrepresented groups, the corpus includes many \nessays from racial minority groups in the US, with 55% of all essays coming from nonwhite \nstudents.\nThe decision to oversample minority students is rooted in present-  day disparities in \nwriting performance across minority subgroups in the US. These achievement gaps are evi -\ndent in national data, such as the National Assessment of Educational Progress ( National \nCenter for Education Statistics, 2012 ), which finds that less than one-  third of high school \nseniors are proficient writers, but this percentage lowers to 15% for Black, Hispanic, \nand ELL students. Choosing a representative sampling approach would carry the risk \nof underrepresenting minority subgroups in terms  of quality writing samples and over-  \nrepresenting examples of poor-  quality writing. Given that minority students constitute a \nsmaller share of the population, their sample sizes are small in terms of the overall dataset \nand examples of high-  quality writing within that subset would be lower than those found \nin the overall population. On the other hand, oversampling minority groups enables the \ncollection of more instances of high-  quality writing from minority students. This, in turn, \nresults in a more diverse dataset encompassing greater variation in student writing and \nquality that should result in less biased AI models of writing proficiency.\nThe sample is also representative based on economic background because the sample  \nstatistics were aligned with national averages using data from the National Center for  \nEducation Statistics as a benchmark. Additionally, the corpus reflects writing from 6th  \nthrough 12th grade students. Thus, the corpus is robust enough to perform exploratory  \nanalysis of student writing among different demographic groups and age groups and study  \nfairness and bias in machine learning algorithms developed from the corpus. Descriptive    \n\n--- Page 4 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n306statistics for demographic and individual differences in the PERSUADE corpus are presented  \nin Table 16.1 .\n16.2.1.1  Discourse Elements\nA teacher and research advisory board helped develop an annotation scheme for identifying \ndifferent elements of argumentative writing or discourse elements . Broadly, a discourse \nelement was defined as a span of text that performs a specific rhetorical or argumentative \nfunction within an essay. The rubric underwent multiple rounds of feedback to ensure \nthe annotations aligned with instructional practice. The discourse elements chosen for the \nannotation scheme come from adapted or simplified versions of the Toulmin argumentative \nframework ( Toulmin, 1958 ). The final discourse elements were:\n •Lead:  An introduction begins with a statistic, a quotation, a description, or other device \nto grab the reader’s attention and point toward the thesis.\n •Position:  An opinion or conclusion on the main question.\n •Claim : A claim that supports the position.\n •Counterclaim:  A claim that refutes another claim or gives an opposing reason to the \nposition.Table 16.1   Demographic Group Distribution in the PERSUADE \nCorpus: Sample Shares of Subgroups\nSample Share\nEconomic disadvantage\nEconomically disadvantaged 34.71%\nNot economically disadvantaged 45.59%\nInformation not available 19.7%\nRace/  ethnicity\nBlack or African American 18.40%\nHispanic/  Latino 24.21%\nWhite 45.26%\nAsian or Pacific Islander 7.56%\nTwo or more races 4.07%\nAmerican Indian or Alaskan Native 0.5%\nEnglish Language Learner status\nYes 7.60%\nNo 87.63%\nInformation not available 4.77%\nGrade Level\n6 4.5%\n8 37.53%\n9 7.90%\n10 28.54%\n11 15.41%\n12 1.71% \n \n  \n\n--- Page 5 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n307 •Rebuttal : A claim that refutes a counterclaim.\n •Evidence:  Ideas or examples that support claims, counterclaims, rebuttals, or the \nposition.\n •Concluding Statement:  A concluding statement that restates the position and claims.\nHuman raters were tasked with identifying and annotating discourse elements within \nthe essays (or the absence of discourse elements). However, raters did not have to assign a \ndiscourse label to every span of text in an essay, so some sections were left unannotated. All \nraters had at least two years of experience in data annotation.\nThe raters also received anti-  bias training and anti-  bias strategy instruction, which \nconsisted of two main components. First, raters underwent individual preparation by \ncompleting Module 1 and Module 2 of the Implicit Bias Module Training Series (Kirwan \nInstitute, n.d.). In these modules, scorers engaged in self-  reflection and explored the crit -\nical concept of implicit bias. Key takeaways from these modules included a heightened \nawareness of unconscious biases related to gender, race, and demographics and con -\ncrete examples of how such biases could manifest in essay scoring. Additionally, scorers \nreflected on how these modules influenced their perception of training and alignment \nwhen scoring essays, emphasizing the need for vigilance in avoiding biases throughout \nthe process.\nAfter completing the modules, scorers participated in a 45-  minute group training session \nto raise awareness of various types of bias and their potential impact on scoring. The group \ntraining was meant to foster discussions on recognizing biases and their manifestations, \nbuilding upon the reflections from the individual preparation phase. Strategies to address \nbias were emphasized, focusing on adhering to the rubric and promoting ongoing reflection \nand review of bias throughout the scoring process. Ultimately, this anti-  bias training and \nstrategy instruction ensured a more equitable and unbiased approach to annotating the \nPERSUADE corpus.\nThe essays were annotated using a rigorous, double-  blind rating process with 100%  \nadjudication, such that each essay was independently reviewed by two expert raters and  \nadjudicated by a third rater. Annotators were not aware of the demographic characteristics  \nof the students. The Jaccard Index was used to assess the agreement between raters during  \nannotation, which measures the overlap between text segments marked by two raters. The  \noverall annotator agreement for each argument category was then determined using the  \nformula from Ferretti, Lewis, and Andrews-  Weckerly (2009), which calculates the per -\ncentage of agreement versus disagreement. Overall inter-  rater agreement prior to potential  \njudgments made by a third rater reported a weighted Cohen’s kappa of 0.73 ( Crossley  \net al., 2022 ), a relatively high level of agreement indicating reliability. However, agreement  \nvaried by discourse element. Table 16.2  presents the IRR for annotations on discourse  \nelement types in the PERSUADE corpus. The IRR values for Counterclaim and Rebuttal are  \nTable 16.2   IRR for Annotations on Discourse Element Type in the PERSUADE Corpus\nVariable Lead Position Claim Evidence Counterclaim Rebuttal Concluding Statement\nInter-  rater \nagreement0.774 0.751 0.628 0.804 0.393 0.349 0.839  \n\n--- Page 6 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n308notably low. This is likely because these elements appear sparsely throughout the corpus. It  \nis important to highlight that any QWKs below 0.6 may be more indicative of noise rather  \nthan genuine signal.\nRegarding frequency, claims were the most common discourse element ( n =  82,584), \nwhile rebuttals were the least common ( n =  7,217).  A large number of segments were \nunannotated ( n =  47,410; see Figure 16.1  for details). Each essay had, on average, ten \nlabeled discourse elements, with low variation ( CV =  0.36), as shown in Figure 16.2 , indi -\ncating the annotations were precise enough to train machine learning algorithms to auto -\nmatically classify multiple argumentative components of an essay.\n16.2.1.2  Discourse Effectiveness\nThe experts who annotated the corpus for discourse elements also rated each element’s \neffectiveness in supporting the writer’s argument. These raters scored each element as \neffective, adequate, or ineffective  (see the Appendix for rubric). These annotations also \nfollowed a rigorous process of double-  blind ratings followed by 100% adjudication.\nMost discourse elements were rated as Adequate ( n =  188,607), followed by Effective \n(n =  38,672), then Ineffective ( n =  10,687), as shown in Figure 16.3 . This distribution poses \na potential limitation to the data. Specifically, the disparity in the number of examples \nacross the categories means that there are relatively few samples of ineffective and effective \nelements.\nMisalignments between the raters in segmenting argumentative and discourse elements  \nmake it difficult to calculate inter-  rater reliability (IRR). Segments with at least 50%  \noverlap between the first and second raters were examined to calculate the IRR. There were  \n159,228 overlapping elements, with approximately 120,000 rated as adequate, 32,000  \nas effective, and 6,000 as ineffective. Two statistics were computed: exact agreement and  \nFigure 16.1   Frequency of Discourse Element Types in PERSUADE Corpus. \n  \n\n--- Page 7 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n309weighted Cohen’s kappa. The overall exact agreement for all classes was 0.718, ranging  \nbetween 0.68 and 0.81 for specific classes. Cohen’s kappa yielded low values ranging from  \n0.17 to 0.38 for specific classes. The overall Cohen’s kappa for all classes was κ =  0.316,  \nindicating a fair agreement.\nFigure 16.3   Frequency of Discourse Effectiveness Ratings.\nFigure 16.2   Frequency Distribution of Discourse Elements Per Essay in PERSUADE Corpus. \n  \n\n--- Page 8 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n31016.2.1.3  Holistic Essay Quality\nThe expert raters also scored each essay holistically to provide an overall assessment of \nwriting quality. The scoring rubric used a 1-   to 6-  scale with interval levels, meaning that \nthe difference between each successive score (e.g., between 1 and 2 or 4 and 5) represents \na consistent measure or distance. For independent essays, raters were trained using a \nstandardized SAT holistic essay scoring rubric that focused on the effective development \nof a well-  reasoned position, critical thinking, well-  structured organization, language use, \nand strong grammatical accuracy. A slightly modified version of the same rubric was used \nfor source-  based essays. The modified rubric included wording related to the inclusion of \nsource material.  Scores follow a positively skewed or right-  skewed distribution, as shown \nin Figure 16.4 . IRR before adjudication indicated a strong agreement between the expert \nraters, with a weighted κ of 0.745 and r of 0.750.\n16.3 Feedback Prize 1.0: Evaluating Student Writing\nFrom December 2021 to July 2022, two data science competitions were launched on the \nKaggle platform to promote the release of the PERSUADE corpus and spur the devel -\nopment of new, accurate, and efficient open-  source algorithms for assisted writing feed -\nback ( Baffour et al., 2023 ). Educational data science challenges like these offer significant \nopportunities for developing algorithms that support the advancement of AWE systems \nand solve critical problems in education. These challenges bring together a diverse group \nof research experts, technical professionals, and experimental methodologists to solve \nproblems previously limited to research institutions and academics. They also promote \nFigure 16.4   Frequency of Holistic Score Ratings.\n  \n  \n\n--- Page 9 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n311the democratization and expansion of research and development efforts by providing open \naccess to new datasets.\nThe competitions were launched because open data science competitions contribute to \nthe growth of knowledge in two important ways. First, participants in these challenges \ngain access to datasets, which they use to develop models and gain insights. Second, the \nmodels, insights, and data generated during the challenges are openly shared once the com -\npetition ends. This allows the work to continue and enables further innovation in methods \nand approaches. In the past decade, numerous data science challenges have been hosted \non platforms like Kaggle, attracting thousands of participants and generating millions of \nsubmissions across various competitions (Kaggle, 2021, 2022a, 2022b). However, educa -\ntional data science challenges are rare.\nIn the first Feedback Prize Kaggle challenge, “Evaluating Student Writing,” teams had to \nbuild a model to segment essays into smaller sections and assign the discourse element type \nlabels. Teams were evaluated for how well their predicted segments matched the segments \nannotated by human raters, using a minimum word overlap threshold of 50%.  The dataset \nwas divided into a training set and an evaluation test set using a 60–  40 split. Both sets \nwere carefully balanced to maintain similar distributions of data annotation labels, stu -\ndent demographic representation, and prompt representation. Kaggle participants were \ngranted access to a single evaluation set, and this test data was entirely unseen until the final \nevaluation. Although Kaggle participants could view their scores on a public leaderboard, \nencompassing approximately 61% of the test data, their final rankings were determined \nbased on their performance over the entire test dataset.\nIn evaluating performance, the final score was a calculation of the true positives, false \npositives, and false negatives for each class, then taking the macro F1 score across all classes. \nIf there was at least 50% word overlap between the machine-  segmented section and the \nhuman-  segmented section and a match between their discourse label, the model prediction \nwas considered correct (true positive). Any unmatched ground truths were false negatives, \nand any unmatched predictions were false positives.\nThe first-  place team’s model had a 75% accuracy rate, similar to the rate at which human \nreaders agreed on the annotations of the Feedback Prize data (73%).\n16.3.1  Architecture and Accuracy of Select Models\nOverall, the winning entries in the Feedback Prize were broadly based on ensembles of \nlarge-  scale, pre-  trained Transformers paired with custom preprocessing and post-  processing \ntechniques to improve accuracy. Transformers are a type of large language model, which \nare deep learning algorithms that can process and analyze textual data ( Vig & Belinkov, \n2019 ). Although all Transformer models are similar in functionality, they may vary in \nstructure. Thus, leveraging diverse Transformer architectures in an ensemble model helps to \nimprove the model’s overall performance, creating more accurate models that can evaluate \nthe organization and flow of an essay.\nThe top model developed by Chun Ming Lee, Udbhav Bamba, and Chris Deotte (Team  \nFeedforward) begins by breaking down input essays into tokens, the individual units or  \nbuilding blocks of the essay, and classifying them into one of the seven discourse elements or  \nlabeling them as “unknown.”  It also classifies whether each token is the beginning of a dis -\ncourse element or a subsequent token. Each of the 27 Transformer models in the ensemble  \nreturns a class probability distribution at the token level for each essay before lifting them   \n  \n\n--- Page 10 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n312to word-  level predictions and segment-  level predictions. The word-  level predictions are  \nconverted to segment –   or discourse element-  level predictions using innovative techniques  \nsuch as weighted box fusion ( Zhang et al., 2021 ). The model’s correct segmentations over -\nlapped with the ground truths at 87%, on average, meaning the segmentations captured  \n86% of the words in the ground truth (see Figure 16.5 ). The model’s overall accuracy score  \nwas 0.740, with a range of 0.546 for Rebuttal and 0.874 for Concluding Statement (see  \nFigure 16.6 ).\nThe top model developed by Ahmet Erdem, Shujun He, and Darek Kleczek (Team \nBestoverfitting) consists of an ensemble of 12 Transformer models based on two architectures, \nDeBERTa and the Longformer. Unlike Team Feedforward’s model, this model does not \noutput segment-  level predictions directly from the Transformers. Instead, the Transformers \nuse word-  level predictions to generate “candidate segments,” potential segment boundaries \nof where a discourse element starts and ends, for each of the seven discourse elements. It \nthen trains separate machine learning models (class-  specific ensembles of Extreme Gradient \nBoosting (XGB) and Light Gradient-  Boosting (LGB) gradient boosting trees) to predict \neach candidate segment’s confidence scores or probabilities. The model then selects the \nmost likely segments as the final predictions. The model’s correct segmentations overlapped \nwith the ground truths at 82%, on average (see Figure 16.5 ). Its overall labeling accuracy \nwas 0.740, with a range of 0.554 for Rebuttal and 0.866 for Concluding Statement (see \nFigure 16.6 ).\nThe top model developed by Chen Jian (Team Tascj) uses a simpler word-  level segment  \nprediction task, predicting seven independent class probabilities (corresponding to the seven  \ndiscourse elements) and segment boundaries for each word in the essay. Once the model  \npredicts the probabilities, the next step is to use a unified confidence threshold to predict  \nFigure 16.5   Word Overlap between True Positives and Ground Truths in Segmentation for Feedback \nPrize 1.0 models. \n  \n\n--- Page 11 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n313the segments around the words. This threshold determines whether or not to start or end a  \ndiscourse element at a particular word. This solution used an ensemble of four Transformer  \nmodels: two DeBERTA-  Large models and two DeBERTA-  xlarge models. On average, the  \nmodel’s correct segmentations overlapped with the ground truths at 87% (see Figure 16.5 ).  \nIts overall labeling accuracy was 0.732, with a range of 0.536 for Rebuttal and 0.858 for  \nConcluding Statement (see Figure 16.6 ).\nAll the algorithms utilize ensemble models, which combine the predictions of multiple \nmodels to improve performance. Some of the post-  processing techniques used by these \nalgorithms are innovative, such as using weighted box fusion and class-  specific ensembles \nof gradient-  boosting trees in the Feedforward and Bestoverfitting models.\nHowever, the Feedforward model requires a significant amount of storage, approxi -\nmately 85 GB, due to its utilization of 27 Transformer models. Similarly, the Bestoverfitting \nmodel requires around 33 GB of storage space. Regarding runtime, the Feedforward solu -\ntion has an amortized runtime of 2.94 seconds per essay using a high-  performance Graphics \nProcessing Unit (GPU), and the Bestoverfitting solution has an amortized runtime of 2.98 \nseconds per essay. Overall, both the space and runtime requirements for the Feedforward \nand Bestoverfitting models can be considered inefficient, given the large storage demands \nand relatively long processing times per essay.\nOptimizing efficiency for these algorithms is vital because it frees up computational \nresources and time for integrating other AI-  powered features in an AWE system, enhancing \nthe overall capabilities of such systems. While a 3-  second processing time per essay may \ninitially seem fast, it is just one step in the evaluation process that identifies the presence \nor absence of discourse elements. When considering the additional processing time needed \nfor subsequent algorithms that assess the quality of these discourse elements, generate \nFigure 16.6   Predictive Accuracy of Feedback Prize 1.0 Models by Discourse Type.  \n\n--- Page 12 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n314feedback based on these ratings, and provide other user-  facing features (discussed later in \nthe chapter), it becomes evident that efficiency optimization is critical.\nThe top model developed by Team Tascj is substantially more efficient than other \nsolutions. It uses four Transformer models and requires the least amount of storage space \n(9 GB) compared to the other models. To generate segmentations and labels, the model \nuses a high-  performance GPU to have an amortized runtime of 0.72 seconds per essay. On \naverage, the model would take about an hour to analyze 5,000 essays for discourse seg -\nmentation. Although this performance may be slow for an AWE system where thousands \nof essays need to be graded quickly and accurately, it is still relatively fast and efficient \nfor many research applications or smaller-  scale platforms that require accurate discourse \nsegmentation.\nThe efficiency of the third-  place solution can be attributed to the simplicity of the model \nand the fact that segment predictions occur almost directly after the Transformer computes \noutputs, with relatively minimal post-  processing. Further optimizations are also possible. \nFor instance, the solution only runs one essay at a time, but implementing batching would \nlikely lead to substantial efficiency improvements.\n16.3.2  Overall Model Trends\nThe models reported a high degree of linear association between the model’s classification  \naccuracy and the inter-  rater agreement on that discourse label, as shown in the scatterplot  \nin Figure 16.7 . Each dot on the scatter plot corresponds to one of the three models analyzed  \nin conjunction with one of the 15 essay prompts included in the corpus. With 3 models and  \n15 distinct essay prompts in the dataset, the scatter plot encompasses 45 individual data  \nFigure 16.7   Correlation between Machine Learning Model Accuracy and Inter-  Rater Agreement for \nDiscourse Labeling by Prompt. \n  \n\n--- Page 13 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n315points. The scatter plot displays the correlation between the classification accuracy of a  \nmachine learning model for a specific discourse label in essays from a particular prompt and  \nthe inter-  rater agreement on that discourse label in those essays. The correlation coefficient,  \nmeasured using Pearson’s r, was 0.92.\nIn simpler terms, the scatter plot demonstrates that when there is a high level of human \nagreement on classifying a discourse label in the essays, there is a correspondingly high level \nof machine accuracy on the same label. The strong correlation between inter-  rater agreement \nand model accuracy highlights the significance of the data annotation phase in developing \nhigh-  quality algorithms for an AWE system. Achieving high inter-  rater agreement will likely \nlead to high performance in subsequently trained models, but this hinges on several key \nfactors, including the quality of the human raters, comprehensive training in the scoring \nand annotation process, and rigorously addressing bias considerations.\nThis high correlation between a discourse element’s inter-  rater agreement and F1 score \nalso suggests that machine learning algorithms may struggle to identify discourse elements \nthat humans struggle to agree on. The machine learning algorithms may require additional \ntraining or refinement to perform well on elements with lower human agreement.\n16.3.3  Bias of Select Models\nThe bias assessment focused on demographic factors such as student race/  ethnicity, eco -\nnomic disadvantage, and ELL status ( Baffour et al., 2023 ). To assess bias, T-  tests and ana -\nlyses of variance (ANOVAs) were conducted on the average true positive rate (TPR) per  \nessay for the models. The criterion for detecting bias was a Cohen’s d with effect size of >  \n0.2, which indicates at least a weak relationship. Because of the large sample size, p- values  \nare not reliable indicators of differences, although we report them as a matter of conven -\ntion. The models demonstrated minimal bias based on these criteria with regard to demo -\ngraphic factors. Table 16.3  presents the results of T-  tests and ANOVAs, indicating that the  \nTable 16.3   True Positive Rate (TPR) by Demographic of Student Writer, \nFeedback Prize 1.0 Team Feedforward Model\nVariable N TPR SD\nELL Status\nELL 7,565 0.717 0.235\nNot ELL 81,207 0.726 0.220\nEconomic advantage\nEconomically disadvantaged 35,696 0.713 0.226\nNot economically disadvantaged 42,698 0.743 0.214\nRace/  ethnicity\nWhite 42,197 0.723 0.217\nBlack 17,060 0.722 0.228\nHispanic 23,055 0.712 0.229\nAsian 6,814 0.777 0.198\nAmerican Indian 574 0.728 0.226\nMultiple races 3,884 0.743 0.197 \n  \n\n--- Page 14 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n316average TPR per essay for the Team Feedforward model did not exhibit significant vari -\nation based on students’ demographic factors. None of the t-  tests or ANOVA tests reported  \nany results with a p- value < 0.01 and a Cohen’s d > 0.2. For example, when comparing the  \nTPR differences between ELL and non-  ELL writing, the Team Feedforward model had a  \nTPR of 71.7% for ELL writing and 72.6% for non-  ELL writing, with a Cohen’s d of 0.103.  \nThese results suggest a negligible difference in model performance ( Baffour et al., 2023 ).\n16.4 Feedback Prize 2.0: Predicting Effective Arguments\nThe second Feedback Prize competition, “Building Effective Arguments,” built on its prede -\ncessor by tasking participants with developing models that predict the quality of argumen -\ntative elements (i.e., effective, adequate, or ineffective).\nThe competition ran separately from the first challenge because it used a smaller subset \nof the data from the first competition (around 6,900 out of the 26,000 essays, or a little \nover one quarter), which had a stronger balance of effectiveness scores (see Figure 16.8 ). \nIt also ran separately because the competition task for Feedback 1.0 was already at a high \nlevel of difficulty. This challenge also prioritized computationally efficient algorithms, with \nwinning algorithms on the inaugural “Efficiency” track demonstrating runtime perform -\nance ten times faster than solutions on the original track.\nThe competition gauged the overall accuracy of models using LogLoss, a common  \nevaluation metric that compares the accuracy of predicted probabilities with the actual  \nprobabilities. Additionally, the efficiency score considered both accuracy and inference  \nruntime, which is the time required for the model to generate predictions. Efficiency was  \ncalculated using the formula: Efficiency =   (1/ (log3–  min LogLoss)) * (LogLoss) +   (1/ 32400) *  \nRuntimeSeconds. By incorporating the LogLoss in the efficiency score formula, models with  \nbetter predictions will have a lower score, indicating higher efficiency.\nFigure 16.8   Distribution of Effectiveness Ratings in Feedback Prize 2.0 Competition Dataset. \n  \n\n--- Page 15 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n317The efficiency score also considers the time it takes for a model to make predictions, \nwhich is important in real-  world applications where speed is critical. By including \nRuntimeSeconds in the formula, models that make predictions faster will have a lower \nscore, indicating higher efficiency. The efficiency score is normalized using a logarithmic \nscale and includes a constant value to ensure that the RuntimeSeconds component does not \ndominate the score.\n16.4.1  Architecture and Performance of Select Models\nThe first-  place Efficiency solution, developed by Philipp Singer and Yuahen Babakhin (Team \nHydrogen), used a single Transformer model, DeBerta-  V3- Large, using a novel approach \nthat involved generating pseudo-  label data from the previous Feedback competition. They \nthen combined this data with out-  of- fold pseudo-  labels for their given training data to \ncreate a larger, pseudo-  labeled dataset, which they used to train a new model without any \noriginal labels. By doing this, they could distill the knowledge from their large ensemble \ninto a single model, which performed very well. Team Hydrogen achieved a LogLoss score \nof 0.558 and an efficiency score of 1.035 on the private evaluation set. Comparatively, their \nLogLoss score for the main track solution was similar at 0.554. However, the runtime for \nthe main track model took nearly 3 hours to process around 1,600 essays. In contrast, the \nmodel in the efficiency track only required slightly over three minutes, resulting in a runtime \nof approximately 0.12 seconds per essay using a high-  performance GPU. This difference \nunderscores the importance of developing efficient machine learning models for this par -\nticular project and advancing AWE systems as a whole.\nThe second-  place Efficiency solution (Team Now You See Me) also used a single Deberta-  \nV3- Large model and pseudo-  labeling to improve the efficiency and accuracy of the model. \nPseudo-  labeling is a machine learning technique used during training that involves the auto -\nmatic generation of labels on unlabeled data, which are then combined with the existing \nlabeled dataset to create an augmented training dataset. Their LogLoss score on the private \nevaluation set was 0.563, with an efficiency score of 1.049. Their solution requires approxi -\nmately 1.8 GB of storage space and has an amortized runtime of 0.173 seconds per essay.\nUnlike Team Hydrogen and Team Now You See Me, the third-  place Efficiency solution \n(Team SKT) did not use pseudo-  labeling with hard labels but generated synthetic data with \nT5, a large language model. Their LogLoss score on the private evaluation set was 0.568, \nwith an efficiency score of 1.056 and an amortized runtime of 0.144 seconds per essay using \na high-  performance GPU.\n16.4.2  Accuracy of Select Models by Effectiveness Rating\nThe models accurately predicted discourse effectiveness but had more difficulty identifying \nineffective discourse segments. On average, the models were 75% accurate in predicting the \neffectiveness rating. However, this accuracy dropped to 44% for the ineffective discourse \nsegments, which were more likely to be predicted as adequate (see Figure 16.9 ). In contrast, \nthe models were more accurate in predicting adequate and effective discourses, with 85% \nand 75% accuracy, respectively.\nThis lower accuracy for ineffective discourse elements may be because there were fewer  \nexamples of ineffective discourses in the competition dataset ( n =  4,225). The lower accuracy  \ncould also stem from the inherently lower writing quality within these ineffective segments,   \n  \n\n--- Page 16 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n318presenting a greater challenge for NLP models to interpret and evaluate the segments accur -\nately. Despite this, the models still performed well overall in predicting discourse effective -\nness. The accuracy of the models also varied by discourse type, with Lead, Concluding  \nStatement, and Evidence being more accurately predicted than other types.\n16.4.3  Bias of Select Models\nThe winning solutions from Feedback Prize 2.0 showed a greater degree of bias among \nfactors related to race/  ethnicity, economic status, and ELL status than Feedback Prize 1.0 \n(Baffour et al., 2023 ). For instance, the Team Hydrogen model was more accurate in iden -\ntifying discourses classified as effective in non-  ELL writing, achieving a 76% accuracy rate \ncompared to a 27% accuracy rate in ELL essays. T-  tests revealed a meaningful difference \nin the model’s average likelihood scores for effective discourses between ELL and non-  ELL \nwriting, reporting a medium effect size (Cohen’s d ~0.671). None of the other t- tests or \nANOVA tests reported any results with a p- value < 0.01 and a Cohen’s d > 0.2.  These \nfindings are presented in Tables 16.4  and 16.5.\n16.5 Leveraging the PERSUADE Corpus and Algorithms to Improve \nStudent Writing Outcomes in AWE Systems\nThe Feedback Prize project, anchored by the PERSUADE corpus, offers new pathways  \nfor automating feedback in argumentative writing at the discourse level. The PERSUADE  \ncorpus boasts over 25,000 essays annotated for argumentative elements and covers various  \nprompts, tasks, and student demographics, ensuring broad representation and minimizing  \nalgorithmic bias. Over 100,000 feedback models emerged from the open Kaggle  \ncompetitions, aiming to classify argumentative elements and rate their effectiveness using  \nFigure 16.9   Predictive Accuracy of Feedback Prize 2.0 Team Hydrogen Model by Discourse Type \nand Effectiveness Rating. \n \n  \n\n--- Page 17 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n319advanced NLP approaches. The winning models, leveraging Transformer architectures,  \nboasted accuracies mirroring human annotators in segmenting essays and labeling dis -\ncourse components.\nDespite their high performance and efficiency, certain models, particularly in the \nFeedback Prize 2.0 competition for predicting discourse effectiveness, demonstrated bias \ntoward students’ demographics, such as the ELL status. Some of this bias can be attributed \nto limitations in the PERSUADE corpus, such as imbalances in effectiveness ratings. These \nlimitations call for cautious application in educational contexts. Additionally, the distribu -\ntion of grade representation within the PERSUADE corpus is notably skewed, with a sig -\nnificant concentration in Grades 8 and 10. Given this imbalance, further research may be \nnecessary before the associated algorithms can reliably offer grade-  level-  specific feedback \nbeyond 8th and 10th grade students. Nonetheless, the Feedback Prize project underscores \nAI and NLP’s capacity to elevate AWE systems.\n16.5.1  Potential User-  Facing Features in an AWE System\nOverall, the annotations in the PERSUADE corpus offer a comprehensive dataset that \neducators and AWE developers can utilize to gain insights into argumentative writing and Table 16.5   Summary of T-  Tests and ANOVA Results for Likelihood Scores, \nFeedback Prize 2.0 Efficiency Track Team Hydrogen\nVariable Test Type Cohen’s d p- value\nELL Status t- test 0.671 < 0.001\nEconomic advantage t- test 0.263 < 0.001\nRace/  ethnicity ANOVA 0.15 < 0.001Table 16.4   Likelihood Scores for Effective Discourses by Demographic of \nStudent Writer, Feedback Prize 2.0 Efficiency Track Team Hydrogen\nVariable N Likelihood STD\nELL Status\nELL 2,623 0.028 0.083\nNot ELL 19,853 0.246 0.321\nEconomic advantage\nEconomically disadvantaged 10,268 0.113 0.224\nNot economically disadvantaged 9,805 0.338 0.353\nRace/  ethnicity\nWhite 9,816 0.270 0.328\nBlack 4,157 0.133 0.246\nHispanic 6,218 0.149 0.261\nAsian 1,721 0.398 0.370\nAmerican Indian 179 0.096 0.176\nMultiple races 888 0.250 0.321 \n \n  \n\n--- Page 18 ---\nPerpetual Baffour and Scott Crossley\n320train algorithms for more effective feedback in AWE systems. The winning algorithms \nfrom the Feedback Prize competition series have the potential to support both students \nand teachers in various ways. Primarily, they can deliver immediate, formative feedback on \ndifferent aspects of a student’s argumentative writing. This feature is particularly valuable as \nteachers often need help finding time to provide feedback and assist students in improving \ntheir writing. Research indicates that more than 70% of educators feel overwhelmed by \ngrading and administrative tasks ( Baffour et al., 2023 ). Furthermore, teachers in low-  \nincome schools are nearly 20% more likely to report feeling burdened by routine duties \nlike grading essays ( Baffour et al., 2023 ).\nConsidering these challenges, one application of AWE systems could assist teachers \nand students in evaluating the structural elements of essays and identifying areas where \nwriting may be effective. Based on the performance of the winning algorithms in identi -\nfying “effective” versus “adequate and ineffective” argumentative elements in essays, it \nappears that the more immediate and evidence-  based application of these algorithms lies in \nassisting teachers and students in identifying the presence of effective writing versus inef -\nfective writing. The algorithms are well-  equipped to determine whether a student’s essay \nincludes a given element and whether it resembles an effective example.\nThis information can also help teachers understand individual student needs and identify \npatterns within the classroom. It can then be used to provide personalized feedback and \nguide classroom instruction. Another application involves integrating these algorithms into \ngrading tools, saving teachers’ valuable time during the grading process. Additionally, AWE \nsystems can provide real-  time formative feedback directly to students as they write. These \napplications can analyze the structural elements of their writing, estimate writing quality, \nand track progress over time. Such feedback empowers students to identify their strengths \nand weaknesses, enabling them to improve their writing skills.\n16.5.2  Supporting the Academic Growth of All Students,  \nIncluding the Historically Marginalized\nThe annotations on the effectiveness of each discourse element help teachers, students, and \nresearchers gain an in-  depth understanding of the nuances of argument development. The \ninsights gleaned from the effectiveness ratings can be used to create targeted interventions \nat the individual student level or inform broader policy changes at the population level. For \ninstance, a higher proportion of Lead and Concluding Statement elements were considered \neffective (~20% and ~18%, respectively), while a lower proportion of Position elements \nwere considered effective (~11%), indicating students may need more support crafting their \nthesis statement in comparison to rhetorical elements.\nPractitioners and policymakers can also implement targeted strategies to address the spe -\ncific needs of historically marginalized students based on the data found in the PERSUADE \ncorpus. For instance, if the data consistently reveals a significant gap in the effectiveness of \ncertain discourse elements among marginalized students, policy initiatives can be developed \nto allocate resources and support to improve performance in those areas. By recognizing \npatterns in students’ strengths and weaknesses and addressing disparities through oper -\national or policy changes, educational systems can work towards creating a more equitable \nand inclusive environment for marginalized students.\nAdditionally, although the holistic scores were not used in the Kaggle challenges, \nresearchers can use these scores to identify trends in the data and determine which aspects   \n\n--- Page 19 ---\nAdvances in Automating Feedback for Argumentative Writing\n321of the writing are most important for predicting overall essay quality. This information can \nthen be used to improve the performance of the algorithms used in an AWE system.\nBefore implementing widespread use, evaluating bias in AWE systems is crucial. The \nPERSUADE corpus highlights a challenge: when reflecting the US population accurately, \ndisparities in educational achievement can manifest as biases in datasets. Specifically, \nminority student groups are a smaller proportion of the population and traditionally \nunderperform in writing assessments. Consequently, fewer high-  quality writing samples \nfrom these populations are available, and data may show differences in scores and writing \ncharacteristics between these groups and the majority. This limited representation of \nminority writing can hinder the ability to train algorithms effectively to recognize and \nevaluate high-  quality writing from these underrepresented student populations ( Baffour \net al., 2023 ). Future efforts in developing educational NLP applications, such as Assisted \nWriting Feedback Tools, should prioritize the identification of potential biases in data, \nincluding label distribution, agreement, and demographic representation, to mitigate bias \nin algorithmic outcomes and promote fairness in these systems.\nIn summary, the annotations and effectiveness ratings provided by the PERSUADE \ncorpus not only contribute to an in-  depth understanding of argument development but \nalso enable personalized feedback and interventions for historically marginalized students. \nBy tailoring instruction to address specific areas of weakness and implementing changes \ninformed by the data, education leaders can promote educational equity, support the aca -\ndemic growth of marginalized students, and ensure that all students can master effective \npersuasive writing.\nReferences\nArroyo González, R., Fernández-  Lancho, E., & Maldonado Jurado, J.
