British Journal of Educational Technology  published by John Wiley & Sons Ltd on behalf of British \nEducational Research Association.1Information Systems and Systems \nEngineering, University of Kassel, Kassel, \nGermany\n2Institut Digital Technology Management, \nBern University of Applied Sciences, Bern, \nSwitzerland\nCorrespondence\nFlorian Weber, Information Systems \nand Systems Engineering, University of \nKassel, Pfannkuchstraße 1, Kassel 34121, \nGermany.\nEmail: weber@uni-kassel.de\nFunding information\nFederal Ministry of Education and \nResearch, Grant/Award Number: \n16DHBKI073Abstract: Recent developments in artificial intelli -\ngence (AI) have significantly influenced educational \ntechnologies, reshaping the teaching and learning \nlandscape. However, the notion of fully automat -\ning the teaching process remains contentious. This \npaper explores the concept of hybrid intelligence (HI), \nwhich emphasizes the synergistic collaboration be -\ntween AI and humans to optimize learning outcomes. \nDespite the potential of AI-  enhanced learning sys -\ntems, their application in a human-  AI collaboration \nsystem often fails to meet anticipated standards, and \nthere needs to be more empirical evidence showcas -\ning their effectiveness. To address this gap, this study \ninvestigates whether formative feedback in an HI \nlearning environment helps law students learn from \ntheir errors and write more structured and persuasive \nlegal texts. We conducted a field experiment in a law \ncourse to analyse the impact of formative feedback \non the exam results of 43 law students, as well as on \nthe writer (students), the writing product and the writ -\ning process. In the control group, students received \nfeedback conforming to the legal common practice, \nwhere they solved legal problems and subsequently \nreceived general feedback from a lecturer based on \na sample solution. Students in the treatment group \nwere provided with formative feedback that specifi -\ncally targeted their individual errors, thereby stimulat -\ning internal cognitive processes within the students. \nOur investigation revealed that participants who \nwere provided with formative feedback rooted in their \n\n--- Page 2 ---\n    | 651\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nINTRODUCTION\nArtificial intelligence (AI) advancements promise to revolutionize traditional educational \nmethods by offering personalized learning experiences (Maghsudi et al., 2021 ) and improv -\ning learning outcomes (Wu & Yu, 2023 ). AI technologies, ranging from intelligent tutoring \nsystems (ITS; Wang et al., 2020 ) to adaptive learning systems (Wambsganss et al., 2021 ), \npossess the capability to process large datasets and customize educational experiences \nto meet the unique requirements of each learner. Traditionally, AI systems within the ed -\nucational sector have been oriented towards maximising the automation of student sup -\nport throughout the learning process (eg, Bredeweg & Kragten, 2022 ; Chen et al., 2020 ). \nHowever, doubts persist regarding the development of AI, capable of multitasking and solv -\ning diverse challenges simultaneously, in the foreseeable future (Russell & Norvig, 2010). \nAccordingly, the application of AI in educational contexts falls short of entirely substituting \nhuman instructors for intricate learning environments. This limitation stems, for example \nfrom AI's deficiency in emotional intelligence (Megill, 2014 ) and its inability to engage in \nflexible thinking and contextual adaptation (Marcus & Davis, 2020 ). These shortcomings be -\ncome particularly evident in tasks like guiding nuanced discussions during literature classes \nor offering feedback tailored to specific contexts (Chan & Tsi, 2023 ). Therefore, discussions \non alternative hybrid approaches, like hybrid intelligence (HI), have emerged (Bredeweg & \nKragten,  2022 ; Järvelä et al., 2023 ). HI is characterized by integrating humans and AI to \naccomplish intricate objectives, achieving outcomes that surpass what either could achieve \nindependently (Dellermann et al., 2019 ). The interaction between humans and computers \nwithin education can catalyse the emergence of a novel form of collective intelligence. This \nevolving dynamic underscores the indissoluble link between the educational advancement \nof both entities, as posited by Gavriushenko et al. ( 2020 ).\nInvestigations into the deployment of HI within educational settings reveal the effective ap -\nplicability of AI systems in enhancing learning outcomes. However, in summary, the majority \nof existing research on HI in the realm of AI-  supported education is of a theoretical nature \n(Holstein et al., 2020 ). Furthermore, there are only a few systems that have been developed \nfor and used in specific learning contexts (eg, Nguyen, Hong, et al., 2024 ; Yang et al., 2020 ), \nwith only a few empirical studies demonstrating the effectiveness of HI systems in achieving \npositive learning outcomes through field experiments (Akata et al., 2020 ). This gap is partic -\nularly notable concerning empirical research involving real-  time learning environments and \ntheir impact on students' learning outcomes. To help close the research gap, we present a errors within structured and persuasive legal writing \noutperformed the control group in producing qualita -\ntive, better legal text during an exam. Furthermore, \nthe analysed qualitative student statements also \nsuggest that formative feedback promotes students' \nself- efficacy and self-  regulated learning. Our findings \nindicate that integrating formative feedback rooted \nin individual errors enhances students' legal writing \nskills. This underscores the hybrid nature of AI, em -\npowering students to identify their errors and improve \nin a more self-  regulated manner.\nKEYWORDS\nformative feedback, hybrid intelligence, learning from errors, \nstructured persuasive writing\n\n--- Page 3 ---\n652 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nfield experiment as a longitudinal study that investigates formative feedback in a HI learning \nenvironment (Nguyen, Kremantzis, et al., 2024 ; Romero et al., 2024 ). Our understanding of \nHI revolves around systematically analysing student texts using AI-  based formative feedback. \nHuman intelligence then contextualizes the errors identified by the AI and places them in the \nrespective context (see Figure  2). To illustrate HI learning environments with formative feed -\nback in a specific learning context, we conducted a field evaluation of an innovation learning \nsystem in a law course. To assess the educational progress of law students in our HI learning Practitioner notes\nWhat is already known about this topic\n• Collaboration between humans and AI in educational settings advances learning \nmutually, fostering a unified developmental process.\n• Collaborative education models advocate leveraging human and AI strengths for \nadaptive learning.\n• Despite abundant theoretical research, empirical studies in HI remain limited. This \ngap underscores the need for more evidence-  based approaches in integrating AI \ninto educational settings.\nWhat this paper adds\n• Field experiment investigating the impact of formative feedback in a hybrid intel -\nligence learning environment based on the theory of learning from errors.\n• Comparison of a traditional legal learning environment (lecturer teaching using \nsample solutions) versus formative feedback in a hybrid intelligence learning \nenvironment.\n• Implementing formative machine learning-  based feedback supports law students \nin producing more structured and persuasive legal texts, leading to enhanced \nexam performance and higher grades.\nImplications for practice and/or policy\n• Our research contributes significantly to computer-  based education by present -\ning empirical evidence of how formative writing feedback impacts students' legal \nknowledge and skills in educational settings. This underscores the importance of \nincorporating empirical data into the development of AI-  based educational tools to \nensure their effectiveness.\n• By focusing on individual errors corrected by formative feedback, we contribute to \nthe learning from errors literature stream. This perspective offers valuable insights \ninto how such feedback can support students' writing and learning processes, fill -\ning a gap in empirical evidence.\n• Our findings demonstrate the potential impact of ML-  based learning systems, par -\nticularly in large-  scale learning environments like legal mass lectures. Formative \nwriting feedback emerges as a scalable and beneficial addition to traditional learn -\ning environments, triggering internal learning processes, fostering self-  regulated \nlearning and increasing self-  efficacy among students.\n• By demonstrating the effectiveness of formative feedback within the framework \nof HI, particularly in legal education, our research underscores the potential of \ncombining human understanding with AI-  supported feedback to enhance learning \noutcomes.\n\n--- Page 4 ---\n    | 653\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nenvironment, we focus on their skills in structured and persuasive legal writing, which is a \nfundamental aspect of legal education (Kosse & Butle Ritchie, 2003 ). The law curricula typ -\nically require students to develop persuasive legal opinions, adhering to specific structural \nguidelines (Enqvist-  Jensen et al., 2017 ; Kosse & Butle Ritchie, 2003 ; Stuckenberg, 2020 ). \nMastery of such writing, crucial for German law programs, depends significantly on feedback \n(Narciss,  2008 , 2013 ; Shute,  2008 ). Formative feedback is a critical component of effective \nlearning and is defined as information provided to learners to change their thinking or be -\nhaviour and improve learning outcomes (Shute, 2008 ). Thus, formative feedback is a sophis -\nticated form of feedback or assessment that takes into account a detailed understanding of \nindividual learning needs and progress, for example by checking the accuracy of answers, \nexplanations, recommendations, or examples of work (Shute, 2007 ). The formative feedback \nof our novel student-  centred learning system LegalWriter draws on the theory of learning from \nerrors (Metcalfe, 2017 ), which should enable students to improve their legal texts in a self-  \nregulated manner (Bandura, 1991 ; Molenaar, 2022 ). Formative feedback is not exclusive to HI \nlearning environments, as it has been researched and applied in various educational settings \n(Fluckiger et al., 2010 ; Rochera & Espasa, 2013 ; Shute,  2008 ). With the advancement of mod -\nern information technologies, which provide numerous opportunities for enhancing formative \nfeedback in learning processes (Goldin et al., 2017 ; Whitelock, 2015 ), there is considerable \npotential for further research into its role as a distinct form of feedback in HI environments. \nHowever, the legal education sector struggles with providing such feedback due to large \nclass sizes and limited faculty availability for reviewing work (Henderson, 2003 ); therefore, \nstudents usually only receive summative feedback in the form of a grade or an assessment \ntext (Taras, 2001 ; Zekoll & Wagner, 2018). Additionally, current learning systems for improving \nlegal writing have fallen short (Beurskens, 2016 ). To tackle these issues, our paper aims to \ndeepen the understanding of how formative feedback in HI learning environments affects the \nlearning of legal writing. To this end, it addresses the following two research questions:\nRQ1:  Does formative feedback help students in a learning environment following the hy -\nbrid intelligence concept to develop structured writing skills in a persuasive legal writing \nassignment?\nRQ2:  How can error-  based learning combined with formative feedback help students in \nlegal courses learn how to write in a structured and persuasive manner?\nTo answer our research questions, we created an experimental design where we paired \nthe assessment of students' legal writing skills (RQ1) with the acquisition of qualitative in -\nsights from the students (RQ2) within the context of a field experiment.\nTHEORETICAL BACKGROUND AND RELATED WORK\nHybrid intelligence  in educational settings\nThe concept of HI is based on the recognition that humans and computers have unique \nstrengths that, when combined in a collective intelligence, enable collaborative achievements \nthat neither could accomplish independently (Dellermann et al., 2019 ). In the context of \nhumans and AI, humans excel in intuitive, creative tasks, while machines are strong at \nrepetitive tasks and data processing (see Figure  1). Human intelligence relies on swift, \nintuitive thinking, while AI operates through logical, rule-  based processes. Despite human \nadaptability, machines often surpass human experts in predictive accuracy, particularly in \ntasks like actuarial modelling (Dellermann et al., 2019 ; Meehl, 1954 ). Expanding on this \nfoundation, Dellermann et al. ( 2019 ) introduced the concepts of AI in the loop of human \n\n--- Page 5 ---\n654 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nintelligence and human intelligence in the loop of AI to enhance understanding of the \nsynergistic advantages offered by human-  AI collaboration. In the subsequent section, we \naim to employ these concepts to show their implications for educational settings.\nIn the field of education, human intelligence also has a crucial role in the loop of enhanc -\ning the capabilities of machine learning (ML) and AI systems. For example, educators con -\ntribute to algorithm development by fine-  tuning parameters, such as adjusting the difficulty \nlevel of learning materials to match students' individual needs (Liu & Wang, 2020 ). Given FIGURE 1  Conceptualization of human-  AI collaboration in learning environments, fostering collective \nintelligence to improve learning outcomes based on Dellermann et al. ( 2019 ).\nFIGURE 2  Conceptualization of our system in a human-  AI collaboration system (Dellermann et al., 2019 ). \nThe graphic shows the intelligent system (AI) as the mediator of the problem information and the human as the \nprovider of problem-  solving capabilities (Von Hippel,  1994 ).\n\n\n--- Page 6 ---\n    | 655\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nour research's foundation relies more on the integration of AI within human intelligence \nloops, we aim to delve deeper into this concept. AI serves a dual purpose in educational \nsettings: automating administrative tasks and providing personalized learning experience \n(Maghsudi et al., 2021 ). For instance, AI-  driven systems can handle routine tasks like grad -\ning assignments, freeing up teachers' time for more meaningful interactions with students \n(Matthews et al., 2012 ; Vittorini et al., 2021 ). Additionally, AI algorithms can analyse stu -\ndents' learning patterns and provide tailored recommendations for resources or study strate -\ngies. This personalized approach can enhance student engagement and learning outcomes \n(Wu & Yu, 2023 ). The emerging trend of HI in education involves integrating human and \nAI (Bredeweg & Kragten, 2022 ; Holstein et al., 2020 ; Järvelä et al., 2023 ). This approach \nis driven by the idea of harnessing the combined strengths of diverse intelligence, namely \nhuman and artificial agents, to achieve complementary goals (Dellermann et al., 2019 ). A re -\ncent study by Nguyen, Hong, et al. (2024 ) highlights how AI tools with large language models \n(LLMs) enhance human collaboration in academic writing, improving productivity, creativity \nand efficiency. Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) advance traditional LLMs by in -\ntegrating text, images, audio and video, offering innovative learning and teaching methods. \nMLLMs can transform educational content delivery by making it more interactive and engag -\ning. For example, they can analyse scientific texts and create visual aids like diagrams or \nanimations, helping students understand complex concepts and catering to diverse learning \npreferences (Nguyen, Hong, et al., 2024 ).\nConceptualisation of  formative feedback\nWhen considering the mechanisms of technology-  mediated learning (Gupta & Bostrom, 2009 ; \nLeidner & Jarvenpaa, 1995 ), the social cognitive theory provides a well-  established frame -\nwork to explain its effectiveness. Developed by Bandura, the social cognitive theory fo -\ncuses on learning through acquiring knowledge by observing models (Bandura, 1977, 1991 ). \nBehavioural modelling, a cornerstone of this theory, has been extensively studied in the \ncontext of technology-  mediated learning and primarily involves learning through observ -\ning the actions of others (Gupta & Bostrom, 2009 , 2013 ). Bandura's theory suggests that \nbehaviour results from the interaction of self-  generated influences and external sources \n(Bandura,  1986 ). Regarding external sources, the social cognitive theory does not limit \nthese to peers and teachers but includes all external sources that model learning. These \nsources can encompass abstract curricula, video recordings and digital sources (see, eg, \nZimmerman & Schunk,  2011 ). Digital sources, particularly AI-  based learning systems, are \nwell-  suited to support learners in their learning activities (Khalil et al., 2024 ; Liao et al., 2024 ). \nAs highlighted by Zawacki-  Richter et al. ( 2019 ), AI-  based learning systems offer a wide \nrange of academic support, from assessment to providing feedback and tutoring in various \nteaching and learning environments. Formative feedback is a critical component of effec -\ntive learning and is defined as information provided to learners to change their thinking or \nbehaviour and improve learning outcomes (Shute, 2008 ). Thus, formative feedback is a so -\nphisticated form of feedback or assessment that takes into account a detailed understanding \nof individual learning needs and progress, for example by checking the accuracy of answers, \nexplanations, recommendations or examples of work. The primary aim of formative feed -\nback is to improve learners' knowledge, skills, and understanding in a specific area or gen -\neral ability (eg, problem-  solving) (Shute,  2007 ). Formative feedback is often differentiated \nfrom summative feedback in the academic literature (Harlen & James, 1997 ; Taras, 2001 ). \nResearchers suggest that formative feedback should be promoted, as it supports deep \nlearning (Higgins et al., 2002 ). On the other hand, summative feedback is provided at the \nend of a learning period, typically during final evaluations, to assess and summarize overall \n\n--- Page 7 ---\n656 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nachievement. Summative feedback is valuable as it also enhances students' ability to self- \nassess (Taras, 2001 ). While formative feedback emphasizes ongoing improvement, summa -\ntive feedback focuses on evaluating final results (Harlen & James, 1997 ).\nEnhanced by advanced technologies and analytical methods (Goldin et al., 2017 ; \nNarciss,  2008 , 2013 ; Whitelock, 2015 ), formative feedback provides context-  sensitive \nand personalized information that aids learners in improving their skills, solving problems \nand learning more effectively (Arkorful & Abaidoo, 2015 ; Narciss, 2013 ). For example, for -\nmative feedback can help students better understand certain concepts by providing de -\ntailed and tailored explanations (Shute, 2008 ). Additionally, it is crucial to customize the \nfeedback according to the individual needs and requirements of students, as well as the \ncapabilities of the available information technologies (Rodríguez-  Martínez et al., 2023 ). \nFeedback ultimately plays a central role in self-  regulated learning (Bandura, 1977 , 1991 ; \nButler & Winne, 1995 ), especially when provided through information technology (IT) or AI- \nbased learning systems (eg, Hooshyar et al., 2019 ; Liao et al., 2024 ; Sharma et al., 2024 ). \nFormative feedback as a special form, is one way to trigger self-  efficacy and better learning \noutcomes (Orsmond et al., 2002 ; Shute,  2008 ). Self-  regulated learning is a process in which \nlearners plan, monitor, and evaluate their learning activities (Clark,  2012 ). A practical appli -\ncation of formative feedback can support students as they write persuasive and structured \ntexts. This can be achieved through the use of ML and natural language processing (NLP) \nmethods. For example, ML-  based formative feedback is already being successfully imple -\nmented in various educational tasks, such as enhancing the quality of students' empathetic \npeer-  review writing (Wambsganss et al., 2020 ) or supporting students' argumentative writing \n(Wambsganss, 2021 , 2022 , 2024 ). These advanced feedback systems can analyse student \nsubmissions, provide insights into their strengths and weaknesses, and suggest specific \nimprovements, fostering better writing skills and deeper understanding.\nLearning from  individual errors through formative feedback\nThere is some evidence in prior research for the positive effects of feedback on individual \nerrors to training skills such as structured and persuasive writing (Hausman & Rhodes, 2018 ; \nKhasawneh et al., 2023 ; Metcalfe, 2017 ; Patchan & Puranik, 2016 ). According to Ericsson \net al. (1993 ), practice and application are essential in the process of learning and acquiring \nskills. This principle holds true for law students who must develop expertise in structured \nand persuasive writing by writing several legal texts throughout their academic journey. In \ntraditional lectures, students gain foundational knowledge and receive examples from their \nprofessors. However, due to the time constraints and large class sizes, formative feedback \non individual legal opinions is rare. Research indicates that repeated practice and learning \nfrom errors contribute to skill improvement and mastery (Ohlsson, 1996 ). Particularly \nfor novice students, errors are expected during the learning process. Metcalfe ( 2017 ) \nemphasizes the importance of providing formative feedback after errors to enhance the \nlearning process (Narciss, 2008 , 2013 ). In their work, Wong and Lim ( 2019 ) delineate \nthree distinct approaches to managing errors: prevention, permission, and promotion. \nThe error prevention approach involves strategies aimed at minimizing mistakes made \nby learners. Achieving this can involve structuring the learning environment to minimize \nthe occurrence of errors or providing learners with exposure to errors made by others \n(Chillarege et al., 2003 ; Potts & Shanks, 2014 ). McLaren et al. ( 2015 ) demonstrate the \npotential of problem solutions containing errors for enhancing learning outcomes through \nrecognition and correction processes. Conversely, the error permission approach permits \nlearners to make mistakes naturally, with subsequent corrective feedback addressing these \nerrors (Lorenzet et al., 2005 ; Potts & Shanks, 2014 ). The third approach, error promotion, \n\n--- Page 8 ---\n    | 657\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nintentionally encourages learners to make errors. This can be accomplished by creating \nparticularly challenging learning conditions or designing learning tasks that prompt students \nto make specific errors (Keith et al., 2010).\nIn summary, we observe that students who are enrolled in legal courses typically receive \nsummative feedback centred around a model solution of a qualitative legal text or receive \nfeedback only in the form of a closing grade (Schwarcz & Farganis, 2017 ). This approach \ncontrasts with the potential benefits of formative feedback tailored to alter their thinking or \nbehaviour and improve learning outcomes (Shute, 2008 ). Unfortunately, the financial lim -\nitations faced by universities and educational institutions hinder the feasibility of offering \nsuch individualized feedback (Cresswell et al., 2015 ). A potential approach to tackle this \nchallenge lies in implementing AI-  based formative feedback (Narciss, 2008 , 2013 ). Yet, the \nexisting body of literature offers limited empirical substantiation for the effectiveness of ML- \ngenerated feedback grounded in the principles of learning through errors. Through this proj -\nect, we aim to contribute valuable insights into the effectiveness of AI-  powered feedback \nwithin a HI learning environment.\nMultidimensional perspective  on feedback\nAlthough the impacts of feedback on cognitive, motivational and emotional aspects can be \nclearly delineated (Ajjawi et al., 2022 ), most studies related to learning and writing systems \nadopt a linear perspective, focusing on the relationship between feedback and student \nwriting performance (Pinkwart et  al., 2008 , 2009 ; Reed et al., 2007 ). To achieve a more \nholistic understanding of the effects of formative feedback in a HI learning environment, it \nis essential to consider the quality of the entire feedback process (Henderson et al., 2019 ). \nTherefore, we focus on three central conceptualizations of writing feedback: feedback as \ninformation, feedback as an internal process, and feedback as a sociocultural interaction \n(Liu & Yu, 2022 ). This approach allows us to maintain the complexity of formative feed -\nback and its broader impact on the writer, the writing product and the writing process (Liu \n& Yu, 2022 ).\nTraditionally, feedback is seen as the provision of comments to students, often in the \nform of error corrections related to the writing product (Liu & Yu, 2022 ). It is a one-  way \nflow of information that follows an external assessment of writing performance and aims to \nprovide correct responses and flag types of errors. This approach focuses on the quality \nof feedback, taking into account elements such as content, type, timing, mode and the \nproviders, while the role of the learner is often overlooked (Hattie & Timperley, 2007 ; Liu \n& Yu, 2022 ). When feedback is approached as an internal process, the focus shifts to the \nstudent's writing process and how they interpret and use feedback (Liu & Yu, 2022 ). This \ncognitivist perspective emphasizes the internal processing of feedback information, high -\nlighting self-  efficacy and self-  regulation (Bandura,  1977 , 1991 ). Feedback helps students \nprocess evaluative information, reshaping their beliefs and mental structures, and involves \nmetacognitive operations for understanding and learning regulation. Models like the inter -\nnal comparison framework and concepts such as engagement and noticing illustrate how \nfeedback fosters cognitive responses, guiding students in knowledge construction and \nhabit formation (Nicol,  2021 ). The sociocultural perspective on feedback underscores its \ninteractive and relational aspects, framing it as a dialogic process where meaning is nego -\ntiated and understanding is co-  constructed (Carless, 2022 ). When feedback is perceived \nas a form of sociocultural interaction, it can have significant emotional, interpersonal, and \nmotivational effects, particularly when it targets the writer's personal development (Liu & \nYu, 2022 ).\n\n--- Page 9 ---\n658 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nDESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF LEGALWRITER\nLearner interaction  in a hybrid intelligence learning environment\nOur learning system LegalWriter is based on the concept of HI, which emphasizes the com -\nbination of human intelligence and AI (see Figure  2). By highlighting errors and providing \nrecommendations, the system helps learners produce high-  quality legal opinions and obtain \nbetter exam grades. Our system thus combines human intuition and contextualization skills \nwith the analytical capabilities of AI. In doing so, the system identifies individual errors and of -\nfers formative suggestions for improvement, providing information about the problem rather \nthan solutions (Shute, 2007 ; Von Hippel, 1994 ). This means that our feedback highlights the \nproblems without providing direct solutions and encourages learners to engage in cogni -\ntive processes to find the solutions themselves (Aleven & Koedinger, 2000 ; Shute,  2007 ). \nIn contrast, systems such as Grammarly provide students with direct solutions, which can \ndiminish the hybrid nature of the learning process by making it more passive. In contrast, \nour system encourages active learning by asking students to analyse and correct their \nown errors (Metcalfe, 2017 ). In this context, AI acts as a mediator of the problem informa -\ntion, and human intelligence provides problem-  solving capabilities (Von Hippel, 1994 ) (see \nFigure  2). This approach encourages deeper engagement with the material and improves \ncritical thinking skills, as students need to understand and apply feedback to improve their \ntext. Accordingly, human intelligence can interpret the errors detected by the AI in legal texts \nand evaluate them in the context of the specific legal context and nuances. This integration \nenables learners to deepen their legal understanding and perform competent legal analysis, \nresulting in improved learning and performance (Wu & Yu, 2023 ).\nBack-  end of  the hybrid intelligence system LegalWriter\nWe designed and built LegalWriter as an ML-  based learning system that gives students \nformative feedback on their errors based on three fine-  tuned BERT (Bidirectional Encoder \nRepresentations from Transformers) models. The models are based on a corpus, which is \nshown in Weber et al. ( 2023 ). The three trained models allow identifying certain components \nin the students' legal texts and, based on the classification, provide formative feedback to \nthe students. In designing the system, we followed the findings of recent literature on digital \nlearning (Afrin et al., 2021 ; Cagiltay, 2006 ; Mathan & Koedinger, 2018), literature related to \nlearning from errors (eg, Metcalfe, 2017 ; Ohlsson, 1996 ; Wong & Lim, 2019 ) and formative \nfeedback (Narciss,  2008 , 2013 ), as well as the social cognitive theory of self-  regulation \n(Bandura,  1977, 1991 ; Nicol & Macfarlane-  Dick, 2006 ). We have created a web-  based ap -\nplication designed to work seamlessly on various devices. For integration into a hybrid learn -\ning framework featuring an AI system, the system is tailored to guide learners in crafting \nproficient legal texts. It facilitates the learning process by engaging learners interactively, \nwhere the AI plays a pivotal role in stimulating the learner's cognitive processes. This is \naccomplished by highlighting errors and offering suggestions for improvement rather than \nsupplying outright solutions (Molenaar, 2022 ). Here, the AI ultimately serves as a provider \nof information about errors. At the same time, the student provides the problem-  solving \nskills to resolve the errors and improve their text in a self-  regulated manner (see Figure  2). \nConsequently, the learning outcome is achieved through the dynamic interaction between \nthe AI and the learner, with the system purposefully not engineered to deliver flawless an -\nswers to the student. When utilizing the application, students are guided through its function -\nalities via intuitive buttons and checklists, allowing them to familiarize themselves with legal \nwriting principles. Our system is illustrated in Figure  3.\n\n--- Page 10 ---\n    | 659\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nUser interaction  with LegalWriter\nWhen starting the application, the students were introduced to the main functionality of the \nsystems through the buttons “more” and to the main principles of legal writing through the \nchecklist on the system's left side. On the right side, the system displaces a feedback dash -\nboard for the learner, which gives more insights in the distribution of the text. After learners \nwrite their texts in the text editor, they can use the feedback button to get different types of \nfeedback. In the checklist, the errors detected by the model are displayed per component \nof the structured legal writing. Based on the errors, students receive different recommenda -\ntions on how the errors could be improved (Cagiltay, 2006 ) (see Figure  4). The highlighting \nis created using the three fine-  tuned BERT models (see section ‘Back-  end of the hybrid \nintelligence system LegalWriter’). In the text editor, learners are provided with highlights \nthat indicate which sentences can be allocated to specific components of structured legal \nwriting. Sentences that could not be assigned to any component of the legal writing remain \nunmarked (see Figure  4). On the right side, learners are presented with a feedback dash -\nboard. Here, students are shown the compositions of their text and receive feedback on \nhow to improve them. Furthermore, the learners are shown the persuasiveness of their text \nin the form of a bar chart. The presented value is lower the more errors occur and the more \nsentences cannot be classified into a component of structured legal writing (see Figure  4).\nMETHODS\nOverview of  the experimental measures and surveys\nTo answer the questions of whether formative feedback is effective in HI learning \nenvironments (RQ1) and what effects formative feedback has on the writer (students \nthemselves), the writing product, and the writing process (RQ2), we conducted a mixed- \nmethod field experiment at a German university. The experiment was designed to collect \nboth quantitative and qualitative data in the form of user statements. For this purpose, we FIGURE 3  Screenshot of the design of our formative feedback system, which gives formative ML-  based \nfeedback on errors. For the purpose of this publication, the interface has been translated into English.\n\n\n--- Page 11 ---\n660 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nconducted a five-  week field experiment (see Figure  5), which included a pre-  and post- \nsurvey as well as a treatment phase (see section ‘Treatment phase’) in the form of three \nwriting tasks and a pre-  and post-  test (see Table  1).\nStudents from the law course where our field experiment takes place could voluntarily \ndecide whether they wanted to participate in the field experiment. All students who wished \nto participate were informed that the experiment complied the data protection regulations of \ntheir university and had been classified as harmless by our university ethics committee.1 To \ncontinue participating in the experiment, the students received and completed a declaration \nof consent. Forty-  three students voluntarily took part in the experiment and completed it. FIGURE 4  Screenshots illustrating LegalWriter functionalities: The checklist is positioned on the left side, \nthe text editor occupies the centre, and the dashboard is located on the right. For the sake of this publication, \nthe interface has been translated into English. The text in the text editor remains in German to better illustrate \nthe feedback.\nFIGURE 5  Overview of the five-  week field experiment in a law course at a German university.\n\n\n--- Page 12 ---\n    | 661\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nTABLE 1  Overview of our methodological approach.\nExperiment stage Description Data Data analysing Research questions and goal\nPre- survey Randomization was tested to eliminate biases \nand ensure data comparability. Demographic data \nwas collected to improve transparency and study \nreproducibilityPerceptions \nmeasures and \ndemographic dataStatistical analysis Test for randomization (RQ1 and \nRQ2)\nPre- test The experiment started with introducing and \nassessing students' prior knowledge (solving a \nlegal problem) to generate comparable data and \nestablish a common foundation for all participantsGrades of the \nassigned textsStatistical analysis Test for randomization and \nmitigation of potential influences \nfrom confounding variables (RQ1 \nand RQ2)\nTreatment phase The participants were asked to write three \nsolutions to legal problems over the course of \n3 weeks, each presented as a legal opinion. This approach aims to generate \nmore precise qualitative insights on the impact of \nformative feedback in an HI learning environment \non the writer (students), the writing and the writing \nprocess and why formative feedback is effectiveQualitative data via \nan online survey \n(Braun et al., 2021 )Transcription and \nanalysis of the qualitative \ndata (statements \nof the participants) \n(Mayring,  2015 )Determine influences on the \nstudents themselves, the writing, \nand the writing process (RQ2)\n\n--- Page 13 ---\n662 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nSeventeen men and 26 women with an average age of 18.9 years ( SD = 3.34) took part in \nthe experiment (see Table  2). The students were randomly assigned to either the control or \ntreatment group; however, differences emerged as some students did not complete the final \nexam.\nPre- survey and pre-  test\nWe collected data and test randomization during the pre-  survey and the pre-  test.2 In the \npre- survey,3 we informed the students about data protection protocols and obtained their \nconsent to participate in the experiment. Additionally, we collected demographic data from \nthe students. The pre-  survey also included questions about various constructs (perception \nmeasures) to evaluate the effectiveness of the randomization. Specifically, we used the con -\nstructs of personal innovativeness in IT (Agarwal & Karahanna, 2000 ) and feedback-  seeking \nbehaviour (Ashford, 1986 ), both rated on a 7-  point Likert scale (see Table  S1). Moreover, we \nincorporated one control question and included an item to serve as a manipulation check.\nBefore the treatment phase starts, we further control for the efficacy of randomization and \nmitigate potential influences from confounding variables. Therefore, we executed a pre-  test. \nThe objective of the pre-  test was to demonstrate that students in both control and treatment \ngroups possessed similar levels of prior knowledge regarding legal writing. To achieve this, \nstudents were tasked with resolving a legal issue in the form of a legal opinion. This was \nthen assessed by a lecturer from the law lecture, where our experiment takes part using \nthe same grading criteria employed in the subsequent post-  test.4 The solution to the legal \nopinion was carried out during the kick-  off event of the legal lecture, and all students solved \nthe legal problem individually with the help of law books. The students entered the solution \ninto the system for collecting the legal texts.\nTreatment phase\nThe treatment phase lasted 3 weeks and took place as part of an extra 90-  minute course \naccompanying the lecture, in which a lecturer5 led. Each week, we asked the participants to \nsolve a legal problem in the course. Each student had 60 minutes to solve the legal problem \nand write a legal text. A translated excerpt from a typical student's legal text can be found \nin the Supplementary Material  (see Figure  S1). In each assignment, the participants are \nrequired to solve a legal problem in the form of a legal opinion. The legal opinion has to be \nwritten in the appraisal style. Since the term appraisal style is peculiar to the German legal \nlanguage, there is no direct equivalent in English. The term appraisal style is often defined \nas ‘the form and writing style of a legal opinion’ (eg, Stuckenberg, 2020 ; Weber et al., 2023 ).\nThe 43 participants of our field experiment were randomly assigned to two groups \n(see Figure  6). Participants in the control group followed traditional legal standards while \nTABLE 2  Overview of participants from the control and the treatment group. The table shows the number of \nparticipants ( n), age and gender.\nGroup n Age Gender\nTraditional legal learning \nenvironment (CG)24 Mean = 18.32, SD = 1.47 10 males, 14 \nfemales\nFormative feedback in a HI \nlearning environment (TG)19 Mean = 19.57, SD = 5.20 7 males, 12 \nfemales\n\n--- Page 14 ---\n    | 663\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nfinishing their writing assignments. They worked individually to solve legal problems, \nusing the necessary legal texts. After completing their legal texts, they received a sample \nsolution from the lecturer. The lecturer explained the sample solution, discussed it with \nthe group and answered any questions the students had. This part lasted 30 minutes. \nBased on the sample solution and the lecturer's explanations, the students continuously \nimproved their texts. In contrast, the treatment group worked on the legal problems using \nthe LegalWriter system (see Figure  6) and received formative feedback. This formative \nfeedback from the system is based on the theory of learning from errors. The system \nindicates to the students where problems and errors appear in their written text. Based \non this feedback, cognitive processes are triggered that activate the students' problem-  \nsolving capabilities. Thus, the students are self-  directed in recognizing and improving \ntheir errors. After the students completed their work with the system and improved their \nassessments, the texts were discussed in a group with the lecturer based on a sample \nsolution (30 minutes). This decision is based on several reasons. First, the use of AI in our \nHI learning environment is intended to complement, not replace, the role of the human \nlecturer. Second, we did not want to deprive the students in the treatment group of the \nexplanations of a human lecturer, as this would conflict with the ethical principles of our \nresearch. Third, there may be questions that the AI cannot adequately answer, requiring \nhuman intelligence. Fourth, AI can make mistakes, and lecturers are necessary to clarify \nand correct any misunderstandings that may arise.\nPost-  test and post-  survey\nThe post-  test, designed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the treatments using the sys -\ntem, was administered as a final exam. Students from both groups participated in this exam, \nwhich was conducted under real conditions and was required for the successful comple -\ntion of the law course. However, the exam's evaluation did not affect the overall course \ngrade; it served as preparation for graded exams. The exam lasted 90 minutes and was \nindependently assessed by the same lecturer. The lecturer remained uninformed, about \nwhether the texts were generated by the control group or the treatment group. Additionally, \nno indicators were present that could unveil the affiliation of the texts with their respective FIGURE 6  Overview of the control and treatment group in the field experiment.\n\n\n--- Page 15 ---\n664 |   \nWEBER  et al .\ngroups. To facilitate a more comprehensive textual analysis, the instructor allocated three \ngrades, ranging from 0 to 18 points (0: indicating failure; 18: very good), to the students' as -\nsignments. This grading system adhered to German legal norms (Zekoll & Wagner, 2018); \nthe whole scale can be found in Table  S7. One grade was assigned for legal structured and \npersuasive writing, one grade for the content quality of the legal text, and one overall grade \nfor the legal text. To determine the grade for structured and persuasive legal writing, we \nresorted to the appraisal style, which is a widely used method of legal writing (Man, 2022 ; \nStuckenberg, 2020 ). Therefore, to assess whether the structure and persuasiveness of \nlegal writing had been adhered to, the lecturer needed to determine whether the com -\nponents of the appraisal style ( major claim , definition , submission , and conclusion ) had \nbeen used appropriately and whether the connections between these components had \nbeen made correctly. In addition, the lecturer had to verify the proper use of legal claims \nand premises in the subsumption process and ensure that the connections between the \ncomponents were coherent and logical. To measure the content quality of the legal text, \nthe lecturer checks if appropriate definitions and paragraphs were used and whether the \nstudent could derive a comprehensible solution to the legal problem of the hypothetical \nfacts (Zekoll & Wagner, 2018). The evaluation of the overall score for the legal text was \ncomposed of the two previously awarded grades on a percentage basis. While the struc -\ntured and persuasive legal writing contributed 30% to the total grade, the content quality of \nthe legal text held a weight of 70%. As Schröder ( 2022 ) indicates, structured and persua -\nsive writing in the appraisal style is part, of every legal exam. Nevertheless, a standardized \ncriterion for the impact of structured and persuasive writing on the final grade through the \nappraisal style is lacking. As a result, we opted to follow the lecturer's evaluation method, \nwhich involves factoring in 30% of the structured and persuasive writing grade into the \noverall final grade.6\nIn the post-  survey, we aimed to assess the perceived impact of formative feedback on \nthe students themselves, the writing product, and the writing process to answer research \nquestion 2 (RQ2) via an online survey (Braun et al., 2021 ). To achieve this, we captured the \nqualitative impressions of students in their learning processes by asking four qualitative \nquestions: “How has the system's usage and feedback influenced your learning process?”, \n“Can you share specific aspects of your interaction with LegalWriter that you enjoyed the \nmost?”, “If given the opportunity, what enhancements would you suggest for LegalWriter?” \nand “Are there any other suggestions you'd like to propose? What additional features would \nyou like to see integrated into the system?” (see Table  S2). The questions aim to provide \nmore precise qualitative insights into why formative feedback is effective in a HI learning \nenvironment. All students in the treatment group participated in the post-  survey, which was \nconducted via an online survey platform. We asked the students to answer the questions for \nat least 15 minutes ( SD = 3.12  minutes).\nRESULTS\nResults of  the pre-  survey and the pre-  test\nWe compared the mean differences of the two constructs measured in the pre-  survey \nto control for the potential impact of confounding variables given our small sample size \nand to confirm the effectiveness of randomization. No significant differences were found \nbetween the control and treatment groups in terms of personal innovativeness ( p = 0.531) \nor feedback-  seeking behaviour ( p = 0.705), indicating successful randomization. The \ncontrol group averages 3.5 ( SD = 0.55) in personal innovativeness and 6.24 ( SD = 0.49) in \nfeedback seeking. Meanwhile, the treatment group averages 3.37 ( SD = 0.71) for personal \n\n--- Page 16 ---\n    | 665\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\ninnovativeness and 6.18 ( SD = 0.47) for feedback seeking. The specific items used for these \nmeasurements are provided in Table  S1.\nIn addition to the two measurements, participants were asked to solve a legal problem \nin the post-  test. This allowed us to determine whether the two groups' abilities to write legal \ntexts differed. Our analysis, conducted via a two-  tailed t-  test comparing the control and treat -\nment groups, yielded p- values exceeding 0.05 for all measured variables (see Table  S12). \nConsequently, examination of three distinct grading criteria—structured and persuasive \nwriting, content quality and overall grade of the legal text—revealed no significant dispari -\nties in mean values between the control and treatment groups. This suggests a comparable \nbaseline level of prior legal writing knowledge across both groups (see Table  S12).7\nImpact on quality of legal writing\nWe start by presenting the results related to our first research question: Does formative \nfeedback help students in a learning environment following the hybrid intelligence concept \nto develop structured writing skills in a persuasive legal writing assignment? To investigate \nRQ1, we specifically tried to validate whether formative feedback from a learning system, \ncompared to feedback from a lecturer based on an example solution, helps students to write \nbetter structured and persuasive legal texts. To answer RQ1, we compared the grades of \nthe written exams of the control group and the treatment group. We used a one-  tailed t-  test \nto check for significance between the variables of structured and persuasive writing quality, \nthe content quality of legal writing, and the overall grade. To ensure that the assumptions \nfor the one-  tailed t-  test are met, we conducted statistical and visual tests for normality and \nhomogeneity of variance (for more detail, see Tables  S4–S6 ). All assumptions were met \nfor all variables. More specifically, we conducted a Shapiro–Wilk test to test the normality \nassumptions (see Tables  S8–S10 ), and a Levene's test to check for the homogeneity of \nvariance assumption (see Table  S11). Q-  Q plots graphically supported the results of the \nShapiro–Wilk test.\nWe analysed the quality of legal writing to gain insights into the students' structured and \npersuasive writing. The assessment involved a comparison between the appraisal styles \nof the control group and the treatment group. The assigned scores for the quality of the \nappraisal style served as the basis for this comparison, with Figure  7 depicting the data dis -\ntribution through boxplots. The control group is represented on the left, while the treatment \ngroup is on the right. Notably, the interquartile ranges reveal a more extensive score distri -\nbution in the treatment group. Red points are used to highlight mean values for better visu -\nalization. The control group has a median score of 8, and the treatment group has a median \nscore of 12 (refer to Table  3). Examining Table  3, we observe that the mean score for the \ntreatment group (mean  = 11.08**, SD = 2.19) exceeds that of the control group (mean = 8.84, \nSD = 2.59). By conducting a t - test, we found a statistically significant difference between the \ncontrol and treatment groups ( p = 0.002). Furthermore, the effect size analysis indicates a \nlarge effect ( d = 0.95) (Cohen,  1992 ), suggesting that the treatment appears to be effective.\nThe assigned scores for the content qualitative legal writing served as the basis for this \ncomparison, with Figure  8 depicting the data distribution through boxplots. The control group \nis represented on the left, while the treatment group is on the right. Notably, the interquartile \nranges reveal a slightly extensive score distribution in the treatment group. Red points are \nused to highlight mean values for better visualization. For the content qualitative legal writ -\ning, the control group shows a mean of 5.53 (median = 6), and the treatment group shows \na mean of 6.58 (median = 7). We did not find a statistically significant difference between \nthe two groups; accordingly, no effect size was calculated. In Figure  8 also, the assigned \nscores for the total grade of the legal text are shown as boxplots. The interquartile ranges \n\n--- Page 17 ---\n666 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nreveal a higher score distribution in the treatment group. The analysis of the total grade of \nthe legal text shows a mean of 6.53 (median = 6) in the control group and a mean of 7.75* \n(median  = 8) in the treatment group.8 We observed a significant difference with a p - value of \n0.035. Further examination of the effect sizes indicates a medium effect ( d = 0.57).\nImpact on the writer, the writing product and the writing process\nSince our findings on RQ1 lead us to assume formative feedback helps students write better \nstructured and persuasive legal texts, we aimed to investigate further our RQ2 about how FIGURE 7  Data distribution of scores for structured and persuasive writing grades. Mean values are \nhighlighted with a red point.\n\n\n--- Page 19 ---\n668 |   \nWEBER  et al .\ncan error-  based learning combined with formative feedback help students in legal courses \nlearn how to write in a structured and persuasive manner? To obtain deeper insights into \nthe observed effect and the mechanisms of formative feedback on errors in an HI learning \nenvironment.\nFor this purpose, we evaluated qualitative students' statements concerning their learn -\ning process; the corresponding questions are shown in the Supplementary Material  (see \nTable  S2). We analysed the students' qualitative answers concerning their perception of \nthe learning process with the system. We identified three main themes among participants' \nresponses based on Liu and Yu ( 2022 ) framework for adopting feedback in the learning \nprocess. These are the topics of (1) feedback as information, (2) feedback as sociocultural \ninteraction and (3) feedback as an internal process. The three characteristics help us better \nrecognize to what extent the formative feedback impacts the writing product (legal text), the \nwriter and the writing process Liu and Yu ( 2022 ). We briefly present the highlights and elab -\norate on them in the discussion.\nFeedback as information : Across all responses, there were positive comments about the \ndifferent feedback channels and how they were embedded in students' learning processes. \nThus, 74% of the students positively highlighted the informational content of the feedback. \nMost frequently, students mentioned the positive information content of the highlights in the \ntext, which helped students identify which sentences do not fit the structure of legal writ -\ning. Interestingly, many students had positive remarks about the dashboard, particularly the \npersuasion bar, often mentioned as ‘the best thing was the feedback on persuasion’. Some \nstudents also appreciated the chart showing the composition of components in the text, \nsaying, ‘because of the chart, I was able to adjust the weighting of my text well’. Feedback \nin the checklist, which provided recommendations for improving the texts, was mentioned \nless frequently. Due to, a student stated, ‘thanks to the comments, I have seen better where \nI have made mistakes and where I need to correct them’. Furthermore, students positively \nmentioned the direct timing of the feedback. Thus, an above-  average number of students \nappreciate the direct feedback provided by the system: ‘I get very fast and detailed feedback \non everything I write. LegalWriter allows me to identify and correct my writing mistakes \nimmediately’. Based on the comments, we can conclude that the information content of for -\nmative feedback helps students improve their texts, especially concerning adherence to the \nstructure and composition of the text. The formative feedback, therefore, directly affects the \nstudents' writing, that is the writing product, which follows Liu and Yu ( 2022 ) explanations.\nFeedback as sociocultural interaction : When feedback operates as a sociocultural in -\nteraction, it can have emotional, interpersonal, and motivational effects, influencing the \ndynamic nature of teaching and learning both in and outside the classroom. As a social ar -\ntefact, learning emotion involves students interpreting feedback within the specific context in \nwhich it is given (Liu & Yu, 2022 ). In our qualitative evaluation, students primarily perceived \nfeedback as a sociocultural interaction regarding trust and accuracy towards the system. \nThe formative feedback seemed to inspire confidence among the students: ‘The accuracy \nof the system and therefore the trust in a quick and thorough review of my work’. Another \nstudent mentioned, ‘I had more trust to start writing freely and focus on structuring afterward \nsince the program pointed out all the errors’. Overall, trust appears to be triggered by forma -\ntive feedback, which positively influences the learner's acceptance of an AI-  based learning \nsystem (Ghazizadeh et al., 2012 ; Parasuraman & Wickens, 2017 ).\nFeedback as an internal process : In terms of the internal processes that the feedback \ntriggered in the student's learning process, the main themes addressed were self-  efficacy \n(Bandura,  1977 ) and self-  regulation (Bandura, 1991 ; Molenaar, 2022 ) in writing. Students \nindicated, ‘I receive quick and detailed feedback on everything I write. LegalWriter helps me \nidentify mistakes in my writing and I was able to correct my errors immediately’. Furthermore, \nstudents noted, ‘that you can generally improve your appraisal technique and feel more \n\n--- Page 20 ---\n    | 669\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\ncourageous with the writing style as a result’. Regarding self-  regulated learning, students \nindicated: ‘I saw what I need to improve. So, in the following cases, I was able to work out the \nthings I had neglected before’ and ‘Using and receiving feedback from this system has been \nvery effective for me. The feedback has helped me better identify where I made mistakes \nand where I need to correct them’. The statements from the students suggest that, based on \nthe formative feedback, their writing process evolved into a more self-  regulated approach.\nDISCUSSION\nOur study aimed to examine the impact of formative feedback on law students' structured \nand persuasive writing skills, as well as its influence on the writing product (legal text), the \nwriter and the writing process. The results indicated that students who received formative \nfeedback from a learning system in an HI learning environment demonstrated significant \nimprovements in their ability to write legal texts. This finding supports our initial assumption \nthat formative feedback in a HI learning environment is more effective than general feedback \nprovided by a lecturer after a writing task, as formative feedback is tailored to each student's \nneeds. Therefore, we can conclude that formative feedback, which is based on individual \nerrors, plays a crucial role in supporting students in a writing environment that is guided by \nAI. Both quantitative and qualitative data obtained from a field experiment corroborate these \nconclusions.\nThe quantitative analysis of our data shows that the students who worked with formative \nfeedback received better grades in structured and persuasive legal writing than students \nwho received only general human feedback based on a case study in traditionally designed \ntutorials. Thus, we might indicate in our context that formative feedback supports students' \nlearning processes better than the common practice in legal teaching. Furthermore, we \ncan also show that the overall grade of students in an exam is higher for those who worked \nwith formative feedback in a legal lecture. This result should be interpreted in the context \nthat 30% of the overall grade depends on the quality of structured and persuasive writing \nin the appraisal style. However, no further assumptions could be made, as we could not \ndemonstrate any significant differences in the grade for the content components of a law \nexam between the two groups. Since the system in its current version can only train legal \nwriting style, the result is unsurprising and even tends to confirm its specific effect size (eg, \nTable  3). The analysis of our qualitative study further demonstrates that formative AI-  based \nfeedback in a HI learning environment significantly supports students' writing product, the \nwriting process and the writer itself. Students perceived the formative feedback provided \nby the learning system as a valuable information source, offering immediate guidance for \nimproving the content and structure of their texts. Moreover, the feedback's influence on \nthe learners became evident, as students trusted the formative feedback in these HI envi -\nronments, specifically mentioning the feedback generated by the system. Future research \ncould explore whether students would continue to trust system-  generated feedback if it \nwere not followed by a lecturer's explanation of a sample solution. Conducting further focus \ngroup interviews could provide deeper insights into this question. Additionally, our qualita -\ntive analysis revealed that the feedback initiated self-  regulation processes, as described \nby Bandura (1991 ). This supports and extends previous findings in this field (eg, Persico \n& Steffens, 2017 ; van Alten et al., 2020 ), by showing that formative AI-  based feedback \nalso promotes self-  regulated learning. Intelligent systems can thus serve as tools through \nwhich students evaluate their progress and reflect on internal benchmarks and standards. \nSystems like these are particularly good at recognizing errors or misunderstandings in stu -\ndents' tasks better than their peers or the students themselves. Consequently, the feed -\nback that these systems provide can significantly support students to use their human skills \n\n--- Page 21 ---\n670 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nin the conceptualization and problem-  solving and to act in terms of collective intelligence \n(Dellermann et al., 2019 ). When combined with the results of the quantitative evaluation, our \nstudy's findings align with existing research, instilling confidence in the validity of our work. \nIt appears that the writing process, driven by enhanced self-  regulation among students, is a \nkey factor contributing to the measured learning success in terms of structured and persua -\nsive writing grades and the overall grade of the legal text. These findings align with research \non learning from errors (Metcalfe, 2017 ) and formative feedback (Hattie & Timperley, 2007 ; \nMathan & Koedinger, 2018).\nFurthermore, we demonstrate that intelligent learning systems can effectively train struc -\ntured and persuasive legal writing. Traditional systems in the domain of persuasive legal \nwriting have primarily focused on using examples (Aleven, 2003 ) or highlighting structures in \ntexts to improve writing (Pinkwart et al., 2008 , 2009 ; Reed et al., 2007 ). However, our study \nshows how formative feedback can support students in structured and persuasive writing, \nenhancing their learning process. This builds on current studies exploring AI in HI learning \nenvironments (Järvelä et al., 2023 ; Nguyen, Kremantzis, et al., 2024 ; Romero et al., 2024 ) \nand adds to the literature by illustrating the long-  term impacts of formative feedback in HI \nenvironments through a practical field experiment.\nOur research offers five valuable contributions to the exploration of how formative feed -\nback in HI learning environments can improve education. First, we make a noteworthy \ncontribution to the field of technology-  mediated learning by presenting empirical evidence \nregarding the impact of formative writing feedback on the advancement of students' legal \nknowledge and skills in educational settings. Second, we contribute, in particular, to the \nlearning from errors literature stream by providing a nuanced perspective on how individual \nerrors corrected by formative feedback can support students in their writing and learn -\ning processes. To the best of our knowledge, empirical evidence for formative feedback \nbased on individual errors is still limited in this area. Third, we contribute to technology-  \nmediated learning by showing that interactions with ML-  based learning systems in a spe -\ncific writing environment have the potential to impact students' learning processes (Gupta \n& Bostrom, 2009 , 2013 ). Especially in large-  scale learning environments such as legal \nmass lectures, formative writing feedback could be a scalable and beneficial addition to \ntraditional learning environments. The qualitative results indicate that this new technology \nmight be able to trigger internal processes in the learning process of students. Thus, forma -\ntive feedback seems to trigger self-  regulated learning and leads to increased self-  efficacy \nin students. Fourth, our experiments provide empirical evidence that formative feedback \nwithin the framework of a HI approach, such as in legal education, can be effective. Through \nthe integration of formative feedback, we observed enhancements in participants' learning \nprocesses and learning outcomes. In our research, directly addressing individual errors \nand providing feedback based on this approach resulted in a significant enhancement in \nthe examination outcomes of students who engaged with our AI system. These findings \noffer tangible indications that the combination of human understanding and AI-  supported \nfeedback represents a promising approach to enhance learning outcomes in legal educa -\ntion and further strengthen the HI paradigm (Dellermann et al., 2019 ; Holstein et al., 2020 ). \nFinally, our extends on existing studies exploring the intersection of AI and education, \nadvancing the development of formative learning systems that can more deeply person -\nalize the learning experience (Järvelä et al., 2023 ; Nguyen, Kremantzis, et al., 2024 ). This \ninvolves not only adjusting task difficulty based on student performance but also integrating \nformative feedback. Additionally, we examine the long-  term effects of artificial intelligence \non student learning outcomes in the form of exam grades. Through our longitudinal studies, \nwe track the impact of AI integration over extended periods, providing a more comprehen -\nsive and nuanced understanding of how continuous interaction with AI technologies influ -\nences HI learning environments (Nguyen, Kremantzis, et al., 2024 ; Romero et al., 2024 ).\n\n--- Page 22 ---\n    | 671\nHYBRID INTELLIGENCE FOR LEGAL EDUCATION\nLIMITATIONS AND FUTURE WORK\nIn respect to our work, some limitations must be mentioned. First, the field experiment was \nlimited in terms of sample size ( n = 43). Further empirical analysis is needed to replicate the \nresults presented. However, we assume that the effects shown are more replaceable, as we \nshowed high effect sizes (Cohen's d = 0.95) for, among others, the quality of structuring and \npersuasive legal writing. The effect sizes suggest a specific effect of formative feedback. \nSecond, we conducted a qualitative online survey, which provided preliminary insights into \nstudents' perceptions of AI-  based formative feedback in HI learning environments. These \ninsights particularly pertain to the feedback's impact on the writing product, the writer, and \nthe overall writing process. However, further research is necessary to delve deeper into the \nreasons behind the students' sense of trust when interacting with the system. Additional \nfocus group interviews could be valuable for a more comprehensive understanding of the \nsystem's effectiveness and for exploring aspects such as trust in HI learning environments. \nThird, we want to highlight the ethical limitations of our study. Concerning the integration of \nformative feedback within an educational system, our intention is by no means to replace \nhuman educators. We firmly believe proficient teachers will consistently excel in offering \npersonalized writing feedback compared to any algorithm. Nevertheless, we aspire for our \nsystem to assist human educators in allocating additional time and attention towards ad -\ndressing intricate inquiries and challenging instances.\nIn summary, our objective is to offer valuable insights into the design of learner-  centred \napproaches to enhance educational applications by integrating cutting-  edge computational \ntechniques in legal pedagogy. We aspire to catalyse the progress of NLP and ML, inspiring \nresearchers to conceive more educational systems tailored to the specific demands of legal \neducation. By doing so, we anticipate making a tangible impact on the advancement of legal \neducation, particularly in cultivating proficient writing skills.\nCONCLUSION\nIn our project, we addressed two research questions. Initially, we examined whether imple -\nmenting formative feedback, rooted in students' errors, enhances their proficiency in con -\nstructing well-  structured and persuasively argued legal texts. Through a field experiment at \na German university, we observed a positive correlation between the provision of formative \nfeedback and advancements in students' legal writing skills. Subsequently, we delved into \nthe influence of error-  based formative feedback on the writing product, the writer and the \nwriting process. As a result of using this form of feedback, students reported heightened \nlevels of self-  regulated learning and increased self-  efficacy in their writing skills.\nIn conclusion, our study provides solid empirical evidence regarding the effectiveness of \nML- based formative feedback in the domain of legal writing. Moreover, our empirical results \nemphasize the efficacy of the fusion of human and AI capabilities in the learning process. \nThey accentuate the additional value AI can contribute to education, particularly within a \nlearning environment, adhering to the HI framework.\nACKNOWLEDGEMENTS\nOpen Access funding enabled and organized by Projekt DEAL.\nFUNDING INFORMATION\nThe results presented in this paper were developed in the research project Komp-  HI funded \nby the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF, grant 16DHBKI073).\n\n--- Page 23 ---\n672 |   \nWEBER  et al .\nCONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT\nThe authors state no conflict of interest.\nDATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT\nThe data that supports the findings of this study are available in the supplementary material \nof this paper.\nETHICS STATEMENT\nIn this study, we made it a top priority to protect participants' rights and maintain the re -\nsearch's integrity. No part of this publication may be reproduced, stored in a retrieval system, or transmitted in\nanyformorbyanymeans—electronic,mechanical,photocopy,recording,oranyotherexceptforbriefquotations\nin printed reviews, without the prior permission of the publisher.\nArgumentation Mining\nManfred Stede and Jodi Schneider\nISBN: paperback\nISBN: ebook\nISBN: hardcover\nSYNTHESIS LECTURES ON HUMAN LANGUAGE TECHNOLOGIES\nLecture #40\nSeries Editor: Graeme Hirst, University of Toronto\nSeries ISSN\nPrint 1947-4040 Electronic 1947-4059© Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2022\nReprint  of original  edition   Morgan   Claypool 201 © & 9\n978-3-031-01041-5\n978-3-031-02169-5\n978-3-031-00180-2\nA Publication in the Springer seriesDOI 10.1007/978-3-031-02169-5\n\n--- Page 8 ---\nArgumentation Mining\nManfred Stede\nUniversity of Potsdam\nJodi Schneider\nUniversity of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign\nSYNTHESIS LECTURES ON HUMAN LANGUAGE TECHNOLOGIES #40\n\n\n--- Page 9 ---\nABSTRACT\nArgumentation mining is an application of natural language processing (NLP) that emerged\na few years ago and has recently enjoyed considerable popularity, as demonstrated by a series\nof international workshops and by a rising number of publications at the major conferences\nand journals of the ﬁeld. Its goals are to identify argumentation in text or dialogue; to construct\nrepresentations of the constellation of claims, supporting and attacking moves (in diﬀerent levels\nof detail); and to characterize the patterns of reasoning that appear to license the argumentation.\nFurthermore, recent work also addresses the diﬃcult tasks of evaluating the persuasiveness and\nquality of arguments. Some of the linguistic genres that are being studied include legal text,\nstudentessays,politicaldiscourseanddebate,newspapereditorials,scientiﬁcwriting,andothers.\nThe book starts with a discussion of the linguistic perspective, characteristics of argumen-\ntative language, and their relationship to certain other notions such as subjectivity.\nBesides the connection to linguistics, argumentation has for a long time been a topic in\nArtiﬁcial Intelligence, where the focus is on devising adequate representations and reasoning\nformalisms that capture the properties of argumentative exchange. It is generally very diﬃcult\nto connect the two realms of reasoning and text analysis, but we are convinced that it should be\nattempted in the long term, and therefore we also touch upon some fundamentals of reasoning\napproaches.\nThen the book turns to its focus, the computational side of mining argumentation in text.\nWe ﬁrst introduce a number of annotated corpora that have been used in the research. From the\nNLP perspective, argumentation mining shares subtasks with research ﬁelds such as subjectiv-\nity and sentiment analysis, semantic relation extraction, and discourse parsing. Therefore, many\ntechnical approaches are being borrowed from those (and other) ﬁelds. We break argumentation\nmining into a series of subtasks, starting with the preparatory steps of classifying text as argu-\nmentative (or not) and segmenting it into elementary units. Then, central steps are the automatic\nidentiﬁcation of claims, and ﬁnding statements that support or oppose the claim. For certain\napplications, it is also of interest to compute a full structure of an argumentative constellation\nof statements.\nNext, we discuss a few steps that try to ‘dig deeper’: to infer the underlying reasoning\npattern for a textual argument, to reconstruct unstated premises (so-called ‘enthymemes’), and\nto evaluate the quality of the argumentation. We also take a brief look at ‘the other side’ of\nmining, i.e., the generation or synthesis of argumentative text.\nThebookﬁnisheswithasummaryoftheargumentationminingtasks,asketchofpotential\napplications, and a—necessarily subjective—outlook for the ﬁeld.\nKEYWORDS\nargumentation mining, natural language processing, claim detection, evidence de-\ntection, argumentative language, argument models, enthymemes\n\n--- Page 10 ---\nix\nContents\nPreface . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . researchers interested in contributing to the ﬁeld\nof argumentation mining, a fast-growing ﬁeld at the intersection of human language technolo-\ngies and computational argumentation. The book’s purpose is to spread existing concepts and\nmethods about argumentation mining widely, providing background about argumentation and\na snapshot of the current state of this burgeoning ﬁeld. As part of the Synthesis Lectures on\nHLT series, this book is directed primarily at the natural language processing and computational\nlinguistics community. A secondary audience is the broader computational argumentation com-\nmunity. Growing the common ground between these complementary realms will, we believe,\ndrive further progress in the ﬁeld.\nThe book focuses on key background, current approaches, and possible future directions.\nIt describes existing models, corpora, and annotation schemes that researchers everywhere can\nreuse in building their own systems. It structures the overall problem of argumentation min-\ning into a number of subtasks used to mine arguments from written documents. Given the\nprimary target audience stated above, we assume a basic knowledge of natural language pro-\ncessing (NLP), as it can be obtained for example from Jurafsky and Martin [2009] and Clark\net al.[2013]. Conversely, for readers coming from an NLP background who would like to study\nsome argumentation literature, good starting points include van Eemeren et al. [2014] and Ba-\nroni et al. [2018].\nOur aim is to give a representative review of progress and challenges in the ﬁeld, as of\nlate 2017 and early 2018. We have focused on capturing work presented on the one hand in\nthe international Computational Linguistics literature—conferences such as ACL, COLING,\nEMNLP, and LREC; workshops such as SemDial and the Argument(ation) Mining series;\njournals such as Computational Linguistics andTransactions of the Association for Computational\nLinguistics —and on the other hand (to a somewhat smaller extent) at computational argumen-\ntation venues such as the COMMA conference, the CMNA workshop, or the Argumentation\n& Computation journal. Argumentation is also studied in the wider artiﬁcial intelligence com-\nmunity, which is however beyond our scope, as are a number of speciﬁc tasks such as political\nideology detection. On the whole, unsurprisingly, our choice of literature is inﬂuenced by our\nown past work and the community with which we have interacted.\nWe hope that parts of this book quickly become obsolete due to new results, new knowl-\nedge, new approaches, and more synthesis. At the same time, it would be nice if the role of a\n\n--- Page 14 ---\nxiv PREFACE\ngentle introduction to the nature of the ﬁeld and its manifold aspects worked for a number of\nyears. In any case, we look forward to the future advances you, our readers, will make!\nManfred Stede and Jodi Schneider\nNovember 2018\n\n--- Page 15 ---\nxv\nAcknowledgments\nThank you to Ming Jiang, Maria Skeppstedt, and Henning Wachsmuth for extensive feedback\non early versions.
