This is supplemented by outlining further central aspects\nof argumentation, viz. the dimensions of logos, ethos, and pathos, and the concept of the ‘criti-\ncal discussion’ as a fundamental idealized context for activities of arguing. We then move to the\napplied side of computational linguistics, and provide a deﬁnition of argumentation mining in\nSection 1.2, followed by an outline of reasons for studying automatic argumentation mining in\nSection 1.3. We ﬁnish the chapter by explaining the structure of the book in Section 1.4.\n1.1 ARGUMENTS AND ARGUING\n1.1.1 A DEFINITION\nArgumentation (as an activity of human beings seeking to sort out their conﬂicting views) has\nbeen of interest to philosophers for a long time, with the best-known of the traditional work\nbeing that of Aristotle. In his Rhetorics, he sought to develop a general theory of persuasion and\napplied it to three types of speeches: the deliberative speech, which advises on a course of future\naction; the judicial speech, which accuses or defends someone whose past activities are to be\njudged; and the epideictic speech, which praises or blames a person of public interest. As the\nconcrete starting point for our introduction, however, we selected a deﬁnition proposed in much\nmore recent work by van Eemeren and Grootendorst [2004, p. 1]:\n“Argumentation is a verbal, social, and rational activity aimed at convincing a rea-\nsonable critic of the acceptability of a standpoint by putting forward a constellation\nof propositions justifying or refuting the proposition expressed in the standpoint.”\nThe main elegance of this deﬁnition is in its bringing together the range of crucial aspects in a\nrather compact form (a single sentence). Let us consider each aspect in a little more detail.\nA verbal activity. People can and do gesture and frown at each other, and occasionally this\nmight be a way of resolving some disagreement. In our conception here, however, argumentation\nis an inherently linguistic activity—either in spoken or written mode. This is to be distinguished\nfrom, for instance, a ﬁstﬁght, which can be a diﬀerent means of sorting out a conﬂict.\nA social activity. Socialemphasizes that argumentation is a matter of interaction among a\nnumber of people, with a minimum of two. Granted, many of us munch on a diﬃcult decision\n\n--- Page 17 ---\n2 1. INTRODUCTION\nfor some time by mentally walking through the consequences of the alternatives, but genuine\narguing requires a person to argue with.\nA rational activity. Obviously, we can perform verbal and social activities in very many ways.\nAmong these, argumentation targets speciﬁcally the dimension of reason. When one person\nreminds the other “Be reasonable!”, the point is to call for a style of dialogue that is not driven\nby emotional outbreak, power struggle, personal oﬀense, etc., but by the sober exchange of—\nreasonable arguments.\nA standpoint. In argumentation, the heart of the matter is some issue on which people may\nhave divergent views. Thus, the argument does not target an undisputed ‘fact’ but a ‘standpoint’\n(or a ‘stance’). Where there is no potential disagreement, there is no need to argue.\nConvincing of acceptability. At the end of an argument, the parties involved may not nec-\nessarily be completely ‘on the same page’ about the standpoint. An argument (usually) does not\nprove beyond any doubt that one particular viewpoint is the single correct one. Instead, the party\nwho initially was skeptical may now be somewhat more inclined to accept the view of the other\nparty (if the argument was successful).\nA constellation of propositions. The shape of a justiﬁcation might be quite simple, for in-\nstance a single convincing sentence. But quite often it will be more complex and involve a web\nof interrelated points that the speaker carefully assembles in a non-arbitrary way; an example of\nsuch a constellation will be shown at the end of this section.\nJustifyingthepropositionofthestandpoint. If the reader is more inclined to accept the par-\nticular standpoint after the argument is ﬁnished, that result is not just due to the speaker having\npointed out that he is the boss, or some such; it is due to the speaker having successfully justiﬁed\ntheir view.1\nA reasonable critic. This phrase in fact combines two distinct aspects. Reasonable reinforces\nthe point made earlier by the ‘rational activity’: the argument is subject to scrutiny on the level\nof rational thought. But in addition, the presence of the external criticpoints to a social context\nin which the argumentation takes place. This can be common political discourse for which most\npeople have the background, or it can be a much more specialized realm such as the scientiﬁc,\nmedical, or legal. Whatever the context, it includes particular rules of conduct that have become\nconvention, which the implicit judge of the argument watches over.\nAs an illustration for the theoretical considerations given so far, here is an example from\nthe corpus of ‘argumentative microtexts’ [Peldszus and Stede, 2016b]:\n1The proviso (given in the quotation from van Eemeren and Grootendorst) that the goal can also be to refutethe proposition\nrefers merely to the situation where said standpoint is about notbelieving something or doing something.\n\n--- Page 18 ---\n1.1. ARGUMENTS AND ARGUING 3\n(1.1) Some may ﬁnd the idea of a school uniform anachronistic, or regard it as too much of an\nintervention into the leeway of students and parents to make decisions. Indeed, however,\nit’s already the case today that students of apparently ‘uniform-free’ schools are essentially\nwearing a uniform consisting of certain brand-name garments. A simply designed\npractical outﬁt would even out the overall visual image of a school, and direct attention\ntoward the character and achievements of the students—and not their buying power.\n(micro-b012.txt)\nThis text was written in response to the trigger question “Should students wear school uni-\nforms?”, and thus the controversial standpoint defended here is “Students should wear school\nuniforms at school”. Incidentally, this standpoint is not spelled out completely explicitly in the\ntext, but it can—and needs to—be inferred by the hearer. For argumentation mining, this situ-\nation of implicit standpoints can be diﬃcult to handle, as we will see later on.\nOne question to ask at this point concerns the range of possible standpoints, or the range\nof ‘things that we can argue for’. That range is naturally very wide, but broad classiﬁcations have\nbeen suggested, in addition to that by Aristotle mentioned above. For Eggs[2000], the three\nbasic categories are:\n• theepistemic argument: some proposition is true or false;\n• theethical (oresthetical ) argument: something is good or bad (or: beautiful or ugly); and\n• thedeontic argument: some action should be done or not done.\nSometimes, the vocabulary used in an argument provides hints as to which category the stand-\npoint belongs to—at least as long as the argument is not too indirect. For illustration, here is an\nexample of an esthetical argument, taken from a ﬁlm review.2We marked some words indicating\nthe realm of esthetics in boldface.\n(1.2) Of all Greenaway’s works (...), this is probably the British ﬁlmmaker’s least eﬀective. As\nwith all of his ﬁlms, the choreography of people and objects before the camera (...) is\nelaborate and splendid. The ﬁlm also marks some of Greenaway’s favorite thematic\nobsessions, including (in no particular order) spiritual and corporeal rotting , Sir Isaac\nNewton and arcane mullings on things historic, classical and numerical.\nBut Greenaway’s narrative and his direction of actors—two elements which only\nrecently has he concerned himself with—are without foundation. After the eﬀects of the\nvisualpresentation have worn oﬀ, the ﬁlm becomes rather tiresome to follow.\n2Desson Howe, The Washington Post. INTRODUCTION\n1.1.2 HOW DO WE ARGUE?\nHaving described the static view of whatconstitutes argumentation, we now move to a more\nprocess-oriented perspective that is interested in howargumentation unfolds. We already em-\nphasized that we are dealing with a social activity that involves a speaker3and a hearer, where the\nlatter can be a speciﬁc person, or alternatively a broader and possibly quite unspeciﬁc audience\n(as with the ﬁlm review in The Washington Post ).\nLet us start with the case where two (or more) people seek to resolve a disagreement. They\nengage in a debate and aim for reaching a conclusion that—at best—leaves everybody happy,\nor—at least—makes none of the participants too unhappy. This is a process that constitutes the\nheartof,forinstance,politicaldeliberation:makingdecisionsafteracarefulandthoroughweigh-\ning of the options and their potential consequences. Greek philosophy had a lot to say about the\nrules of conduct that enable successful deliberation; in more recent times, the German philoso-\npherHabermas [1981] (among others) studied the role of rational activity in modern society and\nespecially in communication. Within the ﬁeld of argumentation theory, the pragma-dialectical\nschool [van Eemeren and Grootendorst, 2004] put forward a theory of what constitutes a ‘crit-\nical discussion’: what kind of behavior is expected of the participants, what protocol to use, and\nso on. Their work exempliﬁes foremost a normative approach to argumentation theory: It seeks\nto specify how things should be done, ideally. For the practical goals of argumentation mining,\nthis may seem of a lesser relevance, but in fact, work in the pragma-dialectical school has also\nstudied the linguistic aspects of the enterprise. For instance, van Eemeren et al. [2007] identiﬁed\npatterns of formulation that can typically occur at diﬀerent stages of a critical discussion.\nThe normative perspective emphasizes the central role of rational thought in argumenta-\ntion, as does the deﬁnition we quoted in the beginning. Indeed, most arguments should ulti-\nmately reﬂect a pattern of sound reasoning, but still, in most real-world instances of argumen-\ntation, there are additional inﬂuences at work. For one thing, beyond claiming to demonstrate\na sound inference, speakers may very well stress their own personal authority on the subject,\nin order to reinforce the acceptability of their standpoint. They may point out that they have\nstudied the matter for a long time, remind the hearer that they are formally in a teacher-student\nrelation, cite an external source that enjoys high public esteem, etc. Obviously, such moves are\nindependent of the underlying reasoning, but they can add ‘weight’ to the standpoint the speaker\nputs forward.\nFurthermore, as we so far only hinted at, argumentation in most cases is a process that\ncan stretch across multiple dialogue turns, or across a sequence of sentences. It brings together\nthe “constellation of propositions”, as the deﬁnition calls them, and importantly, speakers face\nthe task of organizing that constellation in a linear linguistic contribution. Some portions of a\ncomplex argument may be closely related, others may be more distinct. Some points may be\nrated as more important or ‘weighty’ (by the speaker) than others. Therefore, the linearization\n3Throughout the book, we use ‘speaker’ and ‘hearer’ as cover terms that should be taken to also subsume writers and readers;\nin other words, we generally do not distinguish between the diﬀerent linguistic modes.\n\n--- Page 20 ---\n1.1. ARGUMENTS AND ARGUING 5\nof the argument’s portions in a text should not be left to coincidence. On the contrary: being\nable to arrange one’s argumentative speech in such a manner that it promises to be eﬀective has\nfor a long time been considered an art. The discipline in charge of this is Rhetoric , and it studies\nthe relative merits of diﬀerent strategies for communicating a standpoint. The psychological side\nof this task is persuasion: techniques for trying to make sure that the audience will respond to\nthe speaker’s message in the desired way. Persuasion is closely related to argumentation, but it\nclearly has other ingredients in addition.\nIn the terminology of Aristotle, the three central factors determining the success of an\nargumentative exchange are labeled as follows.\n•Logos:Speakers employ rules of sound reasoning:\n(1.3) That building needs to be demolished, because it is full of asbestos, which is known\nto be hazardous, and there is no way to stop its diﬀusion from the diﬀerent parts of\nthe building.\n•Ethos:Speakers signal their authority or credibility (or that of their source):\n(1.4) That building needs to be demolished, because it is full of asbestos, as the report by\nthe university engineers has shown.\n•Pathos: Speakers seek to communicate their standpoint in a manner that seeks to evoke an\nemotional response:\n(1.5) That building needs to be demolished, because it is an irresponsible source of\ndanger to the health and indeed the life of our children who spend so many hours in\nthose poisonous rooms every day!\nOf course, the three dimensions do not usually occur in isolation; most arguments will mix them\nwith each other, to diﬀerent degrees. But the logos dimension is arguably the most important\none, and for argumentation mining the most relevant. Notice that the deﬁnition we worked\nthrough at the beginning of the chapter also centered on logos (“a rational activity”).\nBoth in dialogue and in monologue text, argumentation can become quite complex and\ngive rise to intricate relationships among diﬀerent linguistic units. As argumentation mining\nhas so far focused mainly on written text (monologue, or social media interactions), we will\nin the following emphasize this perspective. In many argumentative texts, such as newspaper\neditorials or blog posts, the audience is not a clearly identiﬁed hearer but an unspeciﬁc set of\nreaders. Still, the task for the speakers remains the same: they seek to inﬂuence the standpoint\nof the audience, and for doing that they need to anticipate the positions that the audience likely\ntakes on the issue. In response to this hearer model, the speaker selects material to present in\nsupport of their view, and furthermore has the option to explicitly consider possible objections\nby the audience. Such counter-considerations, as we will call them, represent the viewpoint not\nof the speaker but of the anticipated hearer—the ‘opposing view’—and the speaker is advised to\n\n--- Page 21 ---\n6 1. INTRODUCTION\nnot only cite them but also refute them, as in this example, which has already been divided into\nits ‘minimal units’ as a ﬁrst step of analysis:\n(1.6) [We really need to turn down that building.] 0[Granted, it will be expensive,] 1[but the\ndegree of asbestos contamination is not tolerable anymore.] 2[Also, it is one of the most\nugly buildings in town!] 3\nArgumentationstructure isthetermwewilluseforwhatwascalleda‘constellationofpropositions’\nin the deﬁnition given at the beginning of this chapter. Looking at Example 1.6, this structure\nconsists of claims made by the speaker (here: unit 0), material they present in support of their\nclaims (here: 3), as well as possible counter-considerations (here: 1) and their refutations (here:\n2). In a similar (yet less explicit) way, the author of Example 1.2above ﬁrst states his verdict\n(the director’s least eﬀective ﬁlm), then presents a positive evaluation (nice choreography; an\nobservation that is in opposition to the general verdict) before closing with an argument that\nsupports the negative verdict, suitably initiated with the conjunction but.\nFinally, to complicate matters, an argumentative text may of course also contain non-\nargumentative portions such as background information, whose identiﬁcation is part of the over-\nall task of argumentation mining.\n1.2 MINING ARGUMENTS: A DEFINITION\nFor illustration, Figure 1.1gives a possible graph representation of the structure found in Exam-\nple1.6. It follows the notation proposed by Peldszus and Stede [2013] (which is in turn based\non that of Freeman [1991]). Circle nodes denote statements representing the proponent’s view,\nwhile the boxed node (1) indicates the voice of the opposing viewpoint. Unit (0) is the central\nclaim of the text, on which (1) places an ‘attack’ of type ‘rebut’: It gives a reason why (0) should\nnot hold. The author proceeds with a counterargument (2), which is an ‘undercut’ type of attack\non the ‘rebut’ relation, thus indicating that (1) is not regarded as a good or suﬃcient argument\nagainst (0). Finally, (3) provides an argument directly in favor of (0); this is commonly called\nthe ‘support’ relation.\nWe will look into such argument diagrams in depth in Section 3.6, and the distinction\nbetween undercutting and rebutting is taken up in Sections 4.1and6.2. At this point, however,\nwe regard a graph of this kind as one possible outcome of argumentation mining and will now\nbrieﬂy summarize the overall problem. In its full-ﬂedged form, it involves the following subtasks\n(possibly, but not necessarily, in this order).\n1. Identify argumentative text (or a portion of a text) (see Chapter 5).\n2. Segment the text into argumentative discourse units (ADUs) (see Chapter 5).\n3. Identify the central claim (see Chapter 5).\n4. Identify the role/function of ADUs (see Chapters 5and6).\n\n--- Page 22 ---\n1.2. MINING ARGUMENTS: A DEFINITION 7\nrebutundercut\nsupport 01\n2\n3\n[0] We real ly need to turn\ndown that building.[1] Granted, it will be\nexpensive,[3] Also, it is one of the\nugliest buildings in town. [2] but the degree of asbestos\ncontamination is not \ntolerable anymore.\nFigure 1.1: Graph representation of argumentation structure for Example 1.6.\n5. Identify relations between ADUs (see Chapter 6).\n6. Build the overall structural representation (see Chapter 7).\n7. Identify the type and the quality of the argumentation (see Chapter 8).\nStep1is of course unnecessary if the text genre under consideration is by deﬁnition argu-\nmentative. Otherwise, in a scenario where the type of text is not clearly known, an argumenta-\ntivity classiﬁcation is needed, which can be applied either to complete texts or to portions of text,\nif documents can contain both argumentative and non-argumentative parts. Step 2 can either be\ncombined with some of the other tasks, or carried out as a separate procedure, which designates\nclauses, sentences, or sequences of them as ADUs of the argumentative structure. An essential\ntask for any argumentation mining scenario is step 3, which tries to isolate the central claim that\nis being argued for. Similarly, step 4classiﬁes the role that ADUs play for the argumentation,\nsuch as whether it is a piece of evidence, or a possible objection. Step 5establishes relations (like\n‘Support’ and ‘Attack’) between the ADUs.\nFor some purposes, simpler versions will do: Often, argument is deﬁned as merely ‘a set\nof premises and a conclusion’, which reduces step 4to identifying premises, and eliminates step\n5 (as the Support relation then is implicitly given).\nOn the other hand, an application that aims at building a full structure like the one given\nin Figure 1.1needs step 6.\n\n--- Page 23 ---\n8 1. INTRODUCTION\nFinally, if desired, in step 7one can detect additional attributes of the argument, such as\nthe particular type of argument from a range of predeﬁned classes, or the underlying reasoning\npattern; or in general assess the quality of the argument made: is it coherent and convincing?\nAll these tasks will be discussed in detail in Chapters 5–8.\n1.3 WHY STUDY ARGUMENTATION MINING?\nThe ability to automatically detect arguments and particularly the support in an argumenta-\ntion can be very valuable for many purposes. Most analyses of arguments so far have relied\non painstaking manual reconstruction and annotation, which severely limits the scalability and\nspeed of argumentative analysis. This, in turn, has limited our ability to build systems that de-\npend on and use argumentative structure.\n(Manual) argumentative analysis can be used to check the soundness of a given (line of)\nargument. Fallacies in argumentation have been studied for millennia, in order to determine the\nconditions under which an argument that is typically a fallacy may be reasonable after all. Thus,\nmanualanalysisallowsargumentstobeexaminedandeithervalidatedordiscarded.Inparticular,\nwhen an argument is fully formalized and represented in logic, it can be treated as blobs that are\nnotevaluatedinternally,whereonlytheoverallstructureisevaluated.Forexample,Figure 1.1can\nbe viewed without attention to the meaning of each numbered text fragment, focusing just on\nthe structure, wherein statement 1 is supported by statement 4; statement 2 attacks statement\n1 and is in turn attacked by statement 3. This can be interpreted as a bipolar argumentation\nframework [Cayrol and Lagasquie-Schiex ,2005], which we will introduce in Section 3.4.1.\nIn such a context, automatic reasoners can be used to determine whether an argument is\nsound. Given conﬂicting information, reasoners can also determine maximally consistent sub-\nsets. However, the application of such systems is naturally limited by the input available to them.\nArgumentation mining could ﬁll this gap by ﬁnding instances of ‘real-life’ arguments in texts.\nWe will discuss the connection between argumentation and reasoning in Chapter 3.\nNatural language processing (NLP) has already contributed to mining both social media\nand open knowledge. Global communication technologies, including social media, have raised\ninterest in large-scale analysis of written conversations. Meanwhile, large corpora of open access\nscientiﬁc documents in some ﬁelds have enabled large-scale mining of knowledge. Argumen-\ntation mining can deepen and enrich these current mining eﬀorts, to truly support web-scale\ndiscourse and debate.\nGiventhe importance of arguments in human sensemaking and decisionmaking,the abil-\nity to detect and extract arguments in written texts can enable computer support using argumen-\ntative structure. Thereby, an online discussion board could visually summarize the current state\nof a discussion, without constraining individual replies or needing a human analyst, showing\neach person’s perspective and its relation to the overall discussion. Currently, human sensemak-\ning and decision making is easily overwhelmed because the work in making sense of a debate\ngrows with each new contribution, limiting the potential of massive groups to have debates.\n\n--- Page 24 ---\n1.4. OVERVIEW OF THE BOOK 9\nFurther, argument identiﬁcation can be used to identify arguments in a written essay, to\naid in essay scoring or to provide instantaneous feedback to support writing instruction. The Ed-\nucational Testing Service in the U.S. is investigating how argumentation mining can contribute\nto automated scoring of argumentative essays that students write as part of college admissions\ntesting; we will come back to these topics throughout Chapters 5–7.\nAlso, argument summarization in near-real-time could be facilitated with argumentation\nmining, by enabling detailed arguments to be viewed at multiple levels of granularity: zooming\nout of the structure would show the main points in the argument, while zooming in would\nshow the detail in each point. This would enable small groups to carefully check the validity\nof arguments. For example, researchers in an Alzheimer’s research consortium are investigating\nhow to automatically interlink scholarly arguments to source materials, and how to capture the\nresearch lab data supporting these arguments.\nAutomatic argument retrieval could help lawyers ﬁnd relevant case law. Similarly, re-\ntrieving arguments for or against a position can also be relevant for e-government and gaining\nfeedback on public policy.\nFinally, we mention the current activity of IBM Research, who are working on Debating\nTechnology with the ultimate goal of a software agent that is able to understand and produce\narguments, and do so in a dialogue with human beings. Various contributions made by this\nresearch group so far will be covered in Chapters 5and6.\n1.4 OVERVIEW OF THE BOOK\nIn Chapter 2we approach the notion of argumentation from a linguistic perspective and dis-\ncuss a range of phenomena that motivate distinctions between argumentative text and non-\nargumentative text. We also touch on a number of concepts that are closely related to argumen-\ntation, such as subjectivity, opinion, and rhetoric. Chapter 3, in contrast, takes the viewpoint of\nargumentationtheory and introducesseveral key aspects of argumentativereasoningand the for-\nmalrepresentationofarguments.Afterward,inChapter 4weturntonaturallanguageprocessing\nand begin with a brief overview of schemata that have been proposed to annotate arguments in\ntext, and we introduce a number of relevant corpora that can be used in argumentation min-\ning research. Chapter 5explains our approach to dividing argumentation mining into a number\nof relatively isolated subtasks, which reﬂects the practice of most current research. The chapter\nbegins with the goals of identifying text as argumentative, and ﬁnding claims, i.e., the most im-\nportant part of an argument. The second most important parts are the statements being made\nin support of a claim, and this is the topic of Chapter 6, which also looks at ﬁnding possible\nobjections to claims. For some purposes, it is important to derive the complete constellation of\nclaims and supporting and objecting statements, which is covered in Chapter 7. Then, Chap-\nter8addresses several tasks that seek more detailed information about the arguments found,\ne.g., their quality and consistency. That concludes the perspective of mining, and we continue in\n\n--- Page 25 ---\n10 1. INTRODUCTION\nChapter 9with a brief discussion of the problem of producing argumentative text automatically.\nFinally, Chapter 10provides a summary and suggests an outlook for the ﬁeld.\n\n--- Page 26 ---\n11\nC H A P T E R 2\nArgumentative Language\nIn this chapter, we consider the linguistic side of argumentation: What does the language of\narguinglooklike,andhowdoesitdiﬀerfromotherwaysofspeakingorwriting?Thechapterthus\nis intended to serve primarily as background for readers who approach argumentation mining\nfrom a technical perspective and are interested in the underlying linguistic phenomena and their\nterminology.\nFor a start, we consider the notion of subjectivity (Section 2.1), which quite clearly sub-\nsumesthephenomenonofargumentation.AsavastamountofNLPworkonsubjectivitycenters\nspeciﬁcally on opinion, we brieﬂy explore its relationship to argumentation (Section 2.2). Then,\nwe approach our topic from the perspective of speechacttheory : some scholars hold the view that\nan argument should be regarded as a complex speech act (Section 2.3). The linguistic realization\nof arguments is often very similar to that of explanations andjustiﬁcations, which can be seen\nas related speech acts, and we will draw comparisons (Section 2.4). Thereafter, we turn to the\nidea of analyzing argumentation as one of ﬁve basic linguistic modes, which supposedly correlate\n(albeit not in a simple way) with particular surface features of utterances or text (Section 2.5).\nThe chapter closes with a look at rhetoric , i.e., the art of crafting a text in such a way that it is\nmost likely to have the intended eﬀects on the readers (Section 2.6).\n2.1 SUBJECTIVITY\nFor deﬁning subjectivity, we follow Wiebe et al. [2005] in adopting the notion of private state\nfrom the English grammar of Quirk et al. [1985]. The idea is: while a person’s actions can be\nobserved by the outside world, her current mental state (what does she think, how does she feel,\netc.) is not open to that observation. This distinction can be projected to that person’s linguistic\nutterances: some of them describe a state of aﬀairs in the world, and listeners can in principle\njudgethemastrueorfalse—these‘objective’statementsareamatterofintersubjectiveagreement\nor disagreement.\n(2.1) There is a cat on the mat.\n(2.2) Winston Churchill came to oﬃce in 1940.\nOn the other hand, when the speaker decides to reveal a private state, there is no point\nin replying Not true! We may very well like or dislike that particular revelation, but objecting to\nits truth is usually not an option. Here are some kinds of private state verbalization that we can\ndistinguish.\n\n--- Page 27 ---\n12 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\n(2.3) Reveal an emotion: Hooray!\n(2.4) Give an opinion: That’s a really bad wine.\n(2.5) Make a judgment: You don’t deserve the prize.\n(2.6) Make a prognosis: There will be snow tomorrow.\n(2.7) Give an estimate or speculation: I guess that’s a llama over there.\nGranted, a listener may legitimately react to these statements with some objection, but then the\nobjection applies to the expressed content of the private state, not to its revelation. For example,\na listener responding with Wrong! to2.7objects to the notion of the creature over there being\na llama—and not to the fact that the speaker thinksotherwise (more technically: wrong does\nnot scope over Iguess). Very often, these cases are ambiguous (and can sometimes produce mis-\nunderstanding) when those verbs of cognition are not explicitly stated but left implicit by the\nspeaker, as is the case in Examples 2.4–2.6.\nOpinion and emotion In NLP, some of these subjectivity categories have received more at-\ntention than others. The most-researched one is that of ‘opinion’, which we will consider in\nmore detail in the next section. The task of ‘opinion mining’ is sometimes interchangeably called\n‘sentiment analysis’, but it seems appropriate to diﬀerentiate between these terms. We will use\n‘sentiment’ for the subclass of subjective utterances that comprises opinion, judgment, and emo-\ntion, where ‘opinion’ is reserved for evaluations that are directed toward some entity—an object,\ninstitution, abstract idea, etc. This list should not include human beings, though, as we follow\nappraisaltheory [Martin and White ,2005] in distinguishing ‘judgment’ (the evaluation of a per-\nson’s behavior, character, appearance, ex. 2.5) from opinions about non-human entities (ex. 2.4).\nEmotion detection (ex. 2.3) is a popular NLP task, too, and it can obviously overlap with\nopinion mining, when, for example, a customer review contains an expression of enthusiasm in\nresponse to the product in question. But in general the two have to be kept distinct: We can ﬁnd\nboth non-opinionated emotions (ex. 2.3) and non-emotional opinions (ex. 2.4).\nPrognoses and speculations While a large portion of opinion, judgment, and emotion es-\nsentially centers on valence, i.e., whether a positive or negative polarity is expressed, prognoses\n(ex.2.6) and speculations (ex. 2.7) focus instead on truth vs. falsity, or more speciﬁcally the de-\ngree of belief in the truth of a proposition. We view prognoses as always referring to the future,\nwhereas speculations may pertain to the past, present, or future.\nIn NLP, detecting speculation or ‘hedging’ is a prominent task (e.g., Farkas et al. [2010]).\nIt can be applied for instance to the analysis of scientiﬁc writing, medical reports, or political\ndiscourse. Hedging can be intentionally employed by a speaker to remain vague so that she can’t\nbe held accountable for having committed to the truth of a statement. The following example\ncarefully avoids taking a deﬁnite stance on the question of the patient having diabetes or not.\n(2.8) There is no clear symptom of diabetes.\n\n--- Page 28 ---\n2.1. SUBJECTIVITY 13\nDetecting subjectivity For many computational tasks it is important to automatically distin-\nguish subjective from non-subjective language. The term subjectivityclassiﬁcation, however, today\nis most frequently used in conjunction with the more narrow goal of opinion mining, where it\nis employed as an initial step of identifying documents or parts of documents in which opinions\nshould be looked for (or not). The classical work on subjectivity classiﬁcation by Wiebe et al.\n[2004], however, started out from a broader goal, viewing subjective language as “expressing\nopinions, evaluations, and speculations” in the spirit of the range we sketched above (cf. ex. 2.3–\n2.7). Their features were purely lexical (n-grams), and the main evaluation task was to separate\nopinionated from non-opinionated Wall Street Journal texts (as derived from the category la-\nbels given in the corpus). This makes the work quite similar to that of genre classiﬁcation, when\nit is applied to genres that are partly deﬁned by subjectivity. The works by Petrenz and Webber\n[2011] or Krüger et al. [2017], for example, address separating newspaper text into opinionated\nvs. non-opinionated sub-genres (essentially: editorials and letters to the editor vs. news); here,\nthe emphasis is less on lexical n-grams but on linguistically motivated features such as the pres-\nence of modal verbs or the tense of verbs: For news reports, there is a tendency to favor past\ntense, while editorials more often use present tense.\nAn ambitious version of subjectivity classiﬁcation would aim not merely at making a bi-\nnary distinction of whether or not a passage is subjective (or opinionated, or hedged), but rather\natdiﬀerentiatingthediﬀerentkindsofsubjectivitywehaveillustratedabove(andpossiblymore).\nThe current work in the ﬁeld, however, tends to focus on speciﬁc subproblems, which are obvi-\nously easier to tackle.\nRegarding argumentative language, we conclude that it is by deﬁnition subjective, but that\nsubjectivity classiﬁcation (as currently operationalized) is too coarse-grained to solve the task of\nﬁnding text passages containing arguments in particular. Since argumentation involves more\nthan a single statement and thus is inherently relational, it is important to consider the subjec-\ntivity status of individual statements as well as the constraints on their potential combination.\nVeriﬁability Amoveintothisdirectionwasmadeby ParkandCardie [2014],whowerespecif-\nically interested in the argumentative relation of support. They proposed to distinguish between\nthe following categories of statements.\n• Veriﬁable: objective assertions (not about personal feelings or interpretations), which com-\nprise two subcategories:\n–Veriﬁable-private: statements that concern the speaker’s personal state or experience.\n–Veriﬁable-public: no personal state or experience is involved; public information is\nsuﬃcient to verify the statement.\n• Unveriﬁable: statements that cannot be proven with objective evidence.\nThedistinctionwemadeatthebeginningofthissectionalreadyseparatedVeriﬁable-publicfrom\nthe other categories; hence, we need to consider Park and Cardie’s suggestion to also separate\n\n--- Page 29 ---\n14 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\nthe categories Veriﬁable-Private and Unveriﬁable. They reserve the former for statements that\nreport on a speaker’s experiences, which are ‘in principle’ veriﬁable, but for practical purposes\nthe necessary information is just not publicly available. Here are three of their examples.1\n(2.9) My son has hypoglycemia.\n(2.10) They ﬂew me to NY in February.\n(2.11) The ﬂight attendant yelled at the passengers.\nSo, in such veriﬁable-private statements, the speaker often talks explicitly about herself, but the\nthird example shows that this is not obligatory: speakers can recall past perceptions, where their\naudience usually has no means of verifying the statement.\nWhen making categorizations of this kind, it is important to be clear about how certain\nmodalizers and verbs of perception or cognition are handled (as we pointed out earlier when\ndiscussing ex. 2.7). For Park and Cardie, both “Peanuts do not kill people” and “I believe that\npeanuts do not kill people” are veriﬁable-public, so in the second example, I believe is merely\na way of weakening the assertion. Along these lines, our Example 2.7(“I guess that’s a llama\nover there”) is also veriﬁable-public: the veriﬁcation pertains to the question of the presence\nof a llama, and not to the speaker’s guessing activity. (Note, however, that in other contexts,\nexpressions like I believe that X may need a more elaborate analysis than that of weakening the\nstatement of X.)\nAs their next step, Park and Cardie propose some constraints on how the diﬀerent types\nof statements are to be supported in argumentation: for unveriﬁable statements, speakers may\ngive areason(“I don’t like this wine, because it has so much tannin”), while for veriﬁable-public\nstatements they can provide evidence : “I tell you Winston Churchill came to oﬃce in 1940. I\nsaw it on Wikipedia!” For veriﬁable-private statements, providing evidence is an optional move;\nalthough hearers are not really in a position to question a statement like (“I have a headache”),\nstill the speaker may go on to explain it (“Maybe I had too much wine last night”).\nSimilar classiﬁcations have been proposed elsewhere in the literature, and we will return to\nthismatterlateroninChapter 6.Fornow,relatingtheideastotheinitialdeﬁnitionof‘argument’\nthat we quoted from van Eemeren and Grootendorst (see page 1), notice that classiﬁcations of\nstatements along the lines of Park and Cardie try to add more ﬁne-grained distinctions to the\nmove of ‘justifying a standpoint’. One question that has to be dealt with here is: what kind of\nstatement qualiﬁes as a standpoint and thus as something that can or should be argued for?\n2.2 OPINION, STANCE, AND ARGUMENT\nWith opinion mining being such a prominent subtask of subjectivity analysis, we brieﬂy take a\nspeciﬁc look at the relationship that arguments have to opinions, and to the related notion of\nstance.\n1For more examples from a diﬀerent corpus study, see Habernal and Gurevych [2017, p. 154].\n\n--- Page 30 ---\n2.2. OPINION, STANCE, AND ARGUMENT 15\nFollowing Liu[2012, p. 11], we deﬁne an opinion as a tuple consisting (maximally) of a\ntarget (the entity being evaluated), the expressed sentiment toward that target, the holder of the\nopinion, and the time at which it is known to hold. A program performing opinion mining thus\ntries to locate the presence of an opinion in a document, and then to instantiate the tuple, as far\nas possible (some elements of the tuple may be regarded as optional).\nThe obvious connection to argumentation mining is given when authors provide one or\nmorereasons for their opinion. An opinionated statement is an instance of a standpoint, as we\ndeﬁned it in Section 1.1, because clearly, diﬀerent people may evaluate the target in diﬀerent\nand potentially conﬂicting ways. Then, when a reason is provided, as in Example 2.12below,\nwe have a constellation of a claim and a supporting statement. This easily extends to multiple\nreasons, and also to more complex structures where a reason can in turn be supported. In 2.12,\nfor instance, the speaker might continue with a statement providing evidence for the overloaded\nnature of a Wagner opera.\n(2.12) I never enjoyed Wagner’s operas, as they are so enormously overloaded.\nFinding the constellation of reasons for an opinion can thus be regarded as an instance of argu-\nmentation mining.\nA more elaborate relationship between the two realms is proposed by Rajendran et al.\n[2016],whoareinterestedinso-called‘implicitopinions’.Intheseopinions,thesentimentarises\nnot from words that generally convey polarity (and thus are to be listed in general sentiment\nlexicons) but from factual statements that only imply an evaluation. These so-called ‘polar facts’\nare domain-speciﬁc and rather diﬃcult to detect automatically; two examples are given below.\n(2.13) camera review The viewﬁnder is somewhat dark.\n(2.14) hotel review The rooms turned out to be small.\nThe two attributes (dark, small) are not in general negative, but when applied to the speciﬁc\nobjects here, they invite us to infer a disappointed attitude on the writer’s side. Rajendran et al.\nnow see a parallel to the task of reconstructing enthymemes2in argumentation analysis: Given\nour two examples above, when the conclusion is a negative verdict by the reviewer, then an\nunstated major premise provides the link between the explicated minor premise (as above) and\nthe conclusion.\n(2.15) The viewﬁnder is somewhat dark (+ A dark viewﬁnder is considered bad).\n!I am not in favor of the camera.\n(2.16) The rooms turned out to be small (+ A small room is considered bad).\n!I am not in favor of the hotel.\nEnthymeme reconstruction is a very diﬃcult problem, but it has been addressed in argumenta-\ntion mining to some extent in recent years, as we will discuss in Section 8.1.\n2Enthymemes are arguments in which a premise or the conclusion are left unstated, for the hearer to supply.\n\n--- Page 31 ---\n16 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\nStance Finally, the similarity between opinion classiﬁcation and stanceclassiﬁcation is in the\ncommon goal of determining a polarity, i.e., a for-or-against attitude on the side of the speaker.\nIn stance classiﬁcation, however, the ‘target’ is pre-deﬁned, and it is often not a speciﬁc entity\n(such as a product) but an issue or a topic under debate. It is often performed for tweets, and\nalso for online forums, where users exchange their views on questions like “behavior X (is/is not)\nacceptable” or “legislation X (should/should not) be dropped”.\nAnother popular genre for stance classiﬁcation is student essays, whose authors have been\ninstructed to explain their position on a certain topic. Here, as well as in online forums, the topic\nor issue is clearly a ‘critical standpoint’, and the texts that are being analyzed are by deﬁnition\nargumentative.\nTherefore, stance classiﬁcation can be considered as a subproblem of argumenta-\ntion mining, when the pairing of topic and stance—such as (mandatory vaccination of\nchildren/against)—corresponds to what we called the ‘central claim’ of the text, i.e., the state-\nment that the speaker is arguing for. We will take a closer look at the task of stance classiﬁcation\nin Section 6.3.\n2.3 ARGUMENT AND SPEECH ACTS\nAs pointed out in Chapter 1, the goal of argumentation usually is to inﬂuence the state of mind\nof the addressees, or to change their behavior. This is, generally speaking, a matter of inﬂicting\nchange on ‘the world’, and this in turn is conspicuously close to the slogan underlying the notion\nofspeechacttheory3:Usinglanguageisaformofcarryingout actions—comparabletoswitchingon\nthe light, cooking dinner, and so on—and therefore it has consequences. A linguistic utterance\nmade by a speaker, once completed, does not simply vanish but leaves its marks on the world (or\nat least on a very small portion of it): The listener may have new information, or be doubtful of\na previously assumed ‘fact’, or feel oﬀended, etc. Thus, there is a close connection between the\nrealms of speech acts and argumentation, and hence we provide a brief overview here.\nThe most profound changes to ‘the world’ are triggered by utterances that occur in situa-\ntions such as the judge sentencing the defendant in court, an authority christening a ship, or the\npriest marrying a couple. Contexts like these were a central motivation for the work of Austin\n[1975], who is nowadays widely credited for the ﬁrst systematic exposition of a theory of speech\nacts. Beyond the relatively dramatic examples just mentioned, Austin entertained—at least for\nsome time—the hypothesis that a certain class of ‘performative’ verbs plays such a fundamental\nrole that they can be used to paraphrase essentially any sentence in such a way that its function\nbecomes transparent.\n(2.17) You shouldn’t read that book. !I advise you not to read that book.\n(2.18) What is your name? !I ask you to tell me your name.\n3For a slightly more elaborate, chapter-long introduction to the topic and a discussion of its contentious points, see Saddock\n[2005].\n\n--- Page 32 ---\n2.3. ARGUMENT AND SPEECH ACTS 17\n(2.19) Yesterday I met a philosopher. !I assert that I met a philosopher yesterday.\n(2.20) Max is the smartest kid in the world. !I claim that Max is the smartest kid in the\nworld.\n(2.21) It’s about 15 degrees out there.! I estimate that it is about 15 degrees out there.\nThe fact that people in daily life typically do notconstantly use those extended versions con-\ntributes to ambiguity and sometimes to misunderstanding (but, arguably, makes communica-\ntion much more interesting); recall our discussion of Examples 2.3–2.7 at the beginning of the\nchapter. This ambiguity in the roles that utterances can play also makes the task of argumenta-\ntion mining diﬃcult, because in some way or another, the status of individual statements that\ntake part in argumentation needs to be determined (and that would be much easier if those\nperformative verbs were present).\nClassifyingspeechacts Austin’s idea of collecting all the relevant verbs in a language in order\nto deﬁne the ‘landscape’ of speech acts is today generally regarded as a dead end for the advance-\nment of speech act theory. Instead, a prominent task has been to come up with a classiﬁcation\n(and deﬁnition) of generalized types of speech acts. A number of such typologies have been\nproposed, and a popular one is that by Searle[1976].\n•Representatives: Speaker commits to the truth of an assertion.\n•Directives: Speaker tries to make addressee perform some action.\n•Expressives: Speaker expresses an emotional state.\n•Declaratives: Speaker changes the state of the world by means of performing the utter-\nance.\n•Commissives: Speaker comits to doing some action in the future.\nWithin these broad classes, sub-taxonomies may be postulated, and ultimately, speciﬁc speech\nacts can be deﬁned. Searle[1969] proposed to construct systematic deﬁnitions by means of dif-\nferent kinds of rules that characterize the propositional content of the utterance, the situational\nconditions that need to hold for the speech act to be performed successfully (‘preparatory rules’),\na ‘sincerity’ rule committing the speaker to be sincere in expressing her psychological states, and\nan ‘essential’ rule that describes the central pragmatic impact of the speech act in question. It\nis important to note that these rules (as opposed to, say, rules of grammar) are not about well-\nformedness—this is a notion that does not apply to speech acts. Instead, the key concept is that\nof a speech act to be ‘felicitous’, to successfully serve its purpose. Infelicitous speech act attempts\noccur, for example, when somebody pronounces somebody else to be married but is in no legal\nposition to do so; or when somebody promises an addressee to do him a favor yet does not really\nintend to do so (insincerity).\n\n--- Page 33 ---\n18 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\nComponents of a speech act The ﬁve class labels mentioned above are often said to describe\nthe ‘illocutionary force’ of an utterance. This derives from another important sub-classiﬁcation\nmade by Austin and (in a slightly diﬀerent way) by Searle. The idea is that the performance of\na speech act involves the following three sub-acts that occur (more or less) simultaneously.\n•Locutionaryact: producing the linguistic utterance, by speaking or writing (or gesturing).\n•Illocutionaryact: the intention or goal the speaker has in mind when performing the act.\n•Perlocutionary act: the eﬀect that the performance of the act has on the addressee.\nOne reason to distinguish illocution from perlocution is that an utterance may well have—from\nthe speaker’s perspective—unintended or even undesired eﬀects. A speaker could comment on\nthe addressee’s new hairstyle in a neutral way, and the addressee might derive the literal meaning\n(as intended by the speaker) but in addition surmise a secondary meaning and feel oﬀended (as\nnot intended by the speaker).\nFor argumentation, the perlocution is of obvious relevance, as it characterizes precisely\nthat ‘change of mind’ on the addressee’s side, which is the purpose of the speaker devising their\nargument.Researchon persuasion seekstodetectorevenmeasurethestrengthofsucheﬀects.For\nspeech act theory, however, the perlocution is a private state that is of limited interest; the heart\nof the matter is the perspective of the speaker and thus the illocutionary force of her utterance.\nLinguistic signals Languages provide a variety of means to explicitly signal the presence of\na speech act, or to constrain the class of possible speech acts, so that listeners may reconstruct\nthe speaker’s intention. Above, we mentioned performative verbs (e.g., ask, advise, ...), which in\nfact are the clearest indicators of illocutionary force. In general, however, the surface of an ut-\nterance contains only hints about the underlying illocution, and there is no simple 1:1 mapping.\nThe term ‘illocutionary force indicating device’, or IFID for short, was coined by Searle[1969]\nand is nowadays often used for referring to those hints. A prominent syntactic IFID is sentence\nmode (declarative, interrogative, imperative), which often enables straightforward identiﬁcation\nof a directive or a question.4But of course, both of these illocutions can also be produced with\ndeclarative mode (e.g., “I would like to inquire about the price of that car over there.”), which\ntherefore is quite ambiguous with respect to the speech act. The class of lexical IFIDs contains,\nbesides the performative verbs mentioned above, modal verbs and many diﬀerent kinds of ad-\nverbials from which the illocutionary force can be inferred. On the side of linguistic pragmatics,\nIFIDs for apologies have been studied intensively for many languages (e.g., Ogiermann [2009]).\nSome examples (more or less explicit) for English are as follows.\n(2.22) I apologize for being late.\n(2.23) Sorry I’m late.\n4Many speech act researchers consider (diﬀerent kinds of) questions as another basic speech act type in addition to the list\nofSearle[1976].\n\n--- Page 34 ---\n2.4. ARGUMENTATION, EXPLANATION, AND JUSTIFICATION 19\n(2.24) I’m a bit late, unfortunately.\n(2.25) I’m afraid I didn’t quite make it on time.\nIndirect speech acts The observation that illocutions can be marked more or less explicitly\npoints to another central notion in speech act theory: the ‘indirect’ speech act. The much-cited\nexample “Can you pass the salt?” on the surface is a yes-no question but is interpreted by the\nhearer as a polite form of a directive (or a subcategory ‘request’). The ambiguity also occurs\nvery frequently with declarative sentences that prima facie merely assert some information, yet\nare intended to convey additional illocutionary force. Our Examples 2.22and2.23above are\ndirect (explicit) apologies, with one being more formal than the other, whereas in Examples 2.24\nand2.25it is up to the hearer to read an apology into the utterances—this depends on the\nsituational context, how close the interlocutors are, etc.\nSpeech act theorists have tried to explain how these interpretations actually originate in\ncommunication. The two main approaches emphasize either a process of conventionalization,\nor the role of active inferencing on the hearer’s side; see Saddock [2005].\nArgumentation and complex speech acts In Section 2.1, we described the ideas of Park and\nCardie [2014] on associating statements with diﬀerent ‘veriﬁability’ statuses, and deriving con-\nsequencesfortheirpossiblerolesinanargument.Therealmofspeechactsprovidesanalternative\nperspective on the same goal: when the inventory of illocutionary force labels makes distinctions\nrelevant to argument components, a process of speech act labeling could be a preparatory step\nthat constrains the identiﬁcation of those components. Speciﬁcally, this can help with ﬁnding\nclaims, which can be opinions, speculations, prognoses, etc.—but not factual statements such as\n“I bought a new coﬀee maker yesterday”. For practical purposes, a crucial empirical question is\nto what extent IFIDs can be exploited for recognizing the relevant distinctions.\nBut the connection between speech act theory and argumentation can go a step further.\nWhile the traditional work on speech acts used the (idealized) notion of ‘sentence’ as the unit\nto be labeled, it is not impossible to extend it to pairs or even more complex constellations of\nlinguistic clauses. A systematic study on the possibilities of combining clauses into complex\nspeech acts of ‘concluding’ was presented (in German) by Klein[1987].\n2.4 ARGUMENTATION, EXPLANATION, AND\nJUSTIFICATION\nSeveral times in this chapter we mentioned the problems of ambiguity for identifying the com-\nponents of arguments and the relations between them. In this section, we provide a concrete\nexample, looking at the straightforward English construction “A, because B” (or equivalently:\n“Because B, A”). Of course, this can be the template for an argument, as Example 2.26demon-\nstrates: a is the claim (or standpoint), and B is the supporting statement.\n\n--- Page 35 ---\n20 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\n(2.26) Using airplanes is really a bad idea because they are among the worst air polluters we\nhave ever created. (Argumentation/Persuasion)\n(2.27) An airplane is able to take oﬀ because the shape of the wings produces an upward force\nwhen the air ﬂows across them. (Explanation)\n(2.28) I need to use airplanes a lot because my job requires me to be in diﬀerent parts of the\ncountry every week. (Justiﬁcation)\nExamples 2.27and2.28make use of the same construction, but they have diﬀerent commu-\nnicative eﬀects. Example 2.27is easily used in a context where the listener already believes that\nairplanes can take oﬀ—the speaker thus does not aim to convince the hearer of that fact. Instead,\nthe new information for the hearer is (supposedly) in the second clause. This is the constellation\nof anexplanation , where A is not a claim but an undisputed fact and B does not ‘support’ A\nbut provides the reason why A holds. Example 2.28can be regarded as a special case, where the\nexplanation pertains to a personal decision. Hence, A does not necessarily have the status of an\nundisputed fact; the speaker has to consider that some hearers might not approve. This is the\nsituation of justiﬁcation: giving a reason for an attitude or an action that might be controversial—\nand if it is, then justiﬁcation becomes a special case of argumentation. Various theories of text\nstructure model diﬀerences like those in Examples 2.26–2.28 by using a speciﬁc coherencerelation\nfor each case; we will discuss this below in Section 2.6.2.\nWhile we used one linguistic construction for illustration here, English of course pro-\nvides many more ways to express the three constellations: other connectives are available, such\nastherefore ordue to, and often the sentences can be adjoined without any connective at all. But\nnotice that our three examples do not behave the same way in this respect: replacing the con-\njunction with a full stop in 2.27produces a somewhat odd result, while it is perfectly possible\nfor the other two.\nIn English, the conjunction because is highly versatile and can fulﬁll a wide range of prag-\nmatic functions. Other languages have tendencies to associate diﬀerent preferences with similar\nconnectives. In German, for example, the conjunctions weilanddennfor many speakers appear\nto be interchangeable (save for their syntactic diﬀerences: one is subordinating, one is coordi-\nnating); but research has shown that weiltends to mark objective causal relations (descriptions\nof causes in the world), whereas dennis more often used for subjective relations such as claim—\nsupport [Pasch, 1982]. In Dutch, an even more pronounced eﬀect along these lines has been\nshown for the conjunctions wantandomdatbySanders and Spooren [2009].\n2.5 TEXT TYPES AND DISCOURSE MODES\nIn Section 1.3, we mentioned a variety of genres that are particularly relevant for argumentation\nmining. The idea of the ‘genre’ (a set of texts that fulﬁll a common purpose and have commonal-\n\n--- Page 36 ---\n2.5. TEXT TYPES AND DISCOURSE MODES 21\nities in terms of functional components and/or linguistic conventions)5is generally well-known,\nand the importance of genre for many tasks in language technology is undisputed. In this sec-\ntion, however, we take a look at a lesser known notion, which has been alternatively called ‘text\ntype’ or ‘discourse mode’. It is related to genre, but should not be confused with it.\nTexttype=DiscourseMode In particular, while the genre is a property of a complete text, we\nhere focus on the unit of a stretch of sentences, often, but not necessarily, forming a paragraph.\nHence, the term ‘text type’ (as used, e.g., by Werlich [1975]) is a bit confusing, and we prefer\n‘discourse mode’, which Smith[2003] introduced for pretty much the same idea. It posits that\nthere is only a small set of basic functions that a series of sentences, or text passage, can fulﬁll.\nThese functions are to a good extent determined by the types of ‘discourse entities’ (events, states,\ngeneralizations, abstractions) that are mentioned in the passage, which in turn tend to correlate\nwith certain surface-linguistic features. One main theoretical goal for Smith (and earlier for\nWerlich) therefore was to establish the discourse passage as a unit of analysis for linguistics\nproper (rather than for the shady area of pragmatics). In Smith’s approach, there are ﬁve classes.\n•Narrative: Events and states are introduced, with events being temporally related. The\nsemantic types of events (un-/boundedness) indicate the progression of narrative time.\nTemporal connectives and adverbials are frequent instruments of clause linkage.\n(2.29) The passengers landed in New York in the middle of the night and then moved\non to Hoboken immediately.\n•Description: Passages include states and ongoing or atelic6events. Text progression is\ndriven by spatial rather than by temporal patterns; time is static. Locative phrases often\nappear in topic position.\n(2.30) Hundreds of people occupied the square. In front of them, the speaker was\nstanding on a small podium.\n•Report: Events, states, and sometimes general statives are introduced; they are not related\nrelative to each other (as in narrative). Tensed verbs, modals, and temporal adverbs are\nfrequent.\n(2.31) My sister visited the new exhibition yesterday.\n•Information: Facts, propositions, and generalizing states are introduced, which need not\nbe anchored in time and space. The text progresses through a ‘metaphorical’ space.\n(2.32) Krypton is one of the noble gases. It is one of the rarest elements on earth.\n5A more thorough introduction to the concept of genre and its role in computational linguistics is given in Stede[2011,\nSct. 2.1].\n6Atelicevent is one that comprises both a preparation and a culmination phase, e.g., ‘traveling to London’, ‘climbing the\nmountain’. An atelic event is homogeneous in time: ‘being ill’, ‘reading’.\n\n--- Page 37 ---\n22 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\n•Argument: Like ‘information’, this is an atemporal mode. States of aﬀairs, facts, and\npropositions are introduced and related to each other, often contrastively.\n(2.33) The award was given to Paul, but he did not deserve it. His work is very shallow.\nEven though these correlations between text types and linguistic features are obviously\ntendencies rather than strict rules, they can serve as useful indicators, and Smith’s book (as well\nas the work of Werlich and others) discusses them in much more detail. Also, a computational\napproach to recognizing modes automatically was presented by Song et al. [2017]. Unfortu-\nnately, for our purposes here, the mode ‘argument’ is the most vague in the sense that it is less\ntightly connected to characteristic patterns than the others are. Still, as demonstrated by Becker\net al.[2016], it is possible to operationalize it for the purposes of recognizing argumentation.\nFollowing up on the huge body of linguistic research on aspectual verb classes, the authors focus\non one crucial feature for separating discourse modes, viz. the ‘situation entity (SE) types’. The\nfollowing types are distinguished.\n•State:Armin has brown eyes.\n•Event:Bonnie ate three tacos.\n•Report: The agency said applications had increased.\n•Generic sentence: Scientiﬁc papers make arguments.\n•Generalizing sentence: Fei travels to India every year.\n•Fact:Georg knows that Reza won the competition.\n•Proposition: Georg thinks that Reza won the competition.\n•Resemblance: Reza looks like he won the competition.\n•Question: Why do you torment me so?\n•Imperative: Listen to this.\nBecker et al. [2016] annotated these SE types in the texts of the ‘argumentative microtext’ cor-\npus ofPeldszus and Stede [2016b] and showed that the SE distribution can help distinguishing\nargumentative text passages from non-argumentative ones. Furthermore, Becker et al. demon-\nstrated that the distribution of SE types correlates with the diﬀerent types of argument compo-\nnent (premise/conclusion) and argumentative relations (support, attack).\n\n--- Page 38 ---\n2.6. RHETORIC 23\n2.6 RHETORIC\nAccording to the New Dictionary of the History of Ideas [Carron ,2005, p. 2122], “Rhetoric gov-\nerns the eﬀective use of verbal and nonverbal communication designed to inﬂuence an audience.\n…in its original and historical form, rhetoric is associated with the use of human discourse to\npersuade and can be deﬁned as the art of speaking, of speaking well, or of speaking eﬀectively\nwith the aim of persuading.” This clearly suggests a connection to argumentation, and indeed\nthis relationship was studied intensively by Aristotle, whom we mentioned in the ﬁrst chapter\nas the proponent of the three ‘means of persuasion’, logos, ethos, and pathos. For our purposes\nhere, the question is which aspects of language use can contribute to a text being argumenta-\ntivelyeﬀective, and we look brieﬂy at the two levels of linguistic description where rhetoric can\nunfold its power: the choices in building a sentence, and the organization of the text.\n2.6.1 BUILDING SENTENCES: RHETORICAL CHOICES\nWhen person A wants person B to close the window, there are many possibilities to formulate\nthe request; consider just two of them.\n(2.34) Close the window! It’s cold.\n(2.35) It is rather cold in here and I’m already not feeling so well. Would you be so kind to\nclose the window for me?\nIn both cases, we have a directive speech act and a justiﬁcation, but stated very diﬀerently.\nWhich one is more appropriate, and correspondingly, more eﬀective , of course depends very\nmuch on context: Who is talking to whom under what circumstances. This may seem trivial,\nbut the point is that a similar array of linguistic options for articulating a sentence is essentially\nalways at the writer’s disposal. We can choose rare and diﬃcult words, or common and simple\nones; we can speak or write in a long sequence of short sentences, or in a short sequence of com-\nplex, deeply structured sentences; and so forth. This borders on the notion of stylistics , where\nmany textbooks are available and some are probably known to the reader. More unusual are\napproaches that explicitly make the connection between rhetoric and grammar. Jeanne Fahne-\nstock’s introductory textbook [Fahnestock ,2011] gives vivid examples of how small changes in\nword choice, sentence construction, and passage construction can produce diﬀerent rhetorical\neﬀects. The introduction by Kolln[2003], centered around the notion of choice, also points to\nthe diﬀerent rhetorical eﬀects of each choice, and explains the alternatives by referring to gram-\nmatical concepts (rather than to intuition). To mention just one example, the author looks at\nthe correlation between lexical and grammatical decisions and the resulting intonation pattern\norrhythm of a sentence, which inﬂuences the perception by the hearer and the reader alike, and\ncan contribute to rhetorical eﬀects—or not, if bad choices have been made.\nRhetorical ﬁgures One phenomenon that is sometimes mentioned in connection with ar-\ngumentation is that of ﬁgures of speech, also called rhetorical ﬁgures, which have been studied\n\n--- Page 39 ---\n24 2. ARGUMENTATIVE LANGUAGE\nextensively in classical rhetoric. This, too, is a vast area, and we can only scratch the surface here.\nTwo such examples are as follows.\n•Hyperbole: Phew, the distance from Newark to Manhattan is a hundred miles!\nThe statement is literally false, but the exaggeration is consciously used (and probably\nunderstood) to emphasize the speaker’s point.\n•Tautology: That nice restaurant was really great.\nThe two predications on the restaurant are barely distinguishable; yet the repetition can\ncontribute to overall eﬀect.\nIn connection to argumentation, we point to the research eﬀorts of Harris and Di Marco [2017],\nwho have extensively analyzed rhetorical ﬁgures and studied many of them as devices for pro-\nducing eﬀective arguments. Following up on their work, Lawrence et al. [2017b] tried to detect\nthe presence of rhetorical ﬁgures in text automatically. They used the Moral Maze radio debate\ncorpus (see Section 3.6) for their experiments. For actually computing correlations with argu-\nmentative moves, the number of instances of rhetorical ﬁgures found was too small, however.\nMost recently, with an eye toward automation, Harris et al. [2018] proposed a new annotation\nscheme for Rhetorical Figures, using standoﬀ XML. They suggest focusing on computationally\ntractable ﬁgures such as antimetabole (reverse repetition of at least two words), which they map\nto several diﬀerent rhetorical functions.\n2.6.2 TEXT ORGANIZATION: RHETORICAL EFFECTS\nAs with sentences, the structure of a text is not arbitrary, either. There are many factors inﬂuenc-\ning the choices of how to order sentences and link them together, with an important one being\nthe genre of the text, which often suggests conventional linearizations. But usually, an author\nhas considerable room left for making choices, which in turn can contribute to rhetorical eﬀect.\nWe look at two alternative ways of capturing this: a ﬂat segmentation and labeling of a sequence\nof text spans, and the postulation of a hierarchical text structure.\nFunctional labels on text spans The idea that a text can be analyzed as a sequence of genre-\nspeciﬁc ‘moves’ goes back to Swales [1990], who suggested that a number of adjacent sentences\nconstitute such a move, and that the text then be a contiguous sequence of moves. Among the\ngenres studied was scientiﬁc writing, which (depending on the type of science) usually follows\nconventionalized patterns of ‘when to say what’ in a research paper (or in a grant proposal, a\nbook, etc.). A computational implementation was later proposed by Teufel and Moens [2002],\nwho coined the term ‘argumentative zoning’ for this approach. Teufel and colleagues annotated\npassagesofscientiﬁcpapersfortherolestheyplayasapartofthepaper’soverallcontribution,and\nhence,zonelabelsinclude‘aim’(researchgoal),‘own’(descriptionofauthor’swork),‘background’\n(generally accepted scientiﬁc background), ‘conclusion’, and several others. Having shown that\nsubstantial human annotator agreement can be achieved, the authors then trained automatic\n\n--- Page 40 ---\n2.6. RHETORIC 25\nclassiﬁers and demonstrated that the recognition of zone labels can be automated with quite\nimpressive quality.\nIn a similar vein, Yamada et al. [2017] studied legal arguments in Japanese court judg-\nments, and ran a human agreement study on labeling units as ‘identifying’ (setting a topic), ‘fact’,\n‘background’, ‘conclusion’, and ‘framing’ (argumentative material in support of the conclusion\nunit), and they obtained good annotator agreement (\u0014 =0.7).\nHierarchicaltextstructure Acomplementaryperspectiveontextstructuresuggeststhatatext\ncan be seen as a hierarchy of text spans that are (recursively) connected via so-called coherence\nrelations . These relations state that a span can, for example, be followed by another one that\nelaborates on the former, as in this example, where the spans are marked with square brackets.\n(2.36) Elaboration: [The new Smart Watch was introduced today.] [It costs $50 more than\nthe old model.]\nRecursion arises when these two segments in turn enter into a coherence relation, for example\nMotivation , which links a recommendation for the reader to the reason:\n(2.37) Motivation: [ [The new Smart Watch was introduced today.] [It costs $50 more than\nthe old model.] ] [You should really buy it.]\nA widely used corpus annotated with such coherence relations is the Penn Discourse Treebank\nor PDTB [ Prasad et al. ,2008]. Annotators inspected all the ‘boundaries’ in a text (roughly,\nclause and sentence boundaries) and decided whether some relation can be discerned between\nthe adjacent spans. The accompanying computational task of recognizing those relations is called\nShallow Discourse Parsing (for an introduction to the problem, see Stede[2011, Sct. 4.3]).\nIn the PDTB, the relations are being annotated independently of one another. Accord-\ningly, there are no assumptions on any overall structure that may arise. In contrast, Rhetorical\nStructure Theory or RST [ Mann and Thompson ,1988] postulates that a well-formed tree struc-\nture can be built, which spans the text completely.7The authors postulate that some 25 diﬀerent\ncoherence relations are suﬃcient for analyzing most texts. A sample RST tree (for an excerpt\nof a text) is shown in Figure 2.1. The best-known English RST corpus is the RST Discourse\nTreebank or RST-DT [ Carlson et al., 2003], and it has led to numerous proposals of auto-\nmatic parsers that try to build the tree structures automatically. Stede[2011, Sct. 4.4] gives an\noverview.\nEvidently, the analysis of argumentation is not entirely diﬀerent from the analyses in the\nPDTB and in the RST-DT. For RST, in particular, parallels between the tree structures and\nsimilar analyses of argumentation structure (recall the example shown in Figure 1.1) are easy\nto notice. However, there is no consensus yet as to how the relationship is to be construed ex-\nactly. A summary of the discussion was provided by Peldszus and Stede [2013], and later on,\n7RST is a theory of linguistic pragmatics; notice that for rhetoricians, the use of ‘rhetorical’ in the name of RST is not\nuncontroversial, as there is certainly more to text-level rhetoric than what is captured by RST.\n\n--- Page 41 ---\n26 2.
