Models describe the components of an argument, such as the\n‘standpoint’ in our deﬁnition from Section 1.1.1. Models diﬀer in how many components they\ndistinguish, and how they connect these components. Various names are used; we will generally\nrefer to the standpoint as aclaim. There is no single best model: Approaches to argumentation\ndepend on the type of text and the task. Argumentation theory itself is interdisciplinary, and\nargumentation mining has been inﬂuenced by rhetoric, informal logic, and formal logic.\nIn the following, we ﬁrst discuss argument components and structure (Section 3.1) and\nthen take a look at the way in which argumentation extends classical inference with defeasible\nreasoning (Section 3.2). Next we introduce the notion of argumentationscheme (Section 3.3) and\ntake a look at important types of argument models (Section 3.4). The chapter closes with a short\ndiscussion of early artiﬁcial intelligence approaches to representing arguments (Section 3.5), and\nan overview of argument mapping (Section 3.6) techniques.\n3.1 ARGUMENT COMPONENTS AND STRUCTURE\nMain components of arguments Earlier we said that that an argument consists of claims\nmadebythespeaker,alongwithmaterialtheypresentinsupportoftheirclaim,aswellaspossible\ncounter-considerations,andtheirrefutations.Wecanfurtherdeﬁnecertainterminologyusedfor\nargumentation structures. An argument structure is comprised of a constellation of propositions\nrelated to a claim(also called standpoint orconclusion), which is the proposition that the argument\nseeks to establish. Other propositions are used as premises , which are brought to bear, in support\nof the conclusion, and sometimes also to attackit. Any claim may play the role of ﬁnal conclusion\nof some argument, and any conclusion can be made into a premise supporting further reasoning.\nDiagramming arguments Diagramming can represent an argument’s structure. We saw one\nargument map in Figure 1.1on page 7. We will give further examples of argument maps in\nSection 3.6below.\nTypically, an argument map represents propositions with some geometric shape such as\ncircles and rectangles. Often there is no visual distinction between the proposition’s role in the\nargument, whether it serves as a top-level claim and ﬁnal conclusion or an intermediate one.\nText representing the proposition may appear directly in the diagram (as we will see in Fig-\nure3.7below) or may be referenced to a key (for instance Figure 1.1refers back to the text\n\n--- Page 43 ---\n28 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\nin Example 1.6). Support and attack relationships between the propositions are distinguished\n(with diﬀerent line types, as in Figure 1.1, or using colors, as in Figure 3.7); sometimes only\nsupport or attack relationships are given.\nLinked, convergent, serial, divergent The structure of arguments, including the relation of\nargument components to one another can also be considered, as shown in Figure 3.1. Vari-\nous proposals have been made. The essential distinction is whether there are multiple distinct\npremises that each stand alone to support a claim (convergent), whether two reasons together\nstrengthen each other (linked), or whether a chain of reasoning is required where one premise\nsupports an interim conclusion, which is the premise of the next argument (e.g., if p, then q,\nif q then r; serial), or one premise that supports two or more conclusions (divergent). Some\ngraphsandexamplesareshowncompactlyin WeiandPrakken [2012].Also, Henkemans [2000]\nsurveys historical approaches and enduring philosophical questions about distinguishing these\nstructure types. Subtleties do arise; for instance, Grennan [1997, pp. 71-72], “[S]ome arguments\ncontain assertions that have a bearing on conclusion support but are not direct evidence for the\nconclusion.” This is an issue of relevance of conclusions, related to the knowledge of the hearer.\nA\nBA A A\nBA B B\nC C\nCC B\n(iv)\nSerial(i)\nSingle(ii)\nLinked(iii)\nConvergent(v)\nDivergent\nFigure 3.1: Common basic argument structures based on Rahwan [2008].\nGranularity Arguments are recursive, zippered structures. The conclusion of one argument\nmay be the premise of the next argument, building a more complex tree. Wyner et al. distin-\nguish between three diﬀerent kinds of argument based on the features of this tree: an Argument\n(capital A) that cannot be subdivided into any other parts that are still arguments (“a one-step\nreason for a claim”); a Case, with only supporting evidence for a claim (“a chain of reasoning\nleading toward a claim”); and a Debate which has both supporting and conﬂicting evidence\n(“reasons for and against a claim (Debate)”) [Wyner et al. ,2015, p. 51].\nWhen we want to think about the internal structure of the argument, this distinction is\nhelpful. The internal structure of an Argument of this sort is just made up of the components we\n\n--- Page 44 ---\n3.2. ARGUMENTATION EXTENDS CLASSICAL INFERENCE 29\ndiscussed above. By contrast, a Case must have multiple inference steps, but without any attacks\non the central claim. And the Debate can be broken into two Cases: one for the claim and one\nagainst it.\n3.2 ARGUMENTATION EXTENDS CLASSICAL\nINFERENCE WITH DEFEASIBLE REASONING\nArgumentation extends classical inference, enabling tentative conclusions. By contrast, in clas-\nsical logic, the conclusion is guaranteed to hold whenever the premises hold, using classical in-\nference rules.\nDefeasibility Argumentation is defeasible: it considers tentative conclusions, which can be\nrevised when new information comes to light. That is, argumentation admits belief revision, is\ndefeasible , and follows a non-monotonic logic. See Koons [2017] for more on defeasible reasoning.\nClassical inference rules In classical logic, however, the conclusion is guaranteed to hold\nwhenever the premises hold, using classicalinferencerules, such as syllogism, modus ponens, and\nmodus tollens.\nAsyllogism derives a conclusion via inference from two premises which share a related\nterm. For example:\n(3.1) Socrates is a man; ( Minor premise )\nEvery man is mortal; ( Major premise )\nTherefore, Socrates is mortal. (Conclusion)\nA syllogism’s premises are called minor and major. This distinction is based on which term they\ncontain; the minor term is identiﬁed by the subject (‘Socrates’) of the conclusion while the major\nterm is identiﬁed by the predicate (‘mortal’) of the conclusion.\nThe rule modusponens enables deriving the consequent,or right-hand side of a conditional:\n(3.2) Given if p, then q.\nGiven p.\nTherefore, q.\nThe rule modus tollens enables ruling out the antecedent, or left-hand side of a conditional:\n(3.3) Given if p, then q.\nGiven not q.\nTherefore, not p.\nSeePrior[2006] for further examples. Argumentation theory has collected its own\nschemes, which can be considered as defeasible rules of inference. We discuss those next.\n\n--- Page 45 ---\n30 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\n3.3 ARGUMENTATION SCHEMES\nArgumentation schemes are patterns of everyday reasoning made up of propositions, a defeasible\ninference rule with the propositions as premises, and a conclusion (a proposition) inferred from\nthe rule using the propositions.\nAn argumentation scheme expresses a defeasible inference rule for showing the accept-\nability of a standpoint. Various treatments of argumentation schemes, highlighting diﬀerent\naspects, have been given, with wide variation in the number of schemes. A recent and authori-\ntative overview of inﬂuential approaches can be found in Walton et al. [2018].\nWalton’s argumentation schemes Walton, Reed, and Macagno’s Compendium of Schemes\ncollects 60 schemes, along with critical questions that identify the potential points of weakness\nin an argument [Walton et al. ,2008]. One such scheme is Position to Know.\nMajor Premise: Source ais in a position to know about things in a certain subject domain\nScontaining proposition A.\nMinor Premise :aasserts that A(in Domain S) is true (false).\nConclusion: Ais true (false).\nThey list three critical questions.\n1. Is ain a position to know whether Ais true (false)?\n2. Is aan honest (trustworthy, reliable) source?\n3. Did aassert that Ais true (false)?\nNote here that the structure of diﬀerent premises may need to be distinguished, e.g., the mi-\nnor premise “serves as independent evidence or support for the conclusion” whereas the major\npremise does not [Grennan, 1997, p. 75].\nPragma-dialectic argumentation schemes The classical pragma-dialectic approach classiﬁes\nschemes into three types: sign, comparison, and cause [Hitchcock and Wagemans, 2011]. As\na prototypical example, the “argument from comparison” scheme compares two situations and\nuses their similarity as a justiﬁcation. Analyzing “It’s not at all necessary to give James 10 dollars\nallowance, because his brother always got just 5 dollars a week.” Hitchcock and Wagemans\n[2011, p. 187] write:\n1James (X) does not need 10 dollars a week (Y).\n1:1James’ brother (Z) did not need 10 dollars a week (Y).\n1:10James (X) is similar to James’ brother with respect to the sum needed for their weekly\n\n--- Page 46 ---\n3.4. TYPES OF ARGUMENT MODELS 31\nallowance\nalong with three critical questions for the comparison scheme:\n1. Are the things that are compared actually comparable?\n2. Are there enough relevant similarities between the things that are compared?\n3. Are there any relevant diﬀerences between the things that are compared?\nTheothertwomainpragma-dialecticschemes,signandcause,havesimilarconsiderations;\nvariants and subtypes of each of the three types are recognized.\nArgumentum model of topics Rigotti and Morasso’s Argumentum Model of Topics\n(AMT) [Rigotti and Greco Morasso, 2010] draws on the study of topoiandloci, from ancient\nand medieval rhetoric. (See also Rapp[2010, Section 7].) The name of a scheme, such as cause-\neﬀect or analogy, is only the ﬁrst level: the procedural starting point. At the second level, certain\ninference patterns that Rigotti and Morasso call ‘maxims’ are needed. In the third level, each of\nthese maxims activates a rule, such as modus ponens or modus tollens. An example maxim is\nthe following [Rigotti and Greco Morasso ,2010, p. 495].\n1. If a certain goal is to be achieved, it is reasonable to activate a cause chain allowing to reach\nit.\n2. If no causal chain is available, the goal cannot be achieved.\n3. If a certain behavior is not oriented toward a goal (as it cannot be considered a proper\nhuman action), it cannot be endowed with any property typically congruous with human\naction (responsibility, merit, guilt, and so on).\nSemantic analysis is used to ﬁll the gap between the scheme type and the maxim. For\ninstance, in the AMT analysis shown in Figure 3.2, an assumption in the audience’s common\nground (‘endoxon’, following Aristotle) is made explicit, namely that the national holiday and\nNew Year’s Eve are comparable (“belong to the same functional genus”). Their approach is more\nﬁne-grainedthanothers,sinceaparticularmaximmustbespeciﬁedanditsapplicabilityjustiﬁed.\n3.4 TYPES OF ARGUMENT MODELS\nBentahar, Moulin, and Bélanger classify argumentation models into rhetorical models, dialogi-\ncal models, and monological models [ Bentahar et al., 2010]. These types of models are comple-\nmentary, each coming from diﬀerent perspectives, as shown in Table 3.1. Monological models\nview arguments as tentative proofs, and link premises and claims to describe the microstructure:\nthe internal inference structure of each argument. Rhetorical models view arguments based on\nan audience’s perception, and link whole arguments in a rhetorical structure emphasizing the\n\n--- Page 47 ---\n32 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\nEndoxon\n/T_he national holiday and Ne w Year’s Eve\nbelong to the same functional genus of “big\ncelebrations,” in which people allow themselves\nto take a day oﬀ and go on a trip somewhere.\nMinor Premise (Datum)\n/T_here were traﬃc jams on\nNew Year’s Eve.\nFinal Conclusion\n/T_here may be traﬃc jams\ntonight (on the national\nholiday).First Conclusion Minor Premise\n/T_he fact that there were traﬃc jams holds for a\ncircumstance that belongs to the same functional\ngenus as the national holiday.MaximLocus From Analogy\nIf something was the case for a\ncircumstance of the same\nfunctional genus as X, this may\nbe the case for X.\nFigure 3.2: An example argument using the Argumentum Model of Topics based on Rigotti\nand Greco Morasso [2010, p. 499].\npersuasion structure of arguments. Finally, dialogical models view arguments through the lens\nof defeasible reasoning and link whole arguments in a macrostructure: the dialogical structure.\nNext, we will cover some prototypical models exemplifying the monological, rhetorical,\nand dialogical perspectives.\n\n--- Page 48 ---\n3.4. We also discuss the IBIS model, which does not ﬁt neatly into these three\ntypes.\nToulmin model One of the most inﬂuential models of argumentation, the Toulmin model,\nwas ﬁrst proposed by British philosopher Stephen Toulmin in 1958. This model takes a mono-\nlogicalviewofargumentation,focusingontheinternalstructureofanargument,whichisviewed\nas a tentative proof. The Toulmin model has a detailed internal structure, as shown in Figure 3.3.\nIn the model, a claim is defeasibly supported by its grounds (also called the data), according to\nsome warrant. If necessary, the warrant may be further supported by a backing. Qualiﬁers or\nrebuttals can also be diagrammed, but are not required.\nIn Figure 3.3, the claim is “Anne now has red hair”. Its grounds is “Anne is one of Jack’s\nsisters”. Its warrant is “any sister of Jack’s may be taken to have red hair”, which has the backing,\n“All his sisters have previously been observed to have red hair.” Its qualiﬁer is “presumably”. Its\nrebuttal is “unless Anne has dyed/ gone white/ lost her hair...”.\nArgument mapping and education have been among the areas inﬂuenced by the Toul-\nmin model. Furthermore, it has been taken up in Computational Linguistics and—with\nmodiﬁcations—used for annotating texts by Habernal and Gurevych [2017]; we will introduce\nthat work in the next chapters.\nThe New Rhetoric Perelman and Olbrechts-Tyteca’s 1969 book The New Rhetoric: A Treatise\nonArgumentation has been very inﬂuential. It takes persuasion and audience as central concerns:\n\n--- Page 49 ---\n34 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\nAnne is one of\nJack’s sistersAnne now has\nred hair\nSince\nAny sister of Jack’s\nmay be taken to have\nred hair\nOn account of the fact that\nAll his sisters have\npreviously been observed to have red hairUnless\nAnne has dyed/gone\nwhite/lost her hair…So, presumably } {\nFigure 3.3: Sample Toulmin diagram based on Toulmin [2008].\nargumentation, in their view, cannot be reduced to formal defeasible logic. Rather, arguments\nseek to persuade a given audience, or to convince the universal audience. Argumentation is thus\na persuasive act involving two or more interlocutors, and it is “relative to the audience to be\ninﬂuenced” [Perelman and Olbrechts-Tyteca, 1969, p. 19]. From this perspective, “The goal of\nall argumentation...is to create or increase the adherence of minds to the theses presented for\ntheir assent.” [Perelman and Olbrechts-Tyteca, 1969, p. 45]. We can describe this as a rhetorical\napproach to argumentation.\nDung’sargumentationframeworks Dung’s inﬂuential 1995 paper [ Dung, 1995] models the\nattack structure between arguments. Dung is not concerned with the internal structure of the\nargument or with support relationships: this is a macroscopic, dialogical view of argumentation\nin which constellations of arguments are evaluated based on defeasible reasoning.\nAn argumentation framework is a directed graph whose nodes represent arguments and\nwhose edges represent relationships between arguments. More formally, Dung deﬁnes an ar-\ngument framework as a pair hS;attacksi where Sis a set of arguments and attacks is a binary\nrelationship on the arguments contained in S\u0002S.\nAll arguments are considered to have the same strength and each attack is considered to\nbe successful, unless it is in turn attacked. For instance, in Figure 3.4,Aattacks BandBattacks\nC. In this situation, it is not coherent to accept both Band either its attacker (A) or what it\nattacks ( B). More formally, acceptability involves means ﬁnding a subset which is conﬂict-free\nand collectively defends itself. A set Sdefends an argument aif for any argument bthat attacks\na,Scontains an argument that attacks b. An argument aisacceptable with respect to the set\nthat defends it.\n\n--- Page 50 ---\n3.5. EARLY ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE APPROACHES 35\nA B C\nFigure 3.4: In this sample Dungian argumentation framework, A attacks B and B attacks C.\nThe acceptable sets are: ;;fAg;fBg;fCg;fA; Cg.\nSolvers for Dungian argumentation frameworks can compute the subsets (extensions ) sat-\nisfying some property. In general, semantics (e.g., credulous ,skeptical ) are used to determine\nwhich coherent sets of arguments are jointly acceptable .\nA number of formal argumentation approaches are modiﬁed from Dung’s framework.\nModiﬁcations may involve using probabilities or values to evaluate argument strength, or ad-\nditional node types, or additional edge types. Several of these are being used to evaluate the\nacceptability of manually and automatically mined arguments, including bipolar argumentation\nframeworks , which allow support as well as attack; abstract dialectical frameworks , where each\nnode gets its own acceptance condition; and the aforementioned Quantitative Argumentation\nDebate (QuAD) framework. These will be discussed when we present examples applying solvers\nin Section 8.3.1.\nIBIS model Not all models ﬁt neatly into Bentahar’s taxonomy. For instance, the IBIS\nmodel—Issue-Based Information Systems—was proposed in 1970 as a coordination and doc-\numentation system for political decision-making such as in urban planning [ Kunz and Rittel ,\n1970]. It is a process for turning an unstructured problem (a controversial topic in a particular\ncontext) into a decision. Parts of the controversial topic are framed as issues—questions that can\nbe debated with arguments either pro or con. Questionsoffact can reference external information.\nIBIShasinspirednumeroussystems,includingarecentcomputationalargumentationfor-\nmalism called the Quantitative Argumentation Debate (QuAD) framework [Baroni et al., 2015]\nwhich connects issues with questions, answers, pros, and cons. QuAD frameworks can be evalu-\nated with the Arg&Dec tool1[Aurisicchio et al. ,2015], which we will return to in Section 8.3.1.\n3.5 EARLY ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE APPROACHES\nTO REPRESENTING ARGUMENTS\nWe now discuss two examples of classical artiﬁcial intelligence approaches to representing ar-\nguments from the 1980’s and 1990’s.\nRobin Cohen One of the earliest approaches to argumentation and natural language was\nRobin Cohen’s 1983 dissertation [Cohen, 1983], which focuses on understanding argumen-\n1http://www.arganddec.com (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 51 ---\n36 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\ntative monologues by reconstructing their structure, as claim and evidence relations between\npropositions supporting a single main point. Cohen relies on discourse coherence and proposes\ncue words and metadiscourse used in arguing. The system focuses on “everyday arguments” [ Co-\nhen,1983, p. 12], leaving aside quality and credibility judgments of logical validity.\nViewing an argument as a tree in which each claim is the parent of its evidence, Cohen\n[1987] presents a design for an argument understanding system. To determine where a propo-\nsition ﬁts, Cohen uses three main considerations: coherence, cue words, and intended support\nrelationships (that the hearer might not believe) in order to restrict the search space. Examples\nof Cohen’s cue words (“linguistic clues”) are shown in Figure 3.5.\nP is prior proposition; S is the proposition with the clue\nCategory Relation: P to S Example\nparallel  brother   First, Second\ninference son   As a result\ndetail  father   In particular\nsummary multiple sons  In sum\nreformulation son (& father)  In other words\ncontrast brother or father On the other hand\nFigure 3.5: Cohen’s semantic classes for clue interpretation based on Cohen [1987].\nArgument units OpEd—an early question-answering system—used what were called ‘Argu-\nment Units’ such as the one shown in Figure 3.6. These “represent patterns of support and attack\nrelationships among beliefs” [ Alvarado ,1990, p. 9]. The clearest treatment is found in Chap-\nter 4 of Alvarado [1990]. “AUs encode language-free and domain-free knowledge which can be\ninstantiated to argue about plans in any domain” (p. 119).\n3.6 ARGUMENT MAPPING\nArgument maps are diagrams used to help make sense of complex arguments. An argument\nmap separates arguments into the various components. Such maps have been manually con-\nstructed for 150 years, particularly in philosophy, and came into legal argumentation in the early\n20th century [Walton, 2005]. Argument maps can show the big picture—which is sometimes\nquite big, such as Robert Horns’ large-scale map of the artiﬁcial intelligence debate. Titled “Can\nComputers Think?”, and exploring 50 years of philosophical argument, the map spreads over 7\nposter-size pages and covers over 800 arguments presented by more than 300 people2[Horn,\n2003].\n2http://debategraph.org/Details.aspx?nid=75 (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 52 ---\n3.6. The inset in Figure 3.7shows part\nof the “ethics of risk” subargument.\n3.6.1 APPLICATIONS OF ARGUMENT MAPPING\nArgument maps have been used in a variety of applications. Dialogue mapping is an approach to\ngroup deliberation that iteratively develops argument maps during a meeting [ Conklin, 2006].\nTim Van Gelder reports that argument maps both encode knowledge and make it “readily re-\ncoverable for anyone in the future” [ Van Gelder ,2003, p. 114]. These maps make the arguments\nand their counterarguments visible all at once, which can help with decision-making and can\nhelp retain and revisit the rationale for a previously taken decision. Such maps also make it pos-\nsible to see more of an argument than the average person can hold in their head at one time,\nmaking it possible to think more critically and with more detachment from a particular way of\nexpressing a claim or rationale or a particular speaker who put it forward [Van Gelder, 2003]. In\nparticular, with external maps “it is safer to make a case against an idea because it isn’t an attack\non the person who suggested it” [Conklin, 2006, p. 175].\nStructured arguments are used to construct safety cases or assurance cases for critical in-\ndustries such as nuclear plants, airplanes, trains, automobiles, and medical devices; for examples,\nseeRinehart et al. [2015, pp. 23-62]. Several diﬀerent argument mapping structures are used\n[Rinehart et al., 2015], including the Goal Structuring Notation [ Spriggs, 2012] (speciﬁed in a\n2011standard[Attwoodetal., 2011]),theClaims-Argument-Evidencegraphicalformat,which\nlinks evidence to claims based on some sort of inference structure, which CAE refers to as the\n‘argument’, or sometimes ‘argument approach’ [Bishop and Bloomﬁeld, 1998].4\nRecently, live radio debates have been mapped in real-time by a team at the University\nof Dundee. On the British Broadcasting Corporation radio program Moral Maze, panelists\ndebate ethical issues related to a recent news story. Using a touch screen they call the Argument\nAnalysisWall [ Bex et al. ,2013], a team of argumentation analysts have collaborated to map radio\ndebates as shown in Figure 3.8. The process starts with real-time transcripts, which are chunked\ninto components by segmentation analysts, and then a team of 8 analysts have connected these\ncomponents into supporting and conﬂicting arguments [Bex et al., 2013].5\nArgument maps were used to express stakeholders’ opinions, based on interviews and\nsurveys in the EcoBioCap project [ Tamani et al., 2014]. A map of the relationship between\n11 arguments around food packaging was developed using data from interviews and surveys of\nstakeholders. Besides conﬂicts and attacks, the system considers preferences, which it resolves\n4https://www.adelard.com/asce/choosing-asce/cae.html (accessed May 28, 2018).\n5For a video of the process, see https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8iELLjHAjEc (accessed May 28, 2018). Annotated\nMoral Maze data is available from http://corpora.aifdb.org/index.php (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 55 ---\n40 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\nFigure 3.8: Analysts mapping a BBC radio debate in real time on the AnalysisWall at the Center\nforArgumentTechnology,Dundee,Scotland.Photofrom http://www.arg-tech.org/index\n.php/projects/argument-analysis-wall/ (accessed May 28, 2018); online representation\nof the ultimate argument map is available at http://aifdb.org/argview/789 (accessed May\n28, 2018), used with permission.\ninto ‘justiﬁed preferences’ using computational reasoning with Argumentation Service Platform\nwith Integrated Components (ASPIC) and DLR-Lite. We will return to computational rea-\nsoning systems in Section 8.3.1.\nArgument maps also have a potential use in medical decision-making. Typically, argu-\nment maps have been made from text. Data tables that have come from text can also be seen as\na starting point. Hunter and Williams have modeled medical evidence from published clinical\nguidelines for treatments for 3 conditions—glaucoma, hypertension, and hypertension during\npregnancy [ Hunter and Williams ,2012]. They use argument maps to connect pairs of possi-\n\n--- Page 56 ---\n3.6. ARGUMENT MAPPING 41\nble treatment options: arrows in the graph go from the preferred treatment to the disprefered\ntreatment, functioning as attack relations. They deﬁne a formal semantics over the graph and\ncalculate overall preferred treatments (a ‘superiority graph’) given up to 25 treatment pairs. A\ntutorial [Hunter and Williams, 2015] further explains their approach. Noor et al. [2017] take\nan analogous approach for reasoning about side eﬀects and experiences, using argument graphs\ndeveloped from patients’ reviews on medical forums.\n3.6.2 ARGUMENT MAPPING TOOLS\nNumerous tools for argument mapping are available. While even explicitly mapping an argu-\nment on paper can enable a clearer understanding of a topic, many computational tools oﬀer\nadditional computational support such as calculating the consistent results as we will discuss in\nSection 8.3.1.\nNext, we brieﬂy review seven representative argument mapping tools; this is just a small\nselection of a diverse and crowded ﬁeld of tools. For more comprehensive reviews of tools,\nseeScheuer et al. [2010], which covers computer-supported learning, and Schneider et al.\n[2013a] which focuses on web-based tools.\n• AGORA-net6[Hoﬀmann, 2011] is free, collaborative web-based argument visualization\nsoftware that aims to help people recognize good reasoning. The system provides four\nargument schemes: modus ponens, modus tollens, disjunctive syllogism, and not-all syl-\nlogism. Sample maps can be viewed online with Adobe Flash. Its creator characterizes\nthe underlying method as “requir[ing] logical validity as a normative standard for the con-\nstruction of arguments” [Hoﬀmann, 2011, p. 151]. Curriculum development has been a\nfocus of the project; for instance AGORA-net has been used to teach engineering ethics\nin Russian Universities and the software is available in ﬁve common world languages.\n• The Adelard Safety Case Editor (ASCE)7[Emmet and Cleland ,2002] is primarily used\nin safety assurance, and can use the common formats of Goal Structuring Notation and\nClaims-Argument-Evidence.\n• Argunet8[Schneider et al., 2007] is an open source (GNU General Public License v2)\ncross-platform editor that can be used as standalone system or with a shared server. In\nArgunet, sentences are the basic elements, which are connected together into arguments.\nSupport and conﬂict relationships are visually distinguished, and the user can add descrip-\ntions for any inference patterns they wish. Individual arguments appear in argument maps\nwhich may be part of larger debates. The debating system can be used by multiple users\nand maps made in Argunet can be displayed online with a JavaScript widget.\n6http://agora.gatech.edu (accessed May 28, 2018).\n7https://www.adelard.com/asce/choosing-asce/index/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n8http://www.argunet.org/editor/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 57 ---\n42 3. MODELING ARGUMENTS\n• Compendium9[Shum et al. ,2006] is a widely adopted tool designed for dialogue map-\nping. It follows Issue-Based Information Systems [Kunz and Rittel ,1970] in distinguish-\ning issues and position nodes, and adds additional types such as questions, references, and\nnotes to create a rich hypertext network. Its online sibling Cohere10[Buckingham Shum,\n2008] focuses on marking connections between pairs of ideas, which can then be visual-\nized in a larger graph. Cohere has a rich selection of connections, including both negative\n(‘challenges’, ‘is inconsistent with’, ‘refutes’) and positive (‘causes’, ‘improves on’, ‘is a value\nof’, ‘is an example of’, ‘is analogous to’, ‘is consistent with’, ‘predicts’, and ‘proves’), and can\nfunction as a bookmarking tool using the Cohere Firefox plugin. Both use the lesser GNU\npublic license.\n• DebateGraph11is an online mapping tool that has been used by media organizations to\nhelp users browse complex ideas, integrated with rich media. Maps can be viewed graph-\nically or in outline format. Its main types are issues, positions, supportive arguments, and\nopposing arguments.\n• Online Visualization of Argument (OVA)12[Snaith et al. ,2010] facilitates analysis of web\npages. Various semantics can be automatically applied to compute winning/losing argu-\nments. It has been adapted into OVA+ [Janier et al. ,2014] to provide particular support\nfor a dialogue-based argument annotation system called Inference Anchoring Theory (see\nSection 4.1, page 50).\n• Rationale13[Van Gelder, 2007] and its cousin bCisive14are commercial argument map-\nping tools created by the Australian Austhink company and overseen by the Dutch parent\ncompany Critical Thinking Skills BV. Rationale is an online system focused on teaching\ncritical thinking as well as essay writing while bCisive is designed for business decision\nmaking. Maps can be public or private. Diﬀerent types of argument maps are supported;\nfor instance, in writing-oriented maps concepts might connected with words such as but,\nhowever, and because.\n3.6.3 FORMALIZING, SHARING, AND QUERYING ARGUMENT MAPS\nWith so many diﬀerent argument mapping tools, approaches for sharing argument maps are\nneeded. The best known format for sharing between computer tools is called the Argument In-\nterchange Format (AIF). AIF is intended as a XML representation of key argumentation com-\nponents. It is extensible, and has been used for formalizing, storing and sharing, and querying\nargument maps.\n9https://github.com/CompendiumNG/CompendiumNG (accessed May 28, 2018).\n10http://cohere.open.ac.uk/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n11http://debategraph.org/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n12http://ova.arg-tech.org (accessed May 28, 2018).\n13https://www.rationaleonline.com (accessed May 28, 2018).\n14https://www.bcisiveonline.com (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 58 ---\n3.6. ARGUMENT MAPPING 43\nFormalizing argument maps for interchange Argument Interchange Format is a formal\nmodel—an ontology—introduced by an international group in 2006 [ Chesñevar et al. ,2006]\nto model the argument networks, communication locutions, and protocols for interchange be-\ntween two participants or two software packages, and contexts such as agents and theories. AIF\nhas provided a technological foundation for various experimental systems for supporting argu-\nmentation on the Web, such as ArgDF [Zablith ,2007] and argument blogging [ Wells et al.,\n2009], as well as an interchange format for some of the argumentation mapping tools described\nabove.\nAIF core ontology includes information nodes (I-nodes) and scheme application nodes\n(S-nodes). Multiple extensions have been made to the original, core ontology. For instance, in\n2007,Rahwan et al. [2007] added Form Nodes, which enables argumentation schemes (see Sec-\ntion3.3) to be directly modeled within the graph. The AIF+ extension distinguishes between\nlocutions and their propositional content, catering for dialogue and dialogue games [Reed et al.,\n2008b], and has been extensively used by the work of the Dundee group. Another recent ex-\ntension, targeting social web discussions, adds Personal, Faction, Audience, Personal Support,\nPersonal Conﬂict, and Implication nodes [Blount et al. ,2016].\nStoring and sharing AIFdb provides a database implementation of AIF [Lawrence et al. ,\n2012]. In practice, AIFdb is not just a database for storing but also a web interface providing\nworldwide-shared access to AIF-formatted data. Currently, a number of corpora, including the\nAraucaria database [ Katzav et al. ,2003] used for early argumentation mining work, have been\ntranslated into AIF and published online15[Lawrence et al., 2012]. Reed et al. [2017] reports\nthat the current database stores 70 corpora containing 11,000 arguments (60,000 claims; 1.2\nmillion words), with source materials in 14 diﬀerent languages, with a variety of diﬀerent scripts.\nWe will discuss corpora further in Chapter 4.\nQuerying Complex queries are possible from arguments expressed in AIF. A higher-level\nquery language called ArgQL uses the Resource Description Framework representation of AIF\nto deﬁne queries using the SPARQL standard, for instance “Find arguments which ‘defend’\n(attack their attackers) all arguments with conclusion ‘cloning is immoral’.” [ Zograﬁstou et al.,\n2017] or “Match pairs of arguments whose premise sets join each other.” ArgQL enables users to\ndirectly query for Argument, Debate Graph, Path, Attack, Support, Rebut, Undercut, Endorse,\nand Back, or any combinations.\n15http://corpora.aifdb.org/index.php (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 59 ---\n45\nC H A P T E R 4\nCorpus Annotation\nAs in other branches of natural language processing, the majority of research on argumentation\nmining is based on corpora, and usually on annotated corpora. Creating them has therefore been\na focus of interest in the years around 2015 when the ﬁeld gained momentum. In this chapter,\nwe ﬁrst describe some relatively generic annotation schemes1that have been suggested and used\nfor corpus annotation (Section 4.1), and then we provide brief descriptions of some corpora that\nhave been made freely available to the research community (Section 4.2). There is some overlap,\nas several of these corpora use schemes we describe in Section 4.1, but for most corpora there\nare separate, purpose-speciﬁc schemes being used.\n4.1 ANNOTATION SCHEMES\nThe general considerations on the structure of argumentation, such as those outlined in the\nprevious chapter, have been translated in various ways into schemes for annotating instances of\narguments found in text. In the following, we present some schemes that have been used for\ncorpus annotation. As they were devised with diﬀerent applications and purposes in mind, the\nreader should be prepared for some notable diﬀerences between the various approaches.\nThemicrotextscheme Following up on early pilot studies by Stede and Sauermann [2008], a\ntree-oriented annotation scheme was proposed by Peldszus and Stede [2013]. It is inspired by\nthe work of Freeman [1991, 2011], whose perspective on argumentation is that of a hypothet-\nical dialectical exchange between the proponent, who presents and defends his claims, and the\nopponent , who critically questions (‘attacks’) them in a regimented fashion. Every move in such\nan exchange corresponds to a structural element in the argumentation tree.\nThe argumentation structure annotation scheme then distinguishes between simple sup-\nport (one ADU provides a justiﬁcation of another) and linkedsupport, where several ADUs\ncollectively fulﬁll the role of justiﬁcation; in other words, one of the ADUs in isolation would\nnot be suﬃcient to perform the support. (This distinction was also made by Rahwan [2008]\nin the basic constellations shown earlier in Figure 3.1.) On the side of attacks, the annotation\nscheme separates rebutting (denying the validity of a statement) and undercutting (denying the\nrelevance of a statement in supporting another).2The annotation scheme is designed in such a\n1There is a slightly unfortunate parallel between the terms ‘argumentation scheme’, as used for instance in Chapter 3and\n‘annotation scheme’, but we see no way of avoiding one or the other term here.\n2For illustration, see Examples 6.6and6.7on page 86.\n\n--- Page 60 ---\n46 4. CORPUS ANNOTATION\nway that the ﬁne-grained representations may also be reduced to coarser ones that, for example,\nonly distinguish between support and attack, as it is customary in most other schemes.\nIn Figure 4.1, we show the representation for a short sample text. The nodes of this tree\nrepresent the propositions expressed in text segments (grey boxes), and their shape indicates the\nrole in the dialectical exchange: round nodes are the proponent’s nodes, square ones are the op-\nponent’s nodes. The arcs connecting the nodes represent diﬀerent supporting (arrow-head links)\nand attacking moves (circle/square-head links): 3 undercuts the attack of 2 on 1; 4 and 5 perform\na linked support on 1. By means of recursive application of relations, representations of relatively\ncomplex texts can be created, identifying the central claim of a text, supporting premises, pos-\nsible objections, and their counter-objections, with potential sub-structures involved in various\nplaces. As one example, ‘serial support’ originates when one segment supports another one,\nwhich in turn supports a third segment (see also Figure 3.1).\nThis annotation scheme is described in detail in Peldszus and Stede [2013], where il-\nlustrative examples for the various relevant constellations are given. It was encoded in speciﬁc\nannotation guidelines, and has been applied to German texts from the ‘Potsdam Commentary\nCorpus’ [Stede and Neumann, 2014], and to the German/English ‘microtext’ corpus (see the\nnext section). A dedicated, web-based annotation tool was developed for building tree struc-\ntures over text spans.3As for inter-annotator agreement, Peldszus [2014] reports \u0014=0.83 for\nwell-trained expert annotators that start from pre-segmented text.\nThe persuasive essay scheme The annotation scheme underlying the persuasive essay corpus\nbyStab and Gurevych [2014a] (see the next section) shares the basic idea of building a claim-\nrooted tree with the microtext scheme. There are a few diﬀerences, though. The ﬁrst results from\nthe genre: Each persuasive essay, according to the scheme, has one segment called the major\nclaim, which is the thesis that the essay argues for. It tends to be found in the ﬁrst paragraph of\nthe essay. Independently of that, claim/premise trees are annotated on the level of paragraphs,\ni.e., one tree is built for each paragraph of an essay.\nWhile there are no explicit proponent/opponent labels, the relation between premise and\nclaim has to be labeled as either support or attack, which therefore also implicitly captures the\ndiﬀerence in the roles of segments. This annotation scheme does not distinguish any further\nsubcategories of support or attack. The reported inter-annotator agreement in terms of Krip-\npendorf’s unitized \u000bis 0.72 for argument components and 0.81 for relations.\nThe science scheme Kirschner et al. [2015] addressed a genre that, somewhat surprisingly,\nso far has not received very much attention in the argumentation mining community: scientiﬁc\npapers, in particular journal papers from educational research. A pilot study was performed on\n24 papers (in German), with an average length of about 10 pages.\nThe argumentative units are always sentences, and they are not labeled with roles. Four\nrelations are used to link the units: Support and Attack on the one hand, and Sequence and\n3http://angcl.ling.uni-potsdam.de/resources/grapat.html (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 61 ---\n4.1. The latter are inspired from theories of discourse structure (cf. Section 2.6):\nDetail is used when “A is a detail of B and gives more information or deﬁnes something stated in\nB without argumentative reasoning” [ Kirschner et al. ,2015, p. 5], and Sequence applies when\n“two (or more) argument components belong together and only make sense in combination” (p.\n5). For illustration, Figure 4.2shows a sample analysis of an argument along these lines. An\ninteresting contribution of the work is a proposal for a new way of measuring inter-annotator\nagreement for graphs.—In general, however, it is not clear whether the authors indeed require\nthe full power of graphs for their representations or whether trees are in fact suﬃcient.\nThe Modiﬁed Toulmin Scheme In selecting a scheme for annotating their corpus of user-\ngenerated web discourse (see next section), Habernal and Gurevych [2017] started from the\nToulmin model (see Section 3.4.1). They kept its basic assumption that the argumentative role\nof a unit fully determines its position in the argument representation—and thus the scheme\nhas no need to explicitly annotate any relations between units. In contrast to the microtext and\npersuasiveessayschemes,itishencenotpossibletobuildrecursivestructures(asneededfor‘serial\nsupport’ or complex counter-attack constellations). The annotation therefore is a ﬂat labeling;\nan example is shown in Figure 4.3.\n\n--- Page 63 ---\n4.1. ANNOTATION SCHEMES 49\nFigure 4.3: Diagrammatic representation of annotated argument in the Modiﬁed Toulmin\nScheme based on Habernal and Gurevych [2017, p. 144].\nHowever, Habernal and Gurevych did make a number of important modiﬁcations to the\noriginalToulminmodel.TheyremovedtheQualiﬁerandtheWarrant,asthesedidnotplayarole\nin their corpus data. The notion of Backing was slightly redeﬁned and now serves as ‘additional\nevidence’, which does not play the same role as a premise but still lends overall support to the\nargument. In order to account for counter-attacks, they introduce the unit type Refutation . And\nﬁnally, to enable the annotation of texts where the claim is not explicit (which is often the case\nin their corpus), annotators were instructed to add an explicit statement of the author’s stance,\nas they infer it from the text.\nSince the annotation process consists of breaking the text into units and labeling them,\nannotator agreement was evaluated in terms of Krippendorﬀ’s unitized \u000b; an overall value of\n0.48 was achieved. Habernal and Gurevych [2017] provide an in-depth analysis of the various\ntypes of disagreement that they found.\nThe Cornell eRulemaking Scheme While the majority of annotations on argumentative\nmonologue text use trees, this is not entirely uncontroversial. Relation types are reasonandevidence .\nNiculae et al. report annotator agreement in terms of Krippendorﬀ’s \u000b: 0.65 for role as-\nsignment, and 0.44 for linking.\nInference Anchoring Theory Inference Anchoring Theory (IAT) concerns what Asher and\nLascarides [2003] called ‘dialogue glue’: the connections between utterances in dialogue, and\nthe locutions put forward by these utterances. To describe the argumentative connections, IAT\nproposes illocutionary schemes that describe how speech acts are performed in dialogue. Exam-\nple illocutionary schemes (see, e.g., Reed[2011]) are analogous to the argumentation schemes\nwe discussed in Section 3.3, but they connect locutions to the logical arguments that they put\nforward. Their main elements are transitions between statements, indicating the illocutionary\nforce (e.g., asserting, challenging, questioning, arguing).\n\n--- Page 65 ---\n4.2. CORPORA 51\nIAT enables locutions in ordinary, everyday conversations to be translated into a dialogue\ngame.Budzyńska and Reed [2011] gave the following example, which translates into the IAT\nmodel shown in Figure 4.5.\n(4.1) (1.1) Bob says, The government will inevitably lower the tax rate.\n(1.2) Wilma says, Why?\n(1.3) Bob says, Because lower taxes stimulate the economy.\n/T_he government\nwill inevitably\nlower the tax rate.Bob says, /T_he government will\ninevitably lower the tax rate.\nTA1\nWilma says, Why?\nTA2 RA1 IF3\nIF4IF2IF1\nBob says, Because lower\ntaxes stimulate the economy.Lower taxes\nstimulate the\neconomy.\nFigure 4.5: Sample annotation for Inference Anchoring Theory based on Budzyńska and Reed\n[2011]. IF=illocutionary force; RA=inference between propositions; TA=dialogue rule that re-\nlate communication acts.\nLocutions may contain propositions, but properties of locution events (such as when or\nwhere they are spoken or by whom) may be important, so locution events themselves can also be\nused in arguments (e.g., about the speaker’s communicative ability or motivation or to establish\nthat someone really said something). Thus, Reed and Budzyńska [2011] describe pragmatics as\nthe connection between the locutions and the logical arguments put forward.\n4.2 CORPORA\nIn this section we list a number of annotated corpora that have been made available to the\ncommunity, grouped in web-based and other text material. For a (hypothetical) example, in order to obtain the gist of a\nTwitter conversation, it can be suﬃcient to extract claims and purported evidence material. By\ncontrast, in order to run a deep analysis of argumentation strategies in left-wing vs. right-wing\nnewspapers, the editorials ideally need to be mapped to a complete constellation of statements,\ntheir argumentative relationships, and the reasoning patterns underlying those relationships.\nTherefore, similar to the surveys of Peldszus and Stede [2013] and Lippi and Torroni\n[2016a], we break the overall problem into a set of individual subtasks. In this chapter, we ad-\ndress the core task of ﬁnding the claim statements made by the writer, i.e., the central compo-\nnent of an argument. The next chapters will be concerned with ﬁnding additional components\n(viz., supporting and objecting statements), organizing them in a structured representation, and\nassessing some ‘deeper’ aspects of the argumentation.\nDepending on the application scenario, before ﬁnding argument components it can be\nnecessary to ﬁrst ﬁlter a set of input texts as to whether they might contain an argument at\nall or not. Thus, in Section 5.1, we consider the task of classifying a text as argumentative or\nnon-argumentative. This step applies both to full documents and to portions of text: many texts\ncontain both argumentative and other material, which then can be separated.\nAnother potential preparatory step concerns the delimitation of potential minimal units\nof argument analysis, i.e., those units that may become argument components. In practice, this is\nnot often operationalized as a separate task, but nonetheless we brieﬂy address it in Section 5.2.\nThen, in Section 5.3, we turn to the central task of identifying claimsin a text: what does\nthe writer argue for? Many implemented approaches combine this step with also ﬁnding the\nother core component of an argument—the supportive statements—but since for some pur-\nposes, just ﬁnding claims can be the most relevant problem, we discuss the two steps separately.\nThroughout this and the following chapters, we mention both work involving human\nannotation (albeit to a smaller extent), and automatic processing, including relevant datasets,\nmethods that have been applied, and the performance results that were achieved. Along the\nway we will see that there are several parallels to well-known NLP problems, such as opinion\nmining, semantic relation extraction, stance classiﬁcation, and discourse parsing. Accordingly,\nmany computational techniques can be borrowed from those areas.\n\n--- Page 71 ---\n58 5. FINDING CLAIMS\n5.1 CLASSIFYING TEXT AS ARGUMENTATIVE VS.\nNON-ARGUMENTATIVE\nThequestion“Argumentativeornot?”canbeaskedforacompletetextdocumentorforparticular\nparts of a text. As a special case of the latter, portions of dialogic interaction can be deemed\nargumentatively-relevant. We discuss these three situations in turn.\n5.1.1 DOCUMENT LEVEL\nWhen dealing with ‘traditional’ kinds of documents, the task can be couched as one of genre\nclassiﬁcation. In linguistics, a genre is conceived as a class of texts that\n• serve the same purpose,\n• often have a typical structure in terms of ‘zones’ playing speciﬁc roles for the common\npurpose (cf. Section 2.6.2), and\n• can have characteristic distributions of linguistic features.\nExamples of fairly ‘prototypical’ genres are recipes, weather reports, and persuasive essays. In\neach case, we expect certain pieces of information, linearized in a suitable or conventionalized\nway.\nNewspaper (and other print) text In NLP, automatic genre classiﬁcation has been applied,\nfor instance, to newspapers, where opinionated text (editorials, letters to the editor) is to be\ndistinguishedfromnon-opinionatednews.Eventhoughnoteveryopinionatedtextisnecessarily\nargumentative, the ability to distinguish categories like these is of relevance to argumentation\nmining, too.\nThe early work of Karlgren and Cutting [1994] and Kessler et al. [1997] on the Brown\nCorpus aimed at distinguishing various categories from each other, with one setting being ‘edi-\ntorial’ vs. ‘reportage’. These researchers experimented with part-of-speech (PoS) tags, document\nand sentence length, type/token ratio, punctuation symbols, and frequencies of speciﬁc words\nthat the authors considered relevant: ‘therefore’, ‘I’, ‘me’, ‘it’, ‘that’, and ‘which’. Kessler et al.\nreported classiﬁcation accuracies of 83% and 61% for reports and editorials, respectively.\nLater work replaced linguistic analysis by bag-of-words [Freund et al. ,2006] or bag-of-\ncharacter-n-grams [Sharoﬀ et al., 2010] models. Such knowledge-free approaches yielded very\ngood results in the domains of the training data, but, as shown by Petrenz and Webber [2011],\nthis idea is extremely vulnerable to shifts in topics and domains. Working with the New York\nTimesAnnotatedCorpus(NYTAC),1PetrenzandWebberreimplementedearlierapproaches,built\nsubsetsofarticlescoveringdiﬀerenttopics,anddemonstratedthattheearlyworkusinglinguistic\nfeatures is more robust when the topics of the articles change.\n1https://catalog.ldc.upenn.edu/ldc2008t19 (accessed May 28, 2018)\n\n--- Page 72 ---\n5.1. CLASSIFYING TEXT AS ARGUMENTATIVE VS. NON-ARGUMENTATIVE 59\nIn the same spirit, Krüger et al. [2017] used texts with diﬀerent topics, and they also var-\nied the newspaper and the time of origin of the texts, by working with the Brown, NYTAC, and\nWall Street Journal corpora. For distinguishing editorials and letters to the editor from news\ntexts, they experimented with a large linguistic feature set and showed that it generally outper-\nforms PoS and bag-of-lemma approaches. Among the most predictive features were ﬁrst- and\nsecond-personpronouns,negationsuﬃxes,andcertainwordclassessuchassentimentwordsand\ncommunication verbs. The results diﬀer quite a bit among the various settings they considered.\nWe mention here just one: When classifying ‘opinion’ vs. ‘news’, trained on the mixed-topic\nWSJ corpus and tested on NYTAC ‘medicine’ articles, the F-score for the best model was 0.87.\nWeb text To assist a user who is interested in diﬀerent viewpoints on a controversial topic,\nRoitman et al. [2016] devised a document retrieval method for Wikipedia articles. First, this\nsystem ﬁnds articles that address the desired topic, by means of current information retrieval\ntechniques. In a follow-up step, the document set is reranked according to its argumentative\npotential. To this end, the authors employ a manually-built list of words that can point to con-\ntroversy, including ‘justify’, ‘deny’, and others.\nAlthough Wikipedia text is relatively orderly, the majority of web text to be exploited\nfor argumentation mining is generated by users and thus can pose well-known challenges for\nautomatic processing. Habernal and Gurevych [2017] compiled a corpus of such texts, designed\nto cover a set of predeﬁned topics within the domain of education. Their work includes an\nannotation study where contributions to online forums and user comments had to be judged\nas either persuasive or non-persuasive.2For a document to be considered persuasive, it also has\nto be on-topic, so that in eﬀect a second classiﬁcation dimension is mixed into the task. Three\nannotators labeled 990 documents and achieved a Fleiss \u0014of 0.59. This step lead to a gold-\nstandard set of 524 persuasive on-topic documents. As a common source of disagreement, the\nauthors note the presence of implicit claims or stances, thus involving interpretation on the side\nof the annotators. Habernal and Gurevych then built an automatic SVM classiﬁer using lexical\nn-gram baseline features and obtained a macro-F score of 0.69. In a follow-up experiment, they\nused a rich feature set, but the results turned out to be worse than the baseline.\n5.1.2 SUB-DOCUMENT LEVEL\nIn principle, the attribute of being ‘argumentative’ can also be applied to paragraphs or other\nstretches of text, but to our knowledge this has not been explicitly addressed in the research yet.\nInstead, the task is commonly tackled on the level of sentences or clauses.\n2While in general not every argument aims at persuasion, within the genre considered here, ‘argumentative’ and ‘persuasive’\ncan be considered as referring to the same class of texts.\n\n--- Page 73 ---\n60 5. FINDING CLAIMS\nSentences Themajorityofresearchonﬁne-grainedargumentativityclassiﬁcationisconcerned\nwith ﬁnding sentences in monologue text, but the task has been framed in a variety of slightly\ndiﬀerent ways.\nWe begin with some pioneering work in argumentation mining by Moens et al. [2007].\nThey worked with texts from AraucariaDB [Reed et al., 2008a] and with court decisions from\nthe European Court of Human Rights (ECHR), and as their ﬁrst analysis step classiﬁed sen-\ntences as argumentative or not. (Some examples of argumentative sentences from the ECHR\ncorpus are shown later in Figure 5.1on page 65.) As features they used lexical (token n-grams,\nadverbs, verbs, modals, argumentative markers) and syntactic (punctuation, depth of parse tree,\nnumber of subclauses) features as well as some text statistics, such as length of sentence and\nposition of sentence in the text. With multinomial naive Bayes and maximum entropy models,\nthey achieved accuracies of 73% and 80%, respectively, for the two data sets.\nFlorou et al. [2013] worked with Greek texts concerning public policy-making, to identify\nsentences expressing a position toward a proposal. The authors speciﬁcally proposed that “future\nand conditional tenses and moods often indicate conjectures and hypotheses which are com-\nmonly used in argumentation techniques such as illustration, justiﬁcation, rebuttal”, and they\nstudied these features in tandem with a manually compiled list of connectives signaling justiﬁ-\ncation, explanation, deduction, rebuttal, and conditionals. With a C4.5 decision tree classiﬁer,\ntheir best result is an F-score of 0.76 for a subset of the morphosyntactic and lexical features.\nAmong the ﬁrst researchers applying the task to social media, Goudas et al. [2014] clas-\nsiﬁed Greek sentences from blogs and other web sites as “containing an argument or not”. They\nused a rich feature set including certain PoS distributions, position, and length features, manu-\nally selected cue words, the number of entities mentioned in previous sentences, as well as token\nn-grams. With a logistic regression classiﬁer, they obtained an accuracy of 77%. Turning to\nTwitter, Dusmanu et al. [2017] used a feature set including n-grams, Twitter-speciﬁc tokens\nlike emoticons, dependency triples, and sentiment information for classifying tweets as argu-\nmentative or not, and they report an F1-score of 0.78, obtained by a linear regression classiﬁer.3\nAl-Khatib et al. [2016a] suggest a distant supervision approach to classifying argumenta-\ntive units: they automatically labeled text from idebate.org as argumentative or not, depending\non which of the pre-deﬁned components in the forum the text belongs to.4On this data, they\ntrain a classiﬁer that uses n-grams, constituency syntax production rules, as well as various mor-\nphosyntactic features. They evaluated the model on the same type of data (obtaining an accu-\nracy of 0.92), as well as on two other corpora: the persuasive essay corpus of Stab and Gurevych\n[2014a] and the web text corpus of Habernal and Gurevych [2017] (both mentioned in our list\nin Section 4.2.2). On those corpora, the accuracy is 0.67 and 0.88, respectively. The authors then\nalso report results on cross-domain train/test experiments.\n3The DART data set [ Bosc et al., 2016a] contains 4,000 Twitter posts that annotators identiﬁed as non-/argumentative (de-\nﬁned as “(not) containing an opinion”). In addition, around 1,900 argumentative tweets were grouped by semantic similarity\n(topics) and then, within groups, pairwise linked via the relations support (446 tweets), attack (122), and unknown (1,323).\n4The resulting corpus is available for research: https://www.webis.de/data (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 74 ---\n5.1. CLASSIFYING TEXT AS ARGUMENTATIVE VS. NON-ARGUMENTATIVE 61\nStudent essays are another very popular genre for argumentation mining, where the ulti-\nmate goal is to evaluate the quality of the essay and hence of the argumentation therein. Follow-\ning this direction, Song et al. [2014] posed the non-/argumentative distinction in a more speciﬁc\nway: they aimed to classify whether a sentence addresses a critical question of an argumentation\nscheme (in the sense of Walton, see Section 3.3) and can thus be considered argumentatively\nrelevant. Features were n-grams of the sentence and the two surrounding ones, sentence po-\nsition and length, PoS tag presence, and lexical overlap between the sentence and the writing\nprompt underlying the essay. The performance of their logistic regression model was measured\nby Cohen \u0014and was in the range of up to 0.5 in various train/test settings involving the same\nor diﬀerent prompts.\nWhile the approaches discussed thus far performed binary classiﬁcation (argumentative\nor not), it is also possible to solve the problem as a byproduct of running a multi-class classiﬁer\nthat detects the speciﬁc argumentative role of a sentence, and also allows for a ‘none’ value. An\nexample for this technique is the system by Stab and Gurevych [2014b], which is also trained\nand tested on student essays. Using a very rich set of features (structural, lexical, syntactic, and\nspeciﬁc lexical cues) they experimented with several classiﬁcation techniques, leading to a best\nresult of 77.3% accuracy (macro-F 0.73) obtained by an SVM. The F-score for the class ‘none’\nwas 0.88. It turned out that the text-statistics and structural features are most helpful, which\npoints to the role of conventionalized writing patterns in the genre of student essays. More\ndetails on this classiﬁer will be provided below on page 70.\nSub-sentences Presupposing that sentences are the proper unit for making the non-\n/argumentative distinction is for many use cases a simpliﬁcation. As, for example, Palau and\nMoens [2009] or Lawrence et al. [2014] pointed out, a complex sentence may very well contain\nmore than one argument component (i.e., a premise and a conclusion), and furthermore it may\ncontain both argumentative and non-argumentative material, which ought to be kept separate\nwhen a ﬁne-grained analysis is being targeted. For automatic analysis this is a complication,\nthough, and hence it is not uncommon (see, e.g., Song et al. [2014]) to let human annotators\nmark arbitrary text spans as argumentative, but then for the automatic approach to reduce the\nﬁne-grained annotation to sentence-level.\nLawrence et al. [2014] argue that the initial step of non/-argument classiﬁcation should\nbe to separate the text into a sequence of individual ‘propositions’, by which the authors mean a\nsequenceofwordsthatisnotnecessarilydelimitedbypunctuationoronsyntacticgrounds.5They\ntokenize the text, compute a feature set for each token, and train two classiﬁers for identifying\ntokens starting and ending a proposition, respectively. Features are the word, its PoS tag and\nlength, and the two words preceding and following the word in question. The results were not\nvery encouraging, though: on a cleaned version of a book chapter, this approach leads to an\naccuracy of 20% of correctly identiﬁed propositions (with exact matching), and the ﬁgure even\n5Hence, like in the other work reported here, the authors are notaiming at any semantic analysis when speaking of ‘proposi-\ntions’.\n\n--- Page 75 ---\n62 5. FINDING CLAIMS\ndecreases (surprisingly) as further chapters are added as training data. Lawrence et al. do not\nmake the decision on the argumentativeness of propositions directly; rather it occurs as a side\neﬀect of classifying argument components (to be discussed in the next chapters). Any ‘leftover’\nmaterial from that step is considered non-argumentative.\n5.1.3 SUMMARY\nThe performance ﬁgures quoted above are generally not bad, but when considering the fea-\ntures that are being used for classiﬁcation, we largely ﬁnd ‘the usual suspects’, including bag-of-\nwords, PoS tag distributions, and positional and length information. This indicates that most\napproaches are geared toward separating a domain-speciﬁc document set in two parts, rather\nthan to speciﬁcally capturing the linguistic signals of argumentativeness. Among the exceptions\nis the idea of manually compiling lists of words indicating controversy [Roitman et al., 2016],\nand of employing larger sets of linguistically motivated features. The latter approach, however,\nled to mixed results: it served the purpose of separating editorials from news in Krüger et al.\n[2017] but did not perform well on web text in Habernal and Gurevych [2017]. At any rate, the\nstandard features appear to capture more general aspects of subjectivity and opinion, while not\nnecessarily those of argumentation in particular. Hence, it is not clear yet whether a relatively\ndomain-independent separation of argumentative and non-argumentative text spans can in fact\nbe achieved using standard surface-based features.\n5.2 SEGMENTING TEXT INTO ARGUMENTATIVE UNITS\nThe task of segmentation amounts to partitioning an argumentative text (or portion of text) into\nunits that can later on be identiﬁed as playing a certain role—or none—in the argumentation.\nThis is diﬃcult, though, and from the perspective of NLP practitioners, it is tempting to eﬀec-\ntively circumvent this segmentation step by using sentences as the ‘default’ unit. This strategy\nhas two obvious consequences.\n• Argumentative units that are smaller than sentences cannot be processed:\n(5.1) [Although the candidate has a few good ideas,] [you should not vote for her!]\n• Argumentative units that consist of more than a single sentence are diﬃcult to process:\n(5.2) We need to tear the building down. 1[It is contaminated with asbestos. 2[In\nevery single corner. 3[From the ﬁrst to the last ﬂoor! 4\nThe ﬁrst problem is illustrated above in Example 5.1. The second problem can be par-\nticularly acute when working with user-generated texts, where the ‘sentence’ can be hard to\ndeﬁne, and material between punctuation marks can be very short. In Example 5.2(taken from\nPeldszus and Stede [2013]), statement 1 is the claim made by the speaker, and the evidence\nis provided by the sequence 2–4; there is no point in assigning an argumentative role to each\n\n--- Page 76 ---\n5.2. SEGMENTING TEXT INTO ARGUMENTATIVE UNITS 63\nsentence individually. Hence, a sentence-oriented system needs a way to distinguish between a\nsequence of sentences that each provide diﬀerent evidence (and which play the same role for the\nargument), and a sequence of sentences that collectively form a single argumentative unit, as in\nExample 5.2.\nSo, in principle, the minimal units of argumentation may span multiple full sentences, or\nbe shorter than a sentence, and thus we can characterize an argumentative discourse unit (ADU)\nas\na span of text that plays a single role for the argument being analyzed, and is demar-\ncated by neighboring text spans that play a diﬀerent role, or none at all.\nHumanannotation Taking our deﬁnition seriously would mean to assign the question of de-\nmarcating units to human annotators, and then try to reproduce it by automatic means. A few\nresearchers took the ﬁrst step and produced datasets where annotators have been asked to de-\nlimit the ADUs, without setting any restrictions on pre-deﬁned unit candidates. For example,\nWacholder et al. [2014], in their annotation of ‘callout’ and ‘target’ in online interactions (see\nSection 4.2), evaluated cases where annotators disagreed only by few tokens, and devised a strat-\negy for deriving a gold standard from their annotations. Also, in the web text corpus of Habernal\nand Gurevych [2017] (see Section 5.3.5), boundaries were decided freely by annotators (yet in\ntheir automatic approach, the authors re-simpliﬁed the task to working with sentences only).\nComputation Among the few approaches that actually tackle the segmentation problem (in-\nstead of working with sentences as default units), some employ a syntax parser to supply clauses,\nwhich then serve as candidates for minimal units. For instance, the early work of Palau and\nMoens [2009] on legal text used syntactic clauses as units to be classiﬁed as argumentative or\nnot. More recently, Persing and Ng [2016] used manually-devised rules for ﬁltering parse trees\nand obtaining argumentative units for analyzing student essays. They worked with the corpus\ncompiled by Stab and Gurevych [2014a] (see Section 4.2.2), which has been annotated on the\nlevel of clauses. Persing and Ng extracted ADU candidates from a parse tree, and in their eval-\nuation, they accounted for boundary mismatches with two separate measures: one for exact\nmatching, and one for partial matching, where success is deﬁned as 50% of the tokens being\nin agreement. Their overall F-score for argument component identiﬁcation is 0.57 with partial\nmatch and 0.47 for exact match, where the diﬀerence indicates the diﬃculties with exact ADU\nboundary detection. However, on the same corpus, Eger et al. [2017] perform a comparative\nstudy of various approaches, where the best one (an LSTM-based dependency parser) achieves\nan F1-score of 0.91 for ﬁnding the exact boundaries of argument components. The authors also\nprovide an informative error analysis, and they point out that their result even beats the human\nagreement that was determined by Habernal and Gurevych [2017] as 0.89.\nA recent thorough study of the segmentation problem was done by Ajjour et al. [2017].\nThese authors experimented with diﬀerent feature sets as well as diﬀerent machine learning\nmodels, and were also interested in cross-domain performance. For this reason they worked with\n\n--- Page 77 ---\n64 5. FINDING CLAIMS\nthree diﬀerent available datasets (student essays, news editorials, and web discourse). In terms\nof features, it turned out that for in-domain analysis, bag-of-words features are most helpful\n(whereas embeddings did generally not help), while structural features (whether the token is at\nbeginning/middle/end of a sentence/clause/phrase) proved most robust when training on one\ndomainandtestingontheother.Regardingmachinelearningapproaches,abidirectionalLSTM\nachieved the best results in most cases, regardless of the domain or the features.\nAn important observation, however, was that the cross-domain scenario suﬀered from\ngenerally bad performance. The authors take this as an indication that the notion of ADU is\nnot quite the same across diﬀerent corpora, and hence across diﬀerent annotation guidelines.\nEvidence for this hypothesis is the high variance that Aijour et al. found in the size of ADUs,\nranging from clause-like segments in the newspaper data to the frequent occurrence of multiple\nsentences in a Wikipedia data set by Aharoni et al. [2014] (see Section 5.3.4).\n5.3 IDENTIFYING CLAIMS\nDetecting claims is the ﬁrst of two indispensable tasks for any argumentation mining system\n(the second one being the detection of evidence or premises), and accordingly, a lot of work has\nbeen undertaken here. However, the reader should also be reminded that in many instances of\nargumentation, there is no explicit claim being formulated at all; instead the reader needs to\nderive it from what is said. In fact, Habernal and Gurevych [2017] report that in their social\nmedia data, almost half of all claims are only implicit. The ensuing problem of actually inferring\nclaims is obviously very diﬃcult and has not received much attention. Instead, the research has\nfocused on the simpler task of only identifying explicit claims.\nWe can broadly distinguish two families of methods that have so far been applied to claim\ndetection.\nClassiﬁcation Given a minimal unit of analysis (in practice this is almost always a sentence,\nas described in the previous section), it can be classiﬁed in diﬀerent ways.\n• Binary classiﬁcation: claim or no claim.\n• Binary classiﬁcation: claim/premise. When the overall goal of the system is restricted to\nﬁnding claims and premises, thus adopting a coarse-grained deﬁnition of argument, then\nthe classiﬁer can directly distinguish between these two types of unit.\n• Multi-class classiﬁcation: When more types of argument components are being consid-\nered, they may be identiﬁed by a single classiﬁer. Also, as pointed out earlier, one class\ncan be ‘none’, so that the decision whether the unit is argumentative at all is also included\nhere.\n\n--- Page 78 ---\n5.3. IDENTIFYING CLAIMS 65\nSequence labeling Some approaches tackle the identiﬁcation of argument components\n(claims and possibly more) as an IOB labeling problem.6Thus, words are tagged as B-premise,\nB-claim, I-premise, I-claim, or O. Again, this can subsume the detection of non-argumentative\nmaterial. Also, when claim detection is the onlytask performed by a system, it is trivially iden-\ntical to the task of non-/argumentative classiﬁcation. We will discuss this type of work in the\npresent section (rather than above in 5.1), because the deﬁnitions used for ‘claim’ in this work\nare more speciﬁc than those generally adopted for ‘argumentative’.\nWe organize the following summary by the genres being addressed, as these imply certain\ndiﬀerences as to what exactly a ‘claim’ is.\n5.3.1 LEGAL DOCUMENTS\n{ [ SUPPORT:  /T_he Court This method represents labeled “target” text spans by tagging the tokens of a text\nwith one of the three letters: B = token is the beginning of a span; I = token is within a span (‘inside’); O = token is not part\nof a span (‘out’). As an example, consider ﬁnding all named entities (NE) in a text. B indicates that NE begins, I indicates\nthat an NE continues: We-O met-O in-O the-O New-B York-I City-I subway-O .\n\n--- Page 79 ---\n66 5. FINDING CLAIMS\nBefore the task of ‘argumentation mining’ was identiﬁed and labeled as such, legal case\ndocuments were analyzed from an information extraction point of view, in an attempt to dis-\ntinguish the diﬀerent functions of sentences, very similar to the ‘argumentative zoning’ idea\nofTeufel and Moens [2002], which we mentioned in Section 2.6.2. For example, Hachey and\nGrover [2006] annotated ‘rhetorical roles’ in judgments of the UK House of Lords, the goal\nbeing that of automatic summarization. Seven roles were distinguished, among them ‘fact’ (re-\ncounting the events triggering the legal proceedings), ‘background’ (citation of source of law\nmaterial), and ‘framing’, which represents parts of the judge’s argumentation. Using features\nsimilar to those of Teufel and Moens (cue phrases, location, entities, sentence length, quota-\ntions, thematic words), the authors obtained a micro-averaged F-score of 0.6 with an SVM\nclassiﬁer using all features, but, interestingly, a decision tree classiﬁer using only location fea-\ntures achieved a considerably better score of 0.65.\nPalau and Moens [2009] went a step further and distinguished the argumentative roles\nshown in Figure 5.1. Their SVM model for premise/conclusion classiﬁcation takes as input sen-\ntences that have already been predicted to be argumentative (see our description in Section 5.1).\nThe resulting F-scores for premise and conclusion are 0.68 and 0.74, respectively. Among their\nfeatures are syntactic ones (subject type, main verb tense), domain-speciﬁc cues, token counts,\nposition of sentence, and a contextual feature with the prediction for the previous and the fol-\nlowing segment.\nMore recently, Rooney et al. [2012] proposed an SVM sequence kernel classiﬁer as an\nalternative to the type of feature engineering done by Palau and Moens. The kernel compares\nsubsequences of sentences, where a word is tagged with its root form and PoS label. These\nauthors worked with the Araucaria DB dataset [Reed et al., 2008a], which contains arguments\nnot only from legal documents but also from newspapers, advertising, and several other genres.\nThe task is to label sentences as containing a premise (1299 instances in the annotated corpus),\ncontaining a claim (304 instances), being part of both a premise and a claim (161), or none\n(1686). Using 10-fold cross-validation, Rooney et al. report an overall accuracy of 0.65, which\nthose authors consider as promising on the grounds of dispensing with sophisticated features.\nFor claims, the result is particularly low, though (around 0.3).\nIn general, mining legal texts is a very diﬃcult task. For an overview of the limitations of\ncurrent IR systems and a sketch of necessary steps for automated argument retrieval, see Ashley\nand Walker [2013a].\n5.3.2 INSTRUCTIONAL TEXT\nInstructions, as they can be found in user manuals, often include advice and warnings; some-\ntimes, these are backed up by an explanation designed to increase the reader’s motivation to\nactually obey them. Here are some examples from Saint-Dizier [2012].\n(5.3) Never put this cloth into the sun; otherwise it will shrink dramatically.\n\n--- Page 80 ---\n5.3. IDENTIFYING CLAIMS 67\n(5.4) It is essential that you switch oﬀ electricity before starting any operation. Electricity\nshocks are a major source of injuries and death.\nAs such, the structure and function correspond exactly to that of an argument, where the claim\nis of the speciﬁc type ‘instruction’ to do or not do something. Based on a corpus study covering\nFrench and English text, Saint-Dizier concluded that such constructions have a highly regular\nlinguistic form, making it relatively easy to identify them. In his approach, a set of manually-\nconstructed rules serves to identify both the ‘claim’ and the supporting statements. The rules\nexploit the linear order of the statements, and a set of common lexical patterns. These pat-\nterns may contain expressions on diﬀerent levels of abstraction such as word form, word set, or\npart of speech. The rule language is processed by a dedicated text processing platform devel-\noped by the author, called <TextCoop> . Saint-Dizier reports recognition accuracies of 88%/91%\n(claim/support) for warnings and 79%/84% for advice.\n5.3.3 STUDENT ESSAYS\nEssays written by students in response to a given prompt are a target of NLP primarily for\nthe application of automatically scoring them, or for supporting the human grader or peer-\nreviewer by automatically adding helpful markup (and thereby encouraging the grader to provide\nqualitative feedback). A signiﬁcant portion of essays in education are persuasive, which Burstein\nand Marcu [2003, p. 457] deﬁne as requiring “the writer to state an opinion on a particular topic,\nand to support the stated opinion to convince the reader that the perspective is valid and well-\nsupported.”\nWe can broadly distinguish two lines of work here, which use slightly diﬀerent labeling\nschemes.\nThesisandconclusion Especially the American tradition of essay writing encourages students\nto make sure that their texts contain a ‘thesis’ and a ‘conclusion’. According to Falakmasir et al.\n[2014, p. 254], a thesis “communicates the author’s position and opinion about the essay prompt;\nit anchors the framework of the essay, serving as a hook for tying the reasons and evidence\npresented and anticipates critiques and counterarguments”, whereas the conclusion “reiterates\nthe main idea and summarizes the entire argument in an essay. It may contain new information,\nsuch as self-reﬂections on the writer’s position.”\nFinding these two elements is made diﬃcult by two features of student essays: as opposed\nto other genres like the legal texts discussed above, or scientiﬁc articles, student essays have little\ninternal structure in terms of headings and subheadings. Furthermore, topics vary widely, and\nthe students’ theses are often substantiated by personal experience rather than by cited sources\nor authorities. Thus, the role of genre-speciﬁc wording can also be expected to be less helpful\nthan for other texts. However, we will see that positional features can play an important role for\nthe task.\n\n--- Page 81 ---\n68 5. FINDING CLAIMS\n“You can’t always do what you want to do!,” my mother said. According to\nthe annotation scheme, an essay can have one major claim, which expresses the author’s stance\nwith respect to the topic, and which is usually found in the ﬁrst paragraph. Altogether, the corpus has 90 major claims (one\nper text) and 429 claims.\nThe detection of argument components is implemented as a four-way classiﬁer (major\nclaim, claim, premise, non-argumentative) presented by Stab and Gurevych [2014b], which\nwas mentioned in Section 5.1.2. Features can be grouped as follows.\n•Structural: location/length/punctuation.\n•Lexical: n-grams, verbs, adverbs, modals.\n•Syntactic: parse tree depth, production rules, verb tense.\n•Cues: connectives from the Penn Discourse Treebank (PDTB) corpus [Prasad et al. ,\n2008], ﬁrst-person references.\n•Attributes of preceding and following sentence: number of tokens and of punctuation,\nnumber of sub-clauses, presence of modal verbs.\nAmong various classiﬁers, an SVM performed best. The F-scores are: major claim 0.63, claim\n0.54, premise 0.83, non-argumentative 0.88. While premises can be identiﬁed quite reliably also\nwhen using just a single group of features (F between 0.65 for syntactic and 0.78 for structural\nfeatures), the corresponding values for claims and major claims are much lower, the maximum\nbeing 0.48 (major claim) and 0.42 (claim) for structural features. In other words, claim detection\nproﬁts more from feature combination than premise detection does.\nIn later work on the same corpus, Nguyen and Litman [2015] describe an alternative\napproach that centers on lexical/cue features.
