[2014] and Levy et al.\n[2014]. These researchers work on the IBM Debater project (cf. Sct. 1.3), whose overall goal is a\nsystem that searches web pages for pro and con arguments on a given controversial topic. Thus,\nthe claim detection task is dependent on a predeﬁned topic, which Levy et al. (p. 1489) deﬁne as\n“a short phrase that frames the discussion”; and a context-dependent claim is “a general, concise\nstatement that directly supports or contests the given topic.” The text source is Wikipedia pages,\nwhere (in contrast to other web text) a certain quality of language and argumentation can be\npresumed.\nA dataset was constructed on the basis of 32 debate motions from Debatabase .7Then, 326\nWikipedia articles were identiﬁed as relevant to these topics, and therein, annotators labeled\n976 topic-related claims, achieving a rather moderate agreement of \u0014=0.39. Figure 5.4shows\nexamples for annotation decisions. (Notice that, in other terminology, this ‘topic’ would itself\nqualify as a ‘claim’, as it represents a thesis or demand by the author.) A ‘V’ indicates that a\nsentence was regarded as a topic-dependent claim, while ‘X‘-marked sentences were not.\nIn general, claims need not be complete sentences but can be smaller units. The automatic\nclaim detection system thus needs to ﬁnd, given a Wikipedia page and a topic, sentences and\nsub-sentences that qualify as a relevant claim. To achieve this, Levy et al. built a pipeline of three\nmodules.\n7http://www.idebate.org/Debatabase (accessed May 28, 2018). Upon request, the authors are making this dataset avail-\nable for research.\n\n--- Page 85 ---\n72 5. FINDING CLAIMS\nFigure 5.4: Topic and associated claim candidates from Levy et al. [2014, p. 1490], used with\npermission.\nThe ﬁrst module is in charge of identifying sentences that contain a claim. A logistic\nregression classiﬁer uses features exploiting topic relevance (cosine similarity between the topic\nphrase and subjects in the sentence; and between the topic and a WordNet-expanded version\nof the sentence) and various topic-independent features (including morphosyntax, subjectivity,\nsentiment). It passes the top scoring 200 sentences to the next component.8\nForeachsentencefound,thesecondmodulegeneratesthe10bestcandidatesub-sentences\nusing a maximum likelihood model that primarily considers the tokens at the beginning and the\nend of the sequence. Then a logistic regression classiﬁer selects the most probable claim, again\nlooking at boundary tokens, along with a few other features.\nThe third module ranks the identiﬁed claims found for all the sentences, using another\nlogistic regression classiﬁer. It considers the scores produced by the previous components and\nalso re-computes some of the features that have been used in the preceding modules.\nIn subsequent work, Shnarch et al. [2017] added a pattern matching approach called\nGRASP, which integrates information from diﬀerent layers of analysis to the previous system.\nGRASP identiﬁes the most discriminative features for the classiﬁcation task, and composes\npatterns out of these. The authors note that these patterns are open to human inspection, hence\nallowing for qualitative error analyses. After adding this approach, signiﬁcant improvements in\nperformance on claim identiﬁcation are reported.\nWorking on a slightly bigger version of the IBM dataset, Lippi and Torroni [2015] ad-\ndressed only the ﬁrst step, i.e., sentence classiﬁcation, and suggested a rather diﬀerent approach.\nThey started from the observation that argumentative sentences are often characterized by com-\nmon ‘rhetorical structures’ and operationalized that intuition as the similarity between syntactic\n(constituency) parse trees. Their goal thus is to account for argumentative language irrespective\nof the domain, and to do so on the basis of syntactic patterns. They obtained the parses from\n8In this dataset, the input to step 1 consists of 1,500 Wikipedia sentences on average.\n\n--- Page 86 ---\n5.3. IDENTIFYING CLAIMS 73\nthe Stanford CoreNLP suite, and trained an SVM classiﬁer that exploits a partial tree kernel\nto compute similarities. The authors conclude that they can obtain results that are competitive\nto those of Levy et al. [2014], even without considering topic similarity. When adding a single\ncontextfeature(cosine similaritybetweenthe candidatesentence andthetopic, bothrepresented\nas bag of words), the F-measure increases by a further 1.2 points.\nIn addition, Lippi and Torroni tested their tree-similarity approach on the essay dataset\nbyStab and Gurevych [2014a] (mentioned in the previous subsection). Considering the union\nof their categories ‘claim’ and ‘major claim’ as the target class, Lippi and Torroni obtained an\nF-score of 0.71, which compares favorably to the results of Stab and Gurevych (whose problem\nwas a more diﬃcult multi-class task, though).\nFinally, we mention that the IBM dataset was used by Laha and Raykar [2016] for exper-\niments with RNNs and CNNs for detecting both claims and evidence (see next section). Their\ngoal was to establish the ﬁrst deep learning baselines for these tasks, and they report compar-\nisons of various architecture variants. For ﬁnding claims, however, the results were not as good\nas those obtained by Levy et al. [2014].\n5.3.5 SOCIAL MEDIA AND USER-GENERATED WEB TEXT\nFor many practical applications, the various kinds of social media (or other user-generated text)\nare a highly relevant source of opinions and arguments to be mined. Some early work addressed\npublic comments on proposed government regulations. Speciﬁcally, Kwon et al. [2007] studied a\ncorpus of user comments on proposed U.S. Environmental Protection Agency legislation. Here,\ntheclaim detectiontaskbeneﬁts fromall documentsaddressingthe same domain(the legislation\nin question). The authors exploited this by computing a feature representing the lexical overlap\nbetween sentences and the text topic ‘public policy’, in addition to various standard features\n(n-grams, frequencies of positive and negative words, position in text, and head verb token\nsequence). In the experiments, a boosting algorithm beat an SVM and achieved an agreement\nwith a human annotator of \u0014=0.55. In a follow-up step, the authors then computed the polarity\n(stance) of the claim by means of a seed word approach that identiﬁes positive and negative\nwords.\nIn later work, Rosenthal and McKeown [2012] sought to detect claims in LiveJournal\nweblogs and in Wikipedia discussion pages. They deﬁne claims as “assertions by a speaker who\nis attempting to convince others that his opinion is true” (p. 30), and more speciﬁcally attend\nto the class of claims expressing opinionated beliefs, which are deﬁned as “personal view[s] that\nothers can disagree with” (p. 30). Figure 5.5shows examples, which demonstrate that especially\nthe LiveJournal text can be very informal. Not surprisingly, it is not trivial to demarcate this class\nof claims precisely; when two annotators labeled 2,000 sentences as claims (without considering\nthe context) in each corpus, they achieved a Cohen \u0014of 0.50 for 663 LiveJournal sentences, and\n0.56 for 997 Wikipedia sentences.\n\n--- Page 87 ---\n74 5. FINDING CLAIMS\n1    oh yeah, you mentioned the race … that is so un-thanksgivingish !\n2    A g ood p hotogr apher can do awesome work with a polaroid or ‘ phonecam .\n3    hugs I feel ike I have completely lost track of a lot of stuﬀ lately .\n4    /T_he goal is to make Wikipedia as good as possible and, more speciﬁcally , this article as good as possible .\n5    /T_his was part of his childhood , and should be mentioned in the article .\n6    If the book is POV or the writer has only a slender grasp of relevant issues , material can be wrong .  \nLiveJournal\nWikipedia\nFigure 5.5: Examples of claims from two online corpora based on [Rosenthal and McKeown,\n2012, p. 31].\nThe focus of the work was on measuring the utility of sentiment and so-called comitted\nbelieffeatures. For the latter, the authors adoptedthe system by Prabhakaran et al. [2010], which\ntags individual words for the underlying type of belief: committed (I know), non-committed ( I\nmay), and not applicable ( I wish). Rosenthal and McKeown report various experiments on in-\ndomain and cross-domain classiﬁcation, including feature impact measurements. In brief, they\nfound that sentiment features are more useful in LiveJournal, while committed belief features\nare more predictive for Wikipedia discussions.\nOn a corpus of 204 diﬀerent social media and news documents (16,000 sentences) in\nGreek, Goudas et al. Their CRF model achieved a precision of 0.62 and recall of 0.32,\nresulting in an F-measure of 0.42. In follow-up work on news text, Sardianos et al. [2015]\nsought to reduce the role of domain-dependent gazetteer lists and report on experiments with\nword embeddings generated by word2vec [Mikolov et al., 2013].\nRecently, Habernal and Gurevych [2017] extended the IOB tagging approach to a set of\nargument components that they derived from the Toulmin scheme (see Section 3.4.1): backing,\nclaim, premise, rebuttal, refutation. They used the Web Discourse corpus (see Section 4.2.1),\nwhose annotation covers the aforementioned components, plus ‘appeal to emotion’ (representing\nthe pathos dimension of argumentation); see the example in Figure 5.6. We will come back to\nthis work in subsequent sections, and here just focus on the claim identiﬁcation. The trained\nhumanannotatorsachievedanagreementof0.59onclaims,measuredbyKrippendorf’sunitized\n\u000b.\nThe 11-class IOB tagging is applied to complete sentences as instances to be classiﬁed;\nthe authors argue that a token-level annotation is too ﬁne-grained for a machine learner. Conse-\nquently, the problem is simpliﬁed to deciding whether a sentence hosts an argument component\nor not. For sequence labeling, Habernal and Gurevych used SVMhmm. The rich feature set is\nsplit into ﬁve groups:\n\n--- Page 88 ---\n5.3. IDENTIFYING CLAIMS 75\nFigure 5.6: Sample annotation from the corpus of Habernal and Gurevych [2017, p. 169], used\nwith permission.\n•Lexical: word n-grams;\n•Structure and syntax: initial and ﬁnal tokens, relative positions, POS n-grams, depen-\ndency tree depth, constituency tree production rules, number of subclauses;\n•Topic and sentiment: LDA topics and ﬁve sentiment categories (-2, …, 2);\n•Semantics and discourse: semantic role labels, various coreference chain attributes, type\nof discourse relation, presence of connectives, attributions; and\n•Embeddings: sums of word embedding vectors.\nAll features are considered not only for the current sentence but also for the four preceding and\nfour subsequent sentences. The overall best results are achieved with the full feature set, yielding\na macro-F score of 0.25, in comparison to 0.6 obtained by human annotators. The classes Claim-\nB and Claim-I are among the top-performing classes, reaching 0.27 when omitting the lexical\nand structure/syntax features. As these numbers show, the problem tackled here is much harder\nthan those we discussed before.\n5.3.6 SUMMARY: FINDING CLAIMS OF DIFFERENT KINDS\nThe claim, undoubtedly, is at the heart of the argument—it states what the author wants us to\nbelieve.Beyondthisfairlygeneralcharacterization,however,diﬀerentauthorsprovidesomewhat\ndiﬀerent characterizations, and the corpus examples we have seen make it clear that there is a\n\n--- Page 89 ---\n76 5. FINDING CLAIMS\nrelatively broad range of statements treated as claims in diﬀerent text types and genres. Often,\nbut not always, claims are indicated by linguistic surface features, which some approaches try to\nisolate as topic-independent ‘claim shells’ that signal the claim. Also, in some genres, there seem\nto be relatively strong position-in-document tendencies that can be exploited, as for example in\nstudent essays.\nRecently, the variety in claim realizations prompted Daxenberger et al. [2017] to run a\nsystematic claim identiﬁcation experiment across six diﬀerent datasets.9They mapped the exist-\ning annotations to the sentence level, thus making a simplifying assumption, which, however, is\nshared by most of the previous work, as we have pointed out above. Daxenberger et al. wanted\nto measure the inﬂuence of diﬀerent groups of features (structure, lexical, syntax, discourse, em-\nbedding)10and learning approaches; they ran three deep learning schemes, and a regularized\nlogistic regression classiﬁer.\nFor in-domain classiﬁcation, they obtained an average macro-F score of 0.67, ranging\nfrom 0.6 (Wikipedia TalkPages) to 0.8 (arg. microtexts). Lexical (unigram), embedding, and\nsyntax features were most predictive, whereas structural features did not help in most cases.\nDiscourse features were useful only on the microtext corpus. The average performance of the\nbest neural network and the logistic regression classiﬁer was virtually the same.\nWith cross-domain training and testing, performance drops were found throughout, most\npronounced for the datasets that performed best in the in-domain setting. The best feature-\nbasedapproachoutperformedthedeeplearningapproachinmostscenarios.However,theneural\nnetworks beneﬁt when trained on all datasets but one and testing on the remaining one, yielding\nthe best results on average. Still, the best NN approach did not show beneﬁts over training on\ngood (single) source training datasets.\nAfter studying the six corpora further, Daxenberger et al. concluded that it is diﬃcult to\npredict cross-domain performance from lexical similarity of the datasets. Their overall conclu-\nsion is that “the essence of a claim is not much more than a few lexical clues.” This points to the\nimportant role of context: depending on genre and topic, a claim may on the surface look like\nany other declarative sentence, and only in the particular context assume the role of an opinion\nthat the speaker wants to convince the hearers of.\nFinally, we have to point out that the notion of claim will be given an additional facet of\ncomplication later in Chapter 7when we discuss structures of complex arguments: a statement\nin a text may be supported by another statement (which makes the ﬁrst one a claim) and at\nthe same time it may in turn support yet another statement and thus play multiple roles in the\nargumentation. But before turning to such recursive structures, we ﬁrst look more closely at the\n‘support’ relation.\n9Most of them have been introduced in Section 4.2.2or will be mentioned in the next chapter: AraucariaDB [Reed et al.,\n2008a], essays from Stab and Gurevych [2014b], web discourse from Habernal and Gurevych [2017], online comments and\nWikipedia talk pages from Biran and Rambow [2011], and argumentative microtexts from Peldszus and Stede [2016b].\n10They also experimented with sentiment dictionaries (as in, e.g., Rosenthal and McKeown [2012]) but found these to be of\nvery little value.\n\n--- Page 90 ---\n77\nC H A P T E R 6\nFinding Supporting and\nObjecting Statements\nDetecting claims, the topic of the previous chapter, is obviously a core task of argumentation\nmining, but in order to ﬁnd a complete argument, there is at least one more component to be\nidentiﬁed: the statement(s) that the author introduced to support the claim. In the argumenta-\ntion literature, this is often called the ‘premises’ of the argument; in other places it is ‘evidence’\nor ‘justiﬁcation’. In this chapter, we use these terms interchangeably with ‘support’.\nBesides claims and evidence, it may be important to also look for counter-arguments, in\ncase the text also mentions the ‘opposing view’, and the application seeks to identify it. Here is\na simple example.\n(6.1) You should buy that camera, because it has a brand-new excellent sensor. OK, it is quite\nexpensive. But it’s worth the money!\nOur speaker, in giving her recommendation, imagines an ‘opponent’ pointing out the high\npriceoftheproduct.Afterquotingthatpotentialcounterargument,sherefutesitbyemphasizing\nthe good value one gets for the money here. Thus, the argument components to be detected are\nas follows.\n•Claim: You should buy that camera.\n•Support: That camera has a brand-new excellent sensor.\n•Objection: That camera is quite expensive.\n•Support: That camera is worth the money.\nNotice that when ‘digging deeper’, we might want to not just enumerate the components but\nalso record in what way the speaker wants them to relate to each other (here especially the\nlink between the objection and the second support)—but that is the topic of the next chapter.\nFor now, in the following sections, we look at the tasks of ﬁnding support (Section 6.1) and\nobjections (Section 6.2). Furthermore, a potentially helpful related NLP task is stance detection,\nwhich determines whether a text communicates a positive or negative attitude toward a given\ntopic. We examine it brieﬂy in Section 6.3.\n\n--- Page 91 ---\n78 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\n6.1 FINDING SUPPORTING STATEMENTS\nSupport or evidence, by deﬁnition, is evidence for something, and therefore stands in relation to\na claim. As long as there is only a single claim in our text, however, there is no need to explicitly\nestablish and represent this relation. Instead, it can just be left implicit. In these cases, sentence\nclassiﬁcation or sequence labeling, as described in the previous chapter for claim detection, is\nalso suﬃcient for identifying evidence.\nBut even when left implicit, the relatedness between claim and evidence can be exploited\nin argumentation mining. For a start, usually one item of evidence is textually adjacent to the\nclaim. Then, the relation may be marked linguistically by a connective such as because. But of\ncourse there can be multiple evidence statements spread across the text. Consider the following\nexample from the ‘argumentative microtext’ corpus [Peldszus and Stede, 2016b], which consists\nof only a claim (marked with a Csubscript) and a set of supporting statements, marked with S.\n(6.2)Should the death penalty be introduced in Germany?\nNo human being or human committee should again be given the permission to rule over\n‘life or death’. S[Courts are also subject to human error. S[That’s why Germany should\nnot introduce capital punishment! C[Every human, even those who have committed a\ndespicable crime, can bring themselves to regret and change their opinion. S[A door\nmust remain open for making amends. S\n(micro_b023)\nHere, the claim contains a phrasal connective ( that’s why ) linking it to the previous supporting\nstatement. The others, however, must be identiﬁed without recurring to such explicit markers.\nIn the rest of this section, we ﬁrst explain an approach that exploits relation marking in\nan interesting indirect way. Then we describe work on evidence detection in Wikipedia pages,\nwhich follows up on the corpus and claim detection of Aharoni et al. [2014] (see Section 5.3.4).\nFinally, we brieﬂy mention again some approaches that were already introduced in the previous\nchapter, as they tackle claim and evidence detection as a uniﬁed task.\n6.1.1 EXPLOITING DISCOURSE RELATION INDICATORS\nWhen the focus is not on classifying claim and evidence individually but on the relation be-\ntween the two, the problem is analogous to that of discourse relation identiﬁcation, as studied\nin frameworks like PDTB [ Prasad et al. ,2008] or RST [ Mann and Thompson, 1988]—recall\nour brief introduction in Section 2.6. The work of Biran and Rambow [2011] focused on ﬁnding\ninstances of the relation of argumentative support, and it targeted two types of web text: Live\nJournalblogthreads(henceforth:LJ)andWikipediatalkpages(WT).Concentratingonﬁnding\nsupporting statements, they assumed the claims as already marked in gold-standard annotated\ndata. For adding the support to the given claims, annotators achieved a \u0014of 0.69.\n\n--- Page 92 ---\n6.1. FINDING SUPPORTING STATEMENTS 79\nBiran and Rambow also oﬀer a classiﬁcation of diﬀerent types of support they found in\nthe data1:\n• Recommendation for action, and motivation for proposed action.\nClaim: “I’d post an update with the new date immediately.”\nJustiﬁcation: “In case anyone makes plans between now and when you post the reminder.”\n• Statement of like or dislike or of desires and longing, and subjective reason for this.\n• Statement of like or dislike or of desires and longing, and claimed objective reason for this.\n• Statement of subjectively perceived fact, with a proposed objective explanation.\n• A claimed general objective statement and a more speciﬁc objective statement that justiﬁes\nthe more general one.\nIn WT, on average there are 2.2 support statements per claim, compared to 1.5 in LJ. As\nfor the position in the threads, in LJ 97.3% are in the same entry as the claim, and 32.4% are\nin the sentence following the claim. In WT, the corresponding numbers are 87.7% and 22.9%.\nHence, looking only at individual entries when mining for support, in WT quite a few will not\nbe found.\nClaim-support relations in text may be explicitly signaled by connectives, or they may be\nonly implicit. For handling the explicit cases, Biran and Rambow compiled a list of connectives\nfrom the annotated RST Discourse Treebank [ Carlson et al. ,2003] (see Section 2.6) and se-\nlected 12 coherencerelationsthat they consideredas likely to correspondto a claim-support con-\nstellation; they are shown in Figure 6.1, together with example connectives (and other phrases)\nthat the authors retrieved from the corpus using a a variant of TF/IDF and a manual ﬁltering\nstep.\nThe resulting set of 69 explicit indicators was then used to indirectly get a handle also on\nimplicit relations. The intuition is that we may expect certain lexical regularities between claim\nand support: When I say something is expensive , I can typically support that with quoting a\nprice; when I suggest that the reader should attend a concert, I might indicate that the music will\nbelovely; and so forth. To establish a dictionary of such word pairs, Biran and Rambow looked\nfor instances of the 69 indicators in a large raw corpus, viz. the standard Wikipedia.2Given the\nbreadth of topics covered in Wikipedia, a potential domain-dependency of extracted word pairs\nis likely to be minimized. For each indicator, word pairs with a frequency >20 are extracted\nfrom sentences in which the indicator occurs.\nFinally, for the target task of ﬁnding claim/support sentences in the LJ and WT corpora,\nBiran/Rambow determined that just using the 69 indicator words does not beat a relatively\nsimplebaseline.Butwhenusingthewordpairslearnedinthepreviousstepasadditionalfeatures,\n1For reasons of space, we reproduce only one of the examples that the authors used to illustrate the classes (p. 364).\n2This is not to be confused with the small Wikipedia Talk pages (WT) corpus, which along with LJ is used for the ultimate\ntask of automatically ﬁnding support statements.\n\n--- Page 93 ---\n80 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\nthe results of a Naive Bayes classiﬁer demonstrate that for both corpora, the large feature set\nclearly beats various baselines, reaching F-measures of 0.47 (LJ) and 0.5 (WT). When training\non one and testing on the other corpus, results are about 0.04–0.05 worse.\nBiran and Rambow [2011] concluded that plain single-sentence classiﬁcation for ﬁnding\nsupport is diﬃcult, but the presence of a claim and its location relative to the support candidate\nare important features that can signiﬁcantly boost performance.\nIn contrast to this decidedly data-driven approach, Eckle-Kohler et al. [2015] started\nfrom a pre-deﬁned list of connectives (and a few other particles) and determined their potential\nutility. Working with a relatively small German corpus (88 documents, mostly news text), the\naim was to determine which connectives correlate with claim, support (before or after the claim),\nand attack (before or after the claim). The before/after distinction is relevant because causal con-\nnectives signal directionality (e.g., ‘claim because support’ vs. ‘support, therefore claim’). German\nconnectives that in the data of Eckle-Kohler et al. frequently occur with claims are also(‘there-\nfore’),doch(‘however’), jedoch(‘though’), and sondern (‘but’); in premises they found denn(‘as’),\noder(‘or’), and und(‘and’). A classiﬁer using such groups of connectives can discriminate be-\ntween claims and premises with accuracies around 0.7, even though a unigram baseline is slightly\nbetter—but obviously using a much larger feature space.\nWhile the important role of connectives is well known, Villalba and Saint-Dizier [2012]\ndirected attention to some diﬀerent means of expressing coherence relations, and pointed out\nthat even non-argumentative coherence relations (i.e., others than those listed in Figure 6.1) can\nacquire an argumentative role when involving evaluative expressions, as they can be found for\nexample in product reviews. They illustrate this with the contrast between:\n(6.3) Red fruit tart (strawberries, raspberries)\n(6.4) Excellent location (3 mns from the Capitole, 5 mns from St Sernin Cathedral,...)\nIn6.3, the coherence relation is Elaboration: The parenthesis provides details on the red fruit.\nIn6.4, we ﬁnd the same surface pattern, also expressing Elaboration, but in addition there is a\nclaim-support constellation, as we are given a positive evaluation (of a hotel), and the elaborating\nmaterial provides good evidence for this.\nIn general, the relationship between discourse structure (as induced by coherence rela-\ntions) on the one hand and argumentation on the other is so far not entirely clear. In addition to\nthe work by Biran and Rambow [2011] and Villalba and Saint-Dizier [2012] mentioned above,\nthe issue is also discussed by Saint-Dizier [2012], Cabrio et al. [2013a], and Peldszus and Stede\n[2016a].\n6.1.2 CLASSIFYING SEGMENTS WITHOUT DISCOURSE CONTEXT\nThe alternative to considering the discourse context is to examine segments in isolation and\ndecide whether they represent evidence for a claim. (e.g., S3 above).\nThe task is to go through all the relevant documents and for each sentence to decide whether it\nconstitutesevidencefortheclaim.(Moreprecisely,sequencesofone,two,andthreesentencesare\nconsidered as instances to be classiﬁed.) The data set for training and testing the system consists\nof274articlesassociatedwith39diﬀerenttopics.Here,3,057sentenceswithcontext-dependent\nevidence were annotated. In the setting here, not all claims are associated with evidence,6but for\nthose that are, on average, a claim is connected to 2.17 evidence statements. 95% of the evidence\nstatements are full sentences.\nArticles\nContext-free S tage\nCoherence\nComponent\nEvidence Characteristic\nComponentTopic and\nRelevant Claims\n \nContext-dependent\nComponent  \n \nClaim Selection\nComponentFilter\nCandidates\nby\nCombined\nScoreRanked\nCandidates for\nSelected Claims\nRanked Candidates with\nRespect to Each Claim\nFigure 6.3: System architecture of evidence detection system based on Rinott et al. [2015, p.\n443].\nRinott et al. devised a modular system architecture shown in Figure 6.3, responding to\nthe observation that a target text segment should satisfy three criteria: it must be coherent; it\nmust have characteristics of the relevant evidence type; and ﬁnally, of course, it must support\nthe claim. Of these, the ﬁrst two aspects are context-independent. In the following, we brieﬂy\ndescribe the corresponding modules of the system.\nThecoherence component makes sure that, for example, there are no unresolved anaphors\nin a sentence and that the ﬁrst sentence does not start with a connective.\nTheevidencecharacteristics component estimates how well the candidate corresponds to\nthedesiredtypeofevidence.Studyevidence,forexample,isstronglyassociatedwithquantitative\nanalysis of data, i.e., the presence of numbers, among other features. Anecdotal evidence is\nexpected to be less semantically related to the corresponding claim, as their relationship may be\nmoreassociativethanfortheStudyorExperttypes.Foreachevidencetype,theauthorsmanually\ncompiled a lexicon of words characterizing this type. Using held-out data, these lexicons were\nautomatically expanded. Other features are named entity types, regular expressions for ﬁnding\nquotations and verb/named entity patterns, and subjectivity.\n6This violates our deﬁnition of ‘argument’, but note that these researchers treat claim and evidence detection as distinct\nresearch tasks.\n\n--- Page 97 ---\n84 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\nThecontext-dependent componentaimstodetectwhetherthecandidateindeedsupports\nthe provided claim in the context of the topic. Hence, it is trained on [topic / claim / evidence]\ntriplets. Four types of features are computed:\n• semantic relatedness between the candidate and the claim;\n• semantic relatedness between text related to the candidate and the claim;\n• relative location of the candidate with respect to the claim; and\n• sentiment agreement between the candidate and the claim.\nHere, semantic relatedness is computed by several methods, including the cosine similarity be-\ntween TF-IDF vectors representing each text (augmented with related words from WordNet)\nand by cosine similarity between word embedding representations of all pairs of words from the\ntwo texts.\nFinally, the claim selection component aims to rank all input claims, according to the\nprobability that evidence can indeed be found amongst top-ranking candidates for the claim. It\nuses a lexicon of ‘claim words’ ( lead,result,development,signiﬁcant, etc.) as well as a more speciﬁc\nlexicon that diﬀerentiates words used in factual claims ( increase, important, relate, etc.) from\nthose in non–factual claims (natural,freedom,right , etc.). The lists were derived from manually-\nannotated claims.\nAll components employ a logistic regression classiﬁer. The evaluation of this multi-\ncomponent pipeline, done by the authors via mean reciprocal ranks, is complex and we do not\nreproduce it here. The authors conclude that assessing both the coherence and the evidence\ncharacteristics of candidates is of great importance. For the context-dependent stage, semantic\nrelatedness turned out as the most valuable feature.\n6.1.3 COMBINED CLAIM/SUPPORT DETECTION\nInSection 5.3,wedescribedafewapproachesthattackledtheidentiﬁcationofclaimandsupport\nsimultaneously. In order to complete our survey on ﬁnding support, we just list these approaches\nand the relevant results again.\n•Palau and Moens [2009] used the same feature set for discriminating claim and support\n(premise) in legal text, reaching an F-score of 0.68 for the premises, which was 0.06 lower\nthan that for claims.\n• The sequence kernel method employed by Rooney et al. [2012] yields much better results\nfor support than for claims; the accuracies are in the area of 0.6, depending on parameter-\nization.\n• The 4-way SVM classiﬁer developed by Stab and Gurevych [2014b] had an F-score of\n0.83 for support, as compared to 0.63 and 0.54 for major claims and claims.\n\n--- Page 98 ---\n6.2. FINDING OPPOSING STATEMENTS 85\n• For the CRF model of Goudas et al. [2014] (IOB tagging for claims and support), no\nclass-speciﬁc results were given.\n• The CRF model of Habernal and Gurevych [2017] obtained slightly better results for\nsupport than for claims, but only when using diﬀerent feature sets.\n• Saint-Dizier’s rule-based approach also fared somewhat better for support than for claims.\nThus, with the exception of the work of Palau and Moens [2009], in these ‘joint’ approaches,\nthe identiﬁcation of support was easier than that of claims.\n6.2 FINDING OPPOSING STATEMENTS\nFor many application scenarios, it is important to ﬁnd both proandcontrapositions on a given\nclaim, or in other words, the arguments andcounterarguments (orattacks). This is the case, inter\nalia, for product evaluations—recall Example 6.1shown at the beginning of the chapter. When\nthecontrais present in the same text as the pro, we call this the ‘opposing view’. It is not un-\ncommon at all—and often advisable from a rhetorical perspective—for an author to anticipate\npotential counterarguments, mention them, and rebut them. (The step of identifying those will\nbe taken up in the next chapter.)\nFor illustration, here is another example from the ‘argumentative microtext’ corpus [Peld-\nszus and Stede, 2016b]; we mark (C)laim, (S)upporting, and (A)ttacking statements.\n(6.5)Should health insurance cover alternative medical therapy?\nHealth insurance companies should naturally cover alternative medical treatments. C\n[Not all practices and approaches that are lumped together under this term may have\nbeen proven in clinical trials, A[yet it’s precisely their positive eﬀect when accompanying\nconventional ’western’ medical therapies that’s been demonstrated as beneﬁcial. S\n[Besides many general practitioners oﬀer such counselling and treatments in parallel\nanyway – S[and who would want to question their broad expertise? S\n(micro_b013)\nThe author states her position up front, and then continues with a concession: there are some\nlegitimate objections to her position (or there is at least this one). However, she considers this\nobjection as being outweighed by the supporting material she then adds to complete her argu-\nment. In student essays, including such considerations is typically regarded positively by evalua-\ntors (the issue of avoiding the myside bias ). But we ﬁnd the technique in many other genres too,\nsuch as in court decisions, where the judge might concede that the defendant is right on one\nparticular count, but still deserves punishment on the grounds of other, more weighty, factors.\nUsing the terms ‘objection’ or ‘attack’ for these cases may be a bit misleading, because\nauthors rarely intend to attack themselves or argue with themselves; instead, they ‘imagine’ an\nopponent and the confrontation. We thus follow Govier [2011] and henceforth use the cover\ntermcounter-considerations for these phenomena.\n\n--- Page 99 ---\n86 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\nWhen the detection of counter-considerations is operationalized as in the annotations\nof Example 6.5above, the computational task remains essentially the same as in the previous\nsection and merely adds a new class (in our example: A) to a premise/conclusion classiﬁer. Some\nannotation schemes, however, go a step further and distinguish between two forms of counter-\nconsideration: the rebuttal and the undercutter.\nPeldszus and Stede [2013], who described the scheme underlying the ‘microtext’ corpus,\nillustrate the distinction with these examples.\n(6.6) We should tear the building down. C[It is full of asbestos. S[On the other hand, many\npeople liked the view from the roof. R\n(6.7) We should tear the building down. C[It is full of asbestos. S[The building might be\ncleaned up, though. U\nIn6.6, the third statement ‘rebuts’ the conclusion by making a point that would invalidate the\nproposal of tearing the building down; it thus questions the validity of the conclusion. In con-\ntrast, the third statement of Example 6.7is directed toward the second (supporting) statement.\nIt does not question the validity of the statement “full of asbestos” (i.e., it does not rebut it), but\nit questions the relevance of the support for the conclusion: Yes, there is asbestos, but that can\nbe removed, and therefore we do not need to demolish the building. This is called an ‘undercut’\non the relation between S and C.\nNotice that in authentic text, a speaker should produce some sort of continuation to Ex-\nample6.6or6.7, so that a coherent and strong argument results. Speciﬁcally, the rebutter and\nundercutter need in turn to be countered. This leads to conﬁgurations of ‘counterattack’, which\nwe do not elaborate on here; the reader is referred to Peldszus and Stede [2013, sct. 2.2.4] for a\ncomparative analysis of various cases.\n‘Microtexts’ and newspaper editorials In his approach to parsing the argumentation struc-\nture of (the German version of) texts in the microtext corpus, Peldszus [2014] operationalized\nthe task with a hierarchical tag set, where the ﬁrst distinction is for an argumentative text seg-\nment to be stated from the ‘proponent’ or the ‘opponent’ role: either the author advances her\nown viewpoint, or temporarily adopts that of the imagined opponent and produces a counter-\nconsideration. Using a common feature set, role identiﬁcation turned out to be the subtask yield-\ning the best results (micro-F of 0.85 using a MaxEnt classiﬁer). As opponent-statements are\nobviously relatively rare (22% in this dataset) it is instructive to also consider the \u0014, which was\n0.52. The most predictive features were lemma unigrams and discourse connectives. The latter is\nnot too surprising, because switching the perspective to an imagined opponent (and then back\nagain) needs to be clearly signaled at the text surface, and contrastive connectives like butoreven\nthough are one standard way of doing that. In the sample text shown above as Example 6.5, the\nswitch signal is yetin the third segment.\nAfter some feature improvements, slightly better results ( \u0014=0.55, macro-F=0.77) were\nobtained in Peldszus and Stede [2015b]. The authors compare the results to those for a corpus\n\n--- Page 100 ---\n6.3. IDENTIFYING STANCE 87\nof German newspaper editorials (124 texts), where the results are considerably lower: \u0014=0.32,\nmacro-F=0.66; the F-score for opponent class was only 0.38. This low performance is attributed\nprimarily to the presence of longer sequences of opponent-role segments in the editorials—where\na signal of perspective switching is typically present only in the ﬁrst segment of such a sequence.\nThe microtexts, on the other hand, are simply too short for such sequences to play a role.\nStudentessays A proponent/opponent distinction is also made by Stab and Gurevych [2014a]\nin their corpus of student essays (see Section 5.3.3). The 429 segments annotated as claim have\nan additional attribute ‘for’ (365) or ‘against’ (64). The stance of the premises is not labeled cor-\nrespondingly, but in principle it can be inferred from the relational structure of the annotations.\nIn total, there are 1,473 relations annotated, of which 161 are of the attacking type. However,\ndue to the relatively low proportion, the authors restricted their automatic classiﬁcation to the\n‘for’ claims and the ‘support’ relations.\nIn follow-up work, Stab and Gurevych [2016] addressed the question of absence of the\nopposing view in essays, as this is relevant for essay grading. They did not address segments in-\ndividually but classiﬁed the complete essays as containing opposing material or not. In their cor-\npus of 402 essays, the opposing view was present in 151 (38%) of all texts. Their SVM classiﬁer\nobtained an accuracy of 0.77; lexical unigrams, syntactic productions, and adversative connec-\ntives turned out as the most predictive features, whereas sentiment and other discourse features\ndid not help.\nWebtext Theannotationschemeof HabernalandGurevych [2017](cf.Section 5.3.5),derived\nfrom the Toulmin model, contains ‘rebuttal’ for opposing material (they do not distinguish it\nfrom undercut), and ‘refutation’ for the counter-attack by the author. In their web text corpus,\nonly 8% of the documents present a rebuttal (attacked by refutation in 4% of the documents).\nIn their IOB tagging experiments, it turned out that their system performs very bad for the\nrebuttal and refutation categories (e.g., F-scores of 0.037 and 0.118 for rebuttal-B and rebuttal-\nI, respectively). The authors attribute this to a corresponding low human agreement on the one\nhand, and to the small amount of data on the other.\n6.3 IDENTIFYING STANCE\nStance detection is an NLP task in its own right that has given rise to several shared tasks, in-\ncluding one for Chinese tweets [Xu et al., 2016] and one for English ones. The organizers of\nthe latter deﬁned the task as follows [Mohammad et al., 2016, p. 31].\nGiven a tweet text and a target entity (person, organization, movement, policy, etc.),\nautomatic natural language systems must determine whether the tweeter is in favor\nof the given target, against the given target, or whether neither inference is likely.\nFor example, consider the target-tweet pair:\n•Target: Legalization of abortion.\n\n--- Page 101 ---\n88 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\n•Tweet: The pregnant are more than walking incubators, and have rights!\nWe can infer from the tweet that the tweeter is likely in favor of the target.\nA connection to argumentation mining is evident in the analysis of online debates. In the most\nsystematic cases of debate, the two-sided ones, a statement or claim is presented, and debaters\nposition themselves explicitly on the ‘for’ or ‘against’ side, and ideally state arguments supporting\ntheir stance. This setting provides convenient train/test data for automatic classiﬁcation.\nAnother genre that has received some attention is news text; Ferreira and Vlachos [2016],\nfor example, present a classiﬁer for news headlines that tries to predict the stance toward the\nclaim made in the article.\nBut systems performing for/against classiﬁcation can be employed in less regulated set-\ntings, too. For instance, a system aiming at retrieving arguments on a particular topic (‘target’)\nfrom general web text needs to ﬁrst identify texts that are on topic and are argumentative; then,\nin order to identify the argument components and their roles, it can be helpful to know the\ngeneral orientation of the text—the author’s stance. And recall the point made at the beginning\nof Section 5.3: very often an argumentative text does not explicitly state its central claim. De-\npending on the speciﬁc application, stance detection may then serve as a way of inducing the\nimplicit claim in a reduced form, i.e., as a for/against label. For these reasons, in the following\nwe brieﬂy point to some relevant stance detection research.\nOnlinedebates The early work of Somasundaran and Wiebe [2009] used Integer Linear Pro-\ngramming (ILP) to determine the stance of posts from the debate site Convinceme.net. The\ndebates in their corpus are restricted to be two-sided as well as oriented to two targets: posts\neither favor one product or one speciﬁc competitor ( Blackberry vs.Iphone, etc.). In this setting,\nconcessions are relatively frequent: An author grants the ‘opposing’ product some advantage,\nbut then gives more weighty arguments for the favored product. Therefore, discourse features\ncentering on the Concession relation were exploited by Somasundaran and Wiebe, in addition\nto topic and subjectivity clues extracted from the training data.\nAnand et al. [2011], working with the same data source, emphasized the role of rebuttals\nin the interactions, which according to the authors should be treated diﬀerently from agreeing\nresponses. Figure 6.4shows a sample exchange where the three follow-up posts all are rebutting\ntheir predecessors. With Naive Bayes and decision tree classiﬁers employing a range of linguistic\nfeatures, the authors were able to identify rebuttals with 63% accuracy, and the stance with\naccuraciesbetween54%and69%,dependingonthetopic.Ageneralinsightwasthattherebuttal\nposts are harder to identify, both for human raters and for the classiﬁers.\nPicking up the work of Anand et al., Hasan and Ng [2013] suggested moving beyond the\nlanguage of the post, to also take aspects of the interaction into account. Their data is from a\ndiﬀerent website, createdebate.com, and comprises ‘ideological’ debates on four topics: abortion,\ngay rights, Obama, and marijuana. The authors propose two features.\n\n--- Page 102 ---\n6.3. IDENTIFYING STANCE 89\nFigure 6.4: Discussion posts with rebut links from Convinceme.net [Anand et al., 2011, p. 1],\nused with permission.\n•Interactionpatterns: In the data, stance labels of the posts in a sequence are not indepen-\ndent of each other: 80% of the time, a post is followed by a reply with opposite polarity. The\nauthors trained a CRF model on sequences and used it to predict such stance sequences\non the test data.\n•Ideology patterns: The opinion of an author on one topic is not independent of his or\nher opinion on another topic. Thus, for posts written by the same author, the informa-\ntion gathered from other posts can be used. Hasan and Ng modeled this as conditional\nprobabilities reﬂecting that, for instance, a pro stance on gay rights correlates with being\npro-marijuana.\nNotice that both of these features might be less helpful with less heated debate topics. But\nnonetheless, Hasan and Ng show how the two types of constraints can be combined in an ILP\ninference problem, and they demonstrate that both constraints improve overall system perfor-\nmance, which altogether beats a reimplementation of the linguistic approach of Anand et al.\n[2011] by 8–14 percentage points, depending on the domain. Later on, Hasan and Ng [2014]\nused their stance identiﬁcation results to better predict classes of reasons given for an argument\n(see Section 6.1.2).\nQiu and Jiang [2013] worked with English and Chinese debate data sets, and were also\ninterested in utilizing user interaction patterns for determining stance. In their unsupervised\n\n--- Page 103 ---\n90 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\nFigure 6.5: Topics mentioned in debate posts by ‘for’ (viewpoint 1) and ‘against’ users (viewpoint\n2) [Qiu and Jiang ,2013, p. 1032], used with permission.\napproach, they built a complete network representing the ‘for’/‘against’ groups of users and the\nsupport/attack relations among them, as computed via their posts. Their main focus, however,\nwas to also pay attention to the topics mentioned in the posts, following the intuition that given\na contentious issue, the ‘for’ users tend to discuss diﬀerent aspects of that issue than the ‘against’\nusers do. Figure 6.5illustrates the idea by giving the distribution of seven topics addressed by\nusers discussing whether to vote for or against Obama. The three factors—topic distribution,\nuser identity, and user interaction—are combined in a latent variable model inspired by Latent\nDirichlet Allocation [Blei et al. ,2003]. The accuracies for stance identiﬁcation range from 60–\n81% depending on the language and data set.\nFinally, we mention the work by Sridhar et al. [2014], which combines linguistic and net-\nwork structure features and proposes to jointly infer the stance labels by means of a probabilistic\nsoft logic (PSL) model [ Bach et al., 2013]. They used data from the Internet Argument Corpus\n(see Section 4.2.1), addressing topics similar to those mentioned above, and demonstrated—in\nline with the above-mentioned work—that accounting for both types of information outper-\nforms a linguistics-only model. An interesting feature of the PSL approach is that weights of\nsymbolic rules are learned, which can be inspected and exploited for error analysis (in contrast\nto the majority of ‘black box’ machine learning approaches).\nStudent essays Besides online debate posts, another interesting genre for stance classiﬁca-\ntion is argumentative student essays that were written in response to a prompt inviting a ‘for’\nor ‘against’ opinion. Faulkner [2014] presented an approach to compute the essay-level stance\nautomatically, which uses two key ingredients.\n\n--- Page 104 ---\n6.3. IDENTIFYING STANCE 91\n• Scoring essay words for being on-topic: Faulkner uses a Wikipedia link-based measure to\ncompute the similarity between words in the essay and words in the essay’s prompt.\n• Parse trees for detecting stance expressions: With the help of a dependency parser and two\nlexical resources of stance words and attitudinal words (both taken from earlier research),\nFaulkner extracts parse subtrees that can be associated with a stance-attitude proﬁle. This\nrecords a positive/negative evaluation of a for/against stance expressed in the sentence.\nTrees are generalized by means of their PoS labels.\nThe train/test data set consist of 1,135 stance-annotated essays from the International Corpus\nof Learner English (ICLE) [ Granger ,2003]. Faulkner demonstrates that an SVM trained on\nthe topic-word model easily outperforms two baselines: bag-of-words and an implementation\nof the best-performing linguistic features from the earlier work of Somasundaran and Wiebe\n(see page 88). Adding the subtree features yields another—if slight—improvement, resulting in\nan overall accuracy of 82%.\nTopic-claim constellations The team developing the IBM argumentative structure dataset\n[Aharoni et al., 2014] also added stance annotation to their data. As we explained in Sec-\ntion5.3.4, their corpus was built by selecting debate topics from idebate.org and manually\nﬁnding claim and evidence statements in Wikipedia articles. The version of this corpus used\nbyBar-Haim et al. [2017] encompasses 55 topics and 2,394 claims. (Examples were given in\nFigure5.4on page 72.) By deﬁnition, all claims in the dataset either support or contest the topic,\nand the new annotations make this explicit. Bar-Haim et al. decompose the automatic stance\ndetection task into three subtasks.\n1. Identify the targetsof the given topic and claim. Targets (or ‘aspects’) are phrases that have\nbeen given a positive or negative evaluation by the author.\n2. For each target, identify the polarity (sentiment) that is expressed toward it.\n3. Determine whether targets are ‘consistent’ (have the same polarity orientation) or ‘con-\ntrastive’; this can involve interpreting the targets and their relationship.\nForlabelingthedata,eachofthe55topicsreceivedtargetandpolarityannotationfromthe\nauthors, and then annotators marked targets and sentiment in all the claims, and also added the\nconsistent/contrastive relation. The claim stance is then derived automatically. A few examples\nof this annotation are shown in Figure 6.6, with the relation denoted by ,and¼, and claim\nstance given in the rightmost column.\nThevariousstepswerethenimplementedassupervisedclassiﬁcationtasks,andtheauthors\nclaim that their decomposed approach beats monolithic stance classiﬁcation.\n\n--- Page 105 ---\n92 6. FINDING SUPPORTING AND OBJECTING STATEMENTS\nFigure 6.6: Sample topic, claim, target, and stance annotations in the IBM dataset [Bar-Haim\net al.,2017, p. 254], used with permission.\n\n--- Page 106 ---\n93\nC H A P T E R 7\nDeriving the Structure of\nArgumentation\nThe tasks explained in the previous two chapters were to label the components of an argument\nand, along the way, to identify spans of text that are not part of the argument. We illustrate this\nwith an extended version of Example 6.1, using the subscripts C, S, A for claim, support, attack:\n(7.1) Last week I bought this new camera here. [You should also buy it,] C[because it has a\nbrand-new excellent sensor.] SIt’s sold in the tech store around the corner. [OK, it is\nquite expensive.] A[But it’s worth the money!] S\nFor some purposes and for some texts, being able to do this is suﬃcient. Sometimes,\nhowever, it is not enough.\nAssume that a text tries to persuade the reader not of one but of multiple diﬀerent claims\nand provides the accompanying arguments. Now a ﬂat labeling is insuﬃcient because we need to\nknow which argument components relate to each other: what supports what; what attacks what.\nNow we need to establish explicitrelations between components, so that the correct mapping can\nbe captured. Hence, in Section 7.1we look at the task of identifying relations between argument\ncomponents, which may be diﬀerent kinds of support and attack.\nSome approaches go a step further and aim at combining the various components of argu-\nments and the relations between them into an overarching structuralrepresentation, which is the\ntopic of Section 7.2. This is necessary for correctly capturing more complex arguments where,\nfor instance, a statement supports the claim not directly but only indirectly via an additional\nstatement; likewise, when several objections are being mentioned and refuted, the task is to ap-\npropriately record the attack and counterattack relationships and to show how they combine\ninto a coherent argumentation structure.\n7.1 ESTABLISHING RELATIONS BETWEEN ARGUMENT\nCOMPONENTS\nWhile in the previous chapters, we dealt with the task of identifying argumentative units and\nlabeling them with their roles, we now turn to a relation -based perspective, which addresses this\ntask:\n\n--- Page 107 ---\n94 7. DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\nGiven two statements, determine the argumentative relation between them, such as:\nDoes one support orattackthe other?\nOne practical motivation for taking this perspective stems from the analysis of multi-party in-\nteractions, where utterances by diﬀerent speakers can be classiﬁed as being in agreement (cor-\nresponding to one utterance supporting the other) or in disagreement (one attacking the other).\nBut also when processing monologue text, relation identiﬁcation can be important, as we\nargued in the introduction above. As soon as we cannot assume that the text in question contains\njust a single argument with no internal sub-structure (or when it is not relevant to account for\nthat sub-structure), we need to explicitly mark the relations between argumentative units.\nThe dialogue and monologue settings obviously diﬀer from each other: statements are\ntaken from the utterances of diﬀerent speakers, vs. from a single, coherent text. Thus, it can be\nassumed that the linguistic form is not the same, and that somewhat diﬀerent approaches or\nfeature sets are relevant. We will discuss the two settings in turn.\n7.1.1 DISAGREEMENT IN ONLINE INTERACTIONS\nTracing the back and forth of argumentative exchanges in online interactions is a very attractive\nbut at the same time quite ambitious goal. To date, no complete solutions have been proposed\nto our knowledge, but there has been work on the initial step of identifying relations between\nindividual statements. Depending on the background (interaction analysis or argumentation\nmining), authors describe their aim either to classify agreement vs. disagreement, or support vs.\nattack (which amounts essentially to the same problem).\nAsanalyzingonlineinteractionsisobviouslyofgreatpracticalrelevance,severalcorpusan-\nnotationeﬀorts have been undertaken. Welisted some of the available resourcesin Section 4.2.1,\nincluding the information on download links. In the following, we look at work that involves\nthose resources and uses diﬀerent techniques to ﬁnd an argumentative relation.\nTextual entailment Some researchers noted the similarity between the task of establishing a\nsupport relation and that of RecognizingTextualEntailment (RTE), which is commonly deﬁned\nas follows: “A text Tentails a hypothesis Hif humans reading Twould typically infer that H\nis most likely true” [ Dagan et al., 2013, p. 3]. Notice the reliance on human judgment and the\ndiﬀerence from strict logical entailment. TE is a fairly broad relation, covering also, for instance,\nphysical causation, but it might be considered as subsuming argumentative support.\nCabrio and Villata [2012] tested how well an existing RTE tool (EDITS, Kouylekov and\nNegri[2010]), which applies an edit-distance measure, performs with pairs of argumentative\nstatements gathered from Debatepedia and labeled with support/attack relations. EDITS was\ntrained on 100 pairs and tested on 100 pairs. The authors reported a fairly promising accuracy\nof 0.67.\n\n--- Page 108 ---\n7.1. ESTABLISHING RELATIONS BETWEEN ARGUMENT COMPONENTS 95\nIn the same spirit, Boltužić and Šnajder [2014] used the Excitement open RTE platform1\n[Padó et al. ,2015] for classifying the relation between (manually created) argumentative state-\nments and comments in the the ComArg corpus (see Section 4.2.1), expecting the comment text\n(which is usually longer) to entail the argument phrase. The classiﬁcation is more diﬃcult than\nin the other work reported here, as it uses ﬁve classes: explicit attack, implicit attack, explicit\nsupport, implicit support, and none. Excitement supplies seven diﬀerent algorithms based on\ndiﬀerent types of information. Boltužić and Šnajder used the outputs (decisions and conﬁdence\nvalues) of all seven algorithms as the features in their classiﬁer, in addition to semantic similarity.\nThe RTE approach was the more successful component, contributing an overall performance of\n0.7 to a 0.82 micro-F in diﬀerent problem settings (SVM classiﬁer).\nRecently, Bosc et al. [2016a] ran a similar experiment and applied Excitement to the\nDART corpus [ Bosc et al. ,2016b], which contains 4000 Tweets dealing with four diﬀerent\ntopics. They have been annotated pairwise with support/attack relations. Trying to predict the\nreations with the RTE platform leads to negative results, however.\nInteractional structure For threaded data, features of the structure of the interaction have\nbeen found to be useful. Rosenthal and McKeown [2015], for example, experimented success-\nfully with meta-thread information in the IAC, ABCD, and AWTP data (see Section 4.2.1),\nsuch as the distance from the ﬁrst post, the post coming from the same or a diﬀerent author,\nand the length of the post.\nWhen looking at longer stretches of conversation, it can make sense to diﬀerentiate the lo-\ncal stance in a single post from the globalposition a user has on an issue. Yin et al. [2012] showed\nthat in their web forum thread data, aggregating the local positions over a user’s posts leads to\nbetter performance than no-aggregation baselines. Mukherjee and Liu [2013] added another\nshift of perspective and modeled the dis/agreement behavior of individual user pairs, thus ab-\nstracting from the task of classifying individual Question-Response pairs to pairs of sets of user\nutterances. They use topic modeling and relevance-based ranking to derive phrases indicative of\ndis/agreement as their mean features.\nLexical and linguistic features Various researchers showed that linguistically-motivated fea-\ntures can beat simple lexical n-gram models for dis/agreement classiﬁcation. For instance, the\nfeature analysis of Yin et al. [2012], who used a logistic regression model, suggested that sen-\ntiment, emotional and durational features can signiﬁcantly improve classiﬁer performance. In a\nsimilar vein, Abbott et al. [2011] worked with an early version of the Internet Argument Cor-\npus (see Section 4.2.1) and measured the relative importance of a broad range of features for\ndis/agreement detection. They found that it is important to use local features (e.g., initial n-\ngrams for approximating discourse markers such as Idon’tknow and dependency triples) of both\nthequoteandtheresponse,ratherthanfocusingontheresponsealone.Infollow-upwork,Misra\n1https://hltfbk.github.io/Excitement-Open-Platform/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 109 ---\n96 7. DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\nand Walker [2013] emphasized the importance of ﬁnding topic-neutral features, in particular\npunctuation and cue words, for cross-domain performance of the models.\nGhosh et al. [2014] used a support vector machine to classify the agree/disagree relation\non the callout/target annotation in technically-oriented blogs from technorati.com (see Sec-\ntion4.2.1). A ‘callout’ is a statement that challenges another statement (by a diﬀerent user), the\n‘target’. The authors achieved F-scores of 0.67 and 0.63 for the agree and disagree category, re-\nspectively, using a sentiment lexicon, initial unigrams in the callout, and lexical overlap between\ncallout and target. Lexical overlap is one way to capture semantic similarity between statements,\nwhich has also been modeled by other researchers, including Boltužić and Šnajder [2014], as a\ndomain-independent measurement.\nFollowing an idea from Mukherjee and Liu [2013], Rosenthal and McKeown [2015]\ndeveloped the notion of similarity further and worked with a theoretical motivation of ‘accom-\nmodation’, i.e., the phenomenon of interlocutors adopting the conversational characteristics of\nother participants as the conversation progresses. Thus, for dis/agreement detection in the IAC,\nABCD and AWTP data (see Section 4.2.1), they used a sentence similarity tool measuring\nword/phrase overlap between Question and Response, and also computed the similarity of PoS\nn-gram overlap, the presence of social media-speciﬁc lexical material, and the distribution of\nLIWC2categories. Their results run up to an F-score of 0.78 for the ABCD corpus, and they\nprovide interesting comparative analyses of the three datasets.\nNeuralnetworks Wementionedabovethat Boscetal. [2016a]soughttodetermineattackand\nsupport relations between tweets, and found that the task is very diﬃcult when using an RTE\nplatform. In addition, the authors implemented a neural approach running on tokens encoded\nas GloVe embeddings [ Pennington et al. ,2014]. With an encoder-decoder architecture and\ntwo LSTMs (the second LSTM initialized with the last hidden state of the ﬁrst LSTM), they\nobtained results that also seem not promising (0.2 F-score for support and 0.16 for attack).\nThis work inspired Cocarascu and Toni [2017a] to try a similar approach on a set of 2,274\nsentence pairs, which are taken apparently from newspaper text, but the source is not speciﬁed\n[CarstensandToni ,2015].Whilethisdatadoesnotstemfromonlineinteraction,itissomewhat\nsimilar to the Twitter data above, in that it contains isolated sentence pairs. ESTABLISHING RELATIONS BETWEEN ARGUMENT COMPONENTS 97\nFigure 7.1: Sample sentence pairs and attack/support/none annotations from Carstens and Toni\n[2015, p. 33], used with permission.\n7.1.2 ARGUMENTATIVE RELATIONS IN MONOLOGUE\nAs we indicated at the beginning of the chapter, when mining arguments in monologue text, a\nﬂat labeling of argumentative roles is not suﬃcient if\n• more than one claim is present, and support/attack material must be linked to the associ-\nated claim; or\n• support and attack are directed not toward the claim but toward other argument compo-\nnents.\nThe second scenario holds for example in the case of ‘serial support’ (a transitive support con-\nstellation), as in the following example.\n(7.2) Vaccines are bad for kids! 1[They can cause all sorts of allergy problems. 2[A recent\nstudy reported a siginiﬁcant increase in allergic skin irritations. 3\nHere segment 1 represents the claim, which is supported by segment 2. Segment 3, however\ndoes not directly support the main claim, but provides evidence for segment 2, which thus plays\nboth the roles of support (for 1) and a minor claim (for 3).\nSimilarly, as we indicated in the previous chapter, once counter-considerations are ad-\nmitted to the argument analysis, it is very likely that ‘counter-attack’ enters the picture, since a\nspeaker probably is not going to let a possible objection just stand as is. Then, the counter-attack\nis obviously directed to the counter-consideration.\n(7.3) Vaccines are bad for kids! 1[I’ve seen some reports claiming tremendous infection\nreduction rates, 2[but those must have been sponsored by the pharmaceutical industry. 3\nHere, segment 2 is a counter-consideration to claim 1, yet it is immediately rejected by 3. In\nsimilar ways, it is possible for a speaker to give a counter-consideration and then to add potential\nevidence to it, before dismissing the entire move by means of a counter-attack.\n\n--- Page 111 ---\n98 7. DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\nGenerally,weareheremoving toward recursion inargumentativestructure.Wewill discuss\nthis in more detail in the next section on identifying full structures, but for now, establishing\nindividual relations between components is a central intermediate step. The task is essentially\nthe same as that described above for dialogue: given a pair of argumentative units, classify their\nrelationship as support, attack, or none (or some more ﬁne-grained subclasses of support and\nattack, but in practice that is only rarely done).\nNote that the extraction of semantic/pragmatic relations is well known in other branches\nof NLP, too. Most often, the focus is on relations between entities, but sometimes, relations\nbetween events are also being considered (for example, causal relations in biomedical text, as\nin the BioCause corpus.4) Furthermore, as we mentioned in Section 2.6and elsewhere, the\nautomatic identiﬁcation of discourse relations, for instance along the lines of the Penn Discourse\nTreebank [Prasad et al., 2008] is a well-known task. In the following, however, we only report\nwork that has been explicitly geared toward argumentation.\nRule-basedidentiﬁcation In the early work of Palau and Moens [2009] on legal documents,\nclassiﬁers were used for ﬁnding argumentative sentences and determining their role, as we re-\nported above. Connections between the components are then established by means of a context-\nfree grammar that checks for predeﬁned cue words and punctuation symbols, identiﬁes the non-\nterminal constituents as premises or conclusions, and joins them in a recursive tree structure. The\nevaluation yielded an accuracy of 60%. However, it is very diﬃcult to adapt the approach to other\ndomains, especially if the role of conventionalized, formulaic expressions is limited.\nFeature-based classiﬁcation Working with texts from the argumentative microtext corpus\n(see Section 4.2.2), Peldszus [2014] operationalized relation detection as a combination of clas-\nsifying the argumentative function of an ADU in isolation (thesis, support, attack) and the dis-\ntance to the target unit, i.e., the unit being supported or attacked. Since the texts are short (on\naverage, roughly 5 units), this usually ranges between -4 (four units to the left of the classiﬁed\none) and +4 (four units to the right). Peldszus used lexical, morphosyntactic, positional, and cue\n(connectives, negation) features and experimented with a variety of classiﬁers. He found that a\nNaive Bayes approach worked best for the support/attack/thesis distinction (F-measure 0.74)\nas well as for a more ﬁne-grained version that distinguishes ‘normal’ from ‘example’ support\nand ‘undercut’ from ‘rebut’ (F-measure 0.67). Connectives, lemma n-grams, and dependencies\nturned out to be the most helpful features. Finding the right target, however, proved to be very\ndiﬃcult,andthusinfollow-upwork, PeldszusandStede [2015a]insteadusedanout-of-the-box\ndiscourse parser [Baldridge et al., 2007] for predicting segment attachment, reaching a macro-F\nmeasure of 0.73, with F being 0.56 for positive attachment.\nA similar result was obtained by Stab and Gurevych [2014b] for the more complex texts\nin the corpus of persuasive student essays (see Section 4.2.2). For illustration, here is an excerpt\n4http://www.nactem.ac.uk/biocause/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 112 ---\n7.1. ESTABLISHING RELATIONS BETWEEN ARGUMENT COMPONENTS 99\nfrom such a text. Subscripts show the unit number, the relation type and target (if any), and the\nargumentative function.\n(7.4) People who are addicted to games, especially online games, can eventually bear\ndangerous consequences. 1IClaim [Although it is undeniable that computer is a crucial\npart of human life, 2>3IP remise [it still has its bad side. 3IMajorClaim\nThe approach disregarded the attack relation and thus solved the binary task of classifying pairs\nof segments as to whether one is in support relation with the other or not.5Using similar fea-\ntures as Peldszus [2014], but adding also word pairs of the two segments, and the results of an\nargumentative-function classiﬁer (which assigned the labels Claim, Major Claim, Premise), this\nled to a macro F-score of 0.72, and 0.52 for positive attachment.\nTopic modeling On the same essay corpus, Nguyen and Litman [2016] also addressed the\nsupport detection task, using the same corpus setup as Stab and Gurevych. For non-/support,\nthey re-implemented and slightly expanded the feature set, obtaining roughly the same results,\nwhich served as a baseline. Then, Nguyen and Litman showed that their technique of LDA-\nbased diﬀerentiation between ‘argument words’ and ‘domain words’, which we described above\nin Section 5.3.3, can lead to superior results. They used the presence of argument words as binary\nfeatures, and several features measuring the domain word overlap between the two segments.\nHere is an example, with argument words in bold face and domain words in italics [ Nguyen and\nLitman, 2016, p. 1131].\n(7.5) Essay 54. Topic: museum and art gallery will disappear soon?\nSource/premise: moreandmore people can watch exhibitions through television or\ninternet athomedue tomodern technology\nTarget/claim: some people think museums andart galleries willdisappear soon\nWhile adding topic features does not beat the baseline, signiﬁcantly better results (macro-F:\n0.75)areachievedwhenalsoaddingtheoutputoftwodiscourseparsers(oneforPDTBrelations,\none for RST structure, both of which have been introduced in Section 2.6).\nIn addition, Nguyen and Litman classiﬁed the relation type (support/attack), assuming\nthat a relation between two segments has also been established. The best results were achieved\nwith the same combination of features as in the ﬁrst task, with a macro-F of 0.7. Note, though,\nthe huge diﬀerence between the F-score for support (0.94) and for attack (0.4).\nSome other researchers experimented with topic modeling features, too. Lawrence et al.\n[2014], for example, measured topical distance between argumentative units in philosophical\npapers, thus targeting a much harder type of text. However, the method was only evaluated on\na very small data set and thus cannot be compared with the other research.\n5Hence, ‘no support’ subsumes both the cases of attack and zero relation.\n\n--- Page 113 ---\n100 7. DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\n7.2 IDENTIFYING COMPLETE ARGUMENT\nSTRUCTURES\nHaving considered all the prerequisite subtasks, we are now well prepared to study approaches\nthat are interested in identifying the complete structures of arguments. Notice, however, that we\nrestrict the discussion here to individual arguments—or, in the terminology of Bentahar et al.\n[2010], to the micro-level of argumentation. In contrast, the macro-level , which would represent\nrelationships between diﬀerent arguments (possibly across diﬀerent documents), is out of our\nscope.\nGiven the variety of approaches to the subtasks we surveyed thus far, it does not come as\na surprise that—in this young research ﬁeld—there is no general consensus on what exactly is\nan appropriate description of an argument’s structure. But we can identify a few general lines of\nresearch. First of all, it is important to distinguish between these.\n•Hierarchical structure: Text segments are identiﬁed as argumentative units, these are\nbeing related to one another and ultimately to the single claim, yielding a graph structure;\nand\n•Sequential structure: Any argument in text is presented in a certain linear order of the\nunits, which inﬂuences rhetorical (and possibly even logical) felicity.\nHierarchical structure, by design, abstracts linear order away, and provides an extract that serves\nto represent the ‘logos’ dimension6of argumentation, i.e., the inferential relations of statements\nsupporting (or attacking) another. In contrast, linear order is closely related to ‘pathos’, the\npersuasive eﬀects intended by the speaker. So far, most work in structure derivation has concen-\ntrated on hierarchy. We will discuss these approaches ﬁrst, and then come back to the sequential\nstructure at the end of the section.\n7.2.1 COMPUTING HIERARCHICAL STRUCTURE\nAs stated in Section 4.1, the prevalent conception for representing (and annotating) argument\nstructure is that of a tree rooted in the central claim of the text. Besides purely theoretical con-\nsiderations, evidence for this stems from data analysis and from experiences with annotation\npractice. For instance, Lawrence et al. [2014, p. 81] point out that “in many cases an argument\ncan be represented as a tree. This assumption is supported by around 95% of the argument anal-\nyses contained in AIFdb [ Lawrence et al., 2012] as well as the fact that many manual analysis\ntools (...) limit the user to a tree format.” A sample tree from the argumentative microtext corpus\n(see Section 4.2.2) is shown below in Figure 7.2.\nIn contrast, the annotation of eRulemaking comments by Niculae et al. [2017] regards\ntrees as unsuitable for capturing the argumentation structure in less well-organized texts. In the\n6Recall the logos/pathos/ethos dimensions described on page 5.\n\n--- Page 114 ---\n7.2.
