DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\nfollowing, we ﬁrst look at diﬀerent ways that have been proposed for computing trees, and in\nthe end brieﬂy describe Niculae et al.’s approach to predicting graphs.\nRule-basedparsing The early rule-based work by Palau and Moens [2009] (cf. Section 5.3.1)\ncomputedpremise-conclusiontrees,withanadditionalunittype‘decision’,bymeansofacontext\nfree grammar (CFG) model. The resulting trees can include serial support as well as convergent\nstructures. Relation types are not represented in the tree, however. The other grammar-driven\napproach that we have mentioned before (Section 5.3.2) is that of Saint-Dizier [2012]: Using a\nlogic- and constraint-based grammar language, which was designed to extend linguistic analysis\nfrom the level of sentence to that of discourse, his system determines the boundaries of various\ntypes of spans and produces embedded structures.\nTemplate slot ﬁlling When the target representation is a predeﬁned set of (possibly related)\ncomponents, the analysis can be framed as a slot-ﬁlling process. Recall the Modiﬁed Toulmin\nScheme used by Habernal and Gurevych [2017], which was illustrated on page 49. When deﬁn-\ning which components are obligatory and which are optional (and possibly, which ones can occur\nmultiple times), these expectations can be used to guide the assignment of argumentative units\nto component types (or ‘slots’ in the schema). Habernal and Gurevych, however, used a diﬀerent\nparadigm, to be descibed next.\nSegment-wise classiﬁcation A classiﬁcation-based approach can be applied to a pre-deﬁned\nsequence of segments, or it can combine segmentation and labeling decisions. The latter was im-\nplemented in the IOB tagging approaches of Goudas et al. [2014] and Habernal and Gurevych\n[2017] (see Section 5.3.5). Of these, Habernal and Gurevych used a much richer type set (that\nof the Modiﬁed Toulmin Scheme) and thus produced a ‘full’ argument structure in the sense of\na pre-deﬁned set of components. Notice that recursion is not accounted for in such a tagging\nregime; there is no serial support, for instance. It is, however, possible to assign the same type\nmore than once.\nA pre-segmented short text is the input to the classiﬁer of Peldszus [2014]. Using the\nannotation scheme encoded in the argumentative microtext corpus (see Sections 4.1and4.2.2),\nthe system can produce recursive structures, where supporting or attacking statements can in\nturn be supported, etc. An example tree is shown in Figure 7.2. The system therefore needs to\naccount explicitly for relations and does so by encoding all the information about a segment in\na complex label. This includes the target segment of the relation, denoted by \u0000n : : : Cnwith n\nbeing the distance to the target (either to the left or to the right). Even though the ‘microtexts’\nused by Peldszus were quite short, target identiﬁcation proved to be very hard in this approach.\nMinimum-spanningtree(MST)algorithm Having observed that an oﬀ-the-shelf discourse\nparser performs quite well on detecting the target segment of a relation, Peldszus and Stede\n[2015a] proposed a parsing technique for predicting the tree structure of argumentation in the\n‘microtext’ corpus. The ﬁrst stage of the system employs an improved version of the segment\n\n--- Page 116 ---\n7.2. IDENTIFYING COMPLETE ARGUMENT STRUCTURES 103\nclassiﬁer introduced by Peldszus [2014], which for a segment determines probabilities for being\ncentral claim, proponent or opponent’s voice, and support or attack function; and for a pair of\nsegments, whether they are connected. The information gathered about the segments was then\nmapped to a fully connected weighted graph, where the weights represent the predictions made\nby the local classiﬁers. Then, an implementation of the standard MST algorithm [ Chu and Liu ,\n1965,Edmonds ,1967] decoded the optimal structure. A central step in this approach is the\nspeciﬁc way of ‘translating’ the numerical results of segment classiﬁcation into the appropriate\nedge weights in the graph. The system achieved an F-score of 0.72 for identifying argumentative\nrelations and 0.87 for recognizing claims.\nIntegerlinearprogramming(ILP) BesidesMST,anothercandidateforoptimizingtheglobal\nstructure is ILP. The key is to specify a suitable objective function to be maximized, as well as\nconstraints on the target structure to be built, which then guide the search. Afantenos et al.\n[2018] suggest various groups of such constraints, including the following.\n•Treeconstraints: All nodes have one or no outgoing edge; the root node has no outgoing\nedge; cycles are ruled out.\n•Relation labeling : Every node has exactly one function (support or attack).\n•Interactions :Therootnode(centralclaim)mustbeinproponent’svoice;asupportrelation\ncan hold only between nodes in the same voice, etc.\nImplementations of tree prediction in an ILP framework have been proposed by Persing and\nNg[2016], Stab and Gurevych [2017b], and Afantenos et al. [2018], using either the persuasive\nessay corpus of Stab and Gurevych [2014a] (Persing/Ng) or the microtext corpus (Afantenos et\nal.), or both (Stab/Gurevych). Results are not directly comparable due to diﬀerent versions of\nthe essay corpus being used, and somewhat diﬀerent feature sets. All authors, however, report\nimprovementsoverpreviouspipeline-basedapproaches.Afantenosetal.alsoreplicatedtheother\ntwo approaches as well as the MST approach of Peldszus and Stede [2015a] and provide a\ncomparative analysis.\nNeuralnetworks One of the ﬁrst NN experiments on the persuasive essay and microtext cor-\npora was done by Potash et al. [2017]. The authors solved the tasks of predicting argument\ncomponents (claim, major claim, premise) and link detection (i.e., unlabeled relations), and they\narrive at a tree structure. They propose that sequence-to-sequence attention modeling, speciﬁ-\ncally a Pointer Network [Vinyals et al., 2015] is well suited for this problem, as it can capture the\nsequential information of argument components, partly enforce the tree structure, and jointly\npredict multiple subtasks with the hidden representations. For representing components, the\nsystem uses bag-of-words, GloVe embeddings, and positional features. Despite the relatively\nsmall amount of training data in the two corpora, the authors report results that outperform\nthose of the ILP approaches by Peldszus and Stede [2015a] and Stab and Gurevych [2017b]\n\n--- Page 117 ---\n104 7. DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\nfor the subtasks that are being addressed here. They also conﬁrm the earlier insight that joint\noptimization (here for segment type and linking) is clearly better than combining individual\nsolutions.\nEger et al. [2017] also ran a number of NN experiments on the persuasive essay corpus.\nAs a potential advantage of neural sequence tagging models, they point out that (at least in this\ncorpus) related ADUs need not be adjacent but, on the contrary, can be at a fairly long distance\nfrom each other; this is a well-known problem for CRF-like models. For ADU identiﬁcation,\nEger et al. obtained best results from a BiLSTM tagger. Identifying support and attack relations\nwas a harder task, but still they achieved better results with an LSTM than the ILP approach\nofStab and Gurevych [2017b] did.\nPredictinggraphs In Section 4.1, we described the Cornell eRulemaking annotation scheme,\nwhich uses general graphs rather than trees for representing argmentation, and employs a set\nof role and relation labels that is more domain-speciﬁc than those used in the work described\nabove. For building such graphs over pre-segmented input, Nicolae et al. use structured learning.\nThey cast the problem in a factor graph approach [Kschischang et al., 2001], which can fully\nlearn the correlations between role assignment and linking, and does not rely on handcrafted\nscoring, as via the objective function in ILP. Inference is done by the Alternating Directions\nDual Decomposition (AD3) algorithm. For parameterization, the authors experimented with\ntwo approaches: a linear structured SVM using the features proposed by Stab and Gurevych\n[2014b] for role identiﬁcation and linking, and a bidirectional LSTM that encodes context for\na segment represented as the average of the LSTM outputs of the words therein. Niculae et al.\nevaluated the approach on their own eRulemaking corpus as well as the persuasive essay corpus\nfrom Stab and Gurevych. For the latter, they obtained competitive results on the link prediction\ntask. Generally, the feature engineering SVM approach outperforms the RNN, which, however,\nyields very good results on unit type classiﬁcation in the persuasive essays.\n7.2.2 SEQUENTIAL STRUCTURE\nA tree or graph structure represents the logical gist of an argument, which for many purposes is\nuseful and may constitute the ﬁnal result of argumentation mining. But it should be noted that\ninformation about the linear order of the argument components found in the text is essentially\nneglected by the approaches shown in the previous subsection. So far, aspects of the linearization\nof texts have received only little attention in argumentation mining. To some extent, the step of\nconstructingagraphmayexploitlocalityconstraintsbypreferringadjacentunitswhenpredicting\nargumentativerelations;butbeyondthisconsideration,aspectsoflinearordertendtobeignored.\nOn the other hand, the fact that linear order does matter has received quite a bit of atten-\ntion in rhetoric (cf. Section 2.6). A simple example of its relevance is the A,butB pattern, which\nis known to express not just a symmetrical contrast but to assign diﬀerent weights to AandB.\n(7.6) The party has good ideas, but the leader is quite dumb. I won’t vote for them.\n\n--- Page 118 ---\n7.2. IDENTIFYING COMPLETE ARGUMENT STRUCTURES 105\n(7.7) The leader is quite dumb, but the party has good ideas. I will vote for them.\nNote that switching the order of AandBin either case (or, alternatively, switching the negation)\nproduces odd results. This general insight can be extended to the text level; for instance, popular\nadvice from rhetorics guidebooks suggests to place your ‘best’ argument maybe at the beginning\nof your text, or at the end, but deﬁnitely not in the middle. And plenty of more sophisticated\nrecipes are being studied for their persuasive power.\nBuilding upon ideas on assigning types to ADUs (recall, e.g., the work on ‘argumentative\nzoning’ mentioned in Section 2.6),Wachsmuth and Stein [2017] suggest to model an argumen-\ntation strategy as a sequence of rhetorical moves. They study diﬀerent sets of move types, such\nas sentiment values (positive, negative, neutral), discourse relations (background, cause, circum-\nstance, ...), or argumentative moves (claim, premise, none, ...). No matter what the type set is,\nthe underlying computational problem is the same: given a segmented text and a classiﬁer that\nassigns a move to each segment, the result is a sequence of labels, which Wachsmuth and Stein\ncall a ‘ﬂow’. The idea is to explore attributes of these ﬂows for predicting properties of the text,\nfor example its persuasiveness. This presupposes, however, that ﬂows of diﬀerent texts can be\nindividually compared, and subsequently analyzed for commonalities, e.g., by clustering algo-\nrithms. Comparing ﬂows is not trivial, though, because texts (and thus ﬂows) are of diﬀerent\nlengths. Wachsmuth and Stein experiment with various techniques for normalizing ﬂows to a\nunit length, so that follow-up computations are possible. Figure 7.3illustrates the overall idea.\nNormalized/abstracted Flow Outp ut Class or Value One Similarity Value for Each Flow Pattern\nNeutral1\nCom puting\nSimilarities2\nLearning\nPrediction\nFigure 7.3: Illustration of the ‘ﬂow’ comparison/clustering approach to predicting text features.\nA dot represents a text segment, and its color represents its type based on [Wachsmuth and\nStein,2017, p. A:7].\nOne more instantiation of this approach was presented by Al-Khatib et al. [2017], who\napply it to newspaper editorials. The three moves of interest are types of evidence given for a\nclaim:statistics,testimony, andanecdote .Sinceaﬂowmustcapturethetextcompletely,everyother\nsegment receives the label other. These moves have been manually annotated on the 300 texts\nof the Webis Editorials corpus (see Section 4.2.2), and this data was used to build a classiﬁer.\n\n--- Page 119 ---\n106 7. DERIVING THE STRUCTURE OF ARGUMENTATION\nThe features were diﬀerent kinds of n-grams (including token, character, chunk, PoS), sentence\nlength and position, NE type distribution, and sentiment. With an SVM, all groups of features\nwere found to be useful, and the resulting F1-scores for the three important categories range\nbetween 0.5 and 0.59, while that for ‘other’ is 0.87.\nThis classiﬁer was then used to label a corpus of 29,000 editorials from the NewYorkTimes\ncorpus, which in addition have all been assigned to a broad topic class (such as economics, arts,\nhealth, etc.) by a Naive Bayes classiﬁer. Al-Khatib et al. then applied the ﬂow normalization al-\ngorithmand wereable tocorrelateﬂowpatternswith thetopics: Signiﬁcantdiﬀerencesemerged,\nfrom which the authors concluded that the topic of an editorial inﬂuences the ﬂow pattern se-\nlected by the author (and, in addition, the proportional distribution of evidence types, as shown\nin a separate experiment).\nFinally,wementiontheworkof Wachsmuthetal. [2017a],whodemonstratethatforthree\ndownstream tasks (computing argumentative text genre, myside bias in arguments, and stance),\nthe prediction beneﬁts from considering boththe explicit linear order of an argumentative text,\nand its implicit hierarchical structure. The authors propose a positional tree kernel model that is\nable to combine the sequence and hierarchy information.\n\n--- Page 120 ---\n107\nC H A P T E R 8\nAssessing Argumentation\nWhile ﬁnding argument components and possibly arranging them in a tree or graph structure\nconstitute the core tasks of argumentation mining, there is a small body of research aiming at\ngoing further and computing ‘deeper’ information about arguments. The ﬁrst to be considered\nhere is the problem of detecting enthymemes, which amounts to construing the (logically) miss-\ning premises for an argument to make sense. Similarly, one can try to identify the underlying\nreasoning pattern or argumentation scheme (cf. Section 3.3), which explains why (or not) a par-\nticular constellation of inferences works. Finally, we discuss work on the quality of arguments,\nwhich encompasses both measuring how ‘good’ an argument is, as well as a set of various other\nattributes that researchers have drawn attention to.\n8.1 RECONSTRUCTING ENTHYMEMES\nEnthymemes are arguments that can be understood by a hearer only if she considers the given\nclaim and premise, and reconstructs a ‘hidden’ premise that provides the link between the two.\nIn the argumentation literature, these are often called minorpremise (stated) and majorpremise\n(unstated). A classical example is as follows.\n(8.1) Minor (stated) premise: Socrates is human.\nMajor (unstated) premise: All humans are mortal.\nClaim/Conclusion (stated): Therefore, Socrates is mortal.\nMore examples from real-life text will follow below. Enthymemes are a very natural phe-\nnomenon, as already pointed out by Aristotle: when a (logically necessary) premise represents\na fact that can be assumed as known to the hearer, then the speaker can leave this premise im-\nplicit in an argument. The hearer then needs to activate her common knowledge to perform the\nreconstruction [Walton, 2008].\nNot surprisingly, this reconstruction task is very diﬃcult to automate—so far, only very\nfew preliminary studies have been done in the argumentation mining community. Wyner et al.\n[2010] provided a manual pilot study on major (implicit) premises in online discussions. They\nﬁrst annotated the premises in a variant of ‘Controlled English’ (i.e., a simpliﬁed and semi-\nformalized language) and then deﬁned propositional logic axioms to explicate the stances of\ndiscussion participants. Overall, this serves as an illustration of the kind of knowledge required\nfor an in-depth treatment of enthymemes. Focusing more on the problem of manually annotat-\n\n--- Page 121 ---\n108 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\ning enthymemes, Razuvayevskaya and Teufel [2017] explored several variants of operationaliz-\ning the task and provide suggestions on how to reach suﬃcient inter-annotator agreement.\nIn another pilot study, which makes a connection to opinion mining in product reviews,\nRajendran et al. [2016] propose linking the handling of implicit opinions (those that on the\nsurface look like factual statements but contain an implicit evaluation) to enthymeme recon-\nstruction. Their idea is to classify an opinion statement as to whether it is implicit or explicit,\nand to regard an explicit statement together with the overall judgment on the product (as derived\nfrom the rating given with the review) as complete arguments: The reviewer likes product X be-\ncause of Y. Implicit opinions, on the other hand, when combined with the conclusion can create\nan enthymeme. Then, common knowledge is necessary to complete the argument—which is the\nmajor unsolved problem.\nTheotherresearchperspectiveonenthymemesis:whatisactuallycomputationallyfeasible\nin practice? From this angle, Boltužić and Šnajder [2016] saw an analogy between major/minor\npremise on the one hand and the claim/claim type pairs that were collected by Hasan and Ng\n[2014], mentioned on page 82. These authors had gathered the reasons that authors provide for\ntheir stance toward an issue of public debate, clustered those reasons, and formulated a meta-\nstatement describing each cluster. Three examples are given on the left hand side of Figure 8.1:\nThe ‘user claim’ is from the forum post, and the ‘main claim’ is the abstract meta-statement\nprovided by Hasan and Ng.\nLike Hasan and Ng, Boltužić and Šnajder tackled the problem of matching user claims\nto main claims (or in other words: given a user claim, ﬁnd the appropriate main claim). But\nhere the idea is to explore the ‘gap’ between the two types of claim, which Boltužić and Šnajder\nproposed to ﬁll with additional premises. This step amounts to making implicit major premises\nexplicit, i.e., to enthymeme reconstruction. Annotators added the major premises to the origi-\nnal Hasan/Ng dataset,1following the instruction to formulate statements that ‘bridge the gap’.\nIn Figure 8.1, the top claim pair has been annotated with two implicit major premises, while\nannotators identiﬁed the other two pairs as non-matching or not in need of any explication,\nrespectively. The authors regard the number of major premises as a measure of the size of the in-\nferential gap (in their corpus, the average is 2.7). To gather evidence for this hypothesis, Boltužić\nand Šnajder ran a crowdsourcing experiment to obtain judgments on the semantic similarity be-\ntween the user claim and main claim, and they indeed found a statistically signiﬁcant (though\nweak) negative correlation between semantic similarity and gap size.\nNext, the authors turned to the question whether the annotated gold premises can support\nthe task of matching user claims to the given set of main claims. They computed semantic simi-\nlarity between claim sentences via cosine distance, where the vectors were produced by summing\nup the embedding vectors for each word of a sentence. Having tested various operationalizations\nfor making use of the major premises, they found that combining the premises with the main\nclaim, and then running the similarity computations, is the best approach.\n1And the result is in turn made available: http://takelab.fer.hr/data/argpremises/ (accessed December 9, 2018).\n\n--- Page 122 ---\n8.2. IDENTIFYING ARGUMENTATION SCHEMES 109\nFigure 8.1: Examples of claim pairs annotated with implicit premises [Boltužić and Šnajder ,\n2016, p. 127], used with permission.\nThe obvious next question is whether it is possible to infer the major premises automat-\nically; Boltužić and Šnajder conducted some ﬁrst experiments but these were not particularly\nsuccessful.\n8.2 IDENTIFYING ARGUMENTATION SCHEMES\nIn Section 3.3, we explained the notion of ‘argumentation scheme’ as put forward by Walton\net al.[2008], Rigotti and Greco Morasso [2010], and others. The central idea is to specify on\nwhat grounds a support or attack relation is supposed to hold among two ADUs, or in other\nwords, what the underlying inferential motif is. A central assumption of this line of research is\nthat a reasonably small set of such inferential patters can adequately describe the range of pos-\nsibilities. For illustration, from the scheme set proposed by Walton et al. [2008], we reproduce\ntheArgument from positive consequences scheme (p. 332).\n• Premise: If A is brought about, good consequences will plausibly occur.\n\n--- Page 123 ---\n110 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\n• Therefore, A should be brought about.\n• Critical questions:\n–How strong is the likelihood that the cited consequences will (may, must) occur?\n–What evidence supports the claim that the cited consequences will (may, must) occur,\nand is it suﬃcient to support the strength of the claim adequately?\n–Are there other opposite consequences (bad as opposed to good, for example) that\nshould be taken into account?\nThe critical questions point to potential objections and thereby guide the speaker in back-\ning up the argument where necessary. Schemes have received some, but not too much attention\nin argumentation mining research. When premises and conclusions have been identiﬁed in a\ntext, it is generally very diﬃcult to reliably identify the underlying scheme automatically.\nAn early corpus annotated with scheme information was Araucaria DB [ Reed et al. ,\n2008a]. Some more recent work that assesses the feasibility of human scheme annotation, and\nsuggests to exploit such data for argumentation mining, will be described in the ﬁrst subsection\nbelow. The actual automatic labeling of scheme information has been addressed only rarely so\nfar; it is the topic of the second subsection.\n8.2.1 HUMAN ANNOTATION STUDIES\nNot surprisingly, deciding on the kind of inference underneath an argumentative move involves\nsubjective judgment to a large extent, and accordingly, it is not easy to obtain good results in\nagreement studies. For example, Reisert et al. [2017] started from Walton’s argument from con-\nsequences (one variant is shown just above) and aimed at operationalizing it for argumentation\nmining by mapping it to a pattern instantiation task, where slots are characterized by their pos-\nitive or negative consequences for participants of the event described. The authors suggested 24\nsuch patterns in total (covering both support and attack under this argumentation scheme) and\napplied it to 20 texts from the ‘microtext’ corpus [ Peldszus and Stede ,2016b]. For two anno-\ntators, however, they reached a rather low kappa ranging from 0.19–0.43 depending on how\nstrictly agreement is deﬁned.\nMusi et al. [2016] developed guidelines for annotating schemes according to the ‘Argu-\nmentum model of topics’ of Rigotti and Greco Morasso [2010]. The authors favor this approach\nover Walton’s, because the 15 schemes are organized in a hierarchy that more explicitly aims at\ndevising mutually exclusive categories. Also, the deﬁnitions refer to semantic properties of the\nparticipating entities rather than to the logical inference steps. They applied the approach to 30\ntexts from the persuasive essay corpus of Stab and Gurevych [2014a], and report a Fleiss \u0014of\njust 0.1, but this involves nine, only lightly trained annotators. An informative error analysis,\n\n--- Page 124 ---\n8.2. IDENTIFYING ARGUMENTATION SCHEMES 111\nincluding a follow-up experiment, is provided. The annotation guidelines and data are available\nfor research.2\nFigure 8.2: Distribution of argumentation schemes in Wikipedia page deletion discussion cor-\npus [Schneider et al. ,2013b, p. 28].\nA larger study, which uses the scheme catalogue of Walton et al. [2008], was performed\nbySchneider et al. [2013b]. In several rounds of annotation, 741 messages from 72 debates on\nWikipedia Talk Pages (discussing whether a certain page should be deleted) were labeled. In\nthe ﬁrst phase, the authors found that 17 of the Walton-type schemes were applicable to the\ndata. Then, two annotators labeled the arguments in each message with one of these schemes,\nand reached a \u0014of 0.48. In the ﬁnal corpus of 1,213 arguments, the authors determined the\nmost common schemes—see Figure 8.2. The distribution, according to the authors, reﬂects the\nfocus on precedent and rules, which is typical for this genre, and furthermore a tendency to\ndiscussWikipediaarticlesintermsofvaluesandcommunitynorms.Theauthorsalsodetermined\ndiﬀerences in scheme usage of novices vs. experts participating in the debates; some results\nare also shown in the ﬁgure. Generally, the study found that the most prevalent patterns are\nthe ‘Rules’ and ‘Evidence to Hypothesis’ schemes from the Walton scheme catalogue (36% of\narguments), and that familiarity with community norms correlates with the novices’ ability to\ncraft persuasive arguments. Also, the study looked into the success of arguments in the course\nof a debate, and found that successful arguments tend to use a rhetoric that is in line with the\n2https://github.com/musielena/argscheme_aclworkshop2016 (accessed Sep 28. 2017).\n\n--- Page 125 ---\n112 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\npolicies and values established in the community, while unsuccessful arguments are mostly based\non personal preference or on inappropriate analogy to other cases.\nLikewise in the tradition of Walton’s approach, Song et al. [2014] exploited the role of the\ncritical questions for purposes of writing support. As stated in the beginning, these questions can\nserve to guide a writer in building up a successful argument, and the hypothesis of Song et al. was\nthat adherence to such conventionalized rules in fact distinguishes good from bad essay writers.\nThe authors found that the original Walton scheme catalogue is occasionally diﬃcult to work\nwith (due to ambiguity), and hence they made modiﬁcations; eventually they used three schemes\n(policy, causal, sample), each associated with various sub-categories and critical questions, for\ntheir essay annotation study. Two prompts were selected, and for each, 4 trained annotators\nlabeled 300 texts. Agreement was calculated for a subset of 40 essays: for common schemes and\ncategories, the pairwise \u0014ranged between 0.55 and 0.85, while rare categories proved to be more\ndiﬃcult to agree on.\nFinally, we mention the work of Green [2015], who works on scientiﬁc papers, which\ngenerally are not yet heavily studied in argumentation mining. Green found the schemes from\nthe ‘standard’ approaches not directly applicable and devised 10 schemes on her own, which she\nfound to represent the major forms of argumentation for scientiﬁc claims in 4 genetics papers.\nOnly some of these schemes overlap with the catalogue of Walton et al. [2008]. To evaluate\nthe approach in a pilot study, Green worked with about 30 subjects and determined to what\nextent schemes were recognized, by means of test questions that had to be answered [Green ,\n2015]. Subsequently, a second pilot study tested whether 6 subjects from biology and computer\nscience research could consistently apply 5 common schemes, this time deﬁned contextually\nwith genetics-speciﬁc concepts [ Green, 2017]. Green has begun to investigate applying these\nschemes in combination with semantic types such as genes, mutations, proteins, and phenotypes\nwhich can be detected by generic bioNLP tools [Green, 2018].\n8.2.2 AUTOMATIC SCHEME LABELING\nExperiments on automatically labeling texts with scheme information have been rare so far. One\ninitial study was done by Song et al. [2014] on the above-mentioned essay annotations. They\ntrained a logistic regression classiﬁer to determine whether a sentence raises critical questions or\nnot (which is relevant for essay scoring), using n-grams, positional and PoS features, as well as\nlexical overlap between sentence and prompt. The crucial question for this task is how well the\nmodel generalizes across prompts. When training and testing on data including both prompts,\nthe system reached a performance of \u0014=0.44, but when training on one and testing on the other,\nthe average is only 0.26.\nFocusing on the core schemes rather than the critical questions, Feng and Hirst [2011]\ntackled the problem of automatically assigning one of the ﬁve most frequent schemes from Wal-\nton et al. [2008] to pairs of premise and conclusion (which are assumed as given already) taken\nfrom the Araucaria DB data [ Reed et al., 2008a]. The schemes are: argument from example,\n\n--- Page 126 ---\n8.3. DETERMINING ARGUMENT QUALITY 113\nfrom cause to eﬀect, from consequences, from verbal classiﬁcation, and practical reasoning. The\nauthors used positional features (absolute and relative, for premise and conclusion), length of\nthe two components, the number of premises, as well as some scheme-speciﬁc features (largely\ncue phrases). In a separate experiment, they measured the impact of additionally specifying the\ntype of argumentation structure (linked versus convergent) to the classiﬁer.\nIn one-against-others classiﬁcation via a C4.5 decision tree, the system produced rather\npromising results: for two schemes, the best average accuracies were better than 90%, while for\nthe other three schemes the results were between 63% and 70%. Adding the linked/convergent\nfeature generally helped, and most dramatically for the Argument from example schema.\nIn an experiment on AIFdb data [Lawrence et al. ,2012] (which includes the Araucaria\nDB used by Feng/Hirst), Lawrence and Reed [2016] also classiﬁed the presence of a scheme,\nand in addition studied the task of identifying the scheme components (premise, conclusion)\nby means of similar features as used by Feng and Hirst. Here, the F-score results vary widely\nbetween scheme component type, and between classiﬁers (Naive Bayes, SVM, Decision Tree),\nranging from 0.57–0.91. One reason for the diﬀerent performances on diﬀerent schemes is\ntheir varying connection to linguistic marking: some co-occur with particular connectives (e.g.,\nfor example ) or other expressions relatively often, while others do not.\n8.3 DETERMINING ARGUMENT QUALITY\nIn some sense, the question about the quality of an argument is the ‘ultimate’ one for argumen-\ntation mining: being able to reconstruct argumentative structures from a text is the groundwork,\nbut assessing the degree of strength of an argument, or comparing the quality of arguments to\none another, is a goal that many practical future applications will envisage. For example, an au-\ntomated debating chatbot that constantly produces lame arguments will not be successful—so\nit better be aware of the quality parameter.\nWe divide this section in three parts. The ﬁrst follows up on Chapter 3and looks at the\nproblem from a logical perspective, where the consistency of a constellation of argument com-\nponents is of interest. Then, our second part considers the quality of an argument in a more\ngeneral sense: How good is it, and, for that matter, what exactly does ‘good’ mean? Finally, the\nthird part focuses speciﬁcally on the role of emotion in argumentation, which in many practical\nscenarios can be a decisive factor for perceived quality.\n8.3.1 CONSISTENCY CHECKING\nThe step from argumentation mining in text to automated reasoning is, as of today, a very diﬃ-\ncult one, but as we pointed out earlier, we believe it to be crucial for making progress with ana-\nlyzing arguments ‘underneath the linguistic surface’. Hence, in this section, we brieﬂy consider\nthe paramount ‘quality’ question for logical reasoning: given a constellation of arguments, which\narguments are consistent with each other? Argumentation solvers address this question for for-\nmal argumentation models. Systems such as Arg&Dec, ASPARTIX, ASPIC, and Carneades\n\n--- Page 127 ---\n114 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\nwhich can reason over these formal models have been applied, typically to manually constructed\nformalisms drawn from real online debates. The underlying models vary, and many are based on\nDung’s abstract argumentation frameworks, which we introduced in Section 3.4.1, and which\ncanbesolvedfor acceptability withnumerousargumentationsolvers.Forinstance,Dung’sframe-\nworks have been extended by bipolar argumentation frameworks [ Cayrol and Lagasquie-Schiex ,\n2009], which use both attack and support relationships, represented as diﬀerent edge types, and\nwhich have also been used for consistency checking, and by abstract dialectical frameworks.\nArgumentation solvers Several existing systems, which we refer to as argumentation solvers\nand computational argumentation systems, can reason over argument frameworks. Cerutti et al.\n[2018] provide a broad review of formal systems and their implementations. Thimm and Villata\n[2017] summarize best-in-class argumentation solvers from the ﬁrst biennial competition of the\nresearch community, and provides background on the answer set programming and satisﬁability\n(SAT) solver approaches that underlie argumentation solvers.\nFor instance, Carneades [ Gordon ,2013],3an opensource reasoning system with an online\ndemo4can evaluate argument graphs, and takes multiple input and output formats. It is moti-\nvated by legal reasoning and can calculate whether an argument meets one of several common\nlegal evidence standards. It can also compute the ‘calculus of opposition’, grounded, complete,\npreferred, and stable extensions of an abstract argumentation framework.\nConnectingnaturallanguagetoargumentationsolvers NoDE(Naturallanguagearguments\nin online DEbates) [ Cabrio and Villata, 2014] is a manually annotated corpus of bipolar argu-\nmentation from three data sources: the Debatepedia5online debate platform, the script of the\ncourtroom play “Twelve Angry Men”, and Wikipedia revision histories. The corpus also con-\ntains images of bipolar argumentation frameworks, such as Figure 8.3, which was generated by\nanalyzing Act 3 of Twelve Angry Men.\nCabrio and Villata [2016] use abstract dialectical frameworks, which generalize Dun-\ngian frameworks by specifying an acceptance condition for each argument node. This enables\nabstract dialectic frameworks (ADF) to express arbitrary relationships (rather than just attacks\nas in Dungian frameworks), and in particular positive and negative weights can be used, also\nencompassing bipolar argumentation. They generalize textual entailment to groups of text frag-\nments in what they call a bipolarentailmentgraph which uses arguments as nodes and the textual\nentailmentrelationsasedges.Theygivetwoexamplesofusingtheirpipelinetogeneratecoherent\nsets of arguments starting from Debatepedia data from NoDE.\nCerutti et al. [2016] create and solve three diﬀerent formalisms based on manual anal-\nysis of an online debate from the createdebate.com forum. These are: a Dungian abstract\nargumentation framework (see Section 3.4.1), a Quantitative Argumentation Debate (QuAD)\nframework [ Baroni et al., 2015] (modeled after IBIS, see Section 3.4.1, and evaluated with the\n3https://carneades.github.io/ (accessed May 20, 2018).\n4http://carneades.fokus.fraunhofer.de/carneades/ (accessed May 20, 2018).\n5http://www.debatepedia.org (accessed May 20, 2018).\n\n--- Page 128 ---\n8.3.
