Each computational argumentation\n6http://www.arganddec.com (accessed May 20, 2018).\n\n--- Page 129 ---\n116 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\nmethod has some advantages for their case. The Dungian approach can be used to identify ac-\nceptable arguments and sets of mutually defending arguments, which “allows participants in the\ndialogue to strategically focus their attention” [ Cerutti et al. ,2016, p. 70] on those arguments\nidentiﬁed as as non-defeated. The QuAD framework represents both support and attack rela-\ntionships (though the same argument cannot be represented as simultaneously supporting one\nargument and attacking another, leading them to duplicate certain arguments). QuAD can also\nnumerically compare the strength of the arguments, given numerically assigned input on the\nintrinsic base strength, though the winning argument can change with small changes in these\nnumerical assignments.\nSimilarly, Cocarascu and Toni [2017b] manually construct a bipolar argumentation\nframework from a set of hotel reviews, and use the DF-QuAD method [Rago et al. ,2016] to\nquantify the strength of arguments. They also suggest using bipolar argumentation frameworks\nfor summarization, since conﬂicting viewpoints and their support can be seen in the graph.\nWyner et al. [2016] modiﬁes sentences from an online discussion hosted by the BBC\nHave Your Say7about who should pay tax on garbage. Rather than mining arguments, they\nenvision leveraging controlled language input and enacting a series of transformations, using\nthe automatic transformation from the controlled language ACE into ﬁrst-order logic. Their\nuse of a solver, however, is informative: ultimately, they use the ASPARTIX system to solve the\nargumentation framework. They consider policy positions, which are preferred extensions (in the\nDungian sense), either for or against the original position.\nComputational argumentation systems and solvers for a variety of formal argumentation\nframeworks are mature. There is clear potential for a pipeline from natural language argumen-\ntation to a ‘solved’ argument showing sets of coherent, non-contradictory positions. So far the\nmost successful pipeline seems to be that of Cabrio and Villata [2016], using textual entail-\nment and abstract dialectical frameworks, while there are several other promising approaches.\nAn important open question is which formalisms are most appropriate, in the senses of being\nconducive for modeling natural language, cognitively intuitive, etc.\n8.3.2 ASSESSING OR COMPARING QUALITY\nBroadening the notion of quality from the logical perspective also to infomal treatments, the\ncomplexity of the question is attested by a body of literature in argumentation theory and\nrhetoric; a comprehensive overview is presented by Wachsmuth et al. [2017b]. For orientation,\nwe mention here only the proposal of Blair[2012], who makes the term ‘quality’ more explicit\nby suggesting to decompose it into three dimensions.\n•Logical: The argument is cogent. This in turn breaks down into three criteria that an\nargument should meet:\n– Relevance: All premises of the argument indeed provide support for the conclusion.\n7http://www.bbc.com/news/have_your_say (accessed May 20, 2018).\n\n--- Page 130 ---\n8.3. DETERMINING ARGUMENT QUALITY 117\n– Acceptability: The premises are worth being believed.\n– Suﬃciency: The premises provide enough evidence for accepting the claim.\n•Rhetorical: The persuasive eﬀect or success of the argument.\n•Dialectical: The argumentation is reasonable fur the purpose of resolving an issue.\nIt is obvious that this characterization does not straightforwardly lead to a computable\ntask of determining quality, as it is rather abstract. One reason is that argumentation in text\nor dialogue can come with so many diﬀerent purposes and in diﬀerent forms, as pointed out\nbyWachsmuth et al. [2017b]: the goal may be to persuade an audience, to resolve a dispute, to\nachieve agreement, to recommend an action, and more. Depending on situation and context,\nthe categories mentioned above are of diﬀerent degrees of importance.\nStill, some initial steps have been proposed, and three possible strategies can be identiﬁed:\nfocus on one speciﬁc dimension; rephrase the problem as comparing two arguments in terms\nof (some aspect of) quality; and try to break the overall quality issue into a number of well-\nmotivated dimensions that can be addressed individually. We discuss them in turn.\nFocusononedimensionandgenre Exploitingtheannotationsinthecorpusof402persuasive\nessays [ Stab and Gurevych, 2014a], work by Stab and Gurevych [2017a] selected the suﬃciency\ncriterion (see above) and applied it to essays. The assumptions are that students have diﬀerent\nabilitiestoactuallysupporttheirarguments;andthattrainedannotatorsareabletoperceivethese\ndiﬀerences; and that these judgments are not entirely subjective. Stab and Gurevych extracted\n1,029 text portions corresponding to complete arguments (claims and premises) in a paragraph,\nwith an average length of 4.5 sentences per argument. Three annotators answered the question\nwhether an argument is ‘suﬃciently supported’, and they agreed on 91.1% of 433 arguments\n(Fleiss \u0014=0.77).\nTaking this result as indicative for the task to be solvable, the whole corpus was annotated,\nwhich lead to 681 suﬃcently supported arguments (66%) and 348 insuﬃciently supported ones\n(34%).8Turning to automatic classiﬁcation, Stab and Gurevych compared a rich-feature SVM\nwith a CNN using word embeddings [Mikolov et al., 2013]. The SVM with optimized fea-\ntures (including 4,000 most frequent unigrams, length, constituency parsing productions, fre-\nquency of named entities) achieved a macro-F1 score of 0.77, narrowly beating a SVM unigram\nbaseline of 0.75. The main problem observed by the authors was a relatively low recall on the\ninsuﬃciently-supported arguments. The CNN performed best, with a macro-F1 of 0.83.\nComparing arguments When considering the quality question in general, it does not seem\nvery practical to take an argument, outside any context of use, and ask a human being to score\nit on some scale of goodness. A more natural task is that of a choice between two (or more)\n8Guidelines and corpus are available at https://www.ukp.tu-darmstadt.de/data/argumentation-mining (accessed\nSeptember 29, 2017).\n\n--- Page 131 ---\n118 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\narguments: which one is more convincing? Labeled data for this scenario can be elicited from\nannotators, or derived from existing data. For example, Wei et al. [2016] worked with online\ndebates. Their data comes from ChangeMyView, which is a subforum of reddit.com. Here,\nusers initiate a discussion thread by posting their thoughts toward some topic, and others reply\nwith opposing arguments, trying to change the initiator’s mind. Also, users can vote which reply\nposts they consider more persuasive, so that each reply is associated with a ‘success’ score. Wei\net al. selected 1,785 threads with 374,000 posts in total.\nGiven the post/score tuples, they trained a pair-wise ranker with three groups of features.\nIn the experiments, the surface features (length, distribution of PoS tags, URLs, punctuation)\nturned out to be not very helpful. (Unigrams and named entities had also been tried but were\neventually discarded.) The second group consisted of interaction features: the size of the reply\ntree generated by a post, and the level of the post in the overall tree (rooted in the initiating\npost). Finally, local argumentation features were computed with a binary classiﬁer that labels\nsentences as non-/argumentative, using the features proposed by Stab and Gurevych [2014b].\nThe proportion of argumentative sentences was taken as a feature, in addition to the number of\nconnectives and modal verbs. And the ﬁnal feature was the cosine similarity between the post\nand its parents, meant to estimate relevance of the post.\nInterestingly, the results diﬀered depending on the stage of the discussion. In the initial\nphase, with only a small number of posts, the argumentation features, and in particular the\nsemantic similarity, worked best. When threads are long, on the other hand, the relatively simple\ninteraction features turned out to be more predictive.\nThe variant of gathering pairwise judgments from human raters was explored by Habernal\nand Gurevych [2016]. From two debate portals (createdebate.com and procon.org), they\nchose 32 discussion topics and randomly sampled about 30 arguments per topic. These were\ncombined into 16,927 argument pairs (avoiding cross-topic pairs). Crowdsourcing was then\nemployed to judge one argument as more convincing, or both as equally good. Habernal and\nGurevych devised a method for performing quality assurance, which was based on constructing\nthe transitive closure of all the pairwise rankings in order to detect problematic claim pairs. The\nﬁnal corpus contains the subset ﬁltered in this way, but also the ‘bad’ pairs in a separate set.9\nTo automate the comparison, Habernal and Gurevych experimented with a feature-rich\nSVM and a bidirectional LSTM. The former obtained an accuracy of 78% and beat the LSTM\n(76%), but the authors point out that they did little optimization work on the NN, and that the\nfeature engineering for the SVM was quite laborious, involving, among others, parsing features,\nsentiment analysis, and NER.\nA follow-up experiment on the same dataset was reported by Chalaguine and Schulz\n[2017]. With a simple forward-feeding neural network (one hidden layer), they achieved an\naccuacy of 77%, essentially replicating the results of Habernal and Gurevych with much less\n9The annotated data is available for research: https://github.com/UKPLab/acl2016-convincing-arguments (accessed\nSeptember 28, 2017).\n\n--- Page 132 ---\n8.3. DETERMINING ARGUMENT QUALITY 119\nmachinery. The authors attribute this success to their idea of doing a precomputation step on\nthe feature values: instead of taking the values per argument ‘as is’, they computed for each value\nits relation to the average value for that feature in the entire dataset. In this way, they added\nsome limited form of context knowledge to the feature space.\nA taxonomy of quality dimensions Another new dataset resulted from the work of\nWachsmuth et al. [2017b]. The authors ﬁrst provide a comprehensive survey of earlier work\non argument quality, both from the argumentation theory and from the argumentation mining\nperspective. On the basis of that study, they propose a taxonomy of dimensions that together are\ntaken to deﬁne ‘quality’. It extends the three categories we cited at the beginning of this section.\n•Logic: Cogency (Co)\n–Local acceptability (LA)\n–Local relevance (LR)\n–Local suﬃciency (LS)\n•Rhetoric: Eﬀectiveness (Ef)\n–Clarity (Cl)\n–Credibility (Cr)\n–Appropriateness (Ap)\n–Emotional appeal (Em)\n–Arrangement (Ar)\n•Dialectic: Resonableness (Re)\n–Global acceptability (GA)\n–Global relevance (GR)\n–Global suﬃciency (GS)\nThe authors tested the taxonomy in an annotation experiment, using data from the above-\nmentioned corpus of Habernal and Gurevych [2016]. For every issue/stance pair, they took the\nﬁve top-ranked texts and selected another ﬁve texts by stratiﬁed sampling, so that arguments of\ndiﬀerent degrees of quality are included. The resulting set of 320 arguments was annotated for\nall 15 dimensions by three annotators and, overall, the agreement was found to be promising.\nFor illustration, we reproduce here (Figure 8.4) the scores given by the three annotators on two\ntexts, which responded to the question whether plastic water bottles should be banned. Anno-\ntators had to assign 1 (low), 2 (medium), or 3 (high); the bottom line represents the majority\nvote for the three annotators.\n\n--- Page 133 ---\n120 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\nFigure 8.4: Annotations of scores on argument quality dimensions [Wachsmuth et al., 2017b,\np. 184], used with permission.\n8.3.3 ARGUMENT AND EMOTION\nThe role of emotion is often a contentious issue in argumentation: when a matter-of-fact, lo-\ngos-oriented exchange is being aimed at, any appeal to emotion is seen as a ﬂaw; while in some\nsituation where the speaker intends to persuade the hearer, emotional involvement may be re-\ngarded as a legitimate rhetorical instrument, involving pathos. For a thorough discussion of these\npoints, see the work of Govier [2010], who discusses the relation between logical reasoning and\nemotion in depth.\nBesidesbeingcontentious,theroleofemotionmaybe diﬃcultto detectempirically.Inthe\nweb corpus annotation project of Habernal and Gurevych [2017] (see Section 5.3.5), annotators\nwereaskedtoalsolabelargumentsforthefeature‘appealtoemotion’,buttheagreementobtained\nwas not substantial. In contrast, Hidey et al. [2017] ran an Amazon Turk experiment to label\npremises (in claim-premise pairs of blog comments) for the logos, ethos, or pathos dimension.\nComparing the majority view of the Turkers to the gold labels, agreement in terms of \u000bwas a\nsolid0.73.Noticethat‘ethos’-typepremisesareveryrare(3%of1,068premisesintotal),though.\nAlso, delegating the emotionality annotation task to Mechanical Turk, Oraby et al. [2015]\nwere interested in the linguistic patterns that ditinguish factual from emotional arguments.\nTo obtain data, they used quote-response pairs from the Internet Argument Corpus (see Sec-\ntion4.2.1), and had them annotated by Turkers who were asked whether the respondent is\nattempting to make a fact-based argument or is appealing to feelings and emotions. This lead\nto a dataset of 3,466 ‘fact’ and 2,382 ‘feeling’ posts.\nThen, using a syntactic-pattern learner [Riloﬀ, 1996], Oraby et al. extracted characteristic\nconstructions from both sets of posts, which they regarded as high-precision, and then used to\naccumulate more patterns by means of a bootstrapping approach on un-annotated data. In the\n\n--- Page 134 ---\n8.3. DETERMINING ARGUMENT QUALITY 121\nFigure 8.5: Examples of ‘fact’ and ‘feel’ argumentation style patterns [Oraby et al., 2015, p. 121],\nused with permission.\nend, they tested the pattern sets and determined an accuracy of 80%. (Figure 8.5shows some\nexamples for extracted patterns.) However, while precision was good, the recall was signiﬁcantly\nlower than that obtained by a supervised unigram baseline.\nA study involving the same fact/emotion-annotated data, but aiming at quite ambitious\nresearch questions, was reported by Lukin et al. [2017]. Their goal is to quantify the extent\nto which readers’ beliefs can change due to being confronted with diﬀerent types of argument\n(factual vs. emotional, inter alia ), and how this depends on personality traits. The experiments\nwere all done via Amazon Turk. In a preparatory step, Lukin et al. assessed the personality of\ntheir Turkers by means of a survey that tries to measure standard traits: openness to experience,\nconscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism.\nNext,forcomparingtheinﬂuenceoffactualvs.emotionalarguments,theauthorsgathered\nexamples from the above-mentioned IAC data, which were reliably annotated on the extreme\nends of the fact—emotion scale. Examples are shown in Figure 8.6.\n\n--- Page 135 ---\n122 8. ASSESSING ARGUMENTATION\nFigure 8.6: Examples of factual and emotional exchanges in the Internet Argument Corpus\n[Lukin et al. ,2017, p. 745], used with permission.\nIn addition, for comparing the diﬀerence between dialogic and monologic argumentation,\ntext for the latter was sampled from procon.org, which contains expert-curated summaries of\narguments on contentious topics.\nThe core experiment then followed the before/after reading paradigm, involving three\nsteps.\n1. Turkers are being asked a stance question to determine their prior beliefs on a socio-\npolitical issue, such as “Should the death penalty be allowed?”\n2. Turkers are being shown an argument from one of the three categories monological, emo-\ntional, factual.\n3. Turkers are being retested with the original stance questions.\n\n--- Page 136 ---\n8.3. DETERMINING ARGUMENT QUALITY 123\nWhen measuring the stance diﬀerences, Lukin et al. found signiﬁcant belief changes for all\nthree argument types, but with certain nuances: As they had expected, the opinion change is\ngreater for those Turkers who are initially more neutral about a topic, than for those who are\nentrenched in their beliefs. Regarding personality, a ﬁnding was that ‘conscientious’ Turkers\nare more convinced by dialogic emotional arguments, whereas ‘agreeable’ Turkers are more per-\nsuaded by dialogic factual arguments.\nThen, Lukin et al. went a step further and looked into predicting belief change. Turkers\nnow were asked to rate arguments for strength, and the authors then identiﬁed the combination\nof features that best predicted argument strength. The main ﬁnding was that, for all three types\nof arguments (neutral monologic / factual dialogic / emotional dialogic), feature sets containing\nall ﬁve personality traits perform signiﬁcantly better than sets without those traits. The authors\nhave made their argument+personality data set available for research.10\nIt seems clear that the relationship between argumentation and emotion will be an active\narea for future work. As a ﬁnal example, we wish to point to another study that ventures to leave\nthe core territory of NLP and argumentation mining. Benlamine et al. [2015] presented the ﬁrst\nexperiment that explicitly assesses the correspondence between the polarity of arguments in an\nexchange and the emotions felt by participants. Their emotional status was analyzed by webcams\nand face reading software on the one hand, and physiological sensors (EEG) on the other;\nboth types of information were combined into scores reﬂecting the status of basic emotions\n(neutral, happy, sad, angry, surprised, scared and disgusted). The participants were engaged in\ndebates on topics that were likely to stir people’s temper, for instance ‘Religion does more harm\nthan good’. The debates were recorded and in a post-processing session mapped to an argument\ngraph, so that support/attack relations could be anchored to points in time, and then correlated\nwith the emotional states of the participants. The authors of the study indeed detected some\ncorrespondences between emotions and argumentative moves, e.g., when two opposite opinions\nwere expressed, this was reﬂected in a negative way on the debaters’ emotions.\n10https://nlds.soe.ucsc.edu/persuasion_persona (accessed October 1, 2017).\n\n--- Page 137 ---\n125\nC H A P T E R 9\nGenerating Argumentative\nText\nStrictly speaking, the generation (or synthesis ) of argumentative text is outside the scope of min-\ning, but nonetheless we consider the topic here, as it is a part of the wider ﬁeld of argumentation\ntechnology and will be increasingly relevant for many applications. However, in contrast to anal-\nysis, the generation of arguments has so far received much less attention. In the following, we\ndiscuss the topic along the lines of the two established techniques of text production: a system\ncan generate from symbolic representations of knowledge or from data (Section 9.1), or it can\nmap existing text to new (or revised) text (Section 9.2).\n9.1 GENERATING TEXT FROM STRUCTURED DATA\nEarly work in automatic text generation was concerned with building systems that were able to\nproduce short texts from a collection of structured data or from knowledge that was represented\nin a suitable formalism, such as Description Logic or Bayesian belief networks. The latter were\nemployed by Zukerman et al. [2000], who showed how the logical structure of an argument can\nbe systematically constructed by combining knowledge of a small set of argument schemes with\na model of hearer beliefs, which the argument should try to inﬂuence. In complete generation\nsystems, the path from plain data to a well-formed text is long, and it was commonly divided\ninto three phases [Reiter and Dale, 2000].\n1.Textplanning: given a set of communicativegoals, the system ﬁrst selects the content units\n(data instances, knowledge chunks) that are to be expressed in the text, and then organizes\nthem into a text plan, which speciﬁes hierarchical relations between content units, and\ndetermines the linear order in which they will appear in the text. The text plan is totally\nagnostic of the target natural language that will eventually be produced.\n2.Micro-planning orsentence planning: the text plan is traversed and mapped onto a se-\nquence of sentenceplans. This involves distributing the series of content units into a certain\nnumber of sentences. Furthermore, each sentence plan now gets linguistic (and language-\nspeciﬁc)information,suchastheintendedembeddingofcomplexsentences.Animportant\ntask islexicalchoice : deciding which words to use for expressing a content unit (or a part of\nit; or several content units).\n\n--- Page 138 ---\n126 9. GENERATING ARGUMENTATIVE TEXT\n3.Realization: each sentence plan is converted to a well-formed sentence in natural lan-\nguage, on the basis of grammatical knowledge: words are properly inﬂected, and appro-\npriate function words (such as determiners or prepositions) are inserted in the right places.\nCommunicative\nGoals\nCommunicativ e\nStrategiesDomain Knowlege\nSources:\n • User Model\n • Domain Model\n • Dialogue History\nLinguistic Knowlege\nSources:\n • Lexicon\n • GrammarText\nPlan\nEnglishText\nPlanner\nText\nMicro-planner\nSentence\nRealizerContent Selection\nand Organization\n(deep generation )\nContent Realization\n(surface generation )\nFigure 9.1: Pipeline architecture of typical text generation systems [Carenini, 2001, p. 2], used\nwith permission.\nA diagram outlining this architecture is shown in Figure 9.1. Notice that the knowledge\nsources include general domain knowledge (which entities occur, what their attributes are, how\nthey are related), a history of the discourse produced so far (be it dialogue or monologue), and\nimportantly a user model . Especially when part of a dialogue system, text generation has been\nconceived as a process whose output is geared toward a particular user, and the system normally\nhas information about this user, so that the text can be speciﬁcally tailored to her or his needs.\nIn the following, we will make this architecture more concrete by explaining three systems that\ninstantiated the model for producing short monologue text of an argumentative nature, followed\nby one system aimed at conducting a dialogue with a user. Each one works in a particular do-\nmain, and in the absence of reusable or generic knowledge sources, the work of building such a\ngeneration system involved a lot of hand-crafting: designing domain knowledge representations,\nlinking them to the lexical knowledge of the target language, etc.\n\n--- Page 139 ---\n9.1. GENERATING TEXT FROM STRUCTURED DATA 127\nADVISOR II This early text generator by Elhadad [1995] produced short texts simulating\na student advisor, with the central issue being to recommend classes that are suitable for the\nstudent. Thus, the domain knowledge records all the courses oﬀered along with a number of\nattributes such as content, prerequisites, diﬃculty level, and the like. The user model speciﬁes\nwhat courses the student has already taken, what her interests are, etc. Three possible commu-\nnicative goals can be posed as input to the system: inform the student about a course, recommend\ntaking a certain course, or recommend not taking it. The latter two involve giving reasons, and\nhence a form of argumentation. Here is a sample output [Elhadad, 1995, p. 192].\nAI deals with many interesting topics, such as NLP, Vision and KR. But it has many\nassignments which consist of writing papers. You have little experience writing pa-\npers. So it could be diﬃcult. I would not recommend it.\nThe content in the ﬁrst sentence was selected by comparing the knowledge base (KB) and the\nuser model (UM). The evaluation interesting is not a fact, i.e., an attribute of the course in the\nKB, but is produced by the system after determining that the topics covered by AI include many\nthat the user enjoys. The comparison also reveals that the user has not produced many written\nassignments yet (according to the UM), while assignments are necessary to pass AI (KB). This\nleads ADVISOR to connect the descriptive second sentence to the ﬁrst by the conjunction but:\nthis signals a shift in argumentative orientation, which is appropriate here, since the ﬁrst sen-\ntence amounts to a positive evaluation of the course (for the user), while the second is negative.\nSimilarly, the predicate diﬃcult is not an attribute of the course per se, but computed by the sys-\ntem on the grounds of comparing the weights of positive and negative evaluations of the course.1\nThe argumentation-theoretic underpinning of Elhadad’s system is the notion of topoias\nadvanced by Anscombre and Ducrot [1983]. A topos is a gradual inference rule of the form\n“the more/less X is P, the more/less Y is Q”, and one possible instantiation in the domain of\nADVISOR is “the more diﬃcult a class is, the less a student wants to take it”. Topoi serve to\nconnect the course knowledge base and user model on the one hand, and the linguistic decisions\nof the system on the other—they trigger the use of evaluative adjectives or of connectives (like\nbutin our example above). But verbs, too, can be chosen on the basis of the argumentative\norientation that is to be conveyed. One of Elhadad’s examples is the following.\n(9.1) You enjoyed AI.\nYou took AI.\nYou struggled with AI.\nAllthreeverbsexpressthatthestudenthasattendedtheAIclass,but enjoyandstuggleinaddition\nconvey evaluative connotations. The lexicon used by ADVISOR is aware of such diﬀerences and\ncan choose among similar word on principled grounds.\n1This overall setting has many parallels to contemporary product recommender systems.\n\n--- Page 140 ---\n128 9. GENERATING ARGUMENTATIVE TEXT\nGEA The idea of the Generator of Evaluative Arguments (GEA) [ Carenini, 2001] is similar\nto that of ADVISOR. Again, the input to the system is a communicative goal to inﬂuence the\nuser’s attitude toward some entity. The sample domain implemented by Carenini was real estate,\nand thus the goal is to get a user to like or dislike a particular house. In analogy to ADVISOR,\nthe KB holds the information about a set of houses, and the UM represents the user’s prefer-\nences. Its format is quite elaborate, though: a tree structure that decomposes a domain concept\n(here: house) into its attributes, and associates importance values to them, which characterize\nthe extent to which the user is keen on an attribute. A house thus is characterized by size, lo-\ncation, price, etc., which may in turn be decomposed further. The preference values indicate\nwhether the user likes a quiet or a buzzlng location, whether a target size of ﬁve rooms is very\nimportant or only mildly important, and so forth.\nOn the basis of this information in the UM GEA computes how valuable a particular\nhouse is for the user, and how valuable the diﬀerent attributes are. In this way, it also identi-\nﬁes which attributes can be used as evidence for parent attributes in producing an appropriate\nargument pro or contra a house.\nFigure 9.2: Sample text plan produced by the GEA system [Carenini, 2001, p. 8], used with\npermission.\nGEA’s text planner implements several argumentation strategies that specify how to order\npositive and negative points. Strategies are coded as operators that decompose abstract goals into\nsimple, concrete ones. For illustration, Figure 9.2shows a sample text plan. The chosen strategy\n(see the top of the tree) is to ﬁrst assert the overall evaluation computed for the house—user\n\n--- Page 141 ---\n9.1. GENERATING TEXT FROM STRUCTURED DATA 129\nmatch, then to provide the main argument in favor (decided via the preference values in the\nUM), and then the remaining positive observations. Decomposition stops at the grey boxes,\nwhich correspond to speech acts involving an attribute and its value.\nSimilar to ADVISOR, the microplanning module of GEA is then in charge of converting\nthe speech act objects into linguistic predicate/argument structures; this mapping uses a lexicon,\nand the choices among near-synonyms are made on the basis of the values associated with at-\ntributes. Likewise, connectives are chosen to indicate a continuing or changing argumentative\norientation. Here is a sample output produced by the system for a particular user (as represented\nby the UM) [Carenini, 2001, p. 8].\nHouse 2-33 is an interesting house. In fact, it has a reasonable location in the safe\nEastendneighborhood.Eventhoughthetraﬃcisintenseon2ndstreet,house2-33is\nreasonably close to work. And also it oﬀers an easy access to the shops. Furthermore,\nthe quality of house 2-33 is good. House 2-33 oﬀers an excellent view. And also it\nlooks beautiful.\nGenIE: The domain of the Genetics Information Expression Assistant [Green et al. ,2011] is\nthe production of genetic counseling letters, which explain the inheritance of recessive genetic\ndisorders to patients. The system was designed after a phase of carefully analyzing authentic\ntexts of this genre, discerning their structure and their use of argumentative moves.\nIn GenIE, the text plan is a tree structure along the lines of Rhetorical Structure Theory\n(RST) [Mann and Thompson ,1988], which we brieﬂy introduced in Section 2.6.2. Many text\nplanning modules developed in the 1990’s and 2000’s made this choice, because RST relations\nare deﬁned in such a way that they can in principle also be operationalized used as planning\noperators.2In this use in text generation, an RST tree does not have natural language sentences\nat its leaf nodes, but semantic representations of content-to-be-verbalized. Hence, the text at\nthe leafs in the sample text plan in Figure 9.3, while looking like English, is in fact a shorthand\nfor a formal representation.\nGenIE builds the text plan by means of hand-crafted discourse grammar, which encodes\nthe structural regularities found in the corpus of counseling letters. Argumentation is added in\na post-processing step: the RST plan is screened for material that needs more motivation for\nthe patients, and a separate argument generation module then builds a small RST tree that is\ninserted into the overall text plan.\nThe argument generator uses argumentation schemes (as introduced in Section 3.3), for\ninstance an eﬀect-to-cause scheme and an increased-risk scheme. Green et al. started from the\nscheme catalogue of Walton et al. [2008] but found that for their speciﬁc purposes, they needed\nto formulate more speciﬁc versions of certain schemes.\n2However, Reed and Long [1998] pointed out that in order to thoroughly distinguish common inference ﬁgures such as\nmodus ponens and modus tollens, a more abstract layer of information—besides RST—is needed in text planning, and they\nsuggest a possible formalization of corresponding planning operators.\n\n--- Page 142 ---\n130 9. GENERATING ARGUMENTATIVE TEXT\nFigure 9.3: Sample text plan produced by the GenIE system [ Green et al., 2011, p. 36], used\nwith permission.\nThe GenIE system has been evaluated with an editing task: College students with genetics\nbackground were given either a human-authored letter or a computer-generated letter and asked\nto make it more understandable to non-specialist readers (i.e., the intended target audience of\nthe letters). It turned out that while the computer-generated letter required more edits, fewer\nadditions of extra material were needed.\nDaphne The Daphne system [Grasso et al. ,2000] embeds the generation of arguments into\nthe architecture of a dialogue system that aims to convince users to eat more healthy food. The\nunderlying approach to argumentation is the schema-based ‘New Rhetoric’ theory of Perelman\nand Olbrechts-Tyteca [1969] (cf. Section 3.4.1). A knowledge base encodes information on\nwhat kinds of food have positive or negative eﬀects on health, and a dynamic network mod-\nels diﬀerent perspectives and values associated with topics, as they can develop in a dialogue.\nDaphne has a component for reasoning about the user’s beliefs, and the text and sentence plan-\nner (which are part of an entire dialogue management system) employ the results for trying to\nselect and formulate arguments that will have a persuasive eﬀect on the user. The system archi-\ntecture is designed in such a way that domain-speciﬁc knowledge and argumentation-speciﬁc\n(strategic, rhetorical) knowledge are kept largely separate from one another, so that the latter\ncould in fact be employed for other domains as well.\n\n--- Page 143 ---\n9.2. GENERATING TEXT FROM TEXT 131\nTowardpresentingformalargumentationtousers Finally, we brieﬂy turn toward formal ar-\ngumentation. Cerutti et al. [2017] explored the idea of constructing a “natural language inter-\nface” to formal argumentation systems. Given a representation in an argument network or an\nabstract argumentation framework (cf. Section 3.4), the goal is to map it to English text, such\nthat users can more easily grasp the contents of the representation. Hence, the authors consider\nfour communicative goals.\n• Present a single argument or an approximate argument.\n• Present an entire argument network.\n• Explain the acceptability status of a single argument or an approximate argument.\n• Explain the extensions, given some semantics.\nA user model is not accounted for, so presenting and explaining arguments here are not tailored\nto a particular user (or user group). The authors provide a blueprint for how the classical text\ngeneration pipeline model can be instantiated to produce such verbal descriptions, using a text\nplanner based on RST relations that are relevant for this domain, in particular Evidence, Justify,\nand Antithesis.\n9.2 GENERATING TEXT FROM TEXT\nAs we indicated in the previous section, the approaches to text generation mentioned there in-\nvolve a lot of manual work, because (except for grammatical realization) up to now there are only\nvery few re-usable or standardized components for the generation process. And even if represen-\ntations of knowledge are designed carefully to avoid hard-wiring domain speciﬁc information,\nthe actual knowledge acquisition process has to be re-started whenever a new domain is being\ntackled. The alternative to this laborious process is to combine argument mining with argument\nsynthesis: ﬁnd textual material that can be rewritten into new text. To make this feasible, the\noriginal text usually is taken not in its raw form, but annotated with linguistic information that\nsupports the re-combining steps.\nLegalarguments Anearlyproposalalongtheselineswasmadeby AshleyandWalker [2013b],\nwho describe a partial implementation with a vision of where the work could be taken. The\napproach occupies the middle ground between our two sections, as it involves quite ‘deep’ an-\nnotations. The idea is to generate legal arguments by re-combining parts of related arguments\nthat have been made in similar cases. The underlying data is a corpus of 35 legal decisions on\nvaccine injuries, where each decision consists of 15–40 pages of text. These have been manually\nannotated with two types of information: (i) domain-speciﬁc semantic relations between en-\ntities, covering, inter alia , causal chains; and (ii) the complex propositional inference structure\nunderlying the decision, using a default logic notation. The authors evisage this information be-\ning used in conjunction with more basic automatic annotations of syntactic dependencies and\n\n--- Page 144 ---\n132 9. GENERATING ARGUMENTATIVE TEXT\ncase-semantic relations, so that a retrieval engine could ﬁnd components of arguments that are\nrelevant to a new case and can be used to produce cogent arguments.\nWide-coverageparagraphgeneration Less ‘deep’ in annotation but fully implemented is the\ntext production system presented by Sato et al. [2015]. Here, the user can enter a topic in the\nform of a motion sentence ( This house should do X ) and a stance toward that motion, and the\nsystem generates three argumentative paragraphs, each relating to a particular aspect of the mo-\ntion.\nFigure 9.4: Excerpt from the ‘value dictionary’ used in the argument generator by Sato et al.\n[2015, p. 113], used with permission.\nThe paragraphs are produced by selecting (and partly modifying) sentences from\n10,000,000 news texts of the Gigaword corpus; hence, the system is not restricted to a few\ndomains only. Manual work is restricted to creating various lexicons of epistemic verbs, evalua-\ntive modiﬁers, etc. The text corpus is stored in a database and annotated with automatic syntax\nparses plus instances of the lexical relations that are speciﬁed in the resources. The processing\npipeline works as follows.\n1.Analyzethemotion: The sentence entered by the user—for example, Thishouseshouldban\ngamblinginthecity —is divided into a ﬁxed number of components: a keyphrase capturing\nthe motion topic, the predicate used in the topic, polarity, etc.\n2.Aspect selection: For the generator, the potentially interesting aspects of the motion are\nthose that trigger evaluative judgment in the audience; the authors hence call these aspects\n‘values’. The system retrieves sentences that contain lexical aﬀect-relations between the\nmotionkeyphraseandaphrasefoundinthevaluedictionary(seetheexcerptinFigure 9.4).\nThe sentence “Gambling increases the number of crimes”, for example, is a good candidate\nbecause increase is a verb of the semantic class aﬀect, and crimeis commonly evaluated as\nnegative. The system tries to make sure that the polarity of the retrieved sentences matches\nthat of the desired argumentation and selects sentence groups for ﬁve aspects/values.\n3.Sentenceretrieval: A full-text search is executed on the corpus, using a query that is being\nbuilt from the motion and value phrases. Among the sentences retrieved, the system ﬁlters\nfor the right polarity (so that an argumentatively-coherent text will result) and it prefers\nsentences that contain promote/suppress relationships.\n\n--- Page 145 ---\n9.2. GENERATING TEXT FROM TEXT 133\n4.Sentenceordering,rephrasing: To build a paragraph, sentences are arranged according to\nan ordering scheme suggesting that the text starts with a claim sentence and is followed by\nsupport sentences. To determine claims, a binary classiﬁer is run on the sentences (this is\nthe task we discussed in Chapter 5). The supporting statements are ordered by maximizing\nthe connectivity between sentences, as suggested by Tan et al. [2013]. Finally, a certain\namount of rephrasing is done: details such as dates or proper names are being eliminated\nfrom the sentences.\nTo evaluate the approach, texts were generated for 50 motions from debatabase.org. Human\njudges ranked the paragraphs (consisting of seven sentences each) on a scale from 0 (makes no\nsense) to 4 (sounds natural). Of the 150 sentences, 86 received label 0, indicating that—probably\nnot surprsing—the overall problem is quite diﬃcult. The three major problems identiﬁed in error\nanalysis were polarity computation, analysis of diﬃcult motion sentences entered by the user,\nand erroneous sentence retrieval due to lexical ambiguity etc.\nRhetorics in re-generation Considering the diﬃculties in producing acceptable text by re-\ncombining sentences found ‘in the wild’, some researchers suggested to pay more attention to\nrhetorics when making selection and ordering decisions. Beyond the patterns of ordering that\nhavebeen used in earlier work (and which wereusually taken from guides to good writing), Aris-\ntotle’s means of persuasion (logos, ethos, pathos ; see Section 1.1.2) have already received some (if\nnot much) attention in argument analysis; Duthie et al. [2016], for instance, presented a study\non ﬁnding ethos in political debates. For the generation task, Wachsmuth et al. [2018] suggest\nthat the three means also need to be accounted for when recombining sentences into a new text.\nThey sketch a model for selecting and ordering sentences, which takes in particular the distinc-\ntion between logos- and pathos-oriented argumentation into account. To gather evidence for\nthe importance of this factor, they conducted an experiment with 26 human ‘authors’ who had to\nrecombine ADUs from a subset of the argumentative microtext corpus (see Section 4.2.2). Ten\ntopics were selected, each of which was addressed by 4-9 short texts from the corpus. Claims and\nother units (i.e., supporting and opposing statements) were put into topic-speciﬁc pools, where\nthe authors could draw from. For this to work, the ADUs need to be as context-independent\nas possible, and the authors applied two operations: removing connectives, and replacing pro-\nnouns by their antecedents. Authors were instructed to build both logos- and pathos-oriented\npersuasive texts, using these instructions.\n•Logos-oriented: Argue based on logical reasoning, which means to make rational and\nlogical conclusions toward the intended stance on the given topic.\n•Pathos-oriented: Argue based on emotional reasoning, which means to appeal to the\nemotions of the reader regarding the topic within your arguments.\nTheADUsinthepoolhadnoinformationonlogosorpathosattached,soauthorshadtoidentify\nit themselves in the sentences. The study found that for selecting ADUs from the pool, the agree-\n\n--- Page 146 ---\n134 9. GENERATING ARGUMENTATIVE TEXT\nment between authors is signiﬁcantly higher within the logos-oriented and the pathos-oriented\ntexts, which indicates that authors (and hence also readers) can indeed sense the distinction. For\narranging the ADUs in the text, three favorite ordering patterns emerged (the most popular one:\nclaim - opp. - supp. - supp. - supp.), but no diﬀerence between logos and pathos texts clould be\nobserved.\nOpen-domain claim generation An interesting step toward open-domain argument gener-\nation was reported by Bilu and Slonim [2016]. These authors sought to minimize the role of\nhuman intervention, and therefore reduced the problem to one subtask: claim generation. The\nbasic idea is to produce new claims by “recycling” linguistic predicates found in the claims of\nother arguments, which Bilu and Slonim illustrate with the example: given the claim banning\nviolentvideogamesisaviolationoffreespeech for the topic banningviolentvideogames, one might\ntransfer this to the topic internetcensorship and generate the claim internetcensorshipisaviolation\nof free speech . Thus, a key task for this approach is to learn the contexts allowing or disallowing a\ncandidate re-combination. The proposed claim generation algorithm works in three steps.\n1.Preprocessing:buildpredicatelexicon(PL) Givenasetofmanuallydetectedclaimsfrom\nthe work of Aharoni et al. [2014] (see Section 5.3.4), extract from each claim the verb and\na concatenation of its right-modiﬁers, which together form the predicate p. It is added to\nthe PL if it contains at least one sentiment word (to select predicates with a clear stance\ntoward their topic). In this way, 1,203 PL entries are produced.\n2.ClaimGeneration: givenatopic t,thepredicates pinthePLaresortedfortheirsimilarity\nwith t, using a measure involving word embeddings. For the top kpredicates, construct\na claim candidate by setting the predicate to pand the subject to the topic t. (See the\nvideo-game example above.) This may require morphological adjustments (esp. for singu-\nlar/plural matching), which are done with the ‘SimpleNLG’ sentence realization compo-\nnent [Gatt and Reiter ,2009].\n3.Claim Selection: a logistic regression classiﬁer ranks the candidate claims for their ap-\npropriateness. It uses three types of features for capturing:\n• predicates pthat seem inherently amenable to generating claims: They state some-\nthing fairly general about their subject, and they are not very speciﬁc to the topic of\ntheir original sentence (by computing similarity);\n• predicates pthat seem relevant for the target topic; this is computed as similarity\nbetween pand the topic’s n-gram lexicon. This resource in turn is built by measuring\nfrequencies of occurrence in topic-related and unrelated Wikipedia articles. Identi-\nfying topic-related articles is a manual step in the overall procedure (and had been\ndone in the earlier work reported in Section 5.3.4); and\n• claim sentences that seem to be linguistically acceptable and plausible, which is de-\ntermined via frequencies of its words and n-grams in Wikipedia.\n\n--- Page 147 ---\n9.3. SUMMARY 135\nIn an experiment for testing the system, it generated claims for 67 topics, which were extracted\nfrom motions on debatabase (at idebate.org). For all topics, previously annotated relevant\nWikipedia articles were already available. The system produced 28 candidate claims per topic,\nand they were presented to crowdworkers via Amazon Turk. Given a debatabase motion and\n10 candidate claims, an annotator had to decide which claims are appropriate for the motion.\nEvaluating this approach is not straightforward, but the authors report that the claim selection\nclassiﬁer achieved an accuracy of 0.75.\n9.3 SUMMARY\nThe strength of the more traditional domain-speciﬁc, handcrafted work discussed in the ﬁrst\nsection was that it had to implement the complete process (text planning, microplanning, real-\nization) as well as the required lexical and knowledge resources for systematically mapping an\nabstract speciﬁcation of communicative goals to a short text in natural language. In doing so, it\nthoroughly attended to the inﬂuence of argumentative aims on the diﬀerent stages of a text pro-\nduction process. The corresponding weakness, obviously, is that this type of work does not easily\ngeneralize to other domains, and that many of the fundamental questions on reusable linguistic\nand non-linguistic knowledge bases from the last century are still open. Therefore, as sketched in\nthe second section, the turn to robust methods for re-producing argumentative text from pieces\nthat have previously been found by automatic mining makes a lot of sense. For such approaches\nto work across several domains—or even in an open-domain setting—it seems that the robust\nautomatic annotation of potential argument components is key: in order to build a good text\nfrom segments, we need to know something about the segments. Attributes exploited so far\ninclude topic aspects, stance/polarity, and means of persuasion (logos, ethos, pathos). As there\nis only early work along these lines so far, with very few running implementations, this list is\nlikely to be revised and reﬁned, on the way to producing readable and pragmatically appropriate\nargumentative text from segments that were found out there ‘in the wild’.\n\n--- Page 148 ---\n137\nC H A P T E R 10\nSummary and Perspectives\nWe conclude our survey of argumentation mining with four ﬁnal steps. First, we provide a sum-\nmary of the core tasks presented in Chapters 5,6, and7, formulated as a procedure for designing\na task-speciﬁc annotation scheme of the desired level of complexity. Then, in Section 10.2we\nobserve that automatically ﬁnding arguments in text or dialogue is not an end in itself per se,\nand thus we brieﬂy consider some follow-up tasks (e.g., visualization, summarization) that may\nbe applied to the collected arguments in order to make use of them. Next, Section 10.3turns\nto the applied side and summarizes a number of downstream applications—most of which have\nbeen mentioned already in previous chapters, but here they are collected. Notice that this is not\nintended as comprehensive survey; we merely provide some indicative pointers to the literature\nas food for thought. We close with a short outlook in Section 10.4.\n10.1 ARGUMENTATION MINING: A COMMON KERNEL\nWork on argumentation mining revolves around a fairly well-deﬁned common target—the\nargument—but then quickly spreads into several diﬀerent directions. This is because argumen-\ntation occurs in very diﬀerent situations of language use, and with a variety of diﬀerent purposes.\nTherefore, the common target does not easily translate into a common set of well-deﬁned sub-\ntasksandmethodsforsolvingthem.Instead,dependingonthepurpose,diﬀerentsetsofsubtasks\ncan become relevant.\nNonetheless, taking the gist of the exposition in Chapters 5–7, we now propose a common\nkernel of a procedure for deﬁning the argumentation mining task, focusing here on monologue\ntext. The procedure can serve as a guideline or orientation in developing some initial idea for an\nargumentation mining application into a more speciﬁc project outline or an algorithm.\nHow to design an argumentation mining algorithm.\n1. Weassumethatwehaveamonologuetext Tthatweknowisargumentative(eitherbecause\nwe have found out—see Section 5.1—or because we know beforehand, for example on the\nbasis of its genre).\n2.Tincludes a minimum of two argumentative discourse units (ADUs) of at least two dif-\nferent types (see step 3). Each ADU is a contiguous span of text: depending on task for-\nmulation, it may be restricted to be a sentence, or it can be a smaller or larger unit. ADUs\ndo not overlap with each other. Tmay consist of just a sequence of ADUs, or of a mix\n\n--- Page 149 ---\n138 10. SUMMARY AND PERSPECTIVES\nof ADUs and non-argumentative text spans. Note that deﬁning what content is required\nfor a text span to be an ADU is to some extent also task-dependent (we have suggested a\nfairly general deﬁnition on page 63).\n3. The set of ADU typesconsists of claimand evidence, and possibly more, depending on\nthe task.\n4.Ifthetaskwarrantstheassumptionthatthereisonlyoneclaiminthetext,andifnofurther\ntypes of ADU are required, thenthe basic problem speciﬁcation is complete: Find the\nclaimADU and all evidence ADUs in T. Implicitly, a support relation holds between\neach evidence ADU and the claim ADU. Go to step 8.\nOtherwise, continue with step 5.\n5.Ifthe task suggests that there may be several claims, and associated evidence ADUs, then\nan explicit support relation needs to be established. support is a total and surjective\nmapping from evidence ADUs to claim ADUs. It may be decided that one item of\nevidence shall not support more than one claim; in this case, the mapping is injective.\n6.Ifthe task suggests that certain ADUs can function simultaneously as claim and evi-\ndence (i.e., they are supporting something else, and they receive support), thenlikewise\nthe support relation needs to be established. In this case it is a transitive relation (allow-\ning for ‘serial support’; cf. Figure 3.1). One may also introduce a separate ADU type, but\nthis is redundant, as the double-faced ADUs can be identiﬁed via outgoing and incoming\nrelations.\n7.Ifthe task suggests that the ‘opposing view’ need not be accounted for in analyzing T,\nthengo to step 8.\nOtherwise, depending on the task, diﬀerent levels of complexity are possible.\n• In the simplest case, when there is only a single claim and a number of evidence\nunits (cf. step 4), it suﬃces to introduce an additional ADU type (e.g., oppose),\nbecause any oppose unit will implicitly attack the unique claim.\n• If the analysis allows for multiple claims in T, or if an oppose segment may be in-\nvolved in a sub-structure (see below), a new relation type (typically: attack) needs\nto be added. Sub-structure arises when:\n–an oppose segment may be in support relation to another oppose segment,\nand/or\n–an oppose segment may be countered by the proponent, either by a single move,\nor recursively by a sub-structure. In this case, attack relations may hold between\nan oppose ADUanda claim/evidence unit,orviceversa.Thatis,itisnecessary\nto make both the types and the relations explicit in the representation.\n\n--- Page 150 ---\n10.2. AFTER MINING: WHAT TO DO WITH ARGUMENTS 139\n8.Ifthetasksuggeststhatsub-typesof claim, evidence, or oppose shouldbeintroduced,\nthenthat can be done.\nLikewise, ifsub-relations of support, attack are necessary, thenthey can be added.\n(For attack, a customary distinction is that between rebut and undercut.)\n9. The result of establishing a set of relations on the set of ADUs in the text (either implicitly,\nas in step 4, or explicitly) is a representation of the argumentation structure of the text.\nDepending on the number of claims present and on the properties of the relations, it is\neither a tree, or a forest, or a (single-rooted or multi-rooted) graph, whose root node(s) are\nof type claim.\n10.2 AFTER MINING: WHAT TO DO WITH ARGUMENTS\nVisualization In a way, visualization was at the very beginning of the computational work\non argumentation: The mapping tools discussed in Section 3.6help people to arrange their\nthoughts, or organize the web of contributions made in a dialogue involving two or more parties.\nLikewise, it seems natural to apply those techniques to arguments that have been gathered and\nanalyzed by automatic mining techniques—both as a means of qualitative error analysis for the\nmining techniques, and to provide input to human analysts or debaters. Some current research is\nlooking into building graphs from arguments or from stances (e.g., Toledo-Ronen et al. [2016]),\nwhich may also lead to visual presentation in one way or another. Also, Sanchan et al. [2017]\nsuggest to build charts that show the ﬂow of topics, and their intensity, in a debate. El-Assady\net al.[2016] apply various visualization techniques to debate protocols, too, emphasizing the\nutility of such an approach for studying political deliberation processes.\nSummarization Another technique that may be needed once argumentation mining works in\npractice at a larger scale is textual summarization. Assuming that a set of arguments has been\nfound for a topic, and it has been analyzed, the next step is to compute relations between those\narguments, so as to identify identical, similar, and diﬀerent arguments. For a good summary,\nthe diﬀerent aspects (or ‘facets’) raised by the variety of arguments would need to be identiﬁed.\nThis is not yet an area of much active research, but as one initial step, a dataset from the Internet\nArgument Corpus (see Sections 4.2.1and7.1.1) has been extended with human-written sum-\nmaries, and ﬁrst results on argument facet similarity were reported by Misra et al. [2015, 2017].1\nSimilarly, Boltužić and Šnajder [2016] explored the task of computing argument similarity by\nclustering techniques. Egan et al. [2016] outline an approach to summarizing the key issues\nbrought up in political debates, and some researchers have applied standard text summarization\ntechniques to online debates, extracting sentences that are topic-central and exhibit sentiment\n[Ranade et al., 2013]. Finally, Saint-Dizier [2018] proposes to use tools and techniques from\nlexical semantics (in particular, the ‘Generative Lexicon’ approach of Pustejovsky [1986]) for\nproducing summaries of argumentation.\n1The summary corpus is available for research: https://nlds.soe.ucsc.edu/node/30 (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 151 ---\n140 10. SUMMARY AND PERSPECTIVES\nEvaluation Finally, argument mining also needs to address the important task of evaluation,\nwhich has been discussed in the discussion of argument quality assessments in Section 8.3. In\nparticular, inconsistent lines of arguing can be determined through solving for acceptability in\nargumentation frameworks, implemented by a large number of argumentation solvers such as\nArg&Dec, ASPARTIX, ASPIC, and Carneades. Whereas currently, consistency calculations\nassume manually-built arguments or controlled natural language (e.g., Wyner et al. [2016]),\nmined arguments can be directly evaluated, when mapped to a suitable representation. In the\nstate-of-the art approach, Cabrio and Villata [2016] calculate argument acceptance conditions\nautomaticallyfromaDebatepediadebateusingaweightedabstractdialecticalframework,which\nhas been automatically induced from textual entailment.\nBesideslogicalconsistency,weintroducedinSection 8.3someinitialworkondetermining\nother dimensionsof quality and the degree of convincingness of arguments. First sets of annotated\ndata have been made available, and some results on automatic classiﬁcation have already been\nobtained. Still, this line of research is certainly still in its infancy.\n10.3 SOME APPLICATIONS OF ARGUMENTATION\nMINING\nSupportingsensemaking Sensemaking refers to making sense of larger or disparate amounts\nof information to construct narratives or explanations, as an individual or as a group. Tools for\nsensemaking support human reasoning, for instance by ﬂagging inconsistencies or visualizing or\nsummarizing information. For example, Dispute Finder highlights disputed claims on the web\nto support skeptical readers [Ennals et al. ,2010]. Among numerous collaborative sensemaking\nplatforms, Videolyzer provides a collaborative platform for assessing the veracity of claims in\nonline political videos [Diakopoulos et al., 2009]; CommentSpace [Willett et al., 2011] helps\nteams gather evidence and organize comments on visualizations and websites. Schneider [2014]\nsuggests argumentation mining could be used to support open source and open knowledge\nprojectsinsensemakinganddecision-making.Groupdecision-makingoftendependsonﬁnding\nand comparing rationales for claims, and may start with a sensemaking process. For instance, vi-\nsualization and representation of diﬃcult conversations is key in dialogue mapping, an approach\nto meeting facilitation that uses argument mapping software [ Conklin, 2006]. Argumentation\nmining could help extract and organize claims and arguments to support visualization, summa-\nrization, synthesis, or evaluation components in such applications.\nPractical reasoning Practical reasoning refers to deciding on a practical course of action. It\nhas been extensively studied in the argumentation community; as just one pointer we mention\nWalton’s book on the subject [ Walton, 2015]. Argument maps are commonly used to help make\na debate accessible. In a computer program called Virgil, for instance, Ball[1994] applied Toul-\nmin’s model to analyze public policy. More recently, Renton and Macintosh [2007] presented\nmaps of the Scottish Parliament’s debate and policymaking on banning smoking in public places\n\n--- Page 152 ---\n10.3. SOME APPLICATIONS OF ARGUMENTATION MINING 141\nthat provide a ‘policy memory’. Systems for supporting public discourse on topics of public con-\ncern, such as ConsiderIt2[Kriplean et al. ,2012], have developed visualizations and analytics.\nArgumentation mining could reduce the manual work in creating support systems for practical\nreasoning.\nArgumentRetrieval Retrieving arguments from text collections corresponds to the core tasks\nof ﬁnding claims and evidence, as discussed in Chapters 5and6. For many purposes, these steps\nalso constitute a complete application. In the science domain, for instance, being able to ﬁnd the\nmain new points in collections of papers would be extremely helpful. This is the aim of Rastegar-\nMojarad et al. [2016], who crawl PubMed abstracts and aim at detecting evidence statements,\nwhich are then mapped to a formal language (‘Biological expression language’). Similarly, in\nthe legal domain the retrieval of arguments made in support of a particular decision is of great\ninterest. An overview is provided by Ashley and Walker [2013a].\nTaking the retrieval task from speciﬁc domains and text collection out into the web\npresents a set of technical challenges for large-scale processing, as surveyed by Wachsmuth et al.\n[2017c]. One particular and very important subtask is to determine the appropriateness or rel-\nevance of a candidate argument for a speciﬁc search query. Wachsmuth et al. [2017d] suggest\nbuilding a graph of arguments found in a document collection, and then applying a variant of the\nPageRank algorithm for ranking these arguments according to relevance. Those authors show\nthat this approach outperforms various other candidate ranking methods. A benchmark dataset\nis made available.3\nSupportingWeb-ScaleDiscourseandDebate Theuseofwebdataforargumentationmining\nhas been mentioned many times in this book, and we have pointed to a number of corpora that\nhave been drawn from online debate forums, as to provide training and test data for mining\ntechniques.Fromadiﬀerentviewpoint,thegoalofactively supporting theexchangeofarguments\non the web constitutes another promising application of argumentation mining. This starts with\nproviding technical frameworks for managing discussions, and including argument detection\ncapabilities, as for instance suggested by Cabrio et al. [2013b]. A related task is that of providing\nactive support to human debaters by suggesting suitable arguments to them. Rosenfeld and\nKraus[2015] conducted large-scale empirical studies on what arguments people select under\nparticular circumstance, and on this basis designed a Predictive and Relevance-based Heuristic\nagent. Taking this a step further to actual debating technology requires an interplay of many\ncomponents (of which the core argumentation mining functionality is but one), as the overview\nbyLawrence et al. [2017a] explains.\nSentiment analysis Connections between argumentation and sentiment analysis have been\nexplored by many researchers, especially in the context of product reviews. For example, Wyner\net al.[2012] studied the role of sentiment words and discourse relations for the analysis of cam-\n2https://consider.it (accessed May 28, 2018).\n3http://argumentation.bplaced.net/arguana/data (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 153 ---\n142 10. SUMMARY AND PERSPECTIVES\nera reviews, and suggest an argumentation scheme for representing the underlying structure.\nWachsmuth et al. [2015] predict the global sentiment of product reviews from the ﬂowof sen-\ntiment, which is modeled as a sequence of sentence sentiment scores. The authors propose a\nmethod for comparing such sequences to each other and demonstrate its utility for three diﬀer-\nent review domains. They suggest thinking of sentiment ﬂow as a key aspect of the argumen-\ntation structure underlying the review. Finally, we mention Liu et al. [2017], who found that\nmanually-annotated argumentative moves (claim, premise, background, recommendation, etc.)\ncan signiﬁcantly improve the prediction of review helpfulness of hotel reviews.\nWriting Support Providing students with qualitative feedback on their writing starts with\nthe word processor complaining about grammatical errors or stylistic infelicities. But it can go\nmuch further, and also include aspects of good argumentation. In the previous chapters, we have\nreferred to work on student essays several times; recall the idea of checking whether arguments\nare suﬃciently supported [ Stab and Gurevych, 2017a], or whether critical questions of argument\nschemes are attended to by the writers [ Song et al. ,2014]. The latter approach is elaborated in\nmore detail from the perspective of education research by Nussbaum and Edwards [2011]. For a\nbroader survey of (pre-argumentation-mining) computational tools that can support teaching of\nargumentation, see Scheuer et al. [2010]. And an online demo of the ArgRewritePITTRevision\nWriting Assistant shows how argumentative aspects are part of the feedback to the student.4\nEssay Scoring Closely related to writing support, automatic essay scoring is an application\nthat in general needs to consider a wide range of linguistic parameters, but for the speciﬁc class\nof argumentative essays, techniques from argumentation mining have proven to be helpful. For\ninstance, Ong et al. [2014] developed a rule-based approach to ﬁrst label the sentences of an es-\nsay with a functional tag: Claim, Supports, Opposes, Citation, Hypothesis, and Current Study.5\nThen, another rule set maps the distribution of labels to a number of points corresponding to\na grade. This relatively simple approach was found to yield acceptable results for comparative\nranking (but not for grading). In contrast, a rich feature set for classiﬁcation was employed\nbyPersing and Ng [2015], which included semantic frames, coreference, predictions of agree-\nment with the prompt, classiﬁed argument components, and more. On a corpus of 1,000 essays\nfrom the International Corpus of Learner English, Persing and Ng [2015] showed that their\nsystem, after feature optimization, signiﬁcantly outperforms the results of Ong et al.\nSong et al. [2014], who exploited the critical questions of argumentation schemes (see\nSection 8.2.2) concluded that their results can contribute “additional useful information about\nessay quality to a strong baseline essay scoring model”, which is Educational Testing Service’s\nE-Rater system. Argumentative features improved on another strong baseline, the open source\nEnhanced AI Scoring Engine, in Nguyen and Litman [2018]’s experiments, particularly when\ntest and training sets responded to diﬀerent writing prompts.\n4http://argrewrite.cs.pitt.edu/ (accessed May 28, 2018).\n5This resembles the ‘argumentative zoning’ of Teufel and Moens [2002], see p. 24.\n\n--- Page 154 ---\n10.4. OUTLOOK 143\nWachsmuth et al. [2016] provide a comparative analysis of a broad range of features (in-\ncluding assessments of linear order, as discussed in Section 7.2.2) in terms of four diﬀerent\naspects of essay scoring: organization, thesis clarity, prompt adherence, and argument strength.\nA strong feature is the distribution of argument components across the paragraphs of an essay.\nSimilarly, Ghosh et al. [2016] manually annotated TOEFL essays and showed that knowledge\nabout argument components and, more importantly, argumentative relations can contribute to\npredicting essay scores.\nDialoguesystems One long-term perspective is the automatic dialogue system, possibly built\nupon chatbot technology, that will be able to give advice (on how to act, on what to buy, and so\non) and provide reasons for that advice. And ideally, it will be able to not only answer a user’s\nquestion but also discern their arguments and respond to them intelligently. Such systems can\nbe bootstrapped by ﬁrst ‘harvesting’ arguments, counterarguments, and audience values from\npeople, as Chalaguine et al. [2018] investigate for health-related behavior change. ‘Persuasive\ndialogue’ is a very active research area, which we have only touched upon in this book, when\ndescribing the Amazon Turk study by Lukin et al. [2017]. More connections between dialogue\nresearch and argumentation mining will most certainly be built, to textual dialogue but also to\nspeech—a topic that we have excluded completely in this book. For a start, the work by Lippi\nand Torroni [2016b] can be considered, which reports on experiments on detecting claims in\noral political debate, incorporating speech features. In terms of language resources, a new audio\nand textual dataset for debate research has recently been created by recording 60 speeches on\ncontroversial topics by professional debaters [Mirkin et al., 2018].6\n10.4 OUTLOOK\nLike any technology, argumentation mining has a potential to beneﬁt society as well as to be\nturned to harmful uses. In sentiment analysis, for instance, work on analyzing and generating\nreviews has in recent years certainly increased the need for ﬁnding fake reviews. The potential\nimpact of argumentation mining seems to us even larger, with its potential to integrate rationales\nas well as emotions. The ubiquity of argumentation makes it particularly powerful. Being able to\nquickly digest arguments in text, summarize them, and create a debating system would enable\nautomated arguing systems to inﬂuence humans, whether in chatbots or in dialogue systems.\nAutomated agents that can argue persuasively may be seen as beneﬁcial when they convince us\nto exercise more, but harmful when used for marketing. Such agents might outreason humans,\nas chess systems do, yet interact in a home-like environment, such as current smartphone as-\nsistants and home automation systems do. When arguing with humans, there is little recourse\nagainst opponents who argue without conviction—playing devil’s advocate—or who artiﬁcially\nstrengthen a position (as the Greek sophists were criticized for making the weaker argument\n6The recorded debating dataset is available for research: https://www.research.ibm.com/haifa/dept/vst/debating\n_data.shtml (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 155 ---\n144 10. SUMMARY AND PERSPECTIVES\nappear the stronger argument). Researchers must be alert to such risks. Communities consid-\nering ethics7can provide guidance, and we encourage the reader to attend to comprehensive\nand thorough evaluations of computer systems and their impacts, including analysis of possible\nrisks.8\nWhile it may seem a little irritating that this new research ﬁeld is not really quite settled\nyet, the positive side is that there are so many things still waiting to be done: argumentation\noccurs in everyday conversation between couples and in families, in the workplace, and of course\neverywhere in the media. There are the more regulated formats such as parliamentary debates,\nlawmakingandjurisprudence;thedecidedly-informalclaimsmadeviaTwitteroritscousins;and\ntheintermediate formof thestudent’sessay.All these—andmore—invitedigestion,sorting,and\nfurther availability for in-depth studies on how argumentation works, when it is successful or\npersuasive, and when it has ﬂaws. The more reliable the automatic tools that support this, the\nbigger the picture that can be drawn.\nAs we remarked earlier, we believe that at some point, further progress will depend on the\nconnection between language processing and automated reasoning (which in turn will require\nhelp from computational semantics). While there is little work on building bridges between\nthesecommunitiessofar,supplementinganautomaticallyconstructedrepresentationofthekind\ndiscussed in Chapters 5–7, with robust systems that can evaluate statements against background\nknowledge, and perform consistency checks, can open up a great many new doors.\n7Such as the Ethics in NLP workshop series: http://www.ethicsinnlp.org (accessed May 28, 2018).\n8See the ACM Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct https://www.acm.org/about-acm/acm-code-of-ethics-\nand-professional-conduct (accessed May 28, 2018).\n\n--- Page 156 ---\n145\nBibliography\nRob Abbott, Marilyn Walker, Pranav Anand, Jean E. DOI: 10.3115/1118253.1118262 125\n\n--- Page 182 ---\n171\nAuthors’ Biographies\nMANFRED STEDE\nManfred Stede is a professor of Applied Computational Linguistics at the University of Pots-\ndam, Germany. He obtained his Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Toronto in\n1996 with a thesis on language generation; in those years he studied discourse structure primarily\nfor its role in text generation. After working for ﬁve years in a machine translation project at TU\nBerlin, he moved to Potsdam in 2001, where his interests shifted to text analysis. He conducted\nresearch projects on applications like information extraction and text summarization, and on\nmore theoretical matters like the semantics and pragmatics of connectives. In conjunction with\nresearch on discourse parsing, he began to work on argumentation in the 2000s, focusing ﬁrst\non newspaper editorials. Following the design of an annotation scheme, he proceeded to work\non approaches to deriving argumentation structure trees from short texts, and on various other\naspects of argumentation mining.\nJODI SCHNEIDER\nJodi Schneider is an assistant professor in the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign’s\nSchool of Information Sciences. She has held research positions across the United States as well\nas in Ireland, England, France, and Chile. She earned her Ph.D. in informatics (National Uni-\nversity of Ireland, Galway), two Master’s degrees in library & information science (UIUC) and in\nmathematics (UT-Austin), and a Bachelor’s degree (Great Books, St. John’s College, Annapo-\nlis, MD). She has authored over 30 research publications on topics in argumentation, artiﬁcial\nintelligence, biomedical informatics, and computer-supported collaborative work. Her research\nuses arguments, evidence, and persuasion as a lens to study scholarly communication and social\nmedia. She also develops and evaluates tools to manage scientiﬁc evidence from the biomedical\nliterature with an NIH-funded project, Text Mining Pipeline to Accelerate Systematic Reviews\nin Evidence-Based Medicine.\n\n--- Page 183 ---\n173\nIndex\nAbstract argumentation, 114,116\nADVISOR II, 127\nArgument\nCategories, 3\nComponent, 27\nConvergent, 28\nDeﬁnition, 1\nDivergent, 28\nFallacy, 8\nLinked, 28\nArgument comparison, 118\nArgument consistency, 113\nArgument diagram, 27,39,42\nTools,41,42\nArgument Interchange Format (AIF), 42,43\nArgument map, 36,39–41\nArgument model, 31\nCohen, 35\nDung Frameworks, 34,35\nIBIS,35\nThe New Rhetoric, 33\nToulmin, 33,48\nArgument quality, 113,117,119,140\nArgument retrieval, 9,141\nArgument summarization, 9,139\nArgument synthesis, 125\nArgument visualization, 139\nArgumentation\nAnnotation, 45–51\nMining (deﬁnition), 6normative, 4\nStructure, 6\nArgumentation scheme, 30,109,112,113\nArgumentum model of topics, 31,32,\n110\nArgumentation solver, 114,116\nArgumentation strategy, 105\nArgumentation structure\nHierarchical, 100,102–104\nSequential, 104\nArgumentative Discourse Unit, 6,62,63\nDeﬁnition, 63\nArgumentative zoning, 25,66\nArgumentativity classiﬁcation, 7,58–62\nAristotle, 1,5\nAttack, 85\nRebut, 6,86\nUndercut, 6,86\nAutomatic reasoning, 8\nClaim, 27\ngeneration, 134\nidentiﬁcation, 66\nConnective, 20,80\nCorpus\nABCD, 52\nAIFdb, 113\nAraucaria, 53,60,66,110\nArgum.       "extracted_text": "--- Page 2 ---\n \n LEARNING LEGAL \nSKILLS AND REASONING \nLanguage skills, study skills, argument skills and the skills associated with dispute \nresolution are vital to every law student, professional lawyer and academic. The 5th edition of Learning Legal Skills and Reasoning draws on a range of areas of law to show how these key skills can be learnt and mastered, bridging the gap between substantive legal subjects and the skills required to become a successful law student. \nThe book is split into four sections: \n  Sources of law: Including domestic, European and international law. \n  Working with the law: Featuring advice on how to fnd and understand the most appropriate legislation and cases. \n  Applying your research:  How to construct a legal argument, answer a problem \nquestion and present orally (mooting). \n  Skills for solving disputes:  From negotiation to mediation and beyond. \nPacked full of practical examples and diagrams to illustrate each legal skill, this new edition has been fully updated and now includes a new chapter on drafting. It will be an essential companion for any student wishing to acquire the legal skills necessary to become a successful law student. \nTobias Kliem is the Head of Arden University’s Berlin Campus. Previously, he worked \nas Programme Lead in Law at Oxford Brookes University and as a Senior Lecturer at Canterbury Christ Church University. His research interests and teaching expertise lie in the feld of constitutional, European and international law. \nBen Waters is Principal Lecturer in Law at Canterbury Christ Church University; he is also \na qualifed Solicitor (non-practising) and an accredited Mediator. He has a particular inter -\nest in dispute resolution and specifcally mediation, areas in which he has active teaching, scholarly and research interests. \n\n--- Page 4 ---\nLEARNING LEGAL \nSKILLS AND REASONING \n5th edition \nSharon Hanson, Tobias \nKliem and Ben Waters \n\n\n--- Page 5 ---\n \n \n \n   \n \n \n Fifth edition published 2022 \nby Routledge 2 Park Square, Milton Park, Abingdon, Oxon, OX14 4RN \nand by Routledge \n605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158 \nRoutledge is an imprint of the Taylor & Francis Group, an informa business © 2022 Sharon Hanson, Tobias Kliem, and Ben Waters The right of Sharon Hanson, Tobias Kliem, and Ben Waters to be identifed \nas authors of this work has been asserted by them in accordance with sections 77 and 78 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988. \nAll rights reserved. This new and revised 16-chapter text is designed to consolidate the magnif -\nicent work that was started by Sharon Hanson in 1999 with publication of the book’s frst \nedition. More than 20 years later the 5th edition of this valuable legal skills text continues to adopt the well-known user-friendly and practical approach of the previous editions of Learning Legal Skills and Reasoning , by consolidating the material into 16 chapters which \nare divided into four discrete parts: ‘Sources of law’, ‘Working with the law’, ‘Applying your research’ and ‘Skills for resolving disputes’. Whilst some of the previous chapters have merged, many have been retained, and there is one new chapter: Drafting skills, which can be found in \nPart 4. \nThe book continues to refect the need for new law undergraduates to grasp a broad \nrange of skills, and our commitment as authors and editors of the latest edition has been to deliver these in one manageable text retaining the important substance of that which has gone before together with additions. The book resumes its objective of entering into dialogue with the reader, explaining how to understand and apply the full range of legal and academic skills required by law students. It addresses basic issues of concern for many students as well as more sophisticated skills relating to arguing, reading the law and those used for resolving disputes. The book is deliberately written in an accessible style which will ensure that students new to the study of law are not overawed as they embark upon their journey through legal education or by the demands of studying a chal -\nlenging academic discipline. \nThe study of law requires students to acquire a range of new and sometimes chal -\nlenging skills. The narrative of this practical manual aims to engage the reader in a highly personalised conversation, at times presuming to voice their worst fears, ‘What if I am not good enough?’, ‘What if I cannot understand?’, ‘What if I fail something?’ The book helps students to confront these uncertainties, and throughout the book context is provided for the reader, which engages the student in dialogue about the matters under consideration. The authors and editors retain Dr Hanson’s belief in the importance of diagrams to dem -\nonstrate interconnections that are not apparent simply from reading or hearing narrative. As she would have wished, they remain one of the particular characteristics of this text introduced by her, as well as the range of exercises and activities with suggested answers to test skills’ development, together with glossaries of troublesome terms. \n\n--- Page 31 ---\n XXX PREFACE \nAs Sharon said in the preface to the 4th edition, this book would not have been pos -\nsible without the incredible support she received from her then-editor Fiona Briden and \nher assistant Emily Wells.
