It can \nbe approached in an order to suit the reader. As a whole it is designed to enable the law student to gain skills vital to the academic stage of legal education. \nThis is a method and skills book, and it is therefore no substitute for texts in your sub -\nstantive areas of study such as criminal law, the law of contract or the English legal sys -\ntem. The book draws on a range of areas of law to demonstrate skills development and to alert you to some of the confusions and mistakes easily made. It is a book that bridges the gap between substantive legal subjects and the skills that need to be acquired in relation to: \nStudy skills How to develop independent and highly effcient learning \nstrategies \nIT skills How to engage with email, word processing, virtual learning environments, internet searches, e-library use, database manipulation \nLanguage skills How to competently understand and use ordinary English and legal English terminology \nCritical thinking skills How to develop the ability to constantly question, seeking the underlying assumptions behind arguments, taking nothing for granted, seeking evidence for your assertions, questioning your own positions \nLegal research skills How to fnd law and texts about law through highly effective library skills \nLegal method skills How to approach and handle legal rules \nArgumentation skills How to identify, construct and evaluate arguments \nReading skills How to read legal rules, judges’ opinions, academic critiques of law reports etc. \nWriting skills How to write notes, summaries, essays, legal problem solutions, exams, reports etc. and draft documents \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-101\n \n\n--- Page 33 ---\n \n 2 INTRODUCTION  \nSpeaking (oral) \nskills How to engage in debating, mock trials (mooting), mediation, negotiation, presentation \nPreparing for Assessments How to effectively prepare for and produce written and oral assessments \nSuccessful legal study depends upon the simultaneous development of different, but \ncomplementary, skills. For example, knowing how to study, understand the sources of law, and where to fnd the law; how to analyse and critique the law, how to construct legal arguments and how to successfully engage in written and oral assessments. All of these issues are covered in this book which is divided into four parts. \nPart 1: \nSources of law \nPart 2: Writing the law \nPart 3: Applying your research Part 4: Skills for resolving disputes \nT\nhroughout the book you will note that the primary focus is inevitably text based. It deals \nwith texts of law (statutes, case law, treaties) and texts about law (textbooks, academic \narticles). This distinction between texts of law and texts about  law is important to grasp. \nTexts of law set out the primary legal rules, while texts about law look at law from a \nrange of perspectives, questioning and critiquing or just summarising the state of law. These are called secondary texts because they are basically commentaries about the legal rules in the texts of law. \nAs you gain competency in legal study and legal skills you will increase your critical \nability to analyse law; this will sharpen your thinking, you will learn to ask questions, never taking anything for granted, looking for evidence to support arguments. \nYou may have found the above listing of the parts of the book daunting as it sets out \nthe range of skills that you need to develop. However, it is better to be informed about the complex interconnectedness of your studies from the start. Too often, students are not clearly informed at the beginning of their studies of the full extent of the skills required. They then wonder why they are not progressing, but it may be that while they will be good at the study of law eventually they initially need to develop skills of library usage, research, IT and personal time management. \nBe warned, however: it is easy to forget the range of skills you need to work on, once \nyou become too busy coping with information overload, the facts of cases, the words making up a legal rule, a defnition, the translation of a Latin phrase used in law, etc. You may think you cannot waste time trying to understand as well! Frequently, memorising becomes a comfortable tranquilliser protecting the student from the productive pain of fghting with incomprehension to reach a place of partial understanding. Sadly, within the discipline of law, successful memorising often merely ensures failure as the student knows it all and yet understands nothing. \n\n--- Page 34 ---\n  \n \n INTRODUCTION 3 \nThe acquisition of knowledge without the ability to understand it and apply it is not \nstudying it; it is just mindless rote learning. The easy  part is acquiring knowledge – the \ndiffcult  part of studying is understanding what you know and applying it. You would not \npay to be advised by a lawyer who knew everything but understood nothing. \nThe majority of books on the market that deal with issues of legal skills and legal \nmethod (that is, the way in which legal rules are used to resolve certain types of disputes) \ndo so in the context of legal process or legal theory. Inevitably, many of these books tend to be weighted in favour of explaining the English legal system, its processes, personnel and doctrines. They do not give time to an appreciation of how to engage with standard academic skills, how to break into texts, to read them and to understand them and how to construct arguments. This book recognises that in order to be successful in your legal studies you need to get inside legal rules, and fully appreciate their various dimensions. \nThis text acknowledges the complexities of legal rules, the importance of critique and \nthe construction of legal arguments, and the need to develop excellent general academic skills, including study skills. But it also assists students, in a user-friendly manner, to make interrelationships within and between texts. It presents language clearly, and uses these interrelationships to allow the commencement of the task of understanding and reading the law, of seeing arguments, evaluating arguments and in turn assisting you to construct arguments. \nLaw is dynamic, not passive. Reading is dynamic, not passive, as you will fnd out – it \nhas to be as you need to enter into ‘conversation’ with what you are reading. Studying is also dynamic, not passive. Learning does not happen to you; it is something that you do. \nEssentially, therefore, this is a book about practical matters, practical skills of stud -\nying, IT strategies, practical thinking and the acquisition of a range of practical legal, research, intellectual and presentational skills and, as such, relies on reader refection and activity. But these practical matters are underpinned by \nPart 1, which sets out, in four \nchapters, the sources of law. Its practical nature means that it relies on your willingness to engage actively with the book. But its practicality is consistently aimed at developing critical thinking and allowing you to develop a complex understanding so that you can engage in highly competent analysis. \nT\nhe original author’s objective in writing this book was to provide a usable manual for \nlaw students new to the discipline and this approach has been adopted by the current authors and editors: the text therefore, draws a map of your studies, it sets out the terri -\ntory and also provides smaller maps to enable you to locate and understand legal texts and to reach a place of understanding where you can recall relevant memorised knowl -\nedge concerning general or specifc contexts and apply it, or interpret it confdently with a clear comprehension of the interrelationships between rules, arguments and language, in the search for plausible solutions to real or imaginary problems. \nThis text is not a philosophical enquiry that asks why English law prefers the methods \nof reasoning it has adopted. Although such texts are of the utmost importance, they will mean more to the student who has frst acquired a thorough competency in a narrow feld of practical legal method and practical reason. Then, a philosophical argument will be \n\n--- Page 35 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  4 INTRODUCTION  \nappreciated, considered, evaluated and either accepted or rejected. This is not a theoret -\nical text designed to discuss in detail the importance of a range of legal doctrines such as precedent, although you must also carefully study these. Further, this is not a book that critiques itself or engages in a post-modern reminder that what we know and see is only a chosen, constructed fragment of what may be the truth. Although self-critique is a valid enterprise, a fragmentary understanding of ‘the whole’ is all that can ever be grasped. \nIntellectual understanding brings with it the ability to realise that we can only ever see \npart of the whole collection of stories that is the law. Therefore we should approach the study of law carefully, checking that our arguments and our criticisms are plausible. We need to constantly check that the arguments and criticisms of others are also plausible. Knowledge is essential but it is equally essential to think of the use of our knowledge in terms of it being a torch shining in the dark. There is a strong central beam of light that enables you to see well. But that beam of light fades through shadows to darkness and although we cannot see it we know that there is more ‘out there’. Study is the same: there is always more we cannot see, and never will see. This should protect us from \nFigure 0.1 The function of this ‘how to’ text \n\n--- Page 36 ---\n  \n \n          INTRODUCTION 5 \nmaking assertions about the whole of law, for we cannot see it all. We do not understand \nit all. \nThis is above all a ‘how-to’ text, a practical manual. Judges make choices when attempting to apply the law. The study of \nlaw is about critiquing the choices not made as well as the choices made. \nThe text as a whole will introduce you to the value of alternatives to purely textual \nexplanations. An ability to comprehend diagrammatic explanations will be encouraged. The diagrams used are integral to the successful understanding of legal skills, legal method, legal reasoning and general academic skills as presented in this text. \nThey have been specifcally designed to: \n  provide a way of taking students to deeper levels of understanding; \n  give a basic description or blueprint for an area; \n  demonstrate interconnections between seemingly disconnected areas/texts/skills. \nDiagrams present another way of seeing, and the sheer novelty value of seeing the inter -\nconnections in a diagram can sometimes be enough to change confusion into compre -\nhension. It is hoped that students will begin to construct diagrams for themselves. \n\n--- Page 38 ---\n PART 1 \nSOURCES OF LAW \nA clear understanding of the different types of legal rule is a basic prerequisite for the \ncompetent exercise of legal skills and reasoning. The four chapters in Part 1 are designed \nt\no map the territory of law. They identify its sources, describe its creation, format and the \nlimits of its jurisdiction. \nCh\napter 1 ‘Domestic legislation’ defnes and explains what legislation is, how it is \ncreated by Parliament and the formats used to set it out. The chapter also distinguishes between primary legislation (created by Parliament) and secondary legislation (created by offce holders and groups on the delegated authority of Parliament). Time is also taken to explain the range of interchangeable words/phrases used when referring to legislation which can be confusing. \nChapter 2 ‘Domestic case law’ gives you a basic appreciation of what common law \nor case law is, and the way in which it is created, developed, discussed and changed by the senior judges in the English courts. It describes the hierarchical structure of English courts and tribunals as well as their jurisdiction, staffng and development of the key doc -\ntrine of precedent by the senior judiciary. Precedent is discussed in detail in Chapter 8 . \nThe importance of three courts outside the hierarchy of the courts is also considered: the Privy Council, the Court of Justice of the European Union and the European Court of Human Rights. \nChapter 3 ‘International and European Law’ is designed to introduce the basic con -\ncept of treaties (formal agreements between nations) and discusses how they are cre -\nated, amended or terminated. It also considers the legal impact of treaties that have been entered into by the government, drawing distinctions between international law and English law. Time is taken to ensure the vocabulary used in treaties and about treaties is understood. The chapter also considers European Law, a source of law originating out -\nside the English legal system in the founding treaties of the European Union (EU). These no longer have legal effect inside the English legal system due to the UK’s withdrawal from the EU. But as the UK and countries within the EU continue to be trade partners, this law remains relevant. EU law includes the treaties, legislation and the case law of the European Union and each area is discussed in this chapter. \nChapter 4 ‘Human rights’ looks at the European Convention on Human Rights, explain -\ning its relationship to domestic human rights law. Human rights law is an increasingly important area of law globally. It is a key issue in political debate and has given rise to \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-1  \n\n--- Page 39 ---\n      SOURCES OF LAW 88 SOURCES OF LAW \nmany controversies in the UK concerning judicial interpretations of both the European \nConvention on Human Rights (ECHR) 1951 created by the Council of Europe and the English Human Rights Act 1998 (HRA). Students of English law are often quite justly confused about the relationship between the ECHR and the HRA. The chapter explains in detail how the English legal system’s human rights law originates outside the English legal system in European treaties. It also explains how parts of the ECHR have been given limited legal effect in the English legal system by the HRA. English legislation is referred to as ‘domestic’ to differentiate it from European Union (EU) legislation enacted by the institutions of the EU. Up until the UK’s withdrawal from the European Union, EU legislation was a major source of English law, but this is discussed in Chapter 3 . \nPrimary and secondary domestic legislation are described and the standard method \nof creating them is set out. The standard layout of domestic legislation is also dealt with. A brief explanation of statutory interpretation by the judiciary is given; however, detailed discussion of this area is reserved for Chapter 7 , which concentrates on the skills of read -\ning, analysing and interpreting legislation. \nWHAT IS DOMESTIC LEGISLATION? \nDomestic legislation is the dominant form of law making in the English legal system and it is created by the authority of Parliament. It exists in two main forms, primary and sec -\nondary legislation. Primary legislation (statutes) applies to the whole of the English legal system and is created by Parliament directly. It can deal with any subject matter that Parliament wishes. \nSecondary legislation (delegated legislation) is created by others acting on powers \ndelegated to them in primary legislation, which in these circumstances can be described as ‘enabling’ or ‘parent’ legislation. For example, an individual minister of state may be given powers to make changes to certain primary legislation. Or a professional body may be allowed to make legal rules affecting its members. A local council\n1 can enact legal \nrules applicable only to the geographic area of the council. Secondary legislation is often described as an indirect form of law making and can be additionally referred to as del -\negated or subordinate legislation. It can be repealed or changed by primary legislation. \nTwining and Miers describe legislation as encompassing a wide variety of rules in \n‘fxed verbal form’.\n2 \nLegislation is enacted in various timescales. Sometimes legislation is quickly created \nas a reaction by Parliament to a crisis or public outcry or a one-off situation, for exam -\nple, in response to an act of terrorism (an often-cited example is the Dangerous Dogs Act 1991).\n3 Sometimes it is a reasonably well-considered response to a particular issue \nsuch as consumer protection. On other occasions it is the end product of several years of public, political and expert consultation. The Equality Act 2010\n4 (EA) is an example of \nlegislation that was the outcome of several years of consultation. \nLegislation can be enacted to create new codifed legal rules on any matter. It can also be \nenacted to consolidate existing law in a particular area, such as theft. In that case, it brings \n1 T echnically referred to as a local authority (LA). \n2 W Twining and D Miers, How to Do Things with Rules (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 2010), 193. \n3 c . 65 1991. \n4 c . 15 2010. \n\n--- Page 42 ---\n   \n \n \n \n   DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 11 \ntogether rules made by judges as part of the common law,5 customary legal rules6 and/or \nexisting legislation into one statute; it does not change the existing law but clarifes it. \nNot all codifying legislation gets it right. A good example is the Theft Act 1968. It codi -\nfed the common law and prior legislation in existence in the area of theft. However, a \nmajor problem with the old law was the defnition of deception. The Theft Act 1968 failed to deal with this adequately and eventually the Theft Act 1978 was enacted to resolve the problem. That too proved inadequate in a range of areas and it was followed nearly 20 years later by the Theft (Amendment Act) 1996. Continuing issues around fraud and deception fnally led to the Fraud Act 2006.\n7 \nAlthough legislation responds to particular issues, the fner details of the situations to \nwhich the rules will have to be applied will vary enormously. Primary legislation is there -\nfore drafted in a general way, in order to be applicable to the widest possible range of situations. This often presents a major challenge to those drafting the legislation and to those who are subsequently called upon to interpret it. \nNaming conventions for legislation \nAn Act of Parliament or statute starts life as a ‘bill’ usually drafted by parliamentary coun -\nsel who are lawyers skilled at drafting proposed laws. A bill can change dramatically as it goes through the processes of enactment, which means that if the bill becomes a statute it should not be consulted for the purposes of interpreting the law. However, it can be an interesting historical record of what was left in and what was taken out of the legislation during the processes leading to enactment. \nThere are several phrases used to refer to primary and secondary legislation, and \nthese are set out in Figures  1.1 and 1.2. \nSecondary legislation, like primary legislation, is covered by a range of synonyms, and \ncan also be of several different types. Figure 1 .2 sets out the main synonyms and types \nof secondary legislation. \nThe statute book \nWhen considering legislation in other texts you will no doubt hear the phrase ‘the stat -\nute book’. This is a reference to all the enacted legislation in the English legal system arranged chronologically. Each statute in any year is a chapter in the statute book. The Wild Animals in Circuses Act 2019 has the full citation The Wild Animals in Circuses Act 2019 c.24, with the lowercase ‘c’ being an abbreviation for ‘chapter’. From this we know it is the 24th statute enacted in 2019; it is Chapter 24 of the statute book for 2019. \nFinding legislation \nLegislation can be found in many places: in handwritten collections,8 print collections \nand online collections held by libraries or institutions such as Parliament or the Courts. \n5 E xplained in Chapter 2 . \n6 Ibid. \n7 c . 35 2006. \n8 T here are surviving parchment rolls of handwritten legislation dating from about 1299. \n\n--- Page 43 ---\n \n    \n   \n \n    \n \n \n \n  12 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \n1. SYNONYMS USED FOR GENERAL REFERENCE TO PRIMARY LEGISLATION: \nA synonym is another word  or phrase meaning the same thing \n• An Act of Parliament \n• An Act • A legislative act • A statute (which means decree) \nPRIMARY LEGISLATION GIVING DELEGATED POWERS TO  \nLEGISLATE CAN BE REFERRED TO AS \nThe parent Act or the enabling Act \n2. DIFFERENT TYPES OF PRIMARY LEGISLATION \nThere are also different types of primary legislation that need to be distinguished from each \nother \n• A Public General Act • A private Act • A private member’s Act • A hybrid Act • Orders in Council \nSINGULAR AND PLURAL FORMS FOR PRIMARY LEGISLATION \nStudents can be confused by plurals in this area; hopefully the following will help: \n• The word ‘legislation’ is understood in the plural sense. • If you want to refer to the singular you need to think in terms of a ‘piece’ of legislation. But the \nappropriate term would be legislative act. \n• More commonly a singular re ference is made to ‘an Act’, or ‘the Act’ or to the statute. The \nplural is denoted by the addition of an ‘s’ to the relevant noun and changing the pronoun \ne.g. ‘The Acts considered together provide’, or ‘these statutes provide’. \nFigure 1.1 Correct reference to primary legislation \nThere is only one online offcial site for UK legislation, which is free and can be located at \nwww.legislation.gov.uk . Other subscription-only online sites exist. Your library should be \nable to give you access to some of these. \nIn some modules, your lecturers might ask you to buy a statute book – a printed col -\nlection containing the latest versions of all relevant statutes for this module. In that case, do invest in the statute book early on and get used to its structure from the beginning. You might be allowed to take it into the exam, which can be a big help. \nThere are a range of publications that provide lawyers, students and researchers \nwith lists of legislation; these are arranged either chronologically or by subject matter. The domestic legislation currently in force has been created by Parliament over the past 700 years, but most of the legislation has been created since 1850. \n\n--- Page 44 ---\n   \n \n \n \n   DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 13 \nSECONDARY LEGISLATION \nSYNONYMS FOR SECONDARY LEGISLATION \nSubordinate legislation OR delegated legislation \nDIFFERENT TYPES OF SECONDARY LEGISLATION \n1. Bylaws \n2. Orders by Council (The Privy Council) \n3. Statutory Instruments \n(1) Local \n(2) Public \n(i) Hybrid statutory instruments \n(ii) Orders: \n(a) Commencement Orders (b) Orders in Council (The Privy Council) \nNB: Orders in Council here expressly excludes the use of the ‘royal prerogative’; \nthis is an instance of an order in council constituting primary legislation. \n(c) Regulatory Reform Orders (d) Remedial Orders (e) Special Procedure Orders \n(iii) Regulations \n(iv) Church Measures (of the Church of England) \n4. Court Rules Committees \nSINGULAR AND PLURAL FORMS FOR SECONDARY  LEGISLATION \nSingular Plural \nBylaw An order in council Statutory instrument Regulation Church measure Bylaws Orders by Council Statutory instruments Regulations Church Measures \nFigure 1.2 Synonyms for secondary legislation and types of secondary legislation \nWHAT IS PARLIAMENT? \nParliament is the main political and legal institution in the English legal system, and \nthe only institution empowered to create primary legislation. It is made up of three ele -\nments. There are two Houses, the elected Members of Parliament (MPs) in the House of Commons (which is often referred to as the ‘commons’ or less often ‘the lower house’) and the non-elected Lords and Ladies (or ‘Peers’) in the House of Lords (which \n\n--- Page 45 ---\n \n \n \n 14 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \nis often just referred to as ‘the Lords’, and less often ‘the upper house’). Both Houses \nof Parliament acting together must agree on the exact wording of legislation. The third element is the monarch, who must give their Royal Assent to all legislation for it to be legitimately enacted. \nThe House of Commons \nThe House of Commons is currently composed of 650 Members of Parliament elected by members of the public who are eligible to vote and contains representatives from the four nations, England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. For this purpose the entire country is divided into constituencies containing one MP. \nSince the Fixed Term Parliament Act 2011, general elections of all members of the \nHouse of Commons usually take place every fve years. In practice, the prime minister has a two-month leeway before or after the expiry of fve years in which to hold the election. The only other way in which an earlier general election could take place would be if there were a successful vote of ‘no-confdence’ in the government passed in the Commons and no alternative government could be formed; or if a two-thirds majority of the House of Commons agreed to an early general election. If an MP resigns or dies, a by-election is held to replace them. \nThe House of Lords \nThe House of Lords is composed of unelected Lords (currently around 800). The majority of these have been appointed (the so-called ‘life peers’), 92 have inherited their title and were elected by the other members of the nobility, and 26 are Bishops of the Church of England. Under the Parliament Act 1949 they have the power to delay legislation for one year but do not have a complete veto. \nRoyal Assent \nThere is also a fnal formal agreement to legislation given by the fgurehead of the state, the monarch. The convention is that the monarch does not refuse consent (the last time this happened was in 1708). \nThe power of government to create legislation \nGiven that the Lords can only delay, and the monarch cannot dissent, the practical centre of power is in the House of Commons. Furthermore, as the government normally con -\ntrols the majority in the Commons, due to it being the party with the most votes in the Commons, it is the government that is the seat of power with only limited checks and balances on the exercise of that power. \n\n--- Page 46 ---\n   \n DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 15 \nTYPES OF DOMESTIC LEGISLATION: PRIMARY AND SECONDARY \nSo far we have noted that Parliament authorises the creation of a range of different types \nof legal rule generally subdivided into primary and secondary legislation, both of which are united by the fact that they are created in a fxed verbal form. The phrase ‘fxed verbal form’ means that only those  words in that order with that punctuation (if any) were agreed \nby Parliament as containing the legal rule.\n9 \nLegislation is classifed as either primary or secondary legislation, bo th of which are \nimportant and they will now be considered in turn. \nTypes of primary legislation \nThere are several types of legislative Act that can become a primary Act of Parliament: \nPublic General Acts \nThese mostly originate through the daily work of government departments and affect the general public. Some may be the result of implementing electoral promises. On occasion they can be created in response to public concern over a controversial problem. Public General Acts comprise the vast majority of primary legislation and will therefore be the main area of focus. \nPrivate Acts \nThese go through the same procedures in Parliament to become law as a Public General Act. But private Acts only contain rules applying to a specifc geographical area, or to a particular institution, or even just one person. They do not apply to all members of the public. Not surprisingly, such Acts are rare. \nHybrid Acts \nThese affect the general public but additionally a smaller locality or group may well be particularly affected by the legislation in ways that may be onerous. The legislation is usu -\nally required to allow work of national beneft and importance to take place. \nOrders in Council by virtue of the royal prerogative \nThis is an order made on the authority of the monarch. By tradition prime ministers use such orders for political appointments. In times of emergency the government can use Orders in Council as a quick response. They can be used to change the decision of courts \n9 A lthough, as you will see in Chapter 7 , judges interpreting words and phrases in court will often deal in the \nsubstitution of words. \n\n--- Page 47 ---\n 16 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \nthat apply to British Overseas Territories without an Act of Parliament. Only a Public \nGeneral Act can be used to reverse a domestic court’s decision. \nPrivate members’ bills \nA private member’s bill is a type of public bill that is not introduced by the government but by an individual member of the House of Lords or the House of Commons. The only condition attaching to this right is that the person concerned must not be a government minister. Such bills follow the normal procedure for the enactment of a statute. One of their values is allowing there to be a debate on an issue. Even a private member’s bill that has not been enacted can have an impact on legislation that later comes from the govern -\nment after serious issues have been aired in debate in the Houses of Parliament during the progress of the private members’ bill. \nTHE PROCEDURES LEADING TO THE ENACTMENT \nOF A PUBLIC GENERAL ACT \nA primary legislative Act, applying generally to all of the public within the state is called \na Public General Act. The bulk of primary legislation is in the form of Public General Acts and therefore the focus is on the Public General Act. Prior to enactment the draft legisla -\ntion is called a bill. \nProcedures for enacting legislation can be broken down into four main areas: \n  Pre-legislative procedures. \n  The passage of the bill through Parliament. \n  Royal Assent. \n  The ‘in force’ date of the Act. \nPre-legislative procedures Public General Bill \nTechnically the processes before a bill is introduced in Parliament are collectively referred to as the pre-legislative procedures. These include getting the views of the public and institutions by informal or formal consultations; and drafting the legislation. \nPublic consultation, Green Papers and White Papers \nIdeas about proposals for future legislation usually go through a consultation period, and on some occasions, a thorough pre-legislative scrutiny by experts in the feld. Modern government relies on consultation prior to bills being drafted to see if it will obtain support from those affected, the so-called ‘stakeholders’. Negative feedback will not necessarily \n\n--- Page 48 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n                                             \n                          \n DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 17 \nstop a government from forwarding proposed legislation, but it will make it think carefully \nabout its proposals before proceeding. \nThe relevant government department or minister of state may publish a completely \nexploratory report asking for general views, which is bound in a green cover and referred to as a Green Paper. Or it may issue a discussion paper with an attached prospective bill to generate more specifc comment. Bound in white, this is called a White Paper. Both are called ‘command’ papers from the header in each, which states: \nPresented to Parliament by the Secretary of State for … by Command of Her Majesty. \nFor example, the coalition government published its White Paper, ‘Water for Life’, on 8 December 2011.\n10 The government department publishing this White Paper was \nEnvironment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA). Each government department has its own select committee and DEFRA’s select committee\n11 voiced their concerns over matters in \nthe proposed legislation. They undertook an inquiry into the White Paper and published their fndings on 5 July 2012. Shortly after this the government published a draft Water Bill. A set period of time is usually given for responses to a consultation. \nThe public is usually given a number of months to reply to a call for views on issues \nin White and Green Papers, and some organisations are explicitly invited to respond to proposals. All such responses are published in Hansard\n12 as government papers. \nThe parliamentary outreach programme also runs free ‘public bill workshops’ to let \nmembers of the public know how to engage with proposals for legislation.13 These include \nonline opportunities to respond. \nDrafting of a Public General bill by parliamentary counsel \nGovernment bills are drafted by lawyers employed as civil servants in the Offce of Parliamentary Counsel (an offce dating back to 1869). \nBefore the Offce of Parliamentary Counsel will accept instructions from a govern -\nment department to draft a bill it must have a European Convention on Human Rights Memorandum,\n14 stating that the proposed legislation is compatible with the Convention. \nThis memo, formally a statement of compatibility, must be printed on the front of the bill. A bill can still be drafted and journey through Parliament in the absence of a memoran -\ndum of compatibility, but there would need to be a most compelling reason given by the government for choosing to go ahead anyway. \nIt is the civil servants in the relevant government department promoting the bill \nthat instructs parliamentary counsel to draft the bill. When full instructions are sent to \n10 Ref: PB13689. \n11 Each government department has an assigned select committee. \n12 Hansard is responsible for ensuring the verbatim notation of all parliamentary debates and proceedings in \ncommit as well as a range of other parliamentary papers. Publication is by the Stationery Offce (TSO). \n13 http://www.w4mp.org/library/your-offce-guides/organising-things-diary-meetings-and-events/parl \niamentary-outreach-free-service-for-the-public/ accessed 2 November 2020. \n14 See Human Rights Act 1998 c. 42, s 19(1)(a) – this is technically referred to as a memorandum of \ncompatibility. \n\n--- Page 49 ---\n \n           \n \n \n 18 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \nparliamentary counsel the relevant government department should also inform them of \nany existing judicial interpretation of legislation that may be relevant to understanding what the current law is. Also, the department should lay out any legal concepts that they are using in instructing the drafting of the bill. Parliamentary counsel also expects the instructions to include alerts when there are any arrangements in the bill proposing to give secondary legislative powers to another person or institution. Counsel will then advise the relevant government department, or a minister, whether what they wish to do is possible from a technical, legal perspective. \nThe bill is divided into small parts called clauses. Linked clauses are usually put \ntogether. These clauses become sections if the bill becomes an Act. \nThe parliamentary legislative timetable \nAt the commencement of each parliamentary session the monarch gives a speech written by ‘her government’ outlining the legislation planned for the current session. Government control of the parliamentary legislative timetable is absolutely key to the success of gov -\nernment bills. \nTwo cabinet committees determine which bills will be presented and when. ‘The legislation committee’ is responsible for the timing of bills in the current Parliament \nand is responsible for drawing up a programme from the Queen’s speech. The ‘future leg -\nislation committee’ determines the bills to go forward in the next session of Parliament. \nThe passage of a public bill through Parliament \nOnce the legislation has been drafted then it has to face a strict series of procedures as it travels through Parliament. Each public bill has three readings, a committee stage and a report stage, in both Houses of Parliament. After the committee stage a report is sent to the relevant House on changes to the bill. A bill can be introduced initially in either House, although most are introduced into the House of Commons. However, the House of Commons can, after waiting for one year, ignore the dissent of the House of Lords using the Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949.\n15 \nPassage of a bill through the House of Commons \nFirst reading \nThis is a mere formality; the only requirement is that the short title16 of the bill is read out \nin the House. Each bill, and subsequently each Act, has a long title set out in its preamble \n(see later in the chapter)17 and a short title which is determined by a section (sections are \nexplained later in this chapter) in the Act and this is the title by which it is known. A time is then set for a second reading. Conventionally this should be after the passing of two weekends. \n15 The delay was initially two years in the 1911 legislation which was reduced to one year in the 1949 legisla -\ntion. Before the 1911 Act, the House of Lords could veto any bill. \n16 See below for details of the short title. Each bill and subsequent Act has a long and a short title. These \nmatters are discussed in detail in Chapter 11 . \n17 A bill is divided into clauses which become sections in the Act. \n\n--- Page 50 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 19 \nSecond reading \nThis is a full debate in the House of the issues raised by the legislation. The relevant min -\nister or spokesperson will introduce the bill. This is immediately followed by the ‘offcial’ \nopposition shadow minister or spokesperson responding.18 After this a general debate \nopens up, and at the end of the debate there is a vote to determine if the bill can continue its passage through the House. The bill must receive a majority of those voting to con -\ntinue on its way. MPs do not have to be in the debating chamber of the House to vote. They can slip into the chamber near the time for a vote. \nVoting procedures \nWhen the time for voting arrives the Speaker of the House of Commons will ask all mem -\nbers present in the Commons chamber to simultaneously call out their agreement or dis -\nsent to the bill.19 This is a noisy event. The Speaker will then gauge from what he or she \nhas heard if the bill has majority support or not. If it is unclear the Speaker will call for a vote by ‘division’. \nIt is called a division because the House physically divides for the purposes of voting. \nAll MPs are asked to show their support or dissent by either walking out of the chamber into one of two areas, called division lobbies. One lobby is the ‘ayes’ (yes) lobby and the other the ‘noes’ lobby.\n20 \nDivision bells ring for eight minutes to allow MPs to arrive from elsewhere in the area of \nParliament. The bells are placed in a range of places within Parliament and its precincts. The sound of the bell for House of Lords divisions is different to that of the Commons. TV screens around Parliament and surrounding parliamentary and government buildings also indicate that a division is taking place.\n21 When the bell stops, the door to the chamber \nis locked. No one can gain access to vote if they have been locked out. \nClerks note the name of the MP as they vote by simply walking through the relevant \ndivision lobby. Those acting as ‘tellers’ of the vote to the Speaker count the MPs through from the chamber into the division lobby and the Speaker announces the result. If there is a tied vote then the Speaker has the casting vote (this is a very rare occurrence). This authority belongs to the Speaker because of a constitutional convention\n22 known as \nSpeaker Denison’s rule.23 Another constitutional convention states that the Speaker must \nmaintain the status quo by voting in favour of the government. \nThe division lobby process can take at least 15–20 minutes and often much longer. \nHowever, it is also possible to have a deferred division that allows MPs to vote at a con -\nvenient time during a limited timescale. The votes in a deferred division remain public to match the lobby/bar procedures for accountability. This can be seen to mirror the frst \n18 The political party not in government in the House of Commons with the largest number of MPs is the \noffcial opposition. They appoint MPs to ‘shadow’ government ministers, the ‘shadow minister’. They will \nrespond to them in debates. \n19 In the House of Lords it is the Lord Speaker who deals with this matter. \n20 In the House of Lords the Lords walk through the ‘bar’ and the lobbies are known as ‘consent’ and ‘not \nconsent’. \n21 Through a feed called the ‘annunciator service’. \n22 An unwritten rule that is important to the UK’s constitution. \n23 Denison was Speaker of the House of Commons from 1857 to 1872. \n\n--- Page 51 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 20 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \nvote after any debate when MPs shout out their views from their seat on the benches. \nThe ‘division list’ is a list of the way in which each Member of Parliament voted and is published the next day in Hansard, and posted on the Parliament website. \nCommittee stage \nA bill that successfully passes the second reading is sent to a public bill committee com -\nposed of 16–50 MPs chosen to maintain the political representation of the parties in the House. So the government will usually have a majority in the committee, with the next high -\nest number of places going to the offcial opposition. It is usually hoped that a bill can go to the committee within a few weeks of the second reading. But the parliamentary timetable is always full and the wait may be longer. Amendments to clauses can be put forward by committee members. However, only the Chair of the committee can decide which amend -\nments are discussed. A list of amendments to the bills in committee is published each day. Votes are taken clause by clause, after detailed scrutiny, and every clause must be either: \n  agreed; \n  agreed as amended; or \n  removed. \nIf the bill is amended then it is reprinted and there is a report stage where it is sent back \nto the House. \nReport stage \nThis takes place in the whole House,24 giving all MPs a chance to debate amendments to \nthe bill in committee. However, unlike the other stages there is no ideal timescale set for the report stage. There may well be attempts to undo changes previously secured at the committee stage. MPs can also forward new proposals for amendments. Debates can continue for several days or even weeks. \nThird reading \nThis usually takes place on the same day as the report stage fnishes, and it is the fnal debate on the contents of the bill. If a clear agreement to the bill is ascertained before a debate there will usually be a motion\n25 calling for the House to proceed to a vote without a \ndebate. If the bill is approved it is tied with a green ribbon and sent to the House of Lords with a request from the House of Commons that it is approved. \nPassage of a bill through the House of Lords \nThe procedure in the House of Lords basically mirrors that in the House of Commons: frst reading, second reading, committee stage, report stage, third reading. \nIt is worth noting, however, that the Speaker of the House of Lords does not have a \ncasting vote in the event of a tied vote of the House. Also, when a vote takes place in the \n24 In rare instances the committee stage can take place as a committee of the whole House. \n25 A motion is the technical term for an MP making a proposal to the House. \n\n--- Page 52 ---\n   \n DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 21 \nchamber, rather than saying ‘ayes’ or ‘noes’, the phrases used are ‘consent’ and ‘not \nconsent’. \nAmendment consideration \nAt the end of the third reading in the House of Lords the bill comes to rest, and it is returned to the originating House of Commons, so that they can consider amendments made by the House of Lords. \nBefore a bill can become an enacted statute, all  wording in it must be agreed upon \nby both Houses of Parliament. You can see now why it is most appropriate to state that legislation is law enacted in a ‘fxed verbal form’. If the House of Commons disagrees with the amendments from the House of Lords and/or makes further amendments of its own, the bill has to go back to the Lords. A bill can be sent back to the Commons again after the Lords have considered the new amendments and agreed or disagreed. \nThis ‘to and fro’ process is referred to as ‘ping pong’ after the game of table tennis. \nIf the House of Lords delay the bill due to disagreements, then the Parliament Acts can be used as noted above to allow the fnal consent to come from the House of Commons only. The House of Lords has delayed and refused consent on several notable statutes in recent years, including the Sexual Offences Amendment Act 2000 and the Hunting Act 2005. \nIt used to be the case that if a bill had not successfully completed all its stages through \nthe two Houses by the end of the parliamentary session it was ‘lost’. Those opposing it would deliberately try to delay it as long as possible in its passage through debates and committees so that the end of the parliamentary session was reached and the bill was lost. However, in 1998 the House of Commons Modernisation Committee proposed that it should be possible to carry over bills that have not completed their passage from one session to the next and since 2004 this has been a Standing Order of the House of Commons. \nRoyal Assent \nEven if the bill receives agreement from the House of Lords and the House of Commons it cannot become law until the monarch has assented to it. There is no legal rule that states the monarch must assent but by convention the monarch does always assent. The last time the monarch refused to assent to an Act was in 1708. The Royal Assent Act 1967 provides for formal assent by notifcation and there just needs to be a formal read -\ning in both Houses of the short title of the Act signifying assent. Once the Royal Assent process has been completed the Act is ordered to be printed by The Stationery Offce.\n26 \nDate in force of the Act \nUnless the statute states anything to the contrary, an Act becomes law on the day it receives Royal Assent, and for the avoidance of doubt the whole of that day is included. \n26 TSO are the offcially sanctioned publishers for all UK legislation, command papers, House of Commons \nor Lords papers, select committee reports and of Hansard. \n\n--- Page 53 ---\n \n   \n 22 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \nIt may be the case that the whole of a statute has a delayed ‘in force’ date (for example, \nthe Equal Pay Act 1970 did not come into force until 1975). \nMore usually it is individual sections of an Act that have delayed and different dates for \ncoming into legal force. The statute itself may just contain a general permissive section \nstating that various parts of the legislation come into force, if they come into force at all, on a day to be set by the relevant authorised minister by order.\n27 \nThe date in force is an important aspect of legal method and you should carefully check \nin Halsbury or the offcial online site for legislation ( www.legislation.gov.uk ) to ascertain \nthe current position of individual sections of any statute that you are researching. \nSECONDARY LEGISLATION \nIn addition to creating primary legislation, Parliament can, by Act of Parliament, delegate the power to create legislation to others such as a minister of the Crown and various professional, regulatory or statutory bodies. Such power is limited to the creation of bind -\ning laws relevant to that body. For example, local authorities have the power to enact secondary legislation, called bylaws, relating to certain matters within their geographical jurisdiction. Ministers enact secondary legislation in the form of statutory instruments when the right to make certain changes to primary legislation has been given to them in the primary legislation itself. \nSecondary legislation can also occur as private and local, but this is rarer and we will \nnot be looking at these matters in detail. \nFigure 1 .3 below gives you a basic idea of the detail of the different types of secondary \nlegislation. It is divided into a range of types but it is statutory instruments that form the bulk of what we generically refer to as delegated or subordinate legislation. \nParliamentary control over secondary legislation \nSecondary legislation does not need to go through the full parliamentary procedure used for primary legislation. This makes it quick to create and saves precious parliamentary time. It also provides fexibility in law making, and often allows those most involved with an area to create the rules. For example, professional bodies are better placed to enact rules regulating their own professions, and local authorities have a better understanding of local issues. \nThis process does raise questions about the adequacy of parliamentary scrutiny of \nsecondary legislation. This is particularly important in relation to powers given to govern -\nment ministers to amend and repeal primary legislation under the Regulatory Reform Order mechanism. \nWhile much secondary legislation is delegated under the authority of primary legisla -\ntion there is an exception in relation to Orders by Council. Additionally the House of Commons has its own Select Committee on Statutory Instruments. Secondary legislation relating to local authority bylaws goes to a separate committee. \nStatutory instruments, the largest group of secondary legislation are drafted by the \nlegal offcers in the relevant government department after consultation with interested parties. \nThey have different terminology to that used in primary legislation and instead of being \nenacted they are ‘made’. They can, however, be ‘laid’ before Parliament as a draft for approval or ‘made’ for a motion for annulment or rejection within a set timescale. If there is no motion at the expiry of the set time they are then ‘in force’. These terms are set out below in Figure 1 .4. \nProcedure for making statutory instruments \nAs the majority of secondary legislation is made under a delegated power to make a statutory instrument (SI) we will concentrate on this to give you a good foundation for understanding the procedure. \nMost SIs are subject to a parliamentary procedure, either the affrmative resolution or \nthe negative resolution referred to below, and follow the procedures for both as set out in the Statutory Instruments Act 1946, ss 4 and 5. The enabling (or parent) Act will prescribe the procedure that is to be used in relation to specifc statutory instruments. \nAll SIs that have to go through the parliamentary procedure must contain explanatory \nnotes setting out their scope. The procedures are relatively simple, as set out below. \n\n--- Page 56 ---\n   DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 25 \nIt is worth noting that the Parliament Acts of 1911 and 1949, which allow primary leg -\nislation to become law without the agreement of the House of Lords, do not apply to sec -\nondary legislation. If the House of Lords object, then the SI cannot proceed. A few SIs are \nlimited by the parent legislation to obtaining only the approval of the House of Commons. \nThe negative resolution procedure \nThe SI is laid before Parliament in draft format and left for 40 days to see if there is any objection (which is in fact quite rare). If there is an objection, then the SI is lost. \nAlternatively, the SI is laid as made and there is a 40-day period to see if there is a \nmotion called a ‘prayer to annul’ during those 40 days. If not, it becomes legally binding. \nThe affrmative resolution procedure \nBoth Houses of Parliament must approve the SI. The SI can initially be laid as a draft order, then later printed and placed into the numerical run of SIs. It cannot be ‘made’ unless both Houses approve it. Or it can be laid after making, but it cannot come into force until it is approved. Another option is that it can be laid after making but cannot remain in force unless it has approval from the House of Commons and Lords within a statutory period of days (which is usually somewhere between 28 and 40 days). \nThe super-affrmative procedure \nThe powers delegated to ministers by the parent Act may require proposals for SIs to be subject to the super-affrmative procedure, which requires them to lay before Parliament for a set period of days. They are then drafted with notes taken of any comments made. Other delegated legislation can also require this procedure. \nDebates to affrm or annul SIs \nIt is diffcult to fnd parliamentary time to debate these matters. Usually motions are heard late in the parliamentary day on the foor of the House or in one of the committees dealing with delegated legislation. \nOther parliamentary procedures \nThere is provision for some SIs to be laid for a set period but they do not require any scrutiny, and some SIs do not have to be laid at all. \nLists of statutory instruments laid before Parliament \nLists of statutory instruments laid, approved and going through parliamentary proce -\ndures are published regularly by the parliamentary publications offce so that members of \n\n--- Page 57 ---\n \n  \n \n   26 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \nUK DOMESTIC LEGISLATION \nPrimary \nLegisla\u0006on \nHybrid \nActs Private \nActs \nApplying to \nIndividuals \nIncluding personal \nActs to \nchange name Applying \nto groups Public \nGeneral \nAct Orders in \nCouncil \n(using the \nroyal \npreroga\u0003ve) Secondary \nLegisla\u0006on \nBylaws \nfor Local \nAuthori\u0003es Church \nMeasures \nRegula\u0003ons Statutory \nInstruments \n(Including \nOrders in \nCouncil) \nHybrid SIs \nFigure 1.5 Types of UK domestic legislation \nthe two Houses know where a SI is in its cycle of days. Figure 1 .5 ‘Types of UK domestic \nlegislation’ sets out primary and secondary forms for your quick reference. Note that \nOrders in Council can manifest themselves as primary legislation (in relation to the royal prerogative), but in all other areas Orders in Council are secondary legislation in the form of statutory instruments. \nUSING LEGISLATION AND UNDERSTANDING \nJUDICIAL STATUTORY INTERPRETATION \nIt is particularly important to note that legislative language can be complex in its format \nand has the following characteristics: \n  unusual grammatical forms; \n  complex structure; \n  tediously literal, dense text; \n  scant punctuation; \n  peppered with hierarchical alphabetical and numerical dividers. \nLegislation as enacted will have inbuilt defnitions of new terms, as well as a change in \ndefnitions of old terms for the purposes of a new area. It will contain defences (if appli -\ncable), and guidance with regard to the interpretation of certain specifed terms or proce -\ndures. Inevitably the judiciary are required to interpret the meaning of words or phrases in a statute. This is known as statutory interpretation or judicial interpretation. \nThe complexity of legal language has repercussions when the language of legislation \nis the object of interpretation. But it is not just complex language: ordinary words can \n\n--- Page 58 ---\n   \n \n \n   \n DOMESTIC LEGISLATION 27 \ncause interpretational headaches. In Mandla v Dowell-Lee28 a claim of indirect discrimi-\nnation rested on the interpretation of the word ‘can’. The query was whether the word \n‘can’ meant ‘can physically’ or ‘can religiously – therefore can in the sphere of thought and belief’. \nThe Act under consideration may have gone through extensive debate concerning the \nwording of sections, both on the foor of the two Houses of Parliament and in committees. It is important that the judiciary in the most senior courts engage in statutory interpreta -\ntion to decide the fnal meaning of a word of a phrase in a statute. However, judges have actually changed the presumed intention of Parliament by their interpretation of legisla -\ntion. This creates important and interesting debates about the power of the judiciary. The Act would not have been passed if the elected representatives did not support it. But the judiciary are not elected by the public in a democratic manner. \nCONCLUSION \nIt is essential to know and understand the processes for the creation of primary and sec -\nondary legislation and the structure of Parliament, the ultimate creators of legislation. But this information is only the background to being able to fnd and understand primary and secondary legislation so that you can competently construct legal arguments or critique aspects of them. Chapter 6 considers in detail how to fnd legislation in both its enacted and draft forms. Chapter 7 looks at issues of understanding it. Chapter 7 also includes a deeper consideration of statutory interpretation by the judiciary and an explanation of the relationship between cases and legislation. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  Legislation is enacted by the UK Parliament. \n  Legislation can be primary or secondary. \n  Primary legislation is enacted by Parliament. \n  Secondary legislation is enacted by others using powers given by primary legislation. \n  Legislation is law in a fxed verbal form. \n  Domestic legislation is the dominant form of law making in the English legal system. Parliament is split into two main ‘Houses’ or ‘chambers’. \n  The House of Commons is composed of 650 elected Members of Parliament. \n  The House of Lords is not elected, but mostly appointed. \n  There is only one online offcial site for UK legislation which can be located at www.legislation.gov.uk . \n  MPs and Lords have means by which they can present a private member’s bill. \n28 [1983] 1 All ER 1062. \n\n--- Page 59 ---\n 28 DOMESTIC LEGISLATION  \n  Drafting of a government bill is by parliamentary counsel in the Offce of Parliamentary \nCounsel. \n  The passage of a public bill through Parliament is the same in both Houses as fol -\nlows: frst reading, second reading, committee stage, report stage, third reading. \n  Drafting of statutory instruments varies. Generally, however, it is the civil servants in the government department covering the area of the parent Act who draft SIs. \n\n--- Page 60 ---\n2 \n  \n DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Appreciate the development of common law and equity. \n  Understand the relationship between common law and equity. \n  Have a frm grasp of the hierarchy of courts. \n  Begin to understand the role and importance of the doctrine of precedent. \n  Have an understanding of the basic jurisdiction of domestic courts. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-3  \n\n--- Page 61 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 30 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nINTRODUCTION \nCase law is the law created by the senior judges deciding disputes in the law courts. The \nlaw that is created in this way is called the ‘common law’, a phrase used here in its nar -\nrower sense of judge-made law rather than in its wider sense of all of the law (legislative and judge-made) common to the English legal system. \nDuring your legal education, you will be required to read many cases. They are often \nthe legal authority pointed to for the presentation of legal arguments. It is important that you understand the law produced by these cases. Today, legislation is the main form of law making, but the judiciary has a major role to play in relation to statutory interpretation. \nThis chapter briefy describes the development of common law and equity, outlines \nthe role of custom, and considers the structure, jurisdiction and judicial personnel of the courts. It also introduces the tribunal system, often a source of misunderstanding for students, and explains how in some circumstances it can interlink with the court system. \nKey to the understanding of case law is the ability to appreciate the doctrine of \nprecedent, which is briefy explained in this chapter, but an in-depth consideration of it is reserved for Chapter 8 , ‘Reading and understanding cases’. Equally important is to \nensure you can competently locate the most up to date cases expressing legal principles or statutory defnitions. Chapter 6 , ‘Finding material’, deals with these issues. \nThe development of the common law \nEnglish law is described as being a common law system the creation and development of which was a by-product of the Norman invasion in 1066, as the conquerors required a law that would apply to everyone, ‘royal law’. There is, however, much that is unknown about the development of the common law. Historical sources are vague about its development, the level of infuence exerted by Roman law\n1 and the precise nature of the range of local \nlegal rules and differing legal systems operating in England prior to the Norman conquest. Much of the development of the common law and the institutions supporting it between the eleventh and thirteenth centuries remains uncertain. \nBefore 1066 there was evidence of separate systems of law operating in different \nareas of England controlled by different tribes (e.g. Danelaw, Wessex law, Mercian law). It is known that Roman law was infuential in Europe generally between the frst and fourth centuries, and that it was through Roman law that Christianity frst exerted an infuence on the English legal system. Despite this, Roman law was not popular in England (although some of our concepts in commercial law can be traced back to Roman law origins). \nWhat is clear is that as the Norman conquerors sought over successive centuries \nto centralise their power in the fragmented political and legal landscape of England, they centralised the law. The Normans developed a fexible system of political control covering the whole of England and Wales, giving power to the aristocracy in return for their loyalty to the monarch. The Normans were content to combine the legal rules and legal systems of local communities with a mix of their own rules. In this way no one \n1 In England, Roman law was only used in the church courts of the Roman Catholic Church, still at that time \nunder the political and religious power of Rome. The courts of the monarch never used Roman law. \n\n--- Page 62 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n DOMESTIC CASE LAW 31 \ncommunity felt that the new legal rules were completely alien. However, because these \nrules were nationalised, ultimately all legal disputes were heard by the Norman mon -\narchs. So whilst differing localised rules and laws operated in selected areas, it was the monarch who offered the ‘common law’, the new royal justice for all. The development of the common law usurped the authority of the local landowners and tribal leaders to resolve disputes. \nIt could be said that fexibility was the supreme act of political diplomacy of the \nNormans. Initially, they maintained that it was not necessary for the English common law to claim exclusive  jurisdiction. This allowed space for the range of localised legal \nsystems to shape English common law. As long as political loyalty locally was intact then local laws were tolerated as part of the nationalised system, with common law, the royal justice, offering dispute resolution in the courts. Over time, however, the Crown claimed exclusive jurisdiction for the common law over all other forms of law. \nOne of the frst needs of the Normans was to have a judiciary capable of effectively \nand effciently dispensing and developing their unifed laws. They were initially restricted by their language ability and local hostility. The judiciary needed to be highly literate, but the obvious choice, the aristocracy, was hostile towards them. In their need they turned to the literate, ordained clerics of the Roman Catholic Church and trained them to be judges in the royal courts. Inevitably Christian infuence and ethics became instilled in the developing common law. \nThese newly appointed ‘judge-clerics’ travelled the country on the monarch’s author -\nity, hearing major criminal disputes, reading evidence, hearing witnesses and deliver -\ning judgment. These journeys and records formed a travelling, localised justice that was centralised administratively. It was this innovation that was to develop ultimately into the unifed ‘common law’ legal system nationalised in terms of administration, jurisdiction, adjudication and law creation. This construction of a law that was common to all came to be referred to as the common law of England – a common law built up from judges’ deci -\nsions as well as the commands of the sovereign. \nIn the early centuries after the Norman invasion, a number of methods of dispute reso -\nlution existed locally alongside the royal, court-based common law. Most of these meth -\nods, such as the blood feud,\n2 trial by battle3 and trial by ordeal4 had their origins in dispute \nresolution within tribal settings. Defendants at criminal law, and litigants at civil law, could initially choose between royal justice and other methods to resolve their legal dispute. \nThe drawback associated with royal justice was its cost, and the fact that if a person \nwere found guilty of breaking the King’s peace – that is, acting against the Crown – his lands and monies would be forfeited to the Crown, leaving his family destitute. Many people elected to die under torture so that local justice would take effect and land and possessions would pass to the family, not the Crown. However, in time litigants began to accept using royal justice for dispute resolution. \n2 W hen the family of a victim sought to exact revenge by killing members of the aggressor’s family. \n3 W hen two sides to a dispute resolved it by engaging each other in battle, or by sponsoring a champion to \nfght on their behalf. \n4 T rial by ordeal was a pagan ritual but was taken over by politics and Christianity. The accused person was \nsubjected to an ordeal. There were several recognised ordeals such as the ‘ordeal of water’, the ‘hot water \nordeal’, the ‘ordeal of the cursed morsel’ and the ‘fre ordeals’. The support of the Church to trial by ordeal was forbidden in 1215. \n\n--- Page 63 ---\n   \n 32 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nAs law professionalised during the eleventh and twelfth centuries, the teaching of \nEnglish law took place via apprenticeships. Judges needed clerks, and litigants needed \nthose who understood the law to advise them of the procedures and arguments that the law required. \nLegal education took place in specialist Inns of Court, the only places which taught \nthe common law necessary for the education of the legal professionals who worked in the royal courts. They were known as ‘inns’ of court because living and working space for lawyers and their students was merged into one area. The development of the role of barrister was made possible through the creation of the Inns of Court, the earliest of which were attached to churches because of the close connection between the clerics and the judges. \nThe universities of Oxford and Cambridge limited the legal instruction they offered to \nRoman law, ignoring the development of the common law. Roman law was considered to be more academically demanding with its links to the idea of a classical education. It was not until the seventeenth century that the frst law schools at Oxford and Cambridge began to turn their attention to the common law. \nAs the common law system evolved and judicial reasoning became more expansive, \nmany justifcations for law were grounded in Christian morality and illustrated with refer -\nence to the Christian sacred text, the Holy Bible. When Henry VIII instigated the split from the Roman Catholic Church in the sixteenth century he changed the nature of the rela -\ntionship between the Christian religion and the state by retaining Christianity in its Roman Catholic form but removing it from the authority of Rome, and replacing that authority with his own. So he Anglicised it, and assumed the role of the Defender of the Faith – the head and protector of the religion. Another consequence of the split was that the church courts (those which dealt with matters relating to religion) which had formerly been under the authority of Rome, became courts Christian, or the ecclesiastical courts, functioning as part of the English legal system. These courts are still operating today but with a more limited jurisdiction. \nReligion was used for many centuries as the litmus test of loyalty to the Crown, and \nreligious oaths were required before people were allowed to engage in many senior public jobs. Increasingly in the common law courts, judges maintained that Christian law and ethics were an integral part of the law of England, a view that continued to be held until the twentieth century. \nThe characteristics of common law became its communality, its inclusivity and its \npreference for providing supplementary legal rules rather than fxed absolutes. The com -\nmon law remained fexible, making it capable of intricate adaptations to situations. These adaptations eventually produced the judge-made common law we work with today, along with the methods of argument preferred by the English legal system, methods that allow permutations and interpretations of those existing rules. \nEventually after several centuries the common law as a whole developed serious prob -\nlems. Its valued inherent fexibility was lost and it became a rigid system of legal rules. Much of the problem lay in the procedure for bringing a case to the royal courts. A litigant \n\n--- Page 64 ---\n    \n \n \n \n DOMESTIC CASE LAW 33 \nhad to buy a special form, called a writ, from the Chancellor’s offce. But it was not an \nopen general form where a grievance could be stated. It was highly specifc and a pro -\nspective litigant had to fnd the right one from hundreds of writs to cover the details of their case. Otherwise they risked their case being thrown out. \nThe writ system meant that bringing a legal case in the royal courts was extremely \nexpensive. Court cases were also subject to heavy delays that could run into years. Another potential problem for a claimant was that they could only ask for fnancial com -\npensation (monetary damages) even though money alone may not have constituted ade -\nquate recompense. A claimant may have needed certain possessions to be restored or returned, or for someone to stop doing something (or do something they were required to do). Common law therefore became unable to meet the demands of claimants. \nDEVELOPMENT OF EQUITY \nRules that came to be known as ‘equitable rules’ began to develop as individual claim -\nants petitioned the Crown for relief from the defciencies of the common law. Although the monarch originally heard these cases in person, they were eventually delegated to the Lord Chancellor. The Lord Chancellor was a senior cleric in the politically and legally established Christian denomination, the Church of England. Because of his senior offce and his role in the Church the Lord Chancellor was known as ‘the keeper of the King’s conscience’. \nThe word equity is derived from the idea of fairness. The Chancellor was able to \nconsider matters from the perspective of fairness, rather than conform to the rigidity of the common law. He would ask questions such as ‘what would constitute a reason -\nable outcome?’, or ‘what is natural justice in the situation?’ From the decisions of the Chancellor, equitable rules were developed to assist decision making. As petitions to the Lord Chancellor grew in the ffteenth century, the Court of Chancery was established to hear cases. \nRivalries developed between the Lord Chancellors’ Court of Chancery and the com -\nmon law courts. This rivalry came to a head in 1614 in several cases. In the case of Courtney v Glanvil\n5 the head of the common law courts, the Lord Chief Justice, declared \nthat the chancery courts, which he called a court of equity, could not interfere with any decision of the common law courts. The response from the Lord Chancellor was to declare in the Earl of Oxford’s case\n6 that, on the contrary, the Court of Chancery had the \nrequired jurisdiction to set aside any decision of the common law courts. Ultimately, after a period of acrimony, the supremacy of equity over common law was established after the matter was referred to King James I and his Attorney General, Sir Francis Bacon. \nThe equitable rules that guided decision making in the chancery courts dealing with \nequity and remedies were broader than just the monetary damages of the common law. In equity defendants could be ordered to ‘stop doing’ something or ‘to do’ something \n5 (1614) Cro Jac 343, 79 ER 294. \n6 (1615) Rep Ch. \n\n--- Page 65 ---\n   \n \n \n 34 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nand/or return possessions belonging to the claimant. But to obtain full compensation, \noften a litigant was put in the position of having to pay to bring a case in the court of equity for non-monetary remedies after having paid to go to a common law court to obtain monetary recompense. \nThis state of affairs continued well into the nineteenth century when the Supreme \nCourt of Judicature Acts of 1873 and 1875 declared that courts could dispense both common law and equitable rules using only one procedure. These Acts also gave statu -\ntory authority to the rule that should there be confict between a common law rule or an equitable rule then equity would prevail (a rule that is now found in the Senior Courts Act 1981, s 49). \nYou will come across equitable doctrines (or maxims), remedies and rights throughout \nyour study of law as they remain an important source of law. It is therefore important that you understand their origins and effect. Table 2 .1 above sets out an illustrative list of avail -\nable equitable maxims, remedies and rights.\n7 \nCUSTOM \nAs the common law developed it incorporated many local, unwritten, customary rules. A customary law or rule is a practice that communities agree is the only right way to act in that matter, because it is the ‘customary way’. Customs can change from generation to generation and between geographic areas. But these customs came to determine how a legal dispute would be dealt with and by whom. Smith and Keenan defne local custom in the following way: ‘local customs consist in the main of customary rights vested in the inhabitants of a particular place to use, for various purposes, land held in the private ownership of another’.\n8 \nOver time these oral customary rules held in the memory of communities were reduced \nto writing and became part of the common law. Slapper and Kelly note, ‘From this point of view, law may be seen as the redefnition of custom for the purposes of clarity and enforcement by legal institutions’.\n9 However, some schools of thought maintain that com -\nmon law legal rules and custom represent two completely different species of rules and that law often replaced custom rather than incorporating custom into itself. \nToday, if a person wishes to maintain that a local customary rule that conficts with a \ncommon law rule should be enforced they need to prove that the custom is reasonable, can be clearly set out and has existed peacefully without any interruptions from ‘time immemorial’ (agreed to be 1189). The normal situation now is that it is suffcient to show the custom has existed within ‘living memory’ rather than ‘time immemorial’. Furthermore, they must prove that there has been no clandestine aspect to the custom, and that it had been enjoyed without the use of force, or permission or underhandedness. Those who are raising the custom must demonstrate that they consider themselves to be bound by it and that the custom does not confict with other local customs. \n7 F or further reading on equity see G Slapper and D Kelly The English Legal System (19th edition, Routledge, \nLondon), 5–7. \n8 C Wild and S Weinstein Smith and Keenan’s English Law (17th edition, Longman, London, 2013), 6–9. \n9 S ee fn 7, 178. \n\n--- Page 66 ---\n    \n   \n \n \n \n  DOMESTIC CASE LAW 35 \nTABLE 2.1 AN ILLUSTRATIVE LIST OF EQUITABLE MAXIMS, REMEDIES \nAND RIGHTS \nEquitable maxims Equitable remedies Equitable rights \n‘He who comes to Specifc performance The equity of \nequity must come with A party to a contract is ordered to redemption \nclean hands’ perform their contractual obligations.
