Customs are, how -\never, proved in court and are a source of case law. The criteria by which customs can be \nproved are also broad enough to allow the judiciary to refuse the validity of a local custom should they so wish. But if the judiciary consider the custom to be established and that it fts the above criteria then it will take priority over a conficting common law rule.\n10 \n10 Egerton v Harding  [1974] 3 WLR 437, LA 150 is an example of a customary rule being proved in court in \nrelatively modern times. \n\n--- Page 67 ---\n   \n \n 36 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nENGLISH LAW AND THE DOCTRINE OF PRECEDENT \nThe decisions of judges in those courts considered to be senior courts must generally be \nfollowed by judges in the same or lower court: if the facts of the legal dispute are similar and the same legal rule is involved. This practice is known as the doctrine of precedent. The doctrine of precedent is reliant upon the existence of a court hierarchy and a good system of law reporting (or courts keeping a reliable, accessible transcript of the judg -\nment). Otherwise no one will know what was said in an earlier case.\n11 \nIt is often said by judges in their judgments that the doctrine of precedent has been \nobserved for centuries. But, like the history of the common law itself, the truth of such statements is unclear. There is evidence of such practice in some cases recorded over the centuries. \nOnly two things can be stated with some certainty. First, that the judiciary has main -\ntained a relatively strict adherence to the doctrine of precedent from the nineteenth cen -\ntury onwards and this coincided with a regularisation of law reporting. Second, whilst all legal systems have some concept of precedent, the English legal system is exceptional because of its strict adherence to the doctrine of precedent.\n12 Law reporting is considered \nin detail in Chapter 6 , and the doctrine of precedent is considered in detail in Chapter 8 . \nTHE COURTS \nAs you will have realised by now, courts of law are the institutions that hear and determine legal disputes based on the infringements of legal rules. Legal rules serve no purpose if there is not a system of offcially sanctioned institutions for the adjudication of legal dis -\nputes with powers, as appropriate, to: \n  punish the defendant in a criminal case or award damages and/or an equitable rem -\nedy to the complainant in a civil case; \n  ensure enforcement of its criminal law punishments or award of civil law remedies; \n  hear appeals from the outcome of trials. \nThe courts have developed over centuries, and very few were created by statute. At one \ntime, the royal courts were part of the monarch’s own household; however, as adjudica -\ntion became a full-time job it could not be conducted by the monarch alone. \nAs the powers of English monarchs were successively usurped or transferred to \nParliament, changes to the structure and administration of the courts have increasingly been made by legislation. New courts have also been created by legislation. But change was slow in coming. \nThe frst major overhaul of the structure (as well as the administration) of English civil \ncourts occurred in the nineteenth century through the Judicature Acts of 1873 and 1875. \nThe Judicature Acts led, among other things, to the setting up of a unifed system of \nappeal and the establishment of the Court of Appeal. The Court of Criminal Appeals was \n11 Law reporting is considered in more detail in Chapters 6 and 8. \n12 Precedent will be discussed in more detail in Chapter 7 . \n\n--- Page 68 ---\n    \n \n     \n \n DOMESTIC CASE LAW 37 \nestablished by the Criminal Appeals Act 1907, and merged with the civil Court of Appeal \nin 1966. From that time onwards the Court of Appeal had a civil and a criminal division. Historically the House of Lords had a judicial function to hear appeals which, technically, were appeals to the Crown-in-Parliament. \nThe frst major overhaul of the criminal court structure did not happen until the Courts \nAct 1975, which led to the establishment of the Crown Court to hear criminal trials. \nThere have been various major changes to civil and criminal court structure and \nadministration since 1975. The Courts Act 2003 introduced far-reaching administrative changes to the organisation of English courts, unifying the administration of the English courts through a new institution, Her Majesty’s Courts Service (HMCS), which was set up in 2005. This was the result of government support for the fndings of a review of the criminal courts conducted by Sir Robert Auld and published in 2001.\n13 In 2011 the tribunal \nsystem was merged into HMCS, creating Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS), fnally streamlining the organisation of courts and tribunals.\n14 \nHMCTS is part of the Justice Ministry; however, it is a completely separate agency. It \ncan currently be accessed at http://www.justice.gov.uk/about/hmcts/ . It encompasses all \ntrial courts and the Court of Appeal (criminal and civil divisions) but does not include the Supreme Court. The Constitutional Reform Act 2005 established the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom as the fnal court of appeal or court of last resort. \nEnglish law is today divided into many distinct areas, with the main areas being civil \nand criminal. Civil law can be further subdivided into a range of distinct specialisms, for example contract, family and employment. Civil and criminal cases are heard in differ -\nent courts, although often in practice a court will predominantly deal with one area, for example, criminal matters, and that court may (or may not) have a limited jurisdiction to deal with civil matters, and vice versa. \nCourts also specialise in the type of hearing they are predominantly engaged with, \ntrials, judicial reviews or appeals. Trials (also known as frst instance hearings) involve the presentation of evidence with witnesses usually being called and examined in open court (unless special arrangements have been made to have a live video link for such an examination). Parties to cases in trial courts can appeal through the appeals procedure within the court system. \nAppeal hearings involve hearing a dispute about the outcome of a trial, either in rela -\ntion to remedies awarded (civil actions) or sentence imposed (criminal trials). The techni -\ncal phrase is that such courts have ‘an appellate function’. Certain criteria have to be met otherwise there can be no appeal and leave to appeal must be sought from the courts, again with criteria determining which court must be approached. Again in practice, whilst a court may predominately hear trials, it may have a limited jurisdiction in relation to appeals, and vice versa. \nGeneric terms applied to courts \nThere are a range of different terms used to refer to courts and one court can qualify for several such descriptions: they are not mutually exclusive. The court sits in its own dedicated building in Parliament Square, London. \nThe Court of Appeal (EWCA) \nThe Court of Appeal is divided into two divisions, the criminal appeal division and the civil appeals division. Its jurisdiction extends to England and Wales, but not to the entire United Kingdom in the way that the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court extends. \nIt is staffed by Lord/Lady Justices of Appeal. Normally three Justices of Appeal sit in \ncourt. For important cases it is possible for fve or seven Justices of Appeal to sit in court. It also hears references from the Attorney General on a point of law or on the grounds of an unduly lenient sentence being given. In cases where there has been an acquittal, the acquittal will stand (Criminal Justice Act 1972, s 36), but a ruling can be given by the court supporting the appeal and this must be taken into account in further similar cases. Finally, it has jurisdiction to hear references by the Criminal Cases Review Commission concerning a potential miscarriage of justice.\n15 \nAs noted above, there is not an automatic right to appeal and the Court of Appeal also \nhears applications for leave to appeal to the Supreme Court. \nAppeal Court: civil division \nThe Master of the Rolls is the head of the civil division, which deals with appeals from the High Court and the county court. It also has jurisdiction to hear appeals from the Upper Tribunal, Employment Appeal Tribunal, Immigration Appeal Tribunal, Lands Tribunal and the Social Security Commissioners. Tribunals are discussed in more detail later in this chapter. Table 2 .3 sets out the appellate courts in a quick access table form. \nSuperior courts \nA superior court is one whose decisions are not subject to any other court except an appellate court. These courts deal with trials and are also called courts of frst instance. Some of these courts are more closely identifed with criminal law and some with civil law cases. Most courts will major in one area of jurisdiction, but exercise limited jurisdiction \n15 s 9 Criminal Appeal Act 1995. \n\n--- Page 72 ---\n      \n      \n \n \n \n \n \n    \n \n \n  DOMESTIC CASE LAW 41 TABLE 2.4 SUPERIOR COURTS: HIGH COURT AND CROWN COURT: ROLE, JUDGES, DIVISIONS AND JURISDICTION\nDescription of court Judges Inferior\ncourt Superiorcourt Criminaljurisdiction Civiljurisdiction Trialcourt Appellatecourt \nTheHighCourt Queen’sBenchDivision First instance jurisdiction: Appellate jurisdiction:criminal appeals from magistrates’ court, CrownCourt sitting without a jury. At the end of the descriptions, Table 2 .5 briefy sets out the main features of \neach court for your quick reference. \nThe High Court \nThe High Court is split into three divisions for administrative purposes: Queen’s Bench \nDivision, Chancery Division, Family Division and each of these three divisions is further subdivided. Its primary jurisdiction is civil at frst instance, but it also has an appellate jurisdiction in a limited range of criminal and civil matters. \nThe judges sitting in the High Court are referred to as ‘ puisne ’ judges, a word derived \nfrom the old French for ‘inferior’. \nQueen’s Bench Division \nThe head of the division is the Lord Chief Justice. Its jurisdiction is primarily civil. However, alongside its civil jurisdiction it exercises an appellate jurisdiction to hear criminal appeals from the magistrates’ court by way of ‘case stated’. No witnesses are called, and the appeal is conducted by legal argument and the submission of documentary evidence. It also has jurisdiction to hear criminal appeals from the Crown Court, which has sat without a jury. \nThe Queen’s Bench Division mainly deals with civil actions in contract and tort (acci -\ndent) claims, fraud, malicious prosecution, claims against the police and contentious pro -\nbate cases. Additionally, it has the jurisdiction to hear civil appeals from the county courts. \nThe sub-divisional courts of the Queen’s Bench Division \nTo more effciently carry out its range of functions, it also has fve specialist sub-divisional courts, the Administrative Court, the Admiralty Court, the Commercial Court, the Technology and Construction Court and the Intellectual Property Enterprise Court. The Administrative Court deals with applications for judicial review. This is an application to review the action of a public or a private body (e.g. a local authority or a sports club), mostly on the grounds that in exercising its public duties and making a determination that body has exceeded its lawful authority. As you may suspect, the Admiralty Court deals exclusively with matters relating to shipping, although it also deals with issues relating to aircraft. The Commercial Court deals with actions arising in the felds of banking, insurance and fnance. The Technology and Construction Court deals with disputes about engeneering, building and surveying. The Intellectual Property Enterproise Court deals with diputes concerning intellectual prop -\nerty, including patents, copyright and registered designs and trademarks. \nThe Chancery Division of the High Court \nThe head of the Chancery Division is the Chancellor of the High Court. Its jurisdiction is exclusively civil. It is mostly concerned with civil trials in the areas of wills, estates, con -\ntentious probate, land and mortgage actions, trusts, company law, intellectual property and partnerships. It also hears appeals from the county court concerning issues such as bankruptcy. Like the Queen’s Bench Division, the Chancery Division has specialist sub-divisional courts. The Patents Court deals with ownership of products, and the Court of Protection is concerned with the rights of persons with a disability. \n\n--- Page 75 ---\n     \n     \n \n \n \n  \n \n \n \n \n \n 44 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nTABLE 2.5 INFERIOR COURTS: COUNTY COURT AND MAGISTRATES’ COURT: ROLE, JUDGES AND JURISDICTION\nDescription Inferior\ncourt Superiorcourt Criminaljurisdiction Civiljurisdiction Trial court (f rst instance) Appellatecourt \nCounty court \nFirst instance jurisdiction: debt, personal injuries compensation,breach of contract relating to goods/property, divorce, adoption, wills, bankruptcy, housing disputes \nincluding mortgages, arrears of rent, repossessions There are geographical \nas well as f nancial limits on its jurisdiction Track system: \nSmall claims, fast track, multi-track \n170 county courts Judges: circuitjudges, deputycircuit judges,district judges,part-time deputy districtjudges √ X √ √ √ X \nMagistrates’court Deals with the majority of all criminal matters (90 per cent); all start in the court: bail applications, warrants for arrest or search, Youth courts, trial criminal: summary offences Trial civil recovery of civil debt, highways issues, family matters excluding divorce, care proceedings linked to children in Youth court Heard by Justices of the Peace who are lay magistrates, sitting as three or a single district judgeworking full-time salaried √ X √ √ √ X \n\n--- Page 76 ---\n    DOMESTIC CASE LAW 45 \nThe Family Division of the High Court \nThe head of division is the President of the Family Division. Its main jurisdiction is civil \nhearing trials relating to defended divorce, adoption and wardship. It exercises limited criminal jurisdiction. If a domestic violence issue is clearly connected to the issue of the settlement of family property, wills and probate, it has jurisdiction to hear the domestic violence issue. It also has a criminal appellate jurisdiction to hear appeals from magis -\ntrates’ courts and the Crown Court in family issues. \nThe Crown Court \nThe jurisdiction of the Crown Court is mainly criminal. It hears criminal trials on indictment heard by a jury, trials where the magistrates declined jurisdiction and trials of offences that can be heard by either the magistrates’ court or Crown Court by the defendant’s choice. \nIt also deals with referrals for sentencing from magistrates’ courts where the statutory \nlimit is considered inadequate and they seek a higher sentence. \nThe Crown Court exercises an appellate jurisdiction in the area of appeals against \nsentences imposed in the magistrates’ court and appeals against conviction in the mag -\nistrates’ court. It also exercises a very limited civil jurisdiction in relation to highways repair and other small matters. \nIt is staffed by High Court judges, circuit judges, deputy circuit judges (part-time), \nrecorders (part-time) and assistant recorders (part-time). \nInferior courts \nThis term basically means that the decisions of these courts are prone to being over -\nturned by the superior courts. \nThe County Court \nCurrently, there are 170 county courts that deal with the majority of civil disputes in the areas of debt, personal injuries compensation, breach of contract relating to goods/prop -\nerty, divorce, adoption, wills, bankruptcy, housing disputes, including mortgages, arrears of rent and repossessions. \nThere are geographical as well as fnancial limits on its jurisdiction. For the purposes of \nadministrative effciency, the court operates a track system. The normal track deals with small claims, mostly under £10,000, although there are a few exceptions. The fast track deals with claims that are under £25,000. The multi-track system deals with complex claims over £25,000. \nThe judges in the county court are circuit judges, deputy circuit judges, district judges \nand part-time deputy district judges. \n\n--- Page 77 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n  \n   46 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nThe Magistrates’ Court \nThis court deals with nearly all criminal matters as the majority of criminal prosecutions \nmust start in the magistrates’ court. A number are then sent on to the Crown Court for trial. The magistrates’ court also exercises criminal jurisdiction to hear bail applications, warrants for arrest or search, and summary offences. It also runs ‘Youth courts’ dealing with young offenders. \nIt also has civil jurisdiction in the area of recovery of civil debt, highways issues, family \nmatters (excluding divorce) and care proceedings linked to children in Youth court. \nIts primary judges are the Justices of the Peace, who are lay magistrates, sitting on a \nbench of three, who are unpaid and part-time. There is provision for some to be appointed as stipendiary magistrates, and then a modest payment is received. The court is also staffed by salaried district judges working full time. \nTribunals \nTribunals were created by legislation in the twentieth century to primarily deal with dis -\nputes by individuals against the state (including government agencies) in particular, in areas such as employment, rents, immigration, mental health and taxations. They are part of the administrative justice stream of the English legal system as their role is to review decision making. The tribunal system developed piecemeal from the 1950s and was restructured by the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007 (TCEA 2007).\n16 \nThe TCEA 2007 creates a two-tier system to include most tribunals and is geared \nonly to appeals against decision making by state offcials. The First-Tier Tribunal is divided into chambers similar to the idea of courts in the courts system, each one hear -\ning cases in particular areas. The Act also creates an Upper Tier Tribunal, which mainly exercises review and appellate functions but has a limited frst instance hearing role in other areas. It is a superior court of record. Its decisions are therefore binding on First-Tier Tribunals. \nIn 2011 the administration of the tribunals was merged with the administration of the \ncourts, creating Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunal Service. Some tribunals are noticeably left out of the restructuring, for example, the Employment Tribunal and the Employment Appeals Tribunal. \nPanels of members decide the outcome of cases in the upper and frst tiers and for \ntribunals outside the tier system. These ‘members’ can be legally qualifed in which case they are called a judge; additionally, judges in the High Court and other courts can sit as a member. Panel members also include experts in the area, for example, doctors or survey -\nors. A judge may sit alone when deciding a case. Each panel has a tribunal chairman or, if a judge is sitting, a tribunal judge responsible for communicating the decision in writing. The Senior President of Tribunals heads up the tier system. \nIt is possible to appeal to the Court of Appeal and on to the Supreme Court from the \nUpper Tribunal, which can also refer some cases to the High Court. \n16 This followed on from the Leggatt Report Tribunals for Users: One System, One Service (2001) www.tribu -\nnals-review.org.uk, accessed 2 October 2020. \n\n--- Page 78 ---\n    \n DOMESTIC CASE LAW 47 \nA notable example of an important tribunal outside the tier system is the Employment \nTribunal and the Employment Appeals Tribunal. Appeals can also go to the Court of \nAppeal and Supreme Court from Appeals Tribunals outside the tier system. This is illus -\ntrated in Figure 2 .1. Table 2 .6 gives information in a checklist format for your use. \nCourts outside the hierarchical system of the English legal system \nTwo courts exert an impact on the English legal system because their decisions can form persuasive precedents or because the statute has provided that their decisions should be taken into account in areas of relevance. The two courts falling into this category are: \n  The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (PC). \n  The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR). \nThe Judicial Committee of the Privy Council \nThe Privy Council is composed of around 500 Privy Counsellors whose duty is to give \nadvice to the monarch concerning the discharge of their state duties. Counsellors have attained high public offce. All past cabinet members, party leaders, archbishops, and current or past speakers of the House of Commons are automatically Privy Counsellors. The ministerial head of the Privy Council is its Senior President. Several committees oper -\nate in the council, and one of them is the Judicial Committee. \nThis is the fnal court of appeal for UK overseas territories, Crown dependencies, \nmilitary sovereign bases overseas, ancient courts (prize courts, Court of Admiralty of the Cinque Ports) and ecclesiastical courts (Arches Court of Canterbury, the Chancery Court of York, Church Commissioners) and for those Commonwealth countries who have retained the court. A court normally consists of three or fve judges. It shares the Supreme Court building in London. Table 2 .7 below sets out checklist information. \nJustices of the UK Supreme Court can sit (as can former Lords of Appeal in Ordinary) \nas well as Privy Counsellors who are judges in superior courts in the Commonwealth. \nThe decisions of the Judicial Committee are considered to be persuasive precedents \nwithin the English legal system, but they do not have to be followed. \nThe European Court of Human Rights \nECtHR \nThis is a court established by the Council of Europe (CoE) in 1959 as a court to hear claims by individuals who had exhausted all of the avenues of complaint nationally available in relation to the European Convention on Human Rights 1950. Revisions to the structure of the CoE in 1998 led to the abolition of the existing ECtHR and the European Commission on Human Rights and the establishing of a new Court of Human Rights. \n\n--- Page 79 ---\n   \n  48 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nFigure 2.1 UK court structure: also showing its relationship with the tribunals, the Privy Council and the European Court of Human Rights \n\n--- Page 80 ---\n      \n  \n  \n \n \n  \n \n \n   \n     DOMESTIC CASE LAW 49 TABLE 2.6 TRIBUNALS TIER SYSTEM: ROLE, ADJUDICATORS AND JURISDICTION\nDescription Panel First instancehearing Appeal hearings Superiorcourt of record \nFirst-TierTribunal\na The First-Tier Tribunal is divided into specialist chambers, and chambers can be added as required. The enactment of the \nHuman Rights Act by Parliament in 1998 changed the domestic judges’ relationship with \nthe ECtHR. This Act allowed nationals to bring claims relating to alleged breaches of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) in domestic courts. Individuals must have exhausted all of the avenues of complaint nationally available in relation to the European Convention on Human Rights 1950 before being able to take their case to the European Court of Human Rights. Section 2 of the Act places a duty on all English judges to take into account the case law of the European Court of Human Rights when deciding cases where they have been given jurisdiction by the Act. More information on this court will follow in  Chapter 4. \nThe hierarchy of the domestic courts (with reference to \ntribunals and the European Court of Human Rights) \nIn the English legal system all courts have a determined place in a hierarchy of courts. It \nis extremely important to know and understand the basic framework for the hierarchy of courts as it provides a framework for understanding the doctrine of precedent. Figure 2 .1 \nsets out a diagram of the court structure of the English legal system indicating the hier -\narchy of courts. An arrow pointing from one court to another denotes that the court the arrow points to holds a higher position in the hierarchy and exercises an appellate func -\ntion over the decisions of the court below it. The most senior court is the Supreme Court. \nThe hierarchy of the courts is key in maintaining the doctrine of precedent, which \nstates that the decisions of senior courts bind those below it and themselves in similar cases. The Supreme Court is an exception in that it is not bound by any court in terms of precedent and it is not bound by itself. \nWhilst the diagram deals with the simple issue of hierarchy, do note that there are \nsmall appellate functions held by trial courts which will have been referred to above in the descriptions of each court. In addition it is possible for an appellant to bypass the Court of Appeal (through a process known as ‘leap-frogging’) and take their appeal directly to the Supreme Court if the appeal fulfls certain criteria. \nThe diagram also refers to two courts that we have already described above, the Privy \nCouncil shown in a grey box and the European Court of Human Rights shown in a blue box. Taken together, these two courts have slightly anomalous positions because they are not part of the hierarchy of the English legal system court structure, yet they are rel -\nevant courts, and their decisions do have a bearing on the way in which English courts determine legal issues dealing with the same legal rules. Often these two courts are a source of confusion because students are not sure where they ft. This diagram clearly explains and shows the nature of their relationship to the English court structure.\n17 \nAdditionally, the diagram refers to the English tribunal system in a grey box. The place \nof tribunals in the English legal system can also be a source of confusion; students want to know how and where tribunals ‘ft’. The legislation setting up many tribunals, but not all, allows an appeal to the main two appellate courts in the English court structure (the Court of Appeal civil division and the Supreme Court).\n18 This can only be done after the \n17 The ECtHR is considered in more detail in Chapter 4 . \n18 The Privy Council is considered in more detail in Chapter 8 . \n\n--- Page 83 ---\n   52 DOMESTIC CASE LAW \nappeals process with the tribunal system has been exhausted. That is why it is important \nto include tribunals in the Figure 2 .1 diagram. \nCONCLUSION \nIn this chapter, you have learnt about the creation and development of both common law and equity and their interrelationship within the English legal system. The develop -\nment of case law through the decisions of senior judges in the English courts has been a piecemeal process, and so too the creation of a court structure, which through periodi -\ncal reform now has a logical hierarchy, operating administratively alongside the system of tribunals. The jurisdiction, nature, and function of the court system within the English legal system, including the role and importance of the doctrine of precedent should now be clear. The importance of three courts outside the hierarchy of the courts, the Privy Council, the Court of Justice of the European Union and the European Court of Human Rights, should also be evident. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  The English legal system is a common law system. \n  Case law is the law created by judges deciding disputes in court. \n  As the common law (also initially referred to as royal justice) developed it got rid of other competing dispute resolution methods such as blood feud, trial by battle and trial by ordeal. \n  Equity was developed as a separate system of law administered by the chancery courts to deal with the rigidity of the common law and its lack of remedies beyond monetary damages. \n  The Supreme Court of Judicature Acts of 1873 and 1875 declared that courts could dispense both common law and equitable principles and that equity prevailed over common law. \n  A customary rule is a practice that communities agree is the only right way to act in that matter; they can change from generation to generation and between geographic areas. \n  Over time customary rules became part of the common law. \n  The English common law system relies on a strict following of the doctrine of precedent. \n  Courts of law are the institutions that hear and determine legal disputes. \n  English courts are in a hierarchical relationship which is pivotal to the operation of the doctrine of precedent. \n  Criminal courts hear cases brought by the state against an individual and they dis -\npense punishment. \n\n--- Page 84 ---\n    DOMESTIC CASE LAW 53 \n  The frst major overhaul of the structure (as well as the administration) of English civil \ncourts occurred in the nineteenth century through the Judicature Acts of 1873 and 1875. \n  The frst major overhaul of criminal courts occurred in the Courts Act 1975, which also established the Crown Court. \n  The Constitutional Reform Act 2005 established the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom. \n  The Courts Act 2003 unifed the administration of the English courts and set up a new institution, Her Majesty’s Courts Service. \n  In 2011 the tribunal system was merged into HMCS, creating Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service. HMCTS does not include the Supreme Court. \n  Tribunals are created by statute, only have statutory jurisdiction and have only been in existence since the mid-twentieth century. Tribunals were administratively reor -\nganised by the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007 and merged with HMC Service in 2011 to form Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service. \n  The Privy Council is the highest appeal court for UK dominions and territories. \n\n--- Page 86 ---\n3 \n  \n INTERNATIONAL AND \nEUROPEAN LAW \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Understand what a treaty is. \n  Appreciate that a treaty operates at the level of international law with no legal effect \nwithin the English legal system unless domestic legislation gives it legal effect. \n  Understand how some or all obligations in a treaty can also become part of English law. \n  Be able to competently read, use and understand treaties. \n  Understand the basic structure of the European Union and its major sources of law. \n  Understand what implications European Law has on the UK even after Brexit. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-4  \n\n--- Page 87 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n        \n        56 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \nINTRODUCTION \nBesides the laws made by the legislators of a country (in the UK, Parliament), there is \nanother area of law that concerns states, corporations and individuals: international law. \nThis area is usually divided into two different topics: \n  Public international law: the study of specifc laws that bind states and individuals, mostly through treaties. \n  Private international law (also called ‘confict of laws’): the study how different national legal systems interact – what happens, for example, if a Russian and an Argentinian got married in South Africa and want a divorce in the United States, or which courts decide a dispute between a Moroccan buyer and a Danish seller, and under which law. \nWhen studying law, you will typically not have to deal with the complications of private international law (maybe in an elective module like International Trade Law, but even there in a simplifed version). Public international law, however, is something you will encounter regularly, and not only in elective modules: treaties and international organisations have regularly shaped and infuenced the British legal systems. \nThis chapter is supposed to help you understand the basic concepts that you need to \nunderstand these interactions. \nEuropean Union law is technically public international law as well – the European Union \n(EU) and its predecessors were created by treaties, but over time it has developed into a whole different area of law. The Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) refers to a ‘new legal order’  of international law.\n1 Through the treaties, through a very wide body of sec -\nondary legislation by the EU institutions, and through the jurisdiction of the CJEU, EU law now is to a large extent directly applicable and effective within each of its member states. \nEven though the United Kingdom left the European Union at midnight on 31 January \n2020, and the transition period ended on 31 December 2020, EU law still has an important infuence on the laws of the United Kingdom, so this chapter will also provide an introduc -\ntion into that area of law. \nINTERNATIONAL LAW \nWhat is a treaty? \nFormally speaking, a treaty is an agreement between two or more states and/or interna -\ntional organisations. Essentially a contract at the state level. Treaties are usually written documents, but the most important defnition of treaties in the Vienna Declaration on the Law of Treaties 1969 (VCLT) – itself a treaty (i.e. a treaty about treaties) – explicitly states that unwritten agreements can also be treaties (Article 3). \n1 C ase 26/62 NV Algemene Transport – en Expeditie Onderneming van Gend & Loos v Netherlands Inland \nRevenue Administration  [1963] ECR 1. \n\n--- Page 88 ---\n    \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 57 \nYou might encounter plenty of other words that mean more or less the same thing as \n‘treaty’: convention, charter, covenant, pact, act, statute, concordat (a treaty that involves \nthe Holy See) or protocol (a treaty that modifes another treaty). All of these mean an agreement between states that all participating states agree to be legally bound by. \nHow do states agree to treaties? \nDrafting \nBefore anyone agrees to a treaty, it will need to be written frst. This stage is usually done behind closed doors by diplomats and lawyers of the countries taking part. As you can imagine, this stage is dominated by politics, power differences between the parties and bargaining/negotiation. Many other factors – internal politics within the states, media coverage, lobbyism, activism, or in some cases bribery, can all infuence this stage. Depending on the complexity of the treaty, this can be a very long process. We will look at drafting skills in Chapter 16 . \nSignature \nOnce the terms of a document are agreed upon, it will be opened for signature. Often, this is done by the Head of State/Government or the Foreign Minister in a ceremony, but it could also be someone else authorised to do this on behalf of their government. \nEven though this act is often the moment the public will see from the creation of the \nnew treaty, it does not by itself create legal obligations for the states signing, besides a rather vague obligation not to work actively against the objectives of the treaty. \nRatifcation \nMore important from a legal standpoint is ratifcation. This means that the signing govern -\nment will need to get formal approval at home for committing to the treaty. How exactly this is done depends on the constitution of the country. Some countries, like Ireland or Switzerland, require a referendum on an important treaty; others, like the UK, require approval by Parliament. Other states might just require formal government approval. In any case, ratifcation means defnite consent to the treaty. \nEffectiveness of the Treaty \nDepending on what is agreed in the treaty, it can then still take a while before the treaty comes into effect – the date could be fxed in the treaty, or it could be stipulated that the treaty only comes into effect once a certain number of state parties have ratifed the treaty. If no date is given, the treaty comes into effect for a Member State once the ratif -\ncation is complete. \n\n--- Page 89 ---\n   \n                       \n        \n 58 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \nThis process is worth keeping in mind when you come across different dates in differ -\nent textbooks – the Treaty of Rome that established the European Economic Community, \nfor example, was signed in 1957, but only came into effect in 1958. In this book, we shall give the latter date, but other authors have decided differently. \nReservations \nThere is, however, one caveat. States can (and very often do) explain that certain parts of the treaty do not apply to them. This is called a reservation, and is legally quite complex. Unless a treaty explicitly prohibits reservations (see, for example, Article 120 of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court), this is allowed as long as the reservation does not go against the object and purpose of a treaty (Article 19 [c] VCLT). \nThe reason for allowing reservations is to maximise participation, but this is often a \nmatter of academic and activist discussion. A good example here is the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) 1979. The United Nations (UN) is quite proud of the fact that CEDAW is one of the most widely ratifed human rights treaties in the world, but sadly it also carries a long list of reservations with it.\n2 A lot of these are clarifcations intended for domestic audiences or concern relatively \nminor issues that even progressive voices can tolerate for the greater good of ratifcation. The UK, for example, made a reservation to retain its discriminatory rules of succession to the Throne (at the time of ratifcation, the rule was that the oldest male heir of the mon -\narch would inherit the title), other states clarifed that the ratifcation of CEDAW will not affect their rules on family names after marriage. \nOther reservations, on the other hand, are more problematic – Saudi Arabia made a \nreservation stating that ‘In case of contradiction between any term of the Convention and norms of Islamic law, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is not under obligation to observe the contradictory terms of the Convention’.\n3 This means that CEDAW does not really have \nany relevance in Saudi Arabia unless it complies with Islamic law (as understood and interpreted by the Saudi authorities). \nIt is up to you what you think of this practice and whether it would be better simply \nto exclude a state like Saudi Arabia from the Convention. On the one hand, Saudi Arabia gets a fg leaf to cover up its highly problematic women’s rights record and can claim to be a party to CEDAW. On the other hand, the state would have never agreed to ratify the Convention without a reservation like this, and women’s rights activists and campaigners in Saudi Arabia now have at least something to refer to. \nWhat does a treaty look like? \nWhile there are no formal rules on how a treaty should look, it is now customary that trea -\nties begin with a preamble. This part does not set out legal obligations, but gives a short summary of the aims of the treaty. Typically, this is done in one very long sentence over several paragraphs. The preamble is quite helpful for understanding the intentions of the drafters of the treaty and can be used for the interpretation of the actual content. \n2 T he full list of reservations by country can be seen here: http://daccess-ods.un.org/access.nsf/Get?Open \n&DS=CEDAW/SP/2006/2&Lang=E. \n3 Ibid., 25. \n\n--- Page 90 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 59 \nThe actual obligations of the parties are laid out in the main body of the treaty in con -\nsecutively numbered articles that often have sub-paragraphs. The treaty itself is (depend -\ning on its length) usually divided into numbered sections or chapters. If you are discussing \nthe legal aspects, you will only need to refer to the number of the article. \nLater changes to a treaty \nIf the member states to a treaty later decide to make changes to a treaty, this is usually done with another treaty. If all member states agree, they can simply make a modifcation treaty that lists all the changes to be made to the initial treaty, and the ‘consolidated version’ of the treaty will show the current version, including all changes to date. Most famously, this has been done multiple times in the European Union: the latest treaty, the Treaty of Lisbon (2007) made changes to the Treaty of Maastricht and to the Treaty of Rome. \nIf some, but not all, member states decide to go further on some aspects of a treaty, \nthey can add what is usually called ‘Additional Protocols’ to the original treaty. This is the case with the European Convention on Human Rights: the original Convention is from 1953, and does not contain all rights that progressive states in 2020 would consider rel -\nevant, so there have been 16 Additional Protocols to date. \nAn example is the death penalty within the member states of the European Convention \non Human Rights. In 1953, this practice was still widespread within Europe, and the right to life in Article 2 explicitly allows ‘the execution of a sentence of a court following his conviction of a crime for which this penalty is provided by law’ as an exception to the right of life. Over time, more and more member states have changed their position on the issue, and adopted Additional Protocol No. 6 (which restricted the death penalty to times of war) and later Additional Protocol No. 13 (which completely rules out the death penalty in all cases). \nThis position changed over time in many member states (by now in all but three), but \nnot all member states would have accepted a change to the Convention itself. Therefore, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Russia can be member states of the ECHR but do not have to rule out the death penalty. \nWhat happens if a state breaks a treaty? \nThis seems to be the most important question given what we regularly hear in the news: states seem to break international law constantly. However, in reality, this is not as big an issue as one might think. In the famous words of international lawyer Louis Henkin, ‘[i]t is probably the case that almost all nations observe almost all principles of international law and almost all of their obligations almost all of the time’.\n4 \nWhat actually happens if a state breaks a treaty is not very straightforward. There are \nmajor differences between national and international law. There is no world legislator – states are sovereign and can (mostly) choose themselves which laws they are bound by and which not, there is no world court with binding jurisdiction (the International Court of Justice works very differently, see below), and there is no world police to enforce treaties or judgments of international courts. \n4 L Henkin, How Nations Behave (2nd edition, Columbia University Press, New York, 1979), 47. \n\n--- Page 91 ---\n   \n 60 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \nIn many cases, the treaties themselves stipulate sanctions. States often have agreed \nthemselves that if they fail to fulfl their obligations they will pay penalties to the other \nstates. As painful as that may be in some cases, it was probably of importance for the state that the other states fulfl their part. In other cases, treaties give jurisdictions to international courts – to special courts set up by the treaty or to the International Court of Justice. However, if none of this is in the treaty, or if a state completely ignores this part as well, there are no legal means of coercion, and we enter the realm of the political. States or international organisations (like the United Nations) might impose sanctions, but this depends on a large number of factors that have little to do with legal obligations: power differences, allies with veto power on the Security Council of the UN, the economic situ -\nation, etc. Other punishments for breaking a treaty can include countermeasures (if state A does not fulfl its part of the treaty, state B might hold back on its own part as well) or declaring the ambassador of the wrongful state a persona non grata , i.e. giving them time \nto leave the country. \nCustomary international law \nBesides treaties, there is another set of rules that bind states: customary international law. You are less likely to come across this outside of elective modules on international law, but it is good to know that this exists. \nCustomary international law is a set of unwritten rules that are formed when two ele -\nments come together: (a) state practice: states have been doing something for quite a while and (b) opinio juris : states have been doing that because they believed they had an \nobligation to do so. All states are presumed to be bound by rules of customary interna -\ntional law unless they persistently objected to the rule while it was formed. \nAll of this is quite vague – there are no rules, for example, how many states have to \npractice something for how long, and it is obviously not easy to determine the belief of a state – but it is surprisingly important. Some of the cornerstones of international law as we know it today are customary rules: the immunity of heads of state and diplomats or the prohibition of slavery, torture and genocide are all rooted within customary international law. This means that even if a state has not, for example, ratifed the Convention against Torture, it is still not allowed to torture its citizens. \nNormally, customary international law can be overridden by a treaty, but some norms \nare regarded as so essential – like the prohibition of torture, slavery or genocide – that they are seen as jus cogens : pre-emptory norms of international law that cannot be \ndisregarded. \nInternational organisations \nLike national law, international law grew in its complexity over time. Early modern interna -\ntional law (often considered to start with Hugo Grotius’ book De iure belli ac paci  (1625)) \nconcerned broad and general agreements between states, but with time international \n\n--- Page 92 ---\n    \n \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 61 \nagreements concerned more and more matters that needed permanent discussions \nbetween the parties involved and structures supporting these discussions. Following examples from private organisations (e.g. the Anti Slavery Union or the International Committee of the Red Cross), states set up organisations to assist them in their tasks (e.g. the International Telegraphic Union and Universal Postal Union in 1874). \nInternational organisations are typically established by a treaty, have a membership \nconsisting of states and/or other international organisations, have a will autonomous from its members, legal personality and the capability to adopt norms addressed to their members.\n5 \nIn today’s complex legal world, their tasks include areas as diverse as creating peace \n(e.g. the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe or the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons), organising the collective defence of member states (e.g. the North Atlantic Treaty Organization), controlling nuclear weapons and power (International Atomic Energy Agency), or controlling trade and fnances (e.g. the World Trade Organization, the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank). International organisations can be worldwide endeavours (e.g. the Universal Postal Union) or regional (e.g. the African Union or the British-Irish Council), and they can be universal (e.g. the United Nations) or highly specialised (e.g. the International Network for Bamboo and Rattan). \nThe UN takes a central place among international organisations. Due to its near-uni -\nversal membership (193 states) and its wide-ranging powers, it is sometimes (wrongly) compared to a world government. All member states of the UN agree that the UN Charter (the treaty establishing the UN) overrides other obligations the state might have (Article 103 Charter of the United Nations) and, even more importantly, to ‘accept and carry out the decisions of the Security Council’ (Article 25 Charter of the UN), the main decision-making body of the UN. The Security Council consists of 15 member states, 10 of which get elected by the other body of the UN, the General Assembly, and 5 of which (US, UK, France, Russia, China) are permanently represented. \nAccording to the Article 2 (4) UN Charter, member states are prohibited from threaten -\ning with or using force against other states, and the only accepted exceptions are self -\ndefence (Article 51 Charter of the United Nations) or a decision by the Security Council (Article 42 Charter of the United Nations). \nThe International Court of Justice \nThe Court \nThe International Court of Justice (ICJ), the successor of the Permanent Court of International Justice, sits in The Hague in the Netherlands. It is an organ of the United Nations, in fact the only principal organ that is not located in New York City. It con -\nsists of 15 judges elected by the UN General Assembly (usually including one judge per \n5 P Sands and P Klein, Bowett’s Law of International Institutions (Sweet & Maxwell 2009), 15. \n\n--- Page 93 ---\n   \n  \n    \n  \n      \n \n \n 62 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \npermanent member of the Security Council, although this unwritten understanding seems \nto have changed when recently the UK candidate failed to be elected). Judges tend to be either high ranking judges from their country of origin, well-known professors of interna -\ntional law or high ranking diplomats, and they tend to be male: in over 70 years, only four judges have been women, with the frst one – Rosalyn Higgins – joining the Court in 1995. \nContentious cases \nBy national standards, this is a very strange court in many ways. While it is often called ‘the world court’ in the media, it has a relatively limited mandate and only deals with a very small number of cases: in some years it might only give one single judgment or advi -\nsory opinion. States in international law are sovereign, which means that they are only bound by treaties and judgments they have agreed to. This means that no state has to appear at the ICJ. \nThe ICJ will only decide a contentious case if … \n1. Both parties have agreed to bring the case to the Court, either after the dispute arose or in the treaty the dispute is about \n2. One party brings the dispute to the Court and the other party then agrees to the jurisdiction (called forum prorogatum ) \n3. Both parties have previously made a declaration that they accept compulsory juris -\ndiction of the ICJ, which they can always withdraw. Currently, 73 states have made such a declaration, including the UK.\n6 \nOnce that is the case, the judgments of the ICJ are binding and can be enforced by the Security Council (Article 94 of the Charter of the United Nations [UNC]). However, you need to keep in mind that in addition to ten elected members, the Security Council has fve permanent members who can block any decision (the so-called veto power, Article 27 [3] UNC). This means that even the best judgment of the Court is not going to help you if, say, you are Nicaragua in 1986 and your opponent is the United States,\n7 but in almost \nall cases the political pressure that follows from an ICJ judgment will be enough to com -\npel a state to comply. \nAdvisory opinions \nThe Court can also give advisory opinions on important topics when asked to do so by the Security Council, the General Assembly and other international organisations. These quite often concern questions that are very contentious – see the opinions on the legality of nuclear weapons,\n8 the Palestinian Wall,9 or more recently on the UK’s mistreatment of \n6 T he list is available on the website of the Court: https://www.icj-cij.org/en/declarations. \n7 S ee Case Concerning Military and Paramilitary Activities In and Against Nicaragua (Nicaragua v. United \nStates of America) ; Merits, International Court of Justice (ICJ), 27 June 1986 and Security Council \nProvisional Verbatim Records S/PV.2718. \n8 L egality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons, Advisory Opinion, ICJ Reports  1996, 226, International \nCourt of Justice (ICJ), 8 July 1996. \n9 A dvisory Opinion Concerning Legal Consequences of the Construction of a Wall in the Occupied \nPalestinian Territory , International Court of Justice (ICJ), 9 July 2004. \n\n--- Page 94 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 63 \nthe Chagos Islands10 – but they are not binding legal decisions. Advisory opinions can \nbe important as a political argument or as support for activism, but states can lawfully \ndecide to ignore them, as the Palestinians11 or the West Saharis12 found out (both advisory \nopinions have been largely ignored by the relevant states). \nWhat is the legal effect of a treaty in the country? \nWhile a lot of treaties only set out rules that concern governments in their relations with each other, some treaties actually give rights and obligations to individuals. The most important example are human right treaties, but other treaties could be important as well (for example, trade agreements affecting corporations operating across borders). \nIn how far individuals can rely on a treaty in a court depends not only on the treaty but \nalso on the country’s constitution. In theory, there are two positions: \nMonism \nMonism assumes that treaties that a state has signed and ratifed are part of the state’s legal system. International law in monist theory is basically another area of law, just like criminal law or family law, and as long as a treaty gives suffcient rights or obligations to individuals, these can be enforced within the state’s court system. \nDualism \nDualism, on the other hand, assumes that there are two very distinct areas of law for a state. Inside the state, national law is enacted by the national legislature and enforced by the courts. Outside the state, the state itself has international legal obligations towards other states. In order for a treaty to have an effect within a state, the state’s legislature will need to implement the treaty into national law frst. \nThe reality \nThe two poles of monism and dualism are often portrayed as absolutes, but in reality almost all states are somewhere in between the two. Switzerland is often used as an example of a very monist state,\n13 while the UK is often seen as an example of a dualist \nstate. However, English courts do generally accept customary international law as part of the law of the land.\n14 Treaties, however, need to be implemented into domestic law by \nmeans of legislation in order to be used by English and Welsh courts.15 \nThe implementation Act could simply transfer the entire treaty into domestic law, but \nit could also only implement parts or change aspects of the treaty for domestic courts. \n10 Legal Consequences of the Separation of the Chagos Archipelago from Mauritius in 1965 , Advisory \nOpinion, International Court of Justice, 25 February 2019. \n11 See note 9 above. \n12 Western Sahara , Advisory Opinion, I.C.J. Reports 1975, 12, 16 October 1975. \n13 See Article 5 (4) of the Swiss Constitution. \n14 See Trendtex Trading Corporation  v. Central Bank of Nigeria  [1977] 2 WLR 356, 64 ILR 111. \n15 See J. H. Rayner (Mincing Lane) Ltd. Appellants v.  Department of Trade and Industry and Others [1990] 2 \nAC 418. \n\n--- Page 95 ---\n   \n \n  \n  \n    \n   64 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \nDualist Monist \nIncorpora˜on \nprocess \nInterna˛onal \nlaw \nNa˜onal \nlaw Na˛onal legal system \nInterna˛onal \nlaw \nINTERNATIONAL LAW \nACCEPTED AS PART OF \nNATIONAL LEGAL SYSTEM \nFigure 3.1 Dualist and monist traditions \nIn that case, the Act is the binding document for courts in England and Wales, not the Treaty. \nCONCLUSION \nInternational law is very important these days, and binds the UK and other states in many different areas. More and more of this concerns individuals as well. However, before you attempt to use an international treaty in a domestic court, you need to check a few things: \n1. Is the UK a member of the treaty – i.e. has it signed and ratifed the treaty/the addi -\ntional protocol in question? \n2. Is the treaty already in effect? \n3. Has the UK made a (valid) reservation that concerns the article you want to apply? \n4. Has the treaty been incorporated by Parliament? Does the incorporation include the \nrelevant article? \nEUROPEAN UNION LAW \nWhat is the European Union? \nThe EU is a supranational international organisation based on a number of international treaties between its member states. Since the United Kingdom left the EU at midnight of 31 January 2020, the EU consists of 27 member states with over 440 million citizens. \n\n--- Page 96 ---\n    \n \n \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 65 \nAt its core, the EU is an economic project that has aimed from its very beginning in \n1958 to establish a common market. It would be wrong, however, to reduce the EU or its \npredecessors to nothing but an economic organisation – one of its goals has always been to create peace in Europe – something we take for granted in today’s world, but that has only ever existed for very short phases in the history of the continent. \nThere are many trading arrangements in the world, for example, the United States– \nMexico–Canada Agreement (formerly known as NAFTA), the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Free Trade Area or the Common Market of Eastern and Southern Africa, but none of them has reached the level of integration that the European Union has. \nHow did the European Union develop? \nAfter the end of the Second World War, the political leaders of Western Europe had a number of issues to solve: the continent was devastated by war, the economies were in collapse, the possibility of another war should be eliminated, and the Soviet Union was looming over Western Europe as the new threat. \nThe approach chosen to address these issues was to establish the European Coal \nand Steel Community (ECSC) in 1951, with the aim of pooling the resources needed for war and economic growth (at least in the 1950s). The ECSC was an important step in the history of the continent, but has no signifcance today, as it ended in 1951. \nAs the next step, the European Economic Community and the European Atomic Energy \nCommunity then followed 1958 with the Treaties of Rome (signed in 1957), two treaties signed and ratifed by France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, (West) Germany and Italy. The European Economic Community (EEC) then went through some changes in the form of further treaties: the Merger Treaty in 1967 and the Single European Act in 1987 (which despite the misleading name ‘Act’ is also a treaty). \nThe progress made in the Single European Act (like the introduction of majority vot -\ning) led the member states to take a further step: the founding of the European Union with the Treaty of Maastricht (or Treaty on European Union) in 1993. At the beginning, the European Union was merely a political construct based around the far more power -\nful European Community (which lost its middle ‘E’ with the Treaty of Maastricht), adding enhanced collaboration in Foreign and Security Policy and in matters concerning Justice and Home Affairs. \nFollowing this were two further reform treaties: the Treaty of Amsterdam (1999) and \nthe Treaty of Nice (2003), but neither of these treaties was seen as suffcient to pre -\npare the European Union for the major challenges ahead, particularly the major enlarge -\nment that was supposed to happen in 2004 (ten, predominantly central and eastern European states were about to join the club, followed only three years later by Romania and Bulgaria). \nTherefore, the member states signed another treaty in 2004 – the Treaty Establishing \na Constitution for Europe. This treaty, often simply called the ‘Constitution’, went into the ratifcation stage and failed two referenda in France and in the Netherlands. The \n\n--- Page 97 ---\n   66 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \ncompromise then taken by the member states was to negotiate, sign and ratify a more \ntraditional treaty that did not introduce any major challenges: the Treaty of Lisbon (in force in 2009). \nThe Treaty of Lisbon abolished the distinction between the EC and the EU that was \nintroduced with the Treaty of Maastricht. From 2009 onwards, there has only been one organisation: the European Union. To date, this is the latest treaty reforming the European Union, and given its diffcult birth (following the failure of the Constitutional Treaty and a long ratifcation process with two referenda in Ireland and a reluctant Czech President), it is probably fair to say that the member states are not overly eager to start negotiations for a new treaty any time soon. \nWhat are the key institutions of the European Union? \nThe European Council \nThe European Council consists of the Heads of State or Government from all member states of the EU. It meets at least twice every six months and takes the major, overarching decisions: should a state be admitted for membership? What strategic direction should the EU take in the next fve years? What is the EU’s position on major international devel -\nopments like climate change or the refugee crisis? The European Council is therefore obviously important for the development of the EU but has only limited relevance for the creation of EU law. \nSince the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Council elects itself a president for the period \nof 2.5 years. The fact that you might not even know the name of the current president shows that this offce does not hold a lot of power. \nThe Council of the EU \nThe Council of the EU is far more important when it comes to the actual day-to-day law making of the Union. The Council meets in different compositions (currently ten) depend -\ning on the topic to be discussed, and every Member State is represented by the minister who is qualifed to speak on behalf of his or her government on the topic – for example, the Secretary of State for the Environment or the Foreign Minister. \nMeetings on Foreign Affairs are chaired by the EU’s High Representative for Foreign \nAffairs and Security Policy (elected by the European Council), all the other meetings are chaired by the representative of the Member State that currently holds the presidency – this rotates between all states every six months. \nThe European Parliament \nThe European Parliament is directly elected by the citizens of the member states for a fve-year term. The elections in the member states usually follow national party lines, and \n\n--- Page 98 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 67 \nthe newly elected Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) then form European party \ngroups in the Parliament. \nThe European Commission \nThe European Commission is probably the most famous institution of the EU. It is often compared to a national government, although that comparison is not entirely accurate. The Commission consists of a President, the High Representative of the EU for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, and 25 Commissioners (adding up to 27), who all get proposed by the European Council following the elections to the European Parliament and then get elected by the Parliament. Each Commissioner is responsi -\nble for a particular area (e.g. Agriculture or Competition) and is independent of their national government. \nThe Commission is responsible to the European Parliament and can be forced to \nresign by a vote of censure in the Parliament. This has almost happened once: in 1999, the Santer Commission resigned collectively before the Parliament could pass such a vote. \nThe Court of Justice of the EU \nThe Court of Justice has a central importance for the EU – not just because this is a law textbook. Throughout the history of the EU and its predecessors, the judicial arm of the EU has often been the driving force when member states were reluctant to act. \nThe ‘Court of Justice of the European Union’ currently consists of two courts: the \nGeneral Court (the court of frst instance for many cases) and the Court of Justice (the main court). Older books and many writers in academia and mainstream media often refer to the ‘ECJ’ – this is strictly speaking outdated. It would be better to use the acronyms ‘CJEU’ for all courts and ‘CJ’ when referring to the Court of Justice, but old habits die hard. \nArticle 19 of the Treaty on European Union also allows for the existence of ‘spe -\ncialised courts’, and the EU actually had a Civil Service Tribunal (deciding employ -\nment questions between the EU and its civil servants) from 2005 until 2016, when the member states decided to abolish this tribunal and to expand the General Court to 56 (now 54) judges instead. While the treaty allows fexibility for the General Court (‘at least one judge per Member State’), the CJ always consists of one judge per Member State. \nIn addition to the judges, the Court also has 11 Advocates General. If an important \ncase reaches the Court, an Advocate General will be asked to submit an opinion on the case. These are usually more interesting to read than the rather technical judgments and are often, but not always, followed by the Court. In the media, an opinion by an Advocate General is sometimes confused with the actual judgment, but it is not legally binding for anyone. \n\n--- Page 99 ---\n   \n \n \n  \n  68 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \nWhat is European Union law? \nEuropean Union law is a complex area of law that does not quite ft into any of the estab -\nlished categories. It is ultimately based on treaties between states, but it is far too inte -\ngrated into the domestic laws of the EU’s member states to be simply considered a \nsub-discipline of international law either. \nThe predecessor of the EU, the EEC, was established in 1958 and has grown ever \nsince. Both in terms of member states and population (from 6 member states in 1958 to 27 in 2020) and in terms of the developments of its legal system. While the original EEC was very much an international organisation limited to very specifc areas as described in the previous sections, today’s EU is a complex organisation sui generis  (of its own kind) \nthat has a large infuence on the daily lives of its ca 450 million citizens. Quite how this development happened – because the member states actively worked towards that or because the institutions developed a momentum of their own – is an interesting feld of study that has flled many political science books (‘European Integration’). \nIn any case, it is certainly true that the Court of Justice of the EU played a large part in \nthis through major landmark decisions that will be discussed below. \nWhat are the sources of EU law? \nTreaties \nThe most important source of law for the EU are the treaties. Legally, they are the only reason for the Union’s existence and have established the different institutions of the EU discussed above. \nEU treaties follow the same procedure as international treaties – they are negotiated, \nsigned and ratifed by the member states. All other forms of EU law have to comply with the treaties, which means that ultimately the member states have the last word on any issue. \nWhat makes this area a bit complicated is that there are many treaties that defned the \nEU, as you already read. Essentially, there are two major founding treaties: The Treaty of Rome establishing the EEC and the Treaty of Maastricht establishing the EU. \nThe other treaties mentioned above – SEA, Amsterdam, Nice and Lisbon – are also \ntreaties in their own right but have modifed the two founding treaties. In some cases, they added or removed articles, and in other cases, they renumbered a signifcant amount of articles (especially in the Amsterdam and Lisbon treaties). \nThis means that for the purpose of understanding the current state of the law, we look \nat the consolidated versions of the two founding treaties – the latest version that incorpo -\nrates all changes from the modifcation treaties: \n1. The Treaty on European Union (TEU, the Maastricht Treaty), explaining the institution and the political processes \n2. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU, the Rome Treaty), going into far more detail on the legal rules governing the internal market. \n\n--- Page 100 ---\n    \n  \n    INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 69 \nWhen reading old cases or journal articles, you need to be aware that the numbering of the Treaty Articles has changed over time (the preliminary ruling procedure, the most important legal procedure in the Court of Justice, has, for example, moved from Article 177 TEEC to Article 234 TEC with the Amsterdam Treaty and to Article 267 TFEU with the Treaty of Lisbon). If you are confused (and you will be), you can fnd the changes in the ‘Table of Equivalences’ that is included in the statute book. \nSecondary legislation \nAs mentioned before, the treaties establish the different institutions. In addition, they also enable the institutions to make secondary legislation, governed by the principle of confer -\nral in Article 5 of the TEU: the institutions are only allowed to make laws in areas where the treaties explicitly enable this. The institutions of the EU cannot, therefore, make laws in other areas like Criminal Law or Taxation. \nThe institutions can, according to Article 288 TFEU, make the following laws: \n  Regulations: rules that immediately apply in all member states \n  Directives: rules that are directed towards the member states and that need to be implemented to have an effect \n  Decisions: administrative rules that are directed at individuals, particular states or companies \nThis is usually done by a process called the Ordinary Legislative Procedure, a process that involves three of the institutions mentioned above: \n1. The Commission has the right of initiative. Every law is proposed by the Commission \n2. The European Parliament and … \n3. The Council of the EU then have to agree to a version of the law. Both institutions can modify the proposal and aim to reach a compromise in a process, not unlike the leg -\nislative ping pong played between the House of Commons and the House of Lords in the UK. \nThis procedure shall ensure that there is a mix of EU interest (Commission), democratic input (Parliament) and Member State representation (Council) involved in the outcome. When the Council votes, it does so in the ‘Qualifed Majority Procedure’ – a vote is suc -\ncessful if at least 55% of the member states agree and these member states represent at least 65% of the population. \nOnce this procedure is done, the legislation is published in the offcial journal of the \nEU. It also gets assigned a number, which is then used to refer to it in the future: \n  Regulations (since 1967) get numbered with a sequential number, the year, and the \norganisation (EU, Euratom or before December 2009 EC) in brackets: Regulation (EC) 1612/88 – regulation number 1612 in 1988 \n\n--- Page 101 ---\n   \n \n \n \n  \n \n  \n \n \n 70 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \n  Directives are numbered similarly, but in a different order: \nDirective 2004/38/EC \n  Decisions also have a slightly different order: Decision No 477/2010/EU \nEffect of EU law \nSo far, none of the above is overly unusual for international organisations, except for, to an extent, the idea of majority voting. What is completely different, however, is how that law applies in practice, which has been established by the Court of Justice in a series of landmark cases. \nDirect effect \nIn van Gend en Loos , the Court established the principle of direct effect. Normal inter -\nnational law only binds states in their relations with each other; what happens with the treaties within the country is entirely up to the country itself (as discussed above in the ‘Monism’ and ‘Dualism’ part). When a Dutch transport company (van Gend) was told by the Dutch Government that the European Economic Community Treaty has no relevance to them, the Court of Justice, however, decided that the European Economic Community is not normal international law. Instead, it is ‘a new legal order of international law’, which does not just create obligations for individuals, but also rights.\n16 Van Gend was therefore \nable to reclaim the custom duties it should not have paid under the EEC Treaty. \nThe Court went even further in the case of Defrenne v SABENA (1976). In this case, \nMs Defrenne, a fight attendant from Belgium, noticed that her male colleagues were receiving higher salaries than she did. Belgian legislation could not help her at the time, so she successfully relied on what is now Article 157 of the TFEU – equal pay for equal work.\n17 What makes the case important is the fact that her opponent in the case was not \nthe Belgian state, but a private airline: the Court of Justice established the principle that not only states have to comply with the obligations under the treaty, but also individuals. In the literature, this is often referred to as ‘horizontal direct effect’ – the treaty is effec -\ntive between private parties – contrary to ‘vertical direct effect’, where the treaty is used against the state. \nIn later cases, the Court has extended the principle of vertical direct effect to second -\nary legislation, including directives,\n18 and it has clarifed that regulations and decisions \nare also capable of horizontal direct effect.19 \nThe situation with horizontal direct effect of directives is more complicated. The Court \nhas decided that directives should, in general, only bind the state, and therefore not have direct horizontal effect,\n20 but it has made exceptions to the general rule.21 \n16 Case 26-62 NV Algemene Transport en Expeditie Onderneming van Gend en Loos  v Nederlandse \nAdminstratie van Belastingen  [1962]. \n17 Case 43/75 Gabrielle Defrenne  v Société Anonyme Belge De Navigation Aérienne SABENA [1976]. \n18 41/74 van Duyn v Home Offce  [1974]. \n19 Case 9/70 Grad v Finanzamt Traunstein  [1970]. \n20 Case C-271/91 Helen Marshall v Southampton Area Health Authority [1993]. \n21 See, for example, Case 14/83 Von Colson and Kamann v Land Nordrhein Westfalen  [1984]. \n\n--- Page 102 ---\n    \n \n \n \n  \n  \n   \n \n INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW 71 \nSupremacy \nShortly after the landmark decision in van Gend , the Court of Justice was confronted with \nanother case of similar signifcance: Mr Costa was not willing to pay his electricity bill, \nbecause he claimed the law that set up the company asking him for payment was illegal under EU law. The Italian Government argued that this should not matter: the EEC treaty was ratifed in 1958, and the Italian law came after the treaty. If two laws are in confict, the general rule is that the newer law prevails over the older one. \nHowever, the Court of Justice disagreed. It argued once more with the ‘new legal \norder’ and stated that allowing later laws to challenge the validity of EU law would mean ‘the legal basis of the Community itself being called into question’.\n22 Essentially, Italy \nwould be able to amend the Treaty as far as its citizens are concerned, and there would be little stopping – let’s say – France from prohibiting its shops from selling Italian wines or Germany banning French workers. Instead of an internal market where a German worker can take up employment in Sweden and a Portuguese company can sell its prod -\nuct to customers in Slovakia, the EU would be a complex set of opposing national rules. Therefore, EU law, according to the Court of Justice, must have primacy (or supremacy) over the laws of its member states: when there is a confict between national and EU law, all national judges have an obligation to ‘set aside’ the national law in question.\n23 \nWhat seems logical from the Court of Justice’s perspective created quite an outrage \namongst national courts. Particularly the German Constitutional Court brought forward challenges to the doctrine of supremacy, followed by other courts. However, all these challenges were raised as points of principle – no court has ruled out the principle of supremacy yet, and it seems to work very well in practice. \nLocating EU law \nLegislation \nAll offcial legal sources of the European Union can easily be found on the website eur-lex .europa.eu. There, you can look at the treaties in their current, consolidated version (in the 23 offcial languages of the EU), and you can search other legal acts – regulations, direc -\ntives and decisions. You can either search for the offcial year and number (e.g. 2004/38 for the citizenship directive) or for fragments of texts you are interested in (‘European citizenship’ or ‘professional qualifcations’). \nCases \nFinding cases of the European Courts is very easy. The Court of Justice of the European Union has a very useful website under curia.europa.eu, where you will fnd a search func -\ntion for cases. Unless you already know the case number (which should be given in a ref -\nerence) or the names of the parties (e.g. ‘van Gend’), you can use the extensive ‘Advanced Search’ function, where you can, for example, search for any cases involving competition law between 2004 and 2006 or for any cases against the Republic of France in 1995. \n22 Case 6-64 Flaminio Costa  v ENEL  [1964]. \n23 Case 106/77 Amministrazione delle Finanze dello Stato  v Simmenthal SpA  [1978[. \n\n--- Page 103 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n            \n                                 72 INTERNATIONAL AND EUROPEAN LAW \nEUROPEAN UNION LAW IN THE UK AFTER BREXIT \nThe extensive detail this chapter gives to an introduction into European Union law might \nbe a little confusing – after all, this book is aimed at law students in England and Wales – and the UK left the EU on 31 January 2020. \nEU law is still important for a number of reasons. For once, you are likely to come \nacross cases from before 2021, and understanding some European law is essential to understanding these cases. Judges in the UK have made decisions based on EU law, have been infuenced by the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice of the EU or might have followed a preliminary ruling from the Court on the issue at hand or on a related question. Law making has been infuenced and shaped by EU treaties, regulations or directives and by decisions made by the Court of Justice. \nMany laws of the EU still apply in the UK. According to the UK’s own European Union \nWithdrawal Act 2018, directly effective EU Law, such as regulations, became part of the UK’s domestic law after the withdrawal,\n24 and directly effective rights and obligations that \nexisted before 31 January 2020 continue to recognised and available in UK domestic law.\n25 \nDoctrines in public law have been infuenced by European debates as well. Important \ncases that involve the European Union (e.g. the case of the ‘Metric Martyrs’26 or the more \nrecent case of Miller and Cherry27) are going to remain very relevant, as they concern \ncentral aspects of the British Constitution like the Rule of Law, Parliamentary Sovereignty and the Royal Prerogative. \nThe European Union is, and probably will remain, the most important trading partner \nof the United Kingdom. Every company in the UK that exports or imports products or services to or from the EU will need to comply with EU law when doing that. The same is true for American or Chinese laws, but it is far more likely that a solicitor gets in contact with businesses from Paris or Dublin than with businesses from Shanghai or Chicago. \nAnd we should not forget that an important part of the UK – Northern Ireland – has \nremained part of most of the single market.
