Nearly all stu -\ndents are surprised by the expectation that they engage in many hours of independent study a week. If one assumes a learning week of 35 hours for a full-time student during the two main teaching terms of the academic year they will spend at least 66 per cent of their time engaged in independent study. This statistic remains relative for a student studying part time as they pursue other activities during the week. \nLife at university allows you the freedom to explore books and electronic learning \nresources – to prepare when you wish, and to discuss ideas with your peer group. We live in an age of ‘lifelong learning’ where more and more people of all ages become students either full time or part time, formally through structured degree programmes or more informally through MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) and other dis -\ntance learning provisions. What they each have in common is that all students have to seize all of the learning opportunities offered and self-manage their own path through them. \nThroughout the course of your law degree, independent studying will involve prepara -\ntion for seminars or tutorials; engaging with pre-set questions and set reading; research -\ning discussion topics; or completing coursework assignments, reports or presentations for formal assessment. \nYour lecturers and seminar or tutorial leaders are generally academics who are not \nonly teachers but are working on their own research and producing publications. Their role is to guide you through their module, giving you a blueprint to use to set the bounda -\nries for you to determine your own independent study. This is an extremely different sce -\nnario from school organisation, where the teacher primarily teaches and pupils usually have exclusively taught classes and are expected to do directed home-based work out of school. \nA required skill of the graduating university student is that they should demonstrate \nthat they have developed a strong personal independency. This is seen as the marker of ‘graduate-ness’. Employers will certainly be looking for evidence of this. The UK Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (the body that checks to ensure universities maintain their own academic standards and quality) require it to be instilled in students. One way of demonstrating that you have this skill is to have good habits of independent study. It is not only essential for your academic and vocational education but also in the legal profession, organising the handling of their client’s fle. \nHOW TO DEVELOP HABITS OF INDEPENDENT STUDY \nIndependent learning involves the development of self-discipline: we are all different; you must not be concerned by others and their plans (or lack of them). You only need to concern yourself with you. You need to take time and decide what works best for you in terms of learning. \n\n--- Page 136 ---\n    GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 105 \nTime-management skills are essential for your development of good learning habits. \nConsider for a moment if you have a good track record of organising your time to get \nthings done. In the past your teacher, your employer or your family may have given you a structure for planning your work. At university you will have to learn to do this for yourself, structuring task completion and also prioritising among tasks. \nThe effcient management of your independent study requires that you obtain the full \nrange of information relating to being able to effciently study, which includes information on: \n  your modules (syllabus/module outline, reading lists, handbooks, set texts); \n  all assessment submission dates; \n  your weekly/fortnightly/termly timetable of taught classes; \n  term dates and the organisation of the academic year; \n  using your department’s virtual learning environment; \n  using required IT (including word-processing packages); \n  how to competently use the library; \n  development of your English language skills and the ascertainment of your strengths \nand weaknesses. \nOnce you have pulled all of this information together, you will need to prioritise your time in terms of lecture attendance, seminar preparation, attendance and participation in sem -\ninars, submission of coursework, revision and taking exams. \nAlways be aware of your own study priorities on a daily and weekly basis by keeping \nan organised digital or print diary. Look ahead and plan out the term, noting when assess -\nments are set and when they are due for submission. \nBeing well organised in your management of class attendance, independent study and \ncoursework submission will help ensure that you do not experience high stress levels. \nTHE CYCLES PATTERNS AND SCHEDULES OF \nSTANDARD UNIVERSITY STUDY \nIt is necessary to understand the organisation of your degree through all of its years, as \nwell as the divisions of the academic year into terms or semesters. You cannot success -\nfully manage your learning if you do not know the patterns of life at your university, what is expected of you and when it is expected. \nThe pattern of your degree \nFull-time students usually complete their studies within three years, although if place -\nments or time abroad is involved it can be four years. Part-time students usually take up to six years to complete their degrees, made up of two years of part-time study for each \n\n--- Page 137 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 106 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nfull-time year of study. But students may be able to complete a part-time degree sooner. \nMany universities will allow a part-time student to study full time for part of the degree if the student is able to do so. \nModules \nEach year you will take a range of modules and obtain credits at certain grades; these determine your degree result. In many universities, year 1 grades do not count towards the calculation of the fnal degree grade, but that may not be the case for all degrees. An often overlooked but important task for students is to understand how many mod -\nules are required for the completion of their degree, and which are compulsory and optional. \nYou should aim to make links between the various modules on your degree course, \nrather than moving from one module to another without any regard for what has gone before. For some modules such as employment law you will be required to draw on con -\ncepts learnt in previous years in the law of contract and law of tort modules. Similarly, make links between each individual topic within each module, seeing them as parts of a whole, and consider them in the context of other issues, such as social scientifc analysis of law as well as legal analysis. \nEach module that you study throughout your degree will carry a set number of cred -\nits towards your degree, with a degree being made up of 360 credits. Each year of your degree is therefore worth 120 credits and each course or module you study will contribute a specifc number of credits to that total. \nUniversities have different systems on how many credits each module is worth, \nand this will be based on the number of hours they expect students on a module. You might have some modules worth 20 credits (often optional modules), some modules worth 10 credits (often introductory modules) and some modules worth 40 credits (complex core modules like the law of contract), but all of this varies from university to university. \nYou will be required to complete a set number of compulsory courses or modules each \nyear. Options usually have to be chosen in the induction week, if not before. Your choices here are important for a number of reasons. If you have a clear idea of the career path you want to follow after your studies (for example, you may want to practise corporate or commercial law), you may choose modules that are more closely aligned with that path. When you have ascertained what your optional modules are you should consider them carefully before making your choice. \nIt is also important that you do a bit of research on what you need to do to qualify \nas a lawyer (if that is what you want). You might need to take specifc options to fulfl the requirements laid down by the professions – either because your university offers a non-qualifying route as the default, or because you might want to qualify in a different common law jurisdiction where you need to have done modules that are not compulsory in your university (some African common law jurisdictions, for example, require the law of \n\n--- Page 138 ---\n    \n \n  GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 107 \nevidence). Unfortunately, there are a lot of required options for a qualifying law degree. \nWith these added to the compulsory modules your university requires you to do, there is often not a lot of choice left. \nThe cycle of the academic year \nThe academic year is usually organised according to terms or semesters. Terms split the academic year into three terms of 11–12 weeks separated by vacations; the semester sys -\ntem splits the academic year into two semesters of around 16–18 weeks, again separated by vacation. The total number of weeks of university teaching is therefore in the region of 33–36 weeks. Some university departments hold exams at the end of each term or semester, others at the end of the academic year. \nHowever, university teaching rarely extends beyond weeks 22–24 of these teaching \nweeks, as time is set aside for revision and examinations. Generally, all of the teaching and learning is squashed into the 22 weeks between September/October and March/ April, a period that also includes around seven weeks of vacation time. The reality is that you are only taught for around six months of the year. \nFirst-year students can easily fail to get into proper study habits and independent \nlearning until January or February by which time the taught year is half over and several modules are completed. In departments where modules are only one term in length, students who take weeks to acclimatise upon arrival can fnd they are failing because they did not even realise modules ended in December: they thought they had more time to improve. \nEach of these front-loaded 22–24 weeks contains lectures and seminars and in many \nweeks there will be assessment submission deadlines. It is this yearly pattern that deter -\nmines the fow of your taught classes, independent study and free time. \nConsideration of the pattern of your taught classes and assessments as well as vaca -\ntions (when you will fnd you still need to be studying) allows you to see where you have spaces for independent study as well as gathering work experience, doing paid employ -\nment if necessary and to recover. \nIt is equally important to understand the rhythm of your term/semester cycle and the \ntimetable of weekly lectures, seminars and assessments. You will need to organise your study outside the classroom for seminars and assessments as well as increasing your general understanding of the subject. The discussion that follows discusses the termly pattern, as shown in Figure 5.1, but it can be adapted very easily to slot into the semester \npattern if your institution uses it. \nZooming into this cycle in more detail, Table 5 .5 sets out the months of the year and \nmaps them against the standard academic activity taking place, so you can begin to see the rhythm of the academic year for the typical student. Not all university departments will have the same pattern, but they will be similar. This will reinforce the comment above that you do not actually have a year to study; at best you have nine months. Of this time, only around six months will be spent with teachers in lectures and seminars. \n\n--- Page 139 ---\n   \n \n \n  108 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nVACATION \n3 – 4 weeks TERM 1 \n11 – 12 weeks \nTeaching \nVACATION \n11 – 12 weeks TERM 2 \nThen the next 11 – 12 weeks \nyear starts! It is here, at the detailed level, that you are most likely to struggle. \nPlanning your weekly and yearly timetable \nIt is essential that you plan your timetable carefully, and that you plan for appropriate self-study time right from the beginning. \nContrary to school, the chances are that you will be able to get through your classes \nas a passive listener without preparing. However, if you do this, you are going to face a very stressful time preparing for your assessments and exams, and your performance is almost certainly going to suffer. In the worst cases the mixture between under- and over -\nwork can have serious consequences for your mental health. \nIf you are a full-time student and have other responsibilities – family, part-time work – a \ngood plan is absolutely essential for your success. Depending on your preferences, this could either be in a paper-based diary (just make sure it is small enough so you can carry it everywhere) or in one of the many online calendar solutions that you can also view and use on your phone. \n\n--- Page 140 ---\n      \n \n \n \n GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 109 TABLE 5.5 TYPICAL ACADEMIC CYCLE FOR A YEAR 1 STUDENT ON A DEGREE DIVIDED INTO TERMS\nMONTHS OFFICIAL ACTIVITY STUDENT TASKS WEEKS \nSEPT TERM 1: INDUCTION MAYBE \nSTART OF TEACHING This is a whirlwind time of highs and lows for most students. Put fears you have failed something behind you and keep your strength up for the next exam.\nJUL VACATION ANDEXAM RESULTS: if you failed any exam, f nd out why from your tutors. If you have failed any exams it is essential to see your tutor before they leave for the long vacation. Work hard for the resits and resolve to develop better revision strategies and independent management skills next year.\nAUG VACATION RESITS POSSIBLE\nSEPT RESITS [NORMALLY] VACATION: THE NEW ACADEMIC YEAR USUALLY STARTS MID TO END OF SEPTEMBER \n\n--- Page 142 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 111 \nEnter your classes frst once you know their dates and times. Then have a look at your \nmodule handbooks for the recommended independent study hours. These are typically \na good representation of what you are going to need to do for succeeding in a particular module. Then arrange and add your paid employment (if you are doing part-time work). Finally, make sure that you have some free time left for recreation and things you enjoy doing! It is extremely important – not only for yourself, but also for your performance on the degree – that you get some time to rest in addition to studying. \nAnother thing to look out for from the beginning is the other activities in your law \nschool and in the wider community – your law school might have mooting competitions, a law society, a law newsletter, a law clinic or many other extra-curricular opportunities. You might be able to volunteer at organisations like Citizens Advice or for an NGO. All of these activities are incredibly important. Law is a very competitive profession, and an engagement with the law that goes beyond going to classes and completing assess -\nments is almost required these days. Employers want to see that you really care about the topic and that you devote time and energy to it. Volunteering and engaging with other law students or lawyers also is a great motivator and keeps reminding you why you are doing all this when you are struggling to revise for a particularly diffcult exam. Make sure to add time for activities like this – whether it is one hour on Wednesday afternoon for your law newsletter meeting or several weeks in summer for work experience. \nAs mentioned before, many universities do not count the frst-year results into the \ndegree classifcation. This leads some students to take a more relaxed stance in that year, a strategy that is almost certain to backfre: it is far more diffcult to change your habits in year 2 than to create new habits in year 1. In addition, future employers will often want to look at your entire transcript. If you apply for a placement or a training contract in a frm specialising in criminal law, for example, the recruiter will not be overly excited about a low mark in your criminal law module – whether that was in year 3 or 1. \nMany management consultants additionally advise that crisis time is built into your \nstandard timetable planning. These are hours that are ‘free’ but ‘in-waiting’: in case you cannot study at the time allotted you can use a crisis-time bloc. There may also be a read -\ning week or independent study week each mid-term when there is no teaching, allowing you to catch up, though this is not the case in all departments. The vacations also allow you some space to have a break as well as catch up with study or work on assessments that may be due. \nTHE RANGE OF SKILLS REQUIRED FOR SUCCESSFUL LEGAL STUDY \nTable 5 .6 sets out the wide range of skills that you need to develop for successful legal \nstudy. Do read these carefully; they are all interrelated and, when taken together, impact your learning. \nYou will by now realise that it is fatal to underestimate the importance of general study \nskills, and that your competent study requires competent English language skills, legal \n\n--- Page 143 ---\n   \n  \n \n \n \n  112 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nTABLE 5.6 THE SKILLS REQUIRED FOR THE SUCCESSFUL STUDY OF \nLAW \nStudy skills How to develop independent and highly effcient learning strategies, \nincluding effcient fling systems, which will tend to be both digital and hard copy. \nIT skills Effcient use of email, word-processing, being able to navigate virtual learning environments, competent internet search, e-library use, database manipulation. You will fnd plenty of online training materials and help on your university’s web pages. \nCommunication skills The ability to clearly and appropriately communicate with staff and fellow students in writing and orally. Competent understanding of the use of electronic communication in your department. \nLanguage skills Competent understanding and use of general English and technical legal language. This requires a good grasp of vocabulary, grammar, punctuation and spelling. The quality of your language skills determines the effectiveness of your communication. \nCritical thinking skills The ability to constantly question, seeking the underlying assumptions behind arguments, taking nothing for granted, seeking evidence for your assertions, questioning your own positions. \nLegal research skills How to fnd law and texts about law through highly effective library search skills. \nLegal method skills Understanding strategies for fnding, analysing and applying the law. \nArgumentative skills Identifcation, construction and evaluation of the argument. \nReading skills How to read legal texts by engaging in active reading for sense; looking for markers in the text to aid reading; scanning for information; appreciating different methods of reading. \nWriting skills Writing effcient notes, summaries, essays, legal problem solutions, exams, reports and more. \nSpeaking (oral) skills Being able to competently engage in debating, mock trials (mooting), mediation, negotiation, presentation. \nSubstantive law Legal knowledge, for example, of criminal law, contract law and so on. \nmethod skills, critical thinking skills and argument construction skills. You will not achieve \nyour potential without engaging with these sets of skills. \nIt is essential to realise that defciency in one group of skills can affect your perfor -\nmance in all areas, and therefore affect your grades. You may have a good ability to \n\n--- Page 144 ---\n    GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 113 \nargue, but you cannot express this competently in writing using grammatically correct \nEnglish and using correct spellings. \nCompetent use of electronic communication \nGiven that we live in an age where cleaners post examples of their spotless work on their Instagram account and your corner-shop sends a weekly email newsletter to inform you that a type of chocolate bar is back in stock, you would think that electronic communica -\ntion does not need to be explained any more. Unfortunately, this is not true. Many stu -\ndents miss classes, submit wrong assessments or misunderstand seminar tasks simply because of mistakes with electronic communication. \nMake sure that you familiarise yourself with the ways your university and your teachers \ndisseminate information. In most universities, this will be with the use of a virtual learn -\ning environment (such as Moodle or Blackboard) and with email. It is important that you check this regularly – at least on a daily basis, and certainly before classes to check for last-minute changes. \nIt is also essential that you understand the structure of the VLE the university is using, \nso you can make full use of the material that your lecturer shares with you. This can be everything from discussion forum entries over a reading list to video lectures. \nMAKING THE BEST USE OF TEACHING \nIt is essential to properly use the offered teaching arrangements, which are planned to give you the opportunities to learn from your teachers. Standard practice for university teaching arrangements on law degree programmes is the use of large lectures, small group work in seminars or tutorials (mostly with tutors, sometimes led by students) and limited one to one sessions with your lecturers or tutors. \nSome students struggle to leave behind a teacher/pupil school mentality in both their \nexpectations of and relationships with teachers. The standard term for the university teacher is either lecturer or tutor. Some of your lecturers will be in charge of the modules they teach, having overall responsibility for their design, recommended reading and the construction of both assessments and the exam, if there is one. Often a module will have a teaching team of several lecturers, assisted by research students. Where a team of lecturers and tutors are involved the lecturer in charge of the module will consult them concerning assessment design etc. It is useful to be aware of these basics. \nWe will look at: \n  one to one learning opportunities with staff; \n  lectures; \n  seminars/tutorials. \n\n--- Page 145 ---\n   114 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nOne to one learning opportunities with staff \nThere are several types of one to one meeting you may have with lecturers or tutors: \n  personal tutor meetings; \n  a meeting with your subject lecturer or tutor pre-arranged by yourself or them; or \n  taking the opportunity to attend a ‘drop-in’ session during staff offce hours. \nWhatever the nature of the one to one session you need to go prepared, ensure you know \nwhat it is about in advance, listen in a focused manner during the meeting, remember what is said, make sense of it, note down important points and ensure you leave under -\nstanding what you need to do next. \nLecturer offce hours/drop-in hour \nMany lecturers/tutors have weekly offce hours on a ‘by-appointment’ or a drop-in basis when students can discuss issues surrounding their learning on the module. ‘By appoint -\nment’ means just that: prior to the offce hour you contact the lecturer/tutor using their preferred contact methods to arrange a meeting. \nThese offce hours are useful if you do not understand why you obtained a low grade \nfor assessment, or if you are having diffculties with any topic or sub-topic. Ensure you go to these one to one sessions knowing what your issues are. Make sure you prepare for your meeting and you have detailed questions – the time is limited, and working out what exactly you need help with can take a bit of time itself. \nIf you are discussing your assessment performance, you must re-read your work \nbefore you attend your session. Carefully re-read the question and consider the feedback given by your marker, linking it to your work and seeing if you understand what has been said. It is a waste of everyone’s time when a student arrives without bothering to engage in pre-thought and just says, ‘Why is my mark so low? I thought my essay was OK’. Lecturers will have marked hundreds of pieces of work, and although they may recall your grade band they will not necessarily recall their detailed feedback. Therefore it is always sensible to take a copy of your coursework and any feedback given to you. \nLectures \nLectures are delivered to facilitate student learning. However, they are not all uniform in their purpose. Some lectures are designed to inform you about the general framework of a large or smaller area of your module. Other lectures focus on specifc issues within a sub-topic of the overall module. The order in which lectures are delivered is carefully planned to give you the basic information you need to make sense of upcoming expected reading, seminar preparation and assessments. \nLectures can be thought of as a map of different areas, and are most defnitely a \nshortcut to understanding the basics. Note that we refer to the basics. No module can \n\n--- Page 146 ---\n    \n  GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 115 \nbe passed on lectures alone. You need to engage with the required reading and with \nseminars. If you choose not to attend, do not be surprised if this choice is refected in low assessment grades, and a continuing lack of understanding. \nYour active engagement with the lecture is vital. You may or may not wish to write \nlecture notes, but it is usually a good idea to note basics and then read more widely on the topic after the lecture. If PowerPoint slides are used, these can often be downloaded in advance and used for adding notes. \nSeminars/tutorials \nUsually, in addition to lectures, each module will have weekly or fortnightly tutor-led small groups, either called seminars or tutorials. Traditionally, there was a difference between the slightly larger and more structured seminars and the smaller tutorials, but most uni -\nversities use these terms interchangeably now. Typically, there will be between 20 and 30 students in a seminar. \nWhatever the nature of the small group work in your modules, pre-work will be involved \nand they will be led by a lecturer or tutor. At the end of all small group work, the tutor will draw your attention to any issues that should have been discussed and were omitted by you in your discussions. You are expected to take on board what is said in the small group and engage in any extra reading as you or the tutor consider necessary. It is a good idea to make sure that you leave each session with written notes relating to the correct approaches to the questions/tasks set. \nStudents often do not prepare at all or inadequately for these sessions, which is short -\nsighted as they take you deeper into the subject. You can test your understanding and check that you are on track in your views. So you will severely disadvantage yourself if you choose not to do the pre-set independent work. If you treat a seminar as a passive experience and expect the tutor to give you the required knowledge, you are not going to learn much from it. \nYour seminar management is an important part of your independent learning develop -\nment. If you neglect it, you will again fnd that your lack of understanding is refected in low assessment grades. At the end of a term, you will see that you remember a lot more from the discussions you were actively engaged in than from the content you passively consumed. \nWorking in groups with fellow students (formally and informally) \nThe development of interpersonal skills through team working is one of the essential skills of a competent graduate. But team working is often demanding and challenging. \nMany of you will have experienced some degree of team working prior to university, \nand it may have been a good or a bad experience. The fact is that success in life is very much down to your ability to engage at the appropriate time in competent interpersonal skills and to work as part of a team. In short, to get on with others, demonstrate you are \n\n--- Page 147 ---\n   116 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \na trustworthy team player, and demonstrate you can self-manage. These skills get you \nnoticed, and you can be judged accordingly. \nMany students working in teams or groups do not stop to consider the challenges \nof working with other people. They may feel angry (either passively or actively) or feel bullied, or they may themselves bully others. Notice that these are emotional issues. Emotions as well as lazy group members can demoralise other group members. Then the actual task they have to work on is de-prioritised whilst problems are resolved. It takes the development of good skills of listening and understanding, as well as appropriate levels of humility to respect the views of others. It takes self-discipline to prepare work for other students and to deal with those who are not pulling their weight. But if this is done you will learn to manage people effectively and allow them to think and develop, and this quality is highly regarded in employment (having lazy co-workers in your team is unfor -\ntunately not an issue limited to university). The quality of group work and discussion will then result in very good work. \nEFFECTIVE NOTE TAKING \nTaking notes \nMuch of your independent study time will involve note taking; it is one of the most impor -\ntant tasks you will engage in. Your note taking includes all of the written records that you have made of what you have heard and what you have read. \nThey are a major contributing factor to your learning, for you will use them to assimilate \nand integrate information, critique concepts from a range of sources and translate them into arguments for your formal written work. \nYou will take notes for many reasons, to: \n  Build up a body of materials that increases your knowledge. \n  Form the basis for constructing exam answers and written (or oral) assessments. \n  Help you express and understand concepts/ideas. \n  Store information in a classifed, ordered manner. \nYou will also take notes in different situations: \n  From your reading. \n  In lectures. \n  In seminars. \nIt is very easy to lose sight of appropriate length for notes and write far too much. A note \nis designed to quickly recall more information to your mind. You do not want to wade through a large pile of notes. It is also easy to write notes of irrelevant material if you do \n\n--- Page 148 ---\n    \n \n \n \n GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 117 \nnot apply your mind to the task at hand. Note taking, like reading, should be a dynamic \nand not a passive activity. \nCottrell9 suggests that asking the following questions can help you to decide what to note. \n  Do you really need this information? If so, which bits? \n  Will you really use it? When, and how? \n  Have you noted similar information already? \n  What questions do you want to answer with this information? \nYou also need to know how to use your notes by: \n  Interconnecting your notes from lectures, seminars, books and articles using a reli -\nable fling system. \n  Using your notes effectively in your written work. \nNote taking presents you with many challenges. You may fnd that:   You make notes from a lot of background reading, but are then stuck when it comes \nto using them for your written work. \n  You may feel overwhelmed in lectures; what do you note? Especially when every word seems factual and/or the lecturer is speaking too quickly for you to note. However, whilst in some schools teachers dictate notes, a lecturer is not dictating; they are speaking about the subject for you to note what you wish in view of handouts, read -\ning and visual aids used in the lecture theatre. \n  You read slowly and feel you cannot follow the sense of a text and write notes, and the notes you make are too detailed. As a consequence you fear that your note taking takes you far too long. \n  After you have made a great deal of notes for an assessment you do not know which words are yours and which you copied out of the text directly, and fnd you are strug -\ngling because you now do not know if the ideas in them are yours or another writer’s; this causes you to worry about falling into accidental plagiarism.  An easy way to avoid this is to give the title of the text and full reference as a header before you begin taking notes. Then make a note of any specifc page you are noting. If you quote verbatim from a text in your notes ensure you use quotation marks. If you are summarising a set of ideas again clearly note whose ideas they are and the page number where they can be located. By giving the full reference and title of every text you note, you also have the ability to quickly construct a sources list or bibliography for your writing. \n By noting specifc pages from the text in your notes it makes it easy to return to that place in the text maybe weeks later because your knowledge has increased and you now think that other information around that page could be important for your work. \n9 S Cottrell The Study Skills Handbook  (2nd edition, Palgrave Macmillan, Basingstoke, 2003), 126. \n\n--- Page 149 ---\n   \n \n \n \n 118 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nStrategies for note taking \nAlways approach note taking by being clear about your purpose for noting. This should \nbe easy enough for reading tasks if you are following a reading strategy and are reading for a purpose. Given your purpose when you fnd texts of relevance you need to briefy cover the core facts or arguments, and to do so briefy. Long notes are no use to you. \nYou do not have to write your notes; you could consider underlining and highlighting \nwords or phrases in your book that seem to be the core of the point being made. Only do this on your own books. If you do not want to write in your own books, you could record the main headings in the text and give a few keywords in your notes about each chapter. \nAs you are reading and noting it is normal for questions or thoughts about the text to \narise in your mind, and it is a good idea to record them in your notes. Your recorded good idea may be very useful for your later written work. Or they can prompt you to engage in more reading as follow up. \nIf it is possible write your notes on one side of paper only, and then you can add in \nmaterial covering the same area from other reading that you undertake later. When you have read a section it is a good idea to summarise it; the advice is to stop reading and take a few seconds to think about what you have just read and then summarise it in your own words, noting page numbers, and the author of any ideas. Then read back over the text to double-check you did not miss any important points. \nThe structure of notes \nYou want to see at a glance core points, summaries, references, headings and subhead -\nings, and leave space to add in more information as you read and refect on your develop -\ning understanding. \nThere are several ways that you can approach note taking and you need to be guided \nby the method(s) that suit you best, as the notes are for your beneft alone. You will soon learn the method you prefer. Some students fnd they use a variety of methods to suit the purpose of their note taking. We will look at the use of: \n  Linear text. \n  Diagrams. \n  Mind maps. \nLinear text \nThe majority of people use this method of writing notes. This involves writing notes in a \nsentence form or bullet point form in the order that you are reading the text. If you use this method it is a good idea to get into the habit of using abbreviations. These should be kept short however, or you will become lost in detail. \n\n--- Page 150 ---\n    \n  GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 119 \nstress     reading \nlibrary \nRESEARCH spell \nWORRY ! note s ENGLISH LANGUAGE SKILLS write \nSTUDY SKILL \nread \nLECTURES/SEMINARS \nLEARNING \nGO! \nconcentra\u000bon STUD Y \nFigure 5.2 Example spray diagram using the keyword ‘STUDY’ \nSpray diagrams \nThese operate on keywords that you have identifed in the text. The keyword is put in \nthe middle of the page and circled. Then you think of words that are connected to this keyword; these words could relate to concepts, facts, etc. They provide a way for you to think more extensively about smaller sections of text. \nFor an example we have taken the keyword ‘study’. As you can see the diagram is random and is only as good as your thoughts. You cer -\ntainly need to know why you are creating the diagram or the exercise is unhelpful. But you can then see simultaneously areas where there are a lot of links and those where there are few. In academic terms you could do this looking at your essay as a whole, noting gaps in your argument to support propositions. \nMind maps \nThese look at frst glance to be a spray diagram; however, there is a frmer patterning to the links, and they are more structured – see Figure 5 .3. \n\n--- Page 151 ---\n   \n \n \n  \n \n  120 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nMethod s to reduce stress  Reading strategies \nGood library skills \nEFFICIENT RESEARCH Grammar \nWORRY ! However, for verbal presentations such as lec -\ntures, speeches, seminars and videos, note taking presents different challenges. \nThe presentation you are listening to may be disorganised, which again creates dif -\nfculties for you. But even a well-organised presentation in a lecture requires you to engage in active listening skills (the note taking side of active reading skills). Active listening requires you to ask questions in your mind as you are listening and simultane -\nously noting. As you can imagine this skill of doing three things at once takes time to develop. \nStudents do ask lecturers to repeat points, but it is often not looked upon too kindly. \nUsually lecturers in the university use PowerPoint slides which are posted on the VLE before the lecture. It is a good idea to print these out using the three slide note taking option format in black and white to keep costs low. You can then write notes beside each \n\n--- Page 152 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 121 \nslide as they are presented in the lecture and discussed. Just record key points and if \nreferences are mentioned that are not on the slide, note them. Equally if information is on the slide do not repeat it in your note. \nAfter the lecture just make sure that you have an effcient method for highlighting fur -\nther reading, any tasks you have been asked to do and fle your notes. You might fnd that using different pens helps you identify areas you need to follow up for more information or where you need to spend time trying to understand the point made. Read (or just fick through) a book on the subject of the lecture. Look for themes, issues, topics and head -\nings. Lookup any technical words you don’t understand. \nQuestions arising in your mind as you write notes \nIf questions arise as you write notes put them in the notes either in another colour or on the back of the page of notes so that you can explore them more fully. If you do not write them down, you will forget them and they are key to your development. Any of the follow -\ning matters may arise in your mind: \n  an idea about a link to other issues; \n  wondering if an interpretation other than the one you have read is better; \n  a reference to follow up; \n  some limitations that you think what you are reading may have, but you need to \ncheck; \n  some questions that your reading is raising in your mind; \n  statistics that you need to look up. \nPERSONAL DEVELOPMENT PLANNING \nIn academic life, both at school and university as well as professional life, personal development plans, or PDPs, are of increasing importance. We have already referred above to goals. A PDP assists you to develop towards your goals in a more formal manner. At root it involves stopping to think about your learning and how you are devel -\noping in your studies, including your good achievements such as assessment marks and engaging in department or national competitions in law. It also involves planning your development at university and beyond from a personal, academic and career perspective. \nUsually, a part of your department’s VLE will be devoted to PDP and will guide you \nthrough the process. Building a PDP is a useful process because it allows you to develop focus. If you want to obtain a scholarship or to ensure a place at a good university for a master’s degree or PhD, or to have a good chance at a start in the professions, you will need a 2.1 or a First. Often you need to demonstrate achievements outside the academic \n\n--- Page 153 ---\n   122 GENERAL STUDY SKILLS \nbut related, such as relevant volunteering, internships or placements. So knowing this, \nit is not a good idea to miss lectures and seminars, attain low grades and be generally careless in your approach to studies. Nor is it a good idea to just do the basics and not seek placements, etc. \nPDP will help you to develop plans to develop independent learning, increase your \ngrades or engage in extra-curricular activity. As you engage with the process you will fnd you become increasingly aware of your strengths and weaknesses in all areas. You will realise what you can change and then seek to identify specifc skills sets that need development. Your tutors will be only too pleased to assist with your academic-related development. \nThe formal process of PDP encourages you to keep a note of your achievements, \nand these are useful references when you are constructing a CV for further study or employment. \nStudents who have engaged in PDP maintain it is extremely useful for keeping them \nfocused, and look at their learning preferences to understand why they have them and why it may be a good idea to try other learning styles. The more you engage in PDP in a fexible manner, the more you genuinely take over the management of your present and future, and take rather than miss opportunities. \nMany law degree programmes integrate PDP into your skills training, as well as pro -\nviding opportunities for work-based learning. All of these matters will be fagged by your department. If they are not then you can speak to the department’s legal careers adviser or failing that to the university careers department. \nCONCLUSION \nAll of the areas considered in detail in this chapter are of comparable importance because they all work together to make you a successful and competent learner. Do not be worried by them; just be aware of them and perhaps use the framework of PDP to indicate where you think you are in each skill, and plan what you need to do to develop. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  The student who takes control of their studies, considers their goals and how to achieve them and develops good habits of independent study will be able to realise their full potential. \n  It is essential to understand the cycles of academic life through the year, your own personal teaching and assessment timetable so that you can effectively plan. \n  Lectures, seminars/tutorials and one to one sessions with tutors are important to the development of your understanding. \n\n--- Page 154 ---\n    GENERAL STUDY SKILLS 123 \n  Studying involves the simultaneous use of a range of skills, self-management, devel -\nopment planning, reading/writing skills, IT skills, interpersonal skills and communica -\ntion skills. Each has an important place in achieving a good degree. \n  Awareness of learning and teaching styles, and recognising which you prefer, and \nthe purposes of each develops fexibility and allows you to be an effective learner. \n  Using personal development planning (PDP) will assist you in goal setting, self-awareness and in having a good resource to use for CVs for law school, training contracts, grants/scholarship applications and employment. \n\n--- Page 156 ---\n6 \n  \n FINDING MATERIAL \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Understand the structure and layout of the standard university library and the con -\ntext of the law library within it. \n  Understand the difference between primary and secondary sources of legal \ninformation. \n  Develop a competent approach to locating, accessing and searching electronic resources. \n  Develop strategies to ascertain the authority and validity of retrieved materials. \n  Locate domestic and European legislation and cases. \n  Develop search strategies for journal articles and books. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-8  \n\n--- Page 157 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 126 FINDING MATERIAL  \nINTRODUCTION \nDuring your studies, research will be one of the key aspects to success. Finding the right books, articles, laws, cases and many other sources will usually be the frst step for writ -\ning an essay, preparing a presentation or putting together the arguments you will need to win a moot court scenario. Later in life, this will continue – whether you become a solicitor or barrister and need to advise a client, whether you become a research student and need to fnd obscure sources in the British Library or whether you leave law altogether – fnd -\ning relevant information is always going to be central to every decision making process. \nAs a student, it is absolutely essential that you are familiar with the library provisions \nof your university and with the other resources available to you. This chapter will therefore frst of all discuss how you can make the most of the library available to you. \nUsing the library \nGetting started \nWalking into the university library can be a daunting experience. New students of all ages often report a feeling of inadequacy when frst confronted with the scenes of a typical library lobby. There are lots of people (all of whom seem to know what they are doing); there are issue desks, banks of computers, banks of photocopiers, unfamiliar signage, student study support staff and private study rooms. There may be coffee bars, and some may have imposing atriums built to a scale that dwarfs individual users; there are cloakrooms and rules about bags. Entrance to the library is often through security checks and the scanning of your library card. Some libraries have not taken on the dimensions of huge factory buildings or implemented security measures, but even these can feel extremely alien to the new student. \nLibrarians and lecturers do realise, however, that students need to be orientated to the \nlibrary and the structure of its resources so that they can use it competently. You will fnd that all libraries arrange a general induction to the layout and range of resources for new students. Additionally the law department, usually in liaison with library staff, will arrange for a series of specialist training sessions to introduce new law students to the print and electronic collections. Often there are opportunities for updates and more advanced train -\ning throughout the frst year and one to one assistance may be offered to students who lack confdence. It is important to be aware of what support and training is on offer in your library so that you can make the best use of it. Many libraries and departments also provide links to in-house and external online tutorials concerned with using the library. You should check for these in your university’s departmental, library, study support and induction web pages as well as on your department’s preferred virtual learning environment (VLE). \nNowadays, the information you can fnd in the big halls of the physical library only makes \nup a small part of the knowledge that is available to you. A wide range of information is \n\n--- Page 158 ---\n   \n \n  FINDING MATERIAL 127 \n2. \nThe university e-library \ncollec\ron: subscrip\ron \ncollec\rons and provided links \nto non-subscrip\ron sites that \naredeemed academically \nsound by the libraryand/or \nlecturer checked. Unfortunately, the world of online publishing is a big mess with different payment structures and subscription modes. It is therefore essential to learn what is and what is not available to your university and how to use the many different collections. \nIn addition to this, there is an enormous amount of information available on the internet \nin the public domain. This is fantastic because knowledge ought to be open and free, but it requires you to be extra careful when using sources – a lot of information on the internet is unreliable, biased or in some cases outright wrong. \n\n--- Page 159 ---\n 128 FINDING MATERIAL  \nThe library catalogue \nThe main library catalogue \nThis is the online catalogue of your library’s print and e-library resources which you can \nsearch by author name, title of book, or the subject area you are interested in. You can also search this catalogue from any PC, laptop or mobile phone (via the browser or in some cases with a dedicated app). In most cases, the library catalogue not only points you to physical books available on the shelf but will also give you access to online resources. \nEach print resource is allocated a ‘classifcation number’ or a ‘class mark’ and these \nnumbers or marks are grouped in subject clusters and sub-groups of subjects. Libraries tend to have signs and leafets that map the area of the law print collection, indicating which part of the building you need to go to for particular subjects. Once you have a clas -\nsifcation number or class mark, and a diagram of the library showing the location of the law resources, you will be able to go to the correct area and locate your specifc resource. \nThe classifcation number is located by searching the main online library catalogue. \nMany libraries, but not all, have banks of computers around the library and in the recep -\ntion area, which you can use to access the catalogue. \nYou will also fnd access to the cataloguing system of the e-library. Often you can \nlocate these in a number of ways by scrolling down a menu of the various resources and databases, or using a quick search to locate a particular database, or journal, or gate -\nway in alphabetic order. For example, if you are in the databases areas and click on ‘fnd databases’ you will get an alpha bar. If you wanted to locate Westlaw, clicking on ‘W’ will bring up all the databases starting with W and you can choose Westlaw. All university e-library and print collections are not exact replicas of each other. There will be deviations from the standard. Do make use of library guides which are usually free in the library or available online. \nPrinted material \nPrinted material comes in all forms and sizes, and it is useful to have a general idea about the different areas in your library. Some university libraries will have a separate section for books on ‘short loan’ – often textbooks and other core reading materials that can only be borrowed for a few days or that sometimes can only be used in the library. \nThe different types of printed material that you can fnd in a law library can usually be \nclassifed as follows: \n  Reference texts, digests, encyclopaedias, indexes, dictionaries. \n  Thin resources (pamphlets). \n  Parliamentary papers. \n  Journals (academic and professional). \n  Law reports. \n\n--- Page 160 ---\n   \n FINDING MATERIAL 129 \n  Legislation. \n  Books about the law (textbooks, scholarly or research works). \nThe nature of each of the above print resources will be briefy described and examples of \nleading publications in the areas of reference and primary law will be given. \nReference \nThere are always some books that tend to be abnormally large. These are usually refer -\nence books and it is standard practice for them to be placed together in a reference section of the main library, as it is recognised they only tend to be dipped into for lim -\nited and highly specifc information. You need to fnd out where they are, whether they are in the law area, in the general reference section or divided between the two areas. Examples of reference books include dictionaries, encyclopaedias, digests, indexes and bibliographies. \nThe sets of reference texts that are the most authoritative source of law are Halsbury’s , \nwhich include the following publications, and are also available online: \n  Halsbury’s Laws of England and Wales : frst published in 1907 to give a full statement \nof all of the laws of England and Wales, case law, legislation and now, more recently, \nEuropean law. It uses an alphabetic system to track law composed of several com -\nplementary cross-referenced publications. It has main volumes (organised by sub -\nject and re-published around every 20 years), a table of contents and a consolidated index published yearly, which will either reference the main volumes or the cumula -\ntive supplement. The cumulative supplement is published yearly to update the main volumes. Additionally, monthly digests give updates to allow a subject search for the appropriate volume. As it is concerned with individual laws classifed by subject one statute could be divided up among several volumes as often different law concerning different subjects can be contained in the one statute. \n  Halsbury’s Statutes of England and Wales : frst published in 1929 it is considered to \nbe the most authoritative source for primary and secondary legislation in England and Wales. It also refers to cases affecting or prompting legislation. The schema used is the same as for the laws, main volumes, tables of contents, indexes, cumula -\ntive supplements and monthly digests. Volumes are published when it is considered necessary. \nThin resources (pamphlets) \nThere are also some print resources that are very thin (pamphlets) and these will tend to be stored together generally in the main library, with law-related ones placed in the law library if it is in a separate area. \n\n--- Page 161 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n 130 FINDING MATERIAL  \nParliamentary papers \nThere is a vast array of materials generated by Parliament, including verbatim reports of \nproceedings of the two Houses of Parliament, details of committee meetings, reports and material produced by government departments (reports, statistics, recommendations and policy reviews). Not all libraries will keep a print collection of parliamentary papers.\n1 They \nare useful for research purposes as secondary texts that shed light on the reasons for leg -\nislation, and for changes to bills as they go through the parliamentary law making process. \nJournals \nJournals are collections of articles about the law published throughout the year. Academic journals (also called periodicals) are written by academics and are an important resource for the development of your understanding of law and are vital for competent perfor -\nmance in seminars and assessed work. \nThere are also a range of professional journals that are written by practising lawyers \nand intended for the profession. These can be of use as long as you remember they are not academic but professional. \nJournals are published two, three or four times a year, with some professional journals \nbeing published more frequently. Because of their publication throughout the year jour -\nnals contain the most up to date information and analysis. \nThe law journals may be grouped together in the law library; however, some libraries \ndo like to keep all their periodicals together in one place regardless of discipline and here science rubs shoulders with art. It is important to be aware that many disciplines in their own specialist journals contain professional and academic articles about the law and you are therefore likely to fnd relevant articles about law in other disciplines such as psychol -\nogy, sociology, anthropology, medicine, politics or history. \nIt is increasingly common for journals to be read online, with all the advantages that \nbrings (easy access, full-text search, etc.). Many newer journals, particularly open access journals, do not even publish printed editions any more. \nLaw reports \nThese are the primary texts of law reports of important cases decided by senior judges in the courts. They are published in several series by private publishers, but the most respected collection is published by a charity, the Incorporated Council of Law Reporters. The courts have established a hierarchy of law reports by publisher and the Incorporated Council of Law Reporting (ICLR) are at the top. Law reports are usually stored in the law library area and are classifed within a particular law report series by year date, although there can be other ways of referencing such as by volume number. \nLegislation \nLegislation enacted by Parliament constitutes a primary text of law. It is divided into collections of primary and secondary legislation by a range of publishers and as noted \n1 T he most extensive collection is housed in the London School of Economics and Political Science Library. \n\n--- Page 162 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n FINDING MATERIAL 131 \nabove, the most authoritative is Halsbury’s Statutes  which is mainly a reference text. We \nwill consider reading and understanding legislation in detail in Chapter 7 . \nBooks \nThese secondary texts tend to be organised by topics and sub-topics, for example, crimi -\nnal law or the law of contract. It is worth remembering that the date of publication of a \nbook is likely to be 6–24 months after the completion of the manuscript of the book, due to the time needed for the publication process. This means that the law described in books may be out of date. You must always check the publication date of the book, and you should double-check the status of the law to be careful. Also, as with journals, it is important to be aware that many other disciplines interact with the law and you are therefore likely to fnd relevant books in other subject areas. \nElectronic material \nMore and more material is being hosted online, and you will fnd that even in the library building most research you do will be through electronic sources. The competent location and search of the range of electronic materials is therefore an essential skill for the law student. You need to learn how to navigate vast reservoirs of electronic resources in the e-library, which will include subscription sites used by the university as well as links to free sites considered to be useful.\n2 \nInitially you may fnd the array of internet sources overwhelming. But in fact they can \nbe reduced to a few overarching categories within which you can research. These will be set out below. Electronic resources mirror in many ways the materials contained in print collections. The best electronic materials are developed by commercial organisations, with annual subscription fees. However, there is a wide range of additional databases and internet gateways that open a huge array of electronic resources. \nAn internet gateway, which can be referred to as a portal, is a single website that \ncollects together a range of internet links on related topics. Search engines are power -\nful tools that have indexed a large number of web pages, and allow you to retrieve data through simple keyword searches. Some gateways and databases are free, whilst others are commercial and require username and password information. Many will be acces -\nsible through the electronic library of your institution, which will invest a surprisingly large amount of money into online subscriptions. \nAccessing the e-library collection \nWhen you sign in to the main library catalogue, click on the icon for the e-library and you will be taken into the sources. Your library will often group access by subject. You can therefore click on ‘law’ and be sent to another listing of sources. Some of these will be subscription sites and some free sites. There will be different access con -\nventions for each of the electronic materials. The majority require an internationally \n2 A s already noted, the invention of printing was revolutionary in the spread of knowledge; a revolutionary \ninnovation of similar dimensions has occurred through the electronic communication of knowledge. \n\n--- Page 163 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  132 FINDING MATERIAL  \nrecognised login and password, referred to as an Athens password. Today, most uni -\nversity library students’ login and password details are also automatically accred -\nited as Athens logins and passwords. At induction you will be told your own library’s \nconventions. \nWhen you have your library access sorted out, take time to explore the e-library at \nyour leisure. It will not be time wasted as you need to acquire the skills to access a range of databases quickly and easily in order to locate materials for seminar and assessment purposes. You would not just walk into a large university library and wander around until you accidentally found the law section and then luckily stumble across a relevant law book. You would locate the catalogue and engage in a methodical search. Many students approaching a database, however, do the equivalent of just aimlessly wandering around. If they do not haphazardly locate any sources from inadequate searches they erroneously conclude no such sources exist. Map the terrain of the electronic sources as well as you would the library print collection. Your lecturers will be only too pleased to guide you generally, as will library staff. \nTypes of electronic material and their standard locations \nThe same types of material available in the print collection are available through elec -\ntronic sources in the e-library, but, with the exception of books, there are also many more materials available in electronic form. These will be discussed below. \nThe resources on the internet include nearly all of those that we have listed above for \nprint collections, but the following additional resources are available: \n  Reference (most notably Halsbury online via Butterworths LexisNexis). \n  UK parliamentary papers from www.parliament.uk , as well as individual government \ndepartments. \n  Journals (academic and professional). \n  Law reports. \n  Legislation. \n  Books about the law (textbooks, scholarly or research works). \n  Blogs by noted academics and practitioners. \n  Websites of pressure groups (e.g. Amnesty International). \n  Websites containing articles and lectures by noted academics. \n  Media sites containing news reports and much more. \n\n--- Page 164 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n  \n  \n \n \n  \n  FINDING MATERIAL 133 \nSelec˙on of \ntypes of \nresource s \non the \ninternet Journal \nar\u0017cles \nGovernment \ndepartment s \nSpeeches, \nlectures, \ninterviews \nEuropa \nOfficial EU \nsite \nLaw reports \nTexts of Law Legisla\u0017on \nTexts of Law Parliamentary \npapers Blogs by \nacademics, \npressure \ngroups \nFigure 6.2 A selection of legal resources available on the internet \nYour librarian \nOne of the most painfully underused resources is your librarian. Many universities have dedicated law librarians, others will have librarians responsible for certain subjects. In any case librarians are a treasure trove of information! The old stereotype of the grumpy loner reading dusty old books and telling you to be quiet could not be further from the truth (although you will soon appreciate the librarian telling others to be quiet when you are revis -\ning for the exam and fellow students seem to treat the reading room as a social space): librarians are experts in locating information and in exploring new ways of learning, and they are often among the most helpful people you can encounter as a student. \nOften, the librarian gets introduced to you during the university induction process or \nin your frst weeks, whilst you are still overwhelmed with a food of information and ques -\ntions: what is my timetable? What is plagiarism? Which modules do I need to study? Will I fnd friends? Where can I get lunch?
