Make sure you take some time to go through these before starting your frst essay. As mentioned before, librarians are very helpful people and they know the problems that students face when it comes to research. \nIf you are struggling with a complex problem and you cannot fnd the answer on the \nlibrary website, most librarians are very happy to talk to you directly. Make sure to check the resources already available before the meeting, and come prepared with clear ques -\ntions – that way, you can make the most of the librarian’s and of your own time. \nHow to fnd legislation \nHow to locate domestic legislation \nThere are a number of different types of primary legislation, as discussed in detail in Chapter 1 . However, this chapter will only refer to the location of the main form of primary \n\n--- Page 166 ---\n   \n FINDING MATERIAL 135 \nlegislation, Public General Acts; and to the main form of secondary legislation, statutory \ninstruments. We will consider how to fnd print and online primary legislation frst and then print and online secondary legislation. Once you have understood the methodology you will be able to transfer that knowledge if you wish to fnd other primary or secondary legislation. \nThere are many print and online resources that enable you to fnd out if there is a \nPublic General Act (a statute) covering a particular subject or to locate a statute by name, or to locate a statutory instrument. \nIt is important, however, that you know how to fnd the up to date version of any stat -\nute. Often the resources will only have the full text of the statute as originally published. Many sources only give summaries of the legislation. This can be useful but must never be confused with the up to date full-text version of the legislation. So you need to become familiar with what each print and online version can offer. \nBefore we consider the available print and online resources it is important to look at \nthe terminology used when referring to primary and secondary legislation, as it can be confusing. We will then consider issues of the citation of legislation which is key to under -\nstanding how it is catalogued and stored. \nTerminology \nSimilar words and phrases meaning legislation tend to be used interchangeably in text -\nbooks, lectures, seminars and the media. Many of these are synonyms (words meaning the same thing). Additionally, certain phrases about legislation are also used that may be unfamiliar, for example ‘date in force’. Therefore it is a good idea to start with some basic defnitions of terms you will come across. \nPrimary legislation \nThe following words are used interchangeably and all mean the same thing – primary legislation: \n  Legislation. \n  Act of Parliament. \n  Act. \n  Legislative Act. \n  Statute (which means a decree). \nTypes of primary legislation \n  A Public General Act. \n  A private Act. \n  A private member’s Act. \n  A hybrid Act. \n  Orders in Council. \n\n--- Page 167 ---\n 136 FINDING MATERIAL  \nSecondary legislation \nThe following words have the same meaning as secondary legislation: \n  Delegated legislation. \n  Subordinate legislation. \nTypes of secondary legislation \n  Bylaws. \n  Orders by Council (the Privy Council). \n  Statutory instruments. \n  Court Rules Committees. \nYear of enactment \nThis is the date that the Act received Royal Assent and was placed in the statute book. \nDate in force \nThe date in force is the date that either the entire primary or secondary legislation comes \ninto force as law, or parts or a part of it comes into force. A major issue when engaged in the task of considering the meaning and application of legislation is whether specifc legal rules contained in the legislation are currently in force as law. When you are engaged in research it is essential to know if the law you have retrieved is the most up to date ver -\nsion. Amendments may have been made, or the entire statute repealed or repealed and its provisions partly placed in other legislation. Changes can occur by: \n  Parliamentary authority, through primary legislation amending it (adding to or sub -\ntracting from it) or by repeal (abolishing it). \n  Others exercising their rights to make changes by secondary legislation to a primary \nAct. \n  The Supreme Court or the Court of Appeal determining the meaning of words and phrases in the legislation. Although English courts have no power to amend or abol -\nish legislation, their power to interpret legislation can have a major impact on its application. \nHow to understand citations for domestic legislation \nIt is essential that you understand the way in which the legislation you are locating is cited. \nCitation of primary legislation: Public General Acts \nEvery statute has a long title and usually a short title. The short title if there is one is stated in one of the sections within the statute itself. For example, the Human Rights Act 1998, \n\n--- Page 168 ---\n   FINDING MATERIAL 137 \ns 22(1) states ‘This Act may be cited as the Human Rights Act’. It is the short title that is \nused for citation purposes. Since 1963 the statute is cited with the year of enactment of the legislation. Please make sure you understand that the year of enactment, however, is not the same as the date in force. \nEvery statute also has its own number in the year identifying it chronologically. This is \nits ‘chapter’ number in the ‘statute’ book for the relevant year. The Human Rights Act was the 42nd Act of 1998 and its chapter number is therefore 42. The number is preceded by a lower case ‘c’ to indicate chapter. \nThe order of the full citation for an Act is (e.g. Human Rights Act 1998 c42): \n  Short title: The Human Rights Act. \n  Year: 1998. \n  Chapter: c. \n  Chapter number: 42. \ne.g. Human Rights Act 1998 c42 \nPrior to 1963 statutes were not cited by the chronological year, but by their number in \nthe years of reign of the monarch at the time of the Act (called the regnal year). The chap -\nter number was still used with regnal years. A regnal year starts from the date of the mon -\narch’s accession to the throne. But there is a little complication as parliamentary years run from autumn to summer, so it may be possible for there to have been two Parliaments in one regnal year depending on when in the year the monarch succeeded. Then both years need to be referred to. The order of the full statutory citation for regnal years was: \n  Short title. \n  Regnal year(s). \n  Monarch abbreviated. \n  Chapter number. \nCitation of secondary legislation: statutory instruments \nStatutory instruments are the largest grouping of secondary legislation. They are cited \nby their name, followed by the date and then the abbreviation SI, the year they were made, and the date is repeated followed by a slash and the noting of the serial number, for example: \nThe Export Control (Russia, Crimea and Sevastopol Sanctions) (Amendment) Order 2014, SI 2014/2932 \nLike chapter numbers, the serial number is consecutive, indicating its order in the SIs for the relevant year. The citation given to the SI by Parliament is used in print copies and online versions of the legislation. \n\n--- Page 169 ---\n \n \n  \n  \n \n \n               \n                                         \n  138 FINDING MATERIAL  \nHow to locate statutes in print form in the university library \nThere are a number of hard copy reference texts that allow you to locate statutes by their \nname or by topic. Sometimes you will want to fnd out if there has been any legislation on a certain topic, rather than looking for a specifc statute and we will show you how to do this. Usually any reference text you access to locate legislation will have a linked series of publications that cross-reference each other. Usually you will be able to search through subjects and sub-topics to locate lists of statutes by name, or you can search by name. Each entry will direct you to the location of the full text. \nSince you are likely to use online resources rather than print copies, not all ways of \nresearch are listed here. \nChronological table of statutes \nThese tables are printed by The Stationery Offce (TSO). The Stationery Offce was cre -\nated when Her Majesty’s Stationery Offce (HMSO) was privatised in 1996. The TSO prints most UK public documentation, including Hansard,\n3 and have partnered with the \nNational Archives to produce the offcial online database for UK legislation, www.legisla -\ntion.gov.uk . \nThe chronological table details all statutes since 1235 by year and chapter number. \nThere is also a chronological table of statutory instruments (which is also online). The tables are a fascinating and essential place for historical research. \nA drawback with the table is that it is always several years out of date. The table indi -\ncates when statutes have been changed in any way. It uses standard abbreviations to indicate whether a statute has been applied (appl) amended (am), or repealed (rep). Any statute in the list that is in italics is either not in force or only partially in force. \nHalsbury’s Statutes \nWhilst Halsbury’s  gives the full text of statutes with amendments and repeals, it is also a \nsummary reference text detailing relevant debates in Hansard, explanatory notes with the bill, and cases applying the legislation and interpreting it. \nThe hard copy version is divided into law reports and statutes. It has a cumulative \ndigest of legal rules and an index. \nHalsbury’s Statutes of England  identifes legislation that has been corrected and/or \nrepealed. Halsbury’s Statutory Instruments  gives a classifcation of statutes ‘in force’, as \nwell as giving the text of a selection of rules, orders and regulations. \nHalsbury’s Statutes  is divided into a series of volumes and updates as follows: \nThe main volumes: these contain the full text of statutes organised by topic and anno -\ntated with changes incorporated into the text. There is a table of contents listing all Acts and also a subject index. \n3 H ansard among other things publishes edited records of debates in Parliament (edited because repeti -\ntions and mistakes are taken out of the record). It is published daily: www.parliament.uk/business/pub \nlications/hansard/commons/ or www.parliament.uk/business/publications/hansard/commons/lords and \ndebates from 1803 can be accessed online at Historic Hansard ( http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/). \n\n--- Page 170 ---\n   FINDING MATERIAL 139 \nCurrent Statutes service: six loose-leaf volumes are published each year, updating the \nmain volumes with Acts passed since their publication. \nThe cumulative supplement: this summarises the effect of new legislation on the legisla -\ntion in the main volumes, so it updates previous volumes with references to repeals \nand amendments of case references. Each Act is updated until the end of the year previous to the date of publication of the supplement. \nThe noter-up service: this gives information concerning changes to the legislation in the \nmain volumes and the Current Statutes service since the publication of the cumula -\ntive supplement. \nConsolidated index: this is the annual index of the main volume and the Current Statutes \nservice, which also contains an alphabetical list of statutes (the table of statutes). A search by name of Act will retrieve a number in bold (the volume number) followed by the page number. The abbreviation ‘(S)’ indicates that the Act is in the Current Statutes service. It is useful as it has alphabetical, chronological and subject indexes to the legislation. \nDestination tables \nUse this to track provisions of consolidating legislation back to earlier provisions. \nIf you know the name of the Act, search for it in the consolidated index in the alpha -\nbetical list of statutes. You will fnd the statute followed by a number in bold and then a second number. The bold number is the volume number and the second number is the page reference in the volume. One diffculty with Halsbury’s  is that the main volumes are \narranged by subject matter. As statutes tend to deal with a range of subjects, one statute may appear in many different sections of Halsbury’s . You will not fnd the full text of the \nstatute. When you have all of the information you wish you will need to check that it is still ‘in force’ or if it is a very new statute if all of it or only part of it is ‘in force’. This facility only goes back to 1961 so you would need to consult another source for pre-1961 statutes. The noter-up will update ‘in force’ changes. \nHow to use Halsbury’s Statutes \nThe way in which Halsbury’s Statutes  is organised means that you need to consult not \nonly the main volumes but the cumulative supplement and the ‘noter-up’ to check the most up to date position of the legislation you are concerned with. A good method to use to locate a specifc Act is as follows: \n  To fnd out which volume has the full text of the Act you need to look at the Table of \nStatutes and Consolidated Index, which gives you the volume number of the statute in bold, as well as the page number, or if it predates the main volumes you are given the reference (S) after the volume number so that you know to consult the Current Statutes Service. \n\n--- Page 171 ---\n \n \n \n  \n    \n  \n   \n  140 FINDING MATERIAL  \n  When you locate the main volume you will fnd the full text of the statute with the text of \namendments in square brackets. You will be alerted to the removal of text by three dots … (ellipses). Footnotes give you more details about interpretation, relevant cases, etc. \n  To ensure you have up to date legislation check the ‘cumulative supplement’ for any updating. You will note that it is subdivided into 50 so you can access the exact volume number that you want and you can then scan it for the page number. If you cannot fnd any entry, this means that you can be certain that up until the date of the supplement there have not been any changes. \n  Then to be absolutely sure check the noter-up, which contains information after the publication for the cumulative supplement, which is divided in the same way as the supplement. \nHow to locate statutes online \nThe easiest way to access legislation online is through your university’s e-library search facility. As already noted many university libraries are moving away from print to e-copy in relation to primary legal material. There is a vast array of online access both subscription-based and in the public domain (free). Subscription databases tend to offer useful search -\nable extras in addition to the full text of the legislation. For example, you can search for cases dealing with your legislation, as well as locate journal articles or e-books discuss -\ning the legislation. \nThe main subscription sites \n  Westlaw: published by Sweet and Maxwell www.westlaw.com containing UK, Irish, EU legislation, a large range of academic and professional journals. \n  LexisNexis: published by Butterworths  www.lexisnexis.co.uk  covers UK legislation \nand also provides Halsbury’s Statutes  online. \n  Justis: www.justis.com containing a growing collection of UK, Irish and EU case \nreports. UK case records go back to the earliest year books in 1163 and it refers to legislation from 1235. \nPublic domain sites \nBy far the largest set of free resources can be found in the public domain, but these do vary in reliability from site to site. The following sites are more reliable and include legis -\nlation made available by government and Parliament. They will all have differing cut-off dates for the start of the collections and will vary in the information on offer. \n  Offcial government site for all UK legislation: www.legislation.gov.uk . \n  British and Irish Legal Information Institute (BAILII): http://www.bailii.org contains \nBritish and Irish legislation. It takes its statutory data from the Offce of Public Sector Information (OPSI) and is a free searchable site. \n\n--- Page 172 ---\n   \n   \n  \n      \n \n  \n \n \n    \n \n  FINDING MATERIAL 141 \n  Offce of Public Sector Information: www.opsi.gov.uk . This site contains the full text \nof Public General Acts, since 1988, and local Acts, since 1991, and reproduces the \nstatute in the form in which it was originally enacted. It contains statutory instruments going back to 1987. This site does its utmost to get a copy of a statute online within a day of its publication. \n  Parliament: www.parliament.uk . Here you can locate current legislation. \nEach site will have its own particular navigation. Which sites you access and what you understand about the site will determine whether you retrieve the most up to date legislation. \nLocating Legislation on legislation.gov.uk \nProbably the most useful site when it comes to legislation is the offcial one: legislation .gov.uk. It is very easy to use and gives you a very clear overview of everything that is relevant when looking at law – primary or secondary. \nIf you know the name of the legislation you are looking for, you can type it into the \nsearch box at the top of the homepage, and you will be presented with the search results. You can also fnd it by typing in parts of the title (e.g. the search results for ‘human rights’ will include the Human Rights Act 1998). The ‘type’ drop-down menu on the right gives you the opportunity to be more specifc whether you are looking for a UK Public General Act or other forms of primary and secondary legislation. There is also an ‘Advanced search’ option, which allows you to search, for example, for all laws that contain the word ‘race’ and were passed between 1995 and 2005. \nOnce you have found a piece of legislation, the website will show you the table of con -\ntents of the latest updated version. When looking at the different sections, you can see the different versions presented in a timeline. Try, for example, to fnd the Immigration, Nationality and Asylum Act 2006 and have a browse through the different sections – you will see that some of these have been changed twice or more, some have been untouched, some have been added later and so on. You can click on the points in the timeline to see what this section of the Act looked like in 2014 or in 2006. This can be very useful information when you are critically analysing a law or researching older cases. \nHow to locate draft primary and secondary legislation \nThere will be times in your studies when it is useful to be able to locate the bills currently going through Parliament. A bill is the draft form of an Act and it can change consider -\nably as it goes through the Houses of Parliament. Or you may wish to locate former versions of bills (draft bills). The offcial online site www.legislation.gov.uk does not keep \nrecords of draft primary legislation, although it does have the full-text draft secondary legislation. \nExtensive information on draft primary legislation can be located on the UK parliamen -\ntary website, www.parliament.uk . Here you can also look at draft bills, which are copies \n\n--- Page 173 ---\n \n   \n   \n \n   142 FINDING MATERIAL  \nof bills before  they have been formally introduced in Parliament and have begun their way \nthrough the procedures for enactment. You can also fnd out where any bill is in its pas -\nsage through Parliament. \nThe best place to fnd these is Parliament’s own website. Having accessed the site, \nnavigate to primary legislation and then to bills. Icons denote whether a particular bill has \nits introduction pending, and whether it is currently in the House of Commons or House of Lords. If you click on any bill in your retrieved list you will be told where it is in its passage through the house and what the next stage is. You will be shown a general diagram of the full procedures of a bill with the current stage of the bill you are considering highlighted in black. When shown online, the procedures in the House of Commons box are green and those in the House of Lords are in red, with the amendments stage showing as an ‘A’ in a half green and half red circle. \nEuropean treaties and secondary legislation \nEU primary law is located in EU treaties and protocols; secondary law is derived from the law making of the EU’s institutions, the main forms being regulations, directives and opinions. \nSince 1 July 2013 print formats of EU law in all but a few cases do not constitute an \nauthentic, offcial copy of the law; the only offcial copy is the online version. If you are studying EU law, it makes sense to get yourself a statute book (such as Blackstone’s ). The \nstatutes that you will need are usually changing at a much slower pace than the domestic ones \nEUR-Lex is the major resource for EU law. The EU site, EUR-Lex: www.eur-lex.europa , \ncontains information and the full text of all EU law. It is also the host for the offcial jour -\nnal of the EU. Similar to legislation.gov.uk, EUR-Lex allows you to search for treaties as well as secondary legislation and preparatory Acts. If you know what you are looking for you can use the quick search box at the bottom of the front page; otherwise, the ‘Advanced search’ is very useful. Additionally you can use the tab ‘national’ to retrieve all the national law of all member states relating to the implementation of treaties and secondary legislation. \nLocating the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and its protocols \nWhen you are researching the ECHR (and any other treaty) you must ensure that you have up to date knowledge of treaties/protocols, their signature and whether all or only some signatory states ratifed them. It is not enough just to check derogations and reservations from the original treaties, and later treaties, whether new or accession. \nWith regard to the Council of Europe (CoE) you can locate this treaty and its subse -\nquent protocols on the Council of Europe Treaty Offce website: www.conventions.coe .int. \n\n--- Page 174 ---\n   \n \n \n FINDING MATERIAL 143 \nHow to fnd cases \nLocating cases in the English legal system \nRecords of law cases are produced in various ways, and not all are available outside the \narchives of the courts. Since 2000 many courts have made their verbatim transcript of the judgment in cases freely available online via the relevant court’s website. Additionally charitable and commercial companies publish general and specialist series of reports of important cases. The reports vary in the information given. Some will give a summary of the case and/or include the arguments of the barristers for the parties as well as the full text of the judgments. They usually list cases referred to in the judgments, noting whether a case has been distinguished or applied. Keywords or catchwords may also be provided, noting the main issues the case is concerned with. These reports are in print series and/or online and often found in both formats. \nYour university library will provide you with access to a wide range of these reports \nboth in print formats and online through the e-library. \nTerminology \nThe words or phrases ‘law cases’, ‘case law’, ‘cases’, ‘legal authority’, ‘authority’, ‘law reports’, ‘court transcripts’ or just ‘transcript’ are often used interchangeably in textbooks, lectures, seminars and in the media. However, they each have a different and precise mean -\ning. Therefore it is a good idea to start with some basic defnitions so that you are at least aware of the technically correct meaning of key words and phrases. Table 6 .1 sets these out. \nThe development of law reporting in the English legal system \nThe English legal system is a common law legal system with a relatively strict adherence to the doctrine of precedent, which states that judges in court must follow the decisions of the senior judiciary in the higher courts when determining cases before them.\n4 As we \nonly know what judges say because of the written reports of proceedings it is essential to have a system of accurate reporting of legal cases. If you cannot trust the reporting upon which the precedent is based, then you cannot trust the law. \nSurprisingly, there are no offcial series of law reports in England to equate with the \nQueen’s Printer’s copy of an Act of Parliament. The Stationery Offce is responsible for publishing revenue, immigration and social security law cases. However, traditionally, law reports remain in the hands of private publishers. It is a long-established but conventional rule that a law report, if it is to be accepted by the relevant court as a legal authority, must have been prepared by, and published under, the name of a fully qualifed barrister. \nBecause the publishers of law reports are private organisations, each publisher will \ntend to structure their reports differently, perhaps adding footnotes or summaries, per -\nhaps including or excluding the arguments put by counsel. However, what remains con -\nstant across all reports is that words attributed to the judge in his or her judgment have to \n4 S ee Chapter 2 for more detail on the operation of the doctrine of precedent. \n\n--- Page 175 ---\n \n  \n \n     \n \n \n   \n                                       \n            \n   144 FINDING MATERIAL  \nTABLE 6.1 TECHNICAL MEANING OF KEY WORDS/PHRASES USED IN \nRELATION TO COURT CASES AND THEIR REPORTING \nTerm Explanation \nLaw case A law case refers to a court hearing of a legal dispute. This can be a trial, in \nwhich case it is the frst time that the legal dispute has been heard in court. The correct terminology is to call this a ‘frst instance’ hearing. Or a court hearing can be an appeal against the trial outcome, the award of damages in a civil case, or against the outcome of a previous appeal. \nCourt A court transcript is the verbatim written record of the judgments delivered in \ntranscripts court compiled by an employee of the court, the court stenographer, although digital technology is increasingly being used in the courts. The transcript is archived by the court. Many English courts make their transcripts freely available online, and these can be accessed through Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk. Additionally many subscription databases which publish law reports also publish the transcript alongside the law report as a pdf. \nCase law This is the term used to refer to law cases in which there has been the creation of, or amendment to, a common law rule by senior judges in their judgments in the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court. When a law case creates or extends a legal rule it creates a legal precedent, and becomes a legal authority.\na \nLegal A law case that, in its written form (which can be a court transcript or a \nauthority privately published report) creates a precedent that can be used in legal argument, and can bind a court in the hierarchy of courts (they must abide by the legal rule created in the law case).\nb \nLaw report A law report is a written record of a law case produced by a private law report publisher. There are no offcial English legal system law reports. Law publishers will publish a case when it is considered that it establishes a precedent, or it resolves an uncertainty in law. Some law reports are considered more reliable than others and the courts have acknowledged, through practice directions, a hierarchy of private law reports with the Law Reports  series by the Incorporated Council of Law Reporting (ICLR) at the top. \naHansard among other things publishes edited records of debates in Parliament (edited because repetitions and mistakes are taken out of the record). It is published daily: www.p arliament.uk/business/publications/hansard/commons/ or www.parliament.uk/business/pub \nlications/hansard/commons/lords and debates from 1803 can be accessed online at Historic \nHansard (http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/). \nbIn Chapter 2 . \nremain a true and accurate record of the words that were actually spoken by the judge. As \nthe editors of each series of law reports can choose which cases to publish, some cases can appear in more than one law report series. \nParties to a legal dispute being heard in court have to accept the decision of the \ncourt at the time it is given. This is the court’s determination of the decision between the \n\n--- Page 176 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n FINDING MATERIAL 145 \nparties. The detail of any precedent developing from the case is noted after the case has been reported and more widely read and discussed. Editors of law report collections, academics and judges may all publish articles and commentaries on a particular case. But it is only in the reasoning of judges in later cases in the senior courts that the prec -\nedent value of a law case can be tested, and affrmed or distinguished. \nWhilst the competent production of reliable law cases is indispensable to the opera -\ntion of the doctrine of precedent, such law reports have actually only been available in England since 1865, but the reference to the use of the doctrine of precedent has been made for hundreds of years.\n5 \nThere were law reports before 1865, but they are not considered completely reliable. \nThere are a range of fragmentary law reports covering the period 1272–1535 known as Yearbooks. The Yearbooks begin with Edmund Plowden’s Commentaries, but it was not until the eighteenth century that three law reporters, Burrow, Cowper and Douglas, began to work towards standardising how the reports appeared. \nTowards the end of the eighteenth century, judges got involved in the appointment of \nreporters to the courts and either reviewed reports of their judgments or made written ver -\nsions of their judgments available to the reporters. The Yearbooks were handwritten for hun -\ndreds of years in legal French, with some being printed from the ffteenth century onwards. \nHowever, it is not always possible to discover if the report in the Yearbook is of an actual \ncase or a moot (a fctional legal argument staged as a competition between lawyers). The detail given in these reports varies. Some reports record outcome but not facts; others record facts and outcome but give no reasoning process. Quite often no judgment is recorded, only the pleadings. The quality of the report also varies considerably. These facts contribute to their unreliability as a source. Consequently they are rarely cited in court. There is a modern reprint of the Yearbooks by the Selsdon Society and by the Ames Foundation with an English translation. The Bodleian Library in Oxford has a full print collection of the Yearbooks. \nThere is also another set of law reports dating from the late ffteenth century to 1865 that \nexist in a series of reports called ‘the nominate reports’ meaning (named reports). These are reports classifed according to the name of the reporter, such as Coke’s Reports. They too suffer from unreliability relating to the information found in them. There are even concerns that some reports are written by partisan lawyers in such a way as to be slanted towards a particular reading of the reasoning of the case to ensure the same reading in later cases coming before the court. \nBy the nineteenth century, a court-authorised reporter was attached to all higher courts \nand their reports were published in collected volumes catalogued by the name of the relevant reporter. In 1865, there were 16 reporters compiling and publishing authorised reports and in that year these reports were amalgamated into the ICLR, which became a charitable organisation in 1970. As a general rule, law reports predating the ICLR’s crea -\ntion in 1865 are considered to be of doubtful accuracy and reliability as legal authorities. Whilst these reports can be referred to in legal argument in court, they rarely are. \n5 Ibid \n\n--- Page 177 ---\n \n \n  146 FINDING MATERIAL  \nToday, there are numerous, often competitive, private publishers of law reports. The \nrange of types of available law reports is shown in Figure 6 .4, which additionally includes \nsources that are pre-1865, indicating whether they are also available online. \nThere are a number of publishers of law reports, and the editors of each will apply \ndifferent criteria for determining which law cases to report. Measured against the vast \nnumbers of cases that are not reported, the percentage of cases that are reported is very small. It has been estimated that the cases in the ICLR Law Reports only cover 7 per cent of the cases in the higher courts in any given year. \nSome published law reports are annotated, particularly for the use of practitioners; \nothers are left without annotations or introductions. There are generalist law report series reporting important cases in a range of areas of law. But private law publishers have also introduced a specialist series of reports dealing with only one area of law such as employment law, criminal law and company law. \nNote on unreported cases generally \nThe vast majority of cases are unreported, but many of these are published online as court transcripts. An increasing number of cases in transcript format in the archives of the court and the Supreme Court Library contain thousands of fles of unreported cases. These record witness statements and judgments. \nCourt transcripts have been free online since 1996 with more and more courts mak -\ning this service available. You can locate Privy Council decisions from 1999 to 2009 at privy-council.org.uk; \nyou will also fnd that there are a few pre-1999 decisions. Post-2009 you can fnd deci -\nsions at www.jcpc.gov.uk . \nCase summaries and full-text cases \nMany of the online databases, as well as the digests in print form, give case summaries. Whilst there is nothing wrong with a case summary you must realise that a summary is an interpretation of the case by someone else. It is not the actual law case, and it does not contain the law, nor is it a legal authority. The author may have misinterpreted the case, accidentally or deliberately. To access the law you need to read the judgments in the full text in the law report. Only the judgment contains the law. \nThe development of digital technology has allowed the development of a vast range of \nelectronic retrieval systems for accessing the details of thousands of unreported cases. \nThis has caused its own problems and there has been a legitimate concern that courts \nwould be inundated with cases that did not really contain any new law. As a consequence of this concern the House of Lords, in the case of Roberts Petroleum Ltd v Bernard Kenny Ltd,\n6 took the step of forbidding the citation of unreported cases of the Civil Division of the \nCourt of Appeal without special leave. \nThe hierarchy of the law reports \nAlthough there are no offcial series of law reports, an accepted hierarchy of law reports has been established by the senior courts through their practice directions. The most reli -\nable reporting is considered to be found in the Law Reports  series published by the ICLR. \nThis series reports the most important cases heard in the Supreme Court (and previously the House of Lords), the Privy Council, the Court of Appeal, the High Court (Chancery, Family and Queen’s Bench divisions), the Employment Appeals Tribunal and the European Court of Justice. They are bound in differing series of law reports, the Appeal Cases (AC), and then the High Court decisions in Queen’s Bench Division, Chancery, Family and Probate. These are checked by the judges sitting in the relevant case prior to publication. \nThe ICLR Law Reports series reports all cases: \n  Where new rules or principles are introduced into the legal system. \n  Which modify existing rules of principles of the legal system. \n  Which resolve doubt in relation to a question of law. \n  Which the Council considers important in terms of instructiveness. \nThe Law Reports  series contains the argument of counsel for the parties and each report \nis checked before publication by the judges’ bench hearing the case. The courts have \n6 [1983] 2 AC 192. \n\n--- Page 179 ---\n \n  \n      \n  \n  \n  \n \n \n  \n   \n  \n  \n \n  148 FINDING MATERIAL  \nmade clear that these are the most authoritative reports and must be cited over and \nabove any other series of reports that may have published the same case. \nThe Law Reports  are published monthly in four sections and bound annually: \n(1) Queen’s Bench (QB), and the Court of Appeal. \n(2) Chancery (Ch) and the Court of Appeal. \n(3) Family (Fam) Divisions of the High Court and the Court of Appeal. \n(4) Appeal Cases heard in the UK Supreme Court and Judicial Committee of the Privy Council. \nThe reports are available in subscription form in print or online-only formats, or both, by the ICLR. \nIn 2012 the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Judge, issued a ‘Practice Direction: Citation of \nAuthorities (2012)’\n7 which in effect sets out the hierarchy for citation of authorities in court \nas it determines the following practice when an authority is cited in court, in written or oral submissions: \n(1) When a judgment is reported in the Law Reports  series of the ICLR (AC, QB, Ch and \nFAM) that report must be cited and no other. \n(2) If the judgment is not in the law reports series at the time of the case, and it is in the ICLR Weekly Law Reports (WLR) or the All England Law Reports (All ER) then either of these reports can be cited. \n(3) If a judgment is not in the Law Reports , WLR or the All ER a report in any authoritative \nspecialist series can be used provided it ‘contain[s] a headnote and [is] made by indi -\nviduals holding a Senior Courts qualifcation (for the purposes of s 115 of the Courts and Legal Services Act 1990)’.\n8 The ICLR also publishes another set of law reports \nknown as the Weekly Law Reports ; these are published prior to any checking by the \njudiciary in small pamphlet format. Ultimately they are bound in volumes for the year. Those in Volumes 1 and 2 can be found checked by the judges in the Law Reports series. Those in Volume 3 have not found their way into the Law Reports . Whilst the \nLaw Reports  take 10–14 months to be published, the Weekly Law Reports , because \nthey are not checked, take fve months. \n(4) If a judgment is not reported in 1–3 above then any report it is cited in can be used. \n(5) Reference can be made to the offcial transcript of a court case if there is no report.\n9 \nA judgment can have two stages, as ‘handed down in court’, which may then be sub -\nject to later changes and the fnal version fled as the offcial transcript. Occasions do arise when one report is fuller \nthan another, or when there are discrepancies between reports. On such occasions, the practice outlined above need not be followed, but the court should be given a brief explanation of why this course is being taken, and alternative references should be given. \nIt is good to get into the habit of automatically adopting the rule that you will only use the most authoritative version of the report in your written work. Similarly, should you decide to engage in mooting, a competitive form of formal legal argument between two teams of students role playing counsel, you will lose vital marks if you do not cite the most authori -\ntative law report of the case you are using. \nWhat is the relationship of electronic forms to print forms of law cases? \nThe electronic collections of unreported as well as reported law cases are huge, far in excess of those printed. It was the huge array of electronic cases that led to the introduc -\ntion of neutral citations by the courts to bring an order to the reference system used in relation to unreported cases. As the use of the internet spirals and more law reports of cases are converted into electronic form this raises an issue for the legal system. What is the relationship of electronic forms of cases to print formats, particularly in relation to the hierarchy of law reporting? When should a court seriously consider cases that are unre -\nported in the print version but are reported electronically? The electronic source does not displace the hierarchy of the print series. \nChoosing your legal authorities \nWhen reading any law report you should ask whether it is the most authoritative version available. Or are there more authoritative versions? You should also consider whether there is any other case that is only recorded electronically that may be of authority. \nYou could also ask yourself if there might be any unreported case that could be more \nauthoritative than the law report you have located. This would only be a task you would undertake for research or professional purposes. As you now know the courts have strict rules about admitting as authoritative, cases where only electronic versions are available. \nJust because a case has not been reported, or if it is only reported in electronic for -\nmat, it does not mean it cannot be an important case or be used. You would need to access court transcripts yourself to determine these matters, and keep to the established rules for using them in court. \nHow to understand citations \nNeutral citations \nSince 2001 every approved judgment in the Supreme Court, Privy Council, Court of Appeal, the Administrative Court and latterly the divisions of the High Court (Chancery, \n\n--- Page 181 ---\n \n   150 FINDING MATERIAL  \nYear \nCriminal Law  S equence numbe r \nJurisdic\u0007o n of court R v Simpson [2003] EWCA Crim 149 9 \n(e.g.  EW = England & Wales) Cour t(CA = Court of Appeal) \nFigure 6.5 Constituent parts of a neutral citation \nQueen’s Bench, Commercial, Admiralty, Family, etc.) has been given a neutral citation \nby the court as shown in Figure 6 .5. It is a very simple citation. The names of the parties \nare given followed by the year of the case in square brackets (indicating this is the year that the case was heard) and the jurisdiction (e.g. UK for the United Kingdom or EW for England and Wales).\n10 This is followed by the court (e.g. SC, CA, HC), the jurisdiction of \nthe court and then whether it is civil (Civ) or criminal (Crim). Finally a sequence or serial number assigned to the case is given. \nTo assist you with learning the court abbreviations and to reinforce court structure, \nFigure 6 .6 below sets out some of the most used abbreviations in neutral citations. \nThe neutral citation is completely independent of any private law report citations. If \nyou are dealing with a case that has a neutral citation, the neutral citation must be given before any citation of a law report of that case. \nThe neutral citation must be given immediately after the names of the parties and this \nis then followed by any report of the case (given in order of hierarchy). Any e-copy of the reported case will also give the citation of the printed report. The citation gives slightly differing information depending upon the print or exclusively online location of the case, and whether the case is reported by a private publisher or is unreported (in which case the only written record would be the court transcript). \nIf the report of the case is only online then the full web address must be given to \npinpoint the case. Additionally, if you are using this citation you must give the date you accessed the site. \n10 The Supreme Court has UK wide jurisdiction whilst the Court of Appeal and the High Court only have \njurisdiction within the English and Welsh legal systems. \n\n--- Page 182 ---\n   \n  \n \n  151 FINDING MATERIAL \nSUPREME COURT \nUKSC \nNote: Prior to 2009 HOUS E OF LORD S UKHL \nCOURT OF APPEAL \nCriminal Divisio n Civil Di vision \nEWCA Cr im EWCA Civ PRIVY \nCOUNCIL \nUKPC \nHIGH COUR T EWHC \nFamily \nEWHC (Fam ) Queen’s \nBenc h \nEWHC (QB) Chancery \nEWHC (Ch) Commercial \nCourt \nEWHC (Com m) Admiralty \nCour t \nEWHC (Adm lty) Technology and \nConstruc˜on Cour t \nEWHC (TCC) Patents Court \nEWHC (Pat ) \nFigure 6.6 Court structure showing neutral citation abbreviations used for court and jurisdiction \nWhilst there may seem at frst to be far too many citations for you to remember you \nwill fnd that understanding the broad logic of citations means that you know how to read \nnew citations. \nThe size and number of important cases cannot be predicted each year and therefore \npublications of law reports must have room to expand. They are therefore published in series. The standard format adopted by many publishers is to issue small loose-leaf pub -\nlications of selected law reports weekly, monthly, quarterly or half-yearly, which will even -\ntually be bound into annual volumes. These pamphlet-sized publications usually have the publisher, date run and prospective volume number and page numbers running along the spine. \nThey are then bound yearly into a book or books, called a volume. The year, the series \nand the volume number for the year are printed on the spine of the book, along with an abbreviated form of the publication’s name. When there is a particularly busy year there will be more than one volume for the year, and each volume will be numbered con -\nsecutively, 1, 2 and 3, and so on. Each volume will run chronologically from January to December, with Volume 1 containing cases from January onwards. \nEach publisher of private reports will have different abbreviations, but what remains \nstatic is the fact that normally a citation includes the year of the case, an abbreviation of the full name of the private report, the volume number if applicable and the page number in the print version of the report. \n\n--- Page 183 ---\n \n      \n \n   152 FINDING MATERIAL  \nTABLE 6.2 ABBREVIATIONS FOR LAW REPORTS PUBLISHED IN PRINT \nAC Appeal Cases (Law Reports series) \nAll ER All England Law Reports \nAll ER (EC) All England Reports European Cases \nBCLC Butterworths Company Law Cases \nCh Chancery (Law Reports series) \nCLR Commonwealth Law Reports \nCMLR Common Market Law Reports \nCox CC Cox’s Criminal Cases (Law Reports) \nCr App R Criminal Appeal Reports \nECC European Commercial Cases \nECHR European Commission on Human Rights Decisions and Reports 1976–1998 \nECR European Court Reports 1954 (Court of Justice of the European Community) \nECR 1 European Court of First Instances/General court report \nER English Reports \nFAM Law Reports Series Family \nHRLR Human Rights Law Reports \nICR Industrial Cases Reports \nIRLR Industrial Relations Law Reports \nKB King’s Bench (Law Reports series) \nQB Queen’s Bench (Law Reports series) \nTLR Times Law Reports \nSome publishers will separate out cases heard in the Court of Appeal and the Supreme \nCourt. Some series of reports only deal with specialist areas of law, such as company law, \nor employment law; other series are generalists dealing with all areas. \nAs you are asked to locate law cases you will become familiar with the range of reports \nand forms of citation. You will start to internalise the different abbreviations without effort. In your early days of study it may be useful to keep a modest list of abbreviations handy as a quick translation. \nThe citation provides all of the information you need to give the proper reference in \nyour written work – with the caveat that there are a few differences in referencing systems used in UK Law schools.\n11 If you do not recognise the abbreviation in your citation then it \nis quick and easy to refer to the Cardiff Index of Legal Abbreviations, which is locatable online at www.legalabbrevs.cardiff.ac.uk . \nYou will fnd over 100 law report abbreviations on the database. Table 6 .2 above lists \nthe most popular abbreviations you are likely to come across in your frst year of study. \nIt is useful at this point to give some detailed consideration of year dates (both of the \ncase and publication) and party names as used in law report citations. \n11 See the section on referencing and plagiarism in Chapter 10 . \n\n--- Page 184 ---\n   \n \n  \n  FINDING MATERIAL 153 \nR v Camplin [1978] AC 705 \nPage number for start of report \nRegina, the prosec u\u000bon is  Year of repor t \nbrought in the name of the \nQueen as the fgurehead The defendant Abbrevia\u000bon of the law report series: \nfor the st ate     Appeal Cases \nFigure 6.7 Constituent parts of a citation for a criminal case published in the ICLR Law Reports series \nYear dates and law reports \nPrior to 1890, year dates were not put on volumes of law reports – other conventions were \nused to locate the case, and the year was not part of the citation. Most usually an abbrevi -\nated version of the author’s name, often just an initial of the surname, was used to locate the case, with volume number and page numbers being indicated, for example, Heydon’s Case (1584) 3 Co Rep 7a 101. \nThe above report abbreviation ‘Co’ refers to Sir Edward Coke, an infuential fgure in \nsixteenth-century law. His reports are in seven volumes, and are a collection of writings. They concerned cases where he had been counsel, cases he had been in court for and cases he had heard of! He began them whilst still a law student. Of variable quality in the early years from 1572, they stabilised from 1579. Note the round brackets indicating you need to know the date to fnd the case in Coke’s Reports. \nToday, the dates of pre-1890 cases are placed in round brackets ( ) in the law report \ncitation. This indicates the fact that you do not need the date in order to fnd the case, though it may be helpful. You will need a name of a publication or an author, and a volume number. Law reports post-1890 place the date in square brackets [ ] to indicate that the year the case was published is necessary to locate it. You may wonder why it is neces -\nsary to mention cases pre-1890. However, in the English common law system, it is quite possible that some of the leading cases you will need to refer to were reported pre-1890. \nDate of reporting a case contrasted with date of hearing a case \nThe year date given in the citation is the year in which the case was reported. You need to be aware that it is possible that the case itself may not have been heard in that year. For example, a case may be heard in late December and not reported until January, when the year date will have changed. Also, sometimes an editor is slow to realise the importance of a case, or its importance is not realised until another case has referred to it. Then the case can only be published at the earliest opportunity, but it may already be several years after the case was heard. It is therefore important to check the date of hearing in the actual report itself so that you do not make an error concerning when the case was heard. \nCase names \nCase names are cited in different ways according to whether they are criminal, civil or judicial review cases, family law cases,\n12 probate cases or shipping cases.13 You will learn \n12 Which are usually anonymised. \n13 Usually the name of the ship is used. \n\n--- Page 185 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n   154 FINDING MATERIAL  \nGeorge Mitchell v Finney Lock Seeds [1983] 2 AC 803 \nPage number of start of report\nAppellant Respondent \nYear of Case Abbrevia\bon of Law \nVolume Report series: Appeal Court \nnumber \nFigure 6.8 Constituent parts of a citation for a civil case published in the ICLR Law Reports series \nthese differences slowly, but initially you are most likely to come across criminal cases \nand civil cases in your frst year of study. Therefore only these two will be considered. \nCriminal cases \nR v Camplin [1978] AC 705 is the citation for a criminal case. You can see that the frst name is a capital letter, R. This is an abbreviation of the Latin for King (Rex) and Queen (Regina). A criminal case is brought in the name of the Crown, for the monarch is the head of state. The defendant’s name in criminal proceedings comes second as the monarch is bringing a case against the defendant for an alleged breach of the criminal law. The notation signifying the prosecution is the italicised letter v, which stands for the Latin ‘versus’, meaning ‘against’. However, if you are speaking, the ‘v’ is always said as ‘and’ not ‘versus’ (unlike in the United States, where lawyers pronounce the letter ‘v’ or say ‘versus’). Figure 6 .4 gives a breakdown of the elements making up the \nfull citation \nInitially you can go to the section of the library where the law reports are kept and \nlocate the volume you need by searching chronologically through the spines of the Appeal Cases series. Once located you turn to page 705. Or you can access it online. \nCivil cases \nThe names of both parties are given in civil trial law report citations with the complainant’s name given frst and the defendant’s second. The notation ‘v’ is used (again, pronounced ‘and’) and the citation rules are the same, as shown in Figure 6 .5, where the breakdown \nis given for George Mitchell v Finney Lock Seeds  [1983] 2 AC 803. This is a civil appeal \nso the complainant’s name is given frst: this is the party bringing the action. The second name is that of the party defending the action. In an appeal case the party bringing the appeal is the frst name given. When the case is located you will note that it was fnally heard in the House of Lords. \nCorrectly citing law cases before and after 2001 \nThere are a few general rules concerning what information goes into citations before and after the introduction of neutral citations by the courts in 2001 and these are set out in Table 6 .3. \n\n--- Page 186 ---\n   \n  \n  \n      \n  \n    \n      FINDING MATERIAL 155 \nTABLE 6.3 CORRECTLY CITING LAW CASES BEFORE AND AFTER 2001 \nType of report Cases before 2001 Cases after 2001 \nReported cases • Party names \n• Law report citation \nIn order of the hierarchy of law \nreporting if more than one e.g. George Mitchell v Finney Lock Seeds Ltd  [1983] 2 AC 803; \n[1983] 3 WLR 163; [1983] 2 All E.R. 737; [1983] 2 Lloyd’s Rep. 272; [1983] Com.
