This section gives you basic information \nto help you to locate these cases. \nLocating European Union law cases \nLocating cases in print collections \nUnlike the English legal system the EU legal system does have an offcial set of law \nreports – the ‘Law reports before the Court’ which since 1991 are organised in two parts. Part I reports cases heard in the Court of Justice of the EU (CJEU), and Part II reports cases of the Court of First Instance/General Court. In the English legal system publi -\ncation of appellate courts and trial court judgments is relatively quick, as discussed. Unfortunately, there is not a quick turnaround of the offcial reports for EU courts. Part of this is due to the need to translate judgments into the offcial languages of the EU (cur -\nrently 21!), and this can take in the region of 18–24 months. This means that the offcial reports are not a useful source for up to date law. Researchers and lawyers needing up to date information on cases must consult private publishers, and as you know now these collections will not be comprehensive but will only cover cases considered impor -\ntant by the editors. \nThere are two main sources of reliable but unoffcial private publications: the Common \nMarket Law Reports which have been published since 1962 by Sweet and Maxwell and the All England Law Reports (European cases), which have been published since 1995. \nLocating cases online \nThere are a range of databases that give details of EU cases. The most important is the offcial database, https://curia.europa.eu, where you can search for the parties (e.g. ‘van Gend’) for the citation (see below), or via the ‘Advanced search’ feature for more complex information – e.g. all cases on Consumer Protection between 1990 and 2005. \n\n--- Page 192 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n   FINDING MATERIAL 161 \nUnderstanding EU case citations \nCases in the CJEU and Court of First Instance (previously the General Court and renamed \nby the Treaty of Lisbon) are reported as two different series: the CJEU as series C and the CFI (GC) as series T. The frst aspect of the citation therefore is stating the series classifca -\ntion as either C or T. This is followed by the year of hearing separated by a forward slash from the serial number of the case, which indicates which case of the hearing year it was. This is similar to the idea of sequence numbers used in neutral citations for domestic cases referred to above. Next the names of the parties to the case are given. After the party names the year recorded in square brackets indicates the year of publication of the offcial record; this is followed by the abbreviated reference ECR to the offcial reports noting in capitalised Roman numerals whether the case is in Part I (CJEU cases) or Part II (CFI/GC). Knowing the part numbers enables you to tell at a glance which court heard the case reported. \nLocating ECHR law reports \nThere exist both offcial and unoffcial reports of cases, and it is important to remember that in addition to the ECtHR, the European Commission on Human Rights had jurisdic -\ntion to hear cases until its abolition in 1998. \nPrint collection \nThere is an offcial print series of reports for the ECtHR which is located in the ‘Reports of Judgments and Decisions’. Most recently there has been a move towards the publication of selected cases only. There is a delay of at least a year before publication. \nResearchers, lawyers and students therefore are again reliant on private publishers for \nup to date information on cases, using the European Human Rights Reports (EHRR). They are acceptable in the English and Welsh courts. \nIf you need access to decisions of the European Commission on Human Rights pre -\n1998, these can be located in two reports series that are split by date. The collection of decisions of the European Commission on Human Rights (citation is CD) contains reports from 1955 to 1973 in Volumes 1–46. From 1974 to 1998, reports can be found in the Decisions and Reports (citation DR) in Volume 46 onwards. \nHUDOC \nHUDOC is the offcial website, containing full judgments which are free to access ( hudoc \n.echr.coe.int/ ). However, you can also access selected cases through the subscription \nservices of Westlaw, Justis, Lawtel and Casetrack. \nFinding secondary material \nIntroduction \nReading secondary texts (books about law) is essential for the development of your understanding of law. There are many types of secondary texts available from the print \n\n--- Page 193 ---\n \n 162 FINDING MATERIAL  \nand e-collections in your university library as well as on open access internet sites. An \nexample of the type of texts available would include: \n  Reference texts: dictionaries, encyclopaedias, digests, indexes, bibliographies. \n  Books/research monographs. \n  Academic and professional journal articles. \n  Offcial documents (command papers, proceedings in Parliament, debates in \nParliament, parliamentary research papers, government presentations to Parliament in the form of policies, briefngs, information and minutes of committees). \n  Reports by charitable organisations in the feld. \n  Reports by independent ‘think tanks’. \n  A large number of organisations, such as charities, universities and pressure groups have extensive literature online. \n  Many universities around the world make some aspects of their electronic materials available free on the internet. \n  Some individual academics in university departments make their speeches, lectures and articles available and often have their own websites. \n  Media reporting. \n  Blogs. \nAs students of law studying for a law degree you are engaged in the academic stage of a legal education. Among other things in your learning you are required to keep up to date with some of the latest academic thought in your area. Academic journals and books critique an area of law, explain the emergence of a new idea or area of law or offer an academic commentary on an area of law. These materials can bring exceptional scholar -\nship to a reader. Where they are concerned with actual legal rules you will need to check that the commentary and the rule given in the book are up to date. \nYour library will subscribe to journals and reference material and in many cases these \nwill be available in both print and electronic formats. Many journals will provide electronic access to current and back issues if your library has a print subscription. Journal articles are never more than two to four months out of date at the date of publication. \nUnfortunately, the world of academic publishing is complex. There are plenty of elec -\ntronic databases and collections that your library will have subscribed to, and there are plenty that it will not. These each contain a variety of journals, depending on the agree -\nment between the databases and the publishers. Often, your library website will have a search function as well, which points you to which of the databases your library sub -\nscribes to contains this particular journal. \nAs you move through the frst year of your studies you will gain an appreciation of the \nimportance of secondary law texts, both from textbooks that explain the general area of law, through to scholarly books which carefully explore one area of law from a complex set of perspectives. As with primary sources, you should also assess whether the author of a secondary text has appropriate credentials. \n\n--- Page 194 ---\n   \n \n \n \n   \n   \n \n FINDING MATERIAL 163 \nBooks written as student textbooks, such as this one, are not books of any legal \nauthority. Some do get mentioned in court (especially the older and more established \nones), but it is not common practice. Books can be out of date before they are published so you do need to consult academic journals for up to date legal commentary. \nThe majority of the journals that you will read will be academic. This means all articles \nplaced in a particular edition of the journal will have been read before publication by two other academics working in the same area, who must agree that the article is academi -\ncally sound and adds to the current debates. This process is called peer review, and the journals which undertake this checking prior to publication are called refereed journals. The peer-review process ensures that the article and the journal are reliable. This does not mean that what is said should be believed or should not be questioned, but it does mean that you can read it and trust it to be of an authoritative nature. \nOther journals are professional and not intended in any way to be academic but prac -\ntical. Some of these can be extremely useful for law students at the academic stage of their training, but bear in mind that there is often no peer-review process involved in the publication. \nGeneral issues \nWilliam Twining, a well-known professor of philosophy, once issued a text that he called the Law Cookbook , a series of ‘recipes’ for success in legal method and reasoning.\n14 \nThis developed into a popular text, co-authored with Professor David Miers, How To Do Things With Rules .\n15 \nThe ‘cookbook’ is an excellent metaphor,16 especially related to electronic and com -\nplex print texts. You may not wish to cook, but if you did, you would not start off by cook -\ning the most complex recipe or by simply reading recipes. You would learn the basics of cooking and then add on more complex variants to your simple starting recipes. With time, you will discover your own ways of cooking depending on the meal you are pre -\nparing. This is the underlying approach of this section, to lay out some basic research strategies, or recipes, for searching print and electronic collections, to acquire secondary material about the law. \nIt will allow you to experiment and provide the tools you need to gain an understanding \nof law library research. You will learn best by going into the print collections, or logging into the electronic collections, and browsing the sources. \nAcademic study involves the application of proper and rigorous research for materials, \nfollowed by your selection of the most appropriate resources, which are then subjected to competent and rigorous interpretation.\n17 The effort taken to locate material is only the \nbeginning of academic work, but it is an essential task because you need to locate the most authoritative and correct texts. \nAs you practise locating secondary material you will fnd that your skills increase and \nimprove. In addition to the face-to-face training that your department and/or library will \n14 W Twining and D Miers How to Do Things with Rules: A Primer of Interpretation (4th edition, Cambridge \nUniversity Press , Cambridge, 1999), Appendix 111, 421–33. \n15 W Twining and D Miers How to Do Things with Rules: A Primer of Interpretation (4th edition, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1999). \n16 A metaphor can be defned as the act of describing something unknown by reference to something known. \n17 Analysis and interpretation of retrieved material will be dealt with later in the book. \n\n--- Page 195 ---\n \n \n \n \n 164 FINDING MATERIAL  \nprovide, there are excellent training guides produced by most university libraries to assist \nin locating and searching particular print and electronic resources. In addition, many data -\nbases such as Westlaw contain detailed instructions both in print format, and online. All databases will contain either help tutorials or ‘hints’ in a drop-down menu. These can be useful if you have a problem. But it is better to also know how to properly navigate the site. \nSearch strategies \nSearch strategies for print and electronic materials both start in the same place, with your research question and an idea of the type of information you are looking for. You need to assess whether the material you have located is reliable and, in the case of journal arti -\ncles, that it is the most current scholarly material. You may fnd that you retrieve articles by leading scholars that are opposed to each other in their views. You need to deal with this difference of opinion and synthesise these views in your writing and research for tuto -\nrials. However, frst things frst: before you can engage in this type of critique you need to know how to locate the best, and most relevant, materials you need with a carefully thought out strategy based on: \n  what you are looking for; and \n  why you are looking for it. \nFor the following discussion on searching for resources we will assume that you are \nresearching for the following essay question: \nIs it correct to maintain that in R v Secretary of State ex. P. Factortame (No 1) and (No \n2) the English courts and the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) made it clear that English courts have the power to suspend Acts of Parliament conficting with the European Union (EU) and that the CJEU can determine what national remedies should be available? Critically discuss. \nThis is an essay based on the reading of law reports and from the previous sections \nyou know how to locate these cases. However, your ultimate task is to decide whether the description given in the quote is correct. To do this, you will need to search for relevant secondary material, which must be mainly from academics. The views of legal profes -\nsionals as well as politicians can sometimes give your research some extra avenues to explore and views to consider. But at university you are primarily responding from an academic legal perspective not a professional legal and/or political perspective. We will look at only three types of secondary text, journals, books and offcial documents. \nJournal articles \nWhat are journals? \nA journal is a collection of articles (and book reviews and case comments) by a range of different writers. Law journals can cover the area of law generally or consider law from a \n\n--- Page 196 ---\n   \n \n       FINDING MATERIAL 165 \nspecifc disciplinary perspective (such as anthropology or sociology) or from one specifc \narea of law (e.g. contract or criminal law). The main focus of a journal can be academic or non-academic (e.g. a professional journal for barristers or solicitors). Law students are always expected to use several academic articles in written work and for tutorial work which may be supplemented by non-academic professional journal articles if relevant. Academic articles are scholarly pieces written about a particular topic or issue within a subject and often constitute the most up to date thinking in an area. \nJournal title abbreviations \nAll journals have an abbreviation of the journal title (e.g. CLR for the Cambridge Law Review) and you will come to know the main abbreviations. The abbreviation can usually be found in the header of each page of an article, and a full listing of abbreviations can be obtained online from the Cardiff Index to Legal Abbreviations.\n18 \nJournal article citations \nPublishers of journals need a recognised system of organising their journals so that they can be easily accessed by readers in their printed formats as well as online. This is essen -\ntially done by date order of publication. Typically, each year will have its own volume, going back to the beginning of the journal. The majority of academic journals are pub -\nlished more than once a year in ‘issues’. Therefore many volume numbers will be followed by a number in brackets; this indicates which issue of the year the article is in (e.g. 72(1) refers to Volume 72 and Issue No 1 for the year). \nThe citation for a journal article is ordered as follows: author name, article title, abbre -\nviation of journal name, year of publication, volume number, issue number in brackets and page reference: \nMunday R, Fisher v Bell revisited: misjudging the legislative craft, CLJ 2013, 72(1), \n50–64 \nAs you can probably work out yourself, this is an article by R. Munday with the title ‘Fisher v Bell revisited: misjudging the legislative craft’. It was published in Issue 1 of Volume 72 of the Cambridge Law Journal  in 2013, and you can fnd it on pages 50–64. \nDo not confuse the general citation used by each journal with the requirements of \nacademic referencing systems for use in the written work method of placing such refer -\nences into essays, etc. There are several different academic referencing systems used in universities (e.g. Harvard or the Oxford System for the Citation of Legal Authorities (OSCOLA)). These may require you to use slightly differing punctuation, fonts or presen -\ntation of author name and journal details \nSee Chapter 10 for fuller details on academic referencing. \n18 www.legalabbrevs.cardiff.ac.uk . \n\n--- Page 197 ---\n \n \n \n \n 166 FINDING MATERIAL  \nFinding online journals using Westlaw \nWhilst print runs of certain journals are currently kept by many university libraries, as a \ngeneral trend universities are moving to online access only. This saves valuable space on the library shelves, and it allows students to access the journal articles whenever they want and wherever they are, without the frustration of walking to the shelf only to discover that someone else has taken it to their desk already. \nWestlaw is not only useful for cases and legislation but can also be used to search \njournals for relevant articles by: \n  keywords; \n  subject; \n  general terms; \n  cases cited in the journal article; \n  journal title; \n  article title; \n  author. \nIt is relatively straightforward to use the quick search box to locate a specifc journal \narticle by name or by author name. But you may well fnd that often you are searching to see if an article has been written on a particular topic. The keyword search allows you to do this. But do not assume that there are no articles if you do not retrieve any. Your keywords may not have retrieved articles that exist; changing your keywords may allow you to locate the articles you want. When you retrieve your search results you will fnd that either the title is clearly relevant or you may need to read the abstract. If you have not used an advanced search to narrow the publication dates of articles you wish to retrieve, do keep a careful eye on dates as you do not want to locate out of date information. Westlaw is useful in that it keeps a list of journals in full text on the site and additionally refers to journals in the abstract where it does not have full text. \nFinding journals on Lawtel \nThis site is also a Sweet and Maxwell site so it will contain some material that is also found on Westlaw. However, it tends to specialise more in the area of professional legal journals, which can be particularly useful in ensuring you know the lawyers’ views of up to date law as well as reading academic views. It too can be searched by using keywords, by subject, general text (free text) or by journal title or author, and your searches can be date limited. \nFinding journals on Lexis®Library \nThis database contains the full text of around 100 journals and the abstracts of many more; it also contains practitioner journals. You can search within one specifc journal, \n\n--- Page 198 ---\n   \n  \n \n \n  \n \n \n \n \n FINDING MATERIAL 167 \nwhich is particularly useful and is a facility that is not available on Westlaw. But do not get \ninto the habit of just using one journal. Even if your preferred journal is excellent it cannot give you the wide-ranging understanding obtained by looking at good academic articles from a range of journals. Many generalist journals contain in-depth articles on a range of topics. If you were researching criminal law and limited yourself to just the criminal law review you may miss an important article in one of the generalist journals such as the journal of legal studies. \nFinding journals on HeinOnline ( www.heinonline.org) \nThis is a database from Hein and Co, a leading American publisher; however, it contains a large number of UK and European journals. It will retrieve your journal as a page image so you see the article as it appeared in the print version. \nThere is a good source of archived academic journal articles held on JSTOR, which \nis a subscription database that you will be able to access through your university library. \nHowever, these are out of date and so you must decide if you need up to date infor -\nmation on an area of law. If you are interested in various academic views relating to a topic then these may be of use, as long as you also use them with updated articles as well. \nUsing other search engines \nAnother very popular way to fnd articles is Google Scholar – https://scholar.google.com. It is very easy to use and shows you articles from a huge number of sources. Often, it will contain links to a pdf version of an article that is published in open access repositories – sometimes draft versions or articles or articles that were only licensed to a publisher for a certain time. Try to use the offcially published version for your writing, as the page refer -\nences in the open access copy might be skewed. In general, be very careful to ensure that what you are retrieving is a proper academic source that has undergone the peer-review process. As mentioned before, you can fnd everything from brilliant research papers to hastily typed conspiracy theories on the internet, and search engines like Google Scholar do not always distinguish between these. \nThe library catalogue \nOften the best way to locate journal articles is your own library’s website. Many library catalogues can not only be used to locate books (see below), but will also have excel -\nlent search facilities for journals. The advantage is that you will only get links to articles that your library has access to, and that you often have links leading you straight to the relevant database (an article might be available on HeinOnline and not on Lexis, for example). \n\n--- Page 199 ---\n \n   \n \n 168 FINDING MATERIAL  \nBooks \nIn addition to journal articles you will also be required to read all or part of a number of \nbooks for each of your modules. You need to know how to access them effciently, either by title, or by researching to see if there are any books of authority on the topic you are concerned with. \nThe library catalogue \nThe print collection of your university library is going to be your main source of books for borrowing or reading and therefore your frst port of call will again be the online library cataloguing system. \nIt is possible with a note from your university library to have reading rights in other \nuniversity libraries. This is most useful if you are studying some distance from your home address: you may be able, out of term time, to read books in any good university law library near your home. Additionally if your library does not stock the book you need, you can fll in an interlibrary loan form, but it can take weeks before your book arrives in your university library. \nThe university online library catalogue will allow you to access books by title, author or \nthe use of keywords. Each university catalogue system will work differently; however, all will contain print or online guides to the system. Again this is an area where you should experiment with accessing books on topics early on in the academic year so that you know how to fnd books when told to read a chapter. \nA valuable online resource for accessing books is COPAC ( www.copac.ac.uk ), which \nis an amalgamation of the online catalogues of major UK as well as Ireland, specialist, university and national libraries (e.g. The British Library). You can fnd some interesting material in this catalogue, including small specialist monographs that are not in your university’s library. \nUsing print-only materials \nYou can also locate books using printed materials by accessing a legal bibliography, which can be general or specialist, and when you have a book in front of you, you can consult its bibliography and may well obtain leads for further reading from it. Or check out the references in footnotes or endnotes in your set text or other books. You might fnd that the textbook may only give a basic outline of an area, but if you look at footnotes you will often fnd that they direct you to further, more detailed, reading. \nGeneral note on module ‘set textbooks’ \nSome lecturers will advise you to buy a particular book for a module. If this is the case, do seriously consider buying the book if your fnances will allow you to do so. This textbook \n\n--- Page 200 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n     \n     FINDING MATERIAL 169 \nwill have been carefully chosen by your lecturer as the best and most up to date book to accompany the course. You will fnd that you will often be expected to read a section or a chapter before a tutorial or a lecture. You may think it will be enough to read the library copy of the set text. Whilst this may be sensible, if many students decide to do this you may fnd that you cannot get your hands on the book to read it for assessments or tutorials. \nIf you decide you want to use a different textbook do check with your lecturer that \nit is appropriate. Your lecturer may have decided not to use that book for very specifc reasons. For example, it may not cover all of the topics on the course. Alternatively, you may feel that the set textbook is too diffcult, or you cannot follow it. Do ask your lecturer for advice as they may be able to recommend another text to use instead, or to read frst before going back to the set text you have a problem with. \nYou can often buy used textbooks, but do make sure that the version you are buying \nis up to date. If it is an older edition of the recommended book, check with your lecturer whether this will still be suffcient. \nEven if you do buy the recommended textbook this does not mean that you will not \nhave to locate and read other books when researching for tutorials or assessments. \nOffcial documents \nThe use of the term ‘offcial document’ refers to publications by the two Houses of Parliament (command papers, parliamentary papers, debates, committee proceedings), the government and government departments, local authorities, etc. If you are research -\ning legislation the parliamentary website\n19 or relevant government or government depart -\nment website20 can offer an invaluable insight into the rationale for proposed legislation. \nFor the purposes of this discussion we will only consider accessing a few offcial \ndocuments: \n  Command papers. \n  Parliamentary papers. \n  Parliamentary debates. \nBut the information given can be transferable and act as a standard guide to access other \ntypes of offcial documents. \nCommand papers \nWhen the government presents publications to Parliament they are known as command papers, so called because of the following formula of words at the beginning of them: \n‘Presented to Parliament by the Secretary of State for … by Command of Her Majesty’. \n19 www.parliament.uk . \n20 www.gov.uk . \n\n--- Page 201 ---\n \n  170 FINDING MATERIAL  \nThere are many different types of command paper. You have already come across two, \nWhite Papers and Green Papers, in Chapters 1 and 7. White Papers present the govern -\nment’s proposals for legislation, or policy initiatives. Green Papers tend to be purely con -\nsultation documents. In addition to these command papers also include: \n  State papers. \n  Government responses to select committee reports. \n  Reports of Royal Commissions as well as other committees of inquiry. \n  Statistics and annual reports of government bodies (but not all). \nThe majority of command papers are kept in series identifable by numbers. In addition \nto numbered series there are some command papers that are not in numbered series. \nThe numbered series of command papers began in 1833; the sixth series, which \nbegan in November 1986, is the current series. \nThe full range of dates and references for the six series are as follows: \nSeries 1: 1833–1869, which is numbered [1]–[4222]. Series 2: 1870–1899, which starts with prefx C. and is numbered [1]–[9550]. Series 3: 1900–1918, which starts with the prefx Cd. and is numbered [1]–[9329]. Series 4: 1919–1956, which starts with the prefx Cmd and is numbered [1]–[9889]. (Square \nbrackets around numbers was abolished in 1922.) \nSeries 5: 1956–1986, which starts with the prefx Cmnd and is numbered [1]–[9927]. Series 6: 1986 to date. \nNote that after the frst series, prefxes are added to differentiate the series so that num -\nbers do not become confused. If you refer to a command paper by the number 2,500, it \nwill not mean anything unless you know the prefx. If it is Cmd 2500, you know that the prefx Cmd was used for Series 4. Therefore it can be located in Series 4. \nYou may fnd that your library organises its collection of command papers according \nto the parliamentary session. This is a problem if you do not know the date of the com -\nmand paper you are looking for. \nAs command papers are offcial government publications, most of them can be located \nin full text on the www.gov.uk website. \nIf you want to see the government’s response to any select committee reports these \nare accessible by consulting the relevant committee pages or through links on the rel -\nevant government department websites. \nLocating parliamentary papers \nHouse of Commons papers and House of Lords papers detail the work of the two Houses, for example, details of voting procedures, minutes, select committee reports. \n\n--- Page 202 ---\n   \n  \n   \n  \n  \n             \n 171 FINDING MATERIAL \nThe Parliament website21 gives the dates and online access for a range of parliamen -\ntary papers. Some are not available online and where this is the case it is stated. From the \nparliament.uk site you can click on each link to immediately access papers. \nFinding reports of parliamentary debates \nWhilst many reports may be given of debates in Parliament, the only offcial reports of parliamentary debates are provided by Hansard, and generally the shorthand reference for offcial reports of debates is just ‘Hansard’. It is printed on a daily basis and reprinted each week in the ‘weekly Hansard’ and an index is published fortnightly. At the end of each parliamentary session all debates are issued as a bound volume; these volumes run into the hundreds. Hansard reports are in a column (two to a page) format, with each column numbered consecutively throughout the year so that passages can be precisely and quickly pinpointed. For referencing purposes the volume number and column num -\nber is given. \nThey are published online at hansard.parliament.uk, where you can look at both \nCommons and Lords debates. You can search by dates, but the current online record only goes back to 1988/9 (House of Commons) and 1994/94 (House of Lords). For online records before that you would need to use the parliamentary archives at hansard-archive .parliament.uk. \nEvaluation of material \nAccess to information has probably changed more radically than most other things over the past 20 years. Nothing is easier than to fnd a plethora of materials for almost any question. \nThe temptation is therefore high to replace complicated and time-consuming research \nwith a few phrases typed into the online search engine of your choice. However, you need to be very careful here. There is an enormous amount of carelessly researched, strongly opinionated or biased and sometimes even outright wrong information on the internet, and you will not receive good marks if you base your arguments on this. \nThe articles you fnd in academic journals have gone through a robust peer-review \nprocess, where other academics review the articles in detail before they are published. This does not mean everything is defnitely correct, and it certainly does not mean that you have to share the opinions of the writers, but it does mean that you can trust the methods used to reach the conclusions. \nWith a lot of online writing, there is no way to ensure similar standards, so you need to \nassess the reliability of the sources yourself. Essentially, you need to ask yourself three questions: \n21 Accessed 5 January 2015. \n\n--- Page 203 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n 172 FINDING MATERIAL  \n  Who has posted this – who is the author or the organisation publishing this, are they \ntrustworthy, what are their credentials? \n  Why have they posted it – is the author part of a campaign group or part of a lobby -\ning organisation, is there an intention behind it? As an example, you need to read an article about climate change differently whether it comes from an environmentalist group or from the oil industry. Even if both use the same facts, the conclusions drawn from those are very likely going to be quite different. \n  When was it posted – is the information still up to date? Especially in law, this can change at a rapid pace! \nIt is important that you develop a good feeling for sources. A website that offers one-paragraph summaries of 20 cases in the law of torts is probably not a good revision guide, as the information is too short and probably full of mistakes. A website that gives free samples of essays that students can buy almost certainly contains sloppy research and badly written ideas. Wikipedia is a fantastic example for collaboration on the internet, and often a great source of information to get an overview of a topic, but it is impossible to trace the content back to the author and to assess the reliability of it. \nWebsites of newspapers or news organisations (even reliable sources such as The \nGuardian or the BBC) will – because of their target audiences – never give you the amount of depth you require for writing a successful law essay. Using the BBC’s website is fne if you want to give a source to facts, opinion polls or historical records, but it is not enough for formulating a strong legal argument. \nCONCLUSION \nThis chapter should give you enough starting points to begin researching for your semi -\nnars and assignments. All of this looks probably a bit much at the moment, but in no time it will become your second nature. Try practising fnding legislation, cases and articles early on, and embrace every opportunity to get more familiar with the different worlds your library can give you access to – both in paper and online. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \nGeneral \n  The study of law is exclusively the study of documents containing the law (primary sources) and books and other resources about the law (secondary sources). \n  The law library functions as a major gateway to help you fnd your source materials in both print and electronic form. \n\n--- Page 204 ---\n   FINDING MATERIAL 173 \n  There are particular conventions for citing primary law, and for the hierarchy of law \nreports, that should be observed. \n  Electronic databases can be particularly useful tools if you do not know the citation of a specifc case. \n  A law case is a court hearing of a legal dispute. \n  A court transcript is the written record of the judgments delivered in court compiled by an employee of the court. \n  Case law is the term used to refer to decided legal disputes in the courts in which there has been the creation of, or an amendment to, a common law rule by judges in their judicial decisions during the hearing of the case. \n  A legal authority is a law case that in its written form (which can be a court transcript or a privately published report) creates a precedent. \n  A law report is a written record of a law case produced by a private law report pub -\nlisher. There are no offcial English legal system law reports. \n  The following hierarchy of law reports emerges from practice directions:  Law Reports  series (ICLR). \n Weekly Law Reports or All England Law Reports. \n An authoritative specialist series. \n  Since 2001 every approved judgment in the Supreme Court, Privy Council, Court of Appeal, the Administrative Court, and latterly the divisions of the High Court (Chancery, Queen’s Bench, Commercial, Admiralty, Family, etc.) has been given a neutral citation by the court. \n  The neutral citation is completely independent of any private law report citations. \n  The year date given in a citation is the year in which the case was reported. You need to be aware that it is possible that the case itself may not have been heard  in that \nyear. \n  Case names are cited in different ways according to whether they are criminal, civil or judicial review cases, family law cases, probate cases or shipping cases. \n  When citing reported cases before 2001 you must give party names and the law report citation (in order of the hierarchy of law reporting if more than one). \n  If citing reported cases after 2001 you must give party names, neutral citation and law report citations (in order of the hierarchy of law reporting if more than one). \n  If citing unreported cases before 2001, you must give party names, date of hearing and court. \n  If citing unreported cases after 2001, you must give party names and neutral citation. \n  Justis is a particularly useful database for research as it contains case law going back to 1163 and legislation back to 1235 for not only the UK but also Ireland and the EU. \n  Her Majesty’s Courts Service publishes Court of Appeal and Supreme Court judg -\nments within one day, with other courts and tribunals as soon as possible. \n  European Union treaties can be found at EUR-Lex, European Union cases can be located on Curia. \n\n--- Page 205 ---\n 174 FINDING MATERIAL  \n  Decisions by the European Court of Human Rights can be found using the HUDOC \nwebsite. \n  An essential aspect of the study of law is the location and use of secondary texts about law. \n  You need to develop effcient and competent research strategies for secondary texts. \nJournal articles \n  A journal is a collection of articles (and book reviews and case comments) by a range of different writers. Law journals can cover the area of law generally or consider law from a specifc disciplinary perspective. \n  Westlaw, Lawtel, Lexis®Library and HeinOnline are all good sources for journals. Many full-text articles are carried as well as abstract only articles. \nBooks \n  Books and in many cases also articles can be found in your university catalogue. \n  You will fnd that some offcial documents will be in print version in your library. \n  You should take care to consider the credibility, version and currency of any source you use. \n  Open access internet sources should be questioned in terms of who posted the material, why and when. \n\n--- Page 206 ---\n7 \n  \n READING AND \nUNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Read, use and understand domestic legislation and the language used in statutes. \n  Understand the relationship between different parts of a statute. \n  Understand how judges approach statutory interpretation. \n  Demonstrate an awareness of the rules of statutory interpretation and other prac -\ntices used when interpreting statutes. \n  Understand how to use unoffcial and offcial databases to effciently and quickly \nobtain an overview of a statute. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-9  \n\n--- Page 207 ---\n    \n \n  \n \n    176 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nLanguage skills \nsophisticated \ncomprehension SKILLS \nCompetent legal \nknowledge of \nsubstantuve law Argument \nconstruction Legal rule handling \nidentification of existing arguments BASIC ADVANCED \nLocation of (legal rules) applying \ninterpreting \ncritiquing case noting \nexcellent aw areness of range of methods of \ncorrect grammar construction of arguments \nexcellent vocabulary: comparison of arguments\n general specialist \nexcellent reading and \nwriting skills \nFigure 7.1 Skills required for understanding legislation \nINTRODUCTION \nThis chapter introduces techniques and skills for using and handling domestic legislation. \nWhen used broadly the word legislation includes domestic UK legislation and delegated legislation. However, the skills you will learn are transferable to secondary legislation and to other types of primary legislation.\n2 \nThe standard layout of domestic legislation will be briefy noted,3 before turning to \nconsider the range of techniques and skills needed to competently handle legislation. These are set out below in Figure 7 .1. \n1 C hapter 3 deals with European Union legislation. \n2 S ee Chapter 1 for a detailed consideration of primary and secondary legislation. \n3 S ee Chapter 1 for a detailed consideration of layout of legislation. \n\n--- Page 208 ---\n     \n \n \n \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 177 \nTHE LAYOUT OF A STATUTE \nCentral to the analysis of statutes is the ability to understand how the statute is structured \nas a whole, and what the relationship is between the different areas of the statute. As discussed in detail in Chapter 1 there is a standard method of laying out statutes which, when recognised and understood, is helpful for analysis. \nA statute is generally divided into a preamble, parts, sections and Schedules. In \nsmaller statutes, parts and/or Schedules may not be used. \nEach part will deal with different aspects of the overall collection of legal rules and \ntheir meanings contained in the statute. These parts can be subdivided into several chap -\nters. Each part and any chapters are divided into sections (often abbreviated as ‘s’ (sin -\ngular) or ‘ss’ (plural)) which give more details in each area. \nAs appropriate, sections will set out legal rules, and deal with defnitions and adminis -\ntrative matters. Sections can be further divided with the use of Arabic numerals into sub -\nsections (abbreviated as ‘sub-s’ (singular) or ‘sub-ss’ (plural)). Sub-sections are capable of further division, with the use of Roman numerals, into paragraphs (abbreviated as ‘para’ (singular) or ‘paras’ (plural)). Paragraphs can be further divided with alphabetical ordering into sub-paragraphs (abbreviated as ‘sub-para’ (singular) or ‘sub-paras’ (plural)). \nSections are used to simplify navigation through the statute, and section numbering runs \nconsecutively across any divisions into ‘parts’ or ‘chapters’. They are not used in Schedules. \nAt the end of the statute, there will often be Schedules (a capital ‘S’ is always used) \nand these are numerically divided as well. These deal with matters raised in the various parts, perhaps setting out administrative procedures to be observed or defnitions to be applied. But note that Schedules can also contain defnitions. Schedules only relate in some manner to previous sections in the Act. They cannot create anything new. \nStatutes also contain marginal notes, headings and sub-headings. These are organising \ndevices and are not part of the law. You will recall that the words in a statute setting out legal rules are referred to as ‘rules in a fxed legal format’. Only those words carry the law. \nCorrect understanding of the relationship between the different areas of the statute ena -\nbles the general layout of the Act to be ascertained. Assistance is also obtained from the ‘long title’ of the Act (which looks more like a long sentence describing the area covered by the Act). Figure 7 .2 shows the differing elements of a statute with a brief explanation of each one. \nUSING AND HANDLING A STATUTE \nUsually you will only need to deal with a few sections in a statute. It is always useful, how -\never, to be aware of the general purpose of the statute. The sections you are analysing and applying can then be seen as part of a whole. It is also important to know how the parts of a statute ft together, and understand when sections are connected to each other and should be read together and when they are not. \n\n--- Page 209 ---\n    \n \n  \n  178 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \n• Law in ÿxed verbal form ena cted by UK Parliament \n• Ref erred to by sho rt title \nPREAMBLE STATUTE \n• Each section may be divided into smaller numbered sub-sections using\n   Arabic numerals enclosed with brackets e.g. (1) \n• Sub-sections may come with Margins and Headers; these do not form pa rt of\n  the law PARTS \nSECTIONS \nSUB-SEC TIONS \nPARAGRAPHS \nSUB \nPARAGRAPHS \nSCHEDULES • First name of monarch • Long title of Ac t \n• Date of royal assent • Words of enact ment \n• A statute will usually be divided into a series of Parts (not all ar e, par ticularl y\n   if they are short statutes) • Each Part will tend to refer to a di °erent topic are a \n• Parts may come with Margins and Headers; these do not form part of the law \n• Each part is divided into smaller numbered sections using Arabic numerals. \n• Sometimes, when a statute is amended and sections are inser ted,\n  capitalised alpha markers are used e.g. A • Sections may come with Margins and Headers; these do not form pa rt of the law \n• Each sub-section may be divided into smaller paragraphs using Roman\n   numerals enclosed within brackets e.g. (ii) \n• Paragraphs may come with Margins and Headers; these do not form pa rt of\n   the law \n• Each paragraph may be divided into smaller sub -paragraphs using lower\n   case alphabetical markers enclosed within brackets e.g. (a) \n• Sub-paragraphs may come with Margin and Headers; these do not form part \nof the law \n• Makes further arrangements , or gives fur ther information concerning matters\n  already mentioned in sections. No new topic matter can be introduced in a\n  schedule, they can only refer to issues raised in parts and sections \n• They use Roman numerals in capitals e.g. IV \nFigure 7.2 Summary: The different elements of a statute \nThe Equality Act 2010 (EA 2010) will be used to assist you to understand: \n  the overall structure of legislation; \n  the importance of careful research to ensure that the legislation you have is the latest \nversion; and \n  the importance of understanding the layout of and links between individual sections. \n\n--- Page 210 ---\n     \n             \n \n  \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 179 \nExercises will be used to further your understanding. \nThe overall structure of legislation \nThose who draft legislation decide whether it should be divided into parts and/or \nSchedules. They also make decisions about the choice of language. Drafters try to ensure that as far as possible the language used in the statute is clear and general, making it both understandable and capable of being applied to new, but connected, situations. Generality of statutory language can cause interpretational issues. \nLegislation can be described as legal rules created in a ‘fxed verbal form’. The \nphrase ‘fxed verbal form’ means that only those  exact words in that order, as enacted by \nParliament, form the legal rule. We will come back to this point when we discuss statutory interpretation by the judiciary.\n4 \nWhen you are dealing with sections in a statute it is important to be aware that these \nsections are part of a collection of rules in the statute and they are linked by the fact that they deal with similar issues. You will need to fnd out which words or phrases used in sections have attached defnitions or defences and if there are any guidelines given in the statute affecting the application of a particular section. These can be set out in a sub-section of the section you are dealing with, in other sections of the Act. Defnition, for example, can be in Schedules attached to the Act. So it is never enough just to assume that the section or sections you have been referred to are the only sections you need to be aware of. \nYou should initially read the section carefully for clues as to defnitions elsewhere, and \nread the table of contents of the statute to see if there are any sections clearly referring to interpretational matters. This also assists you in gaining a more context-based idea of the statute, which is useful to have when considering your sections. \nThe screenshot in Figure 7 .3 shows you the frst entries in the online arrangement of \nthe Equality Act 2010 from the Westlaw database. As Westlaw contains academic journal articles and cases as well as legislation it is also ideal for locating cases, and academic articles that relate to the section(s) you are dealing with. \nWe will consider the information that is given in the Figure 7 .3 screenshot, which shows \nParts 1 and 2 of the Act; there are more, but these are not on the screenshot. This issue is discussed in detail in Chapter 6 . \nThe importance of understanding the layout of \nindividual sections and links between sections \nA basic skill that must be developed if you are to successfully understand and handle \nstatutes is being able to competently navigate sections with confdence, understanding the standard layout of a section. Section 9 of the Equality Act 2010 will be used to dem -\nonstrate how to begin to understand links between parts of a section. But at the time of accessing this section only these characteristics were protected. They cover a range of attributes that people may have, and the characteristics listed are protected by the Act. So if a person is discrimi -\nnated against because of their race this would be illegal under the Act as race is a pro -\ntected characteristic. We can also see that s 9 is necessary because it defnes what is meant by the term ‘race’. The term ‘race’ includes colour, nationality and ethnicity. Other sections in the Act defne each of the protected characteristics in the list in s 4. \nThe explanatory notes state that all of the protected characteristics were protected \nby legislation in force when the Equality Act was going through Parliament. However, it is noted that caste, as an aspect of race, was not protected. It is to be included in s 9 as an area that the minister may wish to add. Read s 9(5) again: note it is giving power for the future, and s 9(4) refers to ‘caste’. \n\n--- Page 220 ---\n     \n   \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 189 \nUnderstanding the impact of changes to statutes \nIt is important to know if the law you have is current. The original s 9(5) gives the min -\nister the right to add ‘caste’ to the list of protected characteristics, and for any use of s \n9 generally or s 9(5) specifcally you would need to check if this had occurred. It is easy to use the drop-down menu on the offcial government website to look for changes to legislation. In relation to s 9 of the Equality Act if you click on the changes to legislation box and expand it, you will see the changes and effects yet to be applied to the whole Act. \nSection 97 only applies to s 9 of the Equality Act 2010 and gives you a good example \nof the use of non-textual amendment. You are told what words to omit and/or add. Note too that only s 97 ss (2)–(4) amend s 9(5). The rest of the sub-sections in s 97 relate to the exercise of the minister’s powers. \nYou need to compare and contrast before and after the change to determine what has \nchanged and what this means. Table 7 .2 above sets out s 9(5) as revised by s 97 of the \nEnterprise and Regulatory Reform Act. \nThis change has a great impact because it opens up the protection of the Equality \nAct to those covered by the caste system. The addition of one word ‘must’ has changed everything. \nArmed with this information you are in a position to describe the changes and then \nconsider the impact of these changes, although at that point you will need to locate sec -\nondary sources to give you the views of academics and professional lawyers on these changes. \nActivity: questions on Section 9 \nThe following questions on s 9 of the Equality Act 2010 are designed to test the consolida -\ntion of the skills you are learning and to ensure that you have a frm foundation. It is also vital to understand how several sections are linked together within a statute \nto obtain a full picture of what the Act is providing. We will now do a guided exercise. \nGuided exercise \nLocate the Equality Act 2010 online on the www.legislation.gov.uk  website and click on \nthe table of contents tab. Scan down the contents and try and get an overview of \nPart 1, \nChapter 2 of the statute, which has the heading ‘Prohibited conduct’. Make a note of what you think it is concerned with before reading on. \nChapter 2 of the contents outlines the three ways in which the Act is infringed, by dis -\ncriminatory behaviour taken because a person has a protected characteristic and/or by harassing or victimising a person because they have a protected characteristic. \n\n--- Page 222 ---\n     \n  \n    191 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nReading s 13 of the Equality Act 2010 \nThis section deals with direct discrimination, one of the behaviours that is illegal if it is done because of a protected characteristic. Read the section carefully and after you have done so consider the following questions: \n(1) Using your own words describe what behaviour is directly discriminatory. \n(2) Write an explanation of the relationship between s 13(1) and Sub-sections (2)–(6). \n(3) Does s 13 contain within it a defence to direct discrimination or indicate that there is one elsewhere in the statute? \nFrom reading s 13 it can be seen that sub-section (1) defnes direct discrimination in general terms as treating someone less favourably than another because they have a protected characteristic. To know if a person had been discriminated against you would have to check an up to date list of protected characteristics in s 4 along with the spe -\ncifc defnitions of each of those protected characteristics. Remember how the protected characteristic of race in s4 is further defned in s 9, including the giving of examples. \nSection 13 in sub-sections (2)–(6) then sets out specifc details concerning when direct \ndiscrimination applies in slightly differing ways to certain protected characteristics. There is no general defence for direct discrimination. Each sub-section in s 13 makes clear the extent of protection within various protected characteristics. \nSome sub-sections are highly specifc, for example, s 13(6) states that breastfeeding \nis included in the protected characteristic of sex, but, however, when a discrimination claim based on breastfeeding occurs in the workplace this is not included in the defni -\ntion of sex. \nIt is also important to note in terms of linking sections together that s 13(7) states that s \n13 is subject to ss 17(6) and 18(7). This means that s 13 must be read in terms of the provi -\nsions in ss 17(6) and 18(7). Equally clear is the absence of any allowed excuse or defence in relation to a claim for direct discrimination. \nIn order to obtain a full and understandable reading of s 13 it has been necessary to \nrefer to s 4 listing the protected characteristics, and to note that in any given case the sections dealing with the defnition of each protected characteristic contained in other sections (e.g. ‘race’ in section 9) may need to be considered. Furthermore we learn the entire section is subject to ss 17(6) and 18(7). \nReading s 19 of the Equality Act 2010 \nThis section prohibits indirect discrimination. It is set out in a tree diagram below to assist with the identifcation of links between the section and its sub-sections. \nNote that s 19 of the Equality Act 2010 contains smaller linking words (e.g. ‘if’ and \n‘and’), which have been highlighted in bold for your ease of reference. These are impor -\ntant connectors (words that link one set of words to another), such as ‘if’, ‘and’ and ‘or’, \n\n--- Page 223 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n 192 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nsmall words that can be easily overlooked. But their function is to enable you to see which \nsub-sections and paragraphs or sub-paragraphs are connected and which, if any, are not connected. \nThe connectors between the sections, sub-sections, paragraphs and sub-paragraphs \nreveal the type and function of the connection. For example, if the connector between two sub-sections or paragraphs within that sub-section is ‘or’ the connector is indicating that two things are in the alternative.  ‘Or’ indicates an either/or situation. The connector \n‘and’ indicates that things on both sides of it have to be present. There is a major differ -\nence between saying ‘1 or 2’, and saying ‘1 and 2’. This distinction is important to bear in mind when reading a legal rule in a fxed verbal format. \nBefore reading on, answer the following questions based on your reading of s 19: \nActivity \nConsolidation questions: s 19 EA 2010 \n1 What is ‘indirect discrimination’? \n2 What conditions have to be met before the behaviour identifed as indirect discrimination is \nactionable? \n3 Does s 19 provide for a defence? \nFrom your reading of s 19, particularly its header, you will have noted that it is about \nindirect discrimination. It occurs when a ‘provision, criterion or practice’ relating to all persons in an environment covered by the Act, places a heavier burden on certain people due to their possession of one or more protected characteristics. \nA concrete example would be a business that listed its criteria for promotion: \n‘attendance at evening in-house training’. It is statistically proven that more women than men have childcare responsibilities in the evening, so fewer women are able to attend. Therefore such a rule is potentially indirect discrimination because it affects women more than men. \nSub-section 19(2)(d) allows a limited defence: if A can show that the provision, criterion \nor practice is a ‘proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim’ then it is not indirect discrimination. Everything depends on what a legitimate aim might be. \nThe phrase ‘legitimate aim’ is not defned in the legislation and therefore what it might \nmean will be a question for the judiciary to decide in cases. As precedents on its mean -\ning are decided by the senior courts any precedents will be read into the Act by courts determining whether a defendant has a ‘legitimate aim’. \nConsolidation exercise \nBefore moving on to consider statutory interpretation, the following exercise is designed to test whether you have a basic understanding of using legislation.
