Judges are called upon to interpret words in many types of legal document. We are only considering legislation and will start by con -\nsidering interpretation from a general perspective. \nThe general idea of interpretation \nIt can be argued that an interpreter creates something new when they engage in inter -\npretation. It could be the case that an interpretation that is triggered by an article, for example, bears no resemblance to the writer’s intention. \nJudicial interpretation \nThe majority of law cases deal with the interpretation of legislation. Senior (unelected) judges effectively have the fnal ‘say’ when they engage in statutory interpretation. This gives them an unprecedented power to determine the meaning of words in legislation enacted by the democratically elected Parliament.\n9 Issues of tremendous importance can \nbe raised when a problem about the meaning of a statutory provision goes before a court. \nImportant questions need to be answered, such as: \n  What does this section provide for? \n  How do these legal rules apply to this factual situation? \n  What is the general social impact of this legislation as a whole? \n  Does this legislation effectively deal with the matters it was intended to deal with? \nJudges must bring an interpretation in court; they cannot say ‘I do not know the mean -\ning of this legislation’ and decline to adjudicate a dispute. Additionally, when judges give their interpretation of legislation in the senior courts they can change the entire meaning of a statutory provision. The power of their authority ensures that their inter -\npretation is the given meaning, until another judge, or the legislature, changes that meaning. \nTHE NEUTRALITY AND OBJECTIVITY OF LAW \nIt is often claimed that the law is objective and neutral. Given the fuidity of law and its vulnerability to a range of external and internal factors, claims that it is neutral and objective can often seem compromised. How plausible is it to maintain the neutrality of \n9 It is also worth noting here that if a given Parliament has a substantial government majority (that is, there \nare a large number of government MPs compared with representatives from other parties) then it is the \ngovernment of the day that gets through the legislation that it wants, which may not be a democratic rep -\nresentation of the will of the majority of the people. \n\n--- Page 227 ---\n    \n \n \n 196 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nEnglish law when considering disputes between litigants as well as the state and the \nindividual? \nA frst question should be ‘What do we mean by the term “neutrality”?’. Academics take \ndifferent positions in relation to this question, depending upon their overall philosophi -\ncal or theoretical positions concerning the development and function of law. Certainly, it cannot be denied that the bulk of modern English law is a political creation of Parliament. This politically constructed law is then interpreted by judges in the court, who continue to mould it as they have done for centuries. Can we ever be certain that judges do not ‘tinker’ with the meanings of words or phrases in legislation to achieve an outcome that represents their partisan view? \nJudges are social actors with their own preferences whom we credit with the attempt \nto act fairly in judgment, despite themselves and their natural inclinations. However, at root a judgment is a subjective text and a student’s or a lawyer’s interpretation of that text is also subjective. Any interpretation should be tested against the text and evaluated to see if it is a plausible reading. \nIf we consider law to be like a feld, we could say that politicians determine the broad \nlandscape whilst judges determine where the gateways in and out of that feld might be. They do this by their chosen defnitions of rules or words, which are then applied to the facts of a particular legal dispute. Their reasoning is powerful as it can narrow or broaden the effect of law. \nThe rules of statutory interpretation \nHow do judges set about deciding the meaning of words? Words can change their mean -\ning over time, and courts will disagree over the meaning of words in differing time periods. \nMeanings, not perceived by those drafting the legislation, may lie latent in the words \nof that legislation. These can then be drawn out in court in a manner potentially defeating the supposed intention of the law, making the rule unft for purpose. Or interpretation may narrow or extend the meaning of the rule. Below, the three rules of statutory interpretation (the literal, the mischief and the golden rules) are discussed as well as the more recent approaches of the purposive rule and the teleological\n10 approach to interpretation. These \nrules are, however, rules of practice not rules of law. Therefore a question to pose to yourself is ‘Do judges really use the rules of statutory interpretation? If so, which rule do they use frst?’ \nJudges rarely, if ever, state that they are applying a certain rule of interpretation. Often, \njudges look to see if there can be a literal meaning to the words used in the disputed statutory rule. However, there is no rule that states that they must use the literal rule frst. Holland and Webb\n11 quite correctly assert that perhaps the better question relates \nto what style of interpretation judges use. Interpretation is more a question of judicial style than the use of interpretational rules. Indeed, should you attempt to use the rules of statutory interpretation as a guide in the interpretation of a statutory word or phrase, the \n10 An approach that looks at the purpose of the law and interprets it accordingly. This can involve looking at \nexternal documentation rather than just staying with the internal dimensions of the statute. \n11 J Holland and J Webb, Learning Legal Rules  (6th edition, Blackstone Press, London, 2006), 257. \n\n--- Page 228 ---\n     \n            \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 197 \nuselessness of the rules as an interpretational tool will become immediately apparent. \nHowever, as a justifcatory label they may have a function. As you gain experience in read -\ning judgments you will notice vast differences in judicial styles. Some judgments seem to be based on a blow-by-blow analysis of precedents and earlier usage of words; others seem to be based on tenuous common sense rationales. \nJudicial decisions based on the external  context of the statute should be identifed by \nthe judge. Sometimes this is the result of decision making that appears to be based on issues of public policy (a particularly favoured device in the 1960s and 1970s). Reliance on public policy rationale can be referred to as the ‘grand style’ or the ‘teleological approach’. \nThe meaning of a rule and words used to construct the rule can also turn on the form \nof the statute itself, that is, its internal  context. Judges who rigidly adopt the internal \napproach are often referred to as formalists.  Such judges say that they do not create law; \nthey fnd it. They fnd it by following the pathways of the rules of statutory interpretation by moving within  the statute. \nA closer consideration of the simplest defnitions of the rules of statutory interpretation \nenables the classifcation of the literal rule as the formalist  approach and the mischief rule \nas the teleological approach. The golden rule, of course, allows one to ignore the formal-\nist approach of the literal rule. It is most likely to result in a teleological approach as the judge, through the golden rule, is released from formalism! \nIt is therefore essential to have some appreciation of the approaches that the judges \ntake to the issue of interpretation. Without this appreciation you will struggle to fully understand the shifts in the meaning of legislation that can occur as it goes through the courts. \nMany court cases require senior judges to interpret domestic legislation (as well as \nEuropean legislation and treaties) in order to determine the outcome of the case before them. Also many appeals centre on doubt about the meaning of rules. \nWhen judges engage in statutory interpretation they have to: \n  apply legislative rules to various fact situations; \n  decide the meaning of words and phrases used in the statute (of course words can mean many things, and that meaning can change over time); \n  deal with judicial disagreement over the meaning of words. \nThe senior judiciary have developed a range of rules of interpretation (although they are not rules in a legal sense; they are more like conventions); however, they are strictly fol -\nlowed. These rules are the: \n  literal rule; \n  golden rule; \n  mischief rule. \nThe mischief rule has developed into the purposive rule and more generally into a tele -\nological approach to interpretation infuenced by the approach of European judges \n\n--- Page 229 ---\n    \n \n \n  \n 198 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nworking within a civil law legal system. This last approach is unsurprising as in cases \ndealing with EU law and also the law relating to human rights (which is embedded in the European Convention on Human Rights) judges have in the past been required by English legislation to keep to the decisions of the CJEU and the ECtHR. \nIn addition, over time, presumptions have also been established. These are pre -\nassumptions by the judiciary concerning certain matters. For example that Parliament would not intend to repeal a statute without expressly providing for this in later legislation. \nGeneral rules for approaching the language of statutes, which we call linguistic rules, \nhave also been established and they still tend to be expressed in Latin. Additionally there are identifable aids to interpretation both from within the statute (intrinsic aids) and per -\nmissible aids to interpretation from sources outside the statute (extrinsic aids). \nWe will now look at each of these groups, rules of statutory interpretation, presump -\ntions, linguistic rules and aids to interpretation in turn. \nThe three main rules of statutory interpretation \nThere are three main rules of statutory interpretation, which are set out below in Figure 7.12 . \nThe mischief rule as already noted also developed into the teleological approach and \ninstead of just fnding the mischief that the statute was intended to remedy, the judge looks for the ‘spirit’ of the Act. \nThe literal rule \nEssentially this rule states that words should always be given their ordinary, plain and literal meaning. If the words are clear those words state Parliament’s intention. Judicial decisions going back over a century agree that this rule is important for preserving the intention of Parliament and ensuring that the democratic parliamentary will is imposed by judges in courts. \nOne of the more interesting cases to demonstrate the literal rule is the criminal case \nof Whiteley v Chappell (1868).\n12 Whiteley was charged with impersonating a ‘person enti -\ntled to vote’, as he had pretended to be a dead person using that name when he voted. The defence argument in court was that a dead person could not vote; or more strictly according to the wording of the legislation was not ‘entitled to vote’. Therefore as the defendant had impersonated someone who was not entitled to vote he had not commit -\nted the offence. At the trial the judges agreed with this argument. \nNow, on a literal interpretation of the words of the offence of impersonating a ‘person \nentitled to vote’ this result causes no problems. Yet from the perspective of the law there is no doubt that had Parliament been asked if they had intended the offence to cover the circumstances of the case against Whiteley they would have said ‘Yes’. \nThis case demonstrates the ways in which it is possible for a literal interpretation to \nundermine the intention of Parliament. You may of course think that the legislators in \n12 (1868) LR 4 QB 147. \n\n--- Page 230 ---\n     \n   READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 199 \nMischief/purposive \nrule – look at the \nreason for the \nenactment of the \nlegisla\u000eon and decide \nthe meaning of the \nwords in this contextGolden rule – of \ncourse, some\u000emes \nliteral interpreta\u000eons \nare absurd and this \nrule says that judges \ndo not have to use the \nliteral rule in such \ncircumstances Literal rule – all words \nhave a literal meaning \nwhich is discoverable \nby the judge \nMischief /purposive \nrule – look at the \nreason for the \nenactment of the \nlegisla\u000eon and decide \nthe meaning o f the \nwords in this context do not \nliteral rule in such \ncircumstances \nThe three main rules of \nstatutory interpreta\u000eon \nFigure 7.12 The three main offcial rules of statutory interpretation \nParliament should have been more careful with their use of words in the legislation, to \nensure that it covered all possibilities. Should the judges, in deciding cases to their sat -\nisfaction in court, fll in gaps in legislation or is that the job of the legislator? Which is the correct path for justice and for interpretation? \nDrafting legislation is not a scientifc art and there will always be mistakes when the \ngeneralised words of a section in a statute do not cover all the specifc instances it should cover. In Whiteley , the statute was designed to stop fraudulent voting at elections by \npeople pretending they were someone else. Parliament only wished those entitled to vote to do so. Whiteley was not entitled to vote. But, as the statute did not list the specifc \n\n--- Page 231 ---\n    \n \n \n \n  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 200 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nscenario of his case, he was acquitted.13 What do you consider to be the best way out \nof this situation if it arose in court? Keep the facts of Whiteley  in your mind and consider \nwhether it would have been useful to apply the second rule of statutory interpretation to the case: the golden rule. \nYou may think that the decision in Whiteley  was in keeping with the section stat -\ning the offence. As there was no other section covering the situation it is right that Whiteley should have been acquitted. Maybe you take the view that Parliament can always amend the legislation to cover the situation in Whiteley.  But another argument \nis that using the literal rule led to absurdity and it should not have been applied. It is worth remembering that one person’s ‘absurdity’ may be another person’s ‘correct’ interpretation. \nThe golden rule \nThis rule states that the literal rule should be followed except on those occasions when to apply the literal rule would lead to absurd results or go against public policy. We can argue that the decision in Whiteley  led to absurdity, allowing a defendant to be acquitted \non a technicality. \nAnother classic criminal case illustrates the golden rule in operation: R v Sigsworth\n14. \nSigsworth had murdered his mother who had died intestate (that is without making a will). The Administration of Estates Act 1925 provided that in such cases the possessions and lands of the deceased go to the next of kin, who was the son, Sigsworth. The court ruled that in a case such as this it would be absurd to allow the son to proft from her death and refused to allow him to inherit, operating a principle of equity that ‘a person cannot beneft from his own wrong’. \nThe mischief rule \nThink of the Whiteley  case again, as we move on to discuss the last of the three main rules \nof statutory interpretation: the mischief rule. This rule in fact predates the previous two, fnding its source in Heydon’s  case.\n15 \nThe mischief rule states that if conditions of doubt arise in a specifc statute the judge \ncan look to the purpose of the Act and the mischief (the wrong) that it was supposed to remedy or prevent. Indeed the initial rationale for legislation was to correct weaknesses in the existing common law. So if a problem with interpretation arose in the court the judge chose the interpretation that best remedied the weakness in the common law. However, it was also extended to cover later legislation and new legislation dealing with mischiefs. \nIn 1980 Lord Diplock, in the case Jones v Wrotham Park Settled Estates ,\n16 made  clear \nthe usefulness and current status of the mischief rule. In his judgment, he took the oppor -\n13 The Law Commission 21 stated very forcefully that the main problem with the literal rule was that it places \n‘undue emphasis on the literal meaning of the words of a provision’ and this in turn ‘assumes an unattain -\nable perfection in draftsmanship’. \n14 [1953] Ch 89. \n15 (1584) 3 Co Rep 7a. \n16 (1980) AC 74. \n\n--- Page 232 ---\n     \n  \n    \n \n \n \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 201 \ntunity to state that the court should be able to say ‘yes’ to three questions before they can operate the mischief rule. \n(1) Can the court precisely ascertain the mischief the Act was intended to remedy? \n(2) Is it apparent that the Act failed to deal with it? \n(3) Is it possible just to state what additional words read into the Act would rectify the situation? \nWould these questions have been of use in Whiteley v Chappell? The court could have answered ‘Yes’ to Questions (1) and (2) above. And no doubt a few words aptly inserted into the relevant section would have resolved the situation. Why do you think they did not themselves think of applying the mischief rule? \nThe purposive rule \nThe mischief rule has been developed into the ‘purposive approach’, which locates a suitable interpretation that gives effect to the general purpose of the legislation. It is an approach of increasing importance and was recognised by Lord Steyn relatively recently in the House of Lords case of R (Quintavalle) v SS Health.\n17 During the course of his judg -\nment, Steyn stated: \nThe pendulum has swung towards purposive methods of construction. This change … has been accelerated by European ideas … the shift towards purposive interpre -\ntation is not in doubt.18 \nThe case of the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) v DHSS\n19 provides a good illustration of \nthe use of the purposive rule. The issue in the case concerned the correct interpretation of the phrase ‘registered medical professional’, a phrase used in a number of statutes. The Royal College of Nursing required a defnitive answer due to its use in abortion legis -\nlation. There were conficting interpretations. Does the phrase ‘registered medical profes -\nsional’ just refer to doctors or could it apply to nurses? \nThe RCN took the Department of Health and Social Security to court over the issue. \nThe court held by a three to two majority that abortions by nurses alone were lawful as the purpose of the Act was to stop back street abortions by medically unqualifed persons,\n20 \nand therefore for the purposes of the Abortion Act 1967 as amended a nurse was a ‘reg -\nistered medical professional’. \nThe teleological approach \nOne can also refer to a fourth possible rule, described as the teleological approach. This asks for a further leap in interpretation from the narrower constraints of locating the mis -\nchief the Act is designed to remedy, or locating its purpose, to looking at the spirit  of the \n17 [2003] 2 AC 687. \n18 In para 21. \n19 The Royal College of Nursing v DHSS [1981] 1 All ER 545. \n20 Ibid. \n\n--- Page 233 ---\n    \n \n \n \n 202 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nAct. It is also used in domestic courts when dealing with claims under the Human Rights \nAct, which require the court to take into account cases in the ECtHR. \nOther aids to statutory interpretation Presumptions \nPresumptions represent the accepted judicial view of the way in which manifestations of particular circumstances will be treated and understood, at least until tangible evidence to the contrary is produced. They tend to arise from theoretical and practical principles of the law. Examples of presumptions are: \n  legislation does not intend to change the common law unless this is clearly expressed; \n  legislation does not have retrospective effect (it cannot make unlawful law -\nful behaviour that occurred prior to the legislation being enacted) unless clearly \nexpressed; \n  Parliament does not intend to bind the Crown by law if this is not clearly expressed; \n  legislation does not intend to prohibit judicial review unless this is clearly expressed. \nLinguistic rules \nLinguistic rules apply to the way in which judges will approach the language of legislation in certain circumstances. These rules are known by their Latin tags, for example: \nejusdem generis (the same type); \nIf general words follow on from a list of specifed things the general words only apply to \nthings of the same nature on the list. A word therefore cannot be dealt with in isolation. \nnoscitur a sociis: A word is known by the company it keeps. expressio unius est exclusio alterius: to state one thing is to exclude another. ignorantia leges non excusat: ignorance of the law is no excuse. \nIntrinsic aids to interpretation \nIntrinsic aids to interpretation are the signposts within a particular piece of legislation to \nassist the reader to make sense of it (often referred to as aids that are ‘within the four corners of the legislation’). Taken to its logical conclusion this suggests that the whole of the statute needs to be referred to for meaning. \nIf you think back to the layout of statutes shown at the beginning of this chapter \ndirected to short and long titles, marginal notes, headers, the preamble and of course punctuation. Additionally any examples in the statute are considered to be intrinsic aids to interpretation. \nAll of these devices are not part of the actual law contained in the statute, but they \npoint to divisions of the statute and its words, and to issues of formatting. They are, as such, aids to interpretation. You will also see that Schedules are referred to as well as parts. Not all statutes have these, but when they are present there may be a sepa -\nrate interpretation section, or such a section may be included in the main body of the \n\n--- Page 234 ---\n     \n \n \n \n \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 203 \nstatute. All of these devices should be included. Schedules are part of the statute and are extremely important in determining the meaning of words or phrases. \nExtrinsic aids to interpretation \nExtrinsic aids to interpretation are the signposts outside  a particular piece of legisla -\ntion that assist the judge to make sense of it. These are of several types. There is a generic interpretation statute, the Interpretation Act 1978 that gives a defnition of words commonly found in statutes. For example, it states in s 6 that words referring to the masculine gender include the feminine (and vice versa). But be warned: any statute can give a different interpretation to these words. Additional extrinsic aids are described below. \nReference to earlier statutes using the same word \nCourts are able to look at the use of some words in earlier statutes for guidance on the meaning of a word, as long as it is clear that the use of the word is about the same matter. The Latin term in pari materia  is used to denote this action. \nDictionaries \nIf a word has no recognisable legal meaning the court is permitted to consult a dic -\ntionary.21 However, since words can change their meaning over time, different editions \nof dictionaries may include different defnitions. Obvious words whose meanings have changed would include, for example, ‘gay’. Each dictionary could also give a different perspective on a word. Which is the ‘right’ one? \nTravaux préparatoires \nIn many European legal systems working from variants of Roman law within civil code systems, courts are able to study public materials produced during the course of the journey from a draft to fnalised legislation. These documents are referred to as prepara -\ntory works or travaux préparatoires. \nHansard \nTraditionally UK judges were not permitted to look at documents produced before the Act was drafted (e.g. government reports, recommendations or other policy documents), or at any proceedings in Parliament as the bill was going through its journey to becoming an Act. These latter documents are recorded verbatim by Hansard. The underlying ration -\nale for not allowing access to this material is the fact that Article [IX] of the Bill of Rights 1689\n22 allows MPs to say what they wish within Parliament, stipulating that ‘Parliament \nought not to be... questioned in any court of law or place outside Parliament’. This had \n21 We have in other chapters referred to the case of Mandla v Dowell Lee [1983] 2 AC 803 which concerned \nascertaining the meaning of the word ‘ethnic’, and the case is a good demonstration of the problems of \nusing dictionaries to fnd the meaning of the word. See judgment of Lord Denning in the Court of Appeal. \n22 1688 c. 2 (Regnal. 1 Will & Mar Sess 2). \n\n--- Page 235 ---\n    \n \n           \n \n         \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 204 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nbeen widely interpreted to mean that it was not even permissible to look at Hansard, the \nverbatim record of the debates and committees in Parliament. \nHowever, a change was signalled in the case of Pepper v Hart .23 The judges in the \nHouse of Lords were of the opinion that Hansard could be referred to if: \n  the legislation that is the object of the statutory interpretation is ambiguous, obscure \nor leads to absurdity; \n  the document relied on relates to statements by the minister or promoter of the legis -\nlation, together with any other parliamentary documents as necessary to understand such statements; \n  the statements relied upon are clear. \nThe House said that this should only happen in rare cases, not as a matter of course. Six judges were in agreement with this course of action, but one, Lord Mackay, dis -\nsented. He argued that the practicalities involved would be tremendously expensive. Lord Bridge considered that the court would not use its power very much, although he was ini -\ntially proved wrong (concurrent with the greater use of this freedom, drawbacks became apparent). Exactly how much ambiguity suffces to open Hansard, and how clear must the minister’s statement be? \nBy 1996 the House of Lords was voicing concern about the freedom given by Pepper \nv Hart.\n24 Lord Steyn25 has even severely criticised Pepper v Hart in non-judicial situations \nsuch as after-dinner speeches or public lectures. The main issue is that, of course, any word in a statute can in certain contexts be thought ambiguous. Opening up Hansard for discussion and determination by the judges raised the possibility that understanding concerning the meaning of words and phrases could be completely overturned. \nIn 1995 a practice direction had been issued relating to the usage of Hansard material \nfor the purposes of statutory interpretation.\n26 This was repeated in a later consolidating \npractice statement in 1999 covering the Court of Appeal (Civil Division)27 and then later \nthe criminal courts.28 Now if a party to a case wishes to rely on Hansard, they must serve \ncopies of the extract and a short précis of their argument on the other party or parties at least fve working days before the hearing. \nSo, the decision in Pepper v Hart has had a mixed reception from the judiciary, and \njudges speaking extra-judicially have been highly critical of it.\n29 Doubtless it marks an \nimportant paradigm shift with regard to judicial interpretation. \nExplanatory notes \nThe department of state sponsoring bills now issues explanatory notes in important areas of law to guide the reader. They do not form part of the statute, are not authorised and \n23 [1993] 1 All ER 42 (HL). \n24 Brown Wilkinson LJ was one of the majority judges in Pepper v Hart , but in Melliush (Inspector of Taxes) v \nBMI (No 3) [1996] AC 454 he said that the ministerial statement had to be directed to the very point that is \nthe subject of doubt in the current case. \n25 J Steyn ‘ Pepper v Hart  A Re-examination’ (2001) 21 Oxford Journal of Legal Studies 59. \n26 Practice Direction (Reference to Extracts from Hansard) [1995] 1 WLR 192; 20 December 1994. \n27 [1999] 1 WLR 1059. \n28 [2002] 1 WLR 2870. \n29 K Llewellyn The Common Law Tradition  (Little Brown, Boston MA, 1960). \n\n--- Page 236 ---\n     \n  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 205 \nhave no legal effect. But such notes do have their uses, particularly as an aid to under -\nstanding the aim and intent of the drafter of the legislation. Those aims and intentions, however, can of course change during the act of interpretation in court. If you read the explanatory notes of legislation, you need to be aware that case law may have changed the interpretation laid upon a certain section, etc., by the explanatory notes. \nInterpretation Act 1978 \nThis Act sets out a range of issues relating to interpretation. The Act provides general meanings for words (e.g. that the masculine always includes the feminine and vice versa unless it is specifcally stated that this is not to be the case). \nWhich rules of interpretation should be used, when, and in what order? The rules of \ninterpretation that have been so far identifed are not, themselves, legal rules but guid-ance rules. And you will not be surprised to learn that no legal rules exist that state which rules of interpretation can be used, nor their order of use. What we should consider, however, is how judges choose the appropriate rules of interpretation applicable to the job at hand, and how they explain that choice. Some might say judges merely want to be seen to have a method so that they are not accused of just creating law, but you would be better off thinking of statutory interpretation as allowing the use of a range of styles of interpretation. Everyone is different, and individual judges prefer and use different styles of interpretation. \nNearly 50 years ago, long before the development of cases such as Pepper v Hart , Karl \nLlewellyn\n30 noted that judges in fact have two styles of interpretation: the grand style and \nthe formal style. The formal style is quite rigid in its deference to tradition, doctrine and the view that judges should not and do not create law. The grand style is used by judges who are more creative and fexible in their use of interpretation.\n31 \nStatutory interpretation and the European \nConvention on Human Rights \nThe Human Rights Act 1998 (HRA 1998) gives claimants the right to go to a domestic \ncourt to bring an action for infringement of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). This requires the judiciary to interpret the Convention. \nThe HRA 1998 states that in doing so they must recognise the decisions of the European \nCourt of Human Rights. Section 2 of the HRA imposes a statutory duty on courts; they must take account of decisions of the ECtHR and the Committee of Ministers. \nSection 3 imposes a positive statutory duty on courts when interpreting primary and \nsecondary domestic legislation to do so in a manner that is compatible with ‘convention rights’ set out in Schedule 1. \nThe requirement for courts to take into account the case law of the ECtHR has exerted \nan impact on the way that English judges interpret both legislation and case law. The \n30 An excellent case study of Llewellyn’s observation can be found in the case of Davis v Johnson  [1978] 1 \nAll ER 841 (CA) affd [1978] 1 All ER 1132 (HL). It is also the subject of an excellent case study by Twining \nand Miers How to Do Things with Rules (2013). An informative and interesting summary of this area is also contained in Holland and Webb Learning Legal Rules (6th edition, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2006). \n31 Is this not another description of the teleological approach? \n\n--- Page 237 ---\n    \n \n \n \n 206 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nEnglish judiciary have had to make changes to their standard methods of interpretation of \nstatutes.32 In those areas where the courts have a duty to consider the case law from the \nEuropean courts they confront a major difference. In English court cases it is customary for dissenting judgments to be published. These are judgments expressing a particular judge’s disagreement with the majority decision of the court. Even where several judges agree on outcome they can disagree on the detailed route they took to their agreement. Each judge can choose to issue a judgment; therefore, in English courts judges are used to dealing with several judgments in previous decided cases that they may be consider -\ning. However, it is customary for the ECtHR to give one decision and the reasons given for their decision are usually less detailed than in English courts, although at times a dis -\nsenting judgment may be published.\n33 \nThis does not mean that English courts do not give reasons in cases dealing with the \nECtHR, but the cases it receives at the European level have to be incorporated into their decisions and these cases come from a different legal tradition where the detailed ration -\nale for the decision is not expected or required.\n34 Although it is accepted that these cases \ndo in fact lay down frm guidelines that need to be followed. \nStatutory interpretation and secondary legislation \nIt is not just primary legislation that calls for statutory interpretation. There are thousands of pages of secondary legislation published each year, and these too can become central to legal disputes prompting a need for interpretation. More or less the same rules apply as those that we have already briefy noted, but with secondary legislation there are also extra tasks and issues that require consideration. \nSecondary legislation has to be read in conjunction with the parent Act. The \nInterpretation Act 1978 states in s 11 that words used in the secondary legislation must be interpreted to have the same meaning as words used in the parent Act. But, if the parent Act itself is vague, the court will probably have to consider the meaning of both. \nWhilst primary legislation has hierarchical standing over common law, secondary leg -\nislation does not. The courts, therefore, will not wish to apply an interpretation that dis -\nlodges established common law. Whilst courts cannot declare a primary Act invalid, they can declare secondary legislation invalid if the powers delegated have been overstepped. \nSummary to statutory interpretation \nThis brief discussion reveals the different approaches to statutory interpretation that can occur as one case travels through the judicial system. It is worth noting that the rules of statutory interpretation that a judge is applying are not generally referred to in the course of the judgment. Context and judicial attitudes or preferences determine the rules used. \n32 See further Chapter 12 . \n33 This was done in the case of Al-Skeiniand others v United Kingdom  (Application no. 55721/07; Reported: \n(2011) 53 EHRR 18; 30 BHRC 561; [2011] Inquest LR 73; Times , 13 July 2011. \n34 That is, deciding current cases on the same basis as previous similar cases in the Court of Appeal or \nSupreme Court depending on where the case is currently being heard – there is more discussion on these \nmatters in the chapters covering case law. \n\n--- Page 238 ---\n     \n   READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 207 \nOnly careful analysis of the judgment will indicate the ‘styles’ of interpretation that seem \nto be represented. \nInterpretational problems can never be solved by the neat application of interpretational \nrules. Even worse, perhaps, the rules do little or nothing to solve problems. Perhaps all they do is justify solutions. There is rarely one right answer, only a range of more plausible and less plausible outcomes, varying according to interpretational styles. Judges use their creativity in working out a solution according to criteria that must be rational either in real-ity or in argument. They invariably go beyond the text when constructing answers. Lord Denning, for example, moved from dictionary defnitions to subjective assertion. Often, judges say no more than ‘this is the answer because I say so’. \nJudges, as previously noted, can be classifed as formalists or contextualists. Knowing \nthis it may sometimes be possible to guess which rules the judges are using, though sometimes you may not understand what they are arguing. At times, judges themselves are wrong and not too sure themselves of the appropriate outcome. This is what makes comprehension of the methods of statutory interpretation, and the use of precedents, so diffcult. It is essential to realise the limits of a supposed scientifc approach and the limitless possibilities that open up when the illogical bridges from one set of rationales to the next are located. \nAs judges have engaged more with the European dimensions of interpretation they \nengaged more often with the teleological approach used in European cases. As dis -\ncussed in Chapter 4 , the Human Rights Act 1998 states that judges deciding cases on \nthe enforcement of European Convention rights must  have regard to the case law and \njurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights. \nCONCLUSION \nThe majority of English law is in the form of legislation. Understanding statutory provi -\nsions context is a core skill for the competent critical evaluation of the rationale for a par -\nticular statute. It is also core for the competent legal analysis and application of statutory provisions when engaging in legal problem-solving. \nBeing able to understand the layout of statutes, and of sections within them, as well \nas appreciating the links between sections in a statute, and between several statutes, ensures that you are in a good position to begin the task of understanding the detail of any legislation you are dealing with. \nCompetent analysis of legislation also involves the equally important skill of reading \ncase law. It is essential to also be aware of any leading cases determining the meaning of words and phrases in the legislation you are considering, and understand the process of statutory interpretation. \nWhilst many databases can assist you with fnding a statute and then searching within, \nit is essential to appreciate that there is only one offcial source of legislation, the govern-ment’s online database, www.legislation.gov.uk, which is hosted by the National Archives. \n\n--- Page 239 ---\n    \n   \n   \n  \n  \n  \n  \n  208 READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  A range of skills need to be used to understand legislation: language skills, substan -\ntive knowledge skills, argumentative skills and rule handling skills. \n  Correct understanding of the relationship between parts, chapters, sections, sub -\nsections, paragraphs, sub-paragraphs, marginal notes, headings and Schedules \nenables the general layout of the Act to be ascertained. \n  Always use up to date, reliable academic or professional sources to ascertain whether legislation is current. \n  The only offcial source of information on statutes and changes to them is the govern -\nment’s online database at  www.legislation.gov.uk. \n  When statutes do not defne the meaning of words in them and a legal dispute is before the courts the judiciary engage in statutory interpretation. \n  There are three conventional ‘rules’ of statutory interpretation developed by the judi -\nciary: the literal, golden and mischief rules. \n  The mischief rule has given rise to the purposive rule and the teleological approach. \n  Judges also use presumptions, linguistic rules and intrinsic and extrinsic aids to interpretation. \n  When secondary legislation is the object of statutory interpretation it must be read in conjunction with the parent Act. \nCONSOLIDATION TO EXERCISE (COMPARISON BETWEEN S 9 OF THE \nEQUALITY ACT 2010 AND S 3 OF THE RACE RELATIONS ACT 1976) \n(1) What general language differences occur between the two sections? \nThe language in s 3 of the RRA 1976 retains the old format of ‘he’ meaning \n‘she’ in general terms. Provision for this is made under the Interpretation Act 1978. \nSection 6 provides: \nIn any Act, unless the contrary intention appears, \n(a) words importing the masculine gender include the feminine; \n(b) words importing the feminine gender include the masculine; \n(c) words in the singular include the plural and words in the plural include the singular. \nHowever, s 9 moves away from masculine and feminine and adopts the more neutral words ‘person’ and ‘persons’ instead. \n(2) Which section is the easier, if any, to understand? \nI would suggest that s 9 of the EA 2010 is easier in terms of using a much more \nstraightforward layout. It is more logically set out, particularly in terms of distinguish -\ning between race and racial grounds. \n\n--- Page 240 ---\n     \n  READING AND UNDERSTANDING LEGISLATION 209 \n(3) What major differences are there between the two sections? \nSection 9 of the EA 2010 introduces the concept of ‘caste’ into the defnition of \nrace, and racial grounds. \nSection 9 does not include the reference to the comparison set out in s 3(4) of the Race \nRelations Act 1976. In fact this is found in s 23 of the EA 2010 and is now applied gen -\nerally (unless expressly excluded in relation to any protected characteristic). This was ascertained by looking down the sections in \nPart 2 of \nChapter 2 and noting one was sub-\nheaded ‘comparison by reference to circumstances’. \n\n--- Page 242 ---\n8 \n  \n READING AND \nUNDERSTANDING CASES \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Understand the rationale and theory behind the doctrine of precedent. \n  Explain the doctrine of precedent. \n  Appreciate the difference between theoretical and practical considerations of \nprecedent. \n  Competently read a case and prepare a case note. \n  Identify the constituent parts of the ratio  of a case. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-10  \n\n--- Page 243 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n   212 READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES \nINTRODUCTION \nAn understanding of the doctrine of precedent is essential for the successful study of law. \nIn this chapter we will briefy consider the theory of precedent before focusing on practi -\ncal advice for reading a judgment by a judge or judges determining cases in a court of law. This chapter will also explain how to read both individual and related cases and look for the links between them. Finally, strategies will be suggested to help you break down the language and argument of a judgment. \nLEGAL DISPUTE RESOLUTION IN COURT \nThe few legal disputes that cannot be resolved by negotiation or another alternative dis -\npute resolution (ADR) process (some of which are considered in \nPart 4 of this book) are \ndetermined by judges in the trial courts and, in an even smaller number of cases, by the senior judiciary in the appellate courts. The word ‘few’ must be stressed here: only about 4 per cent of all formally commenced disputes reach a hearing in court and many of these settle at the doors of the courtroom. \nT\nhe decisions of judges are delivered orally in court when the judge may read a pre-writ -\nten judgment or speak from notes. These words spoken and recorded constitute the text that contains any legally binding rules. At the time of delivery, the judge’s words are usually recorded verbatim by the court stenographer. In addition, law reporters, employed by pub -\nlishers, may be in court taking shorthand notes. The record of all judgments will be kept by the court. But some decisions, thought to be important to the development or understand -\ning of the law, will also be published commercially as a ‘law report’. Each publisher will structure their reports differently, perhaps adding footnotes or summaries, but the words attributed to the judge have to remain a true and accurate record of those spoken. \nUsually, judges in the civil courts and the appellate courts (both criminal and civil) will \nrefect upon the case before reaching a fnal decision – holding back, or reserving, judg -\nment until a later date. In criminal cases the judge may sentence immediately after the jury has reached a verdict in the trial court, or call for reports and sentence at a later date. What judges say in their judgments is of immense importance, not only for the litigants but for the development of the law. \nThe phrase ‘common law’ has different meanings according to the context in which \nit is used. One of its meanings relates to the legal rules developed by senior judges when deciding cases in the appeal courts (the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court). Common law, when used in this sense, relates to legal rules that are not created by the authorisation of Parliament but through the acts of the most senior judges in the English legal system.\n1 \n1 T here has been, and continues to be, much argument among legal philosophers as to whether judges \nactually make  or create  law ‘out of nothing’ through their reasoning, or merely declare  what the law has \nalways been. Many judges state that they do not make the law, they discover it and thus declare what it \nhas always been. This latter viewpoint is referred to as the declaratory theory  of law making. \n\n--- Page 244 ---\n     \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 213 \nINTRODUCING PRECEDENT \nIn the English legal system if a judge knows that the case before the court is similar to an \nearlier decided case then the current case must be decided in keeping with the reason -\ning process used in that previous case. There are certain criteria that must be followed in determining not only whether the current case is similar to a previous case, but whether the court is bound, which depends on the court’s position in the hierarchy of courts.\n2 This \nprocess is known as the ‘doctrine of precedent’. The doctrine is referred to by the use of a Latin phrase: \nStare decisis et non quieta movere: ‘to stand by decisions and not disturb the undisturbed’. \nIn practice this phrase is shortened to: \nStare decisis:  ‘to let the decision stand’. \nThe practice of precedent is not a legally imposed requirement but one that has been developed as a matter of custom and practice in the higher courts since the nineteenth century. Although most legal systems have some notion of previous decisions being taken into account when new cases are decided, in the English legal system it is a prac -\ntice enforced by the senior judiciary with an unparalleled rigour which makes the English legal system unique among all  others. \nA key part of a lawyer’s job is to research previous cases to help predict the outcome \nof the current case – after all, there is no point in going to court if the exact point the client wishes to make has already come before a court and been determined to his detriment. The doctrine of precedent as it stands is therefore a useful tool, although the possibility of a different interpretation being placed, for example, on the meanings of words that were previously thought to be settled can never be ruled out. \nPersuasive precedents \nIn addition to those precedents that are binding there are also a group of precedents that are persuasive only. That means that they are of suffcient standing to be taken seriously but are not binding because they are from another common law legal system, or from the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council. For example, the case of Attorney General of Jersey v Holley\n3 was a Privy Council case. However, it had a bench of seven judges, all of \nwhom were also senior judges in the House of Lords at that time. Because of this the case dealt with identical law to the English, but took a different approach and clarifed doubts. That case was subsequently referred to in the English senior courts and precedents were set using it as a persuasive precedent. \n2 S ee Chapter 2 for a discussion of the hierarchy of courts. \n3 law \nprinciple developed by judges, it will always overrule common law.4 Judges therefore must \nimplement statutory law even if it is in confict with existing applicable common law rules. \nRequirements for an effective system of precedent \nThe doctrine of precedent requires: \n  An effective system of law reporting and/or an effective system of accessing court \ntranscripts of judgments. \n  A clear hierarchical court structure. \n  Clear rules of practice setting out the duties of and responsibilities of judges in each court with regard to the doctrine of precedent. \nHierarchy of the courts \nThe hierarchy makes clear which courts can overrule the decisions of other courts in appeals\n5 and is fundamental to an understanding of when a given court is bound by a \nprevious case. \n4 S ee Chapter 1 on the sovereignty of Parliament. \n5 S ee Chapter 2 \n\n--- Page 246 ---\n     \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 215 \nGenerally a court is bound by precedents of those courts that are above it in the \nhierarchy, and by precedents previously established in the same court, though there are \nsome exceptions. Each court is responsible for drawing up its own practices. Changes are made by ‘practice statements’, which are published in the law reports. \nUnderstanding the theory of the doctrine of precedent \nMany legal theorists and practitioners have attempted, over the years, to give precise defnitions of the English doctrine of precedent. No one is completely right or wrong and the defnitions vary. However, a few theoretical ground rules can be established, which at least place the operation of the doctrine of precedent within a context we have already discussed. For instance: \n  judges at all levels of the court hierarchy must follow  similar decisions of the higher \ncourts; \n  judges in the Supreme Court have the freedom to decline to follow their own previous \ndecisions. \nFrom a theoretical as well as a practical point of view, this strict adherence to precedent brings the following benefts to the legal system: \n  certainty of the law; \n  curbs arbitrary decisions; \n  maintenance of equality; \n  provides a rational base for decision making. \nSome argue that the doctrine also brings disadvantages. It can:   make the law infexible; \n  force legal change to be slow and convoluted; \n  encourage tedious hair-splitting tendencies in legal argument. \nKey to the operation of the doctrine is the meaning of ‘similar’, which we will now consider \nin light of differing academic views. \nWhat does ‘similar’ mean? \nHow similar must a previous case be before it becomes a precedent? The facts of cases usually vary in some way and the doctrine does not specify that the case must be identi -\ncal. Sometimes, legal representatives will strenuously argue that previous cases are not precedents because they can be distinguished on their facts. In other words, they are not similar. \n\n--- Page 247 ---\n216 READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES \nQ: Must the law in the \nbinding case be similar to \nthe law now? are small di˜erences in \nthe facts of each case? The same \nmaterial facts, the legal rule although \nbinding case will possibly perhaps in another place \nbe applicabl e may cons°tute 'similar' \nFigure 8.2 Q & As on similarities \nThere is no single defnition of the word, ‘similar’, and this is where the judge can bring \nsubjective infuences into the decision making processes. He or she can determine what \n‘similarity’ is in the current case weighed against the precedent; in this way, extremely subtle ‘differences’ can be found between two cases. \nLaw is about life and life rarely replicates itself exactly, but trends and degrees of simi -\nlarity can be noted. Figure 8 .2 sets out some questions that are important to the issue of \nsimilarity: \nDealing with the slippery issues of similarity is a diffcult and interpretative exercise. \nBut once you are able to determine that a previous case is similar, then the next one must consider ‘how can the reasoning in the case be extracted?’ \nFinding, understanding and using the reasoning in a case \nCases defned as similar must also be decided in accordance with the same reasoning process, since the actual doctrine of precedent refers to adherence to the reasons  for \ndeciding past cases. But how does one fnd that reasoning? \nWambaugh,\n6 a late nineteenth-century American theorist, suggests that one way of \nascertaining the reason for the decision (the ratio decidendi ) is to look for a general rule \nof law in the judgments and test whether it is foundational for deciding the case by trans -\nlating it into the negative form. You can then see if the case would have been decided differently. This negative method of fnding the ratio  or rule is illustrated in Figure 8 .3. \nAnother respected legal theorist, Goodhart, wrote an infuential article that refers far \nmore to the principle  in the case than the ratio.\n7Goodhart emphasises the consideration \nof facts: \n  What are the material facts, as found by the judge? \n  What is the judge’s decision? \n  Unless there is a new material fact (or there are some missing material facts) a future \ncourt, depending upon its place in the court hierarchy, and thus its obligations under the doctrine of precedent, must follow it. \n6 E Wambough, ‘The study of cases 1894’ cited in R Cross and JW Harris Precedent in English Law \n(Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1991), 52–3. \n7 A Goodhart, ‘Determining the ratio decidendi of a case’ 22 MLR  117. \n\n--- Page 248 ---\n     \n \n  \n   \n \n  \n  READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 217 \nExtract a propos i\u0014on  of law \nChange  its formu la\u0014on to the nega\u0014ve \nApply the nega\u0014ve form ula\u0014on to \nthe case \nIf the outcome  is the same, the \niden\u0014fed  proposi\u0014on of \nlaw is NOT the ra˛o of the \ncase \nIf the  outcome is the same, the iden\u0014fed \nproposi\u0014on  of law IS the ra˛o of the \ncase \nProblem: thi s method is designed to work only with one proposi\u0014on of law \nThere can be more than one proposi\u0014on in a case. \nFigure 8.3 Wambaugh’s method for location of the precedent \nA major problem with Goodhart’s suggested method is his emphasis upon the facts. \nAlthough it can be said that reading a judgment in the light of the facts of the case is a core requirement of the doctrine, attention also needs to be given to the way that the case is: \n  argued; \n  pleaded (exactly how have the lawyers formally lodged the complaint?); \n  reasoned. \nin relation to other precedents. \nWambaugh, Cross and Goodhart’s methods are summarised in Figure 8 .4. \nEven when considered together, there are still problems. Goodhart \nstates that person, \nplace, ˜me, kind and \namounts should be \nassumed to be so \nunless expressly said \nto be material Goodhart \nmaintains that the \njudge creates law \nby his choice of \nthe material fact s It is found by taking into \naccount all facts treated \nas material by the \njudge. Each \ncan give judgment, although often a judge will simply concur. Often in an appeal case there will be a clear majority in agreement with regard to both the outcome of the case and its supportive reasoning. A majority judgment by the senior judiciary in agreement \n\n--- Page 250 ---\n     \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 219 \non outcome and reasoning creates a strong precedent as it represents the ratio of the majority of the court. \nAt times there may be one or more minority judgments. In such cases, there will be \nagreement with the majority view that a particular party should win the case – that is they agree on the outcome. However, there may be disagreement with the majority view of the legal reasoning process leading to that decision. Each of these minority judgments represents a reasoned judgment with a ratio.  Unless all of those in the minority agree with \neach other, it is possible to have several different ratios. If several respected senior judges \nagree in their minority judgment, then it is possible to argue in certain circumstances in a later case that the precedent of the majority should be overridden in favour of the minor -\nity view. \nThe implementation of the doctrine of precedent is diffcult in those cases where there \nis no clear preferred ratio.  But what if the different judges in a case agree on the outcome \nand disagree on the reasons for that outcome? \nJudges may also dissent on the outcome but either agree or disagree with the majority \nratio.  Dissenting judgments do not form precedents. But it is possible with the passage of \ntime that the dissenting view comes to be considered the prevailing view and later courts may be able to privilege that dissenting judgment. \nA lack of agreement among judges about the reasoning process can weaken the prec -\nedent value of the case. \nConsider, for example, these two different scenarios: \n  The majority of judges agree to dismiss/allow the appeal on one ground. A minor -\nity of judges agree with the majority as to the outcome, but base their decision on a different ground. In this situation, the ratio  of the majority is binding and strong. \nThe ratio of the minority may become the object of weighty consideration in a future \ncase. \n  The majority agree to dismiss/allow the appeal, but there is no common ground as to why the appeal has been dismissed or allowed. In this situation, there is no clear majority in favour of any ratio. The case, therefore, lacks authority for the narrowest interpretation of the ratio. It is impossible to state clearly how such a case is viewed \nother than to treat it as a weak authority. \nIt is diffcult, if not impossible, to come up with a clear formula that will always work for ascertaining the ratio  of a case. Law is organic, about life, not mechanics. But a \nreasonable idea of the diffculties in ascertaining the ratio  is a necessary and revealing \nstep for any interpreter. Ignoring these diffculties will ultimately lead to simplistic and inadequate construction of legal arguments. If an argument is being made on weak, tenuous or stretched grounds, it is better to know that it is. Deciding whether a case is a precedent involves consulting a wide range of sources and using a broad range of skills. Counsel for the respondent argues that \nit is not binding on you. Both have also referred you to cases B and C. As part of your legal studies, you will be expected to read cases both in isolation and as a series of cases which (over the course of years) develop a principle of law or which demonstrate how a principle of law has been retained or changed. \nImagine that you are sitting as a judge in the Court of Appeal civil division and you are \ndealing with an appeal court case, Case E. Counsel for both parties have to have followed Case A. Cases in the Court of Appeal and Supreme Court. \nYou will need to ascertain from an objective, neutral perspective which, if any, of these \ncases are binding on you. As you will know from your understanding of the court hierar -\nchy, that the Court of Appeal binds and is bound by the Supreme Court. \nYou should then look at the facts of the cases and the legal rules applicable as well \nas the grounds of appeal in each case to determine at a basic level whether the case is similar and therefore potentially binding on you. \nYour method might look like this: \n  Ascertain the material facts of Case A and consider whether they are similar to the facts in Case E. \n  Ascertain the legal rules applicable in Case A and consider whether they are similar to the legal rules to be applied in Case E. \n  If you are dealing with similar facts and legal rules the Case could well be binding. \n  Ascertain the ratio (or ratios)  applicable in Case A and consider whether you agree \nwith the formulation as given by counsel. They may have given conficting formula -\ntions and you will have to ultimately agree with one not the other. \n  Consider the judgments in Cases B, C and D and their discussion concerning the ratio in Case A and the reasons for fnding themselves bound by it. \n  Finally, formulate a rule of law based on your interpretation of Cases A, B, C and D, and apply this to your reasoning in Case E. \nInterpreting precedent in practice \nPart of the lawyer’s particular expertise is in knowing how to quickly look through past cases to fnd relevant decisions which either support or oppose a client’s case. Searches can be made, frst, to pinpoint cases dealing with specifc legal rules. A range of cases with similar facts can then be pulled from this frst trawl of data. After careful reading, the lawyer must then construct detailed arguments drawing on those similarities with other cases that will support the client’s position, or negate the potential precedent value of cases that would not help the client. This latter skill is called distinguishing , and it is par -\nticularly important for those who wish to argue that a precedent should not be followed. \n\n--- Page 253 ---\n    \n         \n 222 READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES \nA lawyer may need to argue convincingly that the part of the previous judgment that \nthe opposing counsel is relying upon is not part of the reasoning process leading to \njudgment; that it was an ‘aside’ comment, based on a hypothetical situation (technically referred to as an obiter dictum  comment). On the other hand, this may be the only argu -\nment that a lawyer has to support the client’s position. If an obiter dictum  comment was \nmade by a senior judge in the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court, and it is of direct relevance to the exact circumstances of the present case, then it could be argued that this is an important indicator of what that court would do if such a case came before it. \nWhere there is more than one judgment, the lawyer’s task in ascertaining the strength \nof a precedent may be more diffcult. It is possible that a dissenting judgment could even -\ntually come to represent the majority view of an area of law. If the judge who is dissenting has a particular reputation for excellence, then the dissenting judgment will be seriously considered by those coming to read the case for the precedential value of the majority judgments. \nAn understanding of the doctrine of precedent and the ability to locate the reasoning in \na case or series of cases is vital if the lawyer is to succeed in any of these tasks. \nThe practical implementation of the doctrine of precedent \nUnfortunately for law students there are no simple shortcuts to understanding the practi-cal everyday working of the doctrine of precedent in the courts. You will need to read, make notes on, interpret and think about the judgments you are reading and be confdent in your ability to handle and use law reports. \nHandling law reports \nFigure 8 .6 sets out the issues to be considered when handling law reports. \nEngaging with the language of judgments \nLaw reports can present a challenge to students both in terms of their legal content and their usage of sophisticated and complex language. It is useful to consider the law report not just as an offcial public document but also as a literary text.\n8 The examples and illus -\ntrations used may be drawn from many spheres, including politics, history, art, religion or literature. They may include quotations from different languages or be liberally peppered with Latin legal maxims (such as stare decisis). \nYou will need to develop your skills in reading, language and writing in order to be able \nto obtain: \n  a good grasp of the relevant area of substantive law; \n  an appreciation of issues relating to language usage; \n8 In recent years a growing number of scholars have become interested in exploring law as a literary text and \nin exploring literary texts as mirrors of the law. See T Ziolkowski The Mirror of Justice: Literary Refections \nof Legal Crisis (Princeton University Press, Princeton, 2003). For a classic work of fction exploring the ideology of law you may be interested to read F Kafka, The Trial  (Random House Press, New York, 1956). \n\n--- Page 254 ---\n     \n \n  READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 223 \n1. \nCOURT • Name of the Court \n• e.g. Supreme Court \n2. \nCASE \nNAME • Case Name: • e.g. George Mitchell v Finney Lock Seeds \n3. \nCITATIONS • Cita˜ons • Neutral cita˜on post 2001. There may have been a general agreement that such a rule existed, but no such rule had been specifcally created by a court or Parliament. These can be described as cases that are sources of law . They are strictly binding on courts according to their \nplace in the hierarchy. \n(2) Those cases where the judge(s) are grappling with the meaning of legislative words and phrases in order to determine the case. These are cases involving statutory inter -\npretation , that is, the judicial determination of the meaning of words and/or phrases \nin a statute. Here the decision of a senior court concerning the meaning of those words is treated as binding in subsequent cases until challenged. \nFrom the mid-twentieth century the majority of cases have fallen into category 2: statu -\ntory interpretation. Often this application will be purely a matter of routine, but sometimes doubts will arise about the meaning of words in the relevant legislation. The rules of statu -\ntory interpretation are discussed in more detail in Chapter 7 . \nReading a law report: a series of guided exercises on 1983 case of George Mitchell \n(Chesterhall) Ltd v Finney Lock Seeds\n9 (George Mitchell case) \nWe will now turn to a range of practical demonstrations concerning how to read a law \nreport using the George Mitchell case. We will approach it using a range of detailed exer -\ncises and studies which, taken together, are designed to demonstrate a methodology for the competent reading of law reports, taking case notes, evaluating the case, and using it to construct legal arguments. \nWe will deal with: \n  The anatomy of a law report, being comfortable with print and online formats. \n  Obtaining a general overview of the case. \n  Best practice when writing case notes. \n  Breaking into text generally and specifcally. \n  How to engage in a detailed reading of the judgment in this case to assist with under -\nstanding and summarising. This is also designed to help you follow the analysis in the case of a complex issue of the relationship between the common law limiting liability \n9 [1983] 2 AC. \n\n--- Page 256 ---\n     \n \n \n \n      \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 225 \nfor loss and protective statutory rules that run alongside them prohibiting the use of the common law rules if certain statutory criteria apply. \n  Evaluation of the case to use it in the construction of legal argument. \nTo best use these studies and exercises for the development of your understanding of reading law reports and the law, it would be ideal if you have the Westlaw database ver -\nsion of the case open as well as the Westlaw pdf of the print version. While you will effec -\ntively have two windows with seemingly identical text, the print version layout is different and this should be noted. \nThe anatomy of a law report \nBefore you can read a law report with confdence it is essential to understand the layout of standard law reports. Indeed it is crucial to understand how a law report is compiled and to distinguish between the notes by the barrister who is reporting the case, earlier hearings prior to the appeal you may be reading and the judgments in the case you are reading. \nOnly the judgments given by the judges are the legal part of the report, capable of \nmaking common law or interpreting the existing common law and statutory law with legal authority. \nFigure 8 .7 shows you the differing parts of a law report, although you will not fnd these \nheadings in the report itself. This will show how far you can get by close and careful reading without a detailed knowledge of the law (in this case, the law of contract). \nThis exercise requires your active  engagement. You will be given the context of the \ncase, so that you are not working completely in the dark, before being guided through several stages of reading. \nThe context of the case \nWhilst you do not need any pre-knowledge for this exercise it is of course useful if you understand the legal context of the dispute in a case. For this reason, the basic frame -\nwork of the law of contract is set out in Figure 8 .11. The triangles denote the basic stages \nof making a contract, living or keeping it, and ending it. \nA contract is a legally binding agreement between two or more parties. Usually a \ncontract will contain provisions that outline the compensation payable to one party should the other break the contract by not fulflling their obligations under the terms of that contract. \n\n--- Page 260 ---\n229   READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES\nThe events which occur in George Mitchell  are summarised in the square by the tri -\nangle labelled ‘Ending it’. Look at the circular flow of reasons for ending the contract and \nnote what each one is. This case does not concern a mutual agreement to end the con -\ntract, or it coming naturally to an end. This case is set in the text box dealing with one of \nthe parties being accused of breaking the contract, and as a consequence compensation \nis requested.Figure 8.11  The basic framework of the law of contract\n\n--- Page 261 ---\n    \n  \n  \n  \n      \n  \n    \n  230 READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES \nThe facts of the case \nThe contract in this case concerned the purchase of cabbage seed by George Mitchell, the plaintiff company (now referred to as the ‘claimant’) from Finney Lock Seeds, the defendant company. The contract contained a clause stating that damages for breaking the contract (breach of contract) were subject to a damages limitation clause. This clause provided that if the seeds were defective, any damages payable would be limited to the replacement of the seeds purchased. The buyer would not be compensated for any other loss, for example, loss of profts due to having defective seeds. The plaintiff company engaged in industrial farming and purchased the cabbage seeds to grow for the next year. The seeds proved defective and the crop failed, leading to large proft losses. \nThis case is particularly interesting because it is an example of a situation in which \ncommon law rules, created by the judges in previous cases, can operate alongside statu -\ntory rules dealing with the same subject. \nThe basic reading of the case \nTo identify the main issues in the case requires some determination. If you are able to master the methodology used here, you will be able to apply it to other cases. \nStage 1 has been divided into four tasks for you to engage with: \n(1) Locate the case online or in print, and turn to the judgment of Lord Bridge. Read it as quickly as you can but ensure you understand what you are reading, and time yourself. Do not take notes. If this reading takes you more than 60 minutes you need to work on your reading strategies generally. \n(2) Now read the entire law report, being aware of the different types of information given: \n(a) names of the judges; \n(b) court and dates of appeal; \n(c) catchwords added by the publisher; \n(d) summaries of the fnding in previous courts dealing; with this case, constructed by the reporter; \n(e) summaries of the arguments of counsel for both parties; \n(f) all judgments will be reported as near to verbatim as possible; \n(g) the outcome of the appeal you are reading. \n(3) The judgments that you read are the part of the law report that contains the law. As you read the judgment note how each paragraph begins and ends. You will often fnd signposts to meaning at the beginning and end of paragraphs, and they may contain indicators of the progression of a discussion or argument. Note any technical language. Look up words you do not understand in a good English dictionary or law dictionary. Try and extract the issue that is the ground of appeal and the reasoning that has led to the outcome in the case. Write summary notes as you go along to help your understanding. \n\n--- Page 262 ---\n     \n  \n  \n  \n   \n \n \n READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 231 \n(4) Finally summarise in writing, in no more than 200 words, what this case is about: \n(a) Identifying the court, facts and legal issues relevant to the appeal; \n(b) Indicating the reasons for the decision in this case. \n(i) You will fnd that knowledge of facts or of the applicable rules taken alone will not help you identify the reasoning in the case. You need to look for passages in the text that discuss the reasons why those rules applied to those facts, which led to a particular outcome being decided by the court. \nDo not proceed any further until you have quickly read the case and completed the above Tasks 1–4. \nConsideration of your summary for task 4 \nLook at your summary and compare it to the example case summary below. \nSummary of George Mitchell v Finney Lock Seeds  [1983] 2 AC 803 \nThis is an appeal case in the House of Lords. The appellant, a commercial agricultural company \nplaced an order for a specifc type of seed. The supplier sent the wrong seeds and the crop failed leading to a large loss of profts. \nThe contract between the appellants and respondents for the supply of seed contained a \nlimitation clause limiting compensation payable to the cost of replacement seeds. The major fnancial loss incurred by the buyer due to the wrong seeds being sent was far in excess of the cost of the seeds. \nThe trial court said that the seller was liable to pay full compensation. The seller appealed to \nthe Court of Appeal and lost. He then appealed to the House of Lords and again lost on the grounds that the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 took priority over the operation of the common law rule allowing such limitation clauses. \nA particular complicating issue concerned whether the contract was made within a range of \ndates specifed in the legislation. \nAt trial, and on appeal to the Court of Appeal and on appeal to the House of Lords, the buyer \nwon the case. The court held that although at common law the limitation clause was operative, it was rendered inoperative by the application of the Unfair Contracts Act 1977. Therefore the buyer was entitled to receive compensation from the seller for loss of profts as well as the replacement of seeds. \nAlways consider what a reader of your summary needs to know to make sense of the \ncase, and apply it to other situations. \nWhat is useful in the suggested case summary \nIt gives a full summary of the facts, and details the reasons for the dispute and makes clear the issue at stake is whether a common law rule on limitation clauses should apply or \n\n--- Page 263 ---\n    232 READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES \nwhether the common law here is inoperative due to the application of the Unfair Contract \nTerms Act. However, it still has problems: \n  We do not have precise information on the grounds of appeal, just generalised \ngrounds. You must always give the specifc grounds of appeal. \n  We still do not know why  the Court of Appeal decided the case as it did. We are just \ntold that the court noted the common law provision was inoperative because of the Unfair Contracts Terms Act 1977. We do not have the reasoning in the case. Yet, the reasoning is key for an understanding of the operation of the doctrine of precedent. \n  We do not know the case law establishing the common law rules. \n  We do not have precise information on applicable statutory rules. \n  We do not have the basic information on the judges sitting and the dates of hearing. \nIf your summary contained all of the information in the suggested case summary above, you are certainly on the right track. If not, do take the time to consider why you did not pick up on the points in the summary. It is particularly important to know the procedural history of the case. Look at Figure 8 .12, which gives information on this point gained from \na reading of the headnote and confrmed in reading of the judgments. Remember, details in the headnote could be wrong so do check in the judgments. \nWe will return to these summaries at the end of this chapter in the section ‘writing a \nusable case note’. Constructing a competent case note of a law report is the core skill for all students and practitioners. \nHow to break into diffcult text \nDuring the drafting of your case note you may have found it diffcult to identify and under -\nstand the main issues in the case. Whilst it may not be too diffcult to locate the specifc sentences where the judge says what the issues are, you may have to work hard to under -\nstand the narrative, as the judgment will inevitably include unfamiliar vocabulary or legal references, complex grammatical structures and dense text. \nIn his judgment Lord Bridge gave a particular label to the limitation clause at the centre \nof the case. He called it ‘the relevant condition’ and identifed two issues in the case on page 811 in paragraphs G–H of his judgment. \nG The frst issue is whether the relevant condition, on its true construction in the context of \nthe contract as a whole, is effective to limit the appellant’s liability to a refund of the price of the seeds (‘the common law issue ’). The second issue is whether, if the common law issue is \ndecided in the appellant’s favour, they should nevertheless be precluded from reliance on this limitation of liability pursuant to the \nH provisions of the modifed s 55 of the Sale of Goods Act 1979, which is set out in para \n11 of Schedule 1 to the Act and which applies to contracts made between 18 May 1973 and 1 February 1978 (the statutory issue ). \nLord Bridge on page 811 (print or pdf Westlaw version). \n\n--- Page 264 ---\nREADING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES 233  \nFigure 8.12  The procedural history of the case \n\n--- Page 265 ---\n    \n  \n  \n 234 READING AND UNDERSTANDING CASES \nAlthough at frst sight this text is diffcult to follow, note that Lord Bridge gives the two \nissues in the case shorthand labels, as set out below.
