Often, the diffculty with legal rules is that they need \nto be general and need to be applied to specifc, particular situations. This means that the wording of legal rules needs to be carefully considered. But inevitably these words will be the object of interpretation. That a rule seems applicable may be clear, but the precise meaning of an important word or phrase may not always be. \nStatutory rules in our simple majority democracy often refect the political values of \nthe party in power. They can, therefore, be described as instruments of policy. Whatever the original intention of the political designers of the statutory rule, when users of these rules come to interpret them, defects in design are often apparent because words can, so often, be made to mean what the originator did not intend them to mean: another reminder that language is fexible. \nConstructing arguments \nNow that a little thought has been given to: \n  the meaning of argument; \n  critical thinking; \n  the nature of problems and rules; \n  the mediating power of language. \nit is hoped that the complexity of any attempt to solve problems by recourse to rules is \nbetter appreciated. Now we are in a position to consider how to argue. \nHow to argue \nIt is essential that lawyers are able to construct arguments and use effective reasoning to resolve legal problems. Without that core skill, a lawyer lacks competence. One of the diffculties of legal argument is that the answer to a legal problem in court is rarely clear cut. All the evidence will not necessarily have the same degree of plausibility, or be of the same strength. The law may be unclear, and all of these issues need to be ordered into the best argument that can be constructed. This is why argument involves the deploy-ment of imagination and creativity alongside an understanding of applicable legal rules and the problems they address. \nThe good news is that argument construction utilises a number of preparatory skills \nyou have already engaged with: \n  fnding appropriate texts and choosing the most useful; \n  summarising texts; \n  researching and organising texts; \n  critique and analysis; \n  collecting appropriate materials in order to persuade the listener of the validity of the \narguments presented. \n\n--- Page 311 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 280 CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT \nReasoning involves: \n  preparation and collection of information; \n  ordering and organisation of information; \n  working through the information once the issues that it supports are clear. \nWhen people set out on a journey, they normally have an idea of where they are going. If \nthey do not know where they are going, this is usually a matter of deliberate choice. When you begin to consider argument construction, you need to know where you are going: ‘to begin with the end in mind’. If you do not know where you are going, you may become exhausted and frustrated and end up arbitrarily writing in your essay or problem solution, words that imply ‘therefore, this is the end’. It is not possible to craft a good argument by accident. Having said that, useful information to include as evidence for an argument may be uncovered accidentally. However, the argument itself can never be accidentally or mind-lessly constructed. It is a technical ability that must be understood and practised knowingly. \nEvidence \nLegal argument is a delicate balance of propositions backed by evidence. Such evidence will depend on the context of the argument and could involve facts, legal rules and theo -\nries. If the dispute is a legal problem, argument construction will be concerned with the application of existing rules connected by reasoned comments to persuade the listener of the validity of adopting the outcome suggested. In the courtroom, both parties put for -\nward arguments and the judge chooses the argument that is either the most persuasive or the closest to the judge’s own belief concerning the outcome of the case. Evidence substantially increases the persuasiveness of an argument. An argument that is a series of propositions not backed by evidence is unlikely to succeed in any area of study or dispute resolution. On your course you will need to engage with tasks that require you to apply legal rules to hypothetical fact scenarios in legal problem solution activities. \nThe role of judicial judgments in argument construction \nWhen reading judgments, you will note that judges present their decisions in the form of reasoned responses to the questions posed by the case. In the trial court, conficting claims are resolved by a judge or multiple judges, and in the senior courts, judges con -\nsider the grounds of appeal. The case will be decided on the basis of the most persuasive argument when it comes to the specifc grounds of appeal. Obviously, that decision can be quite subjective – something that you see as a good argument for you might not be a good argument for the judge. \nThe reasoning most valued within law demonstrates a consistency of approach and \nlogic; consistency is highly valued. However, the law is not, and cannot be, a closed sys -\ntem. Analytically there are always other possibilities, which inevitably means that much \n\n--- Page 312 ---\n    \n CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT 281 \nlegal decision making is contingent. There may be a better solution, and if one is located \nin another case then decision making may change according to the restraints of the doc -\ntrine of precedent. \nNo argument can ever be 100 per cent sound and our legal system requires less than \nperfect proof. In a civil court the contingent nature of legal decision making turns on proof based ‘on a balance of probabilities’. This means that when the arguments of litigants are weighed against each other, one litigant’s argument appears to be more probably cor -\nrect. In the criminal trial courts the contingent nature of legal decision making is demon -\nstrated by the requirement that the court fnds that the prosecution, or the defence, has ‘proved beyond all reasonable doubt’ the correctness of their argument. So, accusing someone of not having a perfect argument is not in itself a good argument. \nFor the practising lawyer, a valid argument is of the utmost importance. In the class -\nroom, you are constantly called upon to practise and refne your skills in legal problem-solving by engaging in reasoning processes leading to full-scale argument construction. \nIt is now time to explore and apply the more formal aspects of general argument con -\nstruction: logic, deduction and induction. \nLogic \nIt is generally believed that academic and professional lawyers and, indeed, law students are skilled in the art of legal reasoning, which rests on logic. Furthermore, it is believed that they are people who argue ‘logically’. To most, the term ‘logical’ indicates that a per -\nson can separate the relevant from the irrelevant and come to an objective view, based often on supposedly objective formulae. Colloquially, people sometimes accuse those who change their mind or who are emotional in their arguing, of allowing their emotions to get the better of them, of ‘not being logical’. \nThe dictionary defnes logic as the science of reasoning, thinking, proof or inference. \nInference involves drawing a conclusion from something known or assumed using reasoning. \nLogic can even be defned as a science in its own right, a sub-branch of philosophy \nthat deals with the scientifc method in argument and the uses of inference. The German philosopher Georg Hegel described logic as the fundamental science of thought and its categories. It can certainly claim to be an accurate form of reasoning: its root is found in the Greek word logos meaning reason. \nIn natural sciences, things are relatively easy (please do not show this to a natural \nscientist!): a physicist sets up an experiment and observes what happens – the evidence is usually quite clear. Lawyers, however, are usually not there to observe what happens and have to rely on a variety of different evidence: witness statements, statements by the parties themselves, evidence obtained by forensic science, photos, videos and so on. All of that evidence has to be compiled and evaluated legally before presenting it and using it in an argument. \nIn logic, people deal in statements or ‘propositions’. In the context of logic, the word \n‘proposition’ can be most simply explained as a statement or assertion about something. \n\n--- Page 313 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n  282 CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT \nMore particularly it is a statement that is put forward as the basis of an argument that \nbrings evidence for or against its validity. A proposition is expressed as a sentence. In the science of logic, the proposition takes on a more formal role as a particular type of sentence statement in which the topic of the sentence, the predicate is affrmed or denied concerning the subject of the sentence. \nTo put this more simply in English the predicate of a sentence is that part of the sen -\ntence in which you are told something about the subject. The subject is what the sentence is about (a person, a category, a class or concepts). In a formal argument it is expected that there is proof for the predicate in the proposition. \nEssentially, logic is the study of propositions and how conclusions may be correctly \nobtained from them through the process of reasoned argument. There are two main types of logical reasoning: deduction and induction. Each of these will be discussed below. \nDeduction \nDeductive reasoning occurs in an extremely stylised manner and follows a standard pro -\ncedure and structure. It is the process by which two statements (propositions) containing information are used to construct a third concluding statement. This draws out of the precise wording of the previous two propositions, new information to express by way of a concluding statement. \nStatements are variously called ‘premises’ or ‘propositions’. There is no permission to conclude by way of plausibility or probabilities: the third \nstatement conclusion can only be extracted from the linguistic forms making up the major and minor statements. Therefore the conclusion of a deductive argument is said to be compelled, and the reasoning system is closed. The formal model used for this argument is called a syllogism. \nIn deductive reasoning, the argument follows a prescribed form called a syllogism, as \nset out in Figure 9 .7. The frst statement in a deductive argument is known as the ‘major \npremise’ and it is a general or normative statement; the second statement is known as the minor premise and it is particular rather than general. The third statement is the conclusion. Figure 9 .7 sets these three statements out as the component parts of deductive reasoning. \n• A major premise – which tends to \nstate a generality \nThis form of \n• A minor premise – which tends to argument is called \nstate a par\u0007cularity a syllogis m \n• Conclusion \nFigure 9.7 The components of a deductive reasoning argument \n\n--- Page 314 ---\n    CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT 283 \nTo give a concrete illustration we will consider the fctional character of Anna, who is \naccused of stealing a book from a book store, an act that is contrary to s 1 of the Theft \nAct 1968, which prohibits stealing. The argument against her can be set out as follows: \nMajor premise: stealing is contrary to section 1 of the Theft Act 1968. \nMinor premise: Anna has stolen a book. Conclusion: therefore Anna has committed theft under s 1 of the Theft Act. \nYou may already have noticed from this scheme of argument that deductive reasoning \nleaves no space for examining the truth or otherwise of the premises making it up. It is therefore of limited use within a legal context. This leads us to note that in fact whilst a deductive argument can be logically valid (that is it is expressed in the correct form) it cannot be assumed to be true. We can easily verify the truth of the major proposition (that stealing is against s 1 of the Theft Act) by checking the primary law. But we have no way of knowing if the minor proposition is true without a full trial. The proof or otherwise of the major and minor premises is outside the remit of deductive reasoning. \nAnalytically there are always other possibilities. A deductive syllogism can be useful \nwhen a precedent is being teased out for the frst time and its logical consequences need to be tracked. It is also useful for pinpointing exactly what aspects of a legal rule have been infringed. \nInduction \nInductive reasoning involves arguments that put forward a frst particular proposition, or thesis, followed by a series of propositions relating to facts and evidence. The last propo -\nsition, or conclusion, is drawn out of the previous propositions. One of the most important differences from deductive reasoning is that the reasoning system is open, meaning it can be possible for more than one conclusion to be drawn. It is based on inferences. Then decision makers need to choose the conclusion they consider the most plausible in light of the arguments presented to them. \nAs with deductive reasoning, the conclusions are based on propositions. However, in \ninductive reasoning, the conclusion reached extends beyond the facts in the premise. It is not compelled; it is drawn out. The supporting propositions make the conclusion prob -\nable, but there is no one absolutely clearly correct conclusion as there is for deductive argument. \nAn inductive argument can, for example, have as an inference a generalisation, such \nas ‘innocent people do not run away’. Different types of generalisations are set out in Figure 9 .8. \nA generalisation can be quite easily challenged as it is usually constructed on fimsy \narguments. Inductive argument is perhaps the closest to the everyday legal argument where decisions are made concerning which party to a legal dispute wins the case because their ‘story’, in terms of the law’s authority about the way current law applies to \n\n--- Page 315 ---\n   \n  \n  284 CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT \nGeneralisa\u0017ons \nScien\u0017fc \nlaw/opinion Widely held, \nshared conclusions \nof common \nexperience (e.g. \ninnocent people \ndon't run away) Biases, prejudices, \nheld irrespec\u0017ve \nof data or \nopera\u0017ve beliefs \nFigure 9.8 Types of standard generalisations which can fnd their way into inductive argument \ntheir claim, is accepted by the court, a story that will have been made up of a range of \nmain and subsidiary arguments. \nLike deductive reasoning, from a purely scientifc point of view, inductive reasoning \nhas no interest in the actual truth of the propositions that lead to the conclusion. The court, on the contrary, is most concerned with establishing that the conclusion is cor -\nrect and that the propositions are correct. Just because a logical form is correctly con -\nstructed, it does not mean that the conclusion expressed is true. The truth of a conclusion depends upon whether the major and minor premises express statements that are true. The statements may be false. Much time is spent by lawyers in court attempting to prove the truth of statements used as building blocks in the construction of arguments. \nThink back to our one-line propositions above about Anna stealing a book. The pros -\necution may argue she stole the book because she was seen leaving the store with it. The defence will wish to argue that she did not. Or the defence may argue, say, that she did not leave the store intending to take the book but intending to look at the quality of its colour plates in daylight. Both sides will have to support their argument with evidence. The side that the court decides has the stronger argument backed by evidence will win the case. \nAnalogous reasoning \nA subdivision of inductive reasoning is reasoning by analogy or analogous reasoning. The Greek word ‘analogy’ means likeness, or similarity, and is used to describe the equality of ratios of proportions in mathematics. In logic it expresses the resemblance of attributes between two or more things. \nAnalogous reasoning is used in English legal reasoning. Lawyers in the courts argue \nfrom rules developed in previous cases on the grounds they are alike. As you may realise this is the reasoning required by the doctrine of judicial precedent. In doing this they rea -\nson from the general to the particular, applying abstract generalised rules from previous cases to the particular current case. \n\n--- Page 316 ---\n    \n CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT 285 \nLogical fallacies \nSomething to be aware of, both when constructing your own argument and when dis -\nsecting an opponent’s arguments, are logical fallacies. This means drawing conclusions \nthat appear logical, but are in fact wrong, something you can often observe in political debates, personal arguments, but also in the courtroom and in academic writing. \nThere are plenty of examples for logical fallacies, and with some practice in critical \nthinking, you will be able to spot many of them yourself. They often are deceptive – the human brain likes taking shortcuts, and many of these fallacies exploit that characteristic. Typical examples are strawman arguments (exaggerating the opponent’s argument into an obviously undesirable extreme – ‘raising welfare benefts will mean that lazy people who don’t want to work can live in huge houses with swimming pools’), false equivalences (describing two different things as equal – ‘sure, most murderers are men. But have you thought about the fact that a lot of pickpockets are women?’), false dilemmas (describing a situation with only two outcomes when there are more – ‘if we don’t implement this wel -\nfare plan, thousands of people will starve’) or ad hominem  attacks (personal attacks that \nhave nothing to do with the actual argument – ‘the fact that you have no children shows that your opinions about the future are irrelevant’). \nCONCLUSION \nHopefully, this chapter helped you to understand how a good argument is built so that you can construct and dismantle arguments yourself. With this skill, you can not only convince others of your standpoint, but also understand how others try to convince you, take that argument apart and identify its weaknesses. This is the key to success in any area – inside and outside of the university. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  An argument is a series of statements, some backed by evidence, some not, which are purposely presented in order to prove, or disprove, a given position. \n  Problem-solving models can help you work in order through the key steps. \n  A good model for law is Twining and Miers’ Diagnostic model (clarifcation, percep -\ntion, evaluation, identifcation, prediction, prescription and implementation). \n  If a legal problem is wrongly diagnosed, any argument constructed will be as fawed as the erroneous diagnosis in the frst place. \n  Deductive reasoning is a closed system of logic in which the only possible conclu -\nsion is compelled from the major and minor propositions. \n  Inductive reasoning is an open system of logic in which the probable conclusion is drawn out of the propositions. It can result in more than one conclusion. \n\n--- Page 317 ---\n   286 CONSTRUCTING AN ARGUMENT \n  Analogous reasoning is a subspecies of inductive reasoning. It is the preferred \nmethod of argument in the English legal system. In analogous reasoning general rules from previous cases are applied to a particular case to seek a solution to the issue in hand. \n  Reasoning itself cannot always prove or disprove the facts of a case. \n  The civil courts resolve issues based on an argument being considered on a balance of probabilities to be correct. \n  The criminal courts resolve issues based on an argument being considered to be correct beyond all reasonable doubt. \n\n--- Page 318 ---\n10 \n  \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Embark on the task of writing your law essays. \n  Take and organise your notes whilst researching. \n  Structure your essay in a convincing way. \n  Begin to develop your own written voice. \n  Make references to the work of others. \n  Avoid accusations of plagiarism. \n  Submit a nice and coherent essay. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-13  \n\n--- Page 319 ---\n   288 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nINTRODUCTION \nProbably the most common form of assessment used in law schools is the essay. During \nyour study, you will be required to write a lot of them, critically analysing laws or cases, questioning decisions or discussing statements. Like no other form of assessment, an essay gives you the chance to delve deep into a topic and to explore it from all angles. Many (probably most) undergraduate degrees and more or less all postgraduate degrees also include the task of writing a dissertation: a longer essay for which you usually deter -\nmine the topic yourself with the help of your supervisor. \nThe module leader will set a maximum word count for the essay, and it is important \nthat you stick to it. This can be frustrating – often you run out of words with many more ideas to write down. But it is crucial for success. Your lecturer did not choose this word count because she wanted to make your life more diffcult or because she is too lazy to read more, but because being concise is an essential skill to learn as a law student and as a lawyer. Most universities have strict penalties on exceeding the word count – some deduct points according to how many words you went above; others draw a line at the allowed number of words and ignore the rest (which means the lecturer will most likely not read the clever conclusion you wrote!) – make sure you are aware of these and make sure you do not encounter them. If you encounter this regularly, check your writing style (see below) and try to avoid anything that is not strictly necessary for your argument. \nLecturers often use standard words to formulate the essay question, and you can see \nan overview in Table 10 .1. \nDespite these differences, the requirements for an essay are always the same: \n  Discussion of academic texts and in many cases legal texts. \n  The construction of arguments in order to write the essay. \n  The use of critical thinking. \nApproaching the essay question \nChoosing the topic \nThe frst task you often face is to pick an essay question. Some module leaders give stu -\ndents multiple questions to choose from, and in a dissertation module you normally have to work out the question yourself. \nPicking a question is not easy, but it is important not to overthink it. Module leaders \nchoose questions that enable you to give good answers – contrary to student opinion, the choice of question does not in itself determine the mark of the essay. Read all the ques -\ntions carefully and think about which of the topics interested you the most. Once you have chosen a question, stick to it unless you run into a complete dead end – last-minute topic changes are a common source for bad marks and sometimes even failure! \n\n--- Page 320 ---\n    \n  \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS 289 \nTABLE 10.1 DEFINITION OF STANDARD WORDS USED IN ESSAY \nINSTRUCTIONS \nActivity word Defnition \nAccount for Give a detailed explanation of events with reasons for those events (what is \nit and why is it). \nAccount of Give a detailed description, but just to tackle ‘What’, not ‘why’. \nAnalyse Break down one or several things into their various parts; and detail how these parts interact. \nArgue Maintaining a given position based on evidence. \nAssess Weigh up the strengths and weaknesses, the pros and cons of the issue(s) raised. \nClarify Make clear: which could mean to intelligently simplify or explain a theory, institution or process; or to clearly differentiate between two things. \nComment on Demonstrate understanding of what the question or quote is asking/ saying and then give your answer backed by evidence from academic sources. \nCompare Identify both similarities and differences between two things (this could be two judgments in two cases or the same case, or it could be between different ideas on legal reform). \nConsider Give your thoughtful view of a matter backing it with relevant academic evidence. \nContrast Oppose several ideas, processes, judgments or texts, and bring out differences. Whilst similarities should be noted the main thrust of this word is to speak of difference. \nCritically evaluate Careful consideration of an argument and its evidences drawing out hidden assumptions, and determining your view of the strengths and weaknesses of arguments and/or evidences. You should discuss any material that does not back you. \nCriticise Identify arguments about theory or cases, question existing beliefs and assumptions, making a judgment based on the persuasiveness and authority of the sources you have located as the basis for your answer. \nDefne Set out the meaning or the interpretation of a word or phrase; in law there may be competing meanings in which case you may be asked to give a view as to which is best. \nDemonstrate Show how something is done and give examples. \nDescribe Set out the main characteristics of an object or a concept, or give a chronological account of what is happening in a given situation. \n(Continued ) \n\n--- Page 321 ---\n   \n  290 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nTABLE 10.1 (CONTINUED) DEFINITION OF STANDARD WORDS USED IN \nESSAY INSTRUCTIONS \nActivity word Defnition \nDiscuss Conduct an investigation of an area to consider and evaluate the strengths \nand weaknesses of arguments coming to an overall conclusion on that area or process. \nElaborate Information will have been given in the question or a quotation; your job here is to add more detail to the given information. \nEvaluate Determine the value of something. \nExamine A meticulous look at the key issues related to a topic which you then need to critically evaluate. \nExplain An intelligent clear description of how something can be understood, defning words as needed. \nExplore Looking at a topic from differing analytic perspectives to present an argument backed by evidence. \nIdentify Determine the main issues to be dealt with. \nIllustrate This is very much like ‘explain’ or even ‘demonstrate’; you need to show how something works using evidence to back your explanation. \nInterpret Display your understanding of arguments, words, process, research or a given topic and discuss relationships between items and theories by putting forward your view as to what they mean and ensuring that you support your view with evidence. \nJustify Put forward your views with reasoning and support it backed by academic evidence. Presenting an argument that is well-considered and takes into account opposing positions. \nOutline This is a request to give a general, explanatory discussion of an area. \nReview Critically evaluate an area or topic, assessing its strength and weakness with evidence. This is often a two-part question, with a second part asking you to interpret or explain etc. \nShow how Similar to giving an account of (see above). \nState Lay out the main issues relating to a topic with reference to available evidence. \nSummarise Produce a brief précis of the relevant area only composed of relevant material or information. \n\n--- Page 322 ---\n    WRITING LAW ESSAYS 291 \nChoosing a dissertation topic is even more challenging. Normally, the dissertation \nmodule comes at the end of your studies. By now, you must have preferences for which \ntopic interests you the most, and in your lectures, discussions or news consumption you might have come across questions or situations that frustrated you about the state of the law. These are often the best dissertations: students have seen a problem and want to address it. Do make sure that you manage to stay objective in such a case, though. If a topic is too close to your heart to remain objective and to give honest consideration to the other side of the argument, it might be better to avoid it. Make sure to use the opportuni -\nties given by the module leader and the lecturer you would like to use as a supervisor to discuss the topic before deciding on the title. \nRefecting on the question \nThis is an exercise in basic English comprehension as well as an intellectual act, requiring a considered and methodical approach. You need to draw out all of the possible issues raised by your essay question. An effective way to begin to do this is to ask questions of your essay question, such as: \n  What is being asked? \n  How many issues are raised? \nThe actual essay question must be constantly borne in mind as texts are read and \nresearch is conducted. It is very useful to convert the question into a tree diagram that can be annotated as texts are collected. \nLet us look at an example question: \nThe English legal system is like a house that is not only too small, it is in need of repair. The question is do we build another extension and repair as necessary or pull the whole thing down and start again? \nDiscuss the issues arising from this quotation. \nThis is a standard quotation followed by a bland request to ‘discuss the issues arising’. But you are not told what the issues are, so immediately you know that part of the test is your discovery of the ‘issues arising’. \nThe quotation that you have been given is not referenced. It may be the case that it \nis an invented quotation by the lecturer. But equally it could be an actual non-attributed quotation that you might even come across when researching. If you do then you could mention its source. \n\n--- Page 323 ---\n   \n  292 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nYou should also notice that this quotation presents itself as a metaphor. This should \nnot be overlooked but engaged with. Our working defnition of metaphor is that metaphor \ncompares one thing with another either for emphasis or explanation or to describe the unknown by means of the known. Here it is used to describe one thing in terms of another. \nThe frst thing to do is break down the metaphor into its parts. Then each part can be \nconsidered. You may have immediately understood that this is a question about reform and the nature of it, whether in parts or radical wholesale reform. If you did not, do not worry. Draw out your radial diagram as shown in Figure 10 .1, but leave the centre empty \n(this is the core that joins all of the outlying circles). When you have added the metaphor in those circles you may well have found the core issue. \nThere are a number of options referred to in the metaphor; you just need to check back \nto see you caught them all. You may already know quite a bit about this area so you could move to each outlying circle and make it the centre of another diagram. When this is done it is time to move to the next stage. \nThe ‘house’ in the question is the English legal system and you are invited to further \nconsider what the metaphoric terms ‘repair’, ‘extension’ and ‘pulling down’ might mean. Translating this back to our task in the question, we need to look at our house, what is wrong, and then discuss what reforms (repairs) may have been put forward, whether new \nIs the English \nlegal system \nft for \npurpose? . Should we just \nrepair the English \nlegal system? \nHas been too \nextended and the \nend is in sight? \nIs it too small? Should we tear the \nEnglish legal \nsystem down and \nstart again? \nFigure 10.1 Radial diagram for essay question  \n\n--- Page 324 ---\n    \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS 293 \nconcepts or processes have been put forward to deal with issues (extension) or whether an \nentirely new legal system should be developed (pulling it down and starting again). \nThroughout, we should critique ideas about repair or extension, but ultimately the \nquote asks you to choose which of these suggestions is viable. That is a matter for you after the relevant research and thought has gone into the question. But the metaphor also structures the main body of your essay and arguments, as well as the quote. \nResearching for your essay \nSearching for relevant texts \nOnce you have used your preferred techniques to deconstruct your essay task it is impor -\ntant to make sure that you have understood the material at the level you were dealing with it in class. The next stage therefore can involve looking through relevant chapters in your set textbook, or any recommended text (if there is no set text), your lecture notes, your seminar notes and any personal notes you have made extending lecture and seminar work. You may even fnd the source of any quotes used in your essay title this way. Then re-read your question in light of this superfcial trawl through your class-based material. See if what you have read has developed your understanding of the question in any way. If it has, make any changes to your deconstruction of the question. \nIt is at this point that you are well equipped to turn to research and begin to access \ntextbooks, academic books and articles, and any primary legal material you need. Do not forget to refer to any relevant parliamentary papers or other non-academic material, such as speeches, government or EU reports and departmental or EU briefngs.\n1 \nOrganising material \nAs you locate material that is relevant, save it, photocopy it and highlight it, or make notes. It is a good idea to set up a separate fle for this. Stage 3 therefore involves reading eve -\nrything with the actual question in mind and know what aspect of the question you are researching. \nExtract arguments presented and then reconsider the question, both in parts and as \na whole. \nThe frst task for your reading is asking the basic questions detailed below, whilst at \nthe same time recalling the actual issues detailed in the essay question you are doing the research for. Otherwise relevant details in your material could be overlooked. As you read texts you need to ask yourself questions that differ according to the text you are using, as shown below. \nLaw cases \n  What are the facts? \n  What legal rules have been applied and why? \n1 H ow to get the best out of your university library and research strategies for locating domestic and \nEuropean legislation and cases as well as researching secondary materials are discussed in Chapter 6 . \n\n--- Page 325 ---\n   294 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \n  How do the arguments presented assist in relation to the essay? \n  What aspects of this case are relevant to my essay? \nTextbooks \n  Do I understand what I am reading? \n  Does it ft with my understanding of the law or the topic? \n  Have I properly grasped the issues involved? \n  What is of relevance to my essay? \nAcademic books and articles \n  What is the writer’s argument? \n  Is it well supported by the evidence? \n  Does the writer’s argument support or deny my argument in the essay? \n  What is of relevance to my essay? \nIt is also important to note whether there is a majority view developing in the texts con -\ncerning any of the issues raised by the essay question. Go back to any diagram of the \nessay question that you have made during the frst stage when refecting upon the ques -\ntion. Reference your texts on the diagram so that you can see which elements of your essay question you have a number of references for and where you have none or few. You can then seek to look for more texts in these areas. \nThink about how your own views are developing on the various aspects of your ques -\ntion, but do keep an open mind. Your personal ideas may change as more research is conducted and some texts present persuasive arguments that you had not previously thought about. \nWhat you are doing in this stage is methodically going through your retrieved materi -\nals, organising them (as relevant or not relevant) and then classifying whether they relate to part of the question or all of the question. Then you will make notes effciently sum -\nmarising. Using the strategies already discussed in earlier chapters you are breaking into these texts and sifting them, ready to think about your answer. As you read each text keep returning to the question so you do not drift off course. You will then be in a good position to turn to issues of analysis, evaluation and critique. \nYou may fnd that as you engage in reading your retrieved material it raises issues that \nrequire you to return to researching in order to investigate matters further. \nForming an argument \nOnce the retrieved texts have been carefully prepared by ordering and summarising, then: \n  Potential arguments can be refected upon. \n  Arguments can be compared. \n  Differences of opinion expressed by judges and academics can be considered. \n\n--- Page 326 ---\n    \n \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS 295 \nAt this point, you can begin to have a personal view in answer to the essay task and begin \nto write. However, do not begin writing until you: \n  Understand each text as much as possible in isolation. \n  Have considered and understood the interconnections between the texts. \nLaw cases and texts that confict are as intimately interconnected as law cases and texts \nthat agree with each other. You should organise your materials as follows: \n  Materials containing arguments that are the same. \n  Materials containing arguments that are different. \n  Materials that are mixed in that in some areas they agree and some areas they \ndisagree. \nAs Chapter 9 on the anatomy of argument demonstrates, no problem is ever a simple unitary one; problems come in bundles. Whilst questions posed may appear simple and unitary, they never are. Not only is there no such thing as a simple question, but there is also no such thing as a simple answer. All questions are complex and, of necessity, all answers are complex. It is never suffcient to give as an answer a purely descriptive com -\nmentary. No questions posed to test your understanding will only require description. They will require evaluation and critique as well. You need to make choices. Decide what issues are most relevant; and what can, and what cannot, be discussed in the answer to the question. \nTexts that deny your argument are not to be ignored; they are to be dealt with. You \ncan argue that they are unreliable (for example, you may argue that the argument is pure theory with no evidence to back it up); you can argue that it is one possible plausible interpretation but that you are presenting another equally plausible interpretation. If you cannot explain away an argument denying your view, then perhaps you should reconsider your view. How strong is your argument? \nYour lecturer will know of texts that agree and disagree and will be looking to see if you \nhave properly dealt with all the material. \nYou should by now have a reasonably clear idea of how your argument may look. You \nwill know what supporting evidence you have and where your argument lacks supporting evidence. You do not have to throw out weak arguments if they serve to build a broader picture and support a broader argument. But this must be in the context of well-supported propositions or arguments. When you have considered all of your thoughts and potential arguments think carefully about how they apply to your essay, perhaps even returning to the essay the next day. Then refne your argument. Look back at your deconstruction of the question and deal with each assertion. Have you changed your views? Have you seen more issues that you did not see before? Do your arguments or descriptions only relate to what you have been asked or are any irrelevant? \n\n--- Page 327 ---\n   \n 296 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nStructuring your essay \nEach type of essay question requires a different approach, but the same three-part general \nstructure is required. The standard structure is disarmingly simple and is quite likely to be one that you are already familiar with: \n  A clear brief introduction. \n  The main part (the body) of the essay setting out main and secondary arguments. \n  A confdent comprehensive conclusion. \nThe function of the essay introduction \nThe role of the introduction is to clearly and succinctly set out the issues that the essay \nwill discuss (and why). It will give very brief details of the argument(s) to be presented, and indicates the conclusion. It is important to ‘begin with the end in mind’ as it is the intro -\nduction that is key in guiding the reader through your work. It may help you to understand its importance if you think of it as a road map directing the reader to the conclusion and indicating how they will get there. The introduction is also the section in which you set out any areas you have chosen not to discuss, giving your reasons for taking that course of action; often for reasons of word limit it is not viable to cover all potential areas. \nThe introduction should fnalise when the main body of the essay is fnished and your \nconclusions are clearer. You will need to check that the road map promised in your intro -\nduction is the one following in the main body and the conclusion. If it is not, because your views have changed, make sure this is refected in changes to the introduction. Often stu -\ndents forget the promises they make in their introduction and just do not deliver because they lost their way in the essay. \nThe main body of the text \nThe main part of the essay is often referred to as the body of the text. Here, you will set out the propositions of your argument(s) in a carefully pre-planned manner with your propositions supported by evidence from the texts and cases that you have consulted. It is absolutely essential to refer to case law, legislation, and textbooks and articles as appropriate in this main part of the essay or you will have nothing but unsupported claims that do not constitute an argument. \nIt is essential to understand that when writing assessed essays and exams you must \nuse academic texts, such as academic journal articles and academic books. Even though you may be required to discuss primary legal texts in detail these are not academic but legal texts. You must use academic comment and review of primary law. Do remember that primary law and in particular law cases on their own are just law; they are in no way academic. It is particularly important to read academic journals as these are pub -\nlished much more quickly than a book (which could be a year or more out of date when \n\n--- Page 328 ---\n    \n  \n  \n  \n  \n  \n  WRITING LAW ESSAYS 297 \npublished) and represent the latest thought in an area. An essay demands an academic \nresponse to the law. \nIt can take a long time to devise your argument and decide the best ordering of the \nbody text; make sure you plan enough time to do this. \nThe conclusion \nThe conclusion can do one of three things: \n  Answer the specifc question asked. \n  Finalise your own decisions concerning the critique and review of information you \nhave been given ‘to discuss’. \n  Present your fnal views on the issues you have been invited to extract for discussion. \nThe conclusion must align with your introduction and contain a very brief survey of your argument and the evidence supporting it, that also details its strengths and weaknesses before moving to your specifc concluding response to the essay task. \nWriting an outline \nNow you are ready to write an essay plan by looking at: \n  The diagram of the question you originally prepared. \n  The notes of cases and other texts. \n  The notes of your personal ideas/argument. \nProduce an outline divided into three with sub-headers along the following lines: \nIntroduction \n(1) Explain what you are being asked to do by the questions and how you intend to \napproach your essay. \n(2) Deal with any matters you have decided not to deal with, giving reasons. \n(3) Give the plan of the argument. \nBody text \n(1) Main argument(s) with evidence (propositions here may need to be backed by con -\nclusions from secondary arguments). \n(2) Secondary arguments with evidence. \nConclusion \n(1) Brief survey of arguments and why they lead to the conclusion reached. You could use the following narrative signposts: \n\n--- Page 329 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 298 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \n‘Therefore having carefully considered arguments 1, 2, 3, etc. … it is possible to \nconclude that …’ \nWriting your essay \nDeveloping your written voice: your writing style \nFor many students, fnding their ‘written voice’ and developing their style is diffcult. When you speak to others you do not have to consider how you might sound or how you should say something: you just know. You automatically change your vocabulary, accent and tone of voice when speaking to different types of people (e.g. a close friend, an acquaintance, your family or your lecturer). However, you may not be so accus -\ntomed to using and changing your written voice. It may be the case that you only write when you are being assessed in coursework or exams. Unlike the informality of emails, texting, instant messaging and social media, formal academic writing is a measured method of communicating, with clear rules of engagement that cover style as well as content. \nAlthough academic writing uses formal structures and expression, you should avoid \nexcessively formal language. Lakoff identifed the concept of hyper-correct language in speakers who resort to long words and archaic terms because they feel uncomfortably out of their comfort zone.\n2 The classic scenario is the witness in court who says: ‘I imme -\ndiately apprehended that the person was moving his arm in my direction with a clenched fst and he made contact with my left cheek towards the area of the chin, and I experi -\nenced a rush of pain. I noted that I had been the victim of a battery!’ This can be most unconvincing heard orally in court and read in its written form. It is better to speak plainly and directly, ‘Then the defendant punched me in the face’. \nLook out for paragraphs where you are repeating phrases or ideas that you might \nhave already used. Repetition in these circumstances suggests a lack of time to properly edit your work. It is a diffcult matter; how many different ways can you say ‘argues’ or ‘states’? \nIf you can eradicate repetition, you will make your writing more cohesive and interesting. Consider using words as substitutions for ‘argues’ and ‘states’, such as: \n  there is an enormous range for him; the key issue is … \n  she views, \n  she considers that, \n  they hold the view that. \nWhen you are comparing authors you can also note whether they agree with each other and when they do not. \nDeveloping your written voice is exceptionally important. After all, it is the medium that \nwill secure your degree. Take as many opportunities to engage in academic writing as possible, getting yourself used to the medium outside the assessment itself. \n2 R Lakoff Language and Woman’s Place (Harper & Row, New York, 1975). \n\n--- Page 330 ---\n    \n  \n  \n  \n  \n   \n \n \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS 299 \nActivity 10.1: fnding your voice3 \n(1) Stop reading now; fnd a piece of paper and pen and start writing about any-\nthing for ten minutes, your favourite football team, your favourite celebrity, etc. \nDo not at this point worry about style or grammar. But do use punctuation. \n(2) When you have fnished do not read over what you have written but put the \npaper to one side and keep on reading this book (or do something else). \n(3) Later today or tomorrow return to the piece you have written. View it objectively, \nnot as the writer of it. Do you consider that what you have read is well written? Evaluate your writing asking the following questions: \nAre there phrases you like or dislike? \nWhat worked and why? What did not work and why? \nAs you have been asked to write about anything you like with no further instruc-\ntion it is likely that you will have adopted an informal style of writing. It will use abbreviations like ‘didn’t’, ‘don’t’, and may include street language or other col-loquialisms. The ‘voice’ you discover will be your informal ‘voice’. \n(4) Keep trying this exercise until you feel comfortable with the idea of writing. You \nshould start to fnd your voice. \n(5) You can have more than one written voice. For academic writing you need to also \ndevelop a formal method of expressing your voice. This will not be too far removed from your informal written voice, but it will need to keep to certain protocols such as not abbreviating. These protocols will be discussed later in this chapter. \nOne way to assess the effectiveness and quality of your writing may be to read it out loud, so you can hear it and gain a different perspective on what you have written. You could record it and listen to it. \nThe requirements of formal academic language \nLegal writing requires the use of formal language, but it must not be too formal. You do not want to fall into Lakoff’s problem of hyper-correctness. We will run through the detail of what it means to be required to use formal language. \nBeing objective \nIn British academic writing, it is conventional to avoid using the words ‘I’ or ‘my’ (contrary to many American academics). Each lecturer has their own preference regarding the word ‘I’, but you cannot go wrong with following the tradition. This will take time to perfect but is \n3 T he idea for this exercise is taken from P Elbow Writing with Power: Techniques for Mastering the Writing \nProcess  (Galaxy books, Oxford University Press, New York, 1981). \n\n--- Page 331 ---\n   \n           \n \n \n \n \n 300 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nwell worth the effort. By objectifying, you in effect describe to the reader what the essay, \nthe object, will do. The technical term for this is using the passive voice. \nInstead of writing the phrase translate your phrase into objective language. This \nrequirement to use objective language when communicating is not just about style. Whilst undergraduate students are expected to develop independent thoughts and views, in academic writing you should only express the views of those with authority (leading scholars and lawyers) on the issue. Any conclusion to your assessments needs to weigh up the academic and legal sources you have used in your argument. In terms of assessed academic writing your own views are not relevant except insofar as you state a preference for one accepted academic opinion over another. It is better to state, ‘This shows that the views of X are supported’ rather than ‘I think the views of X are correct’. \nThere is no reason to be overly careful and modest about expressing your opinion, \nthough. The essay you are submitting is your work and contains your opinion, and you should have some confdence expressing this. There is no need to use phrases like ‘I believe Hanson is right when she writes …’ – go for something like ‘Hanson rightly states …’. \nIf you fnd language and style diffcult, check to see if your university runs academic \nwriting seminars. \nIncorporating the work of others in your writing \nEven when you are communicating the views of others, the language of your writing should not change. Rather than summarising each source separately and pushing it into your argument you need to consider the words used by your source and properly inte -\ngrate your sources into a coherent argument. Here the value of good note taking in the research process is particularly important. Your written voice should be communicating the views of others. \nQuotations must be used in a considered manner. A direct quote will always break \nthe fow of your argument, and should therefore only be used if the exact wording of the quotation is important. Otherwise, it is preferable to use a referenced paraphrase. \nAll too often quotations placed into the text by the writer appear haphazard and hang \nawkwardly in the text, serving no purpose. This often suggests that the student could not be bothered to dissect the ideas in the quote. Often quotes are not grammatically linked to the writing piece and this too makes them read as out of place. You must think about why you want to quote the author. Then embed the quotation so it reads seamlessly in your work: even when you think the quote speaks for itself it has also to be introduced (and explained if necessary). \nUse of language \nGrammar \nYou will probably not be overly excited about this section, and you might even be surprised it is here. She describes the story of a panda who read in a book that a panda: \nEats, shoots and leaves. \nThis led to a tragedy as the panda went into a restaurant, ordered and ate a meal, took out a gun, began shooting and then left. \nThe punctuation was the cause of this drama. The comma was not required after the \nword ‘eats’ and if the entry had read that a panda: \nEats shoots and leaves. \nThis would have told the panda that it was normal for him to eat shoots and leaves. Sense depended on where the comma was placed. \nPunctuation provides a sense for your writing and it is therefore an essential aspect of \nyour written English. If you use punctuation correctly, it will create a good impression of your ability as a writer. It is also important for the purposes of understanding your reading to have a grasp of the foundations of punctuation. \nVocabulary \nMany students are concerned that their vocabulary is too small. You may recall an experi -\nence when you were talking to someone, or in a small group, and you did not understand most of the words you heard although you all spoke the same language. \nYou will need to acquire a large technical legal vocabulary and at the same time extend \nyour ordinary English vocabulary. \nAn initial feeling of being overcome with too many unknown words is a natural frst \nconcern of law students. Do not worry. With persistent application your vocabularies, and therefore your general comprehension of legal texts, will expand. I have used the term ‘vocabularies’ because there is a difference between general and legal English. \n4 L Truss Eats, Shoots and Leaves: The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation (Profle Books, London, \n2003). \n\n--- Page 336 ---\n    WRITING LAW ESSAYS 305 \nAlso in the study of law you will fnd that many ordinary, general English words will \nhave a specialised meaning within English law. Words such as ‘intention’, ‘negligence’, \n‘recklessness’ and ‘knowingly’ have been the object of much interpretative debate in law cases. At times legislation is enacted to try and clarify the meaning of these words, lead -\ning to more cases about their meaning. \nExtending your general vocabulary \nIn academic life as well as in ordinary life people make unfounded value judgments about us. Because of its link to education vocabulary is routinely used to classify socio-eco -\nnomic status and make assumptions about a language user’s intelligence. Promise your -\nself that you will not just ignore words you do not understand. If you do not understand the meaning of a word how can you know that it is all right to ignore it? An obvious thing that you can do is to keep an alpha ordered vocabulary. You should not assume that because you looked up a word once that you will remember its meaning months later. Ideally it should give the full range of meanings of the word, together with examples of using it in the different vocabularies in which it can occur. Words do change their meaning according to context. As your vocabulary will extend you will be able to use some of this new vocabulary in your academic discussions, or everyday discussions if appropriate. \nAs you concentrate upon extending your vocabulary, whether as a native English \nspeaker or reading English as a second language, you will become aware that many words share the same parts. This knowledge can be used to assist you in understand -\ning new words. Recall the work on affxes and guessing words. But also recall that you should not assume that you have the correct meaning of the word from your guessing; you should also look it up. \nExtending your technical legal vocabulary \nThe meaning of many technical legal words, and the appropriate words to use when referring to certain activities in law, will embed themselves in your memory as you will be using them often. Legal English also resorts to a large number of Latin phrases or tags which stand as shorthand for doctrines and methods of resolving disputes (e.g. obiter , \nratio). These will be considered in more detail in the chapters on legal writing for essays \nand problem solutions. However, you can help yourself to learn this technical vocabulary by keeping an alpha listing of the meaning of such words (or phrases) so that in times of uncertainty about meaning you can just refer to your list. \nIssues with spelling \nThere are many rules and exceptions in English with regard to spelling. Only a few of the more notorious issues are referred to here. Your computer will have a spell checker and it is well worth using it as a preliminary check for mistakes, but do check that it is set \n\n--- Page 337 ---\n   \n 306 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nto British English and not American English.
