The computer will fag up certain easily mistaken words (such as their/there) but not all. \nUnderstanding the relationship between sentences and paragraphs \nWe have so far noted the importance of the use of correct grammar, punctuation, vocabu -\nlary and spelling. These all come together in the sentences, phrases and paragraphs that you choose when constructing your academic writing in response to tasks set by your lecturers. To use sentences and paragraphs properly you do need to understand the defnition and function of them both. For your assistance these are set out in Table 10 .3. \nThe frst draft \nAlthough you will have an idea of what you are doing and where you are going and indeed what your answer is, it is a good idea to start your detailed frst draft in the body of the text: \n  Leave the intro at the outline plan stage. \n  Begin with the body text, the middle section, paying particular attention to the devel -\nopment of your main argument – is it supported by evidence? \n  Review everything for your conclusion. \n  Write the fnal version of the introduction last, ensuring that the body of the text and \nyour conclusion do what your introduction says they will do. \n  Then fnalise your conclusion. \n  When you have fnished this, remember it is a draft not the fnal product. Read it through carefully. \n  Ensure that every item referred to is appropriately referenced. \n  If a bibliography is required ensure that it contains all referenced texts and all texts consulted for the essay but not referred to in the text. \n  It is always worthwhile considering whether you need to search for any more texts. So allow time for this and go back and read the question again. As your understand -\ning has developed through reading you may now spot issues in the question that you initially missed. \n  Revise and produce a second draft going through the same steps as above. \n  This time tackle issues of continuity between the introduction and the conclusion. \nThe fnal version \nCarefully review your second draft: \n  Consider whether there is a need to search for any more texts. \n  Pay attention to the argument – does it clearly present itself? \n\n--- Page 338 ---\n    \n  \n  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS 307 \nTABLE 10.3 UNDERSTANDING THE ROLE OF SENTENCES AND PARA-\nGRAPHS IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF WRITING \nSENTENCE \nDefnition A sentence is a group of words grammatically linked containing a verb intending \nto communicate something. \nComponents • Verb:  Sentences must have a verb. There can be more than one verb in a \nparts sentence. \n• Subject:  Sentences have a subject which is the word controlling the action \nimplied by the verb. A subject can be a pronoun, noun (a proper name or named concepts) and this can include prepositions such as ‘this’. \n• Object:  Sentences can have an object; again this can be a pronoun or a noun. \n• Sentences can also contain other grammatical units such as adverbs or \nadjectives. \n• Some would maintain that you should not start a sentence with a conjunction \nor words ending with the suffx ‘ing’. \nVerb A verb is a word that discusses actions and states, and it is often referred to as a ‘doing’ or ‘being’ word, e.g. running, happy, etc. A verb has different tenses according to whether it relates to an action or state in the present  (present tense), \nthe past  (past tense) or the future  (future tense). \nThere are other tenses, but you need not concern yourself with these now. The other words used in a sentence must agree with the tense of the verb they are in grammatical relation to. To check your understanding of tenses look at Examples 1 and 2 below. Adjectives and adverbs (as appropriate) joined to verbs in the sentence are indicated by dashes joining these words. Example 1. She loves-to-run but she hated-swimming-when-she-tried it = √ Example 2. She love-to-run  but she hates-swimming-when-she-try  it = X \nSENTENCE \nSubject The subject of a sentence is the main focus of the sentence, what it is about. \nOften, but not always, it comes near the beginning of the sentence and determines the rest of the sentence. Sentences can have more than one subject. e.g. The barrister drafted the pleadings subject verb object \nObject Nouns in a sentence that are not the focus of the sentence are objects as they explain more about the subject and what they may be doing or thinking etc. Sentences can have more than one object. \n• A direct object is an object acted on by the subject, e.g. The police offcer \ncaught the thief. \n• An indirect object is where the object is indirectly affected by the action, e.g. \nThe police offcer gave the thief a drink. \nPARAGRAPH \nDefnition A group of sentences that are connected to each other because they deal with \nthe same idea or point. \nComponent Each paragraph will have a: \nparts • Topic sentence , which is what the paragraph is discussing. \n• ‘Body’ sentences  that give information following on from the topic sentence. \nEach new idea should be introduced in a new paragraph. \n• A Concluding sentence  is to smooth the way for the next paragraph or to \nrefer the reader back to the topic of the paragraph, or both. \nFunction/size Each sentence in the paragraph should make sense in that paragraph; it should not be irrelevant, and sentences should be logically ordered within the sentence. There is no set size for a paragraph but ideally it should not be a page long, nor too small, but on some occasions a two-sentence paragraph may be needed. \n\n--- Page 339 ---\n   \n \n  \n  308 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \n  Pay particular attention to the conclusion and thoughts on the introduction. \n  Review the argument. Is there evidence to back it up? Have opposing views been dealt with? \nThen write the fnal draft: \n  Proofread it carefully for spelling, grammar and word count. \n  Double-check all citations and references. \n  Put it aside for a day if possible or a few hours if not and then carefully re-read and \nmake any fnal changes. \nReferencing your sources \nWhy should I make references? \nWhen you submit work to the university for formal assessment you will be expected to describe, review, compare and critically analyse the work of academics, legal profes -\nsionals and others and to use their work to support your own arguments. The university expects their work to be clearly distinguishable from your own work. To ensure that you can do this consistently and thoroughly you need to know how to reference your uses of the work of others. It is part of the skill of an undergraduate and graduate student that they learn to do this and deploy referencing in a way that enhances their work and their writing. \nSeveral academic referencing systems exist and your university may even have set up \nits own preferred referencing system. The two main referencing systems used in UK law schools are OSCOLA (the Oxford System for the Citation of Legal Authorities), which is known as a footnote system, and Harvard, an in-text system (less used in law schools). This chapter will briefy introduce the referencing protocols for both and make reference to sources where you can fnd more detail. Both referencing systems dictate the way in which references should be signalled inside the body of your text and laid out in detail outside the body of your text (e.g. as footnotes, endnotes, and in a bibliography). \nAs important as proper referencing is for academic work, it is also important not to \noverthink it. Students can get stressed about compliance with the minute details of the referencing system, but nobody is going to fail you if you use square brackets instead of round ones or if you did not put a book’s title in italics. Ultimately, there are only two rules that matter: \n1. References need to guide the reader to the source of the text. \n2. References need to be consistent inside your work. \nA set referencing style helps you achieve all of that without having to think too much. A reader of your essay, who is familiar with your referencing style, will recognise immediately \n\n--- Page 340 ---\n    WRITING LAW ESSAYS 309 \nthat you got that quote from a journal article and will be able to fnd it if they want to. It is \ntherefore always advisable to use an established style, even if your law school leaves the choice up to you. \nA lot of the explanations in this chapter will seem complex and scary, but you can trust \nus: once you are used to referencing, it will become second nature, and you will not have to worry about it anymore! \nWhen should I make references? \nReferences fulfl two tasks: they help you avoid allegations of plagiarism (see below), and they give authority to your arguments. As impressive as your thoughts and opinions prob -\nably already are, it is even more impressive if you can show that other people’s research backs them up. \nWhenever you use the work of another or quote directly from them in your writing, you \nmust reference the source. If an idea has been set out at length in a chapter you will most likely just refer to the relevant chapter. If, however, the idea or argument you wish to use is set out in a few pages, you can just refer to those few pages when you reference. These particular references are referred to as pinpoint references and they enable a reader to fnd the exact location in that other work. If you are indebted to the orientation of an entire book or article then you can consider stating this and noting the full work. \nThe requirement to reference does not stop with verbatim quotations but includes \nideas, diagrams, tables, illustrations and the statistics, which have been respectively designed or collected and interpreted by others. Students often overlook the need to reference every time they refer to a legal rule. For example, if you state ‘it is a criminal offence to steal a book’ you must give the pinpoint reference to the relevant legal prohibi -\ntion (which is, of course, s 1 of the Theft Act 1968). \nIf you are referring to issues discussed by a judge(s) in a case such as the develop -\nment of a legal rule, or a matter of interpretation, you must give the full reference to that case and a pinpoint reference to the exact part of the judgment(s) developing the rule or interpretation. \nTherefore, when you discuss statements of law always ask yourself, ‘What is my \nauthority for stating this?’ then reference that authority. You can also ask yourself whether you wish to summarise the point or use a direct quotation, and more will be said about this later in this chapter. \nMany students speak of statistics in their work without referring to the source, but \nwhere did that statistic come from, and how do we know it is from a reputable academic or empirical source? Would you expect to take action based on unsubstantiated statis -\ntics? Hopefully not – you would want to know the source and then weigh up if it were a reputable source. You must give a reference to the report producing those statistics or to the author of the book or journal that cited such a statistic if they did not give the refer -\nence to the statistic. This latter situation would be a secondary source as you obtained the information from a source using the primary statistics. \n\n--- Page 341 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  \n  \n \n    \n \n \n  310 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nWhen you are discussing legal defnitions clearly they have an origin in a source beyond \nyour own work. If they have been defned in case law or legislation, that source must be \ncited. You can cite other sources for defnitions, such as a law dictionary or an article. But this should not be done to the exclusion of referring to the case law and legislation that has defned the legal concept. \nIf you know you have taken existing information from another author, even though you \nhave used your own words to communicate that information, you must still reference your source for your summary. If you are not sure whether to reference or not, play safe and reference. Whilst you can be criticised for over referencing and it could lose you marks for presentation, if you have a genuine dilemma you cannot resolve it is better to err on the side of referencing caution. \nIt is generally considered appropriate not to reference factual information which everyone \nin a particular state or locality should know. This is because it is said to be common knowl -\nedge yet there are no general rules about what constitutes ‘common knowledge’. It is often diffcult to know what to do about referencing information that is said to be ‘common knowl -\nedge’ – that is, a fact everyone should know. For example, if you write who the current prime minister is, do you need to reference it? Do you refer to the results of the last general election from the offcial record? What about a broader non-factual comment? If the information can be found in many places and is indeed known by many people then you need not reference it. But what does ‘many’ mean? If in real doubt it is best to seek advice from your tutors. \nThe OSCOLA system was specifcally developed in the UK to make it easier to deal \nwith references required for primary legal source material. The system is based on foot -\nnotes – small numbers in the text that refer to text at the bottom of the page.\n5 \nHow do I make a footnote? \nThe Word Processor you are using – Microsoft Word, LibreOffce, Openoffce, Google Docs or one of the many others – will have an automatic function for inserting a footnote that takes care of the counting for you. \nThe footnote should usually be placed after the punctuation at the end of the sentence \nyou are referring to.\n6 However, if you are referring to an individual word7 rather than the \nwhole sentence, the footnote should be placed behind the word itself. \nIf you cite multiple sources, you can do this in two ways: \n(1) Twining and Miers,8 Holland and Webb9 and Hanson10 all agree that referencing \nis important. \n(2) Twining and Miers, Webb and Hanson all agree referencing is important.11 \n5 L ike this one. \n6 H ere. \n7 L ike the word ‘words’ in this sentence. \n8 W Twining and D Miers How to Do Things with Rules (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 2010). \n9 J Holland and J Webb Learning Legal Rules  (Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2019). \n10 S Hanson Learning Legal Skills and Reasoning  (Routledge, London, 2020). \n11 W Twining and D Miers How to Do Things with Rules (Cambridge University Press 2010); J Holland and J Webb Learning Legal Rules  (Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2019); S Hanson Learning Legal Skills and \nReasoning  (Routledge, London, 2020). \n\n--- Page 342 ---\n    \n \n \n \n WRITING LAW ESSAYS 311 \nThe frst reference gives the full reference to the source used. If the full reference has \npreviously been given, it is only necessary to refer to your previous footnote. Nowadays, this is done by simply using the authors name and ‘n X’ to show the previous note: Twining and Miers think referencing is important.\n12 In older texts, you will fnd Latin abbreviations \nlike ‘Op. cit.’ ( opere citato  – in the work cited) or ‘Loc. cit.’ ( loco citato  – in the place cited), \nbut these should not be used any more. \nIt is advisable to use automated functions for this as well, like the cross-referencing \nfunction in Microsoft Word. This way the number given in the second footnote is still cor -\nrect, even if you decided to add several footnotes before the frst one later. \nIf you are referring to the footnote directly above, you can use ‘ibid.’, but only for \nthe one directly above. Be careful with this (or avoid it altogether) when writing: once you start editing and moving sentences around, you might not be sure what the ‘ibid.’ referred to. \nReferencing primary source material \nWhat is a legal citation? \n‘Citation’ is a general term for the referral to all primary legal sources – like statutes, case law or other legal statements. \nUK cases \nThere are two types of citation used for UK cases, the neutral citation and law report citation. They are completely independent of each other except for the fact that they both refer to a written record of the same law case. \nThe neutral citation \nThis is the referencing system of the courts and is given to all cases post-2001. This includes the year, territorial jurisdiction and a sequence number, which denotes which judgment it is in that year in the relevant area (e.g. civil or criminal law), e.g. [2004] EWCA Civ 727 denotes that this citation is to the 727th judgment in the England and Wales Court of Appeal for the year 2004. The Supreme Court has UK wide jurisdiction and is denoted by the UKSC, United Kingdom Supreme Court. \nThe private report citation \nThe second type of citation is used for privately reported cases. This private law report citation will set out the year of the case, title of the law report, volume details and the page number for the frst page of the report. Where there is no neutral citation in existence for the reported case because it is pre-2001, the court is given at the end of the citation in abbreviated form enclosed in brackets, R v Moloney [1985] 2 AC 905 (HL). \n12 Twining and Miers (n 8). \n\n--- Page 343 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 312 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nFor all references to private law reports you must give the neutral citation frst (if there \nis one) followed by the references to the private report(s) of the case in order of their hierarchy of authority, R v Bree [2007] EWCA Crim 804; [2008] QB 131; [2007] 3 WLR 600; [2007] 2 All ER 676; [2007] 2 Cr App R 13. \nCiting UK cases \nWhen dealing with cases the citation refers to the name of the parties, the year of the case and if it is not reported the neutral citation giving court and number of the case in the year. If it is reported, then it includes details of the private report (report title, volume number if any and page number). You may like to think of your law case citation as divided into two parts, the names of the parties, and the citation for its location. Each of these is inserted into the text in a different but connected way. \nOSCOLA specifes that only the name of the case in italics with the superscript numeral \nshould be put in the body of your text. It is the matching footnote that contains the cited location of the case. By way of example, one can point to the case of R v Bree .\n13 Note that \nthe superscript marker immediately after R v Bree directs you to footnote 13, which, as you can see, gives the citations for the reports where it can be located, beginning with the neutral citation, followed by other reports in accordance with the hierarchy of law reports. \nConventions for shortening names of parties in civil law \nIn the body of your text you may not wish to set out the full case name, and this is fne. But you need to use the conventional shortening not make one up. The rule is that you can only use the surname of the frst party in the action as an abbreviation. It is important to have such a rule as the shortening of case names is common, and matters will be unduly complicated if different methods prevail. What is less easy to get used to is that customarily some famous leading cases will always be referred to by resort to both party names, and others are conventionally shortened to the frst party. You will just have to get used to these. \nAn interesting example is the case of McAlister (or Donoghue) v Stevenson  [1932] AC \n562. This is a famous civil law case in the area of the law of tort (the law relating to acci -\ndents). In the text this case is always referred to as Donoghue v Stevenson  and rarely \nreferred to as Donoghue . Note too that the frst of the two named parties, McAlister, is again \nonly rarely referred to in the text. If you were writing about negligence as developed within the law of tort and you decided to shorten this case to Stevenson , no one would necessarily \nknow the case you were referring to. If you somewhat exceptionally referred to ‘Donoghue’s case’, most people would know the case but feel that the shortening used was incorrect. \nWhen the second name is rather long and the frst party has a shorter name there will \nbe a natural use of the frst name only which then becomes common usage. For example, the case of Black-Clawson International v Papierwerke Waldhof-Aschaffenburg  [1975] AC \n591 is unsurprisingly referred to orally and in the body of text as ‘ Black-Clawson ’, with \n13 [2007] EWCA Crim 804; [2008] QB 131; [2007] 3 WLR 600; [2007] 2 All ER 676; [2007] 2 Cr App R 13. \n\n--- Page 344 ---\n    \n  \n \n \n \n  WRITING LAW ESSAYS 313 \nParty names in Italic s \nTwo names indicate \nthis is acivil case Volume Number of report \nThere is no neutral cita\u0005on \nas case predates 2001 \nPage number for \nfrst page o f report \nAdler v George [1964] 2 QB 7 (QB) \nCourt name hearing the case: \nQueen’s Bench as \ncase predates neutral cita\u0005ons \nwhich gives the cour t \nDate of publica\u0005on of law repo rt \nName of public a\u0005on producing the reports. \nThis is from t he ICLR: Law R eport Series: \nQueen’ s Bench                                                            \nFigure 10.2 Example reference 1: Adler v George [1964] 2 QB 7 (QB) \n‘International ’ usually being dropped as well. When you are using cases in coursework \nyou will of course be familiar with the area and the standard abbreviations of the names \nof the parties in the cases that you are dealing with. \nConventions for shortening names of parties in criminal law \nWhen charged with an offence and subsequently indicted in court the offender is referred to as the defendant. It is the defendant who has committed a crime against the public and is therefore answering to the state for his or her actions. At one time the local police com -\nmissioner was the formal prosecuting authority, and the frst-named party; however, now that the monarch is the formal head of state, it is used to denote the prosecuting authority and is the frst-named party to the case. Monarch is used in its generic Latin formulation of Regina (for Queen) or Rex (for King). \nCan shortened names be used in your footnote citation? \nYou will think it tedious perhaps, but the standard rule is that the full reference should be used each time a footnote reference is required. This includes the full reference to the names of the parties. The only formal way around this, if you have already cited the full \n\n--- Page 345 ---\n   \n \n  314 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nAgain you will note that this reference has no punctua\fon, except for a semi-colon dividing \nthe neutral cita\fon, [2004] EWCA Civ 727, from the law report cita\fon, [2005] Fam 1 \nThe neutral cita\u0013on (case post 2001) \nDate Jurisdic\u0013on Court Type of ac\u0013on Sequence \nEngland & Wales Court of Appeal Civil number \nParty names \nIn Italics \nEvans v Amicus Healthcare Ltd [2004] EWCA civ 727; [2005] Fam 1 \nNames of par\fes \nYear date of publica\u0013on of law report \nPage number for commencement \nof report \nAbbreviated name of Law Report \nThis is from the ICLR: Law Report Series: Family \nThe private law report cita\u0011on No court name given in brackets because \nneutral cita\u0013on\ngives \ncourt. If a case report has \na popularised name by which it is always known, and one that is not just a simple use of a frst-named party, then you can use the full citation of the parties’ names in the frst full reference, placing the popularised name in brackets immediately after. The next time you reference you may use the shortened more popular name. \nIf there are several reports of the case you are referencing, you could refer to all reports \nin your reference; however, there is no need to do this as it is suffcient to refer to the most authoritative report according to the hierarchy of reporting. \nPinpoint referencing using cases \nWhen using cases and referencing you may wish to directly quote what a judge has said in the body of your text. In this situation you will need to supply a pinpoint reference, as \n\n--- Page 346 ---\n    \n                                         \n     \n \n                             \n  WRITING LAW ESSAYS 315 \nwell as decide what you put in the body of the text, where you should place the super -\nscript marker and the format of the reference for your footnote. \nThe convention for referencing a verbatim quotation from a judgment remains rela -\ntively consistent. If the case is reported you should only quote from the most authoritative \nlaw report. Place the text marker for the footnote at the end of the quotation or after the introduction of the judge in the quotation. \nThe general rule for the verbatim quotation of text holds for quotes from law cases, \nreports, texts or any other form of text. A short quotation of two or three lines can be inte -\ngrated into the text with the use of quotation marks. A longer quotation of over three lines must be indicated by an indentation in the text, allowing the quoted text to stand proud of the rest of the body text. There is no need for quotation marks in that case as the position of the text makes clear it is a verbatim quotation. \nReferencing secondary sources \nUsing the OSCOLA guide \nOSCOLA has slightly different conventions on how to reference secondary sources. The way a footnote for a book is supposed to look is slightly different from the one for a journal article or for a chapter in an edited book. The best thing for this is to download (and pos -\nsibly print) the quick reference guide on the website of the University of Oxford: \nhttps://www.law.ox.ac.uk/sites/fles/oxlaw/oscola_4th_edn_hart_2012quickreferenc \neguide.pdf and to use it while you are making your references. The quick reference guide will cover most – if not all – sources you are using, but if you need to refer to less com-monly used sources (e.g. Hansard or Scottish Law Commission Reports, there is a full guide, also available free at www.law.ox.ac.uk/sites/fles/oxlaw/oscola_4th_edn_hart_ \n2012.pdf). \nAs mentioned before, all of this will become second nature once you have made the \nfrst few references. \nPinpointing references \nThere are different types of reference that you may wish to make; for example, you may wish to: \n  Give a direct reference from the text you are reading – a verbatim quotation – here a \npinpoint page reference is always required. \n  Give an indirect reference – mentioning the author by name when a pinpoint refer -\nence may be required but not always. \n  Give a specifc reference to a viewpoint or argument which does not name the author when the reference is given to the author. If several authors of different texts are to be named, they are separated by a semicolon. \n\n--- Page 347 ---\n   \n 316 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nWhen referencing, you may wish to refer to the entire book or just pinpoint one or more \npages. If you want to refer to a specifc page or pages, then the page number is incorpo -\nrated into the footnote after the bracket closing the main reference for a book: \nYou can never underestimate the power of the word and the role of the library in the \nstudy of law. \nThe key tools of the trade of the law student are found in the library, in the millions of words that constitute the body of the law and the millions of words that have been used to talk about the law.14 \nThe bibliography \nThe OSCOLA system of referencing does not require a bibliography. However, if your lecturer requires a bibliography at the end of your work, you need to prepare one, and it must include all references to source materials that you have consulted in preparing your written work, including those that you did not specifcally refer to by name in your work. This bibliography must be in alphabetical order using headings to separate academic texts, law cases and legislation. \nTo ensure proper alphabetical order in the bibliography, you will need to begin with \nthe last name rather than the frst: ‘Hanson, S’ instead of the ‘S Hanson’ you used in the footnote. \nHow do I use in-text citations? \nIn law schools, the usual way to make references is via footnotes as described above. In some rare cases, however, law schools might prefer in-text citation systems such as the Harvard or Chicago Style. This is the standard in social science departments, and students on combined degrees (e.g. law and politics) or students who take modules from another department (e.g. from criminology) will almost certainly come across this refer -\nencing style. \nThere are some differences as to the details, but the basic idea is to use the author’s \nname and the year of publication to identify the work and to give a detailed bibliography at the end. The year is usually followed by the page where the referred part is to be found, depending on the style denoted by either ‘:’ or ‘p.’, and the author’s name can be in or outside the brackets to make the text easier to read: \nYou need to be careful using material available online (Hanson 2016: 131).\n Hanson (2020: 131) holds that online materials need to be treated with caution. \nIf you are using two publications by the same author, you need to use small letters to pinpoint which one you mean: ‘Hanson (2020a: 131)’ and ‘(Hanson 2020b: 15)’. \n14 S Hanson Legal Method, Skills and Reasoning  (3rd edition, Routledge-Cavendish, London 2010), 42. \n\n--- Page 348 ---\n    \n          WRITING LAW ESSAYS 317 \nThere are no real conventions for citing cases and legislation in in-text styles, but it is \nusually acceptable to use the OSCOLA standard for this. \nAvoiding plagiarism \nFailure to meticulously reference your work can leave you open to an allegation of plagia -\nrism. Plagiarism is the act of passing off as your own the work of another (e.g. their ideas, \narguments, descriptions, critiques, statistics and illustrations). \nThe exact defnitions differ from university to university, but the basic defnition is \nalways ‘using someone else’s work without acknowledging that’. This means that you need to be careful with your referencing and indicating your quotations. If you have done these properly, you have nothing to fear! \nA fnding of plagiarism has serious consequences for students and can jeopardise \nyour degree programme. Accidental plagiarism, due to careless note taking leading to lack of appropriate referencing, as well as intentional plagiarism, will be pursued by the university, although penalties will usually differ. But for law students there are other seri -\nous consequences. The legal professional bodies require universities to inform them if there has been a fnding of plagiarism. This fnding can be taken as evidence of a lack of good character and can therefore potentially have a negative impact on your future employment prospects and even your entry into the legal profession. \nExperience shows that plagiarism often comes from desperation or lack of under -\nstanding rather than from bad intentions. However, the sanctions will be the same. If life makes studying hard (illness, family problems, work-related issues, etc.), make sure to talk to your tutor early on. Some of this could be grounds for an extension (depending on the policies of the University), but none of this is a valid excuse for plagiarism. Even if you cannot be granted an extension, it is much better to submit a bad piece of work and receive a bad mark than to submit a plagiarised piece of work and risk the end of the legal career before it even began. \nSubmitting your essay \nProofreading \nIt is essential that you read the essay before submitting it. Not only to spot errors the automatic spell checker will not pick up (the word ‘pubic’ appears in more public law essays than you might think!), but also to ensure that you communicate effectively with your reader. \nEven better than proofreading yourself is to give the essay to a friend or a family mem -\nber and ask them if your argument makes sense. Obviously, you know your own argu -\nments, and you know what the essay is supposed to say. A critical friend is able to point out that, for example, the second section comes out of nowhere or that you never really explain that crucial point your conclusion relies upon. \n\n--- Page 349 ---\n   318 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \nQuestions you or your friend should ask about the work include: \n  Can I follow the argument? \n  Is there a fow to the language and to the ordering of points? \n  Is there well-referenced evidence for the points made? \n  Are the arguments organised well and structured in the right order? \n  Are the transitions from argument to argument logical and explained? \n  Is there anything that confuses me? \n  Does every new idea get a new paragraph? \nPresentation \nStudents often neglect the presentation aspect of written work. In addition to fnding your \nvoice, understanding the correct use of grammar, punctuation and spelling and refning your writing style, you should always allow time to edit and format your work. Make sure you read carefully for spelling, punctuation, grammar and fow of your work through para -\ngraphs. In addition, follow your department’s conventions on referencing and formatting. Your law department may require a certain font or line spacing to be used, and if you have to submit a paper copy, it might dictate whether you should only use one side of your paper. \nIf you have a free choice of font, choose one that is easy to read (this will keep your \nmarker relaxed and happy). A font size of 12 is recommended as 14 tends to be too big and 10/11 too small. Keep your line spacing to 1.5 or 2 lines, as this again makes reading easier. Justifed alignment also helps the reader. \nCases and statutes should be formatted in order to make them stand out. Conventionally \nthe names of cases are italicised, for example: R v Briggs  [1977] 1 WLR 605. \nIt is important, however, that you fnd out what your department requires and follow \nthose specifcations. \nBe consistent in your use of headings and how they are displayed in your work and \nensure that you number all of your pages. Only use headings if your essay is quite long, they assist with clarity and your lecturer has no objection to their use. \nCONCLUSION \nThis chapter tried to summarise the complex world of academic legal writing into rela -\ntively few pages, but hopefully it helps to give you an understanding of the different pro -\ncesses involved in writing. \nIt is important that you spend some time thinking about your writing skills and your \nwriting style early on in your studies. As a law student and as a lawyer, language is the main tool you are going to use for the rest of your career, so improving it is always worth \n\n--- Page 350 ---\n    WRITING LAW ESSAYS 319 \nthe effort. Think about your style, and read up on grammar and punctuation to ensure you \ncan avoid any mistakes in this regard. \nWhen you start writing, make sure to choose your question carefully and to plan your \nessay before you start writing. You should always have a clear structure that is directed towards convincing the reader of your argument – even if you do not use headings in your essay (if it is too short), you should have headings in your head when you are putting the essay together. \nAnd make sure to understand the rules and regulations on referencing and plagiarism. \nTo support your argument with legal authority, you need to point your reader towards that authority, and you need to be clear about what part of the work is your own and what is taken from somewhere else. \nFinally, invest at least a little bit of time to polish your essay before submitting it. \nProofreading and formatting are essential to ensure the goodwill of your reader. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  Whatever type of essay or problem question you are dealing with, the same type of information base is required for all questions. It is how this information, knowl -\nedge and understanding is drawn on to produce a particular written result that is important. \n  The order in which you make your points is part of the effective communication of your ideas in writing. \n  Following standard methods for the preparation and construction of essay or prob -\nlem question answers can help you effectively order the different tasks involved. \n  Find your written academic ‘voice’ and avoid hyper-correct language. \n  Formal academic writing is a measured method of communicating, with clear rules of engagement that cover style as well as content. \n  Eradicate repetition and make your writing more cohesive and interesting. \n  Adopt an objective style and avoid using the words ‘I’ or ‘my’ in your writing. \n  Ensure that you use the correctly referenced work (words, designs and ideas) of oth -\ners in your writing. \n  Make sure you proofread carefully for errors of spelling, punctuation and grammar, as well as for the fow of your work through paragraphs and follow your department’s conventions on referencing. \n  Most coursework will have word limits imposed and there may be penalties for exceeding them. Work out before  you even start writing how many pages of your \ntyping that amounts to. \n  Not only must verbatim (direct) quotations from work be referenced but so must all summaries indebted to a particular author or authors. \n\n--- Page 351 ---\n   320 WRITING LAW ESSAYS \n  Your university may stipulate a particular system of referencing and if this is the case \nyou must follow it. \n  Plagiarism is using the work of others without referencing it. \n  A fnding of plagiarism, even accidental plagiarism, can seriously affect your studies. \n  A law student is particularly affected as all incidents of plagiarism must be reported to the law professional bodies and can be looked upon as potential unftness of char -\nacter for the legal profession. \n  Good referencing means that you will not accidentally plagiarise. \n  Well written work requires an effective written voice, excellent grammar and appro -\npriate choices of words. \n  The referencing, formatting and presentation of your written work is as important as your grammar, spelling and punctuation and the vocabulary you use. \n\n--- Page 352 ---\n11 \n  \n ANSWERING LEGAL \nPROBLEM QUESTIONS \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Be aware of the approach to be adopted for writing solutions to legal problem \nquestions. \n  Develop greater confdence in your ability to tackle a problem question. \n  Be able to structure a solution to a problem question effectively. \n  Increase your understanding of the way in which the skills of general study, research, legal analysis, argument construction and writing skills work together to produce competent problem solutions. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-14  \n\n--- Page 353 ---\n    \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 322 ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nINTRODUCTION \nThis chapter considers strategies for writing answers to problem questions. Students tend to prefer essays to problem solution questions. However, the fact is that the same general information is required for essays and problem solutions. A problem solution tests whether you understand a particular area of law well and can apply it. So you need to understand the relevant area of law well frst. \nThe structure of essays and solutions to problem questions do differ. Additionally, \nwhile essays require academic texts as their foundational proofs for all arguments for -\nwarded, problem solutions primarily require the use of legal rules as the foundational texts. That is not to say that essays do not refer to legal rules but that these are not the fnal proofs in an academic legal argument for an essay. \nTo produce competent written answers to problem questions you need to have a good \nunderstanding of the way in which series of cases have developed areas of law, and how judgments by senior judges are of relevance in the development of legal argument. You also need to appreciate the relationship between legislation and cases and the role of statutory interpretation by the judiciary. If these matters are frmly understood, you will be able to tackle a problem question confdently clearly demonstrating that understanding in the structure and content of your answer. Additionally marks are awarded for use of a correct method for problem solution, as well as the correct outcome. \nA problem question at the academic stage of education is a fctitious legal dispute \ninvariably drafted in such a way as to raise situations where there are conditions of doubt about facts, legal issues, or the interpretation of the law. The student will be asked to discuss the legal liability of one particular party, or all potential parties to the dispute. Using only the information given in the problem question as their guide, the student is required to identify, discuss and apply relevant legal rules to the issues raised by the problem question. Students are required to not only identify specifc breaches of law but to be aware of any applicable defences and/or interpretational issues attached to the law. \nYou are expected to only refer to legal rules which invariably involve the discussion of \nlaw cases and refer to statements by judges in court. You are not expected to refer to aca -\ndemic articles and textbooks, unless the judges in specifc cases have referred to those articles or books in court (which is unlikely – but possible in certain defned situations). Books and articles can exceptionally be drawn upon if an aspect of the problem solution has been written about and never discussed by senior judiciary. \nThe problem question is raised in the context of one particular area of study and tests \nthe student’s awareness of current law, their ability to carefully analyse information they have been given and their competency in the construction of arguments, applying that law as they discuss the problem question and the issues it raises. Problem questions are often set in areas of doubt, so always be wary if you think the answer to the problem is simple and clear cut. \n\n--- Page 354 ---\n     \n \n \n ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS 323 \nProblem questions bring together all of the skills of research, argumentation, critical \nanalysis and application of law and demonstrate more than any other type of assessed \ntask your aptitude for the legal profession. A key skill is also to retain the ability to see the problem from all sides, engaging in analogic reasoning, to check that you are aware of the potential arguments that can be put forward by all parties. \nProblem questions bring the student very close to the work of a practising lawyer, as \ntheir job is to assist in resolving their clients’ legal problems. Trial Judges listen to lawyers’ arguments, and their job is to make a determination of liability to resolve the legal dispute. Developing problem-solving skills helps you to develop your overall legal reasoning skills. You examine facts given to you, locate relevant legal rules and apply them to the facts to suggest ways of determining issues of legal liability. \nTable 11 .1 sets out two typical problem questions for you to get an idea of the way in \nwhich they can be structured. \nAs you can see from reading these questions they can vary in length and the complex -\nity of facts presented. Question 1 presents relatively complex facts in terms of partici -\npant’s names, actions and the timing of occurring events over a very short time frame of a few hours initially and then occurring over a few weeks. It is also quite long and there is quite a lot of information to consider. Question 2 by contrast is short and divided into two parts, and the overall timescale of the facts given is seven days. \nOften fact scenarios may seem clearly unrealistic, and you may feel that these events \nsimply would not happen in the ‘real’ world. The person setting the problem is aware of this; it is merely a vehicle to get you to discuss legal issues and display your understand -\ning and ability to engage in the correct methodology for answering a problem question. \nWhat range of skills are tested and developed by problem questions? Problem questions are specifcally designed to test your developing abilities to \nresearch, handle and apply legal rules and construct legal arguments according to English legal reasoning protocols. Your ability to competently answer problem questions is affected by the development of your skills of general academic study, legal reasoning, as well as your developing skills specifc to problem solutions. We will briefy list the sub-skills involved. \nGENERAL ACADEMIC STUDY SKILLS \n  Independent study and time management. \n  Library research skills. \n  General reading skills. \n  General writing skills (includes language usage in terms of vocabulary, grammar, punctuation and referencing). \n  Referencing primary legal source material.  Citing law cases \n It is essential to note: \n\n--- Page 355 ---\n    \n  \n  \n  324 ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nTABLE 11.1 TWO SPECIMEN PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nQuestion 1 \nCliff and Norm spend the evening drinking in their usual bar. Cliff offers Norm a lift home in his \ncar, assuring Norm that he will be okay to drive as he is ‘probably only just over the drink-drive limit’. On the journey home Cliff takes a corner too fast and crashes the car. The paramedics who arrive at the scene fnd that Norm has broken his arm but otherwise only has minor cuts and bruises. Norm is taken to hospital to be checked by a doctor and have his arm placed in a cast. At the hospital Norm is seen by Diana, the doctor on duty. Diana disagrees with the paramedics’ opinion on Norm’s arm and, deciding it is not broken but only sprained, puts it in a sling, without setting it in a cast. As she was so busy that evening, she decided not to bother sending him for an X-ray frst. Norm returns to hospital the following month with pain in his arm. It transpires that his arm was in fact broken and, because it was not set in the proper cast, the bones have fused together wrongly, resulting in a permanent disability. An expert consultant orthopaedic surgeon says that there was a chance this might have happened anyway, even if Diana had not been negligent. Norm has to have an operation to try and reset the bones, but this will not improve his arm to the condition it was in before the accident. A week later Norm is knocked down by a speeding motorist who fails to stop and cannot be traced. His right arm is so badly injured that it has to be amputated. Advise Norm in relation to any claims in negligence he may bring. \nQuestion 2 Cedric, a dealer in marble, has a 2kg quantity of rare green Ionian marble for sale. He has \ndone business with Dorothy, a collector of fne green Ionian marble for fve years. She normally pays £250 a kilo. He emailed her last Tuesday, asking if she would be interested in buying the marble. Dorothy emailed back within 15 minutes saying, ‘Yes I will buy the 2kg of the green marble for the usual price of £500. If I hear nothing to the contrary I will consider it mine and bring the money (in cash), and collect it next Monday’. Cedric reads the email but does not reply to it. Advise Dorothy as to her legal position in the following two situations: \n(a) Cedric sells the 2kg of green marble to Timothy for £750.00 on Friday. \n(b) Cedric puts the 2kg of green marble in a box labelled ‘Marble for Dorothy £500 to pay, for \ncollection and payment Monday’. Dorothy decided she did not want the marble after all and so she did not go to Cedric’s on the next Monday. In the meantime Cedric lost out on a sale to Timothy who offered £750 for it on Friday. \n○ The court (Court of Appeal CA, Supreme Court). \n○ The names of judges giving important judgments in cases (which can be \nmajority or dissenting or minority). \n Citing legislation  ensuring you always refer to sections, sub-sections, para -\ngraphs or sub-paragraphs as relevant. \n\n--- Page 356 ---\n     \n \n ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS 325 \n Cases and legislation should be in italics or underlined so they are clearly visible \nin the text. \nFootnotes or endnotes (depending on your law school’s preferred referencing system) must be used to give the full citations of cases, and to give any quite relevant but not absolutely ‘on point’ comments. However, footnotes/endnotes are not expected in exami -\nnation conditions. You could, for example, use brackets in texts to indicate such matters. Nor are you expected to know page numbers, for example, in exams, just the name of the case, the court and the year of the case. \nLegal reasoning skills \n  Understanding legal argument construction and being able to construct a good argument backed by evidence. \n  Competent use of methods of legal reasoning according to the doctrine of precedent. \n  Understanding the relationship between cases and legislation. \nSkills relating to legal problem solution \n  Factual organisation of a problem scenario usually with complex sets of dates, tim -\nings, actions, and multiple participants. \n  Identifcation of the legal issue or issues raised by the given factual scenario. \n  Knowledge of the law in a given area (e.g. criminal law, law of contract, law of tort) so that you can identify legal issues relating to liability and any issues relating to defences. \n  Understanding of any interpretational doubts or gaps about the law revealed by decided cases in the area under consideration. \n  Ability to handle and apply case law and legislation to a problem. \n  The ability to manage and classify the given facts in a problem question and system -\natically apply the law to those facts. \nMETHODS FOR THE PREPARATION AND CONSTRUCTION \nOF ANSWERS TO PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nThe key to answering a problem question successfully lies in spotting the ‘clues’ to the \nlegal issues to be discussed. Primarily the clues are in the facts you have been given in the problem. It is for you to apply your legal understanding to the facts and extract the issues. But also many of these clues are purely linguistic and organisational. You need to carefully consider any signposting words such as prepositions, or the use of any dates and times that may need to be unravelled and understood within the context of the set problem. You also need to be able to make reference to actions that need to be carefully considered. \n\n--- Page 357 ---\n    \n \n 326 ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nAt root in a problem question you are dealing with: \n  A fctitious fact situation involving a dispute disclosing legal issues that may result in \nlegal liability being allocated to one or more of the participants in the factual scenario. \n  Legal rules that need to be found, interpreted and applied to those legal issues. \n  Prediction of whether a particular social actor is likely to be legally liable for actions disclosed in the problem scenario. \nIdeally what should be happening as you read your problem question is that certain facts, or groups of facts, should trigger reminders of cases with similar facts, which you can then seek out. \nMethods for writing solutions to problem questions \nThere are several methods recognised for outlining the issues that need to be dealt with in problem questions. The key skill is to adopt one technique and then methodically fol -\nlow it through. As you gain experience you will fnd the method easier to use and your understanding of the analysis of legal problems will become more sophisticated. Once you have perfected your preferred technique you can use it for all problem questions in all of your subjects throughout your legal studies and beyond into a legal career. Table 11 .2 \nsets out four suggested methods. In fact they are all similar and Column 1, the description column, notes a four-stage general approach. Until each stage is completed you cannot begin to determine the content of each part of the structure to your answer. \nStage 1: identifcation of the legal issues arising \nfrom the facts in the problem question \nSeveral sub-stages are involved here as follows: \nIdentifcation of all relevant facts given in the problem question \nThe key here is your meticulous attention to detail as you read the problem question. If \nyou misunderstand the facts due to a careless reading, you will also fail to pick up rel -\nevant legal issues. The facts will vary in terms of their relevance. Again you need to \nmake judgments about these matters based on your understanding of the law. For exam -\nple, in a shoplifting case, the fact it is heavily raining may well not be a relevant fact, but it would be highly relevant in a dangerous driving prosecution. \nYou may fnd a simple fow chart of the facts and their ordering helps you to grasp \nthe issues; you can then place cases, etc. beside facts. This can be extremely helpful in allowing you to identify all relevant issues. \nIdentifcation of the primary and secondary legal issues raised by the facts \nYou have to ascertain this from the information and facts of the problem. This is part of the skill of answering problem questions. You will locate the law by going over your lecture notes, revisiting any relevant seminar work, reading sections in your textbooks, and read -\ning the full text of relevant cases. \nIt is unwise to assume that all that you identify on a frst reading (before engagement \nwith Stage 2 location of legal rules and other wider reading) is the sum total of the issues to be discussed. As you develop your understanding of the law you may well fnd that more legal issues become apparent. \nChecking the capacity of the defendant or a litigant to be held liable \nIssues of age and mental awareness, for example, can lead to a situation in which the law holds that a given defendant does not have the required capacity to be held liable for a breach of law. \nStage 2: identifcation of all relevant legal rules \nDetermine the relevant legal rules relating to any breach of law \nThis will involve wider reading in textbooks as well as researching cases and legisla -\ntion; the more careful your research, the greater your understanding of the issues will become. \nStage 3: application of relevant legal rules \nto the legal issues identifed \nCarefully consider doubts/interpretational issues and ask yourself \nwhat you consider to be the appropriate response to them \nProblem questions usually involve issues relating to uncertainty or gaps in the law. You \nneed to locate these, research them, read secondary legal texts as well as the law itself, and read relevant primary case law carefully. Then form a view based on existing law and predicted application of law in relation to those doubts or gaps \n\n--- Page 360 ---\n     \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS 329 \nDiscussion of applicable defences/mitigation \nThere are general defences to a range of breaches of civil and criminal law, as well \nas defences that are specifc to given circumstances and breaches. You need to be aware of these when you are considering the answer to a problem question and explain the breach, or provide an accepted legal recognition of the act leading to the breach. In addition there may be certain information that the court can be asked to consider, for example, specifc circumstances existing at the time of the breach that may lead the court to lower damages awarded against a litigant or a sentence imposed on a defendant. \nDecide the order in which you will discuss your identifed legal issues. \nStage 4: your determination of liability based on your \nprediction of the likely application of the law \nConsider the strength of arguments for and against each point raised for answer and \ncome to your view. \nTHE STRUCTURE OF YOUR FINAL WRITTEN ANSWER \nIt is important to develop a clear layout for your problem solution so that your arguments can be followed, and there is no danger of you forgetting to discuss an important issue. Obviously, all sources must be appropriately referenced according to the system required by your department or in the absence of a departmental preference according to the system you prefer. Additionally you must seek to continue to develop a good third party voice for your written work. These general matters have been discussed in detail in earlier chapters. \nWhen all of the matters in Stages 1–4 have been investigated and resolved to your \nsatisfaction your answer needs to be carefully formatted and structured. The standard structure for this is set out in the last column of Table 11.2 and will be familiar to you from \nessay structure: (1) the introduction, (2) the main body of the answer and (3) the conclu -\nsion. Each of these will be discussed in turn, as the detail of each part of the structure is different to that for an essay. \n(1)Introduction \nYour introduction needs to make clear what legal issues are raised by the problem and how you will approach them. If the problem discloses more than one potential issue of liability then these must be discussed separately. It is far too easy to make a mistake and forget something if you discuss everything together. It is also quite easy in these circum -\nstances to confuse the marker of your work too. \n\n--- Page 361 ---\n    330 ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nIf you are discussing separate potential issues of liability, it is also important to note any \ndefences separately. However, do not be tempted to engage in an essay-style debate. A \nproblem question requires a straightforward layout of legal issues and liability. Discussion of irrelevancies is therefore liable to be taken as a sign of confusion on the part of the student or lack of knowledge. \n(2) Main body: the worked out answer to the problem question \nThis is where your legal argument is laid out in detail, and each proposition backed with evidence if possible. Where the law is extremely uncertain it may be acceptable to refer to arguments in textbooks or articles, but your main proof must be the law and its inter -\npretation by the courts. This part of your answer may contain headings and sub-headings as appropriate for different heads of liability. It is certainly a good idea if the problem question involves several breaches of law and/or the discussion of the liability of several parties to an action, or several defendants are being prosecuted. This is a decision for you once you have determined the issues that need to be discussed. \nYou may not have considered that you were constructing legal arguments. However, \nyou were. By the very act of applying legal rules to fact situations to provide a rationale for liability or non-liability of a relevant party you were creating legal argument. \n(3)Conclusion \nIt is always best practice to give an overall conclusion which can just be a few lines. This ensures that you can sum up the important parts of your argument (which you have proved at length in your main body) to answer the problem question. \nFigure 11 .1 sets out the four-stage method for approaching problem questions and \nthe threefold structure for writing your answer to a problem question. Each stage of the process and each aspect of the fnal written solution must be constantly subjected to your critical refection. \nA GUIDED DEMONSTRATION OF THE BASICS OF THE FOUR-\nSTAGE PROBLEM-SOLVING METHOD, USING PROBLEM \nQUESTION 2 IN TABLE 11 .1 AS AN EXAMPLE \nStage 1: identifcation of the legal issues arising \nfrom the facts in the problem question \nThe frst task is to read the question and determine the topic. Look carefully at Question 2 and identify the facts given and list them in a fow chart \nas this gives a timeline as well as making it easier to pick out issues and people (you will fnd an example of this at the end of the chapter). \nThe problem question can be underlined and issues drawn out in a very simple frst \nreading. This combination is demonstrated in Figure 11 .2. The words that are the clues \nto the legal issues are boxed and arrows leading from these words begin to discuss the legal issues raised. \nThere are two things to note in a problem question like this one that comes with two \nlabelled parts: (a) and (b): \nYou must answer both parts unless instructed clearly that candidates are to answer \neither  (a) or (b). Many students can fail here and assume there is a choice. Do not exercise \na choice unless this is clearly given; otherwise, you could lose half of the marks available for the problem question. \nIt is important to break the question down into its constituent issues so that the con -\ntext of (a) and (b) can be appreciated. \nStage 2: identifcation of all relevant legal rules \nIdentify the primary and secondary legal issues raised by the facts, available defences and doubts in the law. \nYou may choose to place the legal issues on a tree diagram. List the facts relevant to \neach issue. \nConsider the law that might apply, for example, legislation or common law. An offer must be communicated and be certain: Gibson v Manchester County Council \n(1978). Cedric’s email uses the words ‘interested’ in buying. It mentions no price. It is hard to see how this could be an offer. If this is the case, then Dorothy’s email cannot be con -\nstrued as an acceptance. However, Dorothy is clearly interested. We could argue that her response to Cedric’s email is an offer in response to his invitation to deal (technically ‘to treat’), an offer that contains both a price and a method of acceptance. This offer is clear and communicated. But has that offer been accepted? \nAn acceptance of an offer must be communicated and will not normally be implied \nfrom silence: Felthouse v Brindley  (1862). \nThe standard rule relating to an acceptance of an offer is that it must be communi -\ncated; however, case law does allow communication to be construed from conduct. \nCan it be said that because in (b) Cedric puts the marble aside labelled for Dorothy \nwith the price to pay he can be said to communicate acceptance in the circumstances by his conduct? To whom has he communicated his acceptance? How would Dorothy know? You will need to ask many similar questions and then check out law texts and primary legal rules to work towards an answer. \n\n--- Page 364 ---\n333   ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS\nFor every proposition you make you must refer to a law case in support. In an area of doubt, for \nexample, on some occasions it may be enough to make a decision and back it by the \nstate of uncertainty and any case support no matter how tenuous. What the reader, who \nis also your marker, is looking for is your skill in dealing with such legal issues with con -\nfidence, competently demonstrating your knowledge of the area and the relevant cases, \nand competently applying that knowledge. Each subject area will have its own areas of \ndoubt and uncertainty, and these are the areas to concentrate upon: the rules, the excep -\ntions to the rules and the doubts. However, as a final demonstration, Figure 11 .3 begins \nto link propositions and cases.\nStage 3: application of relevant legal rules \nto the legal issues identified\nConsider each legal issue that you have raised, treating each potential liability and each \npotential party separately, and:\n  Decide the order in which issues will be raised in your answer.\n  Consider your view of uncertainties and gaps in the law in the area.\n  Consider issues of interpretation and defence.\n\n--- Page 366 ---\n     \n  \n  \n  ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS 335 \nA doubt about the interpretation of the law is not a defence; it is a doubt about the law. \nMake sure you do not make this mistake, as dealing with these doubts requires different approaches. \nIn our example, it should be apparent that you need to have a view as to whether a \ncontract has been concluded between Cedric and Dorothy, and if so when, before you can actually tackle questions (a) and (b). The answer to this is dependent upon whether an offer and an acceptance can be located. The issues to be considered can also be set out as a narrative where you should consider the effect of each component: \n(1) Cedric emails Dorothy stating he has marble to sell and is she interested? Is it an offer or an invitation to treat? \nNo price is mentioned. Is that normal business practice between them? \n(2) Dorothy’s email states yes, she would buy and gives a price. Is that an acceptance or an offer? \nIs Dorothy’s email an acceptance? Is Dorothy’s email a statement of intention? Is \nDorothy’s email an offer? \nCan Dorothy waive the necessity for the communication of the acceptance if she \nso chooses? \n(3) The problem question asks you to evaluate two responses to these facts, the frst (a) where Cedric ignored Dorothy’s email letter and sold to someone else for a higher price; and the second (b) where he put the marble aside in response to the email put -\nting a sticker on it saying sold and the price, but Dorothy did not collect it when she said she would and he missed out on selling it to someone else. \nYou are expected to consider the facts, legal issues and the uncertainties carefully, con -\nsulting case law and you would no doubt consult textbooks as well as case law concern -\ning these matters. \nWith regard to part (a), if a contract has been formed, then Cedric is in breach of this \ncontract when he sells the marble to Timothy. With regard to case law and commentators it does seem highly likely that, in these circumstances, no contract has been formed with Dorothy and Cedric is free to sell the marble. \nWith regard to part (b), if Dorothy has made an offer, not an acceptance, then Cedric \nhas possibly accepted the offer when he takes the step of setting aside the marble, as it is possible to show acceptance by conduct. If this is the case, a contract has been formed and Dorothy is obliged to buy the marble. It needs to be noted that there are faws and weaknesses in this particular question. There are, however, signifcant weaknesses in reaching this conclusion. \nIt should also be noticed that at present we have suggested issues but as yet we have no: \n  Argument by way of linked propositions. \n  Proofs (law cases) supporting or denying our propositions (or texts discussing areas where the law is unknown or uncertain). \n\n--- Page 367 ---\n    \n  \n  \n \n 336 ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nWithout a sustained argument backed by law cases there is no competent answer to the problem question. \nHaving used the word identifcation to sort out the legal issues they come down to the \nfollowing: \n(a) Is Cedric’s email an offer or an invitation to treat? \n(b) The answer to (a) determines the status of Dorothy’s email – it is either a counter offer or an acceptance. \nHow do we approach answering (a) and (b)? Much revolves around the issue of communication. \nStage 4: your determination of liability based on your \nprediction of the likely application of the law \nThe facts in a problem question can give rise to many issues but all of these may not be \nnecessary to resolve the specifc question(s) set in your problem. Problem questions tend to ask you to do one of two main things: \n  discuss the issues raised in the problem scenario; \n  advise one or all of the parties. \nBoth types of problem question require the same knowledge to answer them success -\nfully. However, your approach to the answers will differ. In response to a question about \ndiscussing issues in general you must raise all the issues without privileging one party. Where you have been asked to advise one or all of the parties, you must raise all the issues but orientate your argument to the effect of those issues on the party, or parties, you are specifcally asked to advise, discussing, with reasons, the likely allocation of legal liability and the possibility of any available defences. \nOnce you have come to a decision and know that you have carefully followed each of \nthe four stages you have all of the information required to produce a well-written response to the problem question. This needs to be structured according to the standardised for -\nmat of introduction, main body, and conclusion. \nCONCLUSION \nA problem solution does not require the discussing of academic articles and books \n(unless the book or article has been ‘judicially recognised’ in court). However, you will no doubt need to consult secondary academic texts to develop your understanding of the legal issues involved in your problem question. When you write your answer, however, all you are required to do is to engage in a discussion of relevant legal authority (cases) and statutory rules. \n\n--- Page 368 ---\n     \n \n ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS 337 \nWhatever type of problem question you are dealing with, the same type of information \nbase is required. It is how this information, knowledge and understanding are drawn on \nto produce a particular written result that is important. \nFollowing standard methods for the preparation and construction of problem question \nanswers can help you effectively order the different tasks involved. You can move on to your own preferred methods. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  A problem question at the academic stage of education is a fctitious legal dispute invariably drafted in such a way as to raise situations where there are conditions of doubt about facts, legal issues or the interpretation of the law. \n  A problem solution tests whether you understand a particular area of law well and can apply it. \n  Problem questions are often set in areas of doubt, so always be wary if you think the answer to the problem is simple and clear cut. \n  You have to have a good understanding of the way in which series of cases have developed areas of law, how different judgments by leading senior judges can be of relevance in the development of legal argument, and you need to appreciate the relationship between legislation and case law, and the role of statutory interpretation by the judiciary. \n  The student is expected to only refer to legal (unless the judges in specifc cases have referred to academic articles or books in court, which is unlikely – but possible in certain defned situations). \n  Problem questions bring together all of the skills of research, argumentation, critical analysis and application of law. \n  Problem questions are specifcally designed to test your developing abilities to research, handle and apply legal rules, construct an argument and engage in competent writing. \n  The key to answering a problem question successfully lies in spotting the ‘clues’ to the issues to be discussed. Many of these are purely linguistic and organisational, using prepositions, signposting words, and use of dates and times that may need to be unravelled. \n  There are several methods recognised for outlining the issues that need to be dealt with in problem questions (IRAC, IPAC, CLEO, PLAN). \n  All methods tend to involve the same four general stages. Stage 1: identifcation of the legal issues arising from the facts in the problem \nquestion. \nStage 2: identifcation of all relevant legal rules. Stage 3: application of relevant legal rules to the legal issues identifed (including \nthose relating to any defence or mitigation and discussion of any interpretational doubts concerning relevant legal rules). \n\n--- Page 369 ---\n    338 ANSWERING LEGAL PROBLEM QUESTIONS \nStage 4: your determination of liability based on your prediction of the likely applica -\ntion of the law. \n  In many respects the threefold structure used for essays (introduction, main body \nand conclusion) can equally be used to structure a problem question solution:  Introduction to problem solution. \n The main body of answer which relates to all of the issues raised in the introduction. \n Conclusion. \n  Following standard methods for the preparation and construction of problem ques -\ntion answers can help you effectively order the different tasks involved. \n\n--- Page 370 ---\n12 \n  \n ORAL PRESENTATIONS \nAND MOOTING \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Understand the specifc personal skills of oral delivery, such as volume and tone of \nvoice, body position, eye contact and speed of delivery, and how they equate with written skills. delivery. \n  Start delivering mooting speeches. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-15  \n\n--- Page 371 ---\n    \n 340 ORAL PRESENTATIONS AND MOOTING \nINTRODUCTION \nAny form of rounded academic education should ensure that graduates leave university \nwith excellent communication skills. Legal education at the academic stage provides you with several different opportunities to develop your oral skills. In addition, should you intend to pursue a career in law, the vocational stage of legal training majors on assess -\ning students as they engage in a large number of oral exercises that test competency in a range of differing types of oral communication skills, as well as the ability to apply legal rules or deliver legal information. \nIn any case, however, it is enormously important to be able to make your arguments \nconvincingly – whether you become a lawyer or not. It is highly likely that you will need to present your work or your opinion orally sooner rather than later. This could be in an assessed presentation in your modules, as part of the professional training of becoming a lawyer, as part of a moot exercise, as a way of presenting your report to your line man -\nager, as a way to convince your clients or customers or in many other forms. \nMooting is an excellent way to work on these skills, and it is strongly recommended \nthat you take part in mooting activities at your law school as early as possible – even if you already decided that you do not want to become a barrister. Part of this chapter will explain some of the peculiarities of a mooting presentation. \nMANAGING STRESS \nEveryone fnds speaking in public challenging, and everyone gets stressed and nervous about it – including your lecturers, and including seasoned barristers with years of court experience. The only way to reduce the stress and anxiety is, unfortunately, to confront it. This is one of the reasons why doing presentations during your studies is a great exercise. Keep in mind that your audience – especially at university – wants you to succeed and do well. Your lecturers and your fellow students understand your challenges and are there to support you. If you get stuck, make a mistake, forget something you wanted to say or start sweating or trembling, it is not the end of the world – everyone will understand! Make sure to expose yourself to as many presentation exercises as possible, in modules, socie -\nties (mooting, debating, acting) or outside of university (e.g. in a local Toastmasters club). \nWith time, things will get easier. You can fnd ways to reduce the stress, and you can \nfnd ways of ensuring that people do not notice that you are nervous. Remind yourself constantly to slow down – most people speed up under stress. And one of the most important things is to control your breathing. Remind yourself to breathe calmly through -\nout the presentation, and plan for having breaks in your delivery. There are plenty of exercises that can help you establish calm, natural breathing. Also make sure you have a glass of water with you during the presentation. Stress makes the mouth dry out, which makes speaking more diffcult. \n\n--- Page 372 ---\n     \n \n \n  341 ORAL PRESENTATIONS AND MOOTING \nAnd probably the best way of controlling your nervousness is to be in charge of the mate -\nrial. If you prepare well, know the topic and your arguments, you will be more relaxed than if \nyou have just started reading the night before and are not quite sure what some of the things you say mean. If you rehearse the presentation multiple times, you will also feel more relaxed. \nTHE COMPONENTS OF COMPLETING A PRESENTATION \nThe main types of oral skills exercises that you are liable to encounter on your law degree course are set out in Figure 12 .1. \nSome of these will be individual tasks only; others will require group work. Whatever \nthe nature of the oral skills tasks, their successful completion involves working on six key components (usually several at the same time): \n  understanding the nature of the task; \n  managing the task; \nTYPES OF \nORAL \nEXERCISE Debating \nNegotiation \nMooting \nPresentations Client \ncounselling \nand \ninterviewing Mediation \nFigure 12.1 Types of oral skills exercises \n\n--- Page 373 ---\n    \n \n  342 ORAL PRESENTATIONS AND MOOTING \n  research; \n  content; \n  delivery; \n  teamwork. \nEach of these six components is interconnected, as demonstrated in Figure The \nmain differences occur at the level of delivery in terms of style and language, and whether teamwork is involved. \nThe following sections work through each of the components in detail. \nUnderstanding \nThere are several types of oral skills tasks and each has different requirements. You and your team (if there is one) must commit proper time to make sure you know exactly what the task is, what it is testing and drawing out all its issues. If you do not properly under -\nstand the task itself, you will not obtain a good result. \n\n--- Page 375 ---\n    344 ORAL PRESENTATIONS AND MOOTING \nMake sure you do not only understand the questions but also the surrounding factors: \n  What is the time limit? \n  Are you allowed to or do you have to use slides? \n  Is this presentation supposed to cover the whole topic or is it supposed to be a \npart of a discussion? \nManaging the task \nThere are two levels at which it is important to manage the task: the macro organisation of the order and timing of each sub-task that leads to the fnal product, and the micro organisation of ensuring the time limit for actual delivery is met. \nOverall task management \nThe degree of detail required by the oral skills exercise will be determined by the time -\nscale you have been given. A fve-minute presentation cannot deliver the same level of detail as a 25-minute one. The longer you have, the more detailed your presentation would have to be. \nAlso, an assessed oral exercise will be treated somewhat differently to a non-assessed \nexercise as it will be supplied with assessment criteria. These give details of what the marker is looking for in the fnished exercise, and the skills levels required to obtain marks in each grade. You should be given a copy of the mark sheet and assessment criteria that the assessor will use, or be directed to a general mark sheet and general oral skills assessment criteria that are used for oral assessment. \nThe assessment criteria and the mark sheet are important documents to consider \nbecause they tell you what you have to do and how this should be demonstrated. You should also check the marks allocations as you will fnd out how many marks are avail -\nable for content and argument construction, how many for teamwork if relevant and how many for the purely oral skills of tone of voice, speed of voice, use of appropriate formal language and so on. \nIf you need to prepare a group presentation, this is the time to set out the different \ntasks within the dissertation. \nTime limits \nThe ‘time limit’ given for any oral skills work can be viewed as having the same function as a ‘word limit’ in written work. But whilst departmental regulations can often allow leeway on word counts, time limits in oral assessments are rigorously applied, and the student will be asked to stop speaking when the time is up.
