\nIf the mere sight of it is liable to depress you, move on to the next section and come \nback to it another time. \nThe givens are put in frst, the dates of your exams and the timings of any paid work, \nor any other occasions when you cannot study, for example, family birthdays and spe -\ncial occasions. Relaxation time is also allocated on most days. The third session (see Figure 13 .2) ends at 9 pm so relaxation time is always available after that time. You can \ncustomise the sessions and times to suit you. You need to work with your best times, but be aware that there will be times when you have to revise when you are tired. When you are designing your revision plan do not leave too much to the last minute. You need to know yourself, act wisely and plan effectively so that you can draw up a realistic plan and stick to it. It may be a good idea to try and cut back on paid employment during revision and exams, if your pocket and your employer can cope. \nIt is sensible to allocate a specifed revision session to each module. You may allocate \nless time to those with lower exam weightings. Whether you put a large number of same-subject revision together or split it up throughout your timetable is up to you. If you get easily bored by revision you will relate better to change. \nA comments column allows for working out the weekly revision hours and study ses -\nsions and for any other notes, for instance, if you have missed a session. \nCompiling the list of topics that you will revise \nVery few students can learn everything well, and attempting to learn everything can result in mediocre and patchy knowledge that reduces all of your revision to a superfcial level. It is, however, possible to learn a few topics very well indeed. Since some exams are designed so that a limited series of topics come up, many students will select the topics that they are going to revise, leaving some topics to one side. This process is part of the exam game plan or strategy. Topic picking is a diffcult issue. Attitudes to it among both students and academics vary. \nAbove all else topic picking involves knowing all the examinable topics in your module \nand understanding your own strengths and weaknesses. It may also involve predict -\ning what may, or may not, come up in the exam. You need to listen to the information given to you by your lecturer and read what is said about the exam in your departmental and module subject guides and any module revision guides issued by your lecturer or department. \nThe next step is to make strategic choices about the number of topics that you can \nrevise in each of the subjects that you are studying. Only you can decide the number of topics to pick. You need to know how the topics splinter into a range of sub-topics (for example, theft splits into issues of dishonesty that can be the object of an essay, as well as general problem questions). You also need to know the range of topics that could come up together. Here learning just one topic could mean that you cannot answer the question. For example, if you revise murder and not the partial defences, or indeed do not revise manslaughter, you might have diffculty in a problem question designed to test \n\n--- Page 410 ---\n   \n       EXAMINATION STRATEGIES 379 \nyour knowledge of whether the defendant may be liable for murder or manslaughter, or \nwhether a partial defence applies to murder. \nYou need to make sensible decisions. If you are convinced a topic will come up, but it \nis a topic that you struggle with and have never understood, think carefully before choos -\ning to revise it. Even if the topic is guaranteed to be in the exam, is there any guarantee that you will be able to understand it before the exam? \nFrom the inventory of topics that you draw up for each module you will need to con -\nsider your state of understanding of topics and then choose those that you feel most con -\nfdent about in terms of understanding. Obviously if some topics will form the foundation of a compulsory question you have no choice. Table 13 .4 sets out a potential ‘personal \nknowledge checklist’ and again uses criminal law as our specimen module. \nIn our example in Table 13 .4 there are several areas that have not yet been covered by \nthe student. There are also topics the student fnds ‘confusing’. They will need to decide whether it is worth spending the time getting up to speed on these topics or whether they should leave them. When making decisions about which topics to cover if you have a free choice and know what tends to come up and what does not you should make fnal choices based on your strengths and weaknesses. Also too many topics may be chosen: it looks like possibly nine areas could be chosen. Yet the paper contains eleven questions and students only need to answer two. \nThe value of this exercise lets you know if you are trying to cover too much, diluting the \nability to learn more information about fewer topics in more depth. \nFor every topic that you do cover, it is best to prepare for both an essay and a problem \nquestion scenario, as you cannot always predict how a question will arise on the exam paper. Problem questions require quite extensive primary sources of law. Essay ques -\ntions require academic sources and it is often necessary to discuss primary sources of law. It is important to realise that the same basic information is needed to do a problem question and an essay question and it is best to revise a topic in order to answer whatever type of question comes up. \nAssisting your memory \nOnce you have collated a full set of revision material from: \n  lecture notes; \n  seminar notes; \n  private study notes; \n  case notes; \n  articles/books. \nyou should condense all the information into key point form. You then need to ensure you \nunderstand these key points and can remember them. \nMemorising these key points can be diffcult. However, although law exams cannot be \nsimply passed by rote memory, you have to engage in memory tasks to commit to your \n\n--- Page 411 ---\n \n  \n \n \n   \n  \n     \n \n \n 380 EXAMINATION STRATEGIES  \nTABLE 13.4 SAMPLE KNOWLE\nTOPICS DGE SUMMARY FOR EXAMINABLE \nCriminal law Coverage Type of question I can do Comment \nExaminable Topics Problem question Essay \nThe contexts of criminal law, \n• history \n• media \n• classifcations of \ncriminal acts \n• offcial statistics x – – But I only want to do an essay on classifcations of criminal acts. \nPrinciples and Policies \n• Criminalisation \n• Media \n• Women \n• Actus reus \n• Mens rea √ – √ I only want to do \ncriminalisation. You can \nengage in several different approaches for revision; some may not suit you, but ideally you should engage in all of them. They assist in committing information to memory and putting you in a good position to pass the exam. Table 13 .5 shows a range of different \nactivities that relate to the learning styles discussed in Chapter 5 . You will have your own \npreference for what works best. \nHow long before the exam should I start revising? \nThis is your decision and is infuenced by a range of factors, including how fast you work, how consistently you have studied all year, how much new understanding you need to acquire and how many topics you struggle with. It is quite possible that when you have done your revision programme you will fnd that you have differing amounts of revision to do for each exam. \n  Do not underestimate  how much you need to do. \n  Do not overestimate what you can do in the time you have. \n  Pace your revision . If you push yourself too much and become too tired your brain will \n‘switch off’ and you will fnd it extremely diffcult to keep going with your revision. If \nyou feel this happening, stop and take time to develop a more effcient plan. \n  Sleep . The temptation to revise late into the night is strong for some at exam time, but \nit is important to ensure you have enough sleep. Your brain is your major asset to be used in passing the exams. It needs sleep to be replenished. \n  From your inventory of topics for the course you will need to know which ones you can potentially tackle. \nRevision activities and how to keep motivated \n(boredom sabotages revision!) \nFor many students, revision is not only stressful (because it reminds you that exams are \nlooming); it is also boring. This means that however hard you try you may not remember what you revise as your brain has switched itself off. \nTo avoid getting bored, fnd the revision activity that best suits you. There are many \ndifferent revision activities to choose from, as shown in Figure 13 .3. All of these make \nrevision active. Consider whether any of these would work for you. \nTHE DAY OF THE EXAMINATION \nYou have done all the revising you can and now it is the day of the exam. It is worth think -\ning about what you need to know on the day and what habits you should try to acquire beforehand. Figure 13 .4 lists some ways of staying unfustered and relaxed so you are \nable to perform at your best on the day. \n\n--- Page 413 ---\n \n  \n \n \n \n  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n   \n  \n \n   382 EXAMINATION STRATEGIES  \nTABLE 13.5 LEARNING STYLES AND MEMORY TACTICS FOR ENHANC -\nING YOUR REVISION \nLEARNING \nSTYLES EXAMPLE ACTIVITIES \nKINESTHETIC \nLEARNING STRATEGIES • Link the information you are learning to doing different things. For \ninstance, you could try learning different topics in different places to help recall. \nVISUAL LEARNING STRATEGIES • Construct diagrams of interconnections. \n• Construct a mind map. \n• Draw symbols or even pictures to help you remember cases. All you need \nin the exam is a trigger to release the door to your memory. Then you only need to learn the trigger. \n• Colour code narrative points if you wish. \n• Make revision fashcards: questions on one side and answers on the other. \n• Make revision fashcards: with case name on one side and the facts, \nreasoning and any precedent/interpretational point notes on the other. \n• Make some revision quizzes in the same way. • Making these up is of course part of the revision and memorising process. \nHARNESSING • Speak your notes aloud. \nAUDITORY • Think of rhymes for different things. \nLEARNING • Record your notes and listen to them. • Find a patient friend or relative and explain your topic to them. \nFORMAL • Write answers to past or specimen exam papers under exam conditions in \nCHECKS the time you will have in the exam. Check your answers in your textbook. \n• Remember that all of the conventions for good writing apply in an exam. • Check your answer for legible handwriting. Ask a friend if they can read it. • Check that you have provided evidence for each point in your argument. • Lecturers will often have specifc timescales within which they will look at \nspecimen answers so it is worth asking in good time if they will consider your draft answer. \nIf you fnally realise that you have chosen to not properly prepare, then there is no point \nover-stressing; you can only follow through with the exam and hope for some luck. \nStrategies during the examination \nIt is important that you have a pre-plan of how you will divide up your time during the \nexamination. Before the exam you need to have practised effciently, producing draft answers in the actual time you will have in the exam. \n\n--- Page 414 ---\n   \n          \n  EXAMINATION STRATEGIES 383 \nFigure 13.3 Revision activities \nFigure 13.4 Good habits on exam day \nIf you have a two-hour exam and only need to answer two questions you should allow \nreading time of ten minutes at the start, and ten minutes for edits, proofng review at \nthe end. This means you have around 1 hour 40 minutes to write your two answers (50 minutes each). Some universities allow 15 minutes reading time under exam conditions immediately prior to the commencement of the exam. \nBelow are some suggestions for dividing up your time in a two-hour exam without \nreading time prior to its commencement. \n(1) The frst ten minutes: read the whole paper through carefully and decide which ques -\ntions you will answer. Check the length of the exam and the number of questions you are told to answer; check for compulsory questions. Make sure you know which questions are ‘either/or’ questions and which are asking you to do both parts of a question. Think about what the examiner is looking for in each question and whether you can deliver it. Check that you have properly explored the language of the question \n\n--- Page 415 ---\n \n  \n  \n  \n  \n \n  \n  \n  384 EXAMINATION STRATEGIES  \nso that you do not miss questions you are able to answer, or miss points in the ques -\ntions you have decided to answer. \n(2) The next ten minutes could be used to plan answers to all of your chosen questions, \nor you could start your frst question, planning each question as you go. Whichever \nprocess you use, planning time has to be incorporated into the time you have allot -\nted for writing your answer to each question. Do not be tempted into writing without considered pre-planning of the question on a separate piece of paper. You can plan by making notes or drawing a diagram, and before the exam you need to think about how you will do this, and practise it when you do specimen papers under exam conditions. Invariably there will be a hierarchy in the questions you have picked to answer, with some topics you know well and some less well. Be rigorous, however, about moving on to the next question at the end of your allotted time for each ques -\ntion. This will open up the next set of marks for you. One brilliant answer rarely makes up for missed questions. Even a mediocre answer joined to a great one can push you into the next grade band. But if you continue to make your great question greater, you are not really opening up the marks available to you. Each question has a set number of marks. \n(3) During the planning and writing process constantly refer back to the question to make absolutely certain you are addressing it. You are being tested on your struc -\ntured and methodical approach to the questions you answer, as well as on your knowledge and its application to the questions. \n(4) When structuring your essay make sure that each of your answers has a brief intro -\nduction, a main body and a conclusion. Also that you refer to academic journals in your answer, plus refer to any appropriate cases or legislation. \n(5) Structuring problem answers  Give a brief introduction stating the ambit of the problem. \n Do a fow chart of facts in your rough work to guide you. \n Answer each head of liability for each party separately. \n Ensure you make clear the rules that are relevant. \n State legal areas involved. \n Clearly set out issues. \n Apply statutes and cases methodically to each element. \n Do not forget defences unless told not to deal with them. \n Conclude for each  party in relation to each  head of liability. \nOnly refer to cases and legislation; do not refer to any academic text unless  it has \nreceived judicial notice in a case. \n(6) Rigidly stick to your pre-planned timing for each question. \n(7) Present your work so that it is easy for the examiner to follow, using the rules pre -\nferred in your department for drawing attention to law cases and statutes (for exam -\nple, underlining them). \n(8) Do leave time in the last ten minutes of the exam to recheck your whole paper for spelling and grammar. If you have been writing too fast, you can leave out important \n\n--- Page 416 ---\n   \n \n  \n EXAMINATION STRATEGIES 385 \nlinking words. This simple error can turn a great point into an incomprehensible point. \nCheck that all your sentences make sense. Neatly  correct any problems. Make sure \nall rough work has a line drawn through it and you have correctly labelled your ques -\ntions. This includes labelling parts of questions. If you think of extra materials or points, annotate your question: examiners will follow clear instructions from the exam candidate. You might also fnd that you remember a point of argument, or a case, or an article that you had originally forgotten when answering the question. You can always add this at the end (ensuring you signpost the examiner to the additional material with an asterisk or some other device). \n(9) At the end of the exam it may be a good idea to avoid those who are dissecting the paper to see what everyone else did, discussing whether they are wrong or right. This could needlessly upset you and even unnerve you before your next exam. \nCONCLUSION \nTo perform successfully in the exam requires sustained organisation on your part. You need to understand the structure of the exam and its relationship to the structure of your course. You need to understand what topics in your course are examinable topics that may come up in the exam. You also need to know your own capability with regard to the course, what you do understand and what you do not understand. This will enable you to properly devise a revision timetable, uniting understanding of the topics with any neces -\nsary rote learning required to apply the law and your academic sources to exam ques -\ntions. Having properly revised you can then plan your in-exam strategy. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  Remember that exams are not unexpected events for which you cannot plan. It is essential to plan for them well in advance. \n  Be sure that you know what exams are designed to test. \n  Revision skills and tactics in the exam are an integral part of your skills. Indeed they \nare the summation of your year’s work. \n  Ensure you know the examinable syllabus and have an idea of your competency in each topic. \n  Be quite clear about how fast you write and what you can write in the time of the exam. \n  Ensure your handwriting remains legible when writing to time limits under exam con -\nditions by practising in advance answering questions in the required time. \n  Revise strategically, engaging in topic picking if the exam is not composed of all compulsory questions. \n  Keep a careful and disciplined watch on the time during the exam. \n\n--- Page 417 ---\n 386 EXAMINATION STRATEGIES  \n  Read the exam paper carefully and choose questions wisely. \n  Read and follow all instructions. \n  Answer the required number of questions. \n  Plan each answer. \n  Re-read each of your answers for sense, spelling and errors towards the end of the \nexam. \n  Stay calm – otherwise your ability to think will be impaired. \n  After the exam draw a line under it and move on to the next one. \n\n--- Page 418 ---\n PART 4 \nSKILLS FOR \nRESOLVING DISPUTES \nThe expected learning outcomes of any law degree include an expectation that as a law \nstudent you have competently learned how to analyse and synthesise material to con -\nstruct and sustain, for example, a coherent argument (as covered previously in Part 3) and also learned how to problem-solve effectively. As a law undergraduate, the need to g\nrasp a broad range of skills to prepare yourself for graduate employment is emphasised \nin Part 4. This also refects the willingness of law schools to embrace the introduction of more progressive curriculum strategies, for example the teaching of dispute resolution, which enables your law school to produce effective learning, teaching and assessment practices and curriculum design for transformation. \nTh\ne topics which are covered in this part also refect the fact that some law schools \nhave placed an emphasis on ‘learning law in context’; this has been done through the inclusion of elements of socio-legal education and by utilising practical skills-based learning. \nThe study of dispute resolution as part of the socio-legal education agenda refects \nthe prevailing attitudes to dispute resolution and the prominent place it occupies within the feld of legal practice and is therefore considered to be an important focus for law students’ studies. Learning how to resolve disputes also provides a perfect environment for graduate skills acquisition. \nChapter 14 ‘Negotiation’ not only enables you to gain a sound theoretical understand -\ning of what is now considered to be a recognised academic discipline subject studied by students of both law and business alike, but also gives you the opportunity to acquire some valuable transferable skills. Oral skills competence and confdence in public speak -\ning as well as an appreciation of the interpersonal skills, complement other academic skills which you will be developing such as issues analysis and argument construction. \nIn Chapter 15 ‘Mediation’, you will be introduced to a process of alternative dispute \nresolution which now forms an important part of the dispute resolution continuum and one that has become accepted by lawyers as a viable process for resolving civil dis -\nputes. Communication skills and their importance for effective mediation is emphasised and again the study of mediation presents the opportunity for the acquisition of valuable transferable skills through engagement in role-play simulation exercises. \nThe consolidation of graduate legal skills can also be found in Chapter 16 ‘Drafting’, \nwhich enables students to put their writing skills into practice through the assimilation of \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-17  \n\n--- Page 419 ---\n    388 SKILLS FOR RESOLVING DISPUTES \nfacts and the construction of a piece of writing, whether that be a letter or a more formal \nlegal document, with clarity, accuracy and with the intention of the purpose of that draft -\ning exercise always in mind. \nBy the end of \nPart 4 you should feel confdent in being able to understand the basic \ntheoretical concepts and some key practical skills elements of both negotiation and mediation. You should also be able to approach and successfully complete a rudimentary drafting exercise with more confdence. \n\n--- Page 420 ---\n14 \n  \n NEGOTIATION \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Develop personal confdence in speaking in public. \n  Put into practice general oral skills such as volume of voice, tone of voice, body posi -\ntion, eye contact, pacing. \n  Appreciate the skills requirements of negotiation (analysis of issues, client instruc -\ntions, negotiation positions, team strategies, interpersonal skills, legal research, note \ntaking, referencing, argument construction, in-negotiation strategies). \n  Understand some of the theory associated with the process of negotiation. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-18  \n\n--- Page 421 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n          \n 390 NEGOTIATION  \nINTRODUCTION \nNegotiation is one of several oral skills exercises that you may be required to engage with, \nnot only for non-assessed skills development but also in relation to formal assessment. It depends on a fne balance of personal research, personal oral skills competency and good interpersonal teamwork skills. While mooting represents the litigation paradigm and the concept of court-based dispute resolution, negotiation introduces the ideology of alterna -\ntive dispute resolution (ADR). This is the alternative  to going to court or moving through the \ncourt trial process.\n1 While the aim of a moot is to win (as is the aim of a court case), the aim \nof a negotiation is to reach a settlement or a compromise with the other party. \nAs with mooting the discussion is conducted according to a range of agreed rules of \nengagement concerning who speaks frst and appropriate turn-taking. However, the set -\nting is less formal. \nWhat is negotiation? \nThe process of negotiation may involve two or more parties or representatives. Any nego -\ntiation will require some form of communication between the parties; this may take writ -\nten form or spoken form, either through some form of telecommunication process or as a face to face meeting. In any negotiation there may be mixed motives, interests, require -\nments and goals, both conficting and common. For a negotiation to be successful, there has to be mutual movement from initial positions as well as joint or reciprocal action. The goal of any negotiation is to reach an agreement, but this is by no means guaranteed and there are more than one set of terms or outcomes which are usually possible. \nNegotiation involves identifcation of the following: \n  Issues (in common/which differ); \n  Needs and interests; \n  Options for agreement. \nThe reasons why people negotiate are to accomplish goals. It may be to create or gain something new, for example, a relationship, a partnership, an entity or achieve a transac -\ntion. It may be that the parties to the negotiation hope to resolve a dispute or confict. Essentially, people enter into negotiations because they think that they can use some form of infuence to be better off with the intention of reaching an agreement instead of engaging in a public fght. \nAt the academic stage of legal education, negotiation, like mooting, can be conducted \nas a role play between two teams, who act as legal advisors for the respective clients in a fctitious legal dispute. Unlike mooting, however, the subject matter of a negotiation can be far broader and conceptually different. \n1 A DR encompasses not only negotiation but also other processes such as mediation (when a trained facili -\ntator allows the parties to interact with each other and reach a resolution) and arbitration. You may learn \nmore about it on your English legal system course. Mediation will be considered in Chapter 15 . \n\n--- Page 422 ---\n  \n \n \n NEGOTIATION 391 \nStudents are seated, usually around a table, and while the language is formal and \nrespectful, primary legal sources are not quoted and speeches are not given. There is a conversational dialogue between the two sides as each seeks to implement their pre-planned strategies for obtaining the best deal for their client in light of their client’s instructions. \nRange of skills required for negotiation \nAs you may by now expect, negotiation requires you to integrate a large number of skills, including: \n  personal management of the task; \n  team management of the task and interpersonal skills; \n  research; \n  handling primary legal rules; \n  managing facts and instructions from clients, and other documentation; \n  competent note taking; \n  writing pre-negotiation strategies; \n  competent reporting back to the team; \n  argument construction; \n  oral skills; \n  handling the unforeseen within the negotiation; \n  competent critical review post-negotiation. \nThe skills you bring with you to negotiation \nIt is highly likely that you come to the exercise of negotiation with some naturally \nacquired skills relevant to the task. These will have been deployed and developed just by being in the world, as part of a group of friends or family, in school, university or in the workplace. \nNegotiation is part of everyday life, and you will undoubtedly have engaged in the \nprocess of negotiation at some time or another, so consider the last time that you made a bargain with someone to get something that only they could give you. You probably gave something or offered to do something as an incentive to get what you wanted from the other person. Maybe you wanted time off from your part-time job but thought your boss might refuse. You will have carefully chosen your time to ask for leave and prob -\nably thought of what you could offer in return. Maybe there is a time in the week when you knew that your boss had trouble getting his staff to work. You might have suggested that if he gave you the time off that you wanted, then you would do one or two of those problem shifts straight away, or on your return to work. This situation would be a clas -\nsic example of principled bargaining or negotiation because you need to continue your relationship with your boss. \n\n--- Page 423 ---\n \n \n  \n 392 NEGOTIATION  \nAll of this natural everyday activity involves fexibility. You need to think in advance \nabout what barriers you might have to overcome before you get the ‘yes’, the object that \nyou want. Often you may need to give something in order to get what you want; in nego -\ntiation theory this is often termed as making a concession. Usually you need to have an understanding of how the other person may be thinking, how they will view your request, what it is that you think they may object to, and how you can deal with this. All of this natu -\nral experience can be used to help you gain an understanding of formal legal negotiation. \nNegotiation theory is now the subject of academic discourse, and Fisher and Ury, in \ntheir seminal negotiation text Getting to Yes , suggest that your approach to any negotia -\ntion should include four principles; as best as you can, you should separate the people from the problem; focus on interests, not positions; invent options for mutual gain and insist on using objective criteria.\n2 \nTHE TWO MAIN FORMS OF NEGOTIATION \nNegotiation can take one of two major forms, positional and principled negotiation. Each form requires negotiators to adopt different stances or approaches. You can often deter -\nmine which type of negotiation is called for from the information you are given regarding your client’s instructions to you. However, do not be caught unawares. While your cli -\nent may think the negotiation is of one type, the other party may have different ideas. Negotiation approach or style can often shape the negotiation and determine the kind of agreement reached. \nPositional negotiation \nPositional negotiation is often adversarial or competitive in style approach. Positional negotiators focus on the distribution of outcomes, i.e. a zero/sum or win/lose outcome is likely. Such negotiators are not interested in meeting the needs of others; their gain is at the expense of the other negotiator. In other words the outcome should include the best possible gain for them and is more about who gets the biggest share of the pie (based on the assumption of fnite resources or the fxed pie theory). Positional negotiators style approach is competitive, assertive even aggressive. \nPositional negotiation can refer to a situation where both parties to the negotiation \npropose to reach a settlement on purely fnancial grounds and do not wish to continue any relationship with each other. Because of these factors it can tend to be a more con -\nfrontational form of negotiation. \nPrincipled negotiation \nPrincipled negotiation is often described as collaborative, integrative, problem-solving or interest-based bargaining. Principled negotiators focus on the interests of each party and a distribution of the fxed resources. The principled or collaborative approach will take \n2 F isher R and Ury W, Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In (Penguin, London, 1983), \n16–94. \n\n--- Page 424 ---\n  \n   \n   \n  \n   NEGOTIATION 393 \n1. Pre-nego\u0015a\u0015on planning \n2. In-nego\u0015a\u0015on strategy \n3. Post-nego\u0015a\u0015on cri\u0015cal\n review \nFigure 14.1 The three stages of negotiation \ninto account the other bargainer’s interests. The assumption here is that there is no fxed \npie, and it is a win/win approach or a non-zero/sum game.3 \nPrincipled negotiation can refer to a situation where both parties not only wish a set -\ntlement of the current dispute (which may be seen in fnancial terms), but they also wish, or need, to continue their relationship. This form of negotiation requires a particular approach since the most amicable solution preserving the relationship may not consti -\ntute the best fnancial solution (if money is involved) for one of the parties or even both. However, often in these cases the continuance of the relationship is more important than fnancial issues. By the nature of its aims, principled negotiation tends to be more interac -\ntive and fexible in terms of outcome. \nTHE PROCESS OF A NEGOTIATION \nYou will not be surprised to learn that negotiation is a process. It begins before you and your team enter the room to negotiate and continues afterwards. To help you understand this, it might be helpful to view the negotiation process as a three-stage activity involving: \n(1) pre-negotiation planning; \n(2) in-negotiation strategy; \n(3) post-negotiation critical/refective review. \nThis is demonstrated in Figure 14 .1. \nAs you can see, the greater part of the work takes place before the negotiation. Pre -\nplanning and effective preparation are key to any successful negotiation. \nThere are several ways in which a negotiation can be set up for you by your lectur -\ners, and a variety of ‘paper trails’ may be constructed for you. You may be given the time and opportunity to interview a fellow student role playing a live ‘client’, and here your job will be to extract the details of the dispute and your client’s desired outcome for the negotiation. Or you may be given a written set of client instructions to work from. These written instructions should be relatively comprehensive, giving you all the information you require in order to look into the dispute. They may or may not be supplemented by other \n3 T his approach includes the four theoretical principles expounded by Fisher and Ury mentioned earlier. \n\n--- Page 425 ---\n \n  394 NEGOTIATION  \nconstructed documentation such as letters sent to your client or written by them, copies \nof any relevant contracts or copies of emails and fle notes to and from your client. \nGUIDED NARRATIVE ON THE STAGES IN A NEGOTIATION \nThe next pages will take you briefy through the steps in a typical team negotiation. As with other skills there is no shortage of good guidance available. If you are  to engage in \nnegotiation you will be guided through your exercise by your tutor. However, \nthat does not mean you should not take responsibility for acquiring a general understand -\ning of the area. The negotiation as an exercise, whether assessed or non-assessed, will succeed or fail on the basis of: \n  each individual team member’s independent management of the task; \n  the overall team management of the task. \nFirst meeting with your team and becoming familiar with the client instructions \nThere are usually just two or three students to a team, and you may not know each other \nbefore the task. It is a good idea to meet briefy right at the start, so that introductions can be made. You should then arrange a time to meet to discuss the negotiation, once each of you has had the time to consider: \n  your client’s written instructions, determining the area(s) of law involved and the \npotential issues raised; \n  your client’s instructions concerning the settlement they would fnd acceptable, and their willingness to compromise and if so their leeway for compromise. \nGiving each team member proper time to consider the client instructions will avoid jump -\ning to conclusions. It is important that each team member comes to their own view without being initially led by anyone else. This ensures that several minds have reviewed the instruc -\ntions. If there are uncertainties in the team, a debate can begin about relevant issues. \nThere is no reason why you cannot in your frst brief meeting agree that you will meet one \nor two hours later. The important issue is not to rush these important preliminary stages. \nSecond meeting with the team and allocation of tasks \nA good discussion should take place concerning the areas of law thought to be involved, the nature of the dispute and the client’s desired settlement. Ideally your team should reach a preliminary view as to the areas of law involved and then you can all decide how you will split the initial research between you. You all need to agree on a timescale within which this initial research will be concluded. This will be determined by the date of the actual negotiation or times given to you by your lecturer. You can then work on: \n  researching the area of law that is relevant to your part of your client’s legal dispute. \nThe best place to start is a textbook to get an overview of the area. You can then look at primary legal sources as relevant. Follow any advice from your lecturer on this matter; \n\n--- Page 427 ---\n \n 396 NEGOTIATION  \n  re-considering the facts of the dispute as set out by your client in light of your \nresearch and understanding of the general area of law; \n  considering, if you can at this point, the likely success of your client if the matter were to go to court, given your understanding of the law and the dispute. \nThird team meeting and decisions concerning application of law, \nnegotiating strategies and division of tasks in-negotiation \nAt the third team meeting you should: \n  Pool your research and discuss the likely success of your client, given your under -\nstanding of the law and the dispute, if the matter were to go to court. This information \nlets you know how advantageous it is for your client to settle. It also lets you know the likely response of the other side to your attempts to settle. \n  Consider your client’s directions concerning their desires in relation to settlement. Is it solely a fnancial issue or are there other matters relating to relationships? Effectively, is this a positional or a principled negotiation? \n  Consider any incentives you can offer, such as continuing business relationships. \n  Draw up a plan or agenda for introducing issues during the negotiation. Decide which questions to ask, in which order and determine your best and worst acceptable out -\ncome. Make a plan as to what to do if one of the team ‘freezes’ or begins to discuss a matter out of turn. Is there a leader who will interject? \n  Decide who is responsible for ensuring that at the end of the negotiation there is a clear note of the settlement (if there is one) or the next action to take (if there is no set -\ntlement). If there is a settlement, your note of it should be compared to the other side’s version. Make clear that any settlement has to be fnally agreed upon by your client. \n  Ensure you have a proper strategy for good post-negotiation critical refection. \nAs you discuss all of the matters above, you will agree as a team what further meetings may be required and what written notes have to be made and circulated. \nIn-negotiation strategy \nThe negotiation itself is a dynamic event. You cannot control everything and you do not know if the other team is going to be competent, effcient or professional and what nego -\ntiation style they will adopt. You do not necessarily know what it is that they are going to say or what their plan is, but your team should have thought about their likely strategies and plan. It is a good idea therefore to bring an agenda to the negotiating table and com -\npare the agenda points with those proposed by the other negotiating team (if they have an agenda). Agreeing on an agenda can then help to structure the negotiation. What you do know is your team strategy, where you ft within it and what your job is. Keep to this strategy and your job. Do not jettison it in a panic: you could place your team in jeopardy in the middle of the negotiation. \n\n--- Page 428 ---\n  \n \n  \n \n \n    \n  NEGOTIATION 397 \nAs a team you need to respond to the other team as required. This could mean tak -\ning control of the negotiation at appropriate points to ensure your strategy is worked out \nwhen it is needed. You may also need to change your strategy in response to the other team’s behaviour and strategy. \nAt the micro-level you also need to consider the language that each of you uses. It \nmust be appropriate, formal, professional and not peppered with legal terms. \nWhen you turn to the actual negotiation itself, no matter how much time you have given \nto planning you will be surprised by the speed with which your allotted time passes. You need to have a clear view of the micro-dynamics of the negotiation and the processes it moves through to ensure you reach your goals. These are set out in Figure 14 .3. \n2. Agree basic1. In other words, at \nthe outset of the negotiation, see if you can agree to use one document that both parties \ncan contribute to a set of agreed points that emerge from the ongoing negotiation pro -\ncess. This will ensure that both negotiating teams have the same set of notes/points and this will undoubtedly help to frame the agreement. \nAt the conclusion of the negotiation, the agreed points from the one text document \ncan be written up in a coherent format in order to refect the agreement which has been reached. The chapter on drafting (see Chapter 16 ) should give you some useful guidance \non how to draft a document so as to clearly evidence the terms and details of the agree -\nment reached following your team negotiation. \nPost-negotiation critical review \nReviewing the negotiation after it has taken place is an important learning tool. Indeed, critical refection on any learning task is important as it allows you to achieve your full learning potential. Even if you felt the task went well, discussing the negotiation together as a team can help to tease out real problems and mistakes. You should take time to note which issues were the fault of the other team and which were down to you. However, mistakes by the other team might have caused you or your team to lose confdence. So it is important to discuss all of the issues. Many assessed negotiations will require you to refect on your performance and for the team to submit a post-negotiation review. \nAgenda for post-negotiation refective review \nWhen refecting upon the negotiation you have been involved in, it can be useful to have an agenda to discuss the different aspects of the negotiation. The agenda could include: \nTeam-working issues \n  Was a sensible timescale set up and implemented at the team level? \n  Did anyone fail to meet their obligations and cause a problem for the team? Could this have been avoided? \n  Was there a good set of in-team interpersonal relationships for the task? \n  Is there anything that could be done differently next time? \n  Was there any team mismanagement of the task in terms of timing, preparation or in the negotiation itself? If so, was this inevitable? \n  Is there anything that could be done differently next time? \nIndividual issues \n  Did you effciently manage your own time? \n  Do you consider that you put in adequate time and energy to the team? \n  How did you respond in the team? \n\n--- Page 430 ---\n  \n \n \n   NEGOTIATION 399 \nThe appropriateness of the negotiation strategy – pre-planning \n  Did the team follow the pre-planned strategy? If not, why not? \n  Was the pre-planned strategy extensive enough? \n  Did the team allow themselves enough pre-agreed fexibility? \n  Did the team set suffcient ‘best’ and ‘worst’ case agreed settlements? \n  Did the team set boundaries where they would not settle? \n  Did anything unexpected occur? If so, how successfully did the team deal with it? \n  What would you and/or the team do differently next time regarding a strategy? \nThe negotiation outcome \n  How successful was the outcome – was it the one you had planned for? \n  If you did not want that outcome as a team, is there anything that you or the team \ncould have done differently to avoid it? \n  Was the outcome you achieved the best that you could have got in the circumstances? \nProper attention to the completion of the post-negotiation review enables you to achieve a greater level of critical awareness of the process of negotiation. This will assist the con -\ntinual development of your skills of negotiation. \nCONCLUSION \nNegotiation is a creative activity that provides you with the opportunity to work with a range of skills to refne your understanding of law. It refnes your communication skills and team-working skills and continues to develop your argument construction skills. Not unlike many practical activities which you will encounter as part of your legal education, preparation is key. So, your success in negotiation also depends on your research and analysis skills and the ability to read the instructions in a focused manner, enabling you to work towards the best settlement achievable. Negotiation encourages a sophisticated understanding of the relationship between facts of a dispute, applicable law, and client expectations. \nNegotiation exercises are increasingly being used within the context of the academic \nstage of training because of their great value in allowing students to work within such broad skill sets. If you are able to engage in such exercises, you will fnd that your under -\nstanding of these skills, your ability to handle legal rules and your ability to manage facts will be considerably enhanced. Since these skills are transferable, you will also be enhancing your understanding of other law subjects. You could even consider entering the national negotiation competition open to law students and organised by the Centre for Effective Dispute Resolution (CEDR).\n4 \n4 T his centre also trains practitioners in the areas of mediation and negotiation and it hosts an excellent \nwebsite: https://www.cedr.com/. \n\n--- Page 431 ---\n 400 NEGOTIATION  \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  Along with mediation, negotiation is a major form of alternative dispute resolution. \n  Legal advisors, or other qualifed negotiators, negotiate on behalf of their clients in \naccordance with their client’s instructions, to reach a settlement of a legal dispute without the use of litigation strategies. \n  At the academic stage of legal education an assessed or formative negotiation is conducted as a role play between two teams, who act as legal advisors for the respective clients in a fctitious legal dispute. \n  Negotiation exercises test a number of skills sets from research, legal argument, independent study, management of documents through to oral skills, communica -\ntion skills and teamwork. \n  Engagement with the process of negotiation encourages a sophisticated under -\nstanding of the relationship between facts of a dispute, applicable law, and client expectations. \n  Negotiation exercises are increasingly being used within the context of the academic stage of training because of their great value in allowing students to work within such broad skill sets. \n  Negotiation involves identifcation of issues (in common/which differ), needs and interests and options for agreement. \n  There are two main forms of negotiation: positional and principled. \n  Positional negotiation refers to a situation where both parties often wish for a settle -\nment on purely fnancial grounds and probably do not wish to continue any relation -\nship with each other. \n  Principled negotiation refers to a situation where both parties not only wish a settle -\nment of the current dispute but they often wish, or need, to continue their relationship. \n  Negotiation is a process requiring careful pre-negotiation planning, in-negotiation strategies and post-negotiation review. \n\n--- Page 432 ---\n15
