\n  Further consolidate some of the skills you have already acquired and apply them to \na different context. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-19  \n\n--- Page 433 ---\n 402 MEDIATION  \nINTRODUCTION \nContinuing the theme of communication skills acquisition, the study of mediation is argu -\nably an important way of introducing students to a dispute resolution process that has \nbecome more popular in the UK. Mediation is a process that will enable you to appreciate the importance of communication and in some cases perhaps give you an opportunity to acquire core mediator skills to enable you to engage in peer mediation or even go on to further your practical skills competency through training with, for example, a community mediation service. In order to embed your skills there are also national and international student mediation competitions which are available for you to participate in. \nTaking a broad approach to the teaching of dispute resolution provides a more accu -\nrate representation of the approaches taken in many common law jurisdictions. Through reading this chapter you will gain a sound understanding of the role of mediation within the dispute resolution continuum, develop an awareness of mediation principles and learn how to acquire some of the skills involved in both acting as a mediator and advising as a lawyer. \nFor parties who choose mediation as their dispute resolution process for the frst time, \nit is helpful for them to understand that negotiation forms the basis of the mediation process. In the previous chapter you were introduced to the concept of negotiation and will therefore have a sound platform upon which to build an understanding of mediation. The added dimension which affects the dynamic of a negotiation and transforms it into mediation is the introduction of a third party neutral called a mediator. \nAs well as bringing natural attributes to mediation, a good mediator will need to learn \ncertain skills in order to facilitate the mediation process effectively. There are differing views on how interventionist a mediator should be, and theorists tend to agree that there are two broad mediator style approaches: facilitative and evaluative. Whatever approach is favoured by the mediator, effective communication skills are required. \nWHAT IS MEDIATION? \nSimply put, mediation is facilitated negotiation. It is a voluntary process conducted con -\nfdentially whereby the parties to a dispute are empowered to resolve their differences in a structured yet informal environment with the assistance of an impartial facilitator: the mediator. \nThe foundational principles of mediation \nIt is important to remember that mediation is a wholly voluntary process; the parties must want to try mediation as an appropriate means to resolving their dispute rather than com -\nmencing or continuing litigation. \n\n--- Page 434 ---\n  \n  MEDIATION 403 \nNego˙a˙on----Media˙on-----Arbitra˙on------Li˙ga˙on \nCONSENSUAL ADJUDICATIV E \nFigure 15.1 The dispute resolution continuum \nThe mediation process is also confdential. The parties sign an agreement at the com -\nmencement of the mediation to be bound by confdentiality. Essentially, this means that \nthe parties agree not to repeat anything discussed during the course of the mediation. Similarly, the process is accepted by the parties as being without prejudice, implying that if the dispute does not settle following the mediation and litigation commences or resumes, neither party can use any confdential information disclosed during the course of the mediation in subsequent court proceedings. \nThe mediation process is facilitated by an impartial third party mediator, which brings \na completely different dynamic to the negotiations which may have been conducted hith -\nerto and which are more often than not bilateral. The mediator’s task is not to take sides or pass judgment. In one sense mediation can be described as facilitated negotiation; the mediator assists the parties in fnding a mutually acceptable solution to the dispute, which may well have reached a position of stalemate. \nThe parties have full control over the process and the outcome; they can bring the \nmediation to a close at any time, and with the assistance of the mediator can explore a whole range of settlement options that are unavailable to a judge. All decision-making rests with the parties and as such the process is both fexible and empowering. \nDispute resolution strategies can be viewed as being on a continuum ranging from \n‘consensual’ (the most fexible forms of dispute resolution giving most power to the par -\nties) to the adjudicative (the least fexible forms of dispute resolution with the least power in the hands of the parties). This continuum is set out in Figure 15 .1. \nThe further one moves towards the right hand side of the dispute resolution continuum \nthe parties begin to lose control of their dispute. As a process, negotiation offers the most fexibility in terms of timing, forum and decision-making, whereas litigation offers the least fexible process for decision-making; it is formalised, governed by rules and the decision-making lies with a judge and is therefore out of the control of the parties. Mediation offers a similar level of process fexibility as negotiation; whilst facilitated by a third party, the parties have full control over the decision-making and it hence has a strongly consensual element associated with it. \nTHE MEDIATION PROCESS \nThe mediation process structure can vary depending on the type or subject matter of the dispute. Whether it be a commercial, community, workplace or family dispute the under -\nlying mediation principles are generally the same and whatever the mediation forum, the mediator will use the same set of core skills. For the purposes of this book the civil and commercial mediation procedure is used. \n\n--- Page 435 ---\n \n \n \n       \n \n     404 MEDIATION  \nPHASE 1 PHASE 2 Opening Explora\u0012on \nThe four \nphases of the \nmedia\u0012on \nprocess PHASE 3Prepara\u0014on \nBargaining \nPHASE 4 Se˛lement Concluding \nFigure 15.2 Common civil/commercial mediation phases \nThe mediator will be chosen during the preparatory stage of the process. The type \nof mediator and their style can be important to the parties and their lawyers. Two broad \nmediator styles have been identifed: evaluative and facilitative.1 The evaluative media -\ntor will be inclined to adopt a far more searching and probing style, often bringing their knowledge of the dispute area to the mediation; these mediators may be former judges, practising lawyers or come from a professional background with expertise relevant to the subject matter of the dispute. The facilitative mediator will be rather more inclined to let the parties work things out for themselves and assist, coach or guide them rather than evaluate the parties’ theories, strengths or weaknesses. \nAlthough the mediator will have overall control of the process structure, fexibility is \na key factor and it is this principle of fexibility that very much sets mediation apart from many other dispute resolution processes. For the purpose of this chapter the model’s application to civil/commercial disputes will be examined. \nThe phases of mediation \nOnce the necessary preparation for the mediation has been undertaken, which includes choice of mediator, the mediation process usually follows the same model progressing through four phases in sequence: from opening, exploration, bargaining through to the concluding phase. This is far from prescriptive, however, but for the purpose of simplifca -\ntion the four-phase structure, demonstrated in Figure 15 .2, will be adopted and explained.\n2 \n1 L Riskin ‘Mediator Orientations, Strategies and Techniques’ (1997) 1 Harvard Negotiation Law Review 7. \n2 T he Centre for Effective Dispute Resolution (CEDR) works to the four phase model; see www.cedr.com/. \n\n--- Page 436 ---\n  MEDIATION 405 \nThe four phases of a typical mediation \nThe next pages will take you briefy through the phases in a typical civil and commercial \nmediation, as shown in Figure 15 .2. \nPhase 1: opening \nOnce the mediator choice has been made, and the parties are happy to proceed with mediation, it will be necessary for the mediator to contact the parties to clarify fnal arrangements such as position statements, an agreed bundle of paginated mediation documents, participant clarifcation, dietary requirements, directions to the venue, etc. Fees (if any) should be dealt with in the pre-mediation agreement, which will also cover important aspects of the mediation process, such as session length and confdentiality. All parties will have received a copy of the ‘agreement to mediate’ in advance. It is also important to ensure that those intending to be present at the mediation include a person from each side who has the authority to make decisions about possible settlement. \nOn the day of the mediation, environment is important and the mediator should have \nan awareness of simple things such as the layout of the building, location of toilet facilities and hospitality provision. Familiarity with all these things helps to set the tone and creates a more relaxed atmosphere. It is vital that the mediator develops empathy from the out -\nset, and your communication skills start here as a mediator. This includes attentive listen -\ning and allowing the parties to be heard without interruption. Those attending mediation for the frst time will often be nervous; they do not know what to expect, and it may be the frst time they have ever (or for some time) been face to face with their opponent. A safe and comfortable environment is therefore essential. \nEach person present will usually at this stage be asked to sign the ‘agreement to medi -\nate’. The mediator (and co-mediator) should then go through introductions and clarify the terms of address. Everyone should be thanked for making the effort to attend. The mediator should then describe what the parties might expect to experience during the course of the mediation and this includes an explanation of the principal aspects of the mediation process, that it is: \n  voluntary; \n  non-binding to the point of agreement; \n  without prejudice; \n  confdential; \n  empowering in the sense that the parties come up with the solution. \nThe mediator should then explain their role and make clear to the parties that they are \nthere to guide the discussion, to clarify the issues, not to judge (there are no rules of evidence), form a view or impose a decision. The mediator may point out to the parties that they may, on occasion, feel it necessary to act as ‘devil’s advocate’ and in so doing \n\n--- Page 437 ---\n \n  406 MEDIATION  \nmay be required to ask some diffcult questions. The mediator must remember to remain \nimpartial throughout. Any ground rules for the mediation can also be agreed upon with the parties at this stage. \nThe parties will then be invited to make a short opening statement. They should be \nreminded by the mediator that these oral statements should be uninterrupted. The parties may then present their understanding of the case. This will be a good opportunity to hear some of the facts and issues which each side believes are important. It can provide an effective summary of the respective parties’ positions and the parties should be encour -\naged to address each other rather than the mediator(s). \nIt should be understood, however, that what are displayed by way of the positions held \nby the parties at the opening session will often only really be the ‘tip of the iceberg’ as far as the real interests behind those positions are concerned. \nThe opening phase should give the parties an opportunity to: \n  learn about the mediation process and understand what is expected of them through engagement with it; \n  set out their positions; \n  listen to the other party’s position. \nPhase 2: exploration \nDuring what is described as the exploration phase of mediation, the mediator should have an opportunity to establish the interests behind the positions held by the respective par -\nties through a series of meetings.\n3 These meetings can be held either jointly or in private. \nIt is well advised to make use of private meetings, sometimes called caucuses, when there is a requirement to tackle sensitive or challenging issues, examine the strengths and weaknesses of a party’s case and establish the parties’ true interests and needs. \nJoint meetings allow all parties to see and hear the information exchange. They can \nalso save time. The mediator has control of the process so will decide what form the meeting should take. \nPrivate meetings with the mediator can generate forward momentum in a mediation. \nThe structure and components of such meetings can vary, however. Most commonly they will take place between the mediator and individually with a party. However, if the parties have lawyers present, there may be merit in meeting with the lawyers for both parties individually without their clients present. Caucuses can take place with the experts who may be present either alone or with the parties and their lawyers in attendance. \nThe extra confdentiality layer attributed to these caucus sessions ensures that the par -\nties can speak freely and openly to the mediator and parties will be generally more pre -\npared to share sensitive information in a confdential caucus setting than in a joint meeting. \nCarefully managed joint meetings can allow all parties to see and hear what is happen -\ning. In these meetings there is often the opportunity for useful information to be traded. \n3 R Fisher and W Ury, Getting to Yes (2nd edition, Penguin, London, 1992), 40, provides a useful expla -\nnation of the relationship between positions and interests illustrated by the library dispute. See also C \nMoore, The Mediation Process: Practical Strategies for Resolving Confict  (4th edition, Jossey-Bass, San \nFrancisco, CA, 2014), ch 12. \n\n--- Page 438 ---\n  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n MEDIATION 407 \nThere is, however, the potential for deadlock through positional behaviour and mediators \nshould think carefully about the timing and reason for calling joint meetings. There is also the danger that the mediator might lose control of the process through, for example, an unexpected event occurring triggered by the parties being in the same space. \nOverall the exploration phase of mediation should provide a really good opportunity for \nthe mediator to build trust with the parties. This trust-building process may then enable the parties to experience emotional release and can encourage them to express them -\nselves openly. If approached skilfully, this phase will yield clarifcation of the real issues, reveal parties’ needs rather than rights, expose hidden agendas and give the mediator the opportunity to ‘reality test’ some of the theories held by the parties. \nThis phase should enable development of potential strategies for settlement and facili -\ntate continued forward momentum towards the next phase of the mediation process. \nThroughout the exploration phase of the mediation, the mediator must remain impar -\ntial and is not seen as being an ally or perceived as being aligned with one party at the expense of another. \nDuring the exploration phase the mediator should be able to encourage the parties to: \n  gain the trust of the parties; \n  focus on interests not positions; \n  examine the issues in detail; \n  determine the strengths and weaknesses of each party’s arguments; \n  share information; \n  shift their positions. \nPhase 3: bargaining \nOnce the parties have shared suffcient information with each other and the mediator and they have accepted that the solution to their problem is not the other party’s prob -\nlem, they may be in a position to move towards the bargaining phase of mediation. In order for effective bargaining to take place the parties should have moved from their original positions. Arriving at this point in the mediation will usually be indicated by the parties’ readiness and willingness to start making and trading offers. At this stage in the mediation the parties will start to negotiate possible terms of settlement. At the heart of any bargaining or negotiation process is a desire to achieve some kind of gain. You will have learnt that we negotiate in order to obtain something we cannot get for ourselves. Allied to this, however, may also be a desire to preserve a relationship. As we have seen in the previous chapter on negotiation, interests are the fundamental drivers of any negotiation, and these are often distinct from the positions displayed by parties to mediation during the opening joint meeting. The interests underpinning them will have been explored and revealed in the exploration phase; it is then perhaps a measure of success in mediation as to how well a party’s interests are met through effective bargaining. \n\n--- Page 439 ---\n          \n \n \n \n 408 MEDIATION  \nThere are no hard and fast rules as to how to move the bargaining forward from the \nexploration phase. It is at this stage that mediation can truly be described as facilitated negotiation. The mediator should, through intuition and by observing the unfolding dynamics of the mediation, be able to assess the situation and then respond appropri -\nately to help the parties engage in effective bargaining. Fundamentally, however, the par -\nties must have gained suffcient information up to that point in the mediation to enable the process to move through the next phase. \nAs well as helping the parties to select the alternative that seems best, the mediator’s \nrole during the bargaining phase may also involve providing encouragement on how bar -\ngaining might best be progressed. A good mediator can do this by: \n  being creative; \n  signifcantly infuencing the negotiations; \n  acting as a facilitator; \n  taking offers and counter offers between the parties’ rooms. \nThroughout this phase the mediator should be carefully observing the effectiveness of the \ninter-party negotiations and at the same time be reminded of the importance of mediator impartiality. In turn the mediator should remind the parties that they must be responsible for owning the problem and the solution throughout. \nWith the mediator’s help, the bargaining phase should give the parties an opportunity to: \n  start trading offers; \n  create rather than claim value; \n  explore options for settlement; \n  choose the more favourable options; \n  think about tailoring an agreement to suit all parties’ needs. \nPhase 4: concluding \nWith any dispute which arrives at mediation the overall goal is to meet the parties’ inter -\nests. Perhaps therefore the measure of a satisfactory to good mediation outcome is how well these interests are met. A better outcome than one found elsewhere, i.e. than per -\nhaps the best alternative to a negotiated agreement (or BATNA)\n4 should include a creative \nsolution that captures as much available value for each party as possible. It should be a legitimate solution so that none of the parties feels that they have been taken advantage of. \nThere must be a frm implementable and sustainable commitment, and perhaps an agree -\nment that helps build the kind of relationship the parties want with each other in the future. \nAny mediation settlement agreement must: \n  be clear and not open to misinterpretation; \n  be reached to the satisfaction of the parties and in that sense it will be self-determinate; \n4 T he idea of the BATNA was introduced by R Fisher and Ury (n 3), 97. \n\n--- Page 440 ---\n  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n            MEDIATION 409 \n  as much as possible, deal with all aspects of the dispute; \n  be capable of being implemented and therefore must be workable and sustainable. \nIf these considerations are taken into account the mediation outcome should produce an agreement that avoids the need for further dispute. \nThe mediator’s role during the concluding phase of the mediation is to ensure that the \naspects mentioned above are brought about. Mediation is not concerned with achieving a settlement at all costs and the mediator should not be driven by the need for a successful outcome; remember this is the parties’ dispute. Whilst every effort should be made to reach an agreement that covers all aspects of the dispute, sometimes not all issues can be dealt with, and it may be that any outstanding issues can be the subject of ongoing negotiation. Research suggests that parties who take ownership of the problem and feel responsible for coming to their own resolution are more likely to honour the commitments they make. \nThroughout the mediation and particularly during the concluding phase, the media -\ntor should remain positive and encourage settlement opportunities wherever possible. This will inevitably involve the mediator liaising with the parties and helping them to draft the terms of the settlement agreement once they have reached terms. If the parties are represented, then their lawyers can usually take responsibility for drafting the settlement agreement, which can then be checked by the mediator once written up. \nOf importance for the mediator is to ensure that there are no unforeseen obstacles \nregarding implementation of the settlement agreement; for instance, are there deadlines, should there be a timetable and what happens in the event of default? When encouraging the parties towards settlement the mediator should be able to make use of some well-chosen active intervention techniques, which will include the use of careful questioning about realistic options, on occasion playing ‘devil’s advocate’ and providing helpful infor -\nmation so as to facilitate forward momentum. \nAs already mentioned, mediators should be in control of the process and it is this \n‘process-control’ that can be a useful source of power when encouraging parties to move towards settlement. If properly in control of the mediation, the mediator can affect the perceptions, attitudes and behaviour of others present at the mediation. \nThe source of this mediator power may include associational status; some parties \nmay be drawn to a mediator who is a lawyer or a former judge, for instance. Mediators who have particular expertise in the feld or area of the subject matter of the dispute may gain the trust and confdence of the parties and command respect. Intuitive or personal attributes should not be underestimated, and included in these natural skills is an ability to transmit messages in the right way or to use moral pressure without of course using duress or undue infuence. \nWhen a settlement has been reached the agreement should usually be evidenced in \nwriting and signed by the parties. It should include: \n  clarity of language, specifcity, heads of agreement; \n  reference to confdentiality; \n\n--- Page 441 ---\n \n \n \n 410 MEDIATION  \n  confrmation of the future dispute resolution process to be used in the event of the \nagreement breaking down; \n  overall the agreement should be workable and one that the parties can live with. \nGuidance on how to draft a standard mediation settlement agreement is provided in Chapter 16. \nMEDIATION SKILLS \nAn understanding of the mediation process and its place within the dispute resolution pano -\nrama is necessary before the skills a mediator requires can be acquired. Parties who decide to choose mediation as a process to attempt to fnd a resolution to their dispute may do so because they might have failed in their attempts to reach an agreement through negotiation. \nFailed negotiations sometimes occur because communication has broken down; this \nmay perhaps be due to the fact that the parties have become too entrenched or posi -\ntional. Among other things, barriers to effective negotiation can be explained as being psychological, cognitive or even cultural. \nBecause much of mediation is about effective communication, without active par -\nticipation in a process of communication, parties in dispute who choose to engage in mediation must be prepared to disclose information to the mediator and exchange infor -\nmation with their opponent. Without this facilitated communication information exchange, progress will not be made towards the possibility of a consensual voluntary agreement. \nThe skills you bring to mediation \nMany of the skills that a mediator requires are centred around aspects of communication. We all have the ability to communicate; mediators have to be effective communicators and it is essential that they have a good command of language. Mediators should be prepared to encourage mediation participants to communicate in a positive way so as to develop forward momentum. The range of skills that a mediator is required to develop are set out in Figure 15 .3. \nWe will consider the skills of Positivity, Questioning and Listening located in the com -\nmunication skills set [B] in Figure 15 .3. In relation to the skills of questioning and listening \nwe will also consider their respective associated sub-skills of reality testing, brainstorm -\ning and reframing. They will be set out with their numbered headings enabling you to link them back to  Figure 15 .3. \nPositivity: [B] 2 \nMediators should whenever possible use positive language. They should encourage the parties to maintain a positive focus throughout the process, and their role in using such positive language can be compared to coaching. \n\n--- Page 442 ---\n   \n  \n  MEDIATION 411 The Range\nMediator Skills \n[A]\nOrganisa˜onal\n1.\nProcess\nManagement [B]\nCommunica˜on \n1.\nTone 2.\nPosi˜vity \n(a)\nNon-verbal\n(Body Language) (b)\nVerbal 3.\nQues˜oning \n(a)\nReality Tes˜ng (b)\nBrainstorming 4.\nListening\n(a)\nReframing [C]\nPersonal Skill s \n1.\nPa˜ence 2.\nEmpathy \nFigure 15.3 Mediator skills \n\n--- Page 443 ---\n412 MEDIATION  \nThis positivity includes having the parties focus on interests and the underlying needs \nor requirements rather than positions. If relationships are important to the parties, then \nthey should be reminded that mediation is a future-focused process and any mediation settlement agreement should take account of how the parties would like the future to look as far as their relationship with each other is concerned. During the bargaining phase, for instance, the positive focus can be employed by turning demands into options. \nNon-verbal gestures: [B] 2 (a) \nNon-verbal gestures can communicate information and when used can convey both pos -\nitive and negative intent. Mediators should beware of cultural implications, however, and should be wise to have some familiarity with the cultural norms of those attending media -\ntion. Mediators can manage the use of gestures by using verbal requests, by separating the parties and caucusing or through transmitting indirect signals. The use of silence can on occasion be helpful and through its judicious use the mediator can dictate the pace of the mediation discourse and give non-verbal signals. Silence can provide time for either the mediator or a party to think before speaking. It can also demonstrate interest and/or respect. \nQuestioning: [B] 3 \nEffective communication skills are required during the exploration phase and particularly during the caucus sessions. The choice of questions is important in order to maintain dialogue and draw out information during these sessions. Often the use of open-ended questioning will enable a party to share information with the mediator, for example: ‘what did you think of the other party’s opening statement?’ That kind of question will prompt an open response from the party and may provide the mediator with some useful informa -\ntion which can then lead to a deeper exploration of some of the issues. An open ques -\ntioning strategy can then be followed by closed questions when specifc information is required, for example, ‘so you feel hurt by X’s behaviour ’. \nUnlike a court room there are no strict rules of evidence associated with mediation. \nAs such, leading questions are permitted, for example: ‘ so after going to the supermarket \nand buying the goods, you then took the tin of beans without paying for them didn’t you? ’ \nAt the end of a caucus session it might be sensible, or indeed necessary, for the medi -\nator to provide the party with a task. This might be as simple as asking the party to look at the claim more carefully and provide more accurate fgures. It might even involve request -\ning a party to think more carefully about what areas of the claim, after more detailed scrutiny, might be dropped or discontinued. It could even involve a request for a party to make a telephone call to obtain information from a third party. \nIt is also helpful at the conclusion of a caucus session with a party for the mediator to \nsummarise the main points revealed. This also helps to build trust and confdence in the mediator. \n\n--- Page 444 ---\n  MEDIATION 413 \nReality testing: [B] 3 (a) \nOne useful skill which mediators can use to positive effect is the idea of reality testing. \nMany parties who arrive at mediation have often not really examined the strengths of their case. This may be due to the lack of information or because they have not taken an objec -\ntive view of the dispute. In testing the theories held by parties in relation to the strengths of their case, the mediator can use certain techniques to encourage this, such as playing ‘devil’s advocate’. \nOne of the most diffcult things to achieve for a mediator is to encourage parties to try \nto see the dispute from their opponent’s perspective. If that can be achieved, then this can sometimes help to move the parties from entrenched positions. This does take skill and a certain amount of ‘persuasion’ on the part of the mediator. In no way must these kind of techniques be used to place pressure on a party or even hold them to ransom; such approaches would be in breach of the mediator’s ethical code. \nBrainstorming/option seeking: [B] 3 (b) \nDuring the bargaining stage a number of different tactics can be used by the mediator to encourage the parties to search for settlement options. These may be utilised either in caucus or in joint session. With a view to making settlement easier to reach, brainstorm -\ning is a technique that can be of great assistance. The idea of brainstorming is to encour -\nage the parties to look at the problem from different angles and reinforce those common interests already identifed during exploration. \nThe parties will be required to think of alternative settlement options of differing \nstrengths and appeal; the mediator may ask them for their preferences, perhaps invent a list of options to take if no agreement can be reached and then improve some of the more promising ideas and thus convert them into practical alternatives. \nListening skills: [B] 4 \nAs a mediator it is essential to have good listening skills. Through attentive listening, a mediator will be able to: \n  decode a verbal message; \n  identify the emotion being expressed; \n  be selective about words or phrases heard; \n  be prepared to restate the ‘feeling’ content of the message accurately for affrmation, \nconfrmation and clarifcation. \nMediators should also be prepared to use active or refective listening techniques, such as nodding or smiling, when a party requires affrmation and throughout the exchange the mediator should maintain good eye contact with the party to whom they are listening. \n\n--- Page 445 ---\n \n   \n \n 414 MEDIATION  \nNon-verbal gestures can communicate information. They can be both positive and \nnegative. Mediators can manage the use of gestures by verbal requests, separation (cau -\ncuses) and indirect signals transmitted by the mediator. Beware of cultural implications, \nhowever, and in this regard mediators should be sensitive to cultural norms. \nGood listening skills are essential as a mediator must be sure that they have heard \nexactly what the party who is talking has said. They must then be prepared to accurately verify what they have heard; in so doing the mediator must be able to additionally display personal skills of empathy and be able to demonstrate acceptance and acknowledge -\nment of any emotions displayed by the speaker. This will then in turn allow the competent mediator to explore the reason for those emotions and uncover the underlying issues. Showing empathy can enable the parties to release tension through expression of emo -\ntion; it also gives the mediator an opportunity to manage the process through recognition of emotions by making appropriate responses. \nReframing: [B] 4 (a) \nMediators also use other techniques borrowed from therapeutic approaches, such as active or productive reframing.\n5 Reframing can be used to change the verbal presentation \nof an idea, concern, proposal or question;6 for example, if a party says that ‘Ever since my \nboss caused this problem I have been unable to concentrate at work’ the mediator could actively refect the content of that narrative by saying; ‘so the problem you mention has really been affecting your work performance’. \nNot only does this show to the party who has disclosed this information that they \nhave been listened to by the mediator, but it can neutralise the language used by the party. In other words ‘drawing the sting’, so as to make the meaning of words appear less harsh or confrontational. The mediator intervening in such a way to modify language can help change a party’s perceptions and behaviour and positive reframing techniques can sometimes achieve this. \nLanguage variation or modifcation can: \n  present claims in a different way; \n  sometimes create a more a positive spin; \n  de-personalise it. \nConsider this phrase: ‘I’m not going to agree to anything that deprives me of seeing my kids!’ The mediator could reframe this statement by saying, ‘so maintaining regular con -\ntact with your children is something that is important to you’. \nIt is undoubtedly much easier to reframe positions, interests and issues than it is to \nreframe values, moral codes or beliefs all of which can defne a person.\n7 However, dur -\n5 S ee H Brown and A Marriott ADR Principles and Practice (4th edition, Thomson/Sweet & Maxwell, London, \n2018), 139 and Boulle & Nesic Mediator Skills and Techniques: Triangle of Infuence (Bloomsbury, London, \n2010), 151, who liken reframing to active listening. See also C Moore, (n 3), 237. \n6 B Mayer The Dynamics of Confict Resolution  (Jossey-Bass, London, 2000), 134. Most of the examples \ngiven in this chapter are what Mayer describes as detoxifcation reframing, which helps people get past \ntheir emotional response to the way someone’s thoughts have been presented. \n7 C Moore (n 3), 239–43. \n\n--- Page 446 ---\n  \n  \n  MEDIATION 415 \ning mediation the use of neutral words is often more appropriate than using those with \nconnotations of confict. \nTo test your developing understanding of the idea of reframing read Activity 15.1 and \nanswer the questions that are posed by it in sections (a) and (b). Answers can be found at the end of the chapter. \nActivity 15.1: reframing exercise \n(a) Harsh ‘confict’ words and phrases can be softened in order to remove the \n‘sting’ which they might convey. This is called reframing. Reframe these words and phrases so as to soften their meaning: \n Dispute/Confict \n Claims/Demands: \n Opponent/Defendant: \n Concede and compromise \n It’s a matter of principal/It is fundamental to the claim \n You’re a liar/I don’t believe you \n(b) Harsh statements – reframe these sentences so as to soften their meaning: \n‘The builder’s a cowboy; he completely bodged the job’. ‘The work done on my car has cost me a lot of money and it’s useless to drive’. ‘She’s never going to see the kids again if she doesn’t stop screwing money out of me’. ‘The guy’s an idiot, he’s ignoring me and that’s just plain rude; he just won’t return \nmy calls and refuses to speak to me to discuss the problem’. \n‘If he doesn’t repair the car in one week I’m suing him’. \nCONCLUSION \nMediation is a process-orientated method of alternative dispute resolution within the wider dispute resolution continuum. Although it is a fexible dispute resolution process, it relies on certain core principles and, in the context of a civil/commercial type dispute, the mediator facilitating the mediation through a series of defned phases. \nAs with other areas of dispute resolution, mediation requires the application of spe -\ncifc skills. Some may already be possessed by the mediator and others can be acquired through learning. \nThroughout the mediation process mediators should always: \n  endeavour to be empathetic and patient; \n  uphold the important ethical mediation principles such as impartiality (which includes being non-biased and non-aligned); \n\n--- Page 447 ---\n416 MEDIATION  \n  remember to respect confdentiality. \nAn awareness of parties’ emotions and their culture is important and mediators should \nwherever possible resist making assumptions or holding prejudices. Overall, a good understanding of the mediation process structure is required in order to maintain effec -\ntive process management. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  Mediation is a voluntary process conducted confdentially, which empowers the par -\nties in dispute to resolve their differences with the assistance of an impartial facilita -\ntor: the mediator. \n  The various dispute resolution strategies of negotiation, mediation, arbitration and litigation can be viewed as being on a continuum ranging from ‘consensual’ (the most fexible forms of dispute resolution giving most power to the parties) to the ‘adjudica -\ntive’ (the least fexible forms of dispute resolution with least power in the hands of the parties). \n  Mediation offers a high level of fexibility in that although it is facilitated by a third party, the parties retain full control over the decision-making process leading to set -\ntlement. Therefore it has a strongly consensual element associated with it. \n  The mediation process structure varies according to the type and subject of the dis -\npute, but its underlying principles remain more or less the same. \n  The choice of mediator is important as the mediator and their preferred style deter -\nmine the contours of the mediation. \n  Two broad mediator styles have been identifed: evaluative and facilitative. \n  The evaluative mediator (who is often an expert in the area or has legal expertise) adopts a more searching and probing style. \n  The facilitative mediator tends to allow the parties to work things out for themselves and will assist, coach or guide them when required. \n  It is possible to identify a basic four-phase structure to most civil/commercial media -\ntion involving opening, exploration, bargaining and conclusion. \n  Mediators are required to develop an extensive range of skills circulating around organisational skills, communication skills and personal skills. \n  Communication skills are key and include the ability to remain positive, engage in effective listening and reframing, and develop good questioning skills. Mediators need to be able to draw out the parties into active engagement with the dispute resolution process. \n\n--- Page 448 ---\n  \n  \n  MEDIATION 417 \nActivity 15.1: suggested answers \n(a) Harsh ‘confict’ words and phrases can be softened in order to remove the ‘sting’ \nwhich they might convey. This is called reframing. The suggested reframed \nwords and phrases are in italics:  Dispute/confict – disagreement or difference in opinion \n Claims/demands – needs and requirements \n Opponent/defendant – the person with whom I have a disagreement \n Concede – compromise \nIt’s a matter of principle/it is fundamental to the claim \nThis is important to me \nYou’re a liar/I don’t believe you I fnd it diffcult believing that this is correct. \n(b) Harsh statements – The suggested reframed sentences are in italics: \n‘The builder’s a cowboy; he completely bodged the job’. \nI’m unhappy with the standard of workmanship. There are areas of the \nbuilder’s work that were substandard. \n‘The work done on my car has cost me a lot of money and it’s useless to drive’. I \nwould like to be compensated for the amount of money I have spent on this car or at least have the repairs done at no charge. \n‘She’s never going to see the kids again if she doesn’t stop screwing money \nout of me’. \nWe need to discuss the child contact arrangements and the level of maintenance \npayments. \n‘The guy’s an idiot, he’s ignoring me and that’s just plain rude; he just won’t \nreturn my calls and refuses to discuss the problem’. \nI’m having diffculty speaking to him; can we try to talk this through so as \nto work out a solution? \n‘If he doesn’t repair the car in one week I’m suing him’. \nI think we need to discuss this before the matter escalates. \nNotice that many of the reframing suggestions include elements of communication or interaction. Finding the time or courage to talk about a problem that is dete-riorating can start a dialogue process which may ultimately lead to an agreement. The alternative is to ignore the situation and let the problem deteriorate further with worsening consequences. \n\n--- Page 450 ---\n16 \n  \n DRAFTING \nLEARNING OUTCOMES \nAfter reading this chapter you should be able to: \n  Appreciate the importance of assimilating facts and applying them in a structured \nway. \n  Understand the importance of language and grammar. \n  Gain an ability to write clearly, concisely and accurately. \n  Further consolidate some of the skills you have already acquired and apply them to a different context. \n  Successfully complete a basic drafting exercise. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-20  \n\n--- Page 451 ---\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n 420 DRAFTING  \nINTRODUCTION \nAs a student of law, you will fnd drafting a useful asset whether or not you intend to enter \nthe legal profession. As a lawyer, whether you practice in the area of non-contentious law such as conveyancing (property) or contentious work involving litigation, the need to be able to construct an accurate written document or write a good letter will always arise. Often these transferable skills are acquired as you develop in your place of work. However, the ability to be able to draft effectively will more often than not be required and put into practice much earlier. The requirement to draft a curriculum vitae accompanied by a covering letter for a job application, for instance, is something that students will encounter during compulsory years of schooling. All students will have drafted a per -\nsonal statement to accompany their application for university and will have recognised the importance of ‘getting it right’, often within a limited word count. \nWHAT IS DRAFTING? \nFor students of law, a drafting exercise will sometimes be used as a method of assess -\nment in order to display knowledge and understanding of a particular topic. You may, for instance, be required to draft a particular document so as to evidence the details of the agreement reached following a negotiation. It may alternatively be in the form of advice that provides a suggested answer to a legal problem. As we have seen with problem questions in the chapter on ‘Writing answers to legal problem questions’ (see Chapter 11 ), this kind of exercise is designed to test whether you understand a particu -\nlar area of law well and can apply it in a structured way. We have already seen in the chapter on ‘Mediation’ (see Chapter 15 ) that the agreements reached in civil and com -\nmercial type disputes by way of mediation are most commonly evidenced in writing in the form of a mediation settlement agreement. Such mediation settlement agreements will include clarity of language, specifcity and heads of agreement and which overall must be an agreement that can be implemented and is workable for the parties. An example of a mediation settlement agreement appears towards the end of this chapter (Figure 16 .4). \nRange of skills required for drafting \nAs a student of law, drafting requires you to integrate a range of skills that you may or may not already possess, including: \n  General writing skills. \n  An attention to detail. \n  Accuracy. \n\n--- Page 452 ---\n  \n  DRAFTING 421 \nFigure 16.1 Letter of Claim (workplace accident) \n\n--- Page 453 ---\n  422 DRAFTING  \nFigure 16.2 Screenshot of a precedent for Particulars of Claim (private nuisance) \n\n--- Page 454 ---\n  \n  DRAFTING 423 \nFigure 16.2 Continued \n\n--- Page 455 ---\n  424 DRAFTING  \nFigure 16.3 Screenshot of the frst page of a completed N1 Claim Form (personal injury claim)  \n\n--- Page 456 ---\n  \n  DRAFTING 425 \nFigure 16.4 Screenshot of a Mediation Settlement Agreement  \n\n--- Page 457 ---\n \n \n \n 426 DRAFTING  \n  Clarity of expression. \n  Managing and assimilating facts and their ordering them. \n  General reading skills. \nGENERAL RULES OF DRAFTING \nThere are some key points to bear in mind when drafting; you can call these rules if you like, which are applied during the planning process. Drafting is an exercise in communi -\ncation, and like all forms of communication the sender of the message and the receiver of it need to be talking the ‘same language’ to be understood. So it is important to avoid ambiguity, repetition or confusion. \nThose who draft legislation (Parliamentary Counsel), for instance, as well as decid -\ning whether the draft bill should be divided into parts and/or Schedules (the document’s structure), also make decisions about choice of language. These drafters try to ensure that as far as possible the language used in the statute is suitably clear and general; writing in plain English will make it both understandable and capable of being applied to new but connected situations, see the chapter on ‘Domestic legislation’ (Chapter 1 ). \nThe importance here is that the legislation once passed and in force can be interpreted without ambiguity or confusion by all who need to read and apply it. \nWho is your audience? \nBefore undertaking any drafting task, whether it be composing a letter or email, drafting a legal document such as a contract or a court form or document (called pleadings) during litigation, as part of the planning process you should think about your target audience and what you want to communicate to that audience. What is the intention of the drafting exer -\ncise and what is it that you want that audience or recipient to learn and understand from it? \nLanguage therefore is important and communication style will depend on the nature \nof the exercise and your target audience. For instance, writing in the capacity of a lawyer, letters or emails written to ‘lay clients’\n1 should be stylistically different from those writ -\nten to other lawyers, often referred to as ‘the other side’. Your client will not be a lawyer, they will not understand legal jargon (sometimes called ‘legalese’) and therefore clarity of terms and expressions which your client will understand are required for effective com -\nmunication. Essentially the use of ‘plain English’ is key here. \nLike much that is involved in the study of law or any academic discipline for that matter, \neffective preparation is crucial. It is therefore a good idea to make some notes on what it is you intend to achieve with the drafting exercise upon which you are embarking. There will be a need to assimilate facts and order them logically. The following are therefore important to bear in mind: \n  Precedents . Does the document you are proposing to draft have a helpful precedent \nor template which you can use to base it on? For example, if drafting a will, there are \n1 L ay clients are those for whose beneft or on behalf of whom the Barrister is instructed by the Professional \nClient (a Solicitor) to provide the Services (who may be the Professional Client where the Case concerns \nthe affairs of a Professional Client). \n\n--- Page 458 ---\n  \n \n \n  \n  \n  \n DRAFTING 427 \nusually a whole range of templates available depending on the complexity of the will \ndrafting exercise. This will give you the structure to work with. \n  The message . If using a precedent, how do you want to fll the spaces in order to \nconvey the message? For instance, with a Claim Form in a civil dispute, which is a standard form that can be downloaded from the internet, this needs to be completed with some specifc and perhaps more general information in the boxes provided. Sometimes these forms will have guidance notes to assist you in completing the form (see example in Figure 16 .3). \n  Accuracy . Ensure that what has been included in the document you are drafting \nconveys an accurate message. Any errors can cause problems later on. If you do not complete a court document with the addresses for service, for instance, then the court will not be able to serve the document and it will be returned unissued. If the matter in hand is ‘time sensitive’, this can be costly. \nRylance maintains that the frst rule of writing and drafting is to begin by thinking and then keep thinking about the needs of your readers. Try to acquire the habit of writing every letter and drafting every document as if your clients, or other intended readers, are watching over one shoulder. It would be prudent to become conscious of the court, or other tribunal, lurking over the other.\n2 \nGrammar \nThe key to all good writing and drafting is the confdent use of correct grammar and punc -\ntuation. Understanding grammar, punctuation and spelling conventions will help you to produce good writing and drafting. The section on ‘Use of language’ in Chapter 10, ‘Writing \nlaw essays’, will be helpful here and you can refer back to this chapter for additional guid -\nance on the correct use of grammar to assist you with your writing and drafting techniques. \nWhat is grammar? \nA simple defnition of grammar is: \nA set of rules about the use of a language that describes: \n(1) The standardised acceptable use of words. (2) The acceptable methods for sentence construction (word order in a sentence); \ntechnically this is the study of syntax. \n(3) The acceptable methods for word construction, dealing with the small parts of \nwords; technically this is the study of morphology. \nAll languages have grammar: sets of rules determining their appropriate use in the rel -\nevant community of language users. However, there is a general lack of precision about \n2 P . Rylance, Writing and Drafting in Legal Practice (Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2012), 4–5. \n\n--- Page 459 ---\n 428 DRAFTING  \nwhat the rules of English grammar might be. This is in part due to the fact that English is \nthe result of many different language traditions. English also has a massive vocabulary, with extensive synonyms (words that mean the same thing). \nThere is arguably nothing worse than reading a letter or document which is poorly \npresented and lacks grammatical accuracy. There is no excuse for poor spelling as nowa -\ndays all letters and documents are prepared in electronic format using computer soft -\nware, and auto-correct, as well as other available functions, will help to improve your spelling and grammar. \nHowever, as Rylance argues, whilst not suggesting that you abandon or ignore gram -\nmatical rules entirely, as he says that there is much disagreement about rules of English grammar, even where there is agreement, the rule is often subject to numerous excep -\ntions and the truth is that failure to observe rules, whether from ignorance or for conveni -\nence, does not usually affect the meaning.\n3 \nIt appears therefore that if this is to be accepted, minor grammatical errors should be \nforgiven so long as the meaning of the drafting exercise is communicated/conveyed to the reader. \nWhat follows is not a lesson in English grammar, because as university students you \nwill have acquired the basics of English grammar at school and the section on ‘Use of language’ in Chapter 10 will also be helpful to you. Detailed explanation of grammatical rules, subtleties and nuances in the context of legal drafting is also beyond the scope of this text as these requirements will be more applicable to practice, and the chances are that any drafting exercise you are required to complete as part of an assignment at this stage of your studies, will respect the level of your legal knowledge and understanding. You should, however, bear in mind some grammatical guidelines when embarking on your drafting exercise as part of your studies. \nParagraphs and sentences \nHow these are constructed will have a bearing on the overall structure and presentation of your drafting exercise. Paragraphs are a collection of separate sentences which may vary in length. Each paragraph should deal with a discreet and specifc topic. With legal documents, paragraphs are often numbered for clarity and ease of reference. As will be mentioned below, when considering the structure of your letter drafting exercise, head -\nings, subheadings, numbering and bullet points are permitted. A good piece of drafting logically addresses the subject matter in a sequential way, dealing with each specifc theme or topic before moving to the next. \nAbbreviations, jargon and slang \nSlang words such as kids  or mates  should be avoided at all costs. Such usage is a con -\ntextually sloppy use of English and inappropriate for legal writing. An element of formality or correct plain English is expected and acceptable. The use of jargon may be permitted, but it very much depends on the context and your target audience. For instance, using such Latin phrases as inter alia  (among other things) or res ipsa loquitur  (the thing speaks \n3 Ibid., 35. \n\n--- Page 460 ---\n  \n  \n \n \n \n     \n \n      \n  \n   \n \n \n DRAFTING 429 \nfor itself) would be inappropriate and out of place in a letter to a client (more than anything \nthey will not understand what you are talking about), however, contextually permissible in a letter to another solicitor. Abbreviations such as ADR are also acceptable as long as the frst time they are used in your piece of writing, they are defned as such and in this way: Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR), for example. \nEnglish dictionaries \nDictionaries are not just places to fnd out about spelling; they also give valuable detail on how to use a word, its derivation, how to pronounce it and what it means in differing con -\ntexts. For those students whose frst language is not English the Collins Cobuild English Dictionary  (which has separate editions at beginner, intermediate and advanced level) \ngives you a sophisticated understanding of word usage. For native English speakers, as well as their online dictionary,\n4 Collins also publishes the Collins English Paperback \nDictionary and Thesaurus  set.5 Another good dictionary provider is the Oxford English \nDictionary  series. You could consider the Oxford English Dictionary Paperback .6 Oxford \nalso has a good online presence which your library may subscribe to.7 \nA thesaurus \nThesauri give you synonyms: words meaning the same thing. If you feel that you are repeating a word too much, its capacity to give other words meaning the same thing is extremely useful. The most well-known thesaurus is Roget’s Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases\n8 and now Roget’s Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases 150th-Anniver -\nsary International Edition .9 Both of these can also be accessed online.10 Collins, however, \nhas got an alpha thesaurus, The Collins Gem English Thesaurus .11 Oxford also provides \nthe Oxford Paperback Thesaurus .12 \nLaw dictionaries \nLaw dictionaries are invaluable for locating the meaning of technical terms. They will defne the main terms, as well as concepts and processes of the English legal system. They will include summaries of major areas of law. Many are in print and online and the online versions offer extra links to other reference sites. Your university department may have preferred law dictionaries that they wish you to use, and your library may have online subscriptions to these. Recommended dictionaries include the Oxford Dictionary of Law .\n13 \n4 www.collinsdictionary.com . \n5 C ollins (2nd edition, 2015). \n6 7 th edition, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2013. \n7 A vailable at https://www.oed.com. \n8 Penguin, London, 2004. \n9 Penguin, London, 2019. 10 Available at https:// www.thesaurus.com. \n11 Collins, London, 2016. \n12 4th edition, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2012. \n13 J Law, (Editor) (9th edition, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2018). \n\n--- Page 461 ---\n \n \n \n   430 DRAFTING  \nThe HM Courts and Tribunal Service provides an alpha listing of the meanings for legal \nterms used in court. \nMany libraries will stock a range of law dictionaries. Two particularly good options are \nThe Longman Dictionary of Law14 and Osborn’s Concise Law Dictionary .15 \nLegal writing dos and don’ts: some rules of grammar: \n  Do not use overlong paragraphs and sentences; \n  Deal with one topic in one paragraph; \n  Do not use slang words; \n  Use spell check and other computer functions to ensure accuracy; \n  Make use of dictionaries and thesauri for guidance. \nLetter writing \nThe frst rule of effective letter writing is good preparation. Once you have chosen your \naudience (the proposed recipient of your letter) it is always wise to prepare some brief notes on the subject matter of the letter. These notes should include what it is you want to achieve with this method of communication, or in other words its objective. As a law student an assignment may require you to write a letter of advice to a client based on a certain legal scenario. Such a drafting exercise may be intended to simulate the kind of client advice letter that a legal practitioner may be required to write in order to obtain instructions from a client. In which case, you will need to carefully consider the needs and concerns of your client, what advice you should be giving, its scope and any supportive authority which may be applicable. With a letter to a client, it may be helpful at this stage to imagine yourself in your client’s shoes. This will help to write an audience-appropriate letter and one which your client will hopefully understand. \nTo achieve the letter’s objective a good client advice letter should aim to be concise, \nclear and unambiguous. Webb et al. suggest that particular letter-writing problems con-cern the failure to consider the needs of the reader, verbose sentences and the use of redundant and technical words and phrases. Poor structure and layout can make the letter diffcult to understand and its aims and objectives may therefore not be achieved.\n16 \nStyle \nLetter-writing style should be considered. If you know your client well, then a measure of informality in address may be permitted and it is quite acceptable to use frst name terms. In which case the letter should be signed off Yours sincerely . Similarly, the form \nYours sincerely  can be used if your client is less well known to you (perhaps a new cli -\nent) and you are addressing them by their surname. If writing to another frm of solicitors, however, then the salutation should be Dear Sir or Madam and signed off Yours faithfully . \n14 P H Richards and L B Curzon (Editors) (8th edition, Longman, London, 2011). \n15 M Woodley (Editor) (12th edition, Sweet and Maxwell, London, 2013). \n16 J Webb, C Maughan, M Maughan, M Keppel-Palmer and A Boon, Lawyers’ Skills (22nd edition, Oxford \nUniversity Press, Oxford, 2019), 46. \n\n--- Page 462 ---\n  \n \n \n \n DRAFTING 431 \nThe heading should be brief and concise, indicating the nature of the matter you are writ -\ning about, e.g. Re: Your Claim Against ABC Ltd. The addresses of both your frm (if not \nalready on the letter headed paper) and the addressee should appear at the top of the letter. \nStructure \nHeadings, subheadings, numbering and bullet points are permitted and will assist with structure. Certainly, in a long letter to a client, another solicitor, or a third party, the aims and objectives of the letter can sometimes be more easily followed and understood if such conventions are used. It may also enable your correspondent to respond to your let -\nter more accurately by making reference to specifc numbered paragraphs, for instance. \nAs mentioned above, paragraphs should not be overlong and should deal with a specifc \ntheme or topic. You should refrain from jumping about with topics for discussion in one single paragraph. Try to keep sentences short and concise and refrain from using unneces -\nsary words. By using short sentences, you will also avoid grammatical errors. Short para -\ngraphs favourably assist the presentation of your work and make it easier to read. \nContent \nThe opening of the letter should refer to the last communication. If it was a meeting, then write: Further to our meeting on … Depending on whether the letter is to advise, seek \ninstructions or to report, the content of your letter, whatever its purpose, should cover the main points in the logical structure that you have mapped out for your reader. As mentioned earlier, headings may assist here. The letter should conclude with a summary of the steps required (if any). Note the intention, the logical structure, the content of the letter and the steps required (within an appropriate time-frame if relevant), in Figure 16 .1 \nfor an idea of the content of a letter of claim to an alleged tortfeasor. \nAn exercise \nAs an ‘in-class’ exercise, it might be helpful from an experiential learning perspective \nto draft a brief letter of advice based on a particular legal issue and then swap it with your neighbour in class. \nThen undertake an exercise in peer review if you like. When you have read your \nneighbour’s letter, consider the points discussed above and answer these questions: \n  Fundamentally, does the letter achieve its objective? \n  If it is to give advice, then has it provided the kind of advice you need? That you structure and present your work logically. \n  Is it written clearly, concisely and unambiguously and with grammatical accuracy? \n\n--- Page 463 ---\n \n 432 DRAFTING  \n  Is it easy to follow? Here you can consider the letter’s structure (does the letter \nhave suitable paragraph breaks, for instance, and/or headings/sub-headings/ numbering, which is permitted?). \nThe example provided in Figure 16 .1 is a letter of claim to an employer of a client concern -\ning an accident at work. Within this letter, take note of the following formalities: namely the position of the address and date at the top of the letter, the salutation and the heading. Then note the way in which the letter is signed off; this is consistent with the salutation. When considering the body of the letter, note the way that it has been structured (it uses clear headings). It provides confrmation of its intention. The letter then goes on to sum -\nmarise the facts and consider the relevant law. \nThe general purpose of this letter is to confrm that as legal advisor you have received \ninstructions to act for your client in a civil claim for damages against the company you are writing to. It provides an outline of the issues concerning the matter, including the cir -\ncumstances of the accident, the reason fault is alleged (including details of both common law and statutory breach), brief details of the injury and loss sustained by your client and concludes with the required action which you ask should be taken, including a request for disclosure of documents and other information which may be relevant as well as a request that the company’s insurers be informed of the claim. \nStandard forms and precedents \nPrecedents \nOnce the drafting exercise has been planned and the skeleton of your proposed docu -\nment mapped out, you may wish to use a precedent or template to assist you in drafting your document. Most law frms have precedent banks linked to their word processing systems to avoid the need to draft documents from scratch each time they embark on a drafting exercise. \nStudents of law can turn to online sources where they will fnd helpful precedents and \ntemplates. Traditionally these were found in loose-leaf texts such as The Encyclopaedia of Forms & Precedents , now they are available online and the leading publishers such as \nWestlaw and LexisLibrary have developed their own platforms where precedents can be accessed. \nA word of warning, however: legal practitioners and law students should never slav -\nishly rely on precedents when drafting. They should be used as a guide and as a checklist which will often assist with the structure of the proposed document. As Emmet says, over-reliance on precedents has caused confusion among some students in the past; they have followed precedents to the letter in their drafting, thinking they must be drafting to a very high standard and are puzzled when criticised for it.\n17 \nFigure 16.2 shows you a standard precedent for a Particulars of Claim in an action \nfor private nuisance taken from the Westlaw database. The template will then need to be \n17 D. Emmett (Ed), Drafting  (19th edition, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2018), 4. \n\n--- Page 464 ---\n  \n  \n \n                                     \n               \n                   DRAFTING 433 \namended and the relevant specifc details included to ensure that the document fulfls \nits purpose. Simply copying the precedent without deleting unnecessary and irrelevant material or clauses appearing in the precedent will potentially alter the purpose and inten -\ntion of the document and is very poor practice. To do so is simply form flling not drafting and should be avoided. \nStandard forms \nNowadays, most law frms will have a good bank of standard forms and letters which will include frequently used boilerplate clauses for standard documents in specifc transac -\ntional work, for instance, clauses in commercial leases. \nStandard solicitor/client letters will include the client care letter, which is sector policy \nonce the frm has been instructed to act and which includes among other things the terms and conditions of the retainer or engagement. The SRA provides guidance on what should be included in client care letters and this information will be incorporated into the standard template letter.\n18 \nThese and other regularly used documents will be saved on the frm’s integrated word \nprocessing system. Some lawyers will also save documents from previous fles to use in the future for guidance and checking should a similar legal matter arise and when the same kind of document is required. \nThose legal practitioners operating in the area of civil litigation or dispute resolution, \nfor example, will frequently receive instructions from clients to commence court proceed -\nings. Commencement of civil proceedings will require the completion of an N1 Claim Form, which is a standard form available on the internet and which can be downloaded for completion with the relevant details.\n19 \nFigure 16 .3 shows the frst page of an example N1 Claim Form, which has been com -\npleted after taking instructions from a client pursuing a claim for damages due to having sustained personal injury. The Claim Form required is the one pursuant to Part 7 of the Civil Procedure Rules. It has been downloaded as a pdf from the www.gov.uk website \nand then completed electronically. On the same website page, you will fnd helpful guid -\nance notes for the Claimant, which will assist in completing the N1 Claim Form. \nDrafting other legal documents \nThere may be a need to draft a document for the frst time. In which case the guidelines and conventions set out above will assist you with the drafting exercise. The letter or document you are drafting may have a template or precedent upon which you can base it. But remember to consider the needs of your audience, the choice of words, structure and layout. \nWith all this in mind, the document should be easy to read. Presentation and the basic \nlayout, including use of font, print size, line indentation/spacing, the use of headings and \n18 See The SRA website for guidance on how to draft a good client care letter which is compliant with SRA’s \nexpectations: https://www.sra.org.uk/solicitors/guidance/ethics-guidance/client-care-letters/. \n19 The form can be downloaded from the gov.uk website and is available here: https://www.gov.uk/govern \nment/publications/form-n1cc-claim-form \n\n--- Page 465 ---\n \n 434 DRAFTING  \nnumbering are all important considerations and will assist structure and presentation. \nWhen the drafting task is completed, check the document through carefully for subject matter accuracy (e.g. dates and fgures), grammar, spellings and typos. Consider, for instance, the document which has been drafted at Figure 16 .4. It is a mediation settle -\nment agreement that records the outcome of a mediation concerning a dispute involving the sale and purchase of a car. This document is effectively an agreement that records and evidences the terms which have been reached by the parties to settle their dispute. The document therefore needs to be clear, concise and capable of being implemented. \nCONCLUSION \nEffective writing and drafting depends on your understanding of what exercise you have been asked to undertake. It will involve appropriate reading and research, your use of cor -\nrect grammar, punctuation and spelling, as well as the development of an effective writ -\ning/drafting style. As Rose suggests, it is now clearly appreciated that a need for a sound, basic understanding of the principles of drafting is vital to both branches of the (legal) pro -\nfession, in light of the reforms in civil procedure that have now taken place.\n20 Regardless \nof whether your aspirations include a legal career, this chapter should have provided you with some sound foundational guidance in the art of ‘good drafting’ techniques. \nCHAPTER SUMMARY \n  You should be able to make use of a range of skills required for academic drafting. \n  It is very important to establish who your audience is. \n  Writing and drafting with grammatical accuracy is important. \n  Take account of the conventions involved in effective letter writing. \n  Make use of standard forms and precedents, which can be used to assist your draft -\ning exercise. \n  Ensure that you structure and present your work logically. \n  Make sure you proofread your draft document carefully for errors of spelling, punc -\ntuation and grammar, as well as the fow of your work through paragraphs to ensure that you have followed your instructions. \n20 W Rose, Pleadings Without Tears  (9th edition, Oxford University Press, Oxford , 2017). \n\n--- Page 466 ---\n \n  \n CONCLUSIONS \nThis text has attempted to provide a clear view of the practicalities of studying law, focus -\ning on the required skills of general study, reading legal texts, argument construction, \nwriting and oral presentation. We have also discussed ways of developing good inde -\npendent study habits and approaches to ‘breaking into’ texts to understand the fexibility and the inherent unreliability of language in a discipline that centres on the power of ‘the word’ and of language generally. \nThis brief conclusion fnishes by signalling that only a partial understanding is reached \nif you do not consider the power inherent in any rule imbued with the authority of law. By this is meant the power inherent in law’s context and status, its privileged authority over other institutions, and the power of those who interpret it and create it. \nLaw is applied, used or created by people acting in roles dealing with the memories \nof the law. Much time has been spent looking at mechanistic schemes for understanding legal words, legal texts, intertextual and intratextual links and the arguments for the out -\ncome of the case. However, as Goodrich states, ‘reading is never innocent’.\n1 \nThere are vast dimensions of legal analysis untouched, ready to be tackled by pol -\niticians, philosophers, feminists, criminologists or sociologists. And there are a range of ever-present, yet buried, motivational issues, such as why did the judge adopt that interpretation? Or which rationale for adopting that interpretation do ‘I’ believe? Was that legislation motivated by economics or welfare? We have considered a few raw legal arguments and have noted the reasons given to support outcomes. But valuable issues can also be raised by asking why the judge did not choose to take another plausible interpretation. \nJudgments are the end result after parties and witnesses put their sides’ case, via \noffcial and tortuous questioning. They take place in situations where rules of evidence, magistrates and judges control what is and what is not said, by whom, and how it is said. Lawyers, judges and offcials control defnitions too, as well as choosing interim and ultimate interpretations. Legal texts are never unambiguous representations of the law. They are the words from which interpretations fow. At the level of the obvious, the voice \n1 P Goodrich Reading the Law: Critical Introduction to Legal Method and Techniques (Wiley-Blackwell, \nOxford, 1986), 231. \nDOI: 10.4324/9780429285080-102  \n\n--- Page 467 ---\n 436 CONCLUSIONS  \nof consensus states: ‘we all know what this means, don ’t we?’  Equally, this can be said in \na tone of incredulity, or of ridicule: ‘we all know  what this means, don’t we?’ \nIn their texts, judges build one offcial story, one offcial ending. But the story can often \nbe very different, and so could the ending. The bricks for building are words. Despite our \nfocus on study skills, English language skills, legal method skills and their interrelation -\nship with substantive law and solving legal problems, it is the landscape that decides it all. The landscape of the offcials, the institutions, politics, the judiciary, the police and policy all have an infuence. \nThe critical thinker has to remain engaged not only in micro-questions within texts, but \nalso in macro-questions at the level of law, politics and culture. This includes considering text as the product of a culture, continuing the search for underlying assumptions. \nMuch law degree study will revolve around ‘fghting’ with the language of, and argu -\nments in, cases – reconciling, distinguishing and/or following them and explaining differ -\nences of interpretation where some might say there are no differences. Students learn a growing body of rules and, more and more, the overarching context of institutions and culture shrinks into the background. They may be interesting from an academic perspec -\ntive, but cultural legal content has no place in the everyday life of the law and its media -\ntion of competing interests. It is in the interest of these legal institutional values that the legal ‘story’ is the one that covers all. But there is a danger that the daily process of doing the law blinds the ‘doers’ (the practitioners) to the motivational infuences of some insti -\ntutional creators of law. The law as language is to be read, interpreted, questioned and seen in its fragmented contexts, to be the object of a healthy scepticism. It should not be invested with qualities it cannot control. Law is not justice, for indeed justice may demand that there be no law. \nWhen deciding what words mean in court, judges make far-reaching decisions and \nmaintain that they do so, not on grounds of morality, religion, justice or ethics, but purely as a true interpretation of the words. They support the orthodox view that law is a neutral instrument to achieve a moral society. Law is objective, rational and logical, and one must believe in the ultimate good of the law and the ultimate ability of the law to determine what the law means. A problem can now be seen. As pointed out above, the law is not an autonomous neutral agent; it is used by people in a political and social role. Legal texts can be analysed as social texts created by social actors. Statutes are texts com -\nmunicated via words created by politicians in compromise and interpreted by judges for a range of reasons, some explicit, some not. Can discussions about law, therefore, ever be justifably separated from discussions about power (especially since access to law making power is only available to players in the higher levels of politics or professionals in the higher judiciary)? \nLaw is not logical, nor does it have to be. There is a social agreement that, for a range \nof reasons – political, social and moral – English law should be seen to be fair. But to apply a rule to a problem requires the clarifcation of the problem and proof that the facts of the problem as presented are the facts that occurred. Rules have developed that state \n\n--- Page 468 ---\n  CONCLUSIONS 437 \nwhat must be proved by testimonial or forensic evidence and when evidence itself must \nbe backed up. \nDue to the history of common law, its oral nature of proceedings, the breaking away of \ncourts from the royal household, the ultimate ascendancy of statutory law and the com -\nplete reorganisation of the courts of England and Wales in 1875 and 1978, we now have a system of law which is based upon the reaction to arguments presented to those offcials who decide which argument is legitimate, be they negotiators in offces, tribunals and juries, magistrates’ or appellate courts. We have also developed more sophisticated and imaginative ways of resolving disputes through Alternative Dispute Resolution processes. \nAs you fnish your frst-year journey about study skills, language use, fnding and han -\ndling legal rules, and after the study of the range of modules involved in getting your law degree, look forward to your next journey. Always try to keep the wider issues of law and its contexts and power in mind. As you develop through the stages of your academic legal study you will increasingly be called upon to ponder some of these issues and more; you will be required to spend more time tracing a critical pathway in your work. These are important tasks and may even become a life work for you. \n\n--- Page 470 ---\n   \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n FURTHER READING \nAND USEFUL WEBSITES \nFURTHER READING \nAnderson T., Schum D. and Twining W.
