Cohen\n26.1 Introduction\nTopic models are a set of statistical models and mathematical techniques used to analyze \ntextual data. Their purpose is to extract information about the underlying meaning and \nrelationships within a collection of related texts. These models estimate latent topics, which \nare clusters of words that represent common themes in the text data. Initially developed \nfor machine learning and information retrieval, some topic models have gained interest in \neducational measurement for scoring and analyzing constructed-  response items and mixed-  \nformat assessments.\nA large amount of research in computerized analysis of textual data in educational \nand psychological measurement has focused on creating accurate, reliable, and unbiased \nalgorithms for scoring essays. These algorithms aim to mimic human scores by considering \nthe variation in essay features and the scores assigned by human raters. Well-  known \nautomated essay scoring algorithms, such as the Intelligent Essay Assessor (IEA; Foltz et al., \n1999 ), utilize a variety of topics models that are covered in other chapters of this book, \nincluding Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA; Deerwester et al., 1990 ), the bigram topic model \n(Wallach, 2006 ), the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers topic model \n(BERT; Devlin et al., 2018 ), the General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE; Wang \net al., 2018 ), and other autoencoder topic models (e.g., Chen & Zaki, 2017 ; Vaswani et al., \n2017 ; Wu et al., 2019 ; Zhan et al., 2018 ).\nAlthough these algorithms have made significant advancements, current research \nsuggests that valuable information about students’ abilities may be overlooked, and that \nscores alone do not provide a complete picture. Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA; Blei \net al., 2003 ) is a topic model that has been increasingly used in educational and psycho -\nlogical measurement as a technique to better understand students’ writing and gain add -\nitional information about students’ knowledge beyond the scores provided. Recent research \nin educational measurement has shown that LDA can improve test development and edu -\ncational practices, detect effects from instructional interventions, and be used in the scoring \nof essays and assessments. \n   \n \n \n \n \n  \n  \n  \n  \n\n--- Page 2 ---\nJordan M. Wheeler, Shiyu Wang, and Allan S. Cohen\n536LDA has potential usefulness in test development and instructional practices. For example, \nShin, Guo, and Gierl (2019)  applied LDA to analyze written responses to test items. The \nLDA analysis identified common misconceptions that student possessed. The researchers \nused these results to develop distractors for multiple-  choice items. Wheeler et al. (2024)  \ndemonstrated an application of LDA that extracts and summarizes examinees’ reasoning \nwhen responding to constructed response items using essays. The findings indicated that \nLDA can serve as a valuable tool for offering validity evidence and informing instructional \napproaches for essays. The study demonstrated that LDA provided important insights into \nthe thought processes and reasoning of students.\nAdditionally, LDA has been used to detect the effects from instructional interventions. \nFor instance, Kim et al. (2017)  found that analyzing essays from a pre-  test and post-  test \nusing LDA revealed evidence that an instructional intervention helped students improve \ntheir use of academic language, despite no observable improvement in essay scores. That \nis, the LDA topic model detected instructional effects that were not captured by the change \nin essay scores from pre-  test to post-  test. Duong et al. (2019)  used LDA to analyze essay \nresponses on integrative borrowing, revealing the effectiveness of instructional conver -\nsation in enhancing students’ understanding of multiple perspectives. Choi et al. (2017)  \ndemonstrated how LDA can be used to detect a shift in the language students use when \nresponding to a prompt. In that study, LDA showed that students shifted from using \neveryday language to academic language following an instructional intervention. Kwak \net al. (2017a , 2017b ) demonstrated the ability of LDA to detect changes in topics used by \nstudents following an instruction intervention.\nRecent endeavors have also focused on integrating LDA with popular psychometric \nmodels. For example, Wheeler et al. (2022b)  introduced a new scoring approach for item-  \nresponse theory (IRT) models by using the results from LDA. The study adapted a process-  \ndata-  based scoring procedure to educational assessments that contained textual responses \n(i.e., constructed response items). The methodology used the results of the LDA model from \nthe textual data on the assessments to improve the latent ability estimates of examinees. \nResults showed that incorporating LDA into IRT scoring provided more reliable results \nthan traditional scoring procedures for IRT.\n26.1.1  Purpose of the Chapter\nThe use of topic models is an emerging field of research in educational and psychological \nmeasurement and aims to develop a more holistic approach to evaluating students’ writing \nthat goes beyond reproducing rubric-  based scores. Specifically, the use of LDA as a technique \nfor evaluating essays has shown promising results and the potential for being augmented \nwith other evaluation techniques and models (Wheeler et al., 2023). This chapter aims to \nprovide a comprehensive introduction of the LDA topic model and its role in educational \nand psychological measurement. The remainder of the chapter introduces the statistical \nformulation of LDA, outlines the essential data preprocessing and postprocessing steps \nrequired for estimating LDA, provides an example illustrating the estimation of LDA using \nempirical data collected from an essay on an educational assessment, and concludes with \nsome thoughts on the future prospects of utilizing LDA. Additionally, generalized R and \nPython code are provided in the appendix to provide the reader the opportunity to easily \nimplement the LDA model.  \n \n \n \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 3 ---\nLatent Dirichlet Allocation of Constructed Responses\n53726.2 Latent Dirichlet Allocation\nLDA is a statistical topic model initially developed to process large volumes of textual data \nin order to generate useful measures for downstream tasks, such as clustering, classification, \nindexing, and summarization. It operates as a joint probabilistic model that employs a hier -\narchical structure to identify latent topics within a collection of texts and the usage of these \nlatent topics within each text. The collection of texts constitutes the corpus, where each \ntext is a combination of weighted mixtures from a predetermined number of latent topics. \nLikewise, each latent topic is a weighted mixture over the vocabulary, which is the set of \nunique words that appear in the corpus ( Blei et al., 2010 ). This section introduces the LDA \nmodel from three perspectives: probabilistic model, generative model, and graphical model.\n26.2.1  LDA Model Parameters\nSuppose there is a corpus with kK=…1, ,  corpus-  wide topics and dD=…1, ,  documents. \nA document is denoted as wd and contains Nd words. The LDA model estimates three \nkey parameters from a corpus of documents: a set of word probabilities βk for each topic; \na set of topic proportions τd for each document; and a set of topic assignments td for \neach document, which represents the topic membership (i.e., assignment) of each word in \na document.\nA topic represents a set of probabilities over the words in the vocabulary, which consists \nof the V unique words found across all documents in the corpus. The word probabil -\nities in a topic indicate the likelihood of each word from the vocabulary appearing under \nthat specific topic. Each document is assigned a set of topic proportions, which is a vector \nrepresenting the proportions of each topic used in the document. Additionally, each word \nin a document is assigned a topic, indicating its membership within a particular topic.\nThe LDA model follows a hierarchical mixture model framework, where topics are \ncorpus-  wide parameters, topic proportions are document-  wide parameters, and topic \nassignments are word-  level parameters. The key idea is that topics are word probabilities \nfor the words in the vocabulary and topic proportions are mixtures of topics.\n26.2.2  LDA as a Graphical Model\nFigure 26.1  provides a graphical representation of LDA, illustrating three rectangular plates \nrepresenting the levels of documents, words, and topics within the data ( Blei et al., 2003 ). \nThe document level accounts for the replication of documents, the word level captures \nFigure 26.1   Graphical Plate Representation of Latent Dirichlet Allocation. \n \n \n   \n\n--- Page 4 ---\nJordan M. Wheeler, Shiyu Wang, and Allan S. Cohen\n538multiple words within each document, and the topic level signifies the estimation of mul -\ntiple topics.\nIn the graphical model, variables are represented by circles and their placement inside the \nplates signifies their respective levels. The word probability variable is located at the topic \nlevel, the topic proportion variable is located at the document level, and the topic and word \nvariables are situated at the word level. Shaded circles indicate observed variables, while \nunshaded circles represent latent variables. In the LDA model, only words are observed \nvariables, whereas the other variables are latent and are inferred from the observed data. \nThe document and topic priors are hyperparameter variables in the LDA that control the \nconcentration of word probabilities for topics and topic proportions for documents. The \ndirectional arrows depict the relationships between variables, with the variable at the \narrowhead depending on the variable at the tail.\n26.2.3  LDA as a Generative Model\nLDA functions under an assumed generative process that explains how the documents in \nthe corpus are created. The LDA generative model assumes that a corpus is generated \nthrough the following process ( Blei et al, 2003 ; Blei & Lafferty, 2009 ):\nA corpus consists of K topics (assumed a priori) where the word probabilities for \neach topic kK ,,=…1  is assumed to be generated from a Dirichlet distribution such \nthat βνkDirichlet~ (). Similar \nto the LDA model, the sLDA model estimates the topic distribution over the vocabulary \nand the topic proportions for each document. However, the key distinction is that the sLDA \nmodel incorporates the relationship between individual topic assignments and an observed \ndependent variable ( Perotte et al., 2011 ).\nFigure 26.2  presents a graphical model depicting sLDA. In Figure 26.2 , the plates \nrepresent the different levels of data, while the circles represent the model’s variables. The \nplacement of the circles within the plates indicates the level at which each variable occurs. \nThe arrows illustrate the relationships between the variables. Figure 26.2  includes a shaded \ncircle representing a dependent variable, indicating an observed variable at the document \nlevel, such as a classification, score, or ability estimate. Furthermore, an arrow signifies the \ndependency between the dependent variable and the topics.\nIn the sLDA model, the dependency between the dependent variables and the topics is \ncaptured by regressing the dependent variable on the topics ( McAuliffe & Blei, 2008 ), thus \nenhancing the predictive power of the topics with respect to the dependent variable. For  \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 6 ---\nJordan M. Wheeler, Shiyu Wang, and Allan S. Cohen\n540example, in the context of predicting movie ratings, McAuliffe and Blei (2008)  found that \nthe sLDA model outperformed the LDA model when followed by regression.\nThe sLDA graphical model depicted in Figure 26.2  can also be defined as the joint prob -\nability distribution presented in Equation (4), with an additional model for the dependent \nvariable. Although the dependent variable for the sLDA model can be continuous, it is often \ndiscrete since the dependent variable often represents a classification or discrete score from \na rubric. When the dependent variable is discrete, the sLDA model employs a generalized \nlinear model to capture its characteristics:\n yG LMdd d|, ,, , ttζδ ζδ ∼ () , (26.5)\nwhere y represents the dependent variables for each document, t represents the topics for \neach word in each document, and ζ and δ denote the priors for the dependent variable in \nthe generalized linear model.\n26.2.6  Understanding Word Probabilities of Topics and Topic Proportions\nThe two major results from the LDA and sLDA models are the word probabilities of topics \nand the topic proportions. The word probabilities of topics provide a description of the \ncorpus, highlighting the main themes within the documents. Figure 26.3  illustrates examples \nof word probability distributions of topics. The x- axis represents each word in the vocabu -\nlary and the y- axis represents their respective probabilities (i.e., weights). The plots are with \nthe words most likely to occur to the left (i.e., highest probabilities) and words least likely \nto occur to the right (i.e., lowest probabilities). These probabilities can also be interpreted \nas proportions or frequencies. For example, word W15  has the highest probability for \nTopic 1. By sorting words in each topic, it is possible to obtain a list of words most likely \nto occur in each topic (e.g., W15, W10,  and W124  for Topic 1). The words that are most \nlikely to occur for a given topic can help identify the topic and its use in the corpus.\nThe estimated topic proportions are used to describe individual documents within the \ncorpus. Figure 26.4  illustrates how proportions for the same three topics might be viewed for \neach document. The x- axis represents each topic and the y- axis represents their respective \nFigure 26.2   Graphical Representation of Supervised Latent Dirichlet Allocation. \n \n  \n\n--- Page 7 ---\nLatent Dirichlet Allocation of Constructed Responses\n541proportions. The topic proportions of a document sum to 1 and identify the proportion of \neach topic used in a document. For example, in Figure 26.4 , Document 1 consists of similar \nproportions for all three topics, Document 2 primarily consists of Topic 1, and Document \n3 primarily consists of Topic 2 and Topic 3. These topic proportions allow researchers to \ngain a better understanding of the essays and distinguish between them.\n26.3 Data Preprocessing, Estimation, and Postprocessing for LDA\nThis section provides an outline of the data cleaning and preprocessing, estimation, and \npostprocessing steps involved in LDA.\nFigure 26.3   An Example of the Topic Distribution over the Vocabulary.\nFigure 26.4   An Example of Topic Proportions for Documents. \n \n  \n\n--- Page 8 ---\nJordan M. Wheeler, Shiyu Wang, and Allan S. Cohen\n54226.3.1  Data Cleaning and Preprocessing\nBefore estimating an LDA model, the textual data goes through a set of data cleaning steps. \nThe objective of the data cleaning steps for LDA is to improve the quality and interpret -\nability of the model results ( Schofield et al., 2017 ). There are three major data cleaning \nsteps for LDA: tokenization, normalization (or lemmatization), and stopword removal.\nIt is important to note that LDA and its variants are considered “bag of words” models, \nmeaning that the order of the words is disregarded. While this may initially seem counter -\nintuitive, the objective of these models is to estimate topics and the semantic structure of the \ntext, which does not heavily rely on word order ( Blei, 2012 ). The bag of words assumption \nplays a crucial role in the data preprocessing steps of tokenization, normalization, and stop -\nword removal ( Boyd-  Graber et al., 2014 ).\n26.3.1.1  Tokenization\nIn the natural language processing and topic model literature, words are considered tokens. \nBefore tokenization, all punctuation is eliminated, and words are converted to lowercase to \nensure that the model doesn’t count the same word multiple times due to capitalization. For \nexample, the words “dunes” and “Dunes” should be considered as a single unique word \n(i.e., “dunes”). Tokenization involves splitting each document into its individual words, \nenabling the models to estimate the underlying topic structures ( Vijayarani & Janani, 2016 ).\n26.3.1.2  Normalization (Lemmatization)\nThe tokens undergo normalization through a process known as stemming or lemmatiza -\ntion. This involves retrieving the base form of a word by considering its different tenses \nor variations. For instance, the verbs “swim,” “swims,” “swimming,” and “swam” all \nconvey similar meanings and can be reduced to a single word, “swim.” The same applies \nto nouns, such as “teen,” “teens,” “teenager,” and “teenagers,” which can be transformed \ninto the word “teen.” Stemming aims to enhance topic clarity by utilizing a single repre -\nsentative word, facilitating the clustering of words with similar meanings and improving \nthe interpretability of topics ( Schofield et al., 2017 ). Stemming also includes correcting \nmisspelled words. Although stemming is context-  dependent, several R packages, such as \nhunspell  (Ooms, 2017 ), tm (Feinerer, 2013 ), and SnowballC  (Bouchet-  Valat, 2014 ), can be \nused to assist in this process.\n26.3.1.3  Stopword Removal\nStopwords are commonly used words that contribute little information about the topics \n(Wilbur & Sirotkin, 1992 ). Stopwords tend to occur frequently, and if not eliminated, they \ncan dominate the latent topics, reducing their interpretability ( Choi et al., 2017 ). Typical \nstopwords include words like “the,” “a,” “are,” and “they.” While there is no universal \napproach for selecting and removing stopwords, various techniques exist. Customized \nrules allow researchers to create stopwords lists tailored to their specific corpus analysis \n(Schofield et al., 2017 ). The term frequency–  inverse document frequency (TF-  IDF) index \nis another method to select stopwords, which utilizes term frequencies to determine if a \nword is overly used ( Robertson, 2004 ). Additionally, the general stopwords rule combines  \n \n \n  \n \n \n \n   \n \n  \n\n--- Page 9 ---\nLatent Dirichlet Allocation of Constructed Responses\n543statistical approaches with customization to define stopwords ( Schütze et al., 2008 ). \nPrevious research suggests that customized stopword lists are necessary when analyzing \nessays ( Choi et al., 2017 ).\n26.3.2  Estimation of Parameters\nEstimating the LDA topic model involves selecting hyperparameters for the prior \ndistributions and selecting the appropriate number of topics. This section provides details \nabout prior specifications, estimation algorithms, software options, and methods for model \nselection.\n26.3.2.1  Prior Specification\nThe LDA model incorporates two priors: the topic prior and the document (or topic pro -\nportion) prior. These priors capture beliefs about the concentration levels of words within \ntopics and topics within documents ( Blei & Lafferty, 2009 ). The topic prior reflects the \nbelief regarding word concentration within topics. A small topic prior suggests that words \nare predominantly associated with a single topic, indicating minimal overlap between \ntopics.\nConversely, a large topic prior implies that words are associated with multiple topics, \nindicating a more significant overlap between topics. Similarly, the document prior \nrepresents beliefs about the topic concentration within documents. A small document \nprior indicates that documents primarily consist of a single topic, with a high topic pro -\nportion for that specific topic. On the other hand, a large document prior suggests that \ndocuments encompass multiple topics, with topic proportions uniformly distributed \nacross all topics.\nWhen the hyperparameters for the topic and document priors are set to values less than \n1 (Topic Prior < 1; Document Prior < 1), it reflects a small prior. Consequently, topics pri -\nmarily consist of a few words, and document topic proportions predominantly involve a \nfew topics. Setting the hyperparameters to 1 (Topic Prior =   1; Document Prior =   1) corres -\nponds to a non-  informative prior. In this case, the data have a more significant influence on \ndetermining the topics and document topic proportions. When the hyperparameters for the \ntopic and document priors exceed 1 (Topic Prior > 1; Document Prior > 1), it indicates a \nlarge prior. As a result, topics include words evenly from the entire vocabulary, and docu -\nment topic proportions are uniformly spread across all topics.\nSelecting appropriate values for the prior hyperparameters is crucial, although there \ncurrently needs to be more consensus in the literature regarding selection criteria ( Kwak, \n2019 ). Furthermore, minimal theoretical research has been conducted to investigate the \noptimal method for choosing prior hyperparameter values ( Thomas et al., 2014 ). Wheeler \net al. (2022c)  demonstrated that smaller prior hyperparameters yield better model selection \nin various educational measurement scenarios. Blei et al. (2003)  and Griffiths and Steyvers \n(2004)  suggest using prior hyperparameters of 200 /V for the topic prior and 50 /K for \nthe document prior, where V is the number of words in the vocabulary and K is the \nnumber of topics. It is worth noting since there has been little research on prior specifica -\ntion, especially in educational and psychological settings, it is important to investigate how \nthe change in prior hyperparameters affects the results and interpretation of the model as it \nwill provide evidence for construct validity. \n  \n \n  \n  \n\n--- Page 10 ---\nJordan M. Wheeler, Shiyu Wang, and Allan S. Cohen\n54426.3.2.2  Estimation Algorithm and Software\nThere exist several Bayesian estimation techniques for estimating the parameters, but the \ntwo most utilized methods are variational inference using expectation-  maximization and \nGibbs sampling. Variational inference is an efficient estimation approach, although it can be \nchallenging to implement and may become trapped at local maxima ( Blei et al., 2003 ). On \nthe other hand, Gibbs sampling algorithms are intuitive and easy to implement; however, \nthey may be slow in estimation, and assessing convergence can be difficult. Griffiths and \nSteyvers (2004)  presented a collapsed Gibbs sampling algorithm for LDA that integrates \nout the topics and topic proportions from the posterior distribution, focusing solely on \nestimating the topic assignments of each word. The topics and topic proportions are then \nanalytically derived from the estimated topic assignments.\nIn a simulation study conducted by Mardones et al. (2022) , the performance of these \nthree estimation algorithms was investigated. The study specifically examined conditions \ncommonly encountered in educational measurement settings, such as a small number of \ndocuments, short document lengths, and a limited number of topics. The findings revealed \nthat, in most conditions, the Gibbs sampling algorithm exhibited greater accuracy in \nrecovering the LDA parameters compared to variational inference. This study suggests that \nGibbs sampling algorithms should be favored over variational inference for educational \nsettings ( Mardones et al., 2022 ).\nEstimating a topic model is currently done by selecting the best fitting of different can -\ndidate models. Most estimation packages currently are written in R ( 2013 ) or Python. \nThe topicmodels  package ( Hornik & Grün, 2011 ) and the lda package ( Chang, 2012 ) \nare packages used in R and the sklearn  package ( Pedregosa et al., 2011 ) and the genism  \npackage ( Rehurek & Sojka, 2011 ) are packages used in Python.\n26.3.2.3  Model Selection\nLDA and sLDA models are commonly employed in an exploratory manner, where various \ncandidate models with different numbers of topics are compared to determine the best \nfit and interpretability. Several methods can be used to evaluate the fit of these candi -\ndate models. Since LDA and sLDA models can be estimated using Bayesian inference, one \nindex commonly used for model comparison is the deviance information criterion (DIC; \nSpiegelhalter et al., 2002 ). The DIC consists of two components: the deviance term, which \nmeasures the log-  likelihood, and the penalty term, which accounts for the number of \nestimated parameters. Similar to other information criterion indices, the model with the \nsmallest DIC is considered the best fitting. If two models have similar DIC values, the one \nwith fewer topics is typically preferred.\nAnother approach to model selection involves considering results from downstream \ntasks, such as regression or measures of classification accuracy ( Blei et al., 2003 ). The \nnumber of topics that leads to a more parsimonious model is usually selected as the best \nfitting model. In educational research, the number of topics tends to be small, especially for \nextended-  response items, due to the essay lengths and the influence of the prompts on the \nwords and topics used in the responses ( Choi et al., 2017 ; Xiong et al., 2021).\nIn a comprehensive study, Mardones et al. (2023)  conducted a simulation that \ninvestigated the accuracy of several model selection methods for LDA. The results indicated \nthat the Jensen–  Shannon Divergence and the sample adjusted Bayesian information criterion  \n  \n \n  \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 11 ---\nLatent Dirichlet Allocation of Constructed Responses\n545(SABIC; Sclove, 1987 ) metrics outperformed other methods in selecting the appropriate \nnumber of topics across different educational measurement scenarios. It is worth noting \nthat in educational measurement settings, the selection of the number of topics should also \ntake into account the validity, interpretability, and fairness of the results ( Wheeler et al., \n2022a ).\n26.3.3  Postprocessing and Model Interpretation\nOnce the best-  fitting LDA topic model has been estimated and selected, the next step is to \nanalyze and interpret the results. There are various methods available for interpreting the \noutcomes of the LDA model, which include examining the topic structures and the topic \nproportions associated with each essay. The topic structures can be assessed and interpreted \nby examining the words that are clustered around each topic. This is typically accomplished \nby identifying the words with the highest probabilities of occurrence for each topic, such \nas the top 25 words with the largest estimated probabilities. Alongside examining the top \nwords for each topic, it is also beneficial to analyze a subset of essays that exhibit the \nhighest utilization of each topic. This additional analysis helps provide insights into how \nthe topics are being used and manifested within essays.\nThe topic proportions can be assessed and interpreted by looking at how the use of \ndifferent topics differs among essays (and thus students). The interpretation of topic \nproportions often involves using the interpretation of the topic structures and how the \ntopic proportions relate to other external variables, such as scores. For example, correlation \nanalyses can be conducted to see if there is a relationship between topic usage and score. \nAdditionally, clustering analyses are also common to see how closely related essays are, \nwhich can provide insight into the differences between essays.\n26.4 LDA Example\nIn this section, an example of applying LDA is provided using empirical essay data collected \nfrom an extended-  response item on an educational assessment.\n26.4.1  Essay Data\nThe essay data used in this example was taken from a ninth-  grade English Language Arts \n(ELA) formative assessment from a southeastern state. The formative assessment consisted \nof 20 selected response items and 2–  3 constructed response items, with one of them being \nan extended response item. For this example, the extended response item was used. The \nextended response item was categorized as an opinionated/  argumentative essay with the \nprompt presented in Figure 26.5 .\nThe extended-  response essay was evaluated by trained raters and assigned an integer \nscore ranging from 0 to 7, where 0 represents the lowest score and 7 indicates the highest \nscore achievable. A total of 3,815 essays were evaluated and a total of 3,707 essays \nwere used to fit an LDA topic model (108 essays out of the 3,815 essays were blank and \nthus removed from the LDA model). Across the 3,707 essays, the total word count was \n1,187,835, with 4,318 unique words observed. On average, each essay consisted of 320.43 \nwords and received an average score of 4.16. \n \n  \n  \n\n--- Page 12 ---\nJordan M. Wheeler, Shiyu Wang, and Allan S. Cohen\n54626.4.2  Data Cleaning\nThe initial set of 3,707 essays underwent various data cleaning and preprocessing steps \nas described earlier. These steps encompass tokenization, normalization, and removal of \nstopwords. Figure 26.6  displays the list of stopwords utilized in this particular example. \nFollowing the application of these data-  cleaning steps, the revised sample comprised 3,698 \nessays, with nine essays being excluded due to empty responses after the cleaning pro -\ncess. Across these 3,698 essays, the cumulative word count amounted to 689,666 words, \nencompassing 3,607 unique words. Furthermore, the average length of the essays in this \nupdated sample was 186.50 words.\n26.4.3  Model Estimation and Selection\nIn this particular example, a total of seven candidate models were estimated and compared. \nThese models encompassed a range from a two-  topic LDA model to an eight-  topic LDA \nmodel. During estimation, each model utilized prior hyperparameters ν=1 and η=1 . The \nestimation of the LDA models was performed using the collapsed Gibbs sampling algo -\nrithm implemented by the R package topicmodels . To assess and compare the models, the \nDIC was calculated for each of the seven candidate models. The results of the DIC com -\nparison are depicted in Figure 26.7 . Based on the results from Figure 26.7 , there seems to \nbe an initial break in DIC values at the five-  topic LDA model; therefore, the results in this \nexample will focus on the five-  topic LDA model.\n26.4.4  Interpreting LDA Results\nTable 26.1  presents the 25 words with the highest probabilities for each of the five topics. \nBy examining the words presented in Table 26.1 , along with an analysis of a subset of \nessays that predominantly utilized each topic, the following findings were inferred: Topic 1 \nis related to the negative effects of social networking on teens, specifically relating to fraud, \nsuch as identity theft and personal information theft. Topic 2 is also related to the nega -\ntive effects of social networking on teens, specifically relating to the social and emotional \nFigure 26.6   List of Stopwords Used for the Ninth-  Grade ELA Argumentative Extended-  Response \nEssays.\nFigure 26.5   Ninth-  Grade ELA Argumentative Prompt for Extended-  Response Essays. \n  \n \n  \n\n--- Page 13 ---\nLatent Dirichlet Allocation of Constructed Responses\n547impacts, such as bullying. Topic 3 is related to the positive effects of social networking on \nteens, specifically relating to interpersonal benefits, such as relationships and connecting \nto one another. Topic 4 is related to the positive effects of social networking on teens, spe -\ncifically relating to intrapersonal benefits, such as personal learning. Topic 5 is everyday \nlanguage.\nIt is important to note that looking at the top 25 words with the high probabilities for \neach topic is not always sufficient for interpreting the results from the LDA model. For \ninstance, when the vocabulary is large (i.e., there are many unique words in the corpus), \nthe probabilities can look quite small. To adjust for this, researchers can calculate the mag -\nnitude of word probabilities compared to a uniform distribution over the vocabulary. For \nexample, based on Table 26.1 , the word “information” is the top word in Topic 1 with a \nprobability of 0.061. Without context, this could appear to be quite small, however, since \nthere are 3,607 unique words in the vocabulary, the researcher can calculate how much \ngreater 0.061 is than a uniform distribution of the vocabulary (i.e., 1/  3607 =   0.0003). \nIn this case, the researcher would find that 0.061 is about 203 times greater than 0.0003 \n(0.061/  0.0003), which shows a relative magnitude of the word “information” in the con -\ntext of this data.\nIt is also important to note that it is beneficial to investigate subsets of essays that \npredominantly use each topic. For this example, the researchers could read a couple of \nessays that primarily use Topic 1, a couple of essays that primarily use Topic 2, and so \non. This sort of analysis helps the researchers better identify how each topic is being used \nin practice and lends itself to a clearer interpretation of the results obtained from the \nLDA model.\n26.4.5  Note on Generalized LDA Code\nIn order to provide readers with the opportunity to fit their own LDA model, generalized \nR and Python codes are provided in Appendix A and Appendix B, respectively. The R code \nutilizes the topicmodels  package and the Python code utilizes the gensim  library.\nFigure 26.7   DIC Values for the Seven Candidate LDA Topic Models. \n  \n\n--- Page 14 ---\nJordan M. LDA\nThe use of LDA and other topic models within the field of essay evaluation and educational \nmeasurement is still in its early stages, and there are several crucial issues that require fur -\nther investigation. One significant challenge is determining the optimal number of topics \nthat yield the most meaningful and interpretable results. As previously mentioned, this is \na non-  trivial problem, and while fit indices can provide some guidance, there is currently \nno definitive statistic or established process for selecting the appropriate number of topics. \nAlong with determining the number of topics, it is important to better understand the effect \nof prior specification on the results obtained from LDA. The issues related to the number \nof topics and prior specifications affect the results and interpretations of LDA, which in \nturn affect construct validity. There have been few studies that have investigated methods \nfor assessing construct validity and invariance with LDA in educational and psychological \ncontexts. Addressing these issues should provide more utility and generalizability for evalu -\nating essays using LDA.\nCertain studies have started to establish connections between topic model analysis and \ninstructional outcomes (e.g., Duong et al., 2019 ; Kim et al., 2017 ; Kwak et al., 2017a ; \nXiong et al., 2022). More research, however, is needed to establish stronger links between \nthe measurement of underlying constructs and the practical utilization of LDA results \nwithin educational settings. Additionally, investigating how changes in topic usage over \ntime can be reflective of instructional effects, as demonstrated by research conducted by \nSouthavilay et al. (2013) , would be valuable.\nFurthermore, it would be beneficial to explore approaches for designing targeted \nquestions that elicit specific topics, enabling a more confirmatory approach to topic mod -\neling. This research endeavor would contribute to the advancement of topic models as a \nvaluable tool in educational measurement.\nReferences\nBlei, D. M. (2012). Probabilistic topic models. INTRODUCTION\nLegal research has long been a shadow skill within the legal cur-\nriculum. Even as other skills began to take their prominence in law\nschools across the country in the wake of MacCrate and other reports\nthat advocated the importance of practical lawyering skills,' research is\noften treated as a topic less vital to students' professional success than\nmost others. This is due, at least in part, to false narratives that exist\nconcerning how interesting, hard, and important legal research is-or,\nmore critically, is not.\nThese false narratives exist due to any number of reasons, but\ntheir prevalence is detrimental to law students given the significant role\nlegal research instruction should play in their law school careers and\nwill play in their work as legal professionals. Unfortunately, these mis-\nconceptions surrounding legal research are expounded not only by\nword of mouth, but by the structure and assignments given in many\nfirst-year legal skills programs across the country, as well as the cog-\nnitive limits that students have. These false perceptions can have a\nnegative impact on students' attention to the material, which ultimately\nleads to a lack of retention of these skills. With small changes to the\nfirst-year skills curriculum, instructors can help students expand their\ncognitive capacities, strengthen student learning, and overcome these\nfalse narratives.\nPart II of this Article will explore three of the primary false nar-\nratives that affect students' perceptions of legal research instruction\nand explains why these false narratives are detrimental to students who\naccept them as true. Part III will look at how cognitive load, and the\ninstructional choices instructors make to help our students overcome\ntheir limited working memories, reinforces these false narratives. Part\nIII will also describe how professors can use scaffolding techniques to\nhelp overcome the challenges of students' limited cognitive capacity.\nPart IV will introduce a newly designed research log using the CREAC\n1. See generally Alyson M. Drake, The Needfor Experiential Legal Research\nEducation, 108 L. LIBR. J. 511, 512 (2016) (explaining that new attorneys entering\ninto the legal profession lack the practical skills necessary to act like practicing attor-\nneys).58 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 4 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nstructure commonly used in legal writing.2 Part IV will also demon-\nstrate how legal research professors can utilize the CREAC log as a\nscaffolding tool to help overcome these three false narratives and en-\nsure students gain the analytical research skills they need.\nI. FALSE NARRATIVES ABOUT LEGAL RESEARCH\nSome law students begin their legal education with false percep-\ntions about legal research. These may be due to several factors-word\nof mouth, the legal research class being pass/fail when all other courses\nare graded, having performed research previously in their past educa-\ntion, and more. Three common false narratives surrounding legal re-\nsearch are that legal research is easy, boring, and unimportant. Ulti-\nmately, these narratives can cause students to give less time and\nattention to the material and skills they are learning in legal research\nclass; those hiring new attorneys report that this lack of attention con-\ntributes to the lack of retention of legal research skills.3 The three fic-\ntionalized examples below, which are based on amalgamations of stu-\ndents over ten years of teaching, illustrate how these false narratives\nare formed and the impact of holding these false narratives.\nA. \"Legal Research Is Easy.\"\nAntoine is entering the first year of law school after obtaining a\nMaster's degree in political science from a prestigious university. He\nis looking forward to beginning his new degree program and suspects\nthat his previous experience as a graduate student will give him a leg\nup over his law school classmates. Antoine believes legal research is\neasy and probably does not necessitate multiple class sessions.\nAntoine's misconceptions arise from the fact that he did a great\ndeal of social sciences research in meeting the requirements for his un-\ndergraduate and graduate degrees. While he gained experience using a\n2. CREAC is a paradigm used to help students with legal analysis, often used\nin legal writing to help students learn to structure their legal memos and briefs. Diane\nB. Kraft, CREAC in the Real World, 63 CLEv. ST. L. REv. 567, 567 (2015).\n3. See ACAD. L. LIBRS. SPECIAL INT. SECTION TASK FORCE, A STUDY OF\nATTORNEYS' LEGAL RESEARCH PRACTICES AND OPINIONS OF NEW ASSOCIATES'\nRESEARCH SKILLS (2013), https://www.aallnet.org/allsis/wp-content/up-\nloads/sites/4/2018/01/finalreport_07102013.pdf.59 2021\n\n\n--- Page 5 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nfew select specialized databases, such as JSTOR and Ebsco, as he com-\npleted his Master's degree, he does not have any experience using the\nmajor legal databases. He is unaware that legal research has idiosyn-\ncrasies and challenges that differ from those he encountered while con-\nducting research for his other degrees. Like many law students, An-\ntoine likely classifies research as solely a rote, finding task that uses\ntechnology to locate sources that might be helpful for his research is-\nsues. He believes that once he can figure out how to navigate through\nthe pertinent databases-surely a simple task given his prior experience\nusing research databases-he will have learned everything he needs to\nknow about legal research.\nStudents like Antoine do not understand that the challenge in-\nherent to legal research is not in the gathering of sources, but in the\nlegal analysis researchers should do during the research process. There\nare a number of research tasks unique to the law that are inherently\nanalytical, including, but not limited to, synthesizing legal rules from\nmultiple sources, analogizing the rules found to the client fact patterns\nto determine a case's usefulness, and unpacking the court's reasoning\nto determine how those rules might be applied to the client's situation.4\nIt is doing this analytical work while effectively navigating to relevant\nsources that makes legal research the challenging task it is, even for\nthose students with prior experience doing comprehensive, in-depth re-\nsearch projects. Legal research instruction is so much more than just\nlearning to navigate a pair of databases. These students need a thought-\nfully designed legal research curriculum to help them understand the\nrole analysis plays in research. Making the role of analysis visible to\nour students is critical to garnering students' attention in the legal re-\nsearch classroom, which will play a key role in whether they ultimately\nretain the skills they are learning.5\nLegal research professors must have explicit conversations with\ntheir students about the role analysis plays in legal research.6\n4. Alyson Drake, Research as Analysis in the Modern Legal Academy, LEGAL\nRSCH. PEDAGOGY (Mar. 2018), https://www.legalresearchpedagogy.com/2018/03/re-\nsearch-as-analysis-in-modern-legal.html.\n5. See generally JAMES LANG, DISTRACTED: WHY STUDENTS CAN'T Focus\nAND WHAT You CAN Do ABOUT IT (2020).\n6. Alyson Drake, Using the \"A\" Word in Legal Research Instruction,\nDIPLAWMATIC DIALOGUES (Feb. 20, 2018), https://fcilsis.word-\npress.com/2018/02/20/using-the-a-word-in-legal-research-instruction/.60 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 6 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nOtherwise, many students erroneously believe that analysis belongs\nsolely in the writing stage of the legal research and writing process.\nCorrecting this misconception early in students' law school careers is\nespecially important given that this misconception is often reinforced\nby both the structure of the first-year skills curriculum and the assign-\nments given in those classes.7 Unfortunately, this false impression is\nsometimes reinforced by doctrinal and other skills professors. These\nprofessors likely never had the analytical side of research emphasized\nduring their own legal education and see legal research as a skill set\ndevoid of analysis. For students like Antoine, it is important that in-\nstructors use instructional strategies such as scaffolding to emphasize\nthe analytical aspects of research in the overcrowded first year skills\ncurriculum.8\nB. \"Legal Research Is Boring.\"\nMaria is a first-year law student who came to law school because\nshe believes her calling is to help the less fortunate-those without a\nvoice-stand up for their rights. While Maria is smart and excited\nabout law school, she is unenthusiastic when she sees that she has mul-\ntiple class periods devoted to learning legal research as part of her first-\nyear skills course.\nShe enters the legal research classroom with the impression that\nlegal research is a less-than-thrilling activity that she must suffer\nthrough to reach the more exciting aspects of the legal profession-like\nstanding up and passionately advocating for those who need help in\ncourt. While a strong student, Maria believes legal research is just\n\"finding stuff' and assumes that she will have a paralegal whose main\nfunction will be doing her research for her. She wishes that she could\nspend more time in the first semester honing her oral advocacy skills\ninstead of learning to look up cases and statutes on her computer-isn't\nthat what Google is for?\n7. See infra Part II.B.\n8. Scaffolding is a teaching method in which teachers offer a particular sup-\nport or framework to aid students as they learn or master a new skill. See Content\nScaffolding, IRIS CTR. https://iris.peabody.vanderbilt.edu/module/sca/cre-\nsource/q2/p03/#content (last visited Dec. 30, 2021). For more on scaffolding, see in-\nfra notes 77-101 & accompanying text.61 2021\n\n\n--- Page 7 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nMaria is not alone. Many first-year law students enter legal re-\nsearch classrooms, whether a stand-alone research course or a compo-\nnent of a larger legal research and writing class, wondering why so\nmuch time is spent on research, a skill they may consider boring. Per-\nceived boredom can be severely detrimental to student learning.9 As\nJames Lang argues in Distracted: Why Students Can't Focus and What\nto Do About It, students will not retain anything that they're not paying\nattention to.10 However, research becomes less boring and we are bet-\nter able to maintain student attention when the professor can tie the\nlearning back to the students' own personal reasons for being in law\nschool.\" As Kevin Michael Klipfel and Dani Brecher Cook note in\ntheir 2017 book, Learner-Centered Pedagogy: Principles and Prac-\ntice, \"significant learning takes place for the learner if, and only if, the\nlearner attaches some personal meaning to the subject of inquiry and\nwants to learn about the subject matter. Real, genuine curiosity is cen-\ntral to this kind of learning.\"1 2\nThe additional problem with this false narrative is it results in\nstudents entering our classrooms with primarily extrinsic motivation.\nExtrinsic motivation occurs when students are motivated by an outside\nreward or punishment.13 Students who grasp on to this narrative may\nbe motivated solely by the grades they will receive on research assign-\nments or by the participation points they might lose if they do not show\nup to class ready to engage with the material.4 Intrinsic motivation,\non the other hand, occurs when students are interested in the material\n\"for its own sake.\"5\n9. See generally Guanyu Cui, Meilin Yao, & Xia Zhang, The Dampening Ef-\nfects of Perceived Teacher Enthusiasm on Class-Related Boredom: The Mediating\nRole of Perceived Autonomy Support and Task Value, 8 FRONTIERS PSYCH. 1, 2\n(2017).\n10. Lang explains that attention is necessary for all three stages of the learning\nprocess-attention, encoding, and retrieval from long-term memory. Lang, supra note\n5, at 46 (\"We don't learn anything that doesn't hold our attention for at least a little\nbit.\").\n11. See KEVIN MICHAEL KLIPFEL & DANI BRECHER COOK, LEARNER-\nCENTERED PEDAGOGY: PRINCIPLES AND PRACTICES 7 (2017).\n12. Id.\n13. JULIE DIRKSEN, DESIGN FOR How PEOPLE LEARN 30 (2d ed. 2016).\n14. See generally id.\n15. Id.62 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 8 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nAs one author rightly noted, \"intrinsic motivation kicks extrinsic\nmotivation's ass.\"16 When learners are extrinsically motivated, teach-\ners must make much greater strides to engage their learners, seeking\nways to tie content to students' interests and find anything learners\nmight fmd intrinsically motivating.17 Course design that transfers ex-\ntrinsic motivation into intrinsic motivation will increase student ef-\nfort.18 It is important for students like Maria that educators break the\nfalse narrative that legal research is boring to ensure that learning is\ndeep and sustained.19 Otherwise students like Maria usually perceive\nresearch as merely a source collecting task-which it may have been\nwhen they wrote research reports in undergraduate studies or high\nschool-and will never engage fully with the materials.20 Ultimately,\nthese students will fail to retain the research skills they need in prac-\ntice.21\nOne way to battle this lack of intrinsic motivation and to tie re-\nsearch to students' personal reasons for attending law school is to em-\nphasize research as analysis-the type of deep thinking that many stu-\ndents imagine themselves doing in their lives as attorneys.22 Framing\nresearch as a problem-solving endeavor can engage students who may\nneed help finding intrinsic motivation for their research courses.23\nThese students engage when they can understand how the skills they\nare learning tie to the practical work of lawyering. Incorporating the\npractice of analytical research skills is necessary for these students to\nbuy in to the importance of legal research instruction. Because analysis\nwhile researching is a challenging endeavor for most students, fmding\na way to help students learn effectively is a difficult task. Again, scaf-\nfolding can be used to help these students.24\n16. Id.\n17. See Haleh Yazdi, How Educators Can Foster Student Motivation, DIGIT.\nPROMISE (Aug. 18, 2016), https://digitalpromise.org/2016/08/18/how-educators-can-\nfoster-student-motivation/.\n18. Id.\n19. Drake, supra note 1 at 518.\n20. Yazdi, supra note 17.\n21. See generally Drake, supra note 1.\n22. Id. at 520-22.\n23. Id. at 521.\n24. See infra Part IV.2021 63\n\n\n--- Page 9 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nC. \"Legal Research is Unimportant.\"\nAndy enters law school as a third-generation law student. His\nmother is an intellectual property law professor at another law school,\nbut with ambitions to be a litigator, he chose this law school because of\nits strong advocacy.program. When going over his class schedule with\nhis mother, he got the strong impression that his courses in Civil Pro-\ncedure, Torts, and Contracts are the most important courses, on which\nhe should focus his time and energy.. Andy also notices that his Legal\nResearch and Writing class is only three credit hours while all of his\nother classes are four credit hours.\nIn the first day of his first-year legal skills class, when reviewing\nthe syllabus, he notices that research assignments are only worth fifteen\npercent of his grade, despite the class being called Legal Research and\nWriting. Writing and oral advocacy make up a significantly larger per-\ncentage of his grade. A few weeks later, when he has his first class\ndevoted to legal research, his Legal Research and Writing professor\nintroduces her co-teacher, who will be instructing the legal research\nportion of the class as a member of the library staff-even though her\nco-teacher is a tenure-track library faculty member. Within just a few\nweeks of starting law school, Andy has the impression that the \"least\nimportant\" component of his \"least important\" class is taught by a li-\nbrarian, not a \"real\" faculty member. He concludes that he does not\nneed to worry as much about research because it will not count that\nmuch in the long run.\nStudents like Andy will also benefit from a discussion of re-\nsearch as analysis, even though these students might argue that they are\nlearning analysis in their doctrinal classes.25 However, when students\nare analogizing or synthesizing in their doctrinal and other skills\ncourses, they are often doing it with a body of sources already on\nhand.26 In these situations, they are not grappling with the hard work\nof framing their research issues and analyzing their sources while sim-\nultaneously trying to gather sources.27 Many students struggle just to\nnavigate legal research databases successfully without adding in the\ncritical thinking necessary for efficient and effective legal research.28\n25. Drake, supra note 1.\n26. Id. at 525.\n27. Id. at 519.\n28. Id. at 514.64 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 10 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nGiving students like Andy the opportunity to use their analytical skills\nwhile conducting legal research during the first year is imperative for\nstudents to understand the real work of legal research and to prepare\nfor the work they will spend a significant amount of time doing in prac-\ntice.2 9\nIII. HOw COGNITIVE (OVER)LOAD REINFORCES THESE FALSE LEGAL\nRESEARCH NARRATIVES\nAn overcrowded first-year skills curriculum does little to change\nthe false legal research narratives students bring with them to law\nschool. As students begin this new educational experience, it becomes\nan easy choice for students to de-prioritize legal research as they at-\ntempt to handle the tremendous cognitive load the first year of law\nschool presents to them.\nA. What is Cognitive Load?\nCognitive psychologists use the term cognitive load to describe\nthe mental challenge working memory imposes on a person's learn-\ning.30 As cognitive psychologist Frederick Reif described it, \"[t]he\ncognitive load involved in a task is the cognitive effort (or amount of\ninformation processing) required by a person to perform this task.\"31\nDeveloped by John Sweller, cognitive load theory, in its simplest form,\nexplains that working memory has a limited capacity and that instruc-\ntional methods should avoid adding to that burden by including activi-\nties that do not directly contribute to student learning.32 In other words,\ncognitive load theorists argue that learning complex, new information\n29. ACAD. L. LIBRS. SPECIAL INT. SECTION TASK FORCE, supra note 3.\n30. Fred Paas, Alexander Renkl, & John Sweller, Cognitive Load Theory: In-\nstructional Implications of the Interaction Between Information Structures and Cog-\nnitive Architecture, 32 INSTRUCTIONAL SCI. 1, 2 (2004); see also Terri L. Enns &\nMonte Smith, Take a (Cognitive) Load Off Creating Space to Allow First-Year Legal\nWriting Students to Focus on Analytical and Writing Processes, 20 LEGAL WRITING:\nJ. LEGAL WRITING INST. 109, 110 (2015).\n31. FREDERICK REIF, APPLYING COGNITIVE SCIENCE TO EDUCATION: THINKING\nAND LEARNING IN SCIENTIFIC AND OTHER COMPLEX DOMAINS 361 (2010).\n32. Cognitive Load Theory: Helping People Learn Effectively, MINDTOOLS,\nhttps://mindtools.com/pages/article/cognitive-load-theory.htm (last visited Dec. 30,\n2021).2021 65\n\n\n--- Page 11 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nexhausts students' finite working memory, and posits that there is a\nlimit to how much information students are able to absorb at one time.33\nTo understand cognitive load, one must first have a baseline un-\nderstanding of how memory works. Cognitive load is based on a model\nof human information processing that divides memory into three\ntypes.34 The first type is sensory memory.5 As humans move through\nthe world, they get sensory impressions of everything surrounding\nthem. Sensory memory processes those bits of sensory information\nthat are important enough-usually things that surprise us or that we\nare actively paying attention to-to pass into working memory.36\nOnce sensory memory passes into working memory, the infor-\nmation is either processed or discarded.37 Working memory is the\n\"limited mental 'space' in which humans think;\"38 we are only con-\nscious of information processing during this stage of memory.39 Hu-\nmans are only able to hold on to between five and nine \"chunks\" of\ninformation at any given time.40 Psychologist George A. Miller intro-\nduced the term chunk in his research on short-term memory, describing\nchunks as groups of items collected together and treated by the brain as\na single unit.41 What constitutes a chunk of information will differ\nbased on the strength of the knowledge structures in someone's long-\n33. Clark, Kirschner, & Sweller, supra note 36, at 8.\n39. Id. at 9.\n40. Cognitive Load Theory: Helping People Learn Effectively, supra note 32.\n41. Inbar Levy, Simplifying Legal Decisions: Factor Overload in Civil Proce-\ndure Rules, 41 MELB. U. L. REv. 727, 756 (2017).66 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 12 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nterm memory.42 For an expert, who has strong knowledge structures in\ntheir long-term memory from years of studying a topic, a single chunk\nmight be comprised of multiple complex concepts. In contrast, for a\nnovice learner without a knowledge structure into which she can fit the\nnew concepts she 's learning, each new concept may be its own chunk.43\nFurthermore, working memory is limited in its duration when\nprocessing new information; most information stored in working\nmemory vanishes within thirty seconds if not rehearsed.44 Cognitive\nload theory, moreover, is concerned primarily with the limits of work-\ning memory. While a person is learning, information must be held in\none's working memory.4' As such, when too much information is pre-\nsented, the learner's cognitive capacity is overloaded and much of the\nnew information is lost.46\nFinally, working memory that is not discarded is processed and\ncategorized in the brain into long-term memory.47 Long-term memory\nis \"stored in knowledge structures called schemas,\" which organize in-\nformation according to how people use it.48 Long-term memory is con-\nsidered to be infinite, but the more practiced a person is at using any\ngiven scheme, the more effortless that behavior becomes.49 This pro-\ncess is called automation.50 The aim of learning is to move new infor-\nmation to long-term memory so that students can then draw on this\n42. See Robert Frost, What Makes Chunking Such An Effective Way to Learn?,\nFORBES, (Nov. 8, 2017, 3:03 PM),\nhttps://www.forbes.com/sites/quora/2017/11/08/what-makes-chunking-such-an-ef-\nfective-way-to-learn/#4c 12488660a9.\n43. See Amanda L. Gilchrist, How Should We Measure Chunks? A Continuing\nIssue in Chunking Research and a Way Forward, 6 FRONTIERS PSYCH. 1456, 1456\n(2015).\n44. See Clark, Kirschner, & Sweller, supra note 36, at 9 (\"[E]xpert problem\nsolvers derive their skill by drawing on the extensive experience stored in their long-\nterm memory in the form of concepts ... known as mental schemas. They retrieve\nmemories of past procedures and solutions, and then quickly select and apply the best\nones for solving problems.\").\n50. Cognitive Load Theory: Helping People Learn Effectively, supra note 32.67 2021\n\n\n--- Page 13 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nknowledge when they are exposed to new material.5 As cognitive the-\norist and education scholar Richard E. Clark and his colleagues put it,\n\"[e]verything we see, hear, and think about is dependent on and influ-\nenced by our long-term memory.\"5 2\nCognitive theorists break cognitive load into three distinct types.\nThe first, intrinsic cognitive load, describes the difficulty inherent to\nthe material students are learning.53 In other words, intrinsic cognitive\nload is the challenge specific to the information a student is currently\ntrying to learn.54 The second type of cognitive load is called germane\ncognitive load.5 It is a subset of intrinsic cognitive load and refers to\nthe amount of intrinsic load the working memory is able to effectively\nuse to develop long-term memory.56 It \"is produced by the construction\nof [memory] schema\" and \"assists in learning new skills or infor-\nmation.\"51\nThe third and final type of cognitive load is extraneous cognitive\nload, which occurs when information \"unnecessary to the immediate\nlearning objective\" is introduced to students and interferes with student\nlearning.58 Extraneous cognitive load is anything that requires stu-\ndents' effort and attention without adding to their knowledge base.59\nExtraneous cognitive load is usually a result of ineffective instructional\ndesign and can, therefore, be reduced with good course planning.60 Ex-\namples of course design that can lead to extraneous cognitive load in-\nclude unclear examples, poorly designed course materials, and\n51. Shibli & West, supra note 37.\n52. Clark, Kirschner, & Sweller, supra note 36, at 9.\n53. John Sweller, Cognitive Load Theory: Recent Theoretical Advances, in\nCOGNITIVE LOAD THEORY 29, 40-41 (Jan L. Plass, Roxana Moreno, & Roland\nBrunken eds., 2010).\n54. DIRKSEN, supra note 13, at 167.\n55. Sweller, supra note 53, at 43-44.\n56. Id.\n57. See Roxana Moreno & Babette Park, Cognitive Load Theory: Historical\nDevelopment and Relation to Other Theories, in COGNITIVE LOAD THEORY 9 (Jan L.\nPlass, Roxana Moreno, & Roland Br inken eds., 2010).68 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 14 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\ntechnology that is hard to navigate.61 Ultimately, an effective instruc-\ntional designer will aim to be aware of a learning task's intrinsic cog-\nnitive load and will reduce or eliminate the extraneous cognitive load.62\nThere are several ways that professors can help students manage\ntheir cognitive load. The first is to reduce those ineffective instruc-\ntional design choices that lead to extraneous cognitive load.63 The\nother, which this Article concerns, is to design their course-wherever\npossible-relying on preexisting schemas in students' long-term\nmemory.64 These preexisting schema are any information that has\nmoved into one's long-term memory, including any concepts or skills\ngained in students' life experience or earlier in their educational ca-\nreers.65 When students are learning new things, they retrieve schema\nfrom their long-term memory and move them into their working\nmemory.66 Luckily, working memory treats already-established\nschema as a single chunk of information, rather than the separate pieces\nthat went into building that knowledge structure.67\nIn fact, those schema that have been retrieved and used repeat-\nedly barely register in the working memory as a chunk of information\nbecause schema are so deeply ingrained in the long-term memory.68 As\na result, learning activities that rely upon a learner's existing\nknowledge structures actually expand the capacity of one's working\nmemory, and the cognitive load is reduced.69 That is, \"we can reduce\nthe demands on our processing power-or the cognitive load of a prob-\nlem-by being able to draw upon concepts that we have stored in our\nlong-term memory.\"70\n61. Research Instruction and Cognitive Load in First-Year Legal\nSkills Instruction\nThe limits of first-year law students' working memories are con-\nstantly tested. Aside from the substantive content learned in classes,\nfirst-year law students are adjusting to a new place to live, learning new\nstudy strategies, forming new friendships, and managing financial\nstressors. Many first-generation and underrepresented minority law\nstudents likely also use cognitive space to question whether they belong\nin law school spaces that can feel like they were built for different\ngroups.71 Accordingly, first-year students are constantly processing in-\nformation from working memory to long-term memory. These stu-\ndents are also working to build knowledge structures in their doctrinal\nclasses; because most of the material they encounter is entirely new to\nthem, they lack sophisticated knowledge structures in their long-term\nmemory and their working memories are constantly at capacity trying\nto hold on to and process the new chunks of information continually\nintroduced.\nIn their first-year legal skills courses, students are trying to rec-\noncile the new substantive law they are learning with practical skills\nand analytical skills that also require a great deal of working memory.\nAs Professors Terri Enns and Monte Smith note, \"the complicated pro-\ncess of analyzing legal problems, researching their possible solutions,\nand communicating that analysis in writing can overwhelm students'\nworking memories, leaving no space for the conscious acquisition of\nmore broadly-applicable writing doctrine.\"72\nStudents struggle because they try to internalize large volumes\nof new information and perform new skills \"while being expected to\nperform as if they already have internalized them.\"73 This can be in-\ncredibly frustrating to students. Effective course design makes students\n71. Toni Schmader & Michael Johns, Converging Evidence That Stereotype\nThreat Reduces Working Memory Capacity, 85 J. PERSONALITY & Soc. PSYCH. 440,\n441 (2003) (\"[F]indings suggest that activating negative stereotypes about a social\nidentity that one possesses can create an extra situational burden that interferes with\nthe ability to perform as well at a mental task as might otherwise be possible.\").\n72. Enns & Smith, supra note 30, at 111.\n73. Paula Lustbader, Construction Sites, Building Types, and Bridging Gaps:\nA Cognitive Theory of the Learning Progression of Law Students, 33 WILLAMETTE L.\nREv. 315, 338 (1997).70 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 16 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nfeel both smart and capable.74 While it is important to challenge learn-\ners, professors should take steps to mitigate those experiences that\ncause our students to feel embarrassed about concepts and skills they\nare in the process of gaining.75\nThe overcrowding of the first-year curriculum, while common\nand perhaps difficult to correct, has a similar effect on the acquisition\nof analytical research skills. While students in first-year legal skills\ncourses are provided with a structure for tying together their analysis\nand writing,76 they do not usually receive any structure for how to con-\nduct analytical research. Because this overloading of the first-year\nskills curriculum causes so many challenges to learning, often profes-\nsors make a choice to emphasize other skills-writing, analysis, oral\nadvocacy, or most likely some combination of the three-above re-\nsearch. Courses are designed to emphasize these other important skills\nto the detriment of research skills-especially analytical research\nskills.\nAs such, in many first-year skills courses, the emphasis centers\non the bibliographical retrieval skills, minimizing the analysis. Often\nprofessors ground their research assignments in a fact pattern to give\nthe impression that students are engaging in experiential problem-solv-\ning. Unfortunately, due to class time constraints and a huge variety of\nsources to cover, the problems must be simple ones if students are go-\ning to complete their in-class exercises during class time.\nLikewise, in many cases, first-year open memo problems are\npurposely kept simple to allow students to focus on their writing and\norganizational skills. Problems may be based solely on common law,\ndepriving students of the opportunity to utilize their statutory research\nskills. Problems may also rely upon a very limited body of cases. In\nothers, the research problems may be challenging, but students have\nreceived little guidance in how to engage in research analysis or have\nhad little time to practice conducting research analysis while doing bib-\nliographic research. This results in students engaging in only a surface-\nlevel analysis, skimming to see if cases might seem helpful. This\n74. DIRKSEN, supra note 13, at 35.\n75. Id.\n76. Most legal writing professors use CREAC, IRAC, or some other structure\nas a way of helping novice legal writers engage in legal analysis. See infra Part\nIV.B.2.7 1 2021\n\n\n--- Page 17 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\ngenerally results in students having to reread their carefully cultivated\npile of cases when it is time to write and reinforces students' miscon-\nceptions that analysis should be centered primarily in the writing pro-\ncess.\nStudents may be able to tie certain bibliographic research skills\nback to experiences they had researching in their previous collegiate\nlevel studies, but engaging in legal analysis while researching is new\nto most law students. Unfortunately, while students in first-year legal\nskills courses are provided with a structure for tying together their anal-\nysis and writing, they do not usually receive any structure for how to\nconduct analytical research. Additionally, while most students imme-\ndiately see the importance of legal writing or oral advocacy, there is an\nadditional barrier to overcome with legal research: students' lack of\nintrinsic motivation due to the false narratives surrounding legal re-\nsearch instruction. This lack of intrinsic motivation, when tied to the\nlimited cognitive capacity of these students, means that students strug-\ngle immensely when the time comes to tie their bibliographic and ana-\nlytical research skills together. Providing students with a structure for\npracticing these two skills simultaneously will help them tremen-\ndously-particularly if first-year skills professors can reduce the bur-\nden on students' cognitive load by tying that structure to a structure\nstudents have already been introduced to while learning how to com-\nmunicate legal analysis in writing.\nIV. How SCAFFOLDING CAN HELP OVERCOME COGNITIVE\n(OVER)LOAD\nA. What is Scaffolding?\nWhen working to solve a problem, one must rely on their work-\ning memory.77 Researcher Richard Clark and his team aptly describe\nthe overcrowded, stream-of-conscious thought process that students\nexperience when learning new concepts and skills:\nIf the learner has no relevant concepts or procedures in\nlong-term memory, the only thing to do is blindly search\nfor possible solution steps that bridge the gap between\nthe problem and its solution. This process places a great\n77. Clark, Kirschner, & Sweller, supra note 36, at 10.72 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 18 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nburden on working-memory capacity because the prob-\nlem solver has to continually hold and process the current\nproblem state in working memory (e.g., Where am I right\nnow in the problem-solving process? How far have I\ncome toward fmding a solution?) along with the goal\nstate (e.g., Where do I have to go? What is the solution?),\nthe relations between the goal state and the problem state\n(e.g., Is this a good step toward solving the problem? Has\nwhat I've done helped me get nearer to where I need to\ngo?), the solution steps that could further reduce the dif-\nferences between two states (e.g., What should the next\nstep be? Will that step bring me closer to the solution?\nIs there another solution strategy I can use that might be\nbetter?), and any subgoals along the way.78\nThis is a tremendously difficult task for a novice learner. For this rea-\nson, professors need to adopt pedagogical strategies, such as scaffold-\ning, that will ease students' cognitive burden.\nScaffolding is one method for helping reduce intrinsic cognitive\nload. In instructional settings, scaffolding is defined as supports an in-\nstructor provides to boost student learning and to help students develop\nand master new content and skills.79 As one author described it,\n\"[g]ood scaffolding acts like training wheels; it allows learners to ac-\ncomplish the difficult task in a safely supported way. Ideally, it doesn't\nreduce learners to bystanders but gives them the support they need to\ncomplete tasks they otherwise wouldn't be able to do.\"8 0 That support\nshould be gradually reduced as learners become more competent to\nhandle learning on their own.81\nOne reason scaffolding is so effective is the consistency that\ncomes from using the same scaffolding structure over and over again.82\nOnce students learn the scaffolding structure the first time, they are not\nstarting from scratch the next time they encounter it.83 Instead, they\n78. Id. at 10.\n79. Content Scaffolding, supra note 8.\n80. DIRKSEN, supra note 13, at 43.\n81. Id.\n82. See id. at 142 (describing how consistency is helpful due to the reduction\nin cognitive load it can provide during the learning process).\n83. See id.73 2021\n\n\n--- Page 19 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\ncan just pull the structure from their long-term memory as a single\nchunk.84 When an element of learning is consistent, then students do\nnot have to allocate mental resources to relearning it.85\nSecond, scaffolding gives students a context and a method to\nprocess what they are learning.86 It allows professors to build on stu-\ndents' preexisting knowledge base to teach fundamental concepts in a\nhelpful progression.87 It also helps students to increase and strengthen\nconnections between the pieces of information they are learning.88 The\ndifficulty of a learning experience is based on both the complexity of\nthe information being learned and the prior knowledge of the learner,\nso if professors can tie new learning to prior learning, it will help miti-\ngate some of the difficulty inherent to learning new content.89\nFinally, the structure that scaffolding provides students helps\nthem organize their learning.90 As Clark and his collaborators pre-\nsented in one of their hallmark articles on cognitive load theory:\nDecades of research clearly demonstrate thatfor novices\n(comprising virtually all students), direct, explicit in-\nstruction is more effective and more efficient than partial\nguidance. So, when teaching new content and skills to\nnovices, teachers are more effective when they provide\nexplicit guidance accompanied by practice and feedback,\nnot when they require students to discover many aspects\nof what they must learn.91\nScaffolding provides the guidance students need in processing\nnew information.92 By putting the scaffolding in place, the instructor\nhelps students make connections between knowledge the students have\n84. See id.\n85. DIRKSEN, supra note 13, at 142.\n86. See Lustbader, supra note 73, at 320 (discussing the importance of context\nand method in the learning process).\n87. See id. at 321.\n88. See DIRKSEN, supra note 13, at 48.74 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 20 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nalready acquired and new information the students are learning.93 Scaf-\nfolding helps to break down the subject matter being taught and pro-\nvides an organization for the course content's delivery; students learn\nthe pieces before they are required to understand the whole.94\nThere are a number of different scaffolding techniques that pro-\nfessors can implement into their classroom, including content scaffold-\ning, task scaffolding, and material scaffolding.95 In content scaffold-\ning, the professor selects content that is not too unfamiliar to the\nstudent, so students can focus on the skill being taught and not get lost\nin new content.96 For example, research instructors can apply a concept\ntaught in first-year doctrinal law courses, like intentional infliction of\nemotional distress, and ask students to apply the content to their re-\nsearch plan, building on previously learned material.97 Because they\nknow something about intentional infliction of emotional distress, the\ncognitive burden in completing the assignment is lessened.\nIn task scaffolding, the professor models the steps that must be\ntaken to complete a task while verbalizing her thought processes to the\nstudent.98 For instance, in a research workshop, an instructor can\ndemonstrate how to conduct an index search for a state statute via\nWestlaw and/or Lexis, while verbalizing each step of the process.99 Fi-\nnally, material scaffolding utilizes written prompts to help students per-\nform a task or strategy. One example of material scaffolding could be\na guided outline or example that lists the necessary steps to complete a\ntask.10o\nWhen learners have already mastered some of the knowledge\nthey need to engage in problem solving or analysis, it can help reduce\n93. Research Logs\nResearch logs are a research tool familiar to many legal research\ninstructors that can be easily adapted into a scaffolding aid that can help\nlaw students in developing their legal research analysis skills. By mod-\nifying research logs to follow an IRAC or CREAC structure, legal re-\nsearch instructors can tap into their students' pre-existing schema for\nlegal analysis and help students understand the central role that analysis\nplays in legal research.\n1. Linz, supra note 104, at 73.2021 77\n\n\n--- Page 23 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nand have not missed any important steps in the research process.1 3 In\nreviewing the log, researchers would notice any leads not followed, as\nwell as any sources they have not yet consulted. Finally, the research\nlog is a great tool for supporting new researchers in organizing their\nresearch.14 Good organization is also crucial for newer researchers to\nfeel comfortable concluding their research, knowing they have con-\nsulted all the necessary sources.\"5 All of these benefits make the tra-\nditional log a useful tool for the researcher.\nThis traditional log, however, reinforces the stigma that research\nis a rote, mechanical task, as its primary focus is on how sources are\nlocated during the research process rather than why and how these re-\nsources are relevant to the legal issues being researched.'16 While there\noften is a column dedicated to findings or usefulness, student research-\ners tend to enter any variety of vague answers here, such as the case\napplies to X issue or Y element. The findings column does not require\nthe researcher to critically analyze the source or to consider how they\nwill actually use that source in evaluating the legal issues in a client's\npending case. Nor does it require researchers to consider how the rules\nof a case might be applied to the client's issue or to compare the facts\nof the client's case to those in the cases they have located in their re-\nsearch. The traditional log only requires that the researcher read or,\nmore likely, skim the case to see if it \"seems\" like it may be relevant.\nUndoubtedly, the researcher will have to reread all these sources again\nlater to remember how she thought it was helpful and to confirm that it\nis actually useful to her client's issues.\nAs such, the traditional log suggests research is primarily about\nlocating sources, a technical skill rather than an analytical one.
