The literature on research logs and the columns included in the traditional\nresearch log demonstrate that the emphasis is on organization and bibliographic re-\nsearch, not on legal research analysis. See generally Linz, supra note 104; Osborne,\nsupra note 102.78 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 24 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nmay result in reinforcing the narratives students have about legal re-\nsearch-that it is simply an easy, boring gathering task that precedes\nthe \"real\" legal work-and it leaves the important analytical work to\nthe writing phase.\nBy adjusting the research log to follow a CREAC format,17\naligning research analysis with the structure students are usually intro-\nduced to prior to engaging in legal research, professors can reimagine\nthe research log as a more complete tool. This new tool recognizes\nboth the bibliographic and the analytical sides of legal research. In-\nstructors can maintain the useful aspects of the log in helping research-\ners stay organized throughout the research process but increase its\nvalue as a scaffolding tool that will help reduce students' cognitive load\nwhile they learn the analytical side of research.1' This revised log will\nsave students time, force them to engage in the analytical work inherent\nto research, and reinforce concepts they are learning in the writing por-\ntion of their first-year skills course.\n2. The CREAC Log\nIn first-year legal skills courses, many legal writing faculty in-\ntroduce their students to some form of CREAC or IRAC as a way of\nhelping students understand how to structure their legal analysis.1 19\nThe CREAC abbreviation stands for \"Conclusion, Rule, Explanation,\nApplication, and Conclusion.\"120 The IRAC abbreviation begins with\n117. For the closed memo, professors hand stu-\ndents a case file with a limited number of cases, perhaps accompanied\nby a statute and/or a secondary source and ask students to engage in\nlegal analysis and writing without having to first struggle with finding\ncases and analyzing their relevance to their client's issues.2' Through\nthis process, students are taught that only analysis and writing are in-\ntertwined. Research is removed and as such divorced from the analyt-\nical process, reducing the cognitive burden on students as they learn\nintroductory legal analysis and the mechanics of legal writing.\nAfter spending several class periods learning how to organize\ntheir analysis using CREAC, professors introduce their classes to the\nof [F]IRAC, 10 SECOND DRAFT 1, 12 (1995), https://www.lwionline.org/sites/de-\nfault/files/2016-09/nov95.pdf (FIRAC); Terrill Pollman, Building a Tower of Babel\nor Building a Discipline? Venter, supra, at 633-34.\n121. Venter, supra note 120, at 624.\n122. See Gerald Lebovits, Cracking the Code to Writing Legal Arguments:\nFrom IRAC to CRARC to Combinations in Between, 82 N.Y. ST. B. PRAC. & CLINICAL L. 259,273 (2016).80 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 26 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nbasics of legal research. This instruction traditionally focuses on\ndemonstrating the bibliographic tasks used to locate various sources. It\nthen utilizes practice exercises that allow students to find sources,\nsometimes with a hypothetical to give them context for the issue. In\nthis format, research is kept largely separate from analysis-or at least\nit is not explicitly discussed as an analytical exercise. Students may\nanswer a legal question, but due to time constraints, the hypotheticals\nare necessarily kept on the simpler side and students are not forced to\nstruggle with in-depth legal analysis.\nOnce students have practiced researching cases and statutes (and\nsometimes secondary sources and regulations), they begin researching\nan open memo problem that asks them to tie together their newly ac-\nquired research, analysis, and writing skills. Unfortunately, due to the\nextreme cognitive burden that first-year law students are under, tying\nthese separately taught skills together proves to be a challenging task\nfor most students. This occurs, in large part, because law students have\nnever engaged in complex legal analysis while researching. Their total\nexperience in analysis has come after they have been handed a pile of\nsources, so they lack the framework necessary to tackle bibliographic\nresearch and research analysis as a unified process.\nAs a result, most students engage primarily in bibliographic re-\nsearch with, at most, a shallow level of analysis. Most students attempt\nto find cases that \"seem\" on point due to having similar facts, collect\nthose in a folder, and then begin to engage deeply in legal analysis only\nonce they perceive they are done researching and ready to begin writ-\ning. When conducting legal research in this manner, most students\nskim the cases while researching, perhaps going so far as to note issues\nor sub-issues the cases discuss. Students often fail to consider what\nrules emerge from each precedent, how those rules have been applied,\nand how they might apply to their own set of facts. With such a cursory\nreading, students must reread all their authorities when it comes time\nto conduct their full analysis-usually when it is time for them to begin\ndrafting their open memo.124 This less-than-ideal research method not\n124. In an anonymous student survey given to 2L and 3L students in an Ad-\nvanced Legal Research class, one student noted this propensity on earlier research\nprojects she had completed:\nIn the past, I have often just researched a bunch of cases, scanned\nthem quickly and saved them to a Westlaw folder .... I always\nthought I'd miraculously remember all the details. Obviously2021 81\n\n\n--- Page 27 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nonly requires students to waste time rereading when they are ready to\nstart writing their memos or briefs, but it also reinforces the narratives\nof legal research as a mechanical task. In effect, students are trying to\nrecreate the packet they were handed for their closed memo, and it re-\ninforces the idea that they cannot start analyzing until after they have a\nset of sources. It is not, however, a productive use of students' time or\nenergy to merely find the law without analyzing it simultaneously.\nReimagining the research log as an educational tool, based on\nthe CREAC format, gives students a helpful framework for encounter-\ning the analytical side of research. Even though students are not experts\nin legal analysis after one closed memo, they are at least familiar with\nthe characteristics of how to engage in analysis based on CREAC, and\nit eases their way into performing research analysis.125 The CREAC\nstructure acts as the training wheels students need when doing analyti-\ncal research for the first time. It forces students to organize their re-\nsearch in an effective way and to engage in analysis while researching,\nserving as a scaffold for their learning. Introducing the CREAC log\nduring their first experiences with open legal research also helps stu-\ndents create habits to engage in analysis while researching rather than\nafter they are done researching.\nThe CREAC log follows a fairly simple structure and can be\nmodified as needed based on the professor's preferences or to match\nwhichever format (CREAC, IRAC, etc.) that the legal writing professor\nuses. At the top of each section of the log, students should identify the\nissue or sub-issue they are researching. For example, if students were\nresearching a burglary issue, they might have sub-issues for each of the\nindividual elements of burglary (see Appendix A). This serves to break\ndown students' research into manageable pieces rather than trying to\nthink about multiple complicated issues at once-helping to combat\ncognitive overload-and requires them to analyze the clients' fact\nwhen the time came for me to go back.and write a memo or sum-\nmarize my research, I'd quickly realized how unprepared I was. I\nwould essentially be back at square one!\nAnonymous student survey (on file with author).\n125. See Clark, Kirschner, & Sweller, supra note 36, at 9 (\"We are skillful in an\narea if our long-term memory contains huge amounts of information or knowledge\nconcerning the area. That information permits us to quickly recognize the character-\nistics of a situation and indicates to us, often immediately and unconsciously, what to\ndo and when to do it.\").82 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 28 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nscenario to identify the preliminary issues.126 Each issue or sub-issue\nthen has the following columns beneath it:\nCitation: Here, the researcher puts the citation to the source she\nis analyzing, including the pincite to the part of the source discussing\nthat issue. She might also describe how she found this source if that is\nhelpful to her in remembering which research strategies she has already\nused and which she might want to use when she next resumes her re-\nsearch. It is a good opportunity to explain to students that the first\nquestion they will be asked if they get stuck in their research and need\nto ask for help is what they have already tried-and that it is useful to\nkeep a record of what resources they have already consulted. Research\nprofessors may want to require that additional piece, so they can follow\ntheir students' research paths more easily to give effective feedback on\ntheir students' research processes.\nR(ule): Next, students identify the rule laid out in that case for\nthat particular issue or sub-issue. Students should not identify every\nrule laid out in the case. If a case concerns more than one of the issues\nstudents are researching, it would appear in the log under each of those\nissues. This allows students to keep their authorities for individual is-\nsues straight, which helps when they begin drafting. Learning to iden-\ntify the rule from a source is an important lawyering skill, so the\nCREAC log also reinforces skills that will be helpful in other courses.\nE(xplanation): Next, students explain how the rule they identi-\nfied was applied in the precedent case, including the reasoning the court\ngave for that application. This allows students to practice their analyt-\nical skills as they parse out how a rule was applied to the particular\nfacts of the precedent case and whether the court emphasized certain\npoints in applying that rule to the precedent case.27 For sources such\nas statutes or regulations, students would skip the explanation step, as\nthe rule has not been applied to facts in those resources.\n126. In surveying 2L and 3L students, the benefits of the log became very clear,\nas they were able to compare it to research they had done prior to being introduced to\nthe CREAC log. This is where students engage in their deepest analysis, as they\ncompare and contrast relevant facts of their clients' case against the\nfacts of the precedent cases and analogize how rules might be applied\nto their client's fact scenario based on those rules' application in the\nprecedent opinion.128\nNotes: In this section, researchers can jot down any notes or\nquestions they have after analyzing this source for this sub-issue. This\ncan include questions that arose while researching that they had not\npreviously considered. Because research is a circular process, re-\nsearchers cannot follow all leads from a single source simultaneously.\nAs such, students can also note other potentially helpful sources or rel-\nevant topic and key numbers they came across while reading this source\nand that they want to consult later.129  This column allows the re-\nsearcher to stay organized throughout the research process, like the tra-\nditional research log. This allows students to engage in rule synthesis when appropri-\nate and to make a prediction about how the court is likely to rule on the\nparticular issue.\nBecause first-year students have already been introduced to\nCREAC earlier in the semester while completing their closed memo\nassignment, they have pre-existing knowledge structures in place to\nhelp them organize and engage in their analysis.1 30 In an anonymous\nsurvey we gave asking students to reflect on using the CREAC log,\nstudents noted both of these benefits. For example, one student noted:\nThe CREAC log is the latest tool that I will certainly take\nwith me into practice, for a number of reasons. Just through the process, I\nbegan to see things in my cases I would not have other-\nwise picked up on. Second, it is a great way to stay or-\nganized. Its structure serves as a reminder to look for rules, an-\nalyze how those rules were applied in their precedent, and consider how\nthat rule might be applied in their particular case.13' This is a better\n130. See supra Part III.A.\n131. Anonymous student survey results (on file with author).\n132. One student wrote in the anonymous student survey that:\nOutlining the specific elements of the case and providing quick rule\nstatements and analysis allowed me to always have an overview of\nthe case I was researching that was easy and simple to read, so that2021 85\n\n\n--- Page 31 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nstrategy than skimming a case to see if it seems generally on point and\nthrowing it in a pile with a bunch of other authorities to return to when\nit is time to start writing; the CREAC log prevents students from having\nto reread and only begin analyzing sources when it is time to write and\nfocus on drafting.1 33\nA wonderful side effect of this tool is that it generally results in\nbetter written memos, as students often struggle when they try to sim-\nultaneously analyze sources and draft using the mechanical writing\nskills they are still learning. The CREAC log can serve as a rough\noutline of their analysis, so when it is time to write, students can be\nmore elegant in structuring their arguments because they already have\na basic outline of the rules and their application. More practice with\nlegal analysis can also be a benefit when it comes time for students to\ntake their first-year exams; they will have had more practice utilizing\nCREAC to organize their answers.\nIt is critical that instructors be explicit about how and why stu-\ndents are conducting research using a log. Otherwise, students may see\nthe log as busy work. Explaining that the log is meant to serve as a\nstructure to help students with the analytical work of research will help\nstudents to see the value in the exercise. Talking to students about the\nlearning benefits of scaffolding lets them know that using research logs\nis a carefully designed instructional strategy meant to help them grow\nas future attorneys. It is also prudent to explain the helpful side effects\nof completing the log-serving as a rough draft for their memo, helping\nthem master the CREAC structure to thrive on their writing assign-\nments and exams, and ultimately saving them time in their research and\nwriting projects as they do not duplicate their analytical work.\nI could pick up my train of thought where it last let off when jump-\ning back on the research process.\nAnonymous student survey results (on file with author).\n133. This showed up in the anonymous student survey results as well, with one\nstudent mentioning that it's:\n[M]uch easier to have pre-written analysis of how the rulings in\nspecific cases relate to the matter you are researching than having\nto go back to a case you only have a citation for and trying to re-\nmember why you marked it down as useful for this issue in the first\nplace.\nAnonymous student survey results (on file with author).86 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 32 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\nStudents may think it is not practical to do a complete research\nlog every time they conduct legal research-and they are correct. But\nutilizing the CREAC log during the time we are teaching students to\nengage in research analysis will train them to engage in those mental\nprocesses later in their careers without the aid of the log itself. A key\npart of scaffolding, after all, is eventually to remove those training\nwheels. As students move away from their legal skills courses, stu-\ndents' long-term memories will already have knowledge constructs\nformed to engage in analysis during research. Students, therefore, will\nimmediately and unconsciously begin to engage in this analysis while\nresearching even without the CREAC log's structure to aid them. Oth-\ners may return to the research log throughout their career when they are\njuggling multiple complex cases to keep their research organized.34\n3. How a New Log Overcomes False Narratives\nIn addition to providing students with a knowledge structure to\nhelp them engage in analytical and bibliographic research simultane-\nously, forcing students to engage in legal analysis also helps to correct\nthe three false narratives of legal research that students hold-that legal\nresearch is easy, boring, and unimportant.3' The primary reason for\nthis is that requiring students to engage in legal analysis eliminates the\nperception that research is solely a mechanical gathering task.136\nFor the students like Antoine who believe that legal research is\neasy, engaging in this analysis demonstrates that legal research is a\ncomplex undertaking. It shows students that legal research is not just\nabout finding cases that are factually similar but requires deep thinking\nabout how the rules as applied in precedent cases would be addressed\n134. Several students in the anonymous student survey explicitly stated that they\nintended to use the logs in practice and showed a thoughtfulness of how they could\nadapt it based on the type of research they were doing. Id.\n135. See supra Part II.\n136. The anonymous student survey results show that the students are thinking\nmore deeply about the researching that they're doing. One student stated that: \"the\ndifference in results between [using the log or not] is stark. My thoughts on my re-\nsearch and much clearer once they are organized into the log.\" Anonymous student\nsurvey results (on file with author). Another student echoed that sentiment: \"[The\nCREAC log] helped my thinking and analysis when evaluating a statute or a case ...\n.[It] helped deepen my analysis of the law.\" Id.2021 87\n\n\n--- Page 33 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\nin their client's situation. He will learn that there is much more to legal\nresearch than figuring out how to navigate Westlaw and Lexis.\nFor the Marias, who believe that legal research is boring, the\nCREAC log will help them see that research is, at its heart, a problem-\nsolving endeavor. They will learn that research is a chance to find the\nanswers to their clients' problems. By highlighting research's relation-\nship to the analysis and writing processes, legal skills professors can\nhelp increase these students' intrinsic motivation and maintain their at-\ntention, as they see research as central to their ability to help their cli-\nents. These increases in intrinsic motivation and attention will ulti-\nmately result in better long-term retention of these skills. Students will\nalso leave class understanding that research requires in-depth analysis\nand serious problem-solving chops.\nFinally, the CREAC log can show the Andys, who believe that\nresearch is unimportant, how central legal research is to lawyering.\nWhile research may be worth fewer credits or a smaller percentage of\ntheir first-year skills course grade, the analysis skills they practice\nwhile using the CREAC log will be helpful for their doctrinal classes.\nThey will see how critical research is for successful writing and that\ntheir analytical research abilities will have an impact on their writing\ngrades.'37\nThe CREAC log reduces the burden on students' cognitive\nloads, integrates research more clearly into analysis and the writing\nprocess, increases students' intrinsic motivation for engaging in legal\nresearch, and can have positive impacts on students' final exams and\ntheir writing projects-all while battling the false narratives that deni-\ngrate research's place in the legal curriculum.\nV. CONCLUSION\nThe overcrowding of the first-year curriculum is challenging for\nstudents' limited cognitive capacities. Due to this problem, research\ninstruction has been focused on bibliographic, rather than analytical,\nskills. This lack of emphasis on research as analysis has resulted in\nfalse narratives about the importance and difficulty of legal research\n137. Additionally, because students are engaging in significant analysis while\ncompleting the log, legal skills faculty can attribute more of their overall grade to\nresearch, emphasizing its importance in the course, particularly if the log can serve as\nan outline for their memo drafts.88 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 34 ---\n2021 Building on CREAC 89\ninstruction and reduced students' intrinsic motivation for learning re-\nsearch skills. It has also made it challenging for students to engage in\ncomplex legal analysis while researching, a necessary skill for the effi-\ncient practice of law.\nResearch professors can look to educational psychologists' re-\nsearch on cognitive load theory and scaffolding to aid them in rede-\nsigning their courses and assignments by drawing on preexisting\nknowledge structures that have been introduced in earlier educational\nexperiences. The CREAC log is one example of a scaffolding tech-\nnique professors can use to help law students engage in legal analysis\nwhile researching. Not only will this result in students maintaining\nstronger research and analysis skills, it will help break down damaging\nfalse narratives about the importance of legal research within the legal\nacademy as students learn to engage simultaneously in bibliographic\nand analytical research.\n\n\n--- Page 35 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\no Qd\nca00\na )Vol. 52\nU\n4)\nU,\n'C4 N ) U,\n0\nbi CSa) i\n`. mo o ° $d Ua~ r.\nt- *f c \n)\nU o c ° Qn ' b )\nc ~ ~ ,\ny b 343~ N\n°j\nU\n4)\n.Y4)'\n4)w\n4j 0\ni7r 0*ca f y\nHU) G C 0'O\n0\n.UI\n0\n'O\n4)Y0\n01\nr U Za» p tt C OUz90\n> o\no 2\no oU\n4)\nz\n-a 0\n.N 0tUo\n4)\n\n\n--- Page 36 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\n~E 4\nn 0 o~ .- o\nx So .? 0 o aQ '\noQ ~\nVn aa )\n- 7b' bO p\nQ c 0 -' on\nQ 0 rn \n'\n.cn c~j , 00oNa C ~\n-0 bU f C 0\na. o., 0 0 '\nroO\n`d Q t\nv Z ci~ o02021 91\n\n\n--- Page 37 ---\nThe University of Memphis Law Review\n-a 0\n0 cN C\n0-1\nb\nN 0\na\n.0U\n7SW0 r-\nIo0\na\nC b 0 ona 0\n05 ~ ~ ~ t 0-0-.\nCC a *d 0 3 C e-0\na\n-on\no Ra\no\n4- U~\n0\nzO\n© C92 Vol. 52\n\n\n--- Page 38 ---\nBuilding on CREAC\n\"OO M\n_ CO c\nU b CO\nC0JN t5) 53~ O b3!~ 0 0\n_ C)\n-G0 C\nO 0.0\n-p 0 ~ + ,J\n0\no M\nCO\nCO\nU\nC,)\na)CO\n0 . 2 . - a)\nCO) C\nCO L7 CAO -c\n-. v . --b 0J a) CO CO0)\nCO\nCO\na)\nGC\nC.)\nn O\nU\nj~I .N U - 4\"\nHU- > a.)\nC.) - s.___ _ _ b N b U c_____\nCOS\nv-0-\n0 - on.\no \n.3 c\nCO.       "extracted_text": "--- Page 1 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nhttps://doi.org/10.1007/s40593-024-00399-w\nARTICLE\nHow to Improve the Explanatory Power of an Intelligent\nTextbook: a Case Study in Legal Writing\nFrancesco Sovrano1,2·Kevin Ashley3·Peter Leonid Brusilovsky4·\nFabio Vitali1\nAccepted: 29 February 2024 / Published online: 6 May 2024\n© The Author(s) 2024\nAbstract\nExplanatory processes are at the core of scientiﬁc investigation, legal reasoning, and\neducation. However, effectively explaining complex or large amounts of information,such as that contained in a textbook or library, in an intuitive, user-centered way is still\nan open challenge. Indeed, different people may search for and request different types\nof information, even though texts typically have a predeﬁned exposition and content.With this paper, we investigate how explanatory AI can better exploit the full potential\nof the vast and rich content library at our disposal. Based on a recent theory of expla-\nnations from Ordinary Language Philosophy, which frames the explanation process\nas illocutionary question-answering, we have developed a new type of interactive and\nadaptive textbook. Using the latest question-answering technology, our e-book soft-ware (Y AI4Edu, for short) generates on-demand, expandable explanations that can\nhelp readers effectively explore teaching materials in a pedagogically productive way.\nIt does this by extracting a specialized knowledge graph from a collection of booksor other resources that helps identify the most relevant questions to be answered for\na satisfactory explanation. We tested our technology with excerpts from a textbook\nthat teaches how to write legal memoranda in the U.S. legal system. Then, to seewhether Y AI4Edu-enhanced textbooks are better than random and existing, general-\npurpose explanatory tools, we conducted a within-subjects user study with more than\n100 English-speaking students. The students rated Y AI4Edu’s explanations the high-est. According to the students, the explanatory content generated by Y AI4Edu is, on\naverage, statistically better than two baseline alternatives ( Pvalues below .005).\nKeywords Intelligent textbooks ·Education ·Explanatory artiﬁcial intelligence ·\nAnswer retrieval ·Automated question extraction\nB Francesco Sovrano\nfrancesco.sovrano@uzh.ch\nExtended author information available on the last page of the article\n123\n\n--- Page 2 ---\n988 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nIntroduction\nAs pointed out by UNESCO, the United Nations specialized agency for education,\nin one of its recent publications (Miao et al., 2021 ), the opportunities and challenges\nthat Artiﬁcial Intelligence (AI) offers for education in the AI era are yet to be fully\nunderstood. Nonetheless, the expectations are high given the potential of AI to fosterour ability to acquire and convey knowledge. Indeed, since the invention of writing,\nwe have collected a vast amount of written content that now forms the basis of our\ncollective wisdom and industriousness.\nHowever, fully harnessing the potential of such written knowledge by automati-\ncally explaining it in an intuitive and user-centered way is still an open problem .F o r\ninstance, different explainees\n1may search for and request different types of infor-\nmation, even though, usually, the exposition and content of an explanatory document\n(e.g., a book, an article, a web page, or technical documentation) are predetermined\nand static.\nDifferent books on the same subject expound the same knowledge in different ways\nand with different levels of detail. Additionally, this type of static representation is\nsub-optimal and time-consuming in the most generic scenario because helpful infor-\nmation may be sparse and scattered over hundreds or thousands of pages. As a result,\nexplaining to a person can be an extremely challenging task, regardless of whether theexplanandum\n2is from technical documentation, a scientiﬁc article, a regulation or a\ntextbook. Additionally, the complexity of this task is increased by the elusiveness of\nthe notion of explanation.\nTo address the problem of automatically explaining, we study how to automatically\nenhance static educational books by making them more interactive. We do this by\nreducing the sparsity of relevant information, thereby increasing the explanatory power\nof the medium while also linking it to a knowledge graph extracted from a collection\nof supplementary materials.\nThe approach is based on a recent theory from Ordinary Language Philosophy\n(Sovrano & Vitali, 2022a , explained in section “ Explanations According to Ordinary\nLanguage Philosophy ”), which views explaining as more than just providing answers\nto questions. It emphasizes that explaining involves answering unspoken or implicitquestions in a meaningful and relevant way to the individual seeking understanding.\nFor instance, if you ask “How are you doing?” and the response is “I am ﬁne”,\nthis is not an explanation. However, if the response is “I am okay because I wasworried I could have tested positive for COVID-19, but I am not, and [...]”, it becomes\nan explanation. The reason: this response intends to create an understanding of the\nperson’s state of being.\nThis concept of responding to implicit questions is called illocution (Sovrano &\nVitali, 2022a ). It makes the explanation process more focused on the individual seeking\nunderstanding. By anticipating these implicit questions, both the person explaining\n1Anexplainee is a person receiving an explanation.\n2The word explanandum means “what has to be explained” in Latin.\n123\n\n--- Page 3 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 989\nand the person seeking understanding can communicate more efﬁciently, resulting in\na reduction of steps required to explain something3.\nHence, assuming that the goal of an educational e-book is to explain something to the\nreader and consistent with the abovementioned deﬁnition of explanations (Sovrano &\nVitali, 2022a ,b), we built an explanatory process capable, through question-answering,\nof organizing a textbook’s explanatory space4to enable a reader to more efﬁciently and\neffectively retrieve helpful information. Speciﬁcally, our proposed solution consists\nof a pipeline of Explanatory AI (Y AI) algorithms and heuristics to build, on top of\ntextbooks, intelligent interfaces for:\n•answering explicit questions asked by a user;\n•automatically identifying the topics that can be explained by the contents of a\ntextbook (or any collection of texts);\n•generating explanations by anticipating a set of useful (implicit) questions a user\nmight have about the textbook.\nAssuming that the content of a textbook (or a collection of texts integrating it) properly\nexplains a given explanandum, our work relies on the following hypothesis:\nHypothesis 1 The most useful implicit questions a user may have about a collection of\ntexts are those best answered in the collection as a whole. These questions are neither\ntoo detailed (because they would otherwise only be answered in a minor part of the\ncollection) nor too general (because they would be answered inaccurately in the more\ndetailed textual content).\nIf the assumption mentioned above holds, we believe that the hypothesis is correct\nfor the following reasons:\n•any question falling outside the scope of the collection of documents could not be\nanswered, thus not being useful;\n•whoever wrote the textbook tried to explain as well as possible (for her/his narrative\npurposes) the most important topics at hand, thus (according to the adopted deﬁ-\nnition of explanation) implicitly identifying the most important questions whose\nanswers provide a good overview of the topics.\nConsequently, our main contribution is a novel pipeline of Y AI software for\nenhancing the explanatory power of a textbook based on an algorithm (called Intelli-gent Explanation Generator) for identifying the questions best answered by a collection\nof texts. Indeed, according to theory, what makes a Y AI good at explaining is its ability\nto identify implicit and relevant questions to answer, somehow anticipating the needsof the explainee.\nAs a case study for our proposed Y AI for education (Y AI4Edu, for short), we\nconsidered a teaching scenario where the excerpts of a textbook, “United States Legal\n3This theory has been supported by various experiments and studies involving over 190 participants\n(Sovrano & Vitali, 2022a ,b).\n4The explanatory space is the space of all possible bits of explanation about an explanandum. A more\nformal deﬁnition is given by Sovrano and Vitali ( 2022a ).\n123\n\n--- Page 4 ---\n990 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nFig. 1 Example of intelligent explanatory overview generated by YAI4Edu. This ﬁgure contains an\nexample of interactive overview in the form of a scrollspy showing relevant questions and answers as\nexplanations. The reader can select a new topic to overview by clicking on any underlined word\nLanguage and Culture: An Introduction to the U.S. Common Law System” (Brostoff &\nSinsheimer, 2013 ), together with the encyclopedia of the Legal Information Institute\nof the Cornell Law School and thousands of cases of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals\n(BV A)5are used for teaching how to write a legal memorandum6in support of a\ndisability claim for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) according to the U.S.legal system.\nThe complexity of legal jargon and intricate language in the ﬁeld of law offers a\nsubstantial test for Y AI4Edu, making our case study an ideal showcase of its abilities.\nWe utilize over 16,000 diverse resources for this study, including a textbook actively\nused in a University of Pittsburgh course. This enhances the study’s real-world practi-cality and educational relevance. When coupled with the important societal context of\nveterans’ PTSD disability claims, our case study highlights the potential of AI appli-\ncations in education, particularly in complex ﬁelds such as law. For an example of anintelligent explanation generated by Y AI4Edu in this scenario, see Fig. 1.\nAs an example to clarify what Hypothesis 1means in this case, let us suppose we\nwant to explain what a legal memorandum is. The textbook (Brostoff & Sinsheimer,2013 ) does it by describing what a memo is in a legal sense, what it is for, what the\nproper form of a legal memorandum is, and what sections it should include. The text-\n5The BV A is an administrative tribunal within the United States Department of Veterans Affairs that\ndetermines whether U.S. military veterans are entitled to claimed veterans’ beneﬁts and services.\n6A legal memorandum is an organized document that summarizes relevant laws to support a conclusion\non a particular legal issue.\n123\n\n--- Page 5 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 991\nbook also provides secondary details , explaining each step of drafting a memorandum,\nwhy writing a memo is difﬁcult, what the heading of a memorandum contains, and so\non. Hence, in this case, Hypothesis 1implies that the most useful implicit questions to\nask are not those whose answers are only secondary details. This is because they are\ntoo speciﬁc to represent the whole textbook’s explanatory content adequately. Instead,\nthe best choices are the main questions such as “what is the proper form of a legalmemorandum”, “what is a memo in a legal sense”, because they best represent the\ncontent of the textbook.\nTo evaluate Y AI4Edu and verify Hypothesis 1, we conducted a within-subjects\nuser study , comprising more than 100 students. This was done to study how different\nstrategies to identify helpful implicit questions impact the quality of the resulting\nexplanations. In particular, during the study, different explanations (an example isshown in Fig. 5) were given to English-speaking students about the task of writing a\nlegal memorandum . For more details about the explanations used in the experiment,\nsee Table 2.\nWe compared the explanations generated by the Intelligent Explanation Generator\n(relying on Hypothesis 1) with those of the following two baseline algorithms :\n•arandom explanations generator : an algorithm that organizes explanations by\nrandomly selecting implicit questions from those answered by the corpus of con-\nsidered texts;\n•ageneric explanations generator : an algorithm that uses very generic questions\n(e.g., why ,how ,what ) instead of those extracted from the textbook, under the\nassumption that all possible (implicit) questions are instances of such genericquestions.\nTheresults supported Hypothesis 1. They showed that our Intelligent Explanation\nGenerator outperforms the baselines mentioned above in all the considered expla-\nnations, selecting questions that are not too speciﬁc or generic. The differences in\nperformance were statistically signiﬁcant ( Pvalues below .005). Notably, the results\nalso show that the explanations generated from generic questions are signiﬁcantly\nbetter than those generated from random questions, giving further evidence in support\nof the validity of the hypothesis.\nSynopsis. In section “ Related Work ”, we discuss existing literature on interactive\ne-books for education, focusing on AI-based solutions. In section “ Background ”, we\nprovide sufﬁcient background to understand the theory behind the algorithms presentedin section “ Y AI4Edu: a Y AI for Improving the Explanatory Power of an Intelligent\nTextbook ”. Then, in section “ Case Study: A Textbook for Teaching How to Write\nLegal Memoranda ”, we present our case study on legal writing, and in section “ Exper-\niment ”, we introduce the experiment for verifying Hypothesis 1. Finally, in section\n“Discussion: Results and Limitations ” and section “ Limitations and Future Work ”, we\ndiscuss the experimental results and the limitations of the proposed approach, while\nalso highlighting potential avenues for future work.\n123\n\n--- Page 6 ---\n992 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nRelatedWork\nSome studies suggest that using intelligent textbooks7and interactive e-books leads\nto an increase in use, motivation and learning gains versus static e-books (Ericson,\n2019 ). Of the several streams of work on the topic of interactive e-books and intelligent\ntextbooks, most focus on the cognitive process of the reader, studying how to enhancethe pedagogical productivity of textbooks through expert systems or sophisticated\ninterfaces. They usually accomplish this by:\n•showing personal progress through open learner models (Kay & Kummerfeld,\n2019 ,2021 );\n•specializing on ad hoc tasks through some domain modeling (Beier & Rau, 2022 ;\nDeligiannis et al., 2019 ; Chacon et al., 2021 ; Matsuda & Shimmei, 2019 );\n•modeling a student through questions, in order to identify and suggest personalized\ncontents (Thaker et al., 2019 ; Mohammed & Shaffer, 2021 ; Matsuda & Shimmei,\n2019 );\n•associating pedagogically valuable quizzes and exercises to portions of the e-book\n(Wang et al., 2022 ; Shimmei & Matsuda, 2022 ; Campenhout et al., 2021a ,b);\n•providing tools for manually creating new interactive e-books (Wang et al., 2021 ;\nP u r s e le ta l . , 2019 ; Kluga et al., 2019 ).\nThe use of AI for the automatic generation of interactive e-books seems to be under-\nexplored. In one such project, (Barria-Pineda et al., 2022 ) propose to automatically\naugment the sections of existing books with related YouTube videos by directly anno-\ntating the PDF, thus without breaking the structure of these textbooks.\nUnlike the previous literature examples, our approach attempts to fully automat-\nically convert an existing e-book into an interactive version by exploiting theories\nof explanations, intelligent interfaces, and Y AI. In particular, we are not interested\nin the task of generating verbatim\n8questions for quizzes or exercises as in Wang et\nal. (2022 ); Shimmei and Matsuda ( 2022 ); Campenhout et al. ( 2021a ,b). Instead we\npursue the idea that questions (even non-verbatim ones) can be a practical criterion to\norganize and categorize the content of explanations. Moreover, instead of considering\nany question as a suitable candidate for this task, we empirically show that some ques-\ntions are more useful than others and that the best questions for explanatory overviewsare neither too generic nor too speciﬁc.\nBackground\nThis section aims to provide enough background information for the reader to under-\nstand what an explanation is according to Ordinary Language Philosophy and the\nconsequent theory of Y AI.\n7Intelligent textbooks extend regular textbooks by integrating machine-manipulable knowledge (Wang et\nal.,2021 ).\n8The verbatim question is a question for which an answer can be identiﬁed in a related instructional text\n(i.e., source text) (Shimmei & Matsuda, 2022 ).\n123\n\n--- Page 7 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 993\nExplanations According to Ordinary Language Philosophy\nThe concept of explanation in philosophy9began to have a more precise role in the\n20th century with the growth and development of the philosophy of science. The\npublication by Hempel and Oppenheim ( 1948 ) of their “Studies in the Logic of\nExplanation” gave rise to what is considered the ﬁrst theory of explanations: thedeductive-nomological model. Sometime later, this ﬁrst model came to be considered\nfatally ﬂawed (Bromberger, 1966 ; Salmon, 1984 ). Indeed, Hempel’s epistemic the-\nory of explanations is not empiricist: it is concerned (mistakenly) only with logicalform, so an explanation can be such regardless of the actual processes and entities\nconceptually required to understand it.\nSeveral more modern and competing theories of explanation have resulted from\nthis criticism (Mayes, 2001 ). Some of these theories, for instance, those proposed by\nSalmon ( 1984 ) and van Fraassen ( 1980 ), take a scientiﬁc approach, framing explana-\ntions purely as answers to why questions. These theories represent a theoretical and\nlargely scientiﬁc interpretation of the process of explanation.\nOn the other hand, other theorists have taken a more grounded approach to the\nidea of explanations. These are grounded in the practicalities of how people perform\nexplanations in everyday life (Mayes, 2001 ). An exemplar of this approach is the\ntheory proposed by Achinstein ( 1983 ). His theory, which is ﬁrmly rooted in Ordinary\nLanguage Philosophy, underscores the communicative or linguistic aspect of an expla-\nnation. It highlights the importance of an explanation’s role in fostering understanding\nbetween individuals by answering questions.\nIn particular, according to Achinstein’s theory, explaining is an illocutionary act\nborn of a clear intention to produce new understandings in an explainee by providing\na correct content-giving answer to an open-ended question. According to this view,answering by “ﬁlling in the blanks” of a pre-deﬁned answer template, as with most\none-size-ﬁts-all approaches, prevents answering from being explanatory since it lacks\nthisillocutionary purpose.\nDespite this deﬁnition, illocution seems too abstract to implement in an actual\nsoftware application. Nonetheless, recent efforts towards the automated generation of\nexplanations (Sovrano & Vitali, 2021 ,2022b ), have shown that it may be possible\nto deﬁne illocution in a more “computer-friendly” way. Indeed, as stated by Sovrano\nand Vitali ( 2021 ), illocution in explaining involves informed and pertinent answers\nnot just to the main question but also to other questions that are implicitly relevant to\nthe explanations and the explainee. These questions can be understood as instances\nof archetypes such as why ,why not ,how ,what for ,what if ,what ,who ,\nwhen ,where ,how much ,e t c .\nDeﬁnition 1 (Illocution in Explaining) Explaining is an illocutionary act that provides\nanswers to an explicit question on some topic along with answers to several other\nimplicit or unformulated questions deemed necessary for the explainee to understand\nthe topic properly. Sometimes these implicit questions can be inferred through a thor-\nough analysis of the explainee’s background knowledge, history, and objectives, also\n9One of the ﬁrst known philosophers to work on the concept of explanation was Aristotle with his theory\nof causation (Stein, 2011 ).\n123\n\n--- Page 8 ---\n994 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nconsidering Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs). However, in the most generic case,\nno assumption can be made about the explainee’s knowledge and objectives. The only\nimplicit questions that can then be exploited for illocution are the most generic ones,\ncalled archetypal questions .\nFor example, if someone asks “How are you doing?”, an answer like “I am good”\nwould not be considered an explanation. By contrast, a different answer, such as “I\nam happy because I just got a paper accepted at this important venue, and [...]” would\ngenerally be considered an explanation because it answers other archetypal questions\nalong with the main question.\nDeﬁnition 2 (Archetypal Question) An archetypal question is an archetype applied\non a speciﬁc aspect of the explanandum. Examples of archetypes are the interrogative\nparticles (e.g., why ,how ,what ,who ,when ,where ), or their derivatives (e.g.,\nwhy not ,what for ,what if ,how much ), or also more complex interrogative\nformulas (e.g., what reason ,what cause ,what effect ). Accordingly, the\nsame archetypal question may be rewritten in several different ways, as “why” can berewritten in “what is the reason” or “what is the cause”.\nArchetypal Questions in Linguistic Theories\nCasting the semantic annotations of individual propositions as narrating an archetypal\nquestion-answer pair recently gained increasing attention in computational linguistics(He et al., 2015 ; FitzGerald et al., 2018 ; Michael et al., 2018 ; Pyatkin et al., 2020 ). In\nparticular, the main archetypes coming from Abstract Meaning Representation theory\n(Michael et al., 2018 )a r e :what ,who ,how ,where ,when ,which ,whose ,why .W e\nrefer to these archetypes as the primary ones because they consist only of interrogative\nparticles.\nOn the other hand, the main archetypes coming from PDTB-style discourse theory\n(Pyatkin et al., 2020 ) (also called secondary archetypes because they make use of\ntheprimary archetypes )a r e :in what manner ,what is the reason ,what\nis the result ,what is an example ,after what ,while what ,in\nwhat case ,despite what ,what is contrasted with ,before\nwhat ,since when ,what is similar ,until when ,instead of\nwhat ,what is an alternative ,except when ,unless what .\nAlthough many more archetypes could be devised (e.g., where to orwho by ),\nwe believe that the list of questions we provided earlier is already rich enough to be\ngenerally representative, whereas more speciﬁc questions can always be framed by\nusing the interrogative particles we considered (e.g., why ,what ).Primary archetypes\ncan be used to represent any fact and abstract meaning (Bos, 2016 ). In contrast, the\nsecondary archetypes can cover all the discourse relations between them (at least\naccording to the PDTB theory).\n123\n\n--- Page 9 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 995\nHow to Measure the Degree of Explainability\nDegree of Explainability (DoX) is a model-agnostic approach and metric, proposed by\nSovrano and Vitali ( 2022c ), toobjectively evaluate explainability. It builds on Achin-\nstein’s theory of explanations and the interpretation of illocution given by Sovrano\nand Vitali ( 2022b ). DoX can quantify the degree of explainability of a corpus of texts\nby estimating how adequately that corpus could be used to answer in an illocutionary\nway an arbitrary set of archetypal questions about the explanandum.\nIn other words, Sovrano and Vitali ( 2022c ) show how the degree of explainability\nof information depends on the number of archetypal questions to which it can ade-\nquately answer. In practice, DoX scores are computed by measuring and aggregating\nthepertinence with which a snippet of text can answer a (pre-deﬁned) set of archety-\npal questions. Speciﬁcally, pertinence scores are obtained employing pre-trained deep\nlanguage models for general-purpose answer retrieval (Karpukhin et al., 2020 ;B o w -\nman et al., 2015 ) applied to a particular graph of triplets automatically extracted from\ntext to facilitate this type of information retrieval.\nExplanatory Artificial Intelligence\nAn Explanatory AI (Y AI) is an artiﬁcial intelligence program designed to gener-\nate user-centered, interactive explanations out of (possibly extensive) collections of\nexplainable information (Sovrano & Vitali, 2022a ). An example of Y AI based on\nAchinstein’s theory of explanation is Y AI4Hu10(Sovrano & Vitali, 2021 ,2022b ).\nY AI4Hu is a fully automatic explanatory tool that explains (pre-existing) doc-\numentation about an AI-based system. In particular, the textual content of such\ndocumentation is algorithmically reorganized and represented as a special hypergraphwhere information can be either explored through overviewing or searched via open-\nended questioning . On the one hand, open-ended questioning can be performed by\nasking open-ended questions in English through a search box that uses the knowledgegraph for efﬁcient answer retrieval.\nOn the other hand, overviewing can be performed iteratively from an initial expla-\nnation by clicking on automatically annotated words for which more information isneeded. In particular, annotated words are visible because they have a unique format\nthat makes them easy to recognize. After clicking on an annotation, a modal window\nopens (see Fig. 1), showing a navigation bar of tabs containing explanatory overviews\nof the clicked annotated words. The information shown in the overview is as follows:\n•A short description of the explained word (if available).\n•The list of other words that are taxonomically connected.\n•A list of pre-deﬁned archetypal questions (e.g., why is this aspect/concept impor-\ntant, what is this aspect/concept, etc.) and their respective answers ordered by esti-\nmated pertinence (see section “ Intelligent Explanation Generator: An Algorithm\n10Y AI4Hu stands for Y AI for Humans. Examples of Y AI for reinforcement learning agents are discussed\nby Sovrano et al. ( 2022 ).\n123\n\n--- Page 10 ---\n996 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nfor the Identiﬁcation of Pedagogically Useful Questions from Textbooks ”f o ra\ndeﬁnition of pertinence).\nYAI4Edu:aYAIforImprovingtheExplanatoryPowerofanIntelligent\nTextbook\nThe beneﬁt of answering questions for learning has been shown in many studies\n(Rivers, 2021 ; Pan & Rickard, 2018 ), further supporting the assertion that explaining\nis akin to question-answering and that organizing contents on a question-answer base\nmight be beneﬁcial for the explainee. However, creating questions with proper detailthat effectively helps students’ learning usually requires experience and extensive\nefforts (Shimmei & Matsuda, 2022 ).\nFor this reason, with the present work, we propose Y AI4Edu (pipeline shown in\nFig. 2), an extension of Y AI4Hu (see section “ Explanatory Artiﬁcial Intelligence ”) to\nautomatically transform static educative e-books (in PDF, XML or HTML format) into\ninteractive intelligent textbooks by increasing their explanatory power. Similarly toY AI4Hu, Y AI4Edu uses open-ended questioning andoverviewing as main mechanisms\nfor producing explanations. More speciﬁcally, interaction is given by: i)word glosses\nthat can be clicked to open an overview ;ii)a special kind of search box that allows\nthe reader to get answers to any open-ended English question.\nIn particular, we exploit Achinstein’s theory of explanations to reorganize, on-\ndemand, the contents of a textbook and connect it with external integrative resources(e.g., an encyclopedia) to provide the user with more useful explanations. We build a\nnovel heuristic to identify and anticipate the most useful implicit questions an explainee\nFig. 2 Simpliﬁed Flow Diagram of YAI4Edu. This diagram shows the main components of Y AI4Edu.\nAs in Y AI4Hu, the user can ask questions and get overviews. However, differently, Y AI4Edu uses a new\ncomponent (i.e., the “Intelligent Explanation Generator”) for generating overviews, as described in section\n“Intelligent Explanation Generator: An Algorithm for the Identiﬁcation of Pedagogically Useful Questions\nfrom Textbooks ”\n123\n\n--- Page 11 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 997\nmight have about a textbook, organizing information accordingly. Indeed, according\nto theory (see section “ Explanations According to Ordinary Language Philosophy ”),\nwhat makes an Explanatory AI good at explaining is its ability to identify implicit andrelevant questions to answer, i.e., its illocutionary power .\nWe developed an algorithm capable of automatically extracting questions from\na textbook and identifying those that are neither too detailed (because they wouldotherwise only be answered in a minor part of the textbook) nor too general (because\nthey would be answered inaccurately in the more detailed textual content). We did it\nby starting from the hypothesis that the most useful implicit questions a user may haveabout a collection of texts are those best answered by the whole collection.\nSuppose it is possible to quantify the explanatory power of a collection of\nexplainable texts (i.e., through DoX; see section “ How to Measure the Degree of\nExplainability ”) and organize it accordingly by prioritizing the most explanatory con-\ntents (i.e., those with the highest DoX scores) over the others. In that case, it is also\npossible to identify which texts are the most explained within a corpus of documentsand, therefore, the most useful questions to ask about the textbook. More speciﬁcally,\nfor Y AI4Edu, we developed several AI-based mechanisms that improve over the base-\nline Y AI4Hu algorithm producing more pedagogically useful explanations via:\n•intelligent overviewing (an example of overview is shown in Fig. 3), by auto-\nmatically extracting the most useful questions that the textbook (or the support\nmaterial) is answering;\n•smart annotation generation, through the automatic identiﬁcation of a glossary of\nwords explained by the textbook’s contents.\nIn the following subsections, we will describe the technical details behind these\nnew mechanisms and brieﬂy summarize how the answer retrieval algorithm works.\nWe also release the source code of Y AI4Edu\n11and the anonymized data collected\nto evaluate it (see section “ Experiment ”) under MIT license at https://github.com/\nFrancesco-Sovrano/Y AI4Edu .\nAutomated Question Extraction for Intelligent Overviewing\nAccording to theory, illocution in explaining involves informed and pertinent answer-\ning questions, implicitly relevant to the explanations and the explainee, understood\nas instances of archetypes. In section “ Archetypal Questions in Linguistic Theories ”,\nwe presented different types of these archetypal questions identiﬁed by foundationallinguistic theories.\nSpeciﬁcally, the secondary archetypes coming from discourse theory (Pyatkin et al.,\n2020 ) are meant to capture how Elementary Discourse Units (EDUs)\n12are connected.\nIn contrast, the primary archetypes coming from Abstract Meaning Representation\ntheory13(Michael et al., 2018 ) are meant to capture the informative components within\n11We cannot release the textbook excerpts (Brostoff & Sinsheimer, 2013 ) because they are copyrighted.\n12The smallest unit of coherent text that expresses a complete or partial discourse relation.\n13A semantic formalism that represents the meaning of natural language sentences as rooted, directed, and\nlabeled graphs.\n123\n\n--- Page 12 ---\n998 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nFig. 3 Flow Diagram of the Intelligent Explanation Generator. This diagram shows how an explainee\ncan obtain an intelligent overview. First, the user decides which aspect of the explanandum to overview(i.e., by clicking on an annotated word available on the screen). Then the system extracts an explanation\nfrom the textbook or any other collection of texts (e.g., other textbooks, an encyclopedia) by using an AI\nfor question extraction and an AI for answer retrieval as described in section “ Answer Retrieval ”\nthe EDUs by possibly supporting answering basic questions such as “ who didwhat\ntowhom ,when orwhere ”. For example, from the sentence, “ The existence and\nvalidity of a contract, or any term of a contract, shall be determined by the law which\nwould govern it under this regulation if the contract or term were valid, ” it is possible\nto extract the following discourse relation14about contingency: “In what case would\nthe law govern under this regulation? If the contract or term were valid, ” and the\nfollowing Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR) question-answer: “By what is the\nexistence and validity of a contract determined? By the law that would govern it underthis regulation if the contract or clause were valid.”\nIn particular, the discourse-based and AMR-based archetypal questions we need for\nY AI4Edu are extracted from sentences and paragraphs through a deep language modelbased on T5\n15(Raffel et al., 2020 ), pre-trained on a multi-task mixture of unsupervised\nand supervised tasks.\nSince vanilla T5 is not trained to extract discourse-based and AMR-based questions,\nwe had to ﬁne-tune T5 on some public datasets designed for this task. These datasets are\nQAMR (Michael et al., 2018 ) for extracting AMR-based questions and QADiscourse\n(Pyatkin et al., 2020 ) for discourse-based questions.\nMost importantly, the QAMR and QADiscourse datasets are unrelated to any of\nthe textbooks we will consider (see section “ Case Study: A Textbook for Teaching\n14A discourse relation identiﬁes two EDUs: the ﬁrst one is encoded in the question, the second one in the\nanswer.\n15T5 is an encoder-decoder model based on the assumption that all Natural Language Processing problems\ncan be converted in a text-to-text problem.\n123\n\n--- Page 13 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 999\nHow to Write Legal Memoranda ”) for evaluating Y AI4Edu. In particular, they do not\ncontain any legal document or snippet of text written in legalese. In other words, we\ndo not reﬁne T5 on legal texts but instead train it on spoken English, given the highdata availability. Therefore, training T5 the way we do does not imply any legal ﬁne-\ntuning. Legal ﬁne-tuning would require the costly extraction of a dataset of AMR-\nand discourse-based questions from legal texts, as well as ad-hoc adaptations of thetheories of discourse and abstract meaning representation to legalese.\nIn particular, the QAMR dataset is made of 107,880 different questions (and\nanswers), while the QADiscourse dataset is made of 16,613 different questions (andanswers), as described in section “ Archetypal Questions in Linguistic Theories ”. The\ntwo considered datasets are tuples of <s,q,a>, where sis a source sentence, qis a\nquestion implicitly expressed in s, and ais an answer expressed in s. T5 is ﬁne-tuned\nto tackle at once the following four tasks per dataset:\n•extract agiven sandq,\n•extract qgiven sanda,\n•extract all the possible qgiven s,\n•extract all the possible agiven s.\nSpeciﬁcally, we ﬁne-tuned the T5 model on QAMR and QADiscourse for ﬁve\nepochs.\n16The objective of the ﬁne-tuning was to minimize a loss function measuring\nthe difference between the expected output and the output given by T5. A mathematical\ndeﬁnition of such a loss function is given by Raffel et al. ( 2020 ).\nAt the end of the training, the average loss was 0 .4098, meaning that our ﬁne-\ntuned T5 model cannot perfectly extract AMRs or EDUs from the text composing the\ntraining set. On the one hand, this is a good thing because it is likely that the model did\nnot over-ﬁt the training set. On the other hand, this clearly indicates that the questionsextracted by our T5 model can be imperfect, containing errors that could propagate to\nthe Intelligent Explanation Generator.\nIntelligent Explanation Generator: An Algorithm for the Identification\nof Pedagogically Useful Questions from Textbooks\nAssuming that the goal of a textbook is to explain something to the reader, and based on\nthe theoretical understandings expressed in section “ Explanations According to Ordi-\nnary Language Philosophy ”, our Y AI4Edu is designed around the idea that organizing\nthe explanatory space (i.e., the space of all possible bits of explanation) as clusters of\narchetypal questions and answers is beneﬁcial for an explainee. In particular, Y AI4Edu\nuses the following predeﬁned interactions inherited from Y AI4Hu to allow the user toexplore this explanatory space:\n•Open-ended Question-Answering: the user writes a question and receives one or\nmore relevant answers.\n•Aspect Overviewing: the user selects an aspect of the explanandum (i.e., contained\nin an answer) and receives as an explanation a set of relevant archetypal answers\n16An epoch is one complete cycle through the entire training dataset.\n123\n\n--- Page 14 ---\n1000 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\ninvolving different aspects that can be explored as well. Archetypal answers can\nalso be expanded, increasing the level of detail.\nAs hypothesized (cf. Hypothesis 1), archetypal questions that are too generic are\nunlikely to represent the explanatory goals of a sufﬁciently complex and elaborated col-\nlection of texts. The archetypal questions originally used by Y AI4Hu for overviewing\nare too generic and predeﬁned, frequently not adhering to the explanatory requirements\nof the overview. Therefore, considering the need for Y AI4Edu to be pedagogically\nhelpful, we designed a novel theoretically grounded AI algorithm to quantify howmuch an archetypal question is likely to represent the explanatory goals of a collec-\ntion of texts. We called this algorithm the Intelligent Explanation Generator.\nMore speciﬁcally, instead of using predeﬁned generic archetypal questions for our\nIntelligent Explanation Generator, we also consider more domain-speciﬁc ones auto-\nmatically extracted from the knowledge graph through the AI for question-answerextraction. In particular, once an explanandum is chosen, the workﬂow of the Intelli-\ngent Explanation Generator consists of the following steps (also shown in Fig. 3).\n•Step 1: the algorithm computes the DoX (see section “ How to Measure the Degree\nof Explainability ”) of all snippets of text about a given explanandum (i.e., an aspect\nto overview), ﬁnding the top ksnippets with the highest DoX and also ﬁnding the\narchetypal questions extracted from them by the algorithm described in section\n“Automated Question Extraction for Intelligent Overviewing ”;\n•Step 2: for each question selected in the previous step, the algorithm identiﬁes a set\nof pertinent answers within the text snippets. An answer is said to be pertinent to\na question when its pertinence score\n17is greater than a given pertinence threshold\np;\n•Step 3: the algorithm ﬁlters the pertinent answers, keeping the best qquestions\nandaanswers by executing the following sub-steps: i)questions that are too long\nare removed, i.e., questions whose length (without considering the length of the\nexplanandum label) exceeds a threshold L;ii)if a question has some grammatical\nerror, it is automatically corrected via Gramformer18, a deep neural network; iii)\nquestions that are too similar are removed,19prioritizing the questions extracted\nfrom the most explanatory snippets (i.e., those with the highest DoX) and the\nshortest questions; iv)answers that are too short or too long are removed; v)the\nquestions with no valid answers are removed; vi)the answers that could be assigned\nto several questions are given to the question with the highest estimated pertinence;\nvii)for each question, only the aanswers with the highest pertinence score are\nkept; viii) the questions are sorted by the decreasing pertinence of the ﬁrst answer,\nand only the top qquestions are kept.\nImportantly, step 1 is performed before step 2 to reduce the asymptotic time com-\nplexity of step 2. Selecting the questions best answered by the corpus (step 2) has\n17Pertinence scores are numbers in [0,1]computed by measuring the cosine similarity between vectorial\nrepresentations of question and answer obtained through deep neural networks specialized for answer\nretrieval.\n18https://github.com/PrithivirajDamodaran/Gramformer\n19A question is said to be similar to another when its similarity score is above a given threshold s. Similarity\nscores are calculated like pertinence scores.\n123\n\n--- Page 15 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1001\nan asymptotic complexity O(|Qc|·|S|)that grows with the number of questions\nextracted from the snippets of text, where Qis the set of questions about an aspect c\nto be explained and Sis the set of snippets of text. Therefore, this complexity in the\nworst-case scenario (without step 1) can be quadratic in the size of the textbook or\ncollection of texts, i.e., O(|S|2).\nRather than having a quadratic complexity, a computationally simpler approach can\nperform an initial ﬁltering procedure to consider only those questions coming from\nthe paragraphs with the highest DoX (as step 1 does), thus converting |Qc|into a\nconstant number independent from |S|. Hence, considering that computing the DoX\nof|S|snippets of text has an asymptotic time complexity equal to O(|S|), it follows\nthat step 1 reduces the complexity of the Intelligent Explanation Generator to O(|S|).\nIf Hypothesis 1is true, then the Intelligent Explanation Generator will be able to\nproduce better and more satisfying explanation overviews (than the baseline Y AI4Hu).\nThis is because it will be able to anticipate, in a sense, implicit questions the user may\nhave.\nNot all words, though, require an overview. That is because, in practice, only a tiny\nfraction of the words in a text are helpful to explain. Indeed, many words have common-\nsense meanings (e.g., the words: “and”, “ﬁrst”, “ﬁgure”) and, therefore, should not be\nexplained. Otherwise, the explainee might be overwhelmed by largely redundant and\npointless information that would only hinder the usability of the Y AI.\nTo intelligently avoid jotting down unnecessary words, our smart annotation mecha-\nnism only annotates those concepts and words that can be explained by (the knowledge\ngraph extracted from) the textbook and other supplementary texts. More speciﬁcally, tounderstand whether a word should be annotated, the algorithm executes the following\ninstructions:\n•It checks whether the word is a stop word (i.e., a commonly used word such as\n“and” or “or”). If so, the word is not annotated.\n•If the word is not a stop word, the algorithm generates its overview through the\nIntelligent Explanation Generator. Then, it computes the cumulative pertinence\nscore of the answers composing the overview; if greater than a given threshold, it\nannotates the word.\nThis annotation mechanism is intended to remove noisy annotations and distractors\nso that the reader can focus only on the most central and well-explained concepts.\nMoreover, the cumulative pertinence score, used to understand whether a word shouldbe annotated, can also be used to understand the topics in the corpus of documents\nthat are better explained.\nConsequently, the smart annotation mechanism and the Intelligent Explanation\nGenerator are integral components of the Y AI4Edu system. Notably, the Intelli-\ngent Explanation Generator tackles the challenge of selecting questions that balancebetween being too general or overly speciﬁc through the abovementioned ﬁltering and\nreﬁnement steps. By incorporating these steps, the Intelligent Explanation Generator\nprioritizes questions derived from the most informative excerpts, favors concise ques-tions, and ﬁlters out excessively similar ones. This process aims to identify questions\nthat align well with the explanatory objectives of the text collection, as discussed in\nsection “ Discussion: Results and Limitations ”.\n123\n\n--- Page 16 ---\n1002 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nAnswer Retrieval\nSimilarly to Y AI4Hu, Y AI4Edu uses a pipeline of AI algorithms to extract a particular\ngraph of knowledge from a collection of texts that an information retrieval system can\nexploit to answer a given question. In particular, a dependency parser detects all the\npossible grammatical clauses20within the collection of texts. Each such clause stands\nfor an edge of the knowledge graph.\nIn practice, these clauses are represented as combinations of subjects, templates, and\nobjects/nominal modiﬁers.21We refer to these as template-triplets. Speciﬁcally, tem-\nplates consist of an ordered token sequence connecting subjects and objects/modiﬁers\nin a clause. In these templates, the subjects and the objects/modiﬁers are represented\nby the placeholders “ {subj}/prime/primeand “{obj}/prime/prime, respectively. The resulting template-triplets\nare a sort of function where the predicate is the body, and the object/modiﬁer and the\nsubject are the parameters.\nObtaining a natural language representation of these template-triplets involves\nreplacing the instances of the parameters in the body. This natural language representa-\ntion is then used as a possible answer for retrieval by measuring the similarity betweenits embedding and the embedding of a question. An example (taken from the case\nstudy discussed in section “ Case Study: A Textbook for Teaching How to Write Legal\nMemoranda ”) of template-triple is:\n•Subject: “A constitution”\n•Template: “ {subj}\n/prime/primespeciﬁcally deﬁnes, empowers, and imposes {obj}on each\npart of the governmental structure\n•Object: “limits”\nThe resulting knowledge graph is imperfect because of the adopted extraction proce-\ndure. It may contain mistakes caused by wrongly identiﬁed grammatical dependencies\nor other issues. However, the likelihood of such errors occurring is relatively low. This\nis primarily attributed to the high accuracy of the model we used for part-of-speech\ntagging.22\nTo increase the interoperability of the extracted knowledge graph with external\nresources, we formatted it as an RDF23graph. In particular, RDF has features that\nfacilitate data merging even if the underlying schemas differ. To format a graph of\ntemplate triplets in an RDF graph, we performed the following steps:\n20A typical clause consists of a subject and a syntactic predicate, the latter typically a verb phrase composed\nof a verb with any objects and other modiﬁers.\n21A nominal modiﬁer is a noun (or noun phrase) functioning as a non-core (oblique) argument or adjunct.\n22Known as the “en_core_web_md” model, it boasts an accuracy score of 0.97. More details about this\nmodel can be found at https://spacy.io/models/en .\n23RDF is a standard model for data interchange on the Web (Allemang and Hendler, 2011 ).\n123\n\n--- Page 17 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1003\n•We assigned a URI24to every node (i.e., subject and object) and edge (i.e., tem-\nplate) of the graph by lemmatizing the associated text. We assigned an RDFS25\nlabel to each URI corresponding to the associated text.\n•We added special triplets to keep track of the sources from which the template-\ntriplets were extracted so that each node and edge can refer to its source document\nor paragraph.\n•We added sub-class relations between composite concepts (syntagms) and the\nsimplest concepts (if any) composing the syntagm. For instance, “ contractual\nobligation ” is a sub-class of “ obligation ”. Therefore, we employ the RDFS predi-\ncate “{subj}rdfs:subClassOf {obj}/prime/primeas a template for the triplet that signiﬁes\nthis sub-class relationship.\nFor more technical details about how we performed all the steps mentioned above to\nconvert the template-triplets into an RDF graph, please refer to Sovrano et al. ( 2020 )\nor the source code of Y AI4Edu.\nFinally, the algorithm to retrieve answers from the extracted knowledge graph\nis based on the following steps. Let Cbe the set of concepts in a question q,\nm=<s,t,o>be a template-triplet, u=t(s,o)be the natural language representa-\ntion of m, also called an information unit , and zbe its source paragraph. DiscoLQA\nretrieves answers by ﬁnding the most similar concepts to Cwithin the knowledge\ngraph, retrieving all their related template-triplets m(including those of the sub-\nclasses), and selecting, among the natural language representations uof the retrieved\ntemplate-triplets, those that are likely to answer q. The likelihood of uanswering qis\nestimated by computing the cosine similarity between its contextualized embedding\n<u,z>and the embedding of q.I f <u,z>is similar enough to q, then zis said to\nanswer q.\nThe embeddings of <u,z>andqare obtained through a deep language model\nspecialized in answer retrieval pre-trained in ordinary English to associate similar\nvectorial representations to a question and its correct answers. The pre-trained deeplanguage model we employed in implementing Y AI4Edu is a variation of MiniLM\n(Wang et al., 2021 ) published by Reimers and Gurevych ( 2019 ).\nCaseStudy:ATextbookforTeachingHowtoWriteLegalMemoranda\nTo showcase and evaluate Y AI4Edu, we considered a case study in the intersection\nbetween AI and law. In particular, we applied Y AI4Edu to the following materialexplaining, among other things, how to write a legal memorandum in a U.S. legal\ncontext for a veteran’s PTSD disability claim:\n24A URI, or Uniform Resource Identiﬁer, is a string of characters that provides a simple and extensible\nmeans for identifying a resource on the Internet.\n25RDFS, or RDF Schema, is a language used for creating vocabularies in the semantic web, allowing for\nthe description of classes, properties, and their interrelationships.\n123\n\n--- Page 18 ---\n1004 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\n•22 pages excerpted from the textbook “ United States Legal Language and Culture:\nAn Introduction to the U.S. Common Law System ” (Brostoff & Sinsheimer, 2013\npp. 47-60, 93-96, 101-103, 131-132).26\n•5,407 open access web pages about concepts related to the U.S. legal system\ncoming from the encyclopedia of the Legal Information Institute of the Cornell\nLaw School27(5,406 web pages) and Wikipedia28(1 web page).\n•11,198 legal cases on PTSD disability claims taken from the ofﬁcial website of\nthe Board of Veterans’ Appeals (BV A).29\nAltogether, the included material, comprising more than 16,000 documents, com-\nplements the primary teaching material on which Y AI4Edu focuses, i.e., the excerpts\nof the selected textbook. In particular, the textbook is used in “Applied Legal Ana-lytics and AI,”\n30an interdisciplinary course at the University of Pittsburgh, co-taught\nby instructors from the University of Pittsburgh School of Law and Carnegie Mel-\nlon University’s Language Technologies Institute. It provides “a hands-on practicalintroduction to the ﬁelds of artiﬁcial intelligence, machine learning, and natural lan-\nguage processing as they are being applied to support the work of legal professionals,\nresearchers, and administrators.”\nTeaching how to write a legal memorandum for the U.S. legal system is a course\nobjective, in part, because in a common law system, such as the American one, the\nuse of AI assists practitioners in efﬁciently retrieving legal cases for constructing\narguments (Phelps & Ashley, 2022 ). Alegal memorandum is an organized document\nthat summarizes relevant laws to support a conclusion on a particular legal issue.Writing it can require legal practitioners to navigate through large databases of cases,\ni.e., to retrieve the deﬁnitions of technical and speciﬁc concepts or to understand which\nargumentation patterns are most common in a particular context. Indeed, some of thedistinguishing features of legal writing are:\n•Authority: The writer must back up assertions and statements with citations of\nauthority (i.e., precedents and other decided cases).\n•Argument re-use: A more effective memorandum may reuse existing documents\nas templates or argumentation patterns.\n•Formality: The written legal document should be properly formatted according to\nexisting standards.\nHence, legal practitioners may now be required to learn how to efﬁciently and effec-\ntively interact with existing AI-based technological solutions for information retrieval\nto speed up legal writing and to learn the complexities of legal writing. Given the task’s\ncomplexity and the course’s goals, we envisaged that it might be of utmost relevance\nand utility to design and create a tool such as Y AI4Edu that could ease the acquisitionof the necessary knowledge for a student to learn legal writing.\n26We received explicit consent from the copyright holder to use excerpts of this textbook for our experi-\nments and the related scientiﬁc There, an input box for open-\nended questioning and annotated (i.e., underlined) words for overviewing (shown in\nFigs. 4and1) provide the user with interactive elements to obtain intelligent explana-\ntions without breaking the structure of the textbook.\nThe choice of hyper-parameters (i.e., the pertinence threshold por the question sim-\nilarity threshold s; cf. section “ Intelligent Explanation Generator: An Algorithm for the\n123\n\n--- Page 20 ---\n1006 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nFig. 4 Landing page of YAI4Edu applied to the case study.
