In\nparticular, the hyper-parameters chosen for this instance of Y AI4Edu are the following:\ni)number of snippets with the highest DoX to consider k=10;ii)answer pertinence\nthreshold p=.57;iii)maximum overview question length L=50;iv)question sim-\nilarity threshold s=.95;v)minimum and maximum answer length equal to 150 and\n1000; vi)maximum number of questions per overview q=4;vii)maximum number\nof answers per overview question a=2.\nExperiment\nExplanations and explanatory tools may be complex artifacts whose quality depends\non a wide range of different factors (Sovrano et al., 2020 ), including:\n•the quality of the explainable information;\n•the logic used for presenting this information, namely the set of rules employed to\npresent the information in a meaningful and coherent manner, which we refer to\nas the presentation logic ;\n•the quality of the interface.\nIn particular, with this experiment, we are interested in evaluating the presentation\nlogic used by Y AI4Edu for selecting and reorganizing questions and answers into\nexplanations.\n123\n\n--- Page 21 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1007\nSovrano and Vitali ( 2022a ) have already demonstrated, with several examples and\nexperiments, a user-centered Y AI is better than one-size-ﬁts-all and static explanations.\nIn this experiment, instead of evaluating the whole interactive e-book with a rathertime-consuming test, we focused on evaluating the one feature of Y AI4Edu that should\nbe responsible for improving the explanatory power of the e-book: the Intelligent\nExplanation Generator. According to theory (see section “ Explanations According to\nOrdinary Language Philosophy ”), what makes a Y AI good at explaining is its ability\nto identify implicit and relevant questions to answer, i.e., its illocutionary power.\nTherefore, in this experiment (which is a within-subjects user study), we directly\nask real students to rate explanations (on a scale of 0 to 5 stars) for how well they\nadequately explain a given topic, as shown in Fig. 5. We do it to understand the extent\nto which the explanations generated by our Intelligent Explanation Generator aresatisfactory and whether they are better than baseline explanatory strategies, as stated\nby Hypothesis 1. More details about the experiment can be found in Appendix A.\nThe two baselines against which the Intelligent Explanation Generator is compared\nare variants of the same. They use the same sequence of steps to generate their expla-\nnations, apart from the step responsible for selecting the explanatory questions, which\nis different. These two baselines are:\n•An explainer that uses randomly chosen questions to organize the contents of an\noverview . This explainer randomly selects q=4 questions, setting the maximum\nquestion length to L=∞ and using a lower answer pertinence threshold p=.3\n(and not p=.57 as in the Intelligent Explanation Generator). This prevents the\nnumber of questions from diminishing too much due to not ﬁnding sufﬁciently\nrelevant answers.\nFig. 5 Screenshot of the web application used during the experiment. This ﬁgure shows what the\nparticipants in the user study see during the experiment\n123\n\n--- Page 22 ---\n1008 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\n•Y AI4Hu’s generic overview generator, which instead employs pre-deﬁned and\nvery generic archetypal questions, using the same four questions (i.e., what is it,\nhow is it,where is it and why ) for each topic.\nGiven the case study at hand (see section “ Case Study: A Textbook for Teaching\nHow to Write Legal Memoranda ”), the main objective of the explanatory contents is\nto explain how to write a legal memorandum appropriate for the U.S. legal system and\na veteran’s PTSD disability claim. The excerpts of the considered textbook are aboutlegal writing, while the collection of legal cases of the BV A are about PTSD disability\nclaims. Thus, we can say that some of the goals of the Y AI for this case study are to\nexplain: i)what is the proper form of a legal memorandum; ii)what sections should be\nincluded in a legal memorandum; iii)what legal standard does a veteran need to satisfy\nfor a disability claim; iv)what are the elements of the legal standard a veteran needs\nto satisfy for a disability claim; v)what issues do the required elements of a disability\nclaim raise; and vi)what kinds of legal arguments are appropriate for resolving such\nissues.\nConsidering that we need an experiment lasting a maximum of 10 minutes (in order\nto minimize costs: each participant cannot be paid less than 6£ per hour on Proliﬁc),\nwe chose the following three topics for evaluating the explainers:\n•Topic 1: The proper form of a legal memorandum.\n•Topic 2: The effects of a disability.\n•Topic 3: The elements of the legal standard a veteran needs to satisfy for a PTSD\ndisability claim.\nIn particular, the explanations for the ﬁrst two topics are extracted from the textbook\nand web pages (the ﬁrst is better explained by the textbook, the second by the web\npages). In contrast, the explanations for the third topic are extracted from legal cases.For more details about the explanations used in the experiment, see Table 2.\nDiscussion:ResultsandLimitations\nThrough Proliﬁc, we gathered 130 participants, all students aged between 19 and 38.\n28 participants were discarded for the reasons stated in Appendix A. Eventually, 102\nvalid submissions were collected.\nThe results (shown in Fig. 6) indicate that the intelligent explainer received the\nhighest rates, followed by the generic one; the worst was the random explainer. To\nfurther validate the results and verify that the improvements of the intelligent explainer\nover the baselines are statistically signiﬁcant, we performed one-sided Mann-Whitney\nU-tests (a non-parametric version of the t-test for independent samples) whose results\nare summarized in Fig. 6. Results clearly show that, assuming P<.05 is enough\nto assert statistical signiﬁcance, the intelligent explainer is superior to the baselines\nregarding perceived explanatory power in all three chosen topics. For more details onstatistical tests, see Appendix B.\nInterestingly, looking at the topics separately, we also have statistical evidence\nshowing that the intelligent explainer is better than the generic and the random\nexplainer for the ﬁrst two topics, but not enough statistical evidence for the last one.\n123\n\n--- Page 23 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1009\nTable 2 Questions used during the experiment. This table shows the questions extracted from the three\nexplainers of the experiment. Speciﬁcally, “intelligent” stands for the Intelligent Explanation Generator,\n“generic” is the Y A4Hu explainer, and “random” is the explainer that uses random questions. Note that an\nexplainer uses fewer than four questions (the maximum) for its explanations whenever it does not ﬁnd fourquestions with relevant answers in the knowledge graph. The sum of the relevance scores of all answers\nthat make up each explanation is reported in the column “Cumulative Relevance”\nTopic Explainer Cumulative\nPertinenceQuestions\nThe proper form of a legal\nmemorandumgeneric 2,81 What\nHow\nWhy\nrandom 3,79 What is the result of a memorandum to\na partner in the same ﬁrm?\nIn what manner is a memorandum of\npoints and authority usually\nmandatory?\nWhat does the memorandum usually\ninclude?\nintelligent 4,61 What is a memorandum in a legal\nsense?\nWhat does a memorandum do?What does the memorandum contain?What will the memorandum predict?\nThe effects of a disability generic 3,47 What\nHowWhy\nrandom 4,92 What is the reason schools must\ndetermine if they have a covereddisability under the Act and if that\ndisability is severe enough?\nWhat can a partial disability be?What is an example of state statutes\nrelating to disability retirement?\nIn what manner can a partial disability\nbe permanent?\nintelligent 5,65 What is Disability Law?\nWhat is disability?What is the result of disability in a\nlegal sense?\nWhat does the disability prevent?\nThe elements of the legal standard a\nveteran needs to satisfy for a PTSD\ndisability claimgeneric 4,58 What\nHow\n123\n\n--- Page 24 ---\n1010 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nTable 2 continued\nTopic Explainer Cumulative\nPertinenceQuestions\nWhy\nWhere\nrandom 4,09 Why is element two met?\nWho is the ﬁrst element of a service\nconnection?\nWho found that the Veteran has met the\nﬁrst two elements of service\nconnection?\nintelligent 5,21 What is the ﬁrst element of a service\nconnection?\nWhat are the elements of service\nconnection?\nWhat are elements of the legal standard\na veteran needs to satisfy for a PTSDdisability claim?\nWhat is an element of appeal?\nThis may be because the variance of the cumulative pertinence of the explanations\nabout the third topic (see Table 2) is too low. Alternatively (and more likely), this may\nalso be because the explanations about the last topic were extracted from a corpus of\nlegal cases rather than textbooks or other educational contents as the other two, thus\nbeing harder to explain. In particular, this intuition is corroborated by the statistics ofTable 1, where one can see that the legal cases have a ratio of explained concepts close\nto 0.32%. In contrast, the textbook and web pages have 2.96% (10 times greater). This\ndifference in explainability between the two documents corpora may impact the qual-ity of extracted explanations. Indeed, as pointed out by some qualitative feedback, the\nexplanations extracted from the BV A cases contain too much (unexplained) technical\njargon and too long sentences (e.g., “the ﬁrst topic was easy to understand also the\nsecond one, the problem with the last one it was too long and was not straight to the\npoint.”).\nThis shows that the most useful implicit questions a user may have about a collection\nof texts will likely be those best answered by the whole collection. Furthermore, even\nif the random explanations have a cumulative pertinence score greater than generic\nexplanations (at least for the ﬁrst two topics, as shown in Table 2), they are evalu-\nated as worse explanations nonetheless. This evidence further supports Hypothesis 1,\nshowing that too speciﬁc archetypal questions may be less effective than generic onesat explaining and that intelligently balancing between generality and speciﬁcity is\nneeded, as also suggested by some qualitative feedback:\n•“All of the [random] explanations were OK, but improvement is needed. They lack\na sense of direction. It’s like they go around mountains to prove one single point.\n123\n\n--- Page 25 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1011\nAll [generic] explanations were easy to decode and were straight to the point. All\n[intelligent] explanations were a mixture of ﬁrst and second explanations.”\n•“The [random explanations] proved unsatisfactory for all three topics: the expla-\nnations do not follow a logical order, are incomplete, and often contain incorrect or\nirrelevant elements. The [generic and intelligent explanations] are quite complete.\nThe [generic explanations] seem to ﬁt more practical questions, while [intelli-gent explanations] ﬁt more theoretical ones. I believe [intelligent explanations]\nare preferable for the topic at hand.”\nLimitationsandFutureWork\nOne limitation of our study pertains to its scope, encompassing both the duration\nof the study and the number of participants involved. Speciﬁcally, the study wasconducted over a brief 10-minute period and comprised a relatively small group of\n102 individuals. This restricted scope raises concerns regarding the generalizability of\nour ﬁndings. Furthermore, our research primarily concentrated on participant ratingsand qualitative feedback, without directly measuring changes in learning outcomes.\nAs a result, while our results offer initial insights into the potential applications of\neducational tools like Y AI4Edu, they should be approached with caution. In order tovalidate and expand upon these preliminary ﬁndings, it is necessary to conduct more\ncomprehensive studies over longer time-frames, involving larger and more diverse\nparticipant groups. However, previous research (Sovrano and Vitali, 2022a ) provides\ncompelling evidence supporting the notion that user-centered illocution signiﬁcantly\nenhances the effectiveness of Y AI software, leading to more efﬁcient explanations and\nimproved learning outcomes, as suggested also by qualitative feedback.\nIt is worth noting that even though qualitative feedback was optional, a notable 81%\nof users provided feedback. Interestingly, 19 participants left highly positive feedback\n(e.g., “the explanations were superb and of good quality”) without suggesting any\nimprovement or explaining their rates, unlike the remaining 64 users. Overall, we\nidentiﬁed 6 major suggestions for improvement :\n•Avoid long and redundant explanations : suggested by 32 participants;\n•Avoid or explain legal jargon : 24;\n•Avoid generic or incomplete information : 18;\n•Use simpler questions :9 ;\n•Provide examples when explaining :7 ;\n•Provide better organized and compartmentalized contents :5 .\nThe complaints were primarily about too-long explanations, unexplained legal jar-\ngon, or generic/incomplete information. Some qualitative feedback comments ask for\nmore conciseness, and others for less. Some participants preferred generic explana-\ntions over intelligent ones. Interestingly, one could turn this into a feature if the system\ncould offer users a choice of generic or intelligent explanations.\nThe qualitative feedback was extremely helpful in identifying the main problems\nand limitations of Y AI4Edu and the baselines, pointing to future work. In particular,we believe Y AI4Edu’s smart annotation mechanism can partially mitigate the jargon\n123\n\n--- Page 26 ---\n1012 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\nproblem by explaining it. However, we could not verify this with the experiment\nbecause it was set to take 10 minutes, so intelligent annotations were excluded. See\nAppendix Afor more details on qualitative feedback.\nFeedback has also indicated that Y AI4Edu could signiﬁcantly improve in terms\nof efﬁciently integrating retrieved information into a coherent structure. As it stands,\nexplanations often tend to be lengthy, repetitive, and disjointed. The introduction ofgenerative AI like ChatGPT might serve as a valuable solution to these issues, re-\nelaborating the information retrieved by Y AI4Edu. Indeed, ChatGPT has the potential\nto produce content that is not only concise and coherent but also well-organized. Itcan adeptly avoid or interpret complex (legal) jargon, presenting content in a well-\nstructured and compartmentalized manner. These features could address at least three\nout of the six primary improvement areas identiﬁed in the qualitative feedback. As aresult, the integration of such AI technology could signiﬁcantly enhance the effective-\nness of Y AI4Edu, as shown in Sovrano et al. ( 2023 ).\nIt should be noted, however, that while ChatGPT can complement Y AI4Edu, it\ncannot fully replace it. There are unique challenges associated with using large lan-\nguage models like ChatGPT to generate explanations from input documents, such\nas textbooks. These challenges include memory limitations and the risk of generat-\ning inaccurate or copyrighted content. Unlike ChatGPT, Y AI4Edu primarily relies on\ninformation retrieval technologies, eliminating the need to input the entire contextof the explanation into the language model. This is particularly important also for\nstandard-sized textbooks, where memory constraints can easily become an issue, as\ndiscussed in the study by Sovrano et al. ( 2023 ).\nFuture studies also need to focus on several factors to secure more robust results.\nFirst, we need further investigation into the effectiveness of our random explanations\ngenerator as a baseline. Given the feedback regarding redundant explanations and theneed for better-organized content, exploring sophisticated alternatives like ChatGPT\nmight provide a stronger baseline for comparison with Y AI4Edu.\nSecond, our research did not integrate commonsense and domain-general knowl-\nedge into the Y AI pipeline, making the system highly dependent on well-written,\nlogically coherent texts. This dependency sets a high standard for the source text, poten-\ntially limiting the extensibility of our work. Addressing this concern might be possiblewith the help of large language models, such as ChatGPT, which could potentially excel\nin tasks similar to Y AI4Edu. This holds particularly true for unstructured texts and\nthose not professionally written, offering promising avenues for future research.\nConclusion\nIn this paper, we presented Y AI4Edu, an Explanatory AI for the automatic generationof interactive and adaptive e-books for education. To create Y AI4Edu, we enhanced the\nY AI proposed by Sovrano and Vitali ( 2022b ), making it more explanatory and more\nintelligent through a novel AI, called Intelligent Explanation Generator, for extractingexplanations that are neither too speciﬁc nor too generic.\n123\n\n--- Page 27 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1013\nThe idea behind our work is that explaining is akin to question answering, so the\nmore questions an intelligent textbook can answer, the more it can explain. In other\nwords, the explanatory power of a book can be improved by reorganizing it interac-tively, ﬁrstly to help readers identify the most critical questions to be answered about\nthe textbook, but also to get answers to their questions. In particular, Y AI4Edu uses\nthe Intelligent Explanation Generator, an efﬁcient pipeline for automatic (archetypal)question extraction and answer retrieval, to select these important questions and use\nthem to reorganize the contents of a textbook. This is done following Hypothesis 1\nfor which the most useful questions a user may have about a collection of texts (e.g.,a textbook) are best answered in the collection as a whole.\nWe applied Y AI4Edu to a textbook for teaching how to write legal memoranda\nappropriate for the U.S. legal system and a PTSD disability claim. This was integratedwith 5,406 external web pages from a legal encyclopedia and 11,198 legal cases from\nthe Board of Veterans’ Appeals. Then, to show that our novel strategy for generating\nexplanations is more effective than baseline approaches, we devised a within-subjectsuser study involving more than 100 English-speaking students who evaluated expla-\nnations about three different and relevant topics. The ﬁnal results were in many cases\nstatistically signiﬁcant and always in favor of our Intelligent Explanation Generator,\nsuggesting that Hypothesis 1is true.\nThe impact of our Y AI software pipeline extends to various sectors, including educa-\ntion, professional training, and industry. Within the education sector, our tool enhances\nthe use of textbooks by seamlessly integrating external content, facilitating efﬁcient\nexploration and retrieval of information through answer retrieval mechanisms. In pro-fessional training, it has the potential to elucidate complex concepts and procedures,\nthereby expediting knowledge acquisition, particularly in highly technical domains.\nIn the industrial context, our tool can simplify technical documentation and improvecustomer support, as suggested by Sovrano and Vitali ( 2022b ); Sovrano et al. ( 2023 ).\nLooking ahead, we foresee a notable shift in education with interactive e-books\nand AI-generated content supplementing or replacing traditional textbooks. Thesetools promise personalized, up-to-date learning experiences. Rather than replacing\neducators, these AI tools could augment their capabilities by providing personalized\ninstruction at scale. They could explain basic concepts and answer common questions,thus allowing educators to focus on more complex topics, critical thinking, creativity,\nand personalized guidance.\nAppendixAExperimentDetails\nThe experiment consisted of a 10-minute within-subjects user study where the\nexplanations generated by two baseline explainers and Y AI4Edu were evaluated byEnglish-speaking students assembled with Proliﬁc\n31, an online platform that helps\nrecruit paid participants for online research.\nThrough Proliﬁc, we gathered 130 participants, all students aged between 19 and\n38, each paid £1. 28 of the participants were discarded for the following reasons:\n31https://www.proliﬁc.co\n123\n\n--- Page 28 ---\n1014 Int J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021\n•26 participants were discarded because they were too quick (i.e., they spent less\nthan 4 minutes completing the evaluation of all topics) or they skipped at least one\ntopic (i.e., they spent less than 35 seconds on it without being a legal expert);\n•2 participants were rejected because they reported poor knowledge of written\nEnglish (i.e., A1 or A2) or wrote non-grammatical qualitative feedback.\nEventually, 102 valid submissions were collected.\nOf these 102 participants:\n•46 were males, 52 females, 1 identiﬁed itself as other/non-binary, and three pre-\nferred not to say;\n•81% stated that their written English proﬁciency level is C1 or C2, while 16%\nindicated a B2 level;\n•86% rated their knowledge of the U.S. legal system with a score lower than or\nequal to 3;\n•86 said they are not legal experts;\n•68 reported that they have low or no experience with legal writing, 29 wrote they\nhave some experience, and ﬁve that their experience with legal writing is high.\nParticipants were required to be ﬂuent in English, be resident in English-speaking\ncountries (i.e., USA, UK, Ireland, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa), usea device with a large screen (e.g., a laptop, a desktop computer, a tablet in landscape\nmode), be at least 18 years old, and possess a student status and a minimum approval\nrating of 75% on Proliﬁc.\nMoreover, at the beginning of the study, they were asked to provide the following\ninformation anonymously: age; gender; whether they are legal experts; their proﬁ-\nciency in written English, on a scale of A1 (very low) to C2 (very high); their experiencein legal writing (from none tohigh ); how they would rate their knowledge of the U.S.\nlegal system on a scale of 0 (bad) to 5 (good) stars.\nIt is important to note that during the experiment, for each topic, each participant\ncould compare the explanations generated by all three explainers, provided in random\norder to avoid unwanted biases that might be caused by some explanations being shown\nbefore or after others. Furthermore, using a predeﬁned random seed, the explanationsgenerated by the random explainer were the same for all participants.\nIn the experiment, participants were not informed about the origin of the expla-\nnations they evaluated, speciﬁcally whether they came from random, generic, orintelligent generators, nor were they made aware of the existence of these three dif-\nferent generators. Each explanation was to be evaluated on a 0 to 5-star scale, with\n0 representing “bad” and 5 indicating “good”, as depicted in Fig. 5. Once the testing\nwas completed, participants were also invited to share their qualitative feedback in an\nopen-ended format.\nSome of the most interesting feedback examples are the following:\n•“The more lengthy explanations offer more details and give the reader a greater\nunderstanding but can feel a bit harder to read rather than the [generic explana-tions].”\n•“Dividing the topic into sections is good if the [questions] are relevant and make\nsense. Relatively simple explanations supported by evidence are better, in myopinion.”\n123\n\n--- Page 29 ---\nInt J Artif Intell Educ (2025) 35:987–1021 1015\n•“The longer explanations were more detailed and more understandable. The shorter\ndeﬁnitions were also understandable and compact, but the law should be detailed.\n”\n•“I particularly liked the layout that included ’what, why, how’, as it made the\nexplanations easy to follow. [...] The headings with long sentences lost me before\nI began, and I found it hard to decipher the explanations.”\n•“I would make [explanations] shorter.”\n•“The answers should be less vague and focus more on details.”\n•“The explanations with very long or involved subheadings were difﬁcult to follow.\nOften, when there are large blocks of text, my mind tends to get overwhelmed\n- simply making shorter subheadings and adding more paragraph breaks to the\nexplanations helps with this.”\n•“The answers to the questions could have been more concise, for instance, in\nthe ﬁrst topic on what a memorandum is, though I found [intelligent] and [generic\nexplanations] to be similar in their verbiage. I found [generic explanations] alwayseasier to understand across the board. Because of its simplistic presentation, I did\nnot spend time focusing on unnecessary details”\n•“The explanations are a bit difﬁcult to follow as they are long, so as a reader, you\nget lost in the middle of the explanation and forget what you just read on top.”\n•“They were pretty straightforward and easy to understand, especially because\ndescriptions relating to the law or topics that are difﬁcult to understand are always\nﬁlled with difﬁcult jargon, but this simpliﬁed version made it easy to understand.”\n•“Generally, the explanations were full but a bit difﬁcult to digest. There were cases\nin which not enough was explained to fully understand what a speciﬁc legal term\nmeant and encompassed. The explanations that had a short and quick explanation\nof some legal terms followed by a more prolonged and detailed explanation were,for me, the easiest to grasp.”\nAppendixBStatisticalTests\nComplementing Fig. 6, Table 3provides the extended results of Mann-Whitney U-tests\nconducted on three different comparisons: Random vs Generic, Random vs Intelligent,\nand Generic vs Intelligent. We carried out these tests both on the aggregate data acrossall three topics (memorandum, disability, elements of legal standard), and on each topic\nindividually. For each comparison, the results include the U statistic, the p-value, the\nCommon Language Effect Size (CLES), and the Rank-biserial Correlation.\nThe interpretation of the results across all three topics reveals a consistent pattern.\nOn the whole, we ﬁnd a signiﬁcant difference favoring the Generic over the Random\ngroup, and the Intelligent group over the Random group. The effect sizes of thesedifferences range from small to medium, as indicated by the Common Language\nEffect Size and Rank-biserial Correlation. The differences between the Generic and\nIntelligent groups are also signiﬁcant, albeit smaller.\nWhen it comes to the speciﬁc topic of “Memorandum”, there is no notable difference\nbetween the Random and Generic groups. Some statistical tools that are used in this case\nto reduce the chance of a type I error (false positive) are: the Bonferroni correction,\nthe Holm-Bonferroni method, or the Dunn-Šidák correction. These tools, however,are known to increase false negatives (Armstrong, 2014 ). Regardless, if we would\nuse a Dunn-Šidák correction to adjust for 3 multiple comparisons per topic, then the\nminimum Pvalue for claiming a statistically signiﬁcant result would not be .05 but\ninstead something close to .017.\nNevertheless, the collected ﬁndings still support Hypothesis 1.       "extracted_text": "--- Page 1 ---\n556\n DOI: 10.4324/9781003397618-3227\nCOMPUTATIONAL \nLANGUAGE ANALYSIS AS A \nWINDOW INTO COGNITIVE \nFUNCTIONING\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n27.1 Language as a Window into Cognitive Functioning\nThe evaluation of cognitive and functional abilities in individuals is critical in many \ndomains, such as education, psychology, psychiatry, and neurology. Indeed, language is \none of the primary modalities for psychological assessments, both through standardized \nassessments and through structured interviews. Verbal communication patterns and con -\ntent offer a wealth of information that can be linked to a person’s overall mental state, \nknowledge, cognitive abilities, and ability to function well in social situations. Take, for \nexample, this notable and classic example of disordered language from Andreasen’s Scale \nfor the Assessment of Thought, Language, and Communication (TLC) ( Andreasen, 1986 , \np. 477).\nInterviewer:  Um, what do you think about current political issues like the energy crisis?\nPatient:  They’re destroying too many cattle and oil just to make soap. If we need soap \nwhen you can jump into a pool of water, and then when you go to buy your \ngasoline, m-  my folks always thought they should, get pop but the best thing \nto get, is motor oil, and, money…\nWhile the patient’s response is related to the question posed by the interviewer, it meanders \noff the topic, uses unusual combinations of words, and is not very coherent. Patients with \nbrain disorders may exhibit several features of language, such as poverty of content, \ndistractible speech, tangentiality, derailment, stilted speech, loss of goals, and persever -\nation, among others, which can provide signals of types and severity of disorders. Clinicians \nare trained to pick up on these signals which can then help with diagnosis and treatments. \nHowever, evaluation is a complex, subjective, and expensive process when performed by \nhumans. A high prevalence of neuropsychological disorders require patients to physic -\nally visit a doctor’s office for screening and assessments, leading to healthcare accessibility \nissues which can contribute to unequal access to services and inequity. Furthermore, human \ncognitive and mental states are dynamic over time and context but in-  person traditional  \n  \n \n  \n\n--- Page 2 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n557assessment methods primarily afford cross-  sectional snap-  shots in time due to the required \nin- person attendance for clinical interviews, neuropsychological testing, brain scanning, \nand other sorts of invasive testing ( Chandler et al., 2020c ). Automated techniques can be \nharnessed to reduce language to sets of computational features which analyze semantic, \nsyntactic, and speech properties to characterize these signals, enhancing the efficiency and \naccuracy in assessment. Thus, there is strong utility in applying computational language \nprocessing as digital biomarkers for the purpose of psychological assessment.\n27.1.1  Computational Measurement of Language:  \nCognition, Affect, and Social States\nVerbal communication is a complex task affected by many cognitive skills, as well as mental \nand physical brain pathologies. Distinct brain regions contribute to the progression of speech, \nbeginning with the generation of thoughts and translation to linguistic expressions, and cul -\nminating in the delivery of each utterance ( Dronkers & Ogar, 2004 ; Hoffman, 1987 ). Given \nthat speech is the medium through which signs and symptoms of brain function and dys -\nfunction are manifested, the evaluation of language can be seen as a window into different \ntypes of cognitive, social, and affective functioning. Recent advancements in speech signal \nprocessing, natural language processing (NLP), and machine learning (ML) modeling have \nspurred the development of tools capable of detecting these aspects of mental and cognitive \nwell-  being, as well as affect and social states. This line of work relies on extracting features \nfrom recorded and transcribed (or written) speech and language to objectively assess these \ndimensions of functioning, enable earlier detection of disorders, and track progression and \nchange in well-  being over time.\n27.1.2  Historical Perspectives on Language for Clinical  \nAssessment of Serious Mental Illness\nSerious mental illness (SMI) is characterized by serious cognitive functional impairment \nand encompasses multiple types of illnesses, such as schizophrenia, major depression, \nand bipolar disorders (e.g., Cohen et al., 2014 ). Analysis of discourse in SMI and cog -\nnitive decline have shown significant changes in the quantity, quality, and expression of \nlanguage production. These changes are used as part of diagnostic criteria by clinicians. \nUnderstanding these aspects of language in measurable ways requires indexing the changes \nin language features. A feature can be any statistical or NLP-  derived measure of aspects of \nthe amount and quality of type of language produced by someone. Basic features can be \ncounts of types of words, while more complicated features may be measures of semantic \ncoherence across a discourse, or variability in types of emotions being expressed. While \nindications of SMI through language have been known for years (e.g., Bleuler, 1911 ), work \nin the 1980s was the first to obtain reliable  and objective  measures of language deviance \nand thought disorder, such as type-  token ratios and readability measures (e.g., Manschreck \net al., 1981 ). Snowdon et al. (1996)  manually evaluated the autobiographical essays of \nAmerican Roman Catholic nuns who shared relatively homogeneous characteristics (e.g., \nno drug use and similar living situations) to extract metrics such as grammatical complexity \nand idea density (e.g., number of ideas per N words). In this study, an absence of linguistic \nstructure and complexity was a significant predictor of diminished cognitive ability or the \ndevelopment of Alzheimer’s disease later in life. While these studies were conducted before  \n  \n  \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 3 ---\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n558the availability of significant computing power and the ability to easily collect data in elec -\ntronic form, they indicate the usefulness of computationally identifying linguistic features \nand linking them to indicators related to SMI.\nStarting in the early 2000s, the area of computational modeling of discourse in mental \nhealth began to grow. The growth has been enabled by ongoing advances in NLP-  based \nmethods, increased computing power, and the wide availability of mobile devices for data \ncollection. It has been further enabled by the recognition of how such approaches can \nisolate the underlying mechanisms of serious mental illnesses (e.g., Cohen et al., 2014 ; \nElvevåg et al., 2017 ) in line with the integrative and dimensional transdiagnostic approach \nof the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Research Domain Criteria as well as \nthe greater need for efficient and effective means for monitoring patients. As the field has \nmatured, it has examined mental states in structured language, such as verbal recalls, as \nwell as more unstructured language such as social media posts and personal diaries, and \nhas been evaluated on data from a wide range of clinical areas including schizophrenia and \npsychosis (e.g., Elvevåg et al., 2007 ; Morgan et al., 2021 ), cognitive decline (e.g., Diaz-  Asper \net al., 2022 ; Fraser et al., 2015 ), suicidality ( Roy et al., 2020 ), depression (e.g., Mahdy et \nal., 2020 ), and drug use disorders ( Agurto et al., 2023 ). For reviews, see Corcoran and \nCecchi (2020 ), Goharian et al. (2021 ), and Zhang et al. (2022 ). This chapter provides an \noverview of a common technical approach to the analysis of language for assessing mental \nhealth processes, describes research on areas related to clinical assessment, and concludes \nwith a discussion of implications and caveats for applying the technologies.\n27.2 Underlying Technology and Goals for Assessment of  \nCognitive Functioning\n27.2.1  Overarching Purpose and a Generalized Architecture\nOverall, natural language and speech processing for clinical assessment provides a  \npowerful means to uncover underlying cognitive, social, and affective factors, enhancing  \nour understanding of human functioning and supporting the development of interventions  \nand support systems for individuals in need. NLP techniques enable the extraction and  \nanalysis of spoken and written information, allowing researchers and practitioners to delve  \ninto the intricacies of, and disorders in, language production and comprehension. This  \napproach facilitates the assessment of cognitive processes such as attention, memory, and  \nproblem-  solving abilities, as well as detection of potential disorders and changes in patient  \nmental states. While there exist a broad range of application areas, across disorders and  \ntypes of data collected, the analysis techniques remain highly consistent. Here we describe  \na generalized architecture for such tools (see Figure 27.1 ).\nFigure 27.1   A Generalized Architecture of NLP and Speech Processing as a Window into Cognition. \n \n  \n   \n   \n  \n   \n\n--- Page 4 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n559The typical analysis pipeline starts with gathering language data –   often with the use \nof automated speech recognition which converts spoken language to text –   which is then \nannotated and preprocessed for an experiment’s objective. Next, researchers may take two \ndistinct modeling routes: using an end-  to- end model or deriving features that may align \nwith known constructs and training a model directly on the features. End-  to- end ML mod -\neling involves training a model that learns directly from raw data to make predictions, \neliminating the need for manual feature engineering. In this case, either raw speech or \ntext is harnessed as direct input and models are trained (or fine-  tuned) to predict labels of \ninterest. For example, deep neural networks tend to be harnessed in an end-  to- end fashion. \nIn contrast, feature-  based ML modeling requires the selection and engineering of relevant \nfeatures from the raw data before training the model. Support Vector Machines (SVMs), \ndecision trees, regression, and K-  nearest neighbors are some common model architectures \nfor feature-  based ML. NLP and speech features are extracted to measure the constructs of \ninterest, and statistical analyses or ML approaches are used to select the most predictive \nones. In general, to train and test models, datasets are split into train, test, and validation \nsets, or if the dataset is small, k-  fold cross-  validation is typically used iteratively (often \nwithout an additional held-  out test set). After determining the best features, model types, \nand parameters, accuracy statistics are calculated and reported, and actionable inferences \ncan be made. It should be noted that this analysis pipeline is not highly different from those \nused for educational assessment of writing or speaking. The key differences though may \nbe the kinds of NLP features used to assess language (e.g., disfluencies, coherence, and \ntangentiality) and that the models are trained on signals such as detecting presence versus \nabsence of particular diagnostic categories (e.g., depression and thought disorder).\n27.2.2  Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR)\nAfter speech samples are obtained through a speech elicitation task, which may include pas -\nsively collected speech, standard or spontaneous interviews and conversations, thorough \nneuropsychological batteries, or by simply recording the collaboration between teammates, \nthe speech must be transcribed for NLP techniques to be applied. Automatic speech rec -\nognition (ASR) or manual transcription methods are used to convert spoken words to \ntheir textual equivalents. ASR technologies include commercial tools such as Microsoft \nAzure Speech Service (learn.microsoft.com/  en- us/ azure/  cognitive-  services/  speech-  service/  ), \nGoogle Speech API (cloud.google.com/  speech-  to- text/ ), Amazon Transcribe (aws.amazon.\ncom/  transcribe/  ), and IBM Watson ( www.ibm.com/  cloud/  wat son- spe ech- to- text/ ), as well \nas open source tools such as Whisper ASR ( Radford et al., 2022 ), Kaldi ( Povey et al., \n2011 ), and pre-  trained wav2vec models ( Baevski et al., 2020 ). Typically ASR performance \nis evaluated by the Word Error Rate (WER) based on the Levenshtein distance, where the \nnumber of insertions (incorrect words inserted in the output), deletions (missing words in \nthe output), and substitutions (mismatched words between the output and the reference) \nare counted and then divided by the total number of words in the reference transcript.\nMany factors must be considered when choosing an appropriate ASR tool for their \napplication. The accuracy of these tools differs by the domains in which they are applied \nas well as the population studied (e.g., where racial and age disparities have been shown; \nKoenecke et al., 2020 ; Werner et al., 2019 ). In applications that analyze confidential speech \ndata, such as those that contain personally identifiable information, one must consider the \nsecurity protocols of their chosen tool. For instance, open-  source tools have the advantage \nof being able to run locally, without having to send speech data to the “cloud.” Once the  \n  \n \n   \n\n--- Page 5 ---\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n560language is transcribed, it may be preprocessed before applying feature extraction methods. \nPreprocessing decisions tend to be task and feature dependent, meaning that in some cases \nthe language must be processed before analyses are performed, but in other cases, the raw \nlanguage is sufficient. Standard approaches to preprocessing may include tokenization, \nlemmatization, stemming, removal of stop words and/  or punctuation, and converting text \nto lowercase. It is important to take note of all preprocessing steps taken, both for repro -\nducibility purposes and to ensure that data is formatted in the same manner when testing \nthe models on new data.\n27.2.3  Language and Speech Feature Extraction with a  \nFocus on Several Specific Measures\nThe language features that are typically extracted for psychological assessments can be \ngrouped into three distinct classes of NLP approaches with increasing complexity: first-  \norder lexeme-  level, syntactic, and semantic features. These classes of features further cor -\nrespond to aspects of language that may be differentially affected by mental disorders. \nGenerally, syntactic and lexeme levels of errors may be more associated with aphasias. \nSemantic features are more associated with schizophrenia, affective disorders (e.g., depres -\nsion and bipolar disorder), and cognitive decline (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease and mild cog -\nnitive impairment). Thus, the types of language features chosen must be considered in \nthe development of assessment models. Furthermore, derived acoustic and speech timing \ncharacteristics may provide additional insights to cognitive health.\n27.2.3.1  Lexeme-  Level Features\nFirst-  order lexeme-  level features encompass basic measurements of language at the word \nlevel such as word token counts and word type counts (i.e., unique words) as well as more \nsophisticated measurements of lexical diversity, which assay the amount of unique vocabu -\nlary used in language. This includes metrics like type-  to- token ratio (TTR), content density \n(CD), propositional density (P-  density), Honoré’s Statistic (HS), and Brunet’s Index (BI) \n(e.g., Voletiet al., 2019 ). Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC) is a well-  known set \nof tools that provide counts of over 100 features of texts and have been used widely for \nmeasuring emotional expression, detecting depression, and relating psychological aspects \nto natural language use (see Tausczik & Pennebaker, 2010 ). For instance, research has \nshown that LIWC analyses can classify those with mild cognitive impairment from healthy \ncontrols with 80% accuracy ( Asgari et al., 2017 ).\nWhile counting tokens can be predictive of mental state, it’s worth noting that certain \nfeatures, such as TTR, can be heavily influenced by text length, as longer utterances tend to \nyield higher scores. CD, HS, and BI, on the other hand, demonstrate a weaker dependency \non text length. Therefore, the choice of which features to utilize depends greatly on the \nspecific task. For example, if speech length is considered an aspect of language that should \nbe modeled and heavily taken into account, TTR may be more advantageous over CD as it \ncaptures the quantity of language produced. First-  order lexeme-  level features offer simpli -\ncity, interpretability, and ease of computation. However, they do not provide insights into \nlanguage unit structure, complexity, or the context of the semantic meaning generated by \npatients. \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 6 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n561Features derived from part-  of- speech tags are also an important word-  level feature. \nIndividual word tokens can be automatically assigned their corresponding part-  of- speech \nlabels by commonly using the Penn Treebank tags ( Marcus et al., 1993 ). These automatic \ntaggers generally use statistical models to assign tags to language. Once language is tagged, \nsimple counts and frequencies of these tags, as well as more sophisticated metrics such as \nP- density and CD, provide insights into the relative distribution of different types of words. \nResearch has shown that the use of features derived from part-  of- speech tags (such as CD) \ncan be used as input to ML models to classify those with mild cognitive impairment from \nhealthy controls with an Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 0.732 ( Roark et al., 2011 ).\n27.2.3.2  Syntactic Features\nSentence-  level syntactic features constitute a more intricate type of language feature, cap -\nturing aspects of how well a person can generate language that is both grammatically \ncorrect and shows aspects of complexity. This category may encompass metrics derived \nfrom dependency parses or speech graphs of language. Dependency parses capture the \nrelationships between words in a sentence, such as words that modify one another. On the \nother hand, speech graphs employ networks to represent words, with nodes representing \nwords and edges illustrating temporal relationships between them. Metrics derived from \nthese representations include the depth of dependencies (distance) in parse trees or the count \nof nodes, edges, or loops (connectedness) in speech graphs ( Yngve, 1960 ; Frazier, 1985 ). \nResearchers have proposed such a graph theory approach for analyzing language structure \nto measure symptoms of thought disorder within psychosis ( Mota et al., 2012 ; Mota et al., \n2014 ). While syntactic features offer a more robust assessment of language proficiency \ncompared to lexemes alone, the generation of sentence parses and graphs introduces add -\nitional complexity and potential sources of error in automated models.\n27.2.3.3  Semantic Features\nA hallmark of the disruptions in language in SMI occurs in the expression of meaning. \nThis can include aspects such as the topicality of responses, the coherence, and the density \nof relevant ideas. The crux of automated semantic analysis lies in the utilization of high-  \ndimensional vector space word embeddings of text. These embeddings operate under the \npremise that the meaning of a word can be derived from the context in which it typically \nappears, or that “you shall know a word by the company it keeps” ( Firth, 1957 ). As a \nresult, semantically related words –   or those that tend to appear in similar contexts –   should \nbe close to one another in their derived vector spaces. Various word embedding techniques \nexist, including Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA; Landauer & Dumais, 1997 ; Landauer \net al., 1998 ), word2vec ( Mikolov et al., 2013 ), Embeddings from Language Models (ELMo; \nPeters et al., 2018 ), Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT; \nDevlin et al., 2019 ), XLNet ( Yang et al., 2019 ), and GPT ( Brown et al., 2020 ). It should \nbe noted that this field is rapidly evolving and newer models continue to be developed with \nadditional gains in accuracy. Generally, cosine distance metrics, computed between con -\nsecutive embeddings or windows of embeddings, are used as features in ML  models, but \nfor techniques like ELMo, BERT, XLNet, and GPT, the entire network can be leveraged and \nfine- tuned to produce metrics and predictions. \n  \n \n  \n  \n \n  \n \n \n    \n\n--- Page 7 ---\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n562With real-  valued vector representations of words, phrases, sentences, and entire \nparagraphs, it is possible to quantify notions of typical semantic language usage, such as \nthe content of the language, as well as coherence and tangentially which are measures of flu -\nidity. For example, the coherence of a response can be measured by computing the semantic \nsimilarity of consecutive windows of words to the next windows of words (see Elvevåg \net al., 2007 ; Foltz et al., 1998 ). The topicality can be measured by looking at the semantic \nsimilarity of a patient’s response to the question asked or to previously annotated responses \ngiven by other people.\n27.2.3.4  Speech Signal Features\nAcoustic characteristics of speech can also provide valuable insights into cognitive \nfunctioning, such as a patient’s affective state (e.g., Cheng et al., 2018 ). Various acoustic \nfeatures can be easily extracted using tools like openSMILE ( Eyben et al., 2010 ). These \nfeatures encompass energy, loudness, Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients, Perceptual \nLinear Prediction, the fundamental frequency F0, probability of voicing, voice quality \nmeasures like jitter and shimmer, formant frequencies and bandwidth (F1, F2, F3, F4, etc.), \nas well as harmonics-  to- noise ratio. Additionally, aggregated statistics of these features, \nincluding means, extremes, moments, segments, peaks, linear and quadratic regression, \npercentiles, durations, onsets, and more, can be calculated. For example, research has \nshown that high levels of stress were associated with abnormally small changes in vocal \nexpression within those with a variety of psychiatric symptoms but for those with no active \npsychiatric symptoms, stress levels had more typical effects on voice modulation ( Cohen \net al., 2019 ). Timing mechanisms also play a crucial role in evaluating mental and cognitive \nstates. Generalized slowing is a prominent symptom observed in various psychiatric and \nneurodegenerative conditions. To capture the phenomenon of slowing in speech, timing-  \nrelated features can be utilized, including the length and rate of voiced segments, silent \npauses, the rate and fluctuations of voiced segments to pauses, and measures of rhythm \n(e.g., Pressman et al., 2019 ). A meta-  analysis assessed how timing delays affect cognitive \nprocesses in those with schizophrenia and concluded that tasks which require selective \nattention had the most slowing (2.3 times slower for those with schizophrenia), followed \nby lexical tasks (1.8 times slower), and lastly non-  lexical tasks (1.4 times slower) ( Schatz, \n1998 ). These features may provide a more direct assessment of illness compared to other \nderived acoustic measurements that may align more with other factors such as medications \nor physical differences.\n27.2.4  Training Feature-  Based Machine Learning Models\nOnce features are extracted from the language and speech signal, ML models are trained \nto predict dependent variables of interest. In essence, the goal is to relate the targeted cog -\nnitive functions to the language and speech features that indicate them. ML models gen -\nerally fall into two categories: regression and classification models –   usually performed in \na supervised manner, meaning that models learn from labeled data as opposed to models \nlearning their own representations from unlabeled data (unsupervised learning). Regression \nmodels learn relationships between input variables (the features) and the corresponding \ncontinuous target variable (the dependent variable). Examples of regression tasks include \npredicting essay scores, clinician rating performance on neuropsychological tasks, general  \n  \n \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 8 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n563patient ratings of well-  being, and dimensions of affect such as activation levels. Classification \ninvolves predicting the class or category to which a data instance belongs, where the model \nis trained to accurately assign class labels to new, unseen data instances. Typical classifica -\ntion methods include logistic regression, decision trees, and SVMs. The output of a clas -\nsification model is a discrete class label or a probability distribution over multiple classes, \neither represented as a binary task (two classes) or a multiclass classification task (more \nthan two classes). Examples of classification tasks include detecting the onset of cognitive \ndecline or psychiatric disorders, predicting diagnostic labels, as well as detecting students at \nrisk. In both approaches, the model tries to find the best-  fitting mathematical function that \napproximates the relationship between the input variables and the target variable.\n27.3 Research and Applications Applying Language Analysis to  \nMeasuring Mental Health\nThis section illustrates how the NLP and ML pipeline has been applied in a few areas for \nassessing cognitive functioning. The examples represent a subset of approaches currently \nbeing performed. For more examples, see Clarke et al. (2020) , Corcoran and Cecchi (2020) , \nGoharian et al. (2021) , Zhang et al. (2022) , and Cecchi and Corcoran (2023) .\n27.3.1  Automating Traditional Neuropsychiatric Assessments\nTask-  driven speech may be elicited in many ways for neuropsychological purposes. Current \npsychiatric practice involves many standardized types of speech tasks which are hand-  \nscored by clinicians. For an overview of common neuropsychological assessment tasks, \nsee Lezak et al. (2012) , and for an overview of the use of ML and NLP for the automation \nof a subset of these tasks see Chandler et al. (2020c) . Here the focus is on two popular \ntasks: story recall and animal fluency. The purpose of the story recall task is to assess an \nindividual’s ability to comprehend and remember a story or narrative and is used to identify \nmemory deficits, monitor progress, and develop interventions or treatment plans. The task \ninvolves presenting a story to the participant through an auditory or written format. After \na brief period, the participant is asked to recall as much information as possible from the \nstory. The responses are then assessed based on their accuracy, completeness, and the level \nof detail provided. Automating this task involves (1) collecting human responses to a set of \nstory recall prompts as the set of training data for the scoring model; (2) harnessing ASR to \ntranscribe the spoken recalls and preprocessing the text data; (3) extracting features such \nas word token and type overlap, semantic similarity, and syntactic patterns; (4) training \nan ML model using these features and human-  assigned scores; (5) evaluating the model \nwith metrics such as mean squared error or Pearson’s correlation; and finally (6) applying \nsuch a model in real settings. Results show that these models can be quite accurate to \nmatching clinician ratings and are highly robust to word errors in ASR ( Chandler et al., \n2019 ; Holmlund et al., 2020 ).\nFluency tasks are used to test a person’s verbal fluency, executive functioning, and \nsemantic memory ( Shao et al., 2014 ). In the animal fluency task, the participant is given a \nspecific time limit and asked to generate as many animal names as possible within that time \nframe. Traditionally, this task is scored by simply tallying the number of unique examples \nspoken. This scoring process is easily automated with minimal effort. However, researchers \nhave proposed more detailed analyses that could provide additional insights into cognitive  \n  \n \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 9 ---\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n564processes. Troyer et al. (1997)  introduced an early improvement, suggesting two metrics that \ncapture important aspects of the task: clustering (producing words within the same subcat -\negory of animals, such as safari or house pets) and switching (changing between clusters). \nSuch features can be implemented with hard-  coded categories as supplied by the authors or \nwith the use of word embeddings. The latter involves computing cosine distances between \nthe word embeddings of each exemplar to determine if it belongs to the same category, or if \nthere is a switch to a new one based on a cosine distance threshold. This approach is prefer -\nable to a hard-  coded approach for several reasons. Hard-  coded categories may not consider \nsocietal influences or cultural variations in mental categorizations. For example, the sequence \n“lion, tiger, bear” may not constitute a mental switch –   due to the societal influence of the \nWizard of Oz, but it falls into two distinct Toyer categories. Cultural differences may result in \ndifferent animal responses such as respondents in Norway producing an overwhelming focus \non fish ( Rosenstein et al., 2015 ), which the Troyer categorizations do not account for. The \nhard-  coded approach lacks flexibility for handling animals outside the predefined categories, \nrelying on manual incorporation and introducing bias and non-  standardization, contrary to \nthe goal of full automation. Automating this task follows a similar pipeline as the story recall \ntask except that the features would align with the task more closely: such as unique animals, \ncategories, and switches, as well as semantic features such as average semantic distance \nbetween consecutive animals and average word embedding lengths ( Diaz-  Asper et al., 2022 ).\n27.3.2  Detecting Presence and Severity of Thought Disorder\nAn early investigation that applied computational assessments of language for the detec -\ntion of schizophrenia by Elvevåg et al. (2007)  used LSA word embeddings to measure \nsemantics of thought disorder. LSA coherence features were computed from transcripts of \nparticipants’ responses to various language tasks, such as single word associations, verbal \nfluency, and general interviews. These features were derived as cosine distances between \nLSA vector representations of source words and spoken words, consecutive words, and \nsliding windows of text (n-  grams) with sizes ranging from 2 to 8 words. It should be noted \nthat this same approach has been used for assessing student writing in essays (see Foltz, \net al., 1998 ; Foltz, 2020 ). Additionally, tangentiality, defined as the slope of a regression \nline fit to cosine distances over consecutive text windows with the same parameters, was \nalso extracted. With this set of computational features, the authors were able to accur -\nately assess direct levels of incoherence, as well as whether a given discourse belonged to a \npatient with schizophrenia or to a healthy control. Similar approaches have been used by \nIter et al., (2018)  and Bedi et al. (2015) , where coherence models were used to predict the \nfuture development of psychosis among a small group of psychiatric patients.\n27.3.3  Acoustic Features for Affective and Cognitive State Assessment\nA person’s emotions can be evident from the acoustic properties of their speech, indicating \naspects of mental state. Acoustic properties have been used in many fields for affect detec -\ntion, including in educational assessment such as for developing affect-  sensitive tutors (e.g., \nD’Mello et al., 2007 ). Acoustic features alone can serve as a measurement of patient mental \nstates, such as in the prediction of diagnoses in demographically matched datasets, the pre -\ndiction of self-  reported emotional affect ( Cheng et al., 2018 ), and expert ratings of patients’ \nemotional state. However, their utility is particularly evident when combined with language  \n  \n \n \n  \n  \n\n--- Page 10 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n565or emotional state variables. For instance, in a follow-  on study to Cheng et al. (2018) , \nChandler et al. (2020b)  showed that the unimodal acoustic analyses could be improved \nby combining with language features from spoken story recalls to predict a person’s self-  \nreported affect. Roark et al. (2011)  utilized acoustic and language features to detect mild \ncognitive impairment. They employed manual and automated methods to estimate speech \nduration features, including phonation rate, total phonation time, total pause time, pauses \nper sample, total locution time, and verbal rate. Fraser et al. (2015)  used a hybrid approach \nwith speech and language metrics to classify patients with Alzheimer’s disease and healthy \ncontrols. They considered over 370 distinctive features, including grammatical features, \nsyntactic complexity, information content, and acoustic features associated with patho -\nlogical speech. The combination of speech and linguistic features offers complementary \ninsights into disease progression and severity, leading to a comprehensive feature set for \nimproved classification results in many application areas.\n27.3.4  Detecting Onset of Cognitive Decline\nNumerous studies have documented the prevalence of speech differences between those \nwho experience healthy aging and cognitive decline disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease \nand mild cognitive impairment. As mentioned above, Roark et al. (2011)  and Fraser et al. \n(2015)  used traditional feature-  based ML methods in conjunction with both acoustic and \nlinguistic features to predict mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease, respect -\nively. Other studies have focused on language alone for prediction as this modality has \nbeen shown to be the most predictive of cognitive decline ( König et al., 2015 ; Diaz-  Asper \net al., 2022 ). Researchers have even applied such methods to written responses to a pic -\nture description task, finding that telegraphic speech (i.e., simplified language), repetitive -\nness, and misspellings were indicative of future onset of AD ( Eyigoz et al., 2020 ). Notable \npublic figures like United States presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush have \neven been the subject of such analyses to assess the existence of differences in discourse \ncomplexity between Bush –   a healthy aging person –   and Reagan –   preceding his diagnoses \nof Alzheimer’s disease ( Berisha et al., 2015 ). For a review, see Ivanova et al. (2023) .\n27.3.5  Detection of Students at Risk\nA crossover point between educational assessment and clinical assessment has been research \ninto the detection of students at risk through their writing. A student at risk may be defined \nas one expressing thoughts of harm to self or others. While NLP tools have been broadly \napplied to assessing open-  ended writing in social media (see Coppersmith et al., 2018 ; \nNguyen et al., 2022 ), student essays, which are already being automatically assessed for \nwriting quality, can also be assessed for statements that may indicate sensitive issues of \nharm and distress. While the area of detection of crisis papers is still at the early stages, \neffective rubrics and methods are being developed that can help triage these papers for \nhuman review ( Burkardt et al., 2021 ).\n27.3.6  Applying Deep Learning Models for Mental Health Assessment\nAlthough traditional feature-  based ML models are highly regarded for their interpretability, \nthe advent of deep learning has revolutionized the fields of NLP and ML by significantly  \n \n  \n \n \n  \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 11 ---\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n566improving accuracy across various applications. Deep learning models consist of intricate \nnetworks of interconnected nodes organized in layers, enabling hierarchical learning of \nincreasingly sophisticated data patterns. These models encompass numerous parameters, \nrequiring extensive training data to prevent overfitting and to acquire a generalized \nunderstanding of the training dataset. Particularly in complex domains, a substantial \nnumber of examples per class (i.e., target or dependent variable) are essential for effectively \ncapturing the underlying data patterns. There have been notable achievements in predictive \nmodeling that leverage electronic health records ( Miotto et al., 2016 ; Tran & Kavuluru, \n2017 ) and social media posts ( Gkotsis et al., 2017 ; Guntuku et al., 2017 ). These domains \noffer the advantage of facilitating data collection on a large scale.\nWithin the domain of cognitive decline detection, Orimaye et al. (2018)  developed a \ndeep learning cognitive assessment model, utilizing data from DementiaBank, to classify \nparticipants as having Alzheimer’s disease, mild cognitive impairment, or being cognitively \nhealthy from them describing a picture depicting a cookie theft. The model architecture \nincorporated both a deep neural network and deep language model. Their model achieved \nrelatively high accuracy; however, these accuracies align with those of other ML classifiers \nfor cognitive decline, suggesting that the additional complexity associated with neural \nnetworks may not have been necessary.\nThe application of deep neural network models extends to the utilization of passive \nbehavioral data collected from smartphones. Suhara et al. (2017)  successfully predicted \nsevere depressive states by leveraging a Long Short-  Term Memory (LSTM) neural network \ntrained on 2,382 individual histories of mood, behavioral logs, and sleep information. \nTheir model outperformed a comparable support vector machine-  based implementation. \nAdditionally, the authors highlighted that incorporating a user’s historical information \nenhanced the accuracy of forecasting future depressed moods.\n27.4 Ethical and Measurement Considerations\n27.4.1  What Are We Measuring?\nIt is straightforward to find NLP measures that can correlate with patients’ clinical states. \nFor example, patients with depression, Alzheimer’s disease, or schizophrenia all tend to \nproduce less language than controls. But a count of word types may not be clinically \nuseful. Thus, for developing automated methods for assessing cognitive functioning and \nmental health, it is critical to consider the underlying clinical constructs that are being \nevaluated. The adoption of evidence-  centered assessment design (ECD) ( Mislevy et al., \n2003 ) principles that consider evidentiary arguments to support validity claims (see Foltz \net al., 2023 ) is a compelling methodology. While widely used in educational assessment, \nECD has direct application to measurement of clinical states. This approach requires iden -\ntifying the clinical constructs that are being targeted, which could be some mixture of the \nphenomenological expressions of clinical states or the underlying neurocognitive processes. \nThen NLP features are linked in an evidence model to the targeted constructs, tying the \npsychological constructs to the computational methods within the context of assessment \ntasks. This provides a means of transparency and explainability of the contributions of the \nfeatures to model predictions and also provides a mechanism for actionable inferences. \n   \n  \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 12 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n56727.4.2  Actionable Inferences\nML models are powerful tools that can uncover complex patterns and relationships in large \ndatasets, but these patterns must be explained in ways that they are useful to stakeholders. \nClinicians can use these models to gain a deeper understanding of human behavior, cogni -\ntion, and mental processes. By analyzing the output of ML models, clinicians should be able \nto identify important features, variables, or patterns that contribute to specific outcomes or \nbehaviors. This knowledge can inform the development of interventions, treatment plans, or \ntargeted interventions for individuals or groups (e.g., Holmlund, et al., 2019 ). Additionally, \nmental health researchers can use these models to generate hypotheses and guide further \nresearch, leading to new discoveries and advancements in the field. It is crucial, however, \nfor clinicians to be able to interpret and contextualize the output of ML models within the \nbroader theoretical frameworks and empirical evidence in psychology to ensure the validity \nand relevance of the derived inferences.\n27.4.3  Establishing Trustworthy Measures: Transparency, \nGeneralizability, and Explainability\nA lack of transparency and understanding surrounding AI and ML can undermine trust, \nwhich is crucial in the application of technology for psychological assessments. Clinicians \nneed ways of knowing how and why a recommendation was made by a model, other -\nwise the system won’t be used in practice. For a review of issues on ethical guidelines for \napplying AI in psychological assessment, see Diaz-  Asper et al. (2024) . Thus, to establish \ntrustworthiness, the field must address the three vital concepts of explainability, trans -\nparency, and generalizability (see Chandler et al., 2020a ). These elements are critical for \nensuring the viability of AI, where it can potentially assist in monitoring, evaluation, and \nprognosis of psychological constructs in the near future.\nExplainability can be accomplished in many ways, and tends to depend on the architec -\nture of the model used to produce predictions. Some examples include Local Interpretable \nModel-  agnostic Explanation (LIME) and SHapley Additive exPlanation (SHAP) for neural \nnetworks or feature weight and decision path analyses for more traditional model types like \nlinear regression or decision trees. To establish transparency in an ML model, it is neces -\nsary to provide clear information about its purpose, architecture, training data statistics, \ntraining process, and underlying assumptions, including its appropriateness to types of \ntasks and populations. By applying an ECD framework approach to measurement, the \nsystem can demonstrate transparency of how the model’s features align with the constructs \nbeing assessed. Generalizability is critical to ensure that ML models are not overfitting idio -\nsyncrasies of a training set. The advantage of ML is its ability to leverage the variability \ninherent in large data to provide valid characterizations. Thus, large datasets are required. \nUnfortunately, many studies in psychological assessment have modest and insufficient \nsample sizes, which further exacerbates the issue, especially due to the lack of standard \ncross-  validation practices.\n27.4.4  Bias and Fairness\nThe biases and prejudices present in historical data have led to ML algorithms that per -\npetuate racial, economic, and gender discrimination ( Bolukbasi et al., 2016 ; Dastin, 2018 ;  \n \n  \n \n \n   \n\n--- Page 13 ---\nPeter W. Foltz and Chelsea Chandler\n568Henrich et al., 2010 ; O’Neil, 2016 ), as these algorithms learn from the samples of data \nupon which they are trained. This is a significant issue because it can amplify existing real-  \nworld issues and inequalities, particularly in measuring clinical states where healthcare \ndecisions may be impacted. Addressing bias in ML is crucial for ensuring fairness, equity, \nand ethical use of AI systems in decision-  making processes. To prevent issues related to \nbias and improve generalizability, it is crucial for the scientific community to develop large \nand trustworthy clinical datasets that accurately represent the target populations for the \ntesting of algorithms –   especially those that are widely used and have real consequences for \nmembers of marginalized communities. Such an approach should establish a standard for \nevery model to meet before it can be trusted for real-  world use.\n27.4.5  Human in the Loop ML Processing\nThus far, we have described the conventional ML approach used in psychological \nassessment research to understand how language features are combined to model psycho -\nlogical judgments. However, it has some pitfalls that can lead to incorrect assumptions. \nFor instance, there may be a lack of human understanding of the input data patterns \nwhich result in model uncertainty and how the models may handle such data. Research \nhas shown that outlier and anomaly detection approaches such as the Isolation Forest \nalgorithm ( Liu et al., 2018 ) could be used as a safeguard to mitigate instances of uncer -\ntainty ( Chandler et al., 2021 ). Also, data collection and labeling often prioritize fairly \nhomogeneous data over more diverse data needed to create a robust model ( Fisher et al., \n2018 ). Only rarely is an evaluation dataset put aside until a final model is trained, espe -\ncially when dealing with small datasets ( Foltz et al., 2016 ). Thus, the reported measures \nare biased as the models are created to maximize accuracy on those datasets (rather than \nthe preferred approach of being blind to the test data during model development). This \nframework may not be adequate for high stakes’ assessments that require robust and \nreliable models. Human-  in- the- loop techniques can improve the generalizability, trans -\nparency, reliability, and applicability of the traditional approaches and have been applied \nin educational and clinical assessment ( Baikadi et al., 2019 ; Chandler et al., 2022 ). \nInvolving humans in additional stages of model development enables the understanding \nof how psychological dimensions impact model predictions and supports dynamic, con -\ntinuous real-  world data comprising multiple channels. This approach generates models \nthat are as robust and reliable as the data allows and alerts to unusual inputs before \nspurious decisions are generated.\nA critical component of human-  in- the- loop processes is active learning during model \ntraining, where important data is selected for human labeling as early as possible. The pro -\ncess begins with the collection of both labeled and unlabeled data and a partially trained \nmodel that will improve with each iteration of active learning. Active learning ( Settles, \n2011 ) selects only the necessary data to make the model more certain in areas of uncer -\ntainty and fill general knowledge gaps, thus improving efficiency (i.e., requiring less labeled \ndata to achieve a given accuracy) and model robustness. To avoid biasing the model toward \nlearning overwhelmingly rare examples, these sampling techniques should be used in com -\nbination with random sampling. Once the selected data is labeled, the model is retrained, \nand the process is repeated until accuracy gains stabilize or a specific criterion is met. Similar \nstrategies used in active learning may more generally apply as human-  in- the- loop safeguards \nduring model deployment to investigate stability and robustness in new situations.   \n \n \n \n \n  \n  \n\n--- Page 14 ---\nComputational Language Analysis\n56927.5 Conclusions\nAutomated analysis of language has shown high accuracy for predicting cognitive and psy -\nchological states and has strong potential for needed clinical and assessment applications. \nApplying AI-  based methods can automate traditionally time-  intensive assessment tasks, \nallowing more frequent and timely assessment, diagnostic evaluation, feedback and \ninterventions. This can have positive impacts on increased accessibility to care, early detec -\ntion, personalized treatment plans, reduced stigma in having to go in for assessments. \nHowever, having an accurate ML model is only a small component that contributes within \nthe greater system of psychological assessment and support. Thus, the use of these technolo -\ngies needs to be considered within the larger context of (1) how to work with stakeholders \nto ensure the technology will appropriately be integrated into assessment and treatment \nworkflows, (2) the generalizability, transparency, and robustness of the systems, (3) the \nethical principles of collecting unobtrusive data and measuring and reporting psychological \nstate, and (4) how human and computer-  based psychological assessment and support work \ntogether to provide greatest benefit to end users.\nThis chapter has presented a generalized ML and natural language and speech pro -\ncessing approach to the extraction of inferences in the domain of cognitive functioning, \nspecifically as it pertains to the detection of cognitive states and diagnosis within clinical \npopulations. However, the approach is essentially the same as the approaches used for \nessay scoring, spoken language assessment, as well as for team communication assessment \n(e.g., Cooke et al., 2017 ; Foltz, 2018 ). Advances are being made in each of these areas, and \nit is valuable to draw inspiration from these domains to drive innovation. For example, \nthe health sector has focused very closely on understanding constructs and issues of bias \ndue to the extremely high stakes of misclassifications. Team assessment has focused on \nhow to assess higher level constructs like shared understanding, coordination, and situ -\nation awareness. Research in writing assessment and applying the ECD approaches from \neducational measurement has helped inform work being done in these other areas. All of \nthese fields operate under the assumption that language is a window into important aspects \nof cognitive, affective, and social functioning that are tied to skills, abilities, and/  or brain \nfunctions. By using this generalized approach, a set of construct relevant, reliable, and valid \nfeatures can be determined to create models which can continue to improve assessment and \nprovide practical tools to impact learning and the psychological well-  being of users.\nReferences\nAgurto C., Cecchi G., King S., Eyigoz E.
