      "extracted_text": "--- Page 1 ---\nSecond Series • Autumn 2007                             Volume 11 • Number 1\nPublished by The Green Bag, Inc., in cooperation with the George Mason University School of Law.HOW TO READ A LEGAL OPINION\nA G UIDE FOR NEW LAW STUDENTS\nOrin S. Kerr\nCopyright © 2007  Orin S. Kerr\n\n--- Page 2 ---\n \n  \n   \n \n    \n\n--- Page 3 ---\n \n11 GREEN BAG 2D 51  \n \n \nHOW TO READ A \nLEGAL OPINION \nA GUIDE FOR NEW LAW STUDENTS  \nOrin S. Kerr† \nThis essay is designed to help new law students prepare for the \nfirst few weeks of class. It explains what judicial opinions are, how they are structured, and what law students should look for when reading them. \nI. WHAT’S IN A LEGAL OPINION ? \nhen two people disagree and that disagreement leads to a lawsuit, the lawsuit will sometimes end with a ruling by a \njudge in favor of one side. The ju dge will explain the ruling in a \nwritten document referred to as an “opinion.” The opinion explains what the case is about, discusses the relevant legal principles, and then applies the law to the facts to reach a ruling in favor of one side \nand against the other. \nModern judicial opinions reflect hundreds of years of history and \npractice. They usually follow a simp le and predictable formula. This \n                                                                                                   \n \n† Orin Kerr is a professor of law at the George Washington University Law School. This essay \ncan be freely distributed for non-commercial uses under the Creative Commons Attribution-\nNonCommercial-NoDerivs 3.0 Unported license. For the terms of the license, visit creative-\ncommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/legalcode. W \n\n--- Page 4 ---\nOrin S. Kerr \n52  11 GREEN BAG 2D section takes you through the basic formula. It starts  with the intro-\nductory materials at the top of an opinion and then moves on to the \nbody of the opinion. \nThe Caption \nThe first part of the case is the title of the case, known as the “cap-\ntion.” Examples include  Brown v. Board of Education  and Miranda v. \nArizona. The caption usually tells you the last names of the person \nwho brought the lawsuit and the person who is being sued. These \ntwo sides are often referred to as the “parties” or as the “litigants” in \nthe case. For example, if Ms. Smit h sues Mr. Jones, the case caption \nmay be Smith v. Jones  (or, depending on the court, Jones v. Smith ). \nIn criminal law, cases are brought by government prosecutors on \nbehalf of the government itself. This means that the government is \nthe named party. For example, if the federal government charges John Doe with a crime, the case caption will be United States v. Doe . \nIf a state brings the charges instead, the caption will be State v. Doe, \nPeople v. Doe , or Commonwealth v. Doe , depending on the practices of \nthat state.\n1 \nThe Case Citation  \nBelow the case name you will find some letters and numbers. These \nletters and numbers are the legal citation for the case. A citation tells you the name of the court th at decided the case, the law book \nin which the opinion was published,  and the year in which the court \ndecided the case. For example, “U.S. Supreme Court, 485 U.S. 759 \n(1988)” refers to a U.S. Supreme Court case decided in 1988 that \nappears in Volume 485 of the United States Reports starting at page \n759. \nThe Author of  the Opinion \nThe next information is the name of the judge who wrote the opin-ion. Most opinions assigned in law school were issued by courts \n                                                                                                   \n \n1 English criminal cases normally will be Rex v. Doe  or Regina v. Doe. Rex and \nRegina aren’t the victims: the words are Latin for “King” and “Queen.” During \nthe reign of a King, English courts use “R ex”; during the reign of a Queen, they \nswitch to “Regina.” \n\n--- Page 5 ---\nHow to Read a Legal Opinion \nAUTUMN 2007  53 with multiple judges. The name tells you which judge wrote that \nparticular opinion. In older cases, the opinion often simply states a last name followed by the initial “J.” No, judges don’t all have the \nfirst initial “J.” The letter stands fo r “Judge” or “Justice,” depending \non the court. On occasion, the opinion will use the Latin phrase “per curiam” instead of a judge’s name. Per curiam means “by the \ncourt.” It signals that the opinion reflects a common view among all the judges rather than the wr itings of a specific judge. \nThe Facts of the Case \nNow let’s move on to the opinion it self. The first part of the body \nof the opinion presents the facts of  the case. In other words, what \nhappened? The facts might be that Andy pulled out a gun and shot \nBob. Or maybe Fred agreed to give Sally $100 and then changed his mind. Surprisingly, there are no pa rticular rules for what facts a \njudge must include in the fact se ction of an opinion. Sometimes the \nfact sections are long, and somet imes they are short. Sometimes \nthey are clear and accurate, and other times they are vague or in-complete. \nMost discussions of the facts als o cover the “procedural history” \nof the case. The procedural histor y explains how the legal dispute \nworked its way through the legal syst em to the court that is issuing \nthe opinion. It will include various motions, hearings, and trials that occurred after the case was initially filed. Your civil procedure class is all about that kind of stuff; you should pay ve ry close attention to \nthe procedural history of cases when you read assignments for your civil procedure class. The procedur al history of cases usually will be \nless important when you read a case for your other classes. \nThe Law of the Case \nAfter the opinion presents the fact s, it will then discuss the law. \nMany opinions present the law in two stages. The first stage dis-\ncusses the general principles of law that are relevant to cases such as \nthe one the court is deciding. This section might explore the history of a particular field of law or may include a discussion of past cases \n(known as “precedents”) that are related to the case the court is de-\n\n--- Page 6 ---\nOrin S. Kerr \n54  11 GREEN BAG 2D ciding. This part of the opinion gives the reader background to help \nunderstand the context and significan ce of the court’s decision. The \nsecond stage of the legal section a pplies the general legal principles \nto the particular facts of the dispute.  As you might guess, this part is \nin many ways the heart of the opini on: It gets to the bottom line of \nwhy the court is ruling for one side and against the other. \nConcurring  and/or Dissenting  Opinions  \nMost of the opinions you read as a law student are “majority” opin-ions. When a group of judges get together to decide a case, they vote on which side should win and also try to agree on a legal ra-\ntionale to explain why that side has won. A majority opinion is an \nopinion joined by the majority of judges on that court. Although most decisions are unanimous, so me cases are not. Some judges \nmay disagree and will write a separate opinion offering a different approach. Those opinions are calle d “concurring opi nions” or “dis-\nsenting opinions,” and they appear after the majority opinion. A \n“concurring opinion” (sometimes just called a “concurrence”) ex-\nplains a vote in favor of the winning side but based on a different legal rationale. A “dissenting opini on” (sometimes just  called a “dis-\nsent”) explains a vote in favor of the losing side. \nII. COMMON LEGAL TERMS \nFOUND IN OPINIONS \now that you know what’s in a le gal opinion, it’s time to learn \nsome of the common words you’ll find inside them. But first a \nhistory lesson, for reasons that should be clear in a minute. \nIn 1066, William the Conqueror came across the English Chan-\nnel from what is now France and conquered the land that is today \ncalled England. The conquering Normans spoke French and the de-feated Saxons spoke Old English. The Normans took over the court \nsystem, and their language became the language of the law. For sev-\neral centuries after the French-speaking Normans took over Eng-land, lawyers and judges in Englis h courts spoke in French. When \nEnglish courts eventually returned to using English, they continued to use many French words. N \n\n--- Page 7 ---\nHow to Read a Legal Opinion \nAUTUMN 2007  55 Why should you care about this ancient history? The American \ncolonists considered themselves En glishmen, so they used the Eng-\nlish legal system and adopted its language. This means that Ameri-\ncan legal opinions today are littere d with weird French terms. Ex-\namples include plaintiff, defendan t, tort, contract, crime, judge, \nattorney, counsel, court, verdict, pa rty, appeal, evidence, and jury. \nThese words are the everyday lan guage of the American legal sys-\ntem. And they’re all from the Fren ch, brought to you by William \nthe Conqueror in 1066. \nThis means that when you read  a legal opinion, you’ll come \nacross a lot of foreign-sounding wor ds to describe the court system. \nYou need to learn all of these words eventually; you should read \ncases with a legal dictionary near by and should look up every word \nyou don’t know. But this section will give you a head start by intro-\nducing you to some of the most common words, many of which (but not all) are French in origin. \nTypes of Disputes and the  Names of Participants  \nThere are two basic kinds of legal disputes: civil and criminal. In a \ncivil case, one person files a lawsuit against another asking the court to order the other side to pay him money or to do or stop doing something. An award of money is called “damages” and an order to \ndo something or to refrain from doing something is called an “in-\njunction.” The person bringing the lawsuit is known as the “plaintiff” \nand the person sued is called the “defendant.” \nIn criminal cases, there is no plaintiff and no lawsuit. The role of \na plaintiff is occupied by a govern ment prosecutor. Instead of filing \na lawsuit (or equivalently, “suing” someone), the prosecutor files \ncriminal “charges.” Instead of asking for damages or an injunction, the prosecutor asks the court to punish the individual through either jail time or a fine. The government prosecutor is often referred to as “the state,” “the prosecution,” or simply “the government.” The \nperson charged is called the defenda nt, just like the person sued in a \ncivil case. \nIn legal disputes, each party ordinarily is represented by a law-\nyer. Legal opinions use several di fferent words for lawyers, includ-\n\n--- Page 8 ---\nOrin S. Kerr \n56  11 GREEN BAG 2D ing “attorney” and “counsel.” There are some historical differences \namong these terms, but for the last century or so they have all meant the same thing. When a lawyer addresses a judge in court, she will always address the judge as “your honor,” just like lawyers \ndo in the movies. In legal opinions, however, judges will usually \nrefer to themselves as “the Court.” \nTerms in Appellate  Litigation  \nMost opinions that you read in law school are appellate opinions, \nwhich means that they decide the out come of appeals. An “appeal” is \na legal proceeding that considers whether another court’s legal deci-sion was right or wrong. After a court has ruled for one side, the \nlosing side may seek review of that  decision by filing an appeal be-\nfore a higher court. The original court is usually known as the trial court, because that’s where the tr ial occurs if there is one. The \nhigher court is known as the appellat e or appeals court, as it is the \ncourt that hears the appeal. \nA single judge presides over tr ial court proceedings, but appel-\nlate cases are decided by panels of  several judges. For example, in \nthe federal court system, run by the United States government, a \nsingle trial judge known as a District Court judge oversees the trial stage. Cases can be appealed to the next higher court, the Court of Appeals, where cases are decided by panels of three judges known as Circuit Court judges. A side th at loses before the Circuit Court \ncan seek review of that decision at the United States Supreme Court. Supreme Court cases are decided by all nine judges. Su-preme Court judges are called Justices instead of judges; there is one “Chief Justice” and the other eight are just plain “Justices” (technically they are “Associate Justices,” but everyone just calls \nthem “Justices”). \nDuring the proceedings before th e higher court, the party that \nlost at the original court and is therefore filing the appeal is usually \nknown as the “appellant.” The party that won in the lower court and must defend the lower court’s de cision is known as the “appellee”  \n(accent on the last syllable). Some older opinions may refer to the \nappellant as the “plaintiff in error”  and the appellee as the “defendant \n\n--- Page 9 ---\nHow to Read a Legal Opinion \nAUTUMN 2007  57 in error.” Finally, some courts label  an appeal as a “petition,” and \nrequire the losing party to petition the higher court for relief. In \nthese cases, the party that lost be fore the lower court and is filing \nthe petition for review is called the “petitioner.” The party that won \nbefore the lower court and is responding to the petition in the \nhigher court is called the “respondent.” \nConfused yet? You probably are, but don’t worry. You’ll read so \nmany cases in the next few weeks th at you’ll get used to all of this \nvery soon. \nIII. WHAT YOU NEED TO LEARN FROM \nREADING A CASE \nkay, so you’ve just read a case  for class. You think you under-\nstand it, but you’re not sure if  you learned what your profes-\nsor wanted you to learn. Here is what professors want students to know after reading a case assigned for class: \nKnow the Facts \nLaw professors love the facts. When they call on students in class, they typically begin by asking student s to state the facts of a particu-\nlar case. Facts are important because law is often highly fact-sensitive, which is a fancy way of saying that the proper legal out-\ncome depends on the exact detail s of what happened. If you don’t \nknow the facts, you can’t really understand the case and can’t un-derstand the law. \nMost law students don’t apprecia te the importance of the facts \nwhen they read a case. Students th ink, “I’m in law school, not fact \nschool; I want to know what the law is, not just what happened in this one case.” But trust me: the facts are really important.\n2 \n                                                                                                    \n2 If you don’t believe me, you should take a look at a few law school exams. It \nturns out that the most common form of law school exam question presents a \nlong description of a very particular set of facts. It then asks the student to “spot” \nand analyze the legal issues presented by  those facts. These exam questions are \nknown as “issue-spotters,” as they test th e student’s ability to understand the facts \nand spot the legal issues they raise. As you might imagine, doing well on an issue-O \n\n--- Page 10 ---\n58  11 GREEN BAG 2D Orin S. Kerr \nKnow the Specific  Legal Arguments  Made by the Parties \nLawsuits are disputes, and judges  only issue opinions when two par-\nties to a dispute disagree on a particular legal question. This means \nthat legal opini ons focus on resolv ing the parties’ ver y specific dis-\nagreement. The lawyers, not the judges, take the lead role in fram-\ning the issues raised by a case. \nIn an appeal, for example, the lawyer \nfor the appellant will ar-\nticulate specific ways in which the lower court was wrong. The ap-\npellate court will then look at those arguments and either agree or \ndisagree. (Now you can understa nd why people pay big buc\nks for \ntop lawyers; the best lawyers are highly skilled at identifying and \narticulating their arguments to the court.) Because the lawyers take \nthe lead role in fram ing the issues, you need  to understand exactly \nwhat arguments the two sides were making. \nKnow the Disposition  \nThe “disposition” of a case is the ac tion the court to ok. It is often \nannounced at the very end of the opinion. For example, an appeals \ncourt might “affirm” a lower court de\ncision, upholding it, or it \nmight “reverse” the decisi\non, ruli ng for the other side. Alterna-\ntively, an appeals court might “v acate” t he lower court decision, \nwiping the lower-court decision off the books, and then “remand” \nthe case, sending it back to the lower court for further proceedings. \nFor now, you should keep in mind that when a higher court “af-\nfirms” it means that the lower court had it right (in result, if not in \nreasoning). Words like “reverse,” “remand,” and “vacate” mean \nthat the higher court thought the lower court had it wrong. \nUnderstand  the Reasoning  of the Majority  Opinion \nTo understand the reasoning of an op ini on, you should first identify \nthe source of the law the judge appl ied. Some opinions interpret the \nConstitution, the founding charter of the government. Other cases \nspotter requires developing a carefu l and nuanced understanding of the impor-\ntance of the facts. The best way to prepare for that is to read the fact sections of \nyour cases very carefully.  \n\n--- Page 11 ---\nHow to Read a Legal Opinion \nAUTUMN 2007  59 interpret “statutes,” which is a fancy name for written laws passed \nby legislative bodies such as Congress. Still other cases interpret “the common law,” which is a term that usually refers to the body of prior case decisions that derive ultimately from pre-1776 English \nlaw that the Colonists br ought over from England.\n3 \nIn your first year, the opinions that you read in your Torts, Con-\ntracts, and Property classes will mostly interpret the common law. Opinions in Criminal Law mostly interpret either the common law \nor statutes. Finally, opinions in your Civil Procedure casebook will \nmostly interpret statutory law or  the Constitution. The source of \nlaw is very important because American law follows a clear hierar-\nchy. Constitutional rules trump statutory (statute-based) rules, and statutory rules trump common law rules. \nAfter you have identified the source of law, you should next \nidentify the method of reasoning that the court used to justify its decision. When a case is governed  by a statute, for example, the \ncourt usually will simply follow wh at the statute says. The court’s \nrole is narrow in such settings beca use the legislature has settled the \nlaw. Similarly, when past courts have already answered similar \nquestions before, a court may conclude that it is required to reach a \nparticular result because it is boun d by the past precedents. This is \nan application of the judicial practice of “stare decisis,” an abbrevia-tion of a Latin phrase meaning “That which has been already decided should remain settled.” \nIn other settings, courts may just ify their decisions on public pol-\nicy grounds. That is, they may pick th e rule that they think is the \nbest rule, and they may explain in the opinion why they think that rule is best. This is particularly likely in common law cases where judges are not bound by a statute or constitutional rule. Other \ncourts will rely on morality, fairness, or notions of justice to justify \n                                                                                                   \n \n3 The phrase “common law” started being used about a thousand years ago to refer \nto laws that were common to all Englis h citizens. Thus, the word “common” in \nthe phrase “common law” means common in the sense of “shared by all,” not \ncommon in the sense of “not very special.” The “common law” was announced in judicial opinions. As a result, you will so metimes hear the phrase “common law” \nused to refer to areas of judge-made la w as opposed to legislatively-made law. \n\n--- Page 12 ---\nOrin S. Kerr \n60  11 GREEN BAG 2D their decisions. Many courts will mix and match, relying on several \nor even all of these justifications. \nUnderstand  the Significance  of the Majority  Opinion \nSome opinions resolve the parties’  legal dispute by announcing and \napplying a clear rule of law that is new to that particular case. That rule is known as the “holding” of  the case. Holdings are often con-\ntrasted with “dicta” found in an opi nion. Dicta refers to legal state-\nments in the opinion not needed to resolve the dispute of the par-ties; the word is a pluralized abbr eviation of the Latin phrase “obiter \ndictum,” which means “a remark by the way.” \nWhen a court announces a clear holding, you should take a min-\nute to think about how the court’s rule would apply in other situa-tions. During class, professors like  to pose “hypotheticals,” new sets \nof facts that are different from those found in the cases you have \nread. They do this for two reasons. Fi rst, it’s hard to understand the \nsignificance of a legal rule unless you think about how it might apply \nto lots of different situations. A rule might look good in one setting, \nbut another set of facts might reveal a major problem or ambiguity. Second, judges often reason by “analogy,” which means a new case may be governed by an older case when the facts of the new case are \nsimilar to those of the older one. This raises the question, which are \nthe legally relevant facts for this particular rule? The best way to \nevaluate this is to consider new se ts of facts. You’ll spend a lot of \ntime doing this in class, and you can get a head start on your class \ndiscussions by asking the hypotheticals on your own before class \nbegins. \nFinally, you should accept that some opinions are vague. Some-\ntimes a court won’t explain its reas oning very well, and that forces \nus to try to figure out what the opinion means. You’ll look for the \nholding of the case but become frustrated because you can’t find one. It’s not your fault; some opinions are written in a narrow way \nso that there is no clear holding, and others are just poorly reasoned \nor written. Rather than trying to fill in the ambiguity with false cer-\ntainty, try embracing the ambiguity in stead. One of the skills of top-\nflight lawyers is that they know  what they don’t know: they know \n\n--- Page 13 ---\nHow to Read a Legal Opinion \nAUTUMN 2007  61 when the law is unclear. Indeed, this skill of identifying when a \nproblem is easy and when it is hard (in the sense of being unsettled \nor unresolved by the courts) is one of the keys to doing very well in law school. The best law students are the ones who recognize and \nidentify these unsettled issues without  pretending that they are easy. \nUnderstand  Any Concurring  and/or  Dissenting  Opinions  \nYou probably won’t believe me at  first, but concurrences and dis-\nsents are very important. You need to read them carefully. To un-derstand why, you need to appreciate that law is man-made, and Anglo-American law has often been judge-made. Learning to “think like a lawyer” often means learning to think like a judge, which \nmeans learning how to evaluate wh ich rules and explanations are \nstrong and which are weak. Courts occasionally say things that are \nsilly, wrongheaded, or confused, and you need to think independ-ently about what judges say. \nConcurring and dissenting opinion s often do this work for you. \nCasebook authors edit out any unimportant concurrences and dis-sents to keep the opinions short. When concurrences and dissents \nappear in a casebook, it signals that  they offer some valuable insights \nand raise important arguments. Disagreement between the majority \nopinion and concurring or dissenting opinions often frames the key \nissue raised by the case; to understand the case, you need to under-\nstand the arguments offered in concurring and dissenting opinions. \nIV. WHY DO LAW PROFESSORS  \nUSE THE CASE METHOD ? \n’ll conclude by stepping back and explaining why law professors \nbother with the case method. Every law student quickly realizes \nthat law school classes are very di fferent from college classes. Your \ncollege professors probably stood at the podium and droned on while you sat back in your chair,  safe in your cocoon. You’re now \nstarting law school, and it’s very different. You’re reading about actual cases, real-life disputes, and you’re trying to learn about the law by picking up bits and pieces of it from what the opinions tell I \n\n--- Page 14 ---\nOrin S. Kerr \n62  11 GREEN BAG 2D you. Even weirder, your professo rs are asking you questions about \nthose opinions, getting everyone to join in a discussion about them. \nWhy the difference?, you may be wondering. Why do law schools use the case method at all? \nI think there are two major reaso ns, one historical and the other \npractical. \nThe Historical Reason  \nThe legal system that we have i nherited from England is largely \njudge-focused. The judges have ma de the law what it is through \ntheir written opinions. To understand that law, we need to study the actual decisions that the judges  have written. Further, we need \nto learn to look at law the way that judges look at law. In our sys-tem of government, judges can on ly announce the law when decid-\ning real disputes: they can’t just have a press conference and an-\nnounce a set of legal rules. (This is sometimes referred to as the \n“case or controversy” requirement; a court has no power to decide \nan issue unless it is presented by  an actual case or controversy be-\nfore the court.) To look at the law the way that judges do, we need \nto study actual cases and controversie s, just like the judges. In short, \nwe study real cases and disputes because real cases and disputes his-torically have been the primary source of law. \nThe Practical  Reason \nA second reason professors use the ca se method is that it teaches an \nessential skill for practicing lawyers . Lawyers represent clients, and \nclients will want to know how laws apply to them. To advise a cli-ent, a lawyer needs to understand exactly how an abstract rule of law will apply to the very specific situations a client might encoun-\nter. This is more difficult than y ou might think, in part because a \nlegal rule that sounds definite and clear in the abstract may prove \nmurky in application. (For example,  imagine you go to a public park \nand see a sign that says “No vehicles in the park.” That plainly for-bids an automobile, but what ab out bicycles, wheelchairs, toy \nautomobiles? What about airplanes ? Ambulances? Are these “vehi-\ncles” for the purpose of the rule or not?) As a result, good lawyers \n\n--- Page 15 ---\nHow to Read a Legal Opinion \nAUTUMN 2007  63 need a vivid imagination; they n eed to imagine how rules might ap-\nply, where they might be unclear, and where they might lead to \nunexpected outcomes. The case me thod and the frequent use of \nhypotheticals will help train your brain to think this way. Learning \nthe law in light of concrete situ ations will help you deal with par-\nticular facts you’ll encounter as a practicing lawyer. \nGood luck! \n \n \n\n--- Page 16 ---\nCopyright © 2007 The Green Bag, Inc. “The Green Bag” and the       logo are our registered trademarks.",

      "extracted_text": "--- Page 1 ---\n469\n DOI: 10.4324/9781003397618-2723\nVALIDITY ARGUMENT \nROADMAP FOR AUTOMATED \nSCORING\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n23.1 Introduction\nThis chapter provides a practical validity argument roadmap for automated scoring of \nassessments, with a particular focus on essays and short, constructed response items. As a \ncenterpiece for the chapter, a “how-  to roadmap,” represented graphically, provides a walk-  \nthrough of the major steps involved in constructing and documenting a validity argument. \nIn discussing each of these steps, the following issues are addressed:\n •The relevant sections of the Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing  (referred \nto as Standards ) (AERA et al., 2014 ) and other governing principles and guidelines rele -\nvant to validity arguments.\n •Current principles and practices in artificial intelligence (AI)—  the current predominant \nform of automated scoring—  as they relate to validity arguments. These include how AI \nscoring engines are optimized for specific scoring tasks, the meaning of “fairness” and its \nplace in validity arguments, and important changes in the AI landscape such as explain -\nable and responsible (or principled) AI.\n •The call for more principled approaches to constructing validity technical reports.\nThe chapter concludes with a discussion of ongoing challenges and areas for future \nresearch. Specifically, the role of audits and external evaluations, the pace of change and \nincreased complexity in AI, challenges around fairness and diversity, and future research \nsuggestions are addressed.\n23.2 The Roadmap\nIt is well known throughout the literature on assessment design and validation that validity \narguments come down to providing evidence to support specific claims about what an  \nassessment should do and how well it is doing those things. Yet, despite decades of calls for  \nmore principled approaches to validity arguments, including more careful reasoning around  \nspecific evidence and claims, many validity argument technical reports (VATRs) read more   \n   \n \n   \n\n--- Page 2 ---\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n470like “data dumps” ( Ferrara et al., 2023 ). The hope for this chapter is to provide a concise  \nguide or roadmap for producing quality VATRs—  ones that clearly and concisely provide  \nevidence from test design, test development, and psychometric outcomes to make validity  \narguments that support intended score interpretations and uses. This is more important  \nthan ever, as various forms of AI have been introduced, providing a wide variety of new  \ncomplexities and challenges (e.g., see the special issue edited by Dorsey & Michaels, 2022 ).\n23.2.1  Describe Assessment Constructs, Including Rationale  \nfor Using Automated Scoring\nQuality VATRs should begin with the foundation of all modern measurement: telling \nthe reader what one is presuming to measure, that is, describing or defining assessment \nconstructs. Several researchers have provided guidance on different ways of defining \nconstructs (e.g., Ferrara et al., 2016 ). These include approaches such as construct maps \n(Wilson, 2005 ), cognitive models ( Leighton & Gierl, 2007 ), or various types of construct \nmodels as presented in evidence-  centered design ( Ercikan & McCaffrey, 2022 ). The readers \nFigure 23.1   Validity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring. \n  \n \n \n  \n  \n\n--- Page 3 ---\nValidity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring\n471are referred to the work by Ercikan and McCaffrey (2022) , who deal with the complex -\nities of construct definition in AI-  enabled assessment settings. These authors highlight the \nimportance of describing the details around parts of construct definitions against specific \nautomated scoring algorithms. They provide an example writing construct that includes \nconveying complex ideas. Such a construct element requires a scoring algorithm capable \nof measuring human-  related complexity. Without specifying clear evidentiary chains, we \nare left with somewhat vapid construct definitions and scoring algorithms that appear to \nmatch human scores at a broad level yet have little to do with specific aspects (or features) \nof construct definitions. A wealth of current research discusses the limitations of only infer -\nring construct relevance via the correlation of human and machine/  automated scores (e.g., \nWood, 2020 ). In our view, it is generally accepted at this point that automated scoring \nengines typically evaluate only a small fraction of elements within construct definitions \n(e.g., writing) and that high correlations can be achieved even when humans and machines \nfocus on different features ( Wood, 2020 ). Wood (2020)  discusses several useful ways to deal \nwith such issues from a policy and public communication perspective.\nNote that in practical terms, many, if not most, construct definitions relevant to a VATR \noccur within the context of test blueprints or test specifications—  often driven by subject \nmatter expert (SME) judgments and/  or sets of external standards. Here again, a cautious \nreader should not rely upon overly broad construct claims, particularly in automated \nscoring settings. As pointed out by Ferrara and Qunbar (2022) , the Standards  clearly call \nfor specifications of construct relevance and construct representation. As more complex \nAI- based scoring approaches are developed, some aspects of construct definition may neces -\nsarily be less transparent and explainable. Thus, these authors suggest a focus on feasible \ntransparency and explainability , particularly as it relates to what assessments are actually \nmeasuring, that is, construct definition. This is one of many areas in which measurement \nprofessionals are not alone in wrestling with AI, as entire fields of endeavor exist within \nmodern computer science and data science around “how explainability contributes to trust \nin AI” ( Ferrario & Loi, 2022 ).\nCallout Box: Example of a Construct Definition Statement\nThe current assessment measures the constructs of student writing in terms of content, cre -\nativity, style, mechanics, and organization , as specified and described in the relevant Standards \nfor Writing. *\n* For elaboration of this type of example, see Shermis (2022) . In this case, the researcher would \nspecify and describe in more detail the relevant Standards.\n23.2.2  Document Intended Score Interpretation and Uses (SIUs) \n(Including Scoring Rubrics, Processes, and Features)\nClosely related to describing assessment constructs is the practice of documenting intended \nSIUs (including scoring rubrics, rules, processes, and features). To effectively achieve this \ngoal, it is helpful to be clear about how information is provided. If stakeholders of various \ntypes do not clearly understand why a given set of assessments and scoring methods is  \n  \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 4 ---\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n472used, a key link in an ultimate validity chain/  argument is lost. SIU is the dominant con -\ncept in defining validity and validation processes and criteria in the Standards  (Ferrara & \nQunbar, 2022 ; Ferrara et al., 2023 ). The Standards  specifically call for supporting theory \nand evidence concerning: (1) how test scores are interpreted against presumed end uses and \n(2) how interpretations align with the constructs the tests are intended to measure.\nCallout Box: Example of an SIU Statement\nThe current assessment uses a set of Prose Constructed Response prompts that elicit specific \nknowledge and skills identified in the construct definitions above. The prompts elicit written \nresponses that are scored via automated scoring (details on these scoring methods are provided \nelsewhere in this report), allowing valid inferences about student knowledge and skills in line \nwith the relevant Standards for Writing.\nClear and accurate SIU statements also help define which examinee responses will be \nautomatically scored. They permit the identification of assessment activities that are both \nscorable by AI algorithms and related to the targeted construct(s). Ferrara, Roussos, and \nQin (2023)  provide a useful framework for evaluating the quality of SIU statements for \neach claim and sub-  claim regarding Relevance, Completeness, and Overall Support.\nToo often in modern practice, the idea of applying automated scoring occurs after \nassessment design decisions have already been made. As Ercikan and McCaffrey (2022)  \npoint out, this post hoc design often limits automated scoring to function merely as a human \nscorer replacement. Such an approach fails to consider that many AI algorithms and models \nare better than humans at some scoring tasks. Perhaps the best way to think about this comes \nin the form proposed by Ferrara and Qunbar (2022)  that future automated scoring engines \nshould be thought of as “Optimized Decision Algorithms” rather than “Replicators of \nHuman Decision-  Making Processes” (p. 296). For example, recent AI benchmark research \nsuggests that for tasks such as handwriting recognition, speech recognition, image labeling, \nreading comprehension, and some aspects of language understanding, AI models achieve \nbetter results than humans on the same tasks ( Kiela et al., 2021 ). However, as the authors of \nsuch research point out, this does not necessarily mean that these models have the human-  \nlevel natural language capabilities that such results might suggest. Hence, again we find \nthe need for carefully constructed and supported SIUs and construct relevance arguments. \nThese issues will become paramount with the recent rise of Large Language Models (LLMs; \ne.g., ChatGPT), with debates now occurring within both academic and commercial settings \nabout whether we could experience Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the current era \n(Bubeck et al., 2023 ). In summary, to match the call for using principled validity arguments \n(e.g., National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine [NAS], 2020 ), a prin -\ncipled approach to AI use, i.e., Principled AI ( Field et al., 2020 ), is paramount.\n23.2.3  Describe Test Blueprints and Specifications to  \nClarify Item Types That Use Automated Scoring\nOnce assessment activities that can be scored automatically have been identified and are \nrelated to the constructs through the corresponding SIU statements, the next step is to  \n  \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 5 ---\nValidity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring\n473document the test blueprint and specifications following traditional practices. This involves \nidentifying the content standards and/  or knowledge, skills, abilities, or other characteristics \n(KSAOs) identified in a domain/  job/ practice analysis that must be included in the assessment \nblueprint. Moreover, a blueprint typically documents how these targets are assessed via items \nand other assessment activities that may be machine scored, scored by humans, or combined.\nIn practice, test blueprints are often presented in the form of tables that provide a brief \ndescription of the assessment task/  item type, the primary standards (or KSAOs identified \nin domain analysis) that the task type is designed to assess, information regarding whether \nthe task type is a discrete or set-  based item, the number of raw score points assigned to \neach item, and the number of items that appear on a test form at each level (e.g., grade \nlevel and job level). Assessment designers also sometimes specify elements such as Depth of \nKnowledge estimates, computer adaptive versus fixed form, or other item characteristics as \npart of blueprint descriptions. Assessment designers should also include special consider -\nations regarding whether and how the task/  item type is enhanced with technology and/  or \nautomated scoring in test blueprints. The key takeaway for VATR development is to cap -\nture any details of blueprint design that lead to key claims or sources of validity evidence.\nCallout Box: Example of a Test Blueprint Statement  \nClaim/   Reporting Category Number of \nItemsPossible \nPointsLink to Content \nStandardsAutomated \nScoring\n1. Clearly communicate \nideas in writing, \nfollowing a prompt.3 6 Links to \nStandards #1, \n3, and 5Yes\n2. Use standard grammar, \nusage, and spelling to edit \nwriting tasks.6 6 Links to \nStandards #2, \n4, and 6Yes\n23.2.4  Describe Item/  Test Development Procedures,  \nIncluding Evidence Supporting Validity Arguments\nWithin the professional testing industry, it is well-  known that content development \n(developing the actual items for an assessment) is an art and science unto itself. Typically, \nelaborate processes are used for developing initial items, having multiple rounds of human \nreview (including sensitivity review for screening of content that would be inappropriate, \npotentially biasing, or offensive to different subgroups), and item piloting or field testing. \nFor VATR development, key aspects of item development to capture would be any elem -\nents that support (or do not support) validity claims. These might include the specific item \ndevelopment processes and methods, the expertise and background of item writers and/  or \neditors, and versioning control and item banking methods and features.\nIn the future, we expect that there will be an increased focus on the use of automated \nitem generation (AIG). AIG refers to using statistical or machine-  driven models to produce \ntest items or assist in their production ( Gierl & Haladyna, 2013 ). AIG has been around \nfor decades, with earlier versions following a type of item-  templating approach ( Bejar,  \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 6 ---\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n4742002 ). More modern methods are based on AI/  machine learning (ML) models involving \ntechnologies such as deep learning neural networks ( von Davier, 2018 ). Research on AIG \ndemonstrates promise regarding significant time and cost savings and may even be applic -\nable in high-  stake assessment settings (e.g., Leslie & Gierl, 2023 ). Moreover, with the wide -\nspread availability of LLMs and related generative AI techniques, AIG as a field of endeavor \nis exploding ( Lee et al., 2023 ). If using AIG for operational assessment, assessment designers \nmust document the following in a VATR:\n •Link AIG processes to the design principles, guidelines, and information on constructs \nand SIUs highlighted above.\n •Describe steps to ensure that construct irrelevant variance and biases are not introduced \ninto item development via algorithm/  model use.\n •Describe item evaluation methods that might be part of the AIG process (e.g., automated \npsychometric analyses that prune items during generation).\n •Document why AIG is appropriate or required in the first place.\n23.2.5  Document Approach for Developing AI Scoring Model(s)\nThe approach used to document how an automated/  AI scoring model is developed in \nsupport of validity claims highly depends on the type of AI model used. For assessments \nrelated to essay and constructed response type scoring, most models developed in the recent \npast follow steps such as those described below. The literature contains entire volumes that \nexpand on these steps and address many other aspects of scoring model development (see \nDavis & Papageorgiou, 2021 ; Yan et al., 2020 ).\n •Developers gather initial responses produced by actual test takers along with human-  \nderived scores.\n •The human-  scored essays are imported into the automated scoring model. Often some \ndegree of data cleaning, processing, and standardization is used to prepare the materials \nfor machine readability.\n •Next, developers identify a set of key “features” from the training data. A feature can \nbe any characteristic of a response that is relevant to scoring (e.g., number of words, \nreading level, or the presence of certain words or phrases).\n •Developers then fit a statistical or increasingly ML model to convert the features into a \npredicted score.\n •The result is a set of features that are important for establishing a score and what weights \nor rules are needed to convert feature values into predicted scores.\nTo produce initial validity evidence, developers typically pursue the following additional steps:\n •Developers confirm that the trained model can score new responses—  responses \nthe engine has not seen before. This is done during a model validation process (i.e., \ncross-  validation).\n •Model validation typically involves importing and scoring new responses produced by \nactual test takers. The same steps described above apply.  \n \n \n   \n\n--- Page 7 ---\nValidity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring\n475 •Automated scores are then computed for the new responses and compared to human \nratings/  evaluations. Researchers use a variety of metrics to compare the automated \nscores with human scores, such as score point distributions, exact agreement, and quad -\nratic weighted kappa.\nNote that with the rise of relatively affordable computing and advanced AI/  ML \nalgorithms, the number of features we can capture and include in scoring models has grown \nexponentially (see Lottridge et al., 2023  for a discussion).\nCallout Box: Example Description of Scoring Features*  \nConstruct Possible Scoring Features\nRelevance: Is the content of the \nresponse relevant to the  \nprompt?• Cosine similarity between the response \nand expert responses\n• Probability of the text response based on a \ntrained language model\nAccuracy: Is the answer free of \ngrammatical errors?• Number of spelling errors\n• Number of grammatical errors\nCreativity: Is the use of words  \nand sentence structure creative and \nvaried?• Creativity score from a trained large \nlanguage model ( Li et al., 2023 )\nOrganization: Is the organization \nlogical and coherent?• Coherence measures among sentences\n• Key sentence detection (e.g., intro, \nconclusion)\nNote: * Adapted from LaFlair, Yancey, Settles, and von Davier (2023) .\nWhen implementing automated scoring engines, test providers often use complex sets \nof “validity papers” and routing mechanisms to score responses ( Shin et al., 2019 ). For \nexample, a vendor might create an integrated system between human scoring and automated \nscoring, where both an automated score and/  or a human score can be assigned based on \na predetermined operational flow. With such systems, the client typically approves spe -\ncific quality criteria for evaluating automated scoring. Developers use a set of responses to \nvalidity papers with “known” scores assigned by experts to monitor human scoring over \ntime. The general expectation is that automated systems will score validity papers at least \nas accurately as humans.\nFor VATR development, developers must describe the key elements of model develop -\nment, such as those highlighted above, in terms of their linkages to validity evidence and \nclaims included in the VATR. There are numerous details about model development that \ndevelopers could deem relevant for inclusion in a VATR, ranging from choices of mod -\neling techniques, specific data collection processes, arguments for training data representa -\ntiveness, key software dependencies, scoring outcomes in terms of fairness and subgroup \ndifferences, fairness mitigations used, sensitivity analysis or model “stress testing,” and \nlongitudinal drift analysis to ensure that the scoring model does not become less accurate or  \n  \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 8 ---\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n476relevant over time and/  or over changes happening in the construct domain. Also included \nin these considerations is the possibility that a model can be “gamed” or, in the language of \nthe ML literature, “poisoned” ( Bejar, 2017 ; Oprea et al., 2022 ). Such gaming could result \nin construct-  irrelevant response strategies and must be considered as part of the scoring \nmodel development and validity documentation. Lane (2023)  discusses these and many \nother aspects of model development and how they relate to validity arguments.\nNote that with the rise of new AI models (e.g., LLMs), model development and docu -\nmentation requirements are changing quickly. Researchers have begun investigating LLMs \nas a new form of automated scoring (e.g., Mizumoto & Eguchi, 2023 ), and future research \nwill need to clarify the related validity requirements for such use cases.\n23.2.6  Describe Test Administration Procedures, Including Evidence \nSupporting Validity Arguments and System Security\nAssessment developers may not typically think of test administration procedures as imme -\ndiately relevant to validity arguments. However, there are numerous cases where real-  life \nadministration issues might overturn the most well-  designed validity arguments. Consider \nthe real-  world case of technological disruptions. In 2018, the Tennessee Department of \nEducation (TDOE) experienced widespread technology disruptions with students com -\npleting computer-  based TNReady exams (a high-  stake state-  wide assessment). Designed to \nassess student knowledge and understanding across various domains, TNReady plays a vital \nrole within the Tennessee Comprehensive Assessment Program by providing information on \nwhat students know and can do. Understandably, TDOE was concerned that the disruptions \ncould have negatively affected student test scores. To address this concern, TDOE sponsored \na study using multiple advanced psychometric and statistical methods to conduct a rigorous \ncomparison of student test scores between disrupted and non-  disrupted peers.1 As another \nexample, consider the widespread negative effects of the COVID-  19 global pandemic on \neducational achievement, testing, and accountability ( Harmey & Moss, 2023 ).\nWhile assessment developers cannot plan on all possible contingencies—  especially those \ninvolving widespread technology outages or global pandemics—  they can consider basic \nadministration procedures that account for system integrity, backup, security, and resili -\nence and describe them for VATR documentation. Liao, Attali, Lockwood, and von Davier \n(2022)  provide a helpful discussion of what is required to maintain and monitor modern \ndigital assessments, and Ferrara (2017)  provides considerations to protect against test \nsecurity violations before, during, and after test administrations.\n23.2.7  Document Psychometric Analyses Supporting Validity, Reliability, \nand Fairness Claims, Including Details of AI Scoring Models\nThe broad set of psychometric analyses that developers typically use as evidence in support \nof validity claims is documented elsewhere ( AERA et al., 2014 ; Sireci & Benítez, 2023). \nHere, we suggest consideration beyond traditional estimates of reliability, content validity, \ncriterion-  related validity, and traditional fairness measures (e.g., subgroup differences, dif -\nferential item functioning (DIF) analyses) to reflect on how psychometrics and AI/  ML are \ncombining in the emerging field of computational psychometrics. LaFlair, Yancey, Settles, \nand von Davier (2023)  provide a compelling description of computational psychometrics \nand a consideration of “digital-  first assessments,” where ML and psychometrics are  \n    \n \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 9 ---\nValidity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring\n477combined for item generation and scoring. These authors describe a real-  world assessment \ndevelopment following these principles in the form of the Duolingo English Test.\nDespite changing conceptions of psychometric analyses supporting validity arguments, \nany analytic attempts at developing validity evidence must be tightly coupled with the \ninitial validity arguments/  claims made in the first few steps outlined in Figure 23.1 . It is \nalso important to remember that validity-  related psychometric analyses exist at multiple \nlevels of abstraction and analysis. For example, Lottridge, Ormerod, and Jafari (2023)  \npoint out that validation approaches can focus on the construct, test, and/  or item levels. \nConstruct-  level evaluations might evaluate scoring models as they relate to the constructs, \nSIUs, and assessment tasks and consider methods for detecting unusual responses that \nsuggest the injection of construct-  irrelevant variance into scoring ( Lottridge et al., 2020 ). \nItem-  level analyses might compare the relationships between automated and human scores \nwith other measures, such as response length and overall test scores. In contrast, test-  level \nevaluations might focus on typical psychometric analyses such as item-  total correlations, \ntest reliabilities, etc. ( Lottridge et al., 2023 ).\nThe Standards  indicate that fairness is a “fundamental validity issue and requires \nattention throughout all stages of test development and use” ( AERA et al., 2014 , p. 49). \nThus, consistent with our comments above, all aspects of validity argumentation—  \nacross the entire roadmap—  must be considered regarding fairness implications. Kane \n(2010)  argued that fairness is critical to evaluating test consequences across all groups \nof test-  takers. Claims about fairness depend on evidence that the test supports its SIUs \nfor all individuals and all individual subgroups. For something like a VATR, fairness-  \nrelated analyses have historically focused on evidence of equitable treatment of test-  \ntakers through the assessment process and evidence supporting a lack of measurement \nbias ( AERA et al., 2014 ). This often takes the form of testing for differential functioning \nof items or test scores for test-  takers of equal ability across different groups. In add -\nition, claims related to fairness also center on process issues such as item/  test sensi -\ntivity reviews, standardization of testing procedures, and the use of accommodations for \ngroups such as those with disabilities.\nRecent testing guidelines expand upon these approaches to include issues directly related \nto the use of AI and automated scoring. The International Test Commission (ITC) and the \nAssociation of Test Publishers (ATP) released a comprehensive set of guidelines specifically \nfor technology-  based assessment ( ITC, 2022 ). The Society for Industrial and Organizational \nPsychology ( SIOP, 2023 ) released a publication titled Considerations and Recommendations \nfor the Validation and Use of AI-  Based Assessments for Employee Selection , which serves \nas a supplement to the ITC/  ATP guidelines. Such sources recommend evaluating the \nprocesses used in developing AI algorithms and tuning models, describing the samples used \nfor model building, explaining the features used in scoring, and documenting key facets of \nitem/  test content development, including consideration of how individuals with different \nbackgrounds might interact with test content and scoring algorithms.\nAlthough generally considered part of overall validity arguments, the topic of fairness \nhas continued to emerge as its own independent area of research and practice. In fact, \nHuggins-  Manley, Booth, and D’Mello (2022)  recently explored whether we require a more \nflexible approach to fairness arguments that occur outside of and complementary to val -\nidity arguments to address the many disparate views of fairness. Accordingly, these authors \noffered an argument-  based fairness approach to complement argument-  based validity for  \n \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 10 ---\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n478both traditional and AI-  enhanced assessments. Similarly, Johnson and McCaffrey (2023)  \nand Johnson, Liu, and McCaffrey (2022)  recently conducted in-  depth research into fairness \nfor automated scoring. Among the key ideas that these authors surfaced is a fundamental \nconception of fairness from the AI/  ML literature that involves three central definitions \n(building from the work of Barocas et al., 2019 ), namely:\n •Independence—  Predicted score M is independent of subgroups G\n •Separation—  Predicted score M is conditionally independent of subgroups G given the \ntrue score T; and\n •Sufficiency—  True score T is conditionally independent of subgroups G given the \npredicted score M.\nThe authors subsequently explore advanced empirical measures of fairness consistent with \nthese definitions.\n23.2.8  Document Reporting Procedures, Ensuring Alignment with Core \nInterpretation and Uses\nLike the discussion of test administration above, assessment developers do not always think \nof reporting as a key facet of validity argumentation. Yet, conventional wisdom is that if \nyou do not document it, it does not happen in terms of stakeholder perceptions. In add -\nition, one can foresee the standards for sufficient VATR development changing, hopefully \ntoward the consistent use of principled approaches ( Ferrara, Roussos, & Qin, 2023 ). Note \nalso that reporting requirements do not exist merely around technical documentation. Still, \nthere are increased calls for better reporting for actual assessment users and stakeholders \n(e.g., students, teachers, administrators, parents, and employers) ( Brown et al., 2023 ). In \nthe concurrent roles of information providers and/  or user experience designers, the develop -\nment of end-  user reports can be a critical link in the chain documenting validity reasoning. \nDescribing how a billion-  parameter LLM was used to generate items and assist with \nautomated scoring via a complex fine-  tuning and reinforcement learning approach is hard \nenough to understand and document among testing professionals, but imagine explaining \nthis in plain, understandable language to students, parents, or employers. Thus, practitioners \nshould consider key approaches for effective communication through end-  user reporting in \nVATR documentation.\n23.3 Discussion: Future Directions\nGiven that, as a field, we have been engaged in automated scoring for decades, one might \nthink it is figured out, including validity argumentation, right? So, what could go wrong? \nThe answer is a lot. While we have made amazing strides with incredible innovation in both \nscience and practice, the fundamental technological foundation of our work in automated \nscoring continues to evolve and shift. We have gone from general linear, additive models \nwith maybe a dozen scoring variables to potentially using LLMs with billions, if not \ntrillions, of parameters.\nMoreover, as discussed above, our validity documentation, in many ways, has never \nreally been as robust as it could be, with many VATRs reading like data dumps versus finely \ntuned and supported evidence-  based arguments. Of course, there are exceptions—  many do  \n  \n \n \n  \n\n--- Page 11 ---\nValidity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring\n479this well, and hopefully, that number is increasing. So, where do we go from here? Based on \nour review of the literature and practice and our foundational roadmap presented above, \nhere are a few areas where we see potential growth, threats, and opportunities to enrich \nscience and practice.\n23.3.1  Future Area 1: More External Review\nOne possible trend we foresee is an increased call for external audits of AI systems, including \nautomated scoring systems. Within the educational domain, many systems already fall under \nexternal review standards of one type or another (e.g., U.S. Department of Education Peer \nReview standards, state, or district review standards), but these will likely grow in scope \nand importance. Similarly, professional certification organizations often attempt to meet the \nNational Commission for Certifying Agencies (NCCA) Standards for the Accreditation of \nCertification Programs, which involves a significant amount of review. In the workplace domain, \nlaws are now being written and enforced, such as New York City’s (NYC) Department of \nConsumer and Worker Protection Automated Employment Decision Tools Local Law 144 \nof 2021, which regulates automated employment decision tools. This law, likely a forerunner \nof similar laws, requires that any entity hiring in NYC and using quantitative models to predict \nhiring success has to conduct an external audit, including validation and adverse impact ana -\nlyses, which can be made public. Many companies are already seeking to provide such auditing \nservices, yet the field has not agreed upon what auditing standards might look like. Moreover, \nthere are questions about who will “audit the auditors” ( Landers & Behrend, 2023 ). Landers \nand Behrend (2023)  provide a compelling set of potential audit components, including:\na) components related to AI models in terms of their source data, design, develop -\nment, features, processes, and outputs, b) components related to how information \nabout models and their applications are presented, discussed, and understood from \nthe perspectives of those employing the algorithm, those affected by decisions made \nusing its predictions, and third-  party observers, and c) meta-  components that must be \nconsidered across all other auditing components, including cultural context, respect \nfor persons, and the integrity of individual research designs used to support all model \ndeveloper claims\n(p. 36)\nMuch current AI/  ML development has happened through various public “competitions” \nmade famous by groups such as Kaggle. Perhaps the need is for fewer contests on things \nlike prediction power (in which cases the top leaderboard contenders often differ by insig -\nnificant decimal differences) and more contests on what a thorough audit would look like \n(see work on Stanford’s auditing contest).2\n23.3.2  Future Area 2: Increased Pace of Change and Complexity in AI\nIt is clear at this point that AI will increase in size, capacity, speed, and overall capabilities—  \nand that such changes will happen at expanding rates of change. We used to think funda -\nmental technological advancement was capped at the exponential rates of development \ndiscussed in Moore’s groundbreaking work ( Moore, 1965 ), which subsequently became \nMoore’s law. This law states that the speed and ability of computers doubles every two  \n   \n  \n\n--- Page 12 ---\nDavid Dorsey, Hillary Michaels, and Steve Ferrara\n480years as the number of transistors on a microchip increases. This development speed now \nseemingly pales in comparison to AI capacity development, which appears to be doub -\nling every few months. Thus, what will this mean for validity standards? How can our \nunderstanding and application of sound validity arguments keep pace with such changes? \nThis is an area in need of future research.\nOur opinion is that there is also a need to be clearer in research and practice on the \ndownsides of further AI development and implementation. The upsides can be obvious \nregarding jaw-  dropping capabilities in areas like automated scoring, automated item gener -\nation, etc. However, we seem to focus less on the potential costs, including those highlighted \nby researchers such as Bender and colleagues ( 2021 ). These include:\n •Languages—  90% of the world’s languages, spoken by over one billion people, currently \nhave limited support in terms of language-  related technologies.\n •Environment costs—  training a single LLM (without hyperparameter tuning) is estimated \nto require as much energy as a flight across the US. Such environmental costs may dis -\nproportionally affect disadvantaged people groups.\n •Massive data sources, such as those used to train LLMs, may encode biases and encode \ncertain historically biased associations (e.g., gender, race, ethnicity, and disability).\n •Size does not guarantee diversity. Much of the data used to train LLMs (such as the \nGenerative Pretrained Transformer (GPT) models) is derived from Internet sources such \nas Reddit, Wikipedia, and certain books, which are not necessarily uniformly represen -\ntative of people groups. Note that a better approach for some specific use cases might \ninvolve careful curation and documentation of training data to truly support validity \narguments.\n •Values lock—  training data is necessarily generated in the past, and as societal views, \nbehaviors, and approaches change, AI model users can experience significant model/  \ndata drift, sometimes without detecting it. It is well established in the validity research \nliterature that the values held by assessment stakeholders can threaten the validity \nand fairness of test score interpretations and uses for different groups of examinees \n(Cronbach, 1976 ; Kane, 2006 ; Messick, 1989 ). If used in automated scoring and other \nmeasurement applications, we may have to extend this notion of value effects to data \nand models within the AI realm.\n •Legal/  regulatory—  the use of AI models, in particular emerging generative models such \nas LLMs, is bringing us into somewhat uncharted waters concerning (1) creating uncer -\ntainty about who owns AI-  created content; (2) unintentionally plagiarizing material, \nsuch as prior Internet content incorporated into an AI model as part of training; \n(3) causing security and/  or privacy concerns via activities such as inputting proprietary \ncompany information or sensitive information into a model when interacting with these \ntechnologies; (4) encountering concerns about the accuracy of the content created by \nthese technologies, which in some cases cannot be relied upon; (5) undermining tech -\nnical rigor, such as validity arguments; and (6) violating legal, contractual, or regulatory \nboundaries.\n •As mentioned above, many AI/  ML models are not capable of human-  level natural lan -\nguage understanding. Bender and colleagues ( 2021 ) point out that real language use \nrequires implicit shared mental states between humans—  often cultural; training data  \n    \n\n--- Page 13 ---\nValidity Argument Roadmap for Automated Scoring\n481does not include intent/  shared understandings of speaker–  receiver combinations. Thus, \nwe should ask ourselves, “how does this fundamentally limit our validity claims involving \nsuch models?”\nThese concerns are not intended to signal an anti-  AI perspective; our position is the \nopposite. By addressing such concerns directly and folding them into robust validity \narguments, the ultimate value of AI-  based automated scoring systems can be realized.\n23.3.3  Future Area 3: Continuing Challenges and Opportunities  \naround Fairness and Diversity\nAs discussed throughout this chapter, fairness as a concept is inextricably interwoven \nwith validity. This chapter has highlighted innovative thought and research occurring \nnow on these issues, and more will be required. However, it is important to acknowledge \nthat many researchers are broadening the search for more “fair” assessments, thus likely \nchanging our view of sufficient validity arguments. This broader view includes work on \nsocioculturally responsive assessment ( Bennett, 2023 ), balancing standardization with \nUNDERSTANDardization (Sireci, 2020), and discussions of justice-  oriented approaches \nto assessment ( Randall, 2021 ). How these areas of inquiry might ultimately impact what \nis included in VATRs is to be determined. However, the field is evolving. Our validity \narguments must evolve with it.\nNotes\n1 www.tn.gov/  educat  ion/ news/  2018/  7/ 19/ 2018-  tnre ady- sco res- show-  mixed-  resu lts- - enco urag ing- \nareas-  of- progr  ess.html\n2 https://  hai.stanf  ord.edu/  pol icy/ ai- audit-  challe  nge\nReferences\nAmerican Educational Research Association (AERA), American Psychological Association (APA), \nand National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME). This volume encapsulates the ongoing advancement of AEE, reflecting its application in both large-scale and classroom-based assessments to support teaching and learning endeavors.It presents a comprehensive overview of AEEâ••s current applications, including its extension into reading, speech, mathematics, and writing research; modern automated feedback systems; critical issues in automated evaluation such as psychometrics, fairness, bias, transparency, and validity; and the technological innovations that fuel current and future developments in this field. As AEE approaches a tipping point of global implementation, this Handbook stands as an essential resource, advocating for the conscientious adoption of AEE tools to enhance educational practices ethically. The Handbook will benefit readers by equipping them with the knowledge to thoughtfully integrate AEE, thereby enriching educational assessment, teaching, and learning worldwide.Aimed at researchers, educators, AEE developers, and policymakers, the Handbook is poised not only to chart the current landscape but also to stimulate scholarly discourse, define and inform best practices, and propel and guide future innovations.",
